site_title: Venezuelan oil exports crater as Opec+ set to unleash more crude
summary: Venezuelan oil exports have plummeted by about half, falling to 231,613 barrels a day, due to US sanctions leaving some cargoes stranded in Asia and increased competition with Opec+ members. This slump marks the lowest exports in about seven decades, with December shipments potentially arriving in Asia as early as January, coinciding with an Opec+ meeting scheduled for January 4 to discuss further output increases.

site_title: Three terms that misdefined 2020
summary: US President Donald Trump frequently used the term "witch hunt" in 2020 to describe various controversies, including the Covid-19 pandemic response and tax return investigations. He also employed the phrase "black swan" to describe the pandemic, and "exponential" to describe the rapid spread of the virus. These terms symbolized the year's dominant news headlines, with Trump's usage of them becoming a recurring theme.

site_title: Manchester United's Cavani suspended by FA for three games over use of racial term
summary: Manchester United striker Edinson Cavani has been suspended for three games and fined £100,000 after admitting to using a racial term, "negrito", in an Instagram post. The FA charge stems from a November post after beating Southampton, which was deemed insulting, abusive, and brought the game into disrepute. Cavani will miss three games, including a league match against Aston Villa, and will complete face-to-face education as part of his punishment. The club stated Cavani did not contest the charge out of respect for the FA and the fight against racism in football.

site_title: US Treasury nominee Janet Yellen discloses paid speaking gigs for financial firms
summary: US Treasury nominee Janet Yellen disclosed paid speaking gigs for financial firms, earning at least $7 million over two years, including engagements with Goldman Sachs, Barclays, and Citadel. As part of her confirmation process, Yellen agreed to resign from a consulting role and divest from public company stock. Her candor has been praised by Senator Ron Wyden, who notes her transparency and expertise as a top economic mind.

site_title: Which comes first, wages or rents?
summary: A study finds that many businesses prioritize paying higher rents over increasing wages for employees, particularly those on lower rungs. Companies tend to tolerate higher rent costs, while workers are often resistant to higher wages. This disparity may be attributed to the perception of costs and resources.

site_title: A full jobs recovery only likely after next June, say economists
summary: Singapore's labor market is expected to recover gradually, with a full recovery only likely after June 2021, according to economists. The economy can start to pick up in the first half of 2021, but it will take two quarters for the jobs market to catch up. The recovery will be uneven, with some industries like healthcare, biotech, and logistics experiencing job growth, while others like aviation, aerospace, and hospitality remain muted. The government's support schemes, such as the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, have helped mitigate job losses, but economists are pushing for continued support for harder-hit industries.

site_title: China liquor giant Kweichow Moutai posts slowest revenue growth in five years
summary: China's liquor giant Kweichow Moutai reported its slowest revenue growth in five years, with a 10% increase in 2020, below analyst estimates. The company remains cautious about raising prices to avoid regulatory attention. Moutai's shares surged 69% in 2020, and the company plans to increase direct sales to gain more control over prices. Capacity constraints and a specific climate requirement for baijiu production also contributed to slower growth.

site_title: Goldman leads in M&A advising after year-end comeback for deals
summary: Goldman Sachs Group topped the world's top advisers on mergers and acquisitions (M&A) for the fourth consecutive year in 2020, with over 30% market share, according to Bloomberg data. The bank's global presence and middle-market work helped it gain market share. M&A activity rebounded in the fourth quarter, driven by pent-up demand after the pandemic. Other major banks, such as Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase & Co, also saw increased M&A activity, with some gaining market share. The year also saw a record number of initial public offerings and special purpose acquisition vehicles (SPACs), boosting investment-bank revenue.

site_title: After a year like no other, New York's Times Square empties out on New Year's Eve
summary: New York's Times Square emptied out on New Year's Eve, with only a few dozen authorized guests, including healthcare workers and frontline pandemic responders, attending the ball drop. Unlike previous years, the event was scaled down due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with Mayor Bill de Blasio and police officials urging people to watch the festivities on TV instead. The event featured live performances by Jennifer Lopez and Gloria Gaynor, and aimed to show a message of hope and recovery in 2021.

site_title: Alphabet unit Wing blasts new US drone identification rule, citing privacy
summary: Alphabet's Wing unit criticized the US drone identification rule, calling it a "barrier to compliance" and citing privacy concerns. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated broadcast-based remote identification of drones, which Wing believes will lead to "unintended negative privacy impacts" for businesses and consumers. Wing advocates for internet-based tracking, arguing it allows for identification without sharing flight paths or histories. The FAA received over 50,000 public comments on the rule, with drone manufacturers having 18 months to comply.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: Sinopipe Holdings has entered into a sales and purchase agreement to fully acquire Ten-League Engineering & Technology, increasing market capitalization and investor base. Mary Chia Holdings has extended its deadline to fulfill conditions of its acquisition of Monsoon Hairdressing group companies by three months to March 31, 2021.

site_title: London's luxury new home slump stings Asian developers
summary: Asian luxury home developers face a slump in London, with the city's luxury new home market experiencing a decline in sales. Despite initial optimism, the market has been hit by Brexit, tax increases, and a shift in buyer behavior. The value of homes across London fell £40,000 in the year to September, with buyers prioritizing larger homes with gardens. Developers from Asia, who accounted for two-thirds of land sales by value in 2017, have largely withdrawn from the market, with some projects stalled or abandoned.

site_title: Macau casinos end their worst year with little sign of recovery
summary: Macau casinos ended their worst year on record with a 66% decline in December's gross gaming revenue to 7.82 billion patacas, following a 71% drop in November. The full-year revenue fell 79% to 60.4 billion patacas. The city's struggles to lure back players continue due to a difficult application process and tightened border restrictions. Analysts expect a rebound in 2021, with gaming revenue expected to return to 80% of 2019 levels, but bottlenecks persist.

site_title: Singtel revamps structure to capture new digital growth
summary: Singtel has reorganized its structure to capture new digital growth, with a focus on 5G enterprise business and regional expansion. A 5G enterprise portfolio will drive business across the region, while NCS will report directly to the group CEO to accelerate expansion into Asia-Pacific, particularly Australia and China. The reorganization aims to grow revenue and regain lost ground in the enterprise market, with the goal of turning NCS into a leading regional B2B digital services company.

site_title: Oil edges higher, but posts 20% annual drop in tumultuous 2020
summary: Global crude prices edged higher on the last trading day of 2020, rising to $51.80 a barrel for Brent and $48.52 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. Despite this, prices still fell 21.5% and 20.5% for the year, respectively, due to lockdowns and lower demand. The market's recovery was bolstered by vaccine distribution and optimism, but a new virus variant has raised concerns. Oil prices are not expected to make significant progress in 2021, according to a Reuters poll.

site_title: A spark of fun at FIRE
summary: The article reviews the new 1-Atico restaurant in Singapore, specifically the Argentinian and Japanese-Peruvian Nikkei cuisine offered by FLNT and FIRE, respectively. The reviewer finds that while the food is good, it lacks authenticity and depth. Highlights include the smoky sourdough bread, flavorful empanadas, and tender grilled meats, particularly the mud crab Rescoldo and grain-fed skirt steak. However, the restaurant's service is still rough, with food arriving in spurts and the air conditioning affecting the dining experience. Overall, the reviewer gives the restaurant a 6 out of 10, praising its ambience and view but criticizing its inconsistencies.

site_title: Airbnb and DoorDash set for flurry of analyst coverage next week
summary: Airbnb and DoorDash are set for analyst coverage next week after their initial public offerings. Both companies' stocks soared in their market debuts, with Airbnb more than doubling and DoorDash rising 37% since December 8. Analysts are focusing on valuation, with Airbnb trading 40% above its average price target and DoorDash trading just shy of its average price target. As the quiet period ends, analysts from major banks such as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley will provide their research on the companies.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as UK ends with worst annual drop since 2008
summary: European stocks declined on the final trading day of 2020, with the FTSE 100 posting its worst annual drop since 2008, falling 1.5% and ending the year with a 14% loss. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell 0.3% for the year, with Spain's IBEX Index down 15% for its largest annual drop since 2010. Despite the downturn, some markets, such as Denmark and Sweden, saw gains, driven by digital and renewable energy stocks. Analysts expect a spring renewal to bring upside in 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish the year in the red; STI down 0.89% for the day
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.89% lower on the last trading day of 2020, finishing the year in the red. However, for the month, the STI rose 1.35% or 37.86 points. The State Street Investor Confidence Index increased to 104.1, driven by risk-seeking behavior among US and Asian investors. Top performer Sembcorp Industries edged up 0.59%, while Jardine Strategic Holdings was the biggest decliner, falling 3.23%.

site_title: UK names Tesco and Pizza Hut for biggest breaches of minimum wage law
summary: The UK government has named Tesco and Pizza Hut as the two largest offenders of minimum wage law between 2016 and 2018. Tesco underpaid 78,199 staff by £5.1 million, while Pizza Hut underpaid £845,936. The government has resumed publicly naming firms that broke rules, with 139 employers failing to pay staff the minimum wage. Tesco and Pizza Hut claim the underpayments were due to technical errors and corrections made in 2017 and 2018, respectively. The government emphasized that underpayments often reflect deductions for staff costs.

images.alt_text: Tesco and Pizza Hut were the two biggest offenders among 139 employers who failed to pay staff the minimum wage between 2016 and 2018, Britain's government announced on Friday after it resumed a policy of publicly naming firms that broke rules.

site_title: Gold caps its best year in a decade with US dollar on the ropes
summary: Gold ended its best year in a decade, reaching a record high in August, driven by concerns over US dollar devaluation and inflation. The US dollar declined to its lowest level since April 2018, boosting gold prices. Bullion-backed exchange-traded funds hit an all-time high in October, solidifying gold's gains. The metal's surge was fueled by investor fears of stimulus-induced currency debasement and inflation.

images.alt_text: Gold posted the biggest annual advance in a decade after a tumultuous year, with gains this month aided by the US dollar's decline to the lowest since April 2018.

site_title: Economy stabilising, but not yet out of the woods: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is on track for a rebound in 2021, but recovery will be uneven and activity will likely stay below pre-Covid levels "for some time," said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in his New Year Message. Despite experiencing the "most severe downturn" since independence, the government has supported workers and companies with initiatives such as the Jobs Support Scheme and Covid-19 Support Grant, totaling nearly S$100 billion in 2020. Lee emphasized the importance of maintaining discipline and cooperation to combat the ongoing pandemic, which has stabilized in Singapore but still poses a risk to other countries.

site_title: China reports first case of new coronavirus variant: CDC publication
summary: China has reported its first case of a new coronavirus variant, detected in a 23-year-old female student returning from Britain, according to the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention. The variant, known as "VUI202012/01", is 40-70% more transmissible than the original virus. China has suspended direct flights to and from Britain indefinitely and is investigating the patient's close contacts. The case poses a significant threat to the prevention and control of Covid-19 in China, highlighting the rapid spread of the new variant globally.

site_title: Stage and screen fight for attention
summary: The arts industry is adapting to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic by embracing hybridity, with live performances and digital offerings competing for audience attention. The M1 Fringe Festival and Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) are featuring a mix of live and digital shows, with some companies opting for smaller casts and digital-only productions. Artists are also exploring new ways to collaborate and reach global audiences, with some creating digital-only works that can be shared online. This shift is driven by travel restrictions, social and political turmoil, and the need to adapt to a changing landscape.

site_title: KL-Singapore High Speed Rail terminated, after countries fail to reach agreement
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project has been terminated after Malaysia and Singapore failed to reach an agreement on proposed changes by Malaysia's deadline of December 31, 2020. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Muhyiddin Yassin announced the termination in a joint statement, stating both countries will abide by their respective obligations and proceed with necessary actions. The project, which aimed to reduce travel time between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore to 90 minutes, was initially agreed upon in 2013 but faced multiple delays and terminations.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the now-terminated High Speed Rail Terminal in Jurong East.

site_title: Chelsea Football Club confirm £32.5m profit despite Covid-19 hit on revenue
summary: Chelsea Football Club reported a £32.5 million profit in the 2020 financial year, despite the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, which reduced turnover to £407.4 million. The profit was largely due to the sale of players like Eden Hazard and matchday revenue from the Champions League qualification. Broadcasting revenues decreased by £17.6 million, and matchday revenues fell by £12.2 million, but reduced matchday costs offset some of the losses. The club is on track to post a record profit and is in a strong financial position to continue growing.

site_title: With little ado, a divided United Kingdom casts off into the Brexit unknown
summary: The United Kingdom left the European Union at midnight on December 31, 2020, marking the end of a 48-year association. The Brexit transition period, which lasted 11 months, concluded without significant fanfare amidst the COVID-19 crisis. Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed the move as a "newly independent global Britain," but critics argue it will weaken the economy and reduce Britain's global influence. The UK's departure will likely lead to some disruption at borders, with more red tape and increased costs for importing and exporting goods.

site_title: Amazon to acquire podcasting firm Wondery
summary: Amazon has agreed to acquire podcasting firm Wondery for an undisclosed amount, bolstering its presence in the sound-based medium. The deal comes after Bloomberg reported Wondery was exploring a sale, with Amazon reportedly in the lead at a valuation of around $300 million. Wondery, known for shows like "Dirty John" and "Dr Death," had sought a price of $300 million to $400 million. This acquisition follows Amazon's existing dominance in audiobooks through its Audible division and its recent launch of podcasts.

site_title: Some MyRepublic broadband users face connectivity issues for over 24 hours
summary: Some MyRepublic broadband users experienced connectivity issues for over 24 hours, starting from 7.34am on New Year's Eve. The issue affected customers in various locations, including Yishun, Seng Kang, and Yio Chu Kang. MyRepublic acknowledged the problem and restored connectivity for affected subscribers by 1.48pm on Thursday. However, several customers reported ongoing issues, with 22 reports of connectivity problems on Friday morning, according to Downdetector.

site_title: Tesla short-sellers lost US$38 billion in 2020 as stock surged
summary: Tesla short-sellers suffered a record-breaking $38 billion loss in 2020 due to the company's stock surging 730% to new highs. This is the largest yearly mark-to-market loss for any stock in 2020, surpassing Apple Inc.'s $7 billion loss. Tesla's electric vehicle maker and investors have gained the upper hand against short-sellers, with many closing out their positions and short interest falling to 6% of the float. The company's strong performance is attributed to its five consecutive quarters of profits and growing sentiment on Wall Street that electric vehicles are accelerating.

images.alt_text: Tesla short-sellers lost billions more on the electric vehicle (EV) maker than any other company in 2020, as bears got severely burned by the stock's surge to new highs.

site_title: Dollar on borrowed time as US twin deficits balloon
summary: The US dollar is ending 2020 on a downward spiral, with investors betting on a global economic recovery that will drive riskier assets, despite the country's swelling twin deficits. The dollar fell against the euro, yen, and Chinese yuan, and is down 7.2% on the year. The twin deficits, fueled by a record $84.8 billion trade deficit and a widening current account deficit, have reduced the dollar's safe-haven appeal. The dollar's decline is attributed to the US government's need to borrow more to fund its deficits, with President-elect Joe Biden promising more stimulus next year.

site_title: Metro buys 26% stake in industrial, logistics portfolio for up to S$76.6m
summary: Metro Holdings acquires a 26% stake in a Singapore portfolio of 14 industrial, logistics, and business park properties for up to S$76.6 million. The portfolio, valued at S$15.2 million, has a 99% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 7.7 years. The investment, funded by internal cash and external borrowings, marks Metro's entry into Singapore's industrial real estate market and diversifies its portfolio. CEO Yip Hoong Mun sees the investment as an "excellent proposition" for stable and recurring income.

site_title: Iran allocates US$150,000 for each family of victims of Ukraine plane crash
summary: Iran's Cabinet has allocated $150,000 to the families of each of the 176 victims of a Ukrainian plane crash in January, which was shot down in Iranian airspace. The allocation comes after months of criticism from Ukraine, which described the amount as "unacceptable" and called for those responsible to be brought to justice. Iran's Revolutionary Guards initially stated the plane was accidentally shot down, while Ukraine and the US have expressed frustration over the lack of progress in establishing the causes of the tragedy and holding those responsible accountable.

site_title: What's in store for 2021
summary: Singapore's F&B industry expects a strong rebound in 2021, with dining out continuing as a popular pastime. However, certain segments, such as those dependent on tourism and CBD eateries, are expected to be impacted. Trend forecasts include a continued dominance of Japanese cuisine, a rise in sustainable eating, and alternative meats. The industry faces challenges, including manpower shortages and increased competition, but overall, the outlook is guarded optimism, with many businesses looking to expand and innovate in the coming year.

site_title: US jobless claims dip but show recovery has long way to go
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 787,000 in the week ended Dec 26, down from 806,000 the previous week, but remain at a seasonally adjusted level of roughly 800,000, indicating a slow recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Economists expect the economy to face difficult terrain before improvement takes hold, with concerns about persistently high infection levels and the fractured government response to the pandemic. The US job market still has a long way to go to recover from the devastating effects of the pandemic, with more than 19.5 million people receiving some form of jobless aid.

site_title: Wall Street revives dream of a Bitcoin ETF with new SEC filing
summary: VanEck Associates has filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to launch a Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF), tracking the MVIS CryptoCompare Bitcoin Benchmark Rate. This marks the latest attempt to secure regulatory approval for a crypto-tracking ETF, with some analysts speculating that a change in SEC leadership and Bitcoin's growing adoption on Wall Street may improve the odds. The filing comes as Bitcoin continues to set record highs, with the world's largest digital asset valued above $29,000.

site_title: Pending sales of US existing homes decline for a third month
summary: US pending home sales declined 2.6% in November for the third consecutive month, indicating slower momentum in the housing market due to higher prices and limited inventory. Despite record-low borrowing costs, the drop suggests tempered activity. The National Association of Realtors' index of contract signings to purchase previously owned homes fell to 125.7, up 16% from last year on an unadjusted basis. The shortage of inventory and rising home prices are driving the decline, according to Lawrence Yun, NAR's chief economist.

site_title: Ford Motor pulls plug on plans to cede India business to Mahindra
summary: Ford Motor has reversed plans to cede its Indian operations to Mahindra & Mahindra, terminating a proposed joint venture instead. The decision was made due to the global coronavirus pandemic and the companies will continue Ford's standalone business in the country. Ford had planned to fold its local operations, including two factories, into a majority-controlled Mahindra joint venture, but the future of its business in India remains unclear. The US carmaker took a $799 million impairment charge in 2019 for the expected asset transfer.

site_title: New York Life Insurance closes historic US$6.3b deal for Cigna unit
summary: New York Life Insurance Co completed its largest deal in 175-year history, purchasing a Cigna Corp unit for $6.3 billion. The acquisition adds 3,000 employees and 9 million customers, operating as a standalone business. The deal aims to enhance capital generation and diversify businesses, despite the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on investment income and mortality rates. New York Life is optimistic about the long-term strategy, noting the acquisition fits its purposeful approach to acquisitions.

site_title: Bubble-tea chain Naixue raises new funds at US$2b value
summary: Naixue, a bubble-tea chain, has raised over $100 million in a Series C funding round valued at nearly $2 billion. The funding round was led by private equity firm PAG, with billionaire Jack Ma's Yunfeng Capital also participating. This investment marks a significant valuation increase for the company, which operates under the Naixue and Nayuki names.

site_title: Singapore's market cap up 11.1% to S$814.1b for quarter
summary: Singapore's stock market value rose 11.1% to S$814.1 billion in December, driven by gains from blue chip stocks, particularly banks. Mainboard-listed companies saw a 11.2% increase, while catalist-listed counters rose 3.7%. The top gainers included DBS, OCBC, and UOB, while Singtel, CapitaLand, and Singapore Airlines also made notable gains. The benchmark Straits Times Index fell 9.5% year-on-year. Experts predict a sector rotation in Asian equities, with new technologies and cyclical names potentially benefiting investors in 2021.

site_title: Working for a shrinking asset manager is no fun
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen, a UK asset manager, has undergone significant changes since its 2017 mega-merger. The company's new CEO, Stephen Bird, is working to restore growth and profitability. Bird has divided the business into four areas, set growth targets, and plans to simplify branding and marketing. The company has struggled to execute the merger, with poor morale and underperforming funds. Bird aims to improve customer service, expand passive products, and increase market capitalization, which has dropped to half its pre-merger value.

images.alt_text: At about £6.2 billion, Standard Life Aberdeen's current market capitalisation is half what it was at the time of the merger. Stephen Bird (above) has a long road ahead if he's to restore all of that shareholder value.

site_title: From dives to Broadway, arts aid offers 'lifeline' to devastated venues in US
summary: The US$15 billion allocated in the recent coronavirus relief package aims to support arts venues, including independent music venues, theaters, and museums, which have been severely impacted by the pandemic. Eligible businesses can receive up to 45% of their 2019 revenue, with a cap of $10 million, and priority is given to those that have lost 90% or more of their revenue. The funds are expected to provide a lifeline to the music industry, which has been devastated by the crisis, with many venues at risk of permanent closure.

images.alt_text: The Stone Pony in New Jersey's Asbury Park has hosted dozens of musicians on their ascent to stardom - including none other than Bruce Springsteen - but for months it's sat dark due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: WHO emergency Covid-19 vaccine listing aims to lift access in poor countries
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has listed Pfizer and BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, aiming to speed up access in poor countries. The two-dose shot has been found to be 95% effective and has met the "must-have" criteria for safety and efficacy. The WHO will work with regional partners to distribute the vaccine, which has been approved by several countries, including the UK, US, and Singapore. The move is part of the WHO-backed COVAX alliance, which aims to secure and distribute vaccines to poorer countries.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization (WHO) on Thursday listed Pfizer and BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, in a move seeking to speed access in the developing world.

site_title: Taking some key corporate lessons from 2020 into the new year
summary: CEOs who navigated the 2020 pandemic developed new mindsets, behaviors, and identities, leading to a range of key takeaways for organizations. They prioritized resetting purpose, vision, and culture, curating and composting outdated ideas, and exploring new possibilities. Effective leaders also learned to deal with polarities, focusing on finding a middle path that balances competing priorities. Selflessness, compassion, and servant leadership emerged as essential traits, while developmental conversations and embracing uncertainty became crucial for growth and development. By adopting these new approaches, organizations can thrive in uncertain times.

site_title: Drugmakers including Pfizer, Sanofi, GSK to hike prices for 2021
summary: Drugmakers including Pfizer, Sanofi, and GlaxoSmithKline plan to raise US prices on over 300 drugs on January 1, with hikes ranging from 0.5% to 5%. The increases come amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on demand and the Trump administration's new price-cutting rules. Companies kept price hikes below 10%, with GSK raising prices on two vaccines by 7% and 8.6%. The moves are seen as a way for pharmaceutical companies to make up for lost revenue.

site_title: Normanton Park in Kent Ridge to open for preview
summary: Normanton Park in Singapore, a 1,862-unit private residential project, can now proceed to market after a no-sale licence was lifted on Nov 30, 2020. Developer Kingsford Huray Development must now comply with several conditions, including passing the Building and Construction Authority's Quality Mark assessment. The project, which features smart-home features and a range of unit sizes, will open for public preview on Jan 2, 2021, with indicative prices starting from S$700,000 for one-bedroom apartments.

images.alt_text: The Normanton Park project will have 1,840 condominium units, 22 strata terraces, and eight commercial units. It will likely be the largest project launch in 2021.

site_title: Boustead Singapore sells water solutions unit to Chip Eng Seng for S$7.3m
summary: Boustead Singapore sold its wholly-owned water solutions subsidiary, Boustead Salcon Water Solutions, to Chip Eng Seng Corporation for approximately S$7.3 million. The disposal aims to redeploy funds to core businesses, re-strategize, and reallocate management and financial capital. Although expected to have a minimal impact on net tangible assets per share, it is expected to positively impact earnings per share for the financial year ending March 31, 2021. The sale price led to a 0.6% increase in Boustead Singapore's shares, while Chip Eng Seng's shares rose 2.3%.

site_title: Keppel 'cautiously optimistic' about 2021; looks to asset-light approach, third party co-investments
summary: Keppel Corporation CEO Loh Chin Hua expressed cautious optimism for 2021, citing the company's progress in asset monetization and its adoption of an asset-light approach. Keppel aims to raise S$3 billion to S$5 billion through asset sales and tap third-party co-investments. The company has already divested S$1.2 billion worth of assets and plans to deploy technology to improve productivity and provide better value propositions to customers. Despite divided views on 2021's economic outlook, Keppel prioritizes preparedness for different scenarios and seizing opportunities that may arise.

site_title: China's strong recovery shows signs of peaking
summary: China's manufacturing sector shows signs of peaking, with the official manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 51.9 in December, down from a three-year high of 52.1 in November. The non-manufacturing gauge also dropped to 55.7, indicating a moderation in industrial growth. Economists suggest the pace of industrial growth may have passed its peak, with the Chinese economy forecast to expand by about 2% in 2020, driven by exports and a recovering consumer sector.

site_title: US imposes US$30 million penalty on Daimler for delayed truck recalls
summary: Daimler AG's North American truck unit has agreed to a US$30 million civil penalty to resolve a National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) investigation into delayed truck recalls. The probe found Daimler failed to recall vehicles in a timely fashion and comply with reporting requirements. As part of the settlement, Daimler will develop an advanced data analytics program, pay US$10 million upfront, and spend an additional US$5 million on safety projects. A US$15 million deferred penalty remains payable if Daimler fails to comply with the consent order.

images.alt_text: Daimler AG's North American truck unit on Thursday agreed to a US$30 million US civil penalty to resolve an investigation of delayed recalls, the second time since late 2019 the German automaker has agreed to settle a probe by US auto safety regulators.

site_title: Chinese regulators probe Ant Group's equity investments
summary: Chinese regulators are reviewing Ant Group Co Ltd's equity investments in dozens of companies, mainly in technology and fintech startups, for potential unfair competition and anticompetitive behavior. The review may lead to divestments, which would deprive Ant of lucrative investments and scale back its influence in China's fintech industry. This intensifies existing regulatory pressure on Ant to revamp its business structure and increase capital for its consumer lending business, amid China's broader crackdown on anticompetitive behavior.

site_title: Local pandemic plays come out tops in 2020, as investors hunt for yield
summary: The Singapore stock market saw a mixed performance in 2020, with the Straits Times Index (STI) declining 12.6% to 2,843.81 points. However, smaller companies, known as pandemic plays, outperformed, with Medtecs International Corp and UG Healthcare Corp being the top performers. The FTSE ST Small Cap Index gained 47.8% and the STI rose 27.3% over the same period. Investors sought higher returns due to a weak macroeconomic outlook and low interest rates, driving growth in smaller companies.

site_title: Huawei removes Tencent games in dispute over cooperation
summary: Huawei removed Tencent games from its app store following a dispute over cooperation between the two Chinese technology giants. The decision was made after Tencent made a "big change" on December 31, 2020, which Huawei's legal team deemed unilateral. This action affects games such as Arena of Valor, which are no longer available in Huawei's app store. The reason behind the change is not specified by Tencent, and no immediate comment was given by the company.

site_title: Enphase joins Tesla as latest clean-tech firm to enter S&P
summary: Enphase Energy, a California-based clean-tech firm, will join the S&P 500 index on January 7, marking a significant milestone for the solar industry. The company's shares have surged 562% since 2019, alongside the WilderHill Clean Energy Index's 206% growth. This inclusion reflects the S&P's evolution to recognize the importance of decarbonization, according to analyst Joe Osha. The move follows Tesla's historic inclusion in the index last year, and highlights the growing recognition of clean energy companies in the market.

site_title: Singapore bank lending ticks up in Nov after eight-month decline
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.2% in November to S$676.67 billion, reversing an eight-month decline. Consumer loans, mainly driven by housing loans and unsecured personal loans, grew 0.4% month-over-month. Business loans remained flat, halting a seven-month contraction streak. Loans to financial institutions declined 0.4% for the fourth straight month. Total bank lending was down 2.3% year-on-year.
