Key events include Tesla's formal entry into India, robotaxi expansion plans in California and Arizona, and partnerships between FedEx and QuikBot for robot deliveries. Additionally, Delta Air Lines has lifted its travel demand outlook, and Japan's carmakers have reduced export prices to the US to offset tariffs. BYD and other EV battery makers face pressure to cut emissions, and Nissan is poised to issue a record-high coupon in a US$4 billion bond sale.

site_title: Products for a better tomorrow
summary: Eight young designers showcase their creations at the exhibition "Visions of the Future" in response to the pandemic. The designs focus on health and hygiene, sustainability, and wellbeing, addressing topics such as hand washing, mental health, and social distancing. The designs include a tea set promoting mindfulness, a soap-making machine, a cognitive stimulation tool for seniors, a sustainable shoe repair kit, and objects using pressurized air to promote social distancing. The exhibition runs until January 7 at the National Design Centre.

site_title: 2020 has been 'a write-off for the hospitality sector', says analyst
summary: Singapore's hospitality sector has been severely impacted by the pandemic, with 2020 being a "write-off" according to analyst Derek Tan. International visitor arrivals reached 14,700 in November, a 9.5% month-on-month increase but down 82% year-on-year. Hotel room revenue was S$66.3 million, down 0.6% month-on-month and 82% year-on-year. The government has extended the deadline for parties to apply for relief on event and tourism-related contracts to January 31, 2021, allowing for reassessment of the Covid-19 situation and potential alternative arrangements.

site_title: Normanton Park in Kent Ridge to open for preview after no-sale ban dropped
summary: Singapore's Normanton Park private residential project, developed by Kingsford Huray Development, is set to open for public preview on January 2, 2021, after a two-year no-sale ban was lifted. The project, which has 1,862 units, will be the largest project launch next year and is expected to obtain its temporary occupation permit in 2023. Conditions tied to the sale of its units include passing the Building and Construction Authority's Quality Mark assessment, ensuring homebuyers are assured of a reasonable standard of quality.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy is showing signs of stabilization, with employment picking up and multinational corporations investing in the country. However, Prime Minister Lee emphasized that the country is not yet out of the woods. The Singapore Budget for 2021 is expected to be delivered by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat on February 16. In business news, Singtel is reorganizing its structure to capture new digital growth, while DBS and Keppel have extended a revolving credit facility to KrisEnergy. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed the year in the red, down 0.89%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks retreat in thin trading, set to end 2020 with losses
summary: European stocks retreated on the last trading day of 2020, closing with a 3.8% drop, due to rapid coronavirus cases and Brexit concerns. Thin trading volumes, with many traders away on New Year's Eve, contributed to the decline. The decline lagged Asian and Wall Street equities, which traded near record highs. The US also raised tariffs on some EU products, dampening sentiment. The year ended with losses for European stocks, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index recording its worst performance since 2015.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector issues. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow Airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, an Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Former SICCI chairman and MDIS secretary-general R Theyvendran dies at 79
summary: Former SICCI chairman and MDIS secretary-general R Theyvendran died on December 29 at the age of 79. Theyvendran, who was chairman of SICCI from 2014, aimed to improve the chamber's credibility and grow its membership. He successfully turned around loss-making companies Stamford Press and MDIS, achieving ISO 9001 certification and expanding revenue streams. Theyvendran was also a respected figure in various other institutions, and his contributions to MDIS were acknowledged by the governing council.

site_title: Former SICCI chair R Theyvendran dies
summary: Former chairman of the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SICCI) and secretary-general of the Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) R Theyvendran died on Dec 29, 2020, at the age of 79. Theyvendran was known for turning organizations around, transforming Stamford Press into a successful group and building MDIS into a profitable institution. He was also recognized for his contributions to education, receiving honorary degrees from several universities.

site_title: NYSE to delist Chinese telco giants on US executive order
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) will delist three Chinese corporations - China Mobile, China Telecom Corp, and China Unicom Hong Kong - to comply with a US executive order restricting companies with military ties. The order, signed by President Donald Trump in November, prohibits US investors from buying and selling shares in these firms. The delisting will take place between January 7 and 11, and the companies have separate listings in Hong Kong. This move follows a series of companies being removed from indices compiled by major indices, as a result of the executive order.

images.alt_text: The New York Stock Exchange said it will delist three Chinese corporations to comply with a US executive order that imposed restrictions on companies identified as affiliated with the Chinese military.

site_title: 10 sparkling wines for leaving 2020 behind
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

To celebrate the end of 2020, a writer has curated 10 sparkling wines worth drinking, from under $30 to over $60. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, celebrations will be smaller and more intimate, allowing for the versatility of sparkling wines to shine. The writer's list includes a mix of budget-friendly options and premium Champagnes, highlighting lesser-known producers and unique blends. From Portugal to Italy, France, and the US, these sparkling wines offer a range of flavors and styles to mark the end of a challenging year, perfect for quiet gatherings or solo celebrations.

images.alt_text: The Covid-19 pandemic precludes the usual sorts of holiday blowouts and packed celebrations. Instead, corks will be popped quietly among couples, small friendship pods, over Zoom and even alone for those who have had to isolate for one reason or another.

site_title: Fauci sees US gaining control over pandemic by autumn
summary: US infectious disease specialist Anthony Fauci predicts the US will regain "some semblance of normality" by autumn 2021, driven by collective immunity from Covid-19 vaccinations. Despite early vaccine rollout setbacks, Fauci expects immunizations to become widely available by April and gain momentum in the coming months. However, the emergence of more infectious variants, such as the B.1.1.7 variant in California, may prolong the pandemic. Fauci stresses that immunity from previous infections will protect against new variants and that newly approved vaccines will remain effective.

site_title: US dollar weakening to extend into 2021, lends strength to Singdollar
summary: The Singapore dollar is expected to strengthen in 2021 as investors shift away from the US dollar amid improved global risk appetite and a recovering economy. Analysts forecast the USD/SGD exchange rate to reach 1.36 in the first quarter, 1.35 in the second and third quarters, and 1.34 in the fourth quarter. A strengthening Chinese yuan, driven by vaccine rollouts and reduced US-China tensions, is also expected to lend strength to the SGD. However, risks such as renewed Covid-19 waves and vaccine distribution concerns could potentially boost the US dollar.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2021 set for Feb 16
summary: The Singapore Budget 2021 is set to be delivered on February 16, 2021, by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. The budget comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to an unprecedented four Budgets and two ministerial statements, with an estimated deficit of S$74.2 billion. The government is accepting public feedback on the budget until January 8, 2021. The budget will outline the government's response to the pandemic and its overall economic outlook, which is expected to be highly uncertain.

site_title: At one with nature
summary: In 2021, green architecture and home design are expected to dominate, prioritizing comfort over trends. Architects and designers believe that the pandemic has reaffirmed the importance of incorporating nature and greenery into buildings and homes. This shift will lead to more emphasis on communal spaces, flexibility, and wellness features, such as natural ventilation, hand-crafted furniture, and minimalist designs. As working from home continues, homeowners will focus on creating a sanctuary with timelessness, ergonomics, and comfort. The trend towards softness, calmness, and natural materials will also continue, with bathrooms becoming a focus for rejuvenation and relaxation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end year on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended 2020 on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.31% to 27,231.13. Investors were optimistic about the economic recovery, building on a two-day rally. The gains came as the market headed into the new year, despite concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Tiffany shareholders approves sale to LVMH
summary: Tiffany & Co. shareholders have approved the $16 billion sale to LVMH, with over 99% of votes in favor of the deal. The transaction is expected to close in early 2021, following a year-long saga. The deal was initially agreed upon in October, with LVMH reducing the price from $135 to $131.50 per share. Tiffany will be dropped from the Standard & Poor's 500 Index, and the deal marks a significant expansion for billionaire Bernard Arnault's luxury brand portfolio.

site_title: Ex-Man Utd boss Tommy Docherty dies aged 92 after long illness
summary: Former Manchester United and Scotland manager Tommy Docherty has died at 92 after a long illness, his family announced. He won 25 caps for Scotland and managed Chelsea, Aston Villa, and Derby, with a notable FA Cup win over Liverpool in 1977. A family spokesperson stated that Docherty passed away peacefully at home, surrounded by family, and will be "terribly missed." There will be no further comment at this time, respecting his family's privacy.

site_title: China approves first vaccine for use in general population
summary: China's National Medical Products Administration approved its first coronavirus vaccine for general public use, allowing it to be commercially available and administered to the general population. The vaccine, developed by state-owned China National Biotec Group Co, has been authorized for emergency use in China since mid-year. China aims to inoculate 50 million people by early February, targeting high-risk groups such as the elderly and those with pre-existing conditions. The vaccine has shown a ratio of adverse reactions of about two in every one million, and the developer has pledged to publish detailed data in international medical journals.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust extends master leases, grants rent abatements to Citadines properties in France
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has extended master leases and granted rent abatements to 28 properties in France managed by Citadines. The leases have been renewed for 2-3 years, with fixed rent components adjusted downwards, ranging from €180,000 to €2 million. Variable rent will be 10.35% of total revenue. The rent abatement reflects the market norm in France, and ART expects its distribution per stapled security to fall 0.8% to 7.55 Singapore cents.

site_title: What I'd like for the new new work normal this year
summary: The author reflects on the "new normal" of work during the pandemic, which they believe will need to be retired and replaced with a new normal that incorporates the best of both worlds. Key takeaways include: the value of telephone calls over video conferencing, the benefits of in-person walks with colleagues, the importance of office kitchens for collaboration and creativity, an end to presenteeism and guilt associated with remote work, and a desire to reclaim weekends and maintain office boundaries between work and home.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 17.20 points lower on Thursday, at 1,627.21, with 620 losers outweighing 474 gainers. The index saw 5.509 billion lots traded, worth RM3.109 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong's top court puts media tycoon Jimmy Lai back in custody
summary: Hong Kong's top court has remanded media tycoon Jimmy Lai in custody until a bail hearing on February 1, following his release on $1.3 million bail last week. Lai, a prominent democracy activist, was charged under Hong Kong's national security law, which critics say aims to crush dissent and erode freedoms. Prosecutors immediately appealed against the bail decision, citing concerns that Lai posed a flight risk. Lai's case has drawn international attention due to his criticism of Beijing and frequent visits to Washington.

site_title: Singapore economy stabilising, but 'not yet out of the woods': PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to rebound in 2021 after experiencing the "most severe downturn" since independence, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Despite this, the recovery is expected to be uneven, and activity will likely stay below pre-Covid levels "for some time". The government has implemented various support schemes, totaling nearly S$100 billion, to prevent job losses and business failures. With the pandemic stabilizing and vaccination efforts underway, Lee emphasized the importance of maintaining discipline and continuing with safe distancing measures to ensure a safe and healthy recovery.

site_title: Statement pieces
summary: The Asian Civilisations Museum in Singapore has launched "Faith Beauty Love Hope - Our Stories, Your ACM" to showcase personal favorites among its staff, volunteers, and supporters. The exhibition, which runs until February 28, features over 60 objects, including a 17th-century Japanese chest and a 10th-century sandstone work. The show acknowledges the challenges faced by individuals in 2020 and aims to provide solace and inspiration. Meanwhile, master potter Iskandar Jalil's new exhibition at the ION Art Gallery has sold 80% of its pieces, including stoneware pots and vessels, within the first three days.

images.alt_text: Asian Civilisations Museum's new exhibition features antiquities such as a set of mahjong table and chairs (above) from the early 20th century, and a Dancing Ganesha sandstone piece from the early 10th century.

Asian Civilisations Museum's new exhibition features antiquities such as a set of mahjong table and chairs from the early 20th century, and a Dancing Ganesha sandstone piece from the early 10th century (above).
Iskandar Jalil's latest works once again display his unerring sense of colour, balance and texture. Some 80 per cent of his pieces were snapped up on the first day.

site_title: 30 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including five in the community
summary: Singapore reported 30 new Covid-19 cases, including five in the community, as of December 31, bringing the total to 58,599. The cases include two family members of a marine surveyor and three from a harbour pilot family cluster. Five new community cases were linked to the marine sector, prompting a review of precautionary measures for workers. The new B117 strain, reported to be 70% more contagious, was detected in a Singapore Airlines pilot and a work pass holder who recently returned from the UK.

site_title: Pandemic waves rock the Singapore market
summary: Singapore's market capitalization increased 11.1% to S$814.1 billion for the quarter, despite pandemic waves affecting the market. Oil prices rose over 2% due to market outlook and tariffs. The Singapore public offer of NTT DC Reit was oversubscribed 9.8 times. However, Creative Technology warned that its second-half revenue may be below target and operating loss may be similar to the first half. The article suggests that investors are searching for yield in pandemic-affected markets, with local pandemic plays emerging as top performers in 2020.

site_title: Businesses, what are your 2021 New Year resolutions?
summary: Business leaders, facing the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic, can use 2021 as an opportunity for digital transformation, focusing on commitments such as investing in digital fitness, balanced meal planning, and employee development. Companies should move beyond temporary measures like panic rooms and focus on long-term strategies, investing in people, face-to-face interactions, and meaningful business practices. By doing so, businesses can regain their sense of fellowship, adventure, and wonder, and emerge stronger and more resilient in 2022.

images.alt_text: Let us commit to making 2021 a year where we regain our sense of fellowship, adventure and wonder.

site_title: UK-Singapore FTA kicks in from Jan 1
summary: The UK-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) will take effect on January 1, 2021, after being provisionally applied for three weeks. The agreement eliminates tariffs for goods trade and increases access to services and government procurement markets for British and Singapore companies. The EU-Singapore FTA will cease to apply to UK-Singapore trades on the same day, providing the new agreement is ratified by both countries.

site_title: Amazon to acquire Wondery in podcast push
summary: Amazon is acquiring podcast startup Wondery for over $300 million, aiming to boost non-musical content on its Amazon Music app. Wondery, home to popular podcasts like "Dirty John" and "Business Wars," has 20 million monthly unique listeners. This deal comes as Amazon enters the podcast space, following major investments by Spotify and other companies. The acquisition is part of Amazon's efforts to expand its audio content offerings and compete with Netflix in the audio space.

site_title: Pentagon keeps US$398b F-35's full-rate production on hold
summary: The Pentagon has put the decision on approving full-rate production of the F-35 fighter jet on hold indefinitely due to technical challenges and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The previous deadline of "no later than March" was scrapped, and a new date will be determined after an independent technical review. The testing facility is still being prepared, and the testing is now expected to occur in mid- to late-2021. The full-rate production decision will be made months into the Biden administration, with the program continuing low-rate initial production in the meantime.

images.alt_text: The Pentagon has put a decision on approving full-rate production of Lockheed Martin's F-35 on indefinite hold, as officials remain unable to say when the fighter jet will be ready for combat testing that's been delayed repeatedly since 2017.

site_title: China's Fosun plans plant to make BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: China's Fosun Pharmaceutical Group plans to establish a facility in China to produce BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine, with an initial production capacity of 200 million doses. A joint venture with BioNTech is reportedly in the works. This partnership aims to increase global vaccine supply and address the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group is planning a facility in China to produce the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Germany's BioNTech.

site_title: Theatres look to Bond and Black Widow to spark 2021 moviegoing
summary: US movie theatre operators are optimistic about a 2021 comeback, driven by blockbuster films like James Bond's No Time to Die and Black Widow. Despite a 2020 box office plunge of 80% due to the pandemic, vaccines and new releases may help theatres recover. Initial excitement has been tempered by slow vaccine distribution and increased streaming options. Some theatres, like B&B Theatres, have seen week-over-week attendance increases, but expect a slow return to normal until vaccination limits are lifted and attendance limits can be lifted.

site_title: Virus-hit British Airways obtains £2 billion loan
summary: British Airways has secured a £2 billion loan from a syndicate of banks, partially guaranteed by UK Export Finance, to help the airline recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. The loan, which includes restrictions on dividend payments, aims to tap into an anticipated vaccine-driven recovery in global aviation next year. The loan is part of a larger overhaul by parent group IAG, which also includes Aer Lingus and Iberia, to ensure compliance with EU laws following Britain's exit from the bloc.

site_title: Alden Global seeks to buy Tribune Publishing
summary: US hedge fund Alden Global Capital is planning to buy newspaper chain Tribune Publishing, citing people familiar with the matter. Alden, already Tribune's largest shareholder with a 32% stake, could disclose an offer for the remaining stake as early as Thursday. The deal comes amid a decline in print newspapers due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with Tribune valued at approximately $467 million.

site_title: Chinese regulators probe Ant Group's equity investments: sources
summary: Chinese regulators are reviewing Ant Group's equity investments in dozens of companies, mainly in technology and fintech start-ups, amid a crackdown on billionaire Jack Ma's financial technology empire. Regulators are considering whether to instruct Ant to divest some investments, potentially depriving the group of lucrative investments and scaling back its influence over China's fintech industry. The probe follows existing regulatory pressure to revamp Ant's business structure and put up more capital for its consumer lending business, and comes after Ant's US$37 billion IPO was torpedoed in November due to Mr. Ma's public criticism of China's regulatory system.

site_title: Singapore's competition watchdog gets new chairman, board members
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has announced changes to its board, with Max Loh Khum Whai, managing partner of Ernst & Young, taking over as chairman from January 1, 2021. Three new members have also been appointed: Agnes Koh Puay Eng, Chandra Mallika, and Jaspal Singh. The changes aim to bring in fresh expertise and experience to the commission. Under Loh's leadership, CCCS will continue to safeguard competition and protect consumers. The changes are effective immediately, following the completion of the terms of the outgoing board members.

site_title: Investors bullish on US stocks, hoping for a brighter 2021
summary: US stocks close 2020 on a strong note, defying a tumultuous year marked by a resurgent coronavirus pandemic and a short-lived bear market. Despite risks, many investors, including Commonwealth Financial Network's head of portfolio management Peter Essele, believe stocks are in the early stages of a multi-year bull run. The US Senate runoffs and vaccine rollout concerns are being largely ignored, with investors optimistic about a brighter 2021.

site_title: Microsoft says Russian hackers viewed some of its source code
summary: Microsoft says Russian hackers viewed some of its source code by accessing an employee account, but were unable to access emails or products, and did not modify the code. The hackers, suspected to be working for Russia's SVR intelligence agency, may have breached Microsoft's network as far back as October 2019. The attack appears to be more widespread than initially believed, with other companies, including FireEye and CrowdStrike, also targeted. Microsoft initially said it was not breached, but an ongoing investigation has found no evidence of access to production services or customer data.

site_title: Escape to wide open spaces and quiet hideaways
summary: Luxury travel companies anticipate a surge in demand for guided holidays in 2021 due to the uncertainty and stress caused by the pandemic. Travelers are seeking destinations with wide-open spaces, fresh air, and a chance to avoid crowds, with popular options including New Zealand and Switzerland. Multi-generational travel, or "travel bubbles," with family and friends are also gaining popularity. To address travelers' concerns about safety and financial assurance, luxury travel companies are offering flexible itineraries, private villas, and exclusive-use properties.

site_title: Pakistan to purchase 1.2m Covid-19 vaccine doses from China's Sinopharm
summary: Pakistan has agreed to purchase 1.2 million Covid-19 vaccine doses from China's Sinopharm, with the doses to be provided free of cost to frontline workers in the first quarter of 2021. This is the first official confirmation of a vaccine purchase by the South Asian country. Pakistan had previously approved $150 million in funding for vaccine purchases, with a panel of experts compiling a list of recommended vaccines. The country is battling a second wave of infections, with 58 deaths reported on Wednesday, taking the total death toll past 10,000.

site_title: China state banks seen buying US dollar to ease sharp yuan rally
summary: China's state-owned banks are buying US dollars to curb the yuan's rapid rise, reaching a high of 6.5148 per dollar in morning trade. The move aims to prevent the yuan from breaching a key level of 6.5, which could trigger further intervention from authorities. The onshore spot market opened at 6.5204 per dollar and surged to 6.52 per dollar, which is seen as the current ceiling for the market. The action is part of efforts to maintain market stability and prevent a sharp yuan rally.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust extends master leases, grants rent abatements to Citadines properties in France
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has extended master lease agreements and revised rents for 15 properties in France managed by Citadines. The fixed rent components have been adjusted downwards, with variable rent ranging from 10.35% of total revenue. ART has also granted rent abatements to 13 properties during specific lockdown periods. The group expects a 0.8-2.3% decrease in distribution per stapled security due to the rent adjustments. The move aims to adapt to the challenging hospitality sector recovery amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: China gives conditional approval for Sinopharm's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: China has given conditional approval for the general public use of Sinopharm's Covid-19 vaccine, with an efficacy rate of 79.34% based on interim data. The approval allows the vaccine to be used in major public health emergencies where benefits outweigh risks. This is the first approval for a Chinese coronavirus vaccine candidate in public use. The approval comes after the UAE became the first country to roll out the vaccine, and follows China's own inoculation efforts for its citizens, which have administered 1.5 million doses using various products.

site_title: Homebuyers in US face worst affordability squeeze in 12 years
summary: US homebuyers face their worst affordability squeeze in 12 years, with buyers needing to spend almost 30% of their average wage to afford a typical house, according to Attom Data Solutions. Record-low mortgage rates have driven up prices, with 79% of counties experiencing double-digit price increases during the pandemic. Over half of these counties are now less affordable than their historic averages, with affordability expected to worsen unless interest rates rise or supply improves.

site_title: Australia: Shares close year of historic highs and lows little changed
summary: Australian shares ended 2020 little changed from the start of the year, closing at 6,587.1 after a year of record highs and historic lows. Tech stocks, particularly buy-now-pay-later firms, drove growth, while energy stocks saw their worst year since 2015. Trading volumes were low due to year-end holidays, with traders watching for stricter Covid-19 movement curbs. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished 1.4% lower, just 1.5% below its opening price in January 2020.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on the final trading day of 2020, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% or 10.84 points to 2,858.38. Singtel declined 0.4% after announcing a reorganisation to capture new digital growth, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also fell. Global markets were mixed, with the Dow Jones closing at a record high and European stocks ending a five-day winning streak.

site_title: Brazil fails to secure syringes for Covid-19 vaccine jabs
summary: Brazil's coronavirus vaccination programme is at risk due to the government's low auction prices for syringes, which deterred bids from companies. The Health Ministry purchased only 8 million syringes, falling short of its target of 331 million. The country needs around 320 million syringes to distribute vaccines, which would cost up to 120 million reais. The low prices may lead to panic or costly imports, with the medical supplies and equipment industry lobby group Abimo warning of the risk to the vaccination programme.

site_title: Singtel reorganises structure to capture new digital growth
summary: Singtel has reorganized its structure to capture new digital growth, effective January 1, 2021. The telco created a 5G enterprise portfolio under the group enterprise division and brought its international business under the CFO office. Arthur Lang will become group CFO, while Samba Natarajan leads the strategic portfolio unit, overseeing digital marketing and business development. NCS, Singtel's ICT arm, will report directly to the group CEO to expand into the Asia-Pacific region. The changes aim to create more value for the group by turning NCS into a leading regional B2B digital services company.

site_title: US warships transit Taiwan Strait for second time this month
summary: US warships USS John S McCain and USS Curtis Wilbur sailed through the Taiwan Strait on December 31, the second time this month, amid heightened tensions with China. The US Navy described the transit as a "routine mission" in accordance with international law, while China's military had previously denounced a US warship passing through the strait. The US demonstration of naval presence in the region is seen as a response to China's claims over Taiwan, further straining relations between the US and China.

site_title: Bank lending in November up 0.2%: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.2% in November, reversing an eight-month decline, according to MAS data. Total loans stood at S$676.67 billion, with consumer loans increasing 0.4% to S$258.31 billion, while business loans remained flat. Year-over-year, total bank lending fell 2.3%, with business loans down 2.7% and consumer loans down 1.7%.

site_title: DPM Heng Swee Keat to deliver Singapore Budget on Feb 16, 2021
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver Singapore's Budget on February 16, 2021, amidst an uncertain economic outlook due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has recorded 58,569 coronavirus cases and forecasts a full-year economic contraction of 6.5-6.0%. The Budget will be broadcast live and the public can provide feedback until January 8, 2021. The government expects a deficit of SGD 74.2 billion due to stimulus packages and support measures. The economic recovery trajectory remains uncertain, with the possibility of an adaptation if the situation worsens.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish the year in the red, STI down 0.89%
summary: Singapore stocks ended 2020 in the red, closing 0.89% lower at 2,843.81 points. Despite this, the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.35% for the month. The decline was attributed to investor caution on the last trading day of the year.

site_title: Gold firms as US dollar slides to multi-year low
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,890.61 per ounce, as the US dollar slid to its lowest in over two years following a delay in COVID-19 relief checks. Global vaccine rollouts and increased risk appetite limited gains, but analysts see gold as a hedge against inflation and currency debasement from large stimulus measures. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with spot gold rising to its highest level in over two years.

site_title: McConnell thwarts Trump bid for US$2,000 virus relief checks
summary: US Senate leader Mitch McConnell has blocked a bill to increase COVID-19 relief checks to $2,000 from $600, dealing a likely death blow to President Donald Trump's bid. McConnell stated that the bill has "no realistic path to quickly pass the Senate" and controls the Senate's agenda, opposing the increase in aid. The move appears certain to kill the effort, with a new Congress set to be sworn in on Sunday. McConnell's remarks came after Trump ramped up pressure on fellow Republicans to back the bigger checks, but some Republican senators had already backed the increase.

site_title: Fauci sees US gaining control over pandemic by next fall
summary: US infectious disease specialist Anthony Fauci predicts the country will regain "some semblance of normality" by fall 2021, driven by collective Covid-19 immunity from vaccinations. Despite initial vaccine rollout setbacks, Fauci expects the US to catch up on vaccinations by April and reach herd immunity by early fall, allowing for the reopening of schools, theaters, and other public spaces. The emergence of a more contagious UK variant may accelerate the vaccination effort, but Fauci notes that immunity from earlier strains is protective against this particular strain.

images.alt_text: The leading US infectious disease specialist, Anthony Fauci, said on Wednesday he foresees America achieving enough collective Covid-19 immunity through vaccinations to regain "some semblance of normality" by fall 2021, despite early setbacks in the vaccine rollout.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Thursday with small gains, building on previous days' strong rallies, and are on course for a positive end to a tumultuous year. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.18%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. This follows a strong rally over the past two days.

site_title: Lewis Hamilton knighted in UK honours list
summary: Lewis Hamilton, 35, has been knighted in the UK's New Year Honours list for equalling Michael Schumacher's record of seven Formula One world titles. Hamilton surpassed Schumacher's record during the shortened 2020 season due to the coronavirus pandemic. He has been an outspoken supporter of equality, diversity, and the environment, and has made strong human rights statements. The recognition comes after a group of British lawmakers called for Hamilton to be recommended for a knighthood.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, DBS, Keppel, Boustead, Chip Eng Seng
summary: Singapore stocks traded on Thursday, with notable developments including Singtel's reorganization to capture new digital growth, Singapore Airlines' first SilkAir Boeing 737 MAX flights back to Changi Airport, and DBS extending its revolving credit facility to KrisEnergy. Keppel Corporation also extended its bilateral contract with KrisEnergy to support debt restructuring. Other companies saw share price movements due to various announcements, including Boustead Singapore selling its water solutions unit to Chip Eng Seng and UOL Group announcing leadership changes.

site_title: Nearly 14,700 travellers visited Singapore in November: STB
summary: Singapore welcomed nearly 14,676 visitors in November, a 9.5% increase from October and a fraction of the 1.53 million visitors in the same period last year. More than a quarter of these visitors came from China. Hotel room revenue stood at S$66.3 million, down 0.6% from the previous month and 82% from last year. Average occupancy rates were 53.8%, down from 88.9% last year, while standard average room rates increased to S$144.6, but hotel revenue per available room fell 59.6% year on year.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars storm ahead as markets bet on brighter 2021
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged to fresh highs on December 31, 2020, as markets anticipated a vaccine-fueled economic recovery in 2021. The Aussie dollar reached US$0.7707, a 10% gain for the year, while the New Zealand dollar rose to a 40% gain from its low in March. Analysts attribute the surge to expectations of increased commodity prices and riskier assets.

site_title: Bitcoin touches US$29,000 for another high in banner year
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$29,292 on December 31, 2020, advancing almost 50% in December and quadrupling in value this year. The cryptocurrency's price surge has sparked debate over its validity and potential as a hedge against dollar weakness and inflation risk. Regulatory concerns remain, with the Securities and Exchange Commission accusing Ripple Labs of misleading investors. The latest price surge follows other digital currencies, such as Ether, which have also rallied, with the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index up about 280% this year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end lower as risk rally winds down
summary: European stocks ended a five-day winning streak, closing 0.3% lower as investors locked in recent gains. Despite positive vaccine and Brexit trends, the pan-European Stoxx 600 is set to shed over 3% this year due to coronavirus disruptions. Travel and leisure stocks rose 0.2%, while German shares ended lower in their last trading day of 2020. UK stocks fell despite the approval of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine, with resource stocks weighing on the FTSE 100.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Indonesia, Japan, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand are closed on December 31, 2020, for a public holiday. In contrast, European stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU tariffs also in focus. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Airbus nears 550 deliveries in year derailed by Covid-19
summary: Airbus delivered nearly 550 aircraft in 2020, surpassing its pre-pandemic forecast of 880 deliveries. The European planemaker tallied 477 deliveries through November, nearing the milestone three days before the end of the year. This surpasses Boeing's 118 deliveries by the end of November. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, Airbus remains comfortably ahead of Boeing and is set to retain its title as the world's largest planemaker for a second year. The company's deliveries represent a 36% drop from 2019.

site_title: DBS, Keppel extend contract for KrisEnergy's revolving credit facility
summary: Keppel Corp has extended KrisEnergy's revolving credit facility (RCF) from DBS by six months to June 30, 2021, with the option to extend it further to June 30, 2024. The facility has US$185 million in outstanding principal. Keppel, which owns a 40% stake in KrisEnergy, has signed a bilateral contract with DBS to support KrisEnergy's debt restructuring efforts. The extension will provide liquidity for KrisEnergy's ongoing expenses and help retain the possibility of a successful financial restructuring.

site_title: Covid-19 has no grand lesson for the world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has failed to provide a clear lesson for the world, with no governmental or economic model consistently outperforming its rivals in combating the virus. Despite varying levels of public spending on welfare states and civic freedoms, neither big nor small governments have reliably outperformed each other. The pandemic has also shown that correlations between economic factors and resilience do not hold true, and the success of East and South-east Asia is attributed to a mix of communist and democratic systems. The world is left with ambiguity and confusion, and the challenge is to resist forcing a narrative on to facts that do not support one.

site_title: China's factory activity expands at slower pace in Dec
summary: China's factory activity expanded in December, but at a slower pace, with the official manufacturing PMI falling to 51.9 from 52.1 in November. Exports remained strong, but tougher coronavirus control measures in trading partners and domestic infections could dent industrial demand. The Chinese economy is expected to expand around 2% for the full year, the weakest in over three decades.

site_title: Bitcoin hits new peak again with biggest monthly gain since 2019
summary: Bitcoin surged above US$28,000 on Wednesday, reaching a record high and marking its biggest monthly gain since May 2019, adding 47% to its December value. The digital asset has almost quadrupled in value this year, with the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index up 270%. Regulatory concerns remain, with the SEC accusing Ripple Labs of misleading investors and Coinbase delisting XRP amid the lawsuit. Bitcoin's rally continues to divide opinion, with some viewing it as a hedge against dollar weakness and inflation, while others question its validity as an asset class.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US crude stock draw supports but demand hopes dim
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, supported by a 6.1 million barrel draw in US crude inventories, but pressured by swelling year-over-year supply and dwindling demand hopes. Brent crude futures settled up 25 cents to $51.34 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled up 40 cents to $48.40 a barrel. Despite a report showing lower inventories, traders noted that US crude inventories still ended the year 10% higher than the last week of 2019. A January OPEC meeting also looms, which may boost supply and further dampen prices.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia launches Myanmar's first credit bureau
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) launched Myanmar's first credit bureau, a 60:40 joint venture with MB Investment. The bureau aims to promote responsible lending by implementing a credit reporting system, supporting financial institutions and consumers. It will provide credit monitoring services, industry analyses, and data analytics reports, expanding access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises. The launch is seen as a significant milestone in Myanmar's economic development, enhancing transparency of the financial sector and managing customer borrowing risk through credit information sharing.

site_title: US dollar plumbs more than two-year lows as more stimulus in view
summary: The US dollar has hit more than two-year lows against major currencies, including the euro, Aussie, and New Zealand dollar, amid expectations of additional US fiscal support and a boost in global growth. Investors are positioning for year-end gains, despite concerns about US economic growth lagging behind peers. Rising fiscal and current account deficits are also contributing to the dollar's decline. The outlook for the US economy is seen as improving with the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and stimulus measures.

site_title: Terence Loh lodges police report over 'improper transfers' of S$5m
summary: Terence Loh, a director of Giron Wines, has lodged a police report alleging six unauthorised transfers totaling S$5.25 million from the company's accounts. He claims these transfers were made to a relative's bank accounts between April 27 and May 5. The police confirmed a report was lodged, and investigations are ongoing. Giron has been placed in receivership due to bank financing issues and the company's revenue was S$19.5 million last year. The incident has raised questions about the Loh cousins' business dealings, following a series of scandals and disputes.

site_title: Thailand clears use of herbal medicine for Covid-19 treatment
summary: Thailand's health ministry approved the use of Andrographis Paniculata, a herbal plant extract, to treat early stages of Covid-19 as a pilot program. The treatment aims to reduce severity and costs, with initial availability in five state-owned hospitals. The treatment is voluntary for those aged 18-60 with minor symptoms, administered within 72 hours of infection. Human trials showed improved patient conditions without side effects, citing studies that suggest the extract can curb virus and reduce inflammation.

site_title: HDB to trial smart parking system at Punggol Northshore
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) will conduct a trial of a smart parking system, Parking@HDB, at Punggol Northshore starting Jan 4, 2021. This is the latest addition to the waterfront district's suite of smart features, which includes smart-enabled Build-To-Order (BTO) flats. The system aims to improve parking efficiency and convenience for residents.

site_title: US: Dow edges to record as US stock rally resumes
summary: US stocks resumed their holiday season rally, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average edging to a fresh record at 30,409.56, up 0.2%. The rally comes despite dimmed chances of US stimulus and criticism from Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell on raising stimulus payments. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also added 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. Meanwhile, Britain approved a low-cost Covid-19 vaccine, and the US has cleared vaccines from Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna. Investors took a breather, citing exhaustion after big moves in the last quarter.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks resumed their holiday season rally Wednesday, shrugging off the dimming chances of more US stimulus being enacted while another coronavirus vaccine advanced.

site_title: US 20-city home price index posts biggest gain since 2014
summary: US home prices in 20 cities rose 7.95% in October, the largest gain since 2014, driven by ultra-low mortgage rates and increased buyer appetite for more space. Home prices rose 1.6% from the previous month, and the lack of inventory and surge in prices threaten to slow housing momentum and price some buyers out of the market. Sales of new and existing homes declined in November, with a gauge of home prices nationwide increasing 8.4% from a year earlier, the most since March 2014.

site_title: Boustead Singapore sells water solutions unit to Chip Eng Seng for S$7.3m
summary: Boustead Singapore sold its wholly-owned water solutions subsidiary, Boustead Salcon Water Solutions, to Chip Eng Seng Corporation for approximately S$7.3 million. The disposal will allow the group to redeploy funds to core businesses and re-strategize. Boustead Singapore expects the sale to have a positive impact on earnings per share for the 2021 financial year, despite no material impact on net tangible assets per share. The transaction will exclude two subsidiaries of Boustead Salcon, which will be acquired by the buyer.

site_title: Ringing in the new year, with hope, resolve and determination
summary: The world is entering a new year amidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with hopes of a better future. However, new waves of infections are expected, potentially leading to lockdowns and party cancellations. Despite this, people look forward to leaving the regrets of the past year behind and ushering in a new one. The pandemic continues to circumscribe celebrations, and countries prepare for an explosion of cases after the fireworks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 1.7 points or 0.1% to 1,642.71. The market saw a slight volume of 138.5 million lots worth RM59.4 million, with gainers beating losers 231 to 98. The index's performance was not directly related to any specific event or news.

site_title: Which developing economies will rise after the Covid-19 pandemic?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has created opportunities for developing economies to rise, despite the crisis's obstacles. The digital revolution, economic reform, and a potential commodity price revival could power growth in emerging economies. Countries like India, Indonesia, and Brazil are pushing reforms to boost productivity and growth. While the path to prosperity through manufacturing is narrowing, it hasn't closed, and countries like Vietnam and Poland are experiencing transformative effects. A few growth stars, rather than a global "rise of the rest", are likely to emerge, with some developing economies rising again in the 2020s.

site_title: EU seeks to rebalance China ties with investment pact
summary: The European Union and China agreed on an investment deal, giving European companies greater access to Chinese markets. The deal includes sectors such as electric cars, private hospitals, and telecom cloud services, with some requirements for joint ventures lifted. China has pledged to be more transparent on subsidies and ban state-owned enterprises from discriminating against foreign investors. The agreement brings Europe parity with the US, which has struck a Phase One trade deal with China, and includes commitments on climate change and labor rights. The deal is expected to take at least a year to enter into force.

site_title: Putin targets US social media, secret agent leaks with new laws
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin signed new laws giving the government more power to restrict US social media, label individuals as "foreign agents," and control the disclosure of security officers' personal data. The laws also cap Putin's term limits, allowing him to stand for two more six-year terms. The moves are seen as part of a campaign to increase Russia's internet sovereignty, with analysts warning of potential China-style controls. The laws follow a year of constitutional reforms that have strained Russia's ties with the West.

site_title: US adjusts tariffs on EU goods hit in Airbus, Boeing fight
summary: The US has adjusted tariffs on EU goods hit in the Airbus, Boeing dispute, following a WTO-approved EU decision to impose duties on US$4 billion in trade. The US Trade Representative's office added tariffs on aircraft-manufacturing parts, certain non-sparkling wine, and cognac from France and Germany. The move comes as the US and EU discuss a negotiated solution to the long-running dispute, with President-elect Joe Biden signaling a desire to repair trade relations with the EU.

site_title: Students can still assimilate different cultures via virtual learning
summary: The Singapore Management University (SMU) has launched a virtual learning platform, SMU-X Overseas, allowing students to work on real-world projects with overseas companies despite the COVID-19 pandemic. A recent project involved 28 SMU students working with Bank OCBC NISP in Indonesia to promote its digital banking solutions. The students developed a campaign called 3 Cs: Creation, Collaboration, and Continuation, which utilized YouTube and Instagram to promote the bank's platform to SMEs. The project demonstrated the potential for virtual learning to equip students with cultural exposure and skills in international business.

site_title: Stamford Land to sell Grade A Perth commercial development for A$67.8m
summary: Stamford Land Corporation is selling its Grade A Perth commercial development, Stamford Green, for A$67.8 million. The 14-storey office building has been vacant since Chevron's lease expired in April 2020 due to poor leasing conditions and high vacancy in the Perth central business district. The sale, which is subject to foreign investment approval, is expected to allow Stamford Land to avoid significant costs and expedite the transaction. The company plans to reinvest the net sale proceeds into future opportunities and believes the sale will not impact its risk profile.

site_title: Apple loses copyright claims against 'virtual iPhone' maker
summary: Apple lost its copyright claims against Corellium LLC, a Florida company that creates "virtual iPhones" for security research. District Court Judge Rodney Smith ruled that Corellium's product creates a new, virtual platform with capabilities not available on Apple's iOS devices, falling under an exception to copyright law. The judge also stated that Corellium's fair use defense is supported by the public benefit of the product, despite the company selling its virtual iPhones. The case will continue, with the two sides submitting a status report by January 11.

site_title: More parks, fewer offices? How the coronavirus will change city centres
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a shift in urban planning, with cities adapting to a future with more remote work and reduced public transportation demand. Mixed-use developments, including luxury and affordable housing, are expected to become more prevalent in city centers. WELL certification, focusing on health and hygiene, will also become a priority. In contrast, public transportation use is unlikely to recover, with cities instead promoting cycling, walking, and personal mobility vehicles. Additionally, there is a growing emphasis on provisioning more parks and public spaces, and the emergence of "doughnut cities" with abandoned city centers and thriving suburbs.

site_title: Economists expect smaller but more calibrated Budget in 2021
summary: Economists predict a smaller but more targeted Budget 2021 for Singapore, focusing on sectors still in need of support during the pandemic-led recession. The budget may include measures to ease firms' liquidity and support business costs, with a greater emphasis on medium-term support and incentives for training and reskilling. Continued assistance for the lower-income group is also expected, with subsidies or incentives to spur transformation and training. The government aims to revitalize growth and create opportunities for businesses, while addressing the challenges faced by the lower-income group and workers.

site_title: Mainland cash chasing Hong Kong stocks after record year
summary: Mainland Chinese investors have purchased a record HK$666 billion (S$114 billion) in Hong Kong stocks in 2020, with over US$51 billion raised from initial public offerings and secondary listings. Despite Hong Kong's worst stock performance in over two decades, investors are optimistic about the city's market in 2021, citing attractive valuations and government support. Regulatory risks in China and US-China tensions may loom, but bulls believe Hong Kong firms have room for growth and are chasing high-growth companies.

site_title: Safety paramount in vaccination exercise: Gan
summary: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasizes the importance of a slow and careful vaccination process in Singapore, citing challenges and the need for verification of individuals' identities, pre-existing conditions, and allergies. Over 30 National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) staff received their first doses, with a second dose scheduled for January 20, and other healthcare workers to follow. The general public's vaccination will begin in February for those aged 70 and older, with medically eligible individuals to follow. The minister prioritizes a smooth and safe rollout over a mass rollout to avoid unforeseen difficulties.

images.alt_text: An NCID staff nurse prepares the Covid-19 vaccination for his fellow healthcare workers on Dec 30, who were among the first Singaporeans to receive the vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech.

site_title: China's Yahua bags five-year deal to supply lithium to Tesla
summary: China's Yahua Industrial Group Co Ltd has signed a five-year deal to supply lithium hydroxide to Tesla Inc, valued at $630-$880 million. The contract, signed by Yaan Lithium, will provide 63,000-88,000 tonnes of lithium hydroxide per year. The deal underscores Tesla's "huge demand" for battery-grade lithium hydroxide, particularly for Model Y production in Shanghai. Yahua's shares rose 10% after the announcement, with the company's year-to-date gain reaching almost 157%.

images.alt_text: The Yahua deal underscores Tesla's "huge demand" for battery-grade lithium hydroxide, Daiwa analysts wrote in a note.

site_title: WFH investment bankers thriving but some fear being left behind
summary: Investment bankers working from home (WFH) have thrived during the pandemic, but some fear being left behind as the industry adapts to a post-lockdown world. Citigroup's global co-head of mergers and acquisitions, Cary Kochman, rewrote his 30-year playbook to advise on the sale of US printing services provider InnerWorkings Inc. in March 2020, highlighting the shift in the industry's dynamics.

site_title: China stymies sale of US consulate staff compound in Hong Kong
summary: China has blocked the sale of a US consulate compound in Hong Kong, forcing the deal to be delayed. The HK$2.57 billion (S$439 million) purchase, which was set to complete on Wednesday, is the latest casualty of growing tensions between China and the US. The development comes amid a host of issues between the two economies, including trade and security concerns. The delay is a significant blow to Hang Lung Properties, which had planned to acquire the property.

site_title: Brexit border chaos forces truckers to shun UK deliveries
summary: Freight forwarders in Europe are rejecting UK delivery contracts due to post-Brexit border chaos, particularly in Dover. The rejection rate for cargo from France to Britain tripled last week and doubled for the Germany-Britain route. Concerns include the risk of stuck trucks and logjams after the UK leaves the single market and customs union. The UK government is still dealing with the Kent turmoil triggered by France's Covid-19 blockade, which has raised concerns about driver welfare and the willingness of EU hauliers to send drivers to the UK.

site_title: Firm outlook for private housing market belies risk factors
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to appreciate slightly more than in 2020, driven by a brighter economic outlook, easing travel restrictions, and low interest rates. However, analysts flag potential cooling measures if developers bid aggressively for land, and a deterioration in the employment situation, potential resurgence of Covid-19, and government intervention in the property market. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's benchmark overall private home price index is expected to post growth ranging from 0-4% in 2021.

images.alt_text: Ms Lagarde said she instructed the IMF team to continue discussions on a loan programme with the goal to "reach a rapid conclusion." "I stressed my strong support for Argentina's reforms to date, and expressed the Fund's readiness to continue to assist the government," she said in a statement following her meeting with Argentina economy minister Nicolas Dujovne.
Dr Mahathir was sworn in just before 10 pm on Thursday at the Istana Negara by Malaysia's King, Sultan Muhammad V (above).
Dr Mahathir (left, in a file photo with PKR leader Wan Azizah) was sworn in just before 10 pm on Thursday at the Istana Negara by Malaysia's King, Sultan Muhammad V.

JLL's Ong Teck Hui says that the expected increase in completion of private homes in 2021 might add more downward pressure on rents.
Savills' Alan Cheong flags an existing group of mortgagors previously deemed as low-risk borrowers but who may find themselves out on a limb.
Edmund Tie & Co's Lam Chern Woon says that the resale market has seen some strains of distress selling this year.

site_title: China regulator suspends Moody's Chinese JV over Yongcheng default
summary: China's National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors (NAFMII) has suspended the credit rating business of Moody's Chinese joint venture, China Chengxin International Credit Rating Co (CCXI), for three months due to its role in the default of state-owned coal miner Yongcheng Coal & Electricity Holding Group Co. CCXI was found to have violated rules by failing to conduct on-site due diligence and adequately disclose risks. The suspension is the latest move by Chinese regulators to repair investor confidence after recent defaults by state firms.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mirach Energy, a Singapore-listed oil and gas company, is winding up due to inability to secure a reasonable exit offer. OUE Lippo Healthcare will jointly manage an obstetrics and gynaecology hospital in Changshu, China, with China Merchants Group, starting 2023. Koufu Group will sell its stake in Indonesian joint venture Super Tea Indonesia to reduce costs, while continuing its licensing agreement.

site_title: EU leaders sign Brexit deal, as British MPs debate swiftly to clear it
summary: EU leaders signed a 1,246-page trade deal with Britain, ending the UK's 50-year European experiment. The agreement, set to take effect on Thursday, avoids a cliff-edge separation that would have imposed quotas and tariffs on cross-Channel trade. Despite criticism from some British fishermen and Labour party concerns, the deal is expected to pass in the UK Parliament, with the government aiming to rush through all stages in one day. The agreement marks a new relationship between Britain and the EU, with cooperation on issues like climate change and pandemics.

site_title: CDL director steps down over concerns with Sincere investment
summary: CDL director Koh Thiam Hock has resigned over concerns about the company's investment in Sincere Property Group, following another director's abrupt departure in October. Koh cited disagreements over CDL's investment in Sincere and its continued financial support to the Chinese property group. Carol Fong, group chief executive of CGS-CIMB Securities, has been appointed as the new independent non-executive director. CDL has also made changes to its board and committees following Koh's resignation.

site_title: A return to 'normalcy' in the form of a new Roaring 20s?
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has campaigned on a promise of restoring "normalcy" to the country, echoing Warren Harding's 1920 campaign slogan. Harding, the 29th US president, brought about a period of economic growth and prosperity known as the Roaring Twenties after World War I and the Spanish Flu pandemic. However, his presidency was marked by scandals and failure to address structural issues. Biden's plan for a return to normalcy faces the risk of repeating Harding's mistakes, and he must recognize that presidential leadership requires more than just economic growth.

site_title: Landlords' post-virus refit will leave scars
summary: Landlords are refitting properties in response to the pandemic, with Amazon buying defunct malls and offices turning into flats, potentially boosting the $33 trillion global commercial property market. However, assets will still be worth less than five years ago, with shopping malls in a worse state due to the e-commerce boom. Refurbishment costs are minimal, but yields have dropped, with UK shopping malls experiencing a 44% decline in value. Repurposing offices and warehouses also poses challenges, with affordable housing shortages and limited planning permission.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust stuck in limbo after unitholders vote against change of manager
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) faces uncertainty after unitholders voted against a proposed change of manager, with one of four interconditional resolutions failing to receive sufficient votes. The proposed base fee supplement for the new Reit manager, SCCPRE Hospitality Reit Management, was rejected with 56.3% of the vote, falling short of the required 75% threshold. As a result, EHT has no manager, and its trustee, DBS Trustee, is considering available options. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated it will provide timely updates to unitholders on the next steps for the Reit.

site_title: HSBC break-up will turbocharge CEO's more lucrative Asian pivot
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn is expected to accelerate his pivot towards the more lucrative Asian business due to a lagging share price. The bank's shares have fallen by a third since 2019, trading at a 16% discount to Citigroup. To boost capital, HSBC may consider selling its US retail network and spinning off its UK unit, potentially creating a stand-alone unit that could participate in future UK bank consolidation. This move would focus investors' attention on Asia, where HSBC's operations have generated an adjusted return on tangible equity of 15.8% in 2019.

site_title: Taiwan to buy 10m doses of AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Taiwan has agreed to purchase 10 million doses of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine, with the total purchase to be around 20 million doses. The government also confirmed Taiwan's first case of the British variant of the disease. Taiwan has managed to keep the pandemic under control with strict quarantine measures, with 798 cases and seven deaths. The purchase of the vaccine is aimed at protecting the island's population.

site_title: STI gains 0.74% to close at 2,869.22 as shares climb steadily through day
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.74% to close at 2,869.22, driven by steady climbs throughout the day. Wilmar International and Singapore Airlines led the gains, increasing 2.38% and 2.12% respectively. Asian markets ended mixed, with the Nikkei 225 Index down 0.45% and the Kospi up 1.88%.

site_title: UK pet owners have bone to pick with post-Brexit travel rules
summary: The UK has ended its participation in the EU passport scheme for cats and dogs, moving to a new category under European Union pet travel rules. Pet owners must now obtain an animal health certificate (AHC) within 10 days of travel to the EU and Northern Ireland, adding potential expense and bureaucracy. Vets have expressed concerns about the new system, citing complexity and increased hassle for owners and animals. Pet owners, including those who regularly travel with their pets to Europe, are also disappointed, with some predicting fewer trips due to the added costs.

site_title: Boeing 737 Max resumes flying US passengers after 2-year halt
summary: The Boeing 737 Max has resumed flying US passengers after a 2-year halt, with American Airlines Flight 718 being the first to carry paying passengers. The plane was grounded worldwide after two fatal crashes in 2019, killing 346 people. To fly again, the Max must install software updates, modify wiring, and undergo other changes. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has lifted its grounding order, with other regulators expected to follow. Some airlines, including United and Alaska, have also resumed flying the plane, while others, like Delta, do not use it.

images.alt_text: American Airlines Flight 718 left Miami around 10:30am and landed after 1pm in New York City, well ahead of schedule. The plane made the return trip on Tuesday afternoon.

site_title: S Korea holds final hearing in Samsung leader Jay Y Lee's graft trial
summary: South Korea's Seoul High Court is set to decide on a new sentence for Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee, who was convicted of bribery in 2017. Lee's original sentence was reduced and suspended, but a subsequent Supreme Court ruling sent the matter back to the court. A decision is expected in early 2026, with the bribery case being the biggest immediate threat to Lee's leadership. Lee, who served a year in jail before being freed, is also on trial for alleged fraud and stock price manipulation.

site_title: Singapore must position for success within new global supply chains: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore must position itself as a critical node in the new global supply chains, said Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing. Amid the Covid-19 pandemic, the country secured S$13 billion of fixed asset investment commitments in the first four months of 2020. Chan highlighted three future-shaping factors: shifts in global supply chains, inequalities in growth, and threats to global cooperation. He emphasized the need for Singapore to create trusted environments, attract capital and talent, and provide a safe harbour, as traditional factors such as land and natural resources become less important.

site_title: Wonder Woman and her evolving look
summary: Wonder Woman's iconic costume has undergone significant changes since her debut in 1941. Over the years, her look has evolved from a golden-eagle emblem and skirt to a W logo breastplate and leggings. Notable transformations include a shorter skirt, addition of armaments, and changes in the tiara and WW emblem. In 1984, she donned golden armor, which was inspired by a comic book storyline. In 2010, her timeline was altered, leading to a new uniform that covered her legs. The character's costume has been influenced by various factors, including comic book reboots and social commentary, with Wonder Woman's look remaining a symbol of female empowerment.

site_title: Is this the end of the mink coat?
summary: The mink coat, once a symbol of luxury and elegance, is experiencing a decline in popularity. The 1987 stock market crash marked the beginning of its decline, as the industry struggled to diversify and adapt to changing consumer trends. The rise of synthetic alternatives and growing concerns over animal welfare have led to a shift away from fur coats. Many luxury brands, including Burberry and Chanel, have banned fur, and several countries have implemented bans or restrictions on the sale of fur products. As a result, the world's largest fur auction house is closing, and retailers are selling off their remaining coats.

site_title: 2020 - the year Reaganism died
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an economic relief bill on December 27, 2020, extending unemployment benefits for a few months. The move came after months of crisis and demonstrated the effectiveness of government aid in times of distress. This event marked the "death of Reaganism," a philosophy that prioritized limited government intervention in economic matters. The bill's passage led to a rise in stock market futures and a positive forecast for economic growth in 2021, highlighting the benefits of government aid for the nation as a whole.

site_title: 2020 wrap: Robinsons, Hin Leong and lay-offs among year's most-read stories
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

In 2020, The Business Times' most-read stories included Robinsons Singapore's 162-year closure, tax deductions for working from home, Singapore's potential 100,000 layoffs, and the financial struggles of debt-hit oil giant Hin Leong Trading. Other notable stories featured the departure of BreadTalk's CFO, the bankruptcy of Home-Fix's founder, and warnings from the Singapore Medical Council about DoctorxDentist's unprofessional practices. The COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on businesses and employees dominated the headlines, with readers seeking information on navigating retrenchment and employment matters amidst the crisis. The year's stories highlighted the challenges faced by various industries.

site_title: Delhi's clean power goal has to grapple with problem of idled fossil fuel plants
summary: India's capital city, Delhi, is seeking to shed its contracts with fossil fuel power plants to reduce costs and free up funds for clean energy. Tata Power Delhi Distribution Ltd plans to offload some of its supply deals to other states and oppose lifetime extensions for ageing plants, aiming to reduce power purchase costs. The company aims to expand its renewable power portfolio and improve the reliability of power supplies, with plans to spend 10 billion rupees to upgrade Delhi's overhead cable networks.

site_title: Home prices in UK rise most in 6 years
summary: Home prices in the UK rose 7.3% in December, the largest annual increase in six years, driven by tax incentives and a surge in demand for larger homes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This contrasts with weakness in other parts of the economy. Demand for detached homes rose 8% over the past year, while flat prices increased 4%. However, Nationwide economist Robert Gardner warns that housing market activity is likely to slow in 2021 if the labour market weakens, particularly after the stamp duty holiday expires at the end of March.

site_title: Currency markets stay 'risk-on' as US$ hits lowest since 2018
summary: The US dollar hit its lowest level in over two years, falling 0.3% to 89.737 against a basket of currencies, as investors bet on an economic recovery in 2021 despite rising Covid-19 infections and delayed US fiscal stimulus talks. Riskier currencies, such as the euro and Australian dollar, gained, while the Japanese yen rose against the dollar. The UK approved a Covid-19 vaccine and a Brexit deal, boosting market sentiment, but analysts expect the dollar to weaken further in 2021 as President-elect Joe Biden pushes for more economic support.

site_title: UK first to approve Oxford, AstraZeneca vaccine
summary: The UK has become the first country to approve a coronavirus vaccine developed by Oxford University and AstraZeneca, granting emergency authorization after a recommendation from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency. The approval allows for rapid distribution of 100 million doses, with hundreds of thousands available for administration next week. The vaccine is seen as crucial for mass immunizations in developing countries and Britain, despite concerns over trial data. Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed the approval as a "triumph for British science," with the Health Secretary confident that vulnerable people can be vaccinated by spring.

images.alt_text: Britain on Wednesday became the first country in the world to approve a coronavirus vaccine developed by Oxford University and AstraZeneca, hoping that rapid action would help it stem a surge of infections driven by a highly contagious variant of the virus.

site_title: Surprise ending for publishers: In 2020, business was good
summary: Book publishers experienced a surprising surge in business in 2020, with print sales up nearly 8% and e-book sales increasing over 16% compared to the previous year. The COVID-19 pandemic led to a rise in reading, with many people turning to books for entertainment and escapism. The Black Lives Matter protests and presidential elections also drove sales of books on social justice and politics. However, some segments of the industry, such as travel and religious books, struggled. Despite these challenges, publishers are optimistic about the year's performance, with many expecting it to be the best year in a long time.

site_title: US blocks imports of palm oil from Malaysian producer Sime Darby
summary: The US has banned imports of palm oil from Malaysian producer Sime Darby Plantation due to allegations of forced labor in the production process. The US Customs and Border Protection issued a "withhold release order" allowing it to detain shipments based on suspicion of forced labor involvement. This ban is the third this year for a Malaysian company over forced labor allegations, affecting the industry that faces mounting allegations of labor and human rights abuses.

site_title: Opec+ oil output cut compliance at 101% in November: sources
summary: The Opec+ group of oil producers fully complied with supply cuts in November, reaching 101% compliance, according to sources. This comes as Russia has expressed interest in raising output by 500,000 barrels per day in February, despite concerns over the impact of the latest surge in coronavirus infections. The decision will be discussed at the Opec+ meeting on January 4, with several European countries imposing lockdowns and limiting oil demand.

site_title: Is there room for a corporate version of the Gini index?
summary: A lecturer at the Henley Business School, Filipe Morais, proposed six years ago developing a framework to link a company's internal Gini coefficient with national Gini coefficients to promote income equality. The idea, which was initially met with academic and governance interest, has yet to gain traction. Regulators and companies may consider adopting Morais's proposal, which could provide a more effective way to address income inequality, particularly in light of the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on income disparities. A corporate Gini index could help companies disclose their compensation structure at a macroeconomic level, allowing for more accurate benchmarking and accountability.

site_title: FTSE Russell may delete more Chinese firms after US bolsters executive order
summary: FTSE Russell may remove more Chinese firms from its global benchmarks due to the strengthened US executive order banning investment in companies with alleged Chinese military backing. The order, signed by President Trump in November, prompted a rush to remove US-blacklisted Chinese companies from indices to maintain client compliance. The scope of the sanctions was seen as vague, leading to a potential broader removal of Chinese firms. This move follows the US bolsters its executive order, adding to the pressure on global index publishers.

site_title: Facebook to close Irish units at centre of tax dispute
summary: Facebook is closing its Irish subsidiaries amid a tax dispute with US authorities. The move follows a claim by the US that Facebook Ireland Holdings owed billions in taxes for improperly shifting profits offshore. The closing is part of a change to Facebook's operating structure, with the holdings of the three subsidiaries being distributed to the US parent company. This decision comes after previous reports by media outlets, including the Times of London.

site_title: Australia's biggest city tightens Covid-19 curbs for New Year's Eve
summary: Australian authorities have tightened COVID-19 curbs in Sydney ahead of New Year's Eve, limiting household gatherings to five people and capping public gatherings at 30. The restrictions aim to prevent a "super spreader" event, following a new cluster of infections. The measures will be in place until further notice, and the city's New Year's Eve fireworks display has been scaled back. Three new COVID-19 cases were reported in Victoria, sparking concerns of a possible outbreak.

site_title: Dialysis clinics roll out Covid-19 antibody drugs in US
summary: Dialysis clinics in the US are rolling out COVID-19 antibody treatments, with nearly half a million doses allocated but only 21% administered. The treatments, manufactured copies of proteins the body produces to combat the virus, are being administered to high-risk patients, including those with chronic illnesses like kidney disease. Despite logistical challenges and skepticism, healthcare providers hope the timely use of the treatment can reduce hospital admissions.

site_title: CDL obtains S$470m green revolving credit facility
summary: CDL obtains a S$470 million green revolving credit facility for refinancing its Republic Plaza commercial property and on-lending to other eligible green projects.
