The five-year facility, starting in January 2021, was provided by a group of lenders including DBS and HSBC, which also act as green loan advisers. This follows CDL's 2019 bagging of S$500 million in green loans for new property developments. The move reflects the growing importance of green financing amid the pandemic.

site_title: Ukraine signs up for China's Sinovac vaccine, with doses expected soon
summary: Ukraine has signed a contract to purchase 1.8 million doses of China's Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine, with delivery expected in February. The move follows multi-month negotiations, as stated by President Volodymyr Zelenskiy. The vaccine purchase is seen as a significant step in Ukraine's efforts to combat the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia signs US$9.8b EV battery deal with LG Group unit
summary: Indonesia has signed a US$9.8 billion electric vehicle (EV) battery deal with LG Group's unit, LG Energy Solution. The agreement, signed on Dec 18, includes investments across the EV supply chain, from mining to producing lithium batteries. The project will be located in North Maluku and Central Java, with at least 70% of nickel ore processed in Indonesia. This makes Indonesia the first country to integrate the electric battery industry from mining to producing electric car lithium batteries.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare in joint venture with China Merchants Group to operate Changshu hospital
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare has entered a 50:50 joint venture with China Merchants Group to operate a 140-bed obstetrics and gynaecology hospital in Changshu, China's Jiangsu province. The project, expected to be commissioned in 2023, will be structured under a 19.5-year lease. This is the company's second hospital in China, following one already operational, and its third in development. The joint venture is seen as a strategic move for OUE Lippo Healthcare, with the company's shares rising 10% following the announcement.

site_title: AMC cinema chain files to offer 50m more shares
summary: AMC Entertainment Holdings, the world's largest cinema operator, plans to offer up to 50 million more shares to avoid bankruptcy. The company registered 200 million shares earlier this month and warned that it might seek an in-court restructuring, which could wipe out equity investors. Movie theatre owners, including AMC, have been hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic, with limited box office earnings. AMC shares rose 1.3% in premarket trading, but are down 68% for the year.

site_title: China will allow more annuity funds to invest in equities
summary: China plans to increase the proportion of annuity funds that can invest in equities, lifting the threshold from 30% to 40%, and allowing investments in Hong Kong-listed stocks. The move aims to inject 300 billion yuan (S$60.84 billion) into capital markets and support Hong Kong's financial markets. The expanded investment scope includes preference shares, asset-backed securities, and treasury bond futures. China's annuity funds have assets of 3.1 trillion yuan and generated an average annualised return of 7.07% in 2007 and 2019.

site_title: EU will shut door to UK travellers at end of Brexit transition
summary: The European Union is set to shut its borders to UK travellers at the end of the Brexit transition period on Friday, joining the US, Canada, and other countries that have not contained the coronavirus outbreak. The UK will be treated like any other country outside the bloc, and EU governments will not make any changes to their common travel "white list". The eight countries currently allowed to visit without constraint are Australia, China, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand.

site_title: Japan, S Korea to run with Viet coal plant despite climate vows
summary: Japan and South Korea are moving forward with a controversial coal plant in Vietnam, despite Japan's pledge to become carbon-neutral by 2050. The state-aligned Japan Bank for International Cooperation will lend $636 million to the Vung Ang 2 project, with private financial institutions and the Export-Import Bank of Korea providing additional funding. Environmental groups have criticized the project, citing Japan's lack of commitment to reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Tiffany shareholders back LVMH takeover, ending long-drawn dispute
summary: US jeweller Tiffany & Co's shareholders approved a $15.8 billion deal with France's LVMH, ending a long dispute that lasted over a year. The deal, valued at $131.5 per share, was initially agreed upon last year but was delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic and French political intervention. LVMH backed out of the deal in 2020 but later renegotiated the price, lowering it by $425 million. The deal is expected to close in early 2021, marking the end of the acrimonious dispute between the two luxury retailers.

site_title: UK Parliament approves Brexit trade deal as both sides look to future
summary: The UK Parliament has approved Prime Minister Boris Johnson's post-Brexit trade deal with the European Union, ending over four years of negotiation. The deal safeguards nearly $1 trillion of annual trade and paves the way for Britain's formal departure from the EU on January 1. Despite criticism from opposition parties and fishermen, Johnson has secured support from his party's hardline Brexiteers, marking a break with the EU. The agreement will regulate ties from January 1, covering trade, transport, energy links, and fishing.

site_title: Thai Q3 household debt surges to 86.6% of GDP as economy contracts
summary: Thailand's household debt surged to 86.6% of GDP in the third quarter, the highest since 2003, due to the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. The debt rose to 13.77 trillion baht, equivalent to 83.8% of GDP in June, and is expected to shrink 6.6% this year, the deepest contraction since the 1997/98 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: China slaps jail terms of up to three years on HK activists
summary: China has sentenced 10 Hong Kong activists to between 7 months and 3 years in jail for illegally crossing the border. The group, who faced charges in Hong Kong over anti-government protests, were held incommunicado in a mainland prison for 4 months before the mock trial. The court found 8 guilty, with sentences ranging from 7 months to 3 years, and imposed fines. Rights groups and family members criticized the legal process, citing concerns over the defendants' safety and treatment.

site_title: China fines JD.Com, Alibaba's Tmall, Vipshop for irregular pricing
summary: China's market regulator fined JD.Com, Alibaba's Tmall, and Vipshop 500,000 yuan each for irregular pricing during Nov 11 shopping events. This decision follows recent regulatory moves against internet giants in China, including draft rules aimed at preventing monopolistic behavior. The fines are part of the State Administration of Market Regulation's efforts to ensure compliance with anti-trust regulations. The companies have been ordered to address the matter and standardize their business operations.

site_title: Taiwan firms up AstraZeneca Covid vaccine, finds new UK variant
summary: Taiwan has agreed to purchase nearly 20 million Covid-19 vaccine doses, including 10 million from AstraZeneca, amid the island's first confirmed case of a new British variant. The government aims to vaccinate 65% of its population with 30 million doses. Taiwan has kept the pandemic under control with strict quarantine measures, with most cases being imported. The AstraZeneca vaccine was approved by the British regulator, and the first doses are expected to arrive in March. The government will further tighten entry curbs starting Friday.

site_title: SIA flies 737 MAX back to Changi Airport after CAAS approval
summary: Singapore Airlines has flown the first of six SilkAir Boeing 737 MAX planes back to Changi Airport after receiving approval from the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. The planes were grounded since March 2020 following two fatal accidents. While the return to Singapore marks a step towards commercial use, approval for flights has not been granted yet. SIA prioritizes customer and staff safety and will work with regulators to ensure safe operations.

site_title: Air crew to undergo more frequent PCR tests, further minimise contact with locals on layovers: CAAS
summary: Singapore's Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has implemented tightened measures for air crew on layovers, following two positive COVID-19 cases among Singapore Airlines personnel. Crews must now undergo more frequent PCR tests, minimize contact with locals, and wear full personal protective equipment when traveling to and from high-risk destinations. Those returning from high-risk destinations must undergo tests on arrival, departure, and upon return to Singapore. These measures take effect immediately and apply to crew members of Singapore carriers.

site_title: US Congress inches closer to Trump veto override as Republican tensions grow
summary: The US Senate is set to hold a procedural vote on a defence bill, which could pave the way for Congress to override President Donald Trump's veto. The veto was due to the bill's failure to repeal tech giants' legal protections and include $2,000 stimulus checks for Americans. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has urged lawmakers to override the veto, which would be the first such rebuke of Trump. The House has already overturned the veto, and final passage of the override could come later in the week or over the weekend.

site_title: Samsung leader Jay Y Lee vows change in graft trial's final hearing
summary: Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee vowed to "make a new Samsung" in the final hearing of a graft trial, stating he will focus on social contributions and fix the company's social role and public trust. Lee, who was convicted of bribing an associate of former President Park Geun-hye and served one year in jail, is seeking a new sentence after a Supreme Court ruling sent the case back to the Seoul High Court. The court must decide on a new sentence by January 18, which could impact Lee's leadership of Samsung Electronics.

site_title: US nurse tests positive over a week after receiving Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine
summary: A US nurse in California tested positive for COVID-19 over a week after receiving the Pfizer vaccine, contradicting common perceptions of the vaccine's effectiveness. The nurse, Matthew W, experienced mild side effects after the first dose but became sick with symptoms on Christmas Eve. An infectious disease specialist confirmed that it's normal for the vaccine to take 10-14 days to develop protection, with the first dose providing only 50% immunity. This case highlights the importance of waiting for the full effects of the vaccine.

images.alt_text: A nurse in California tested positive for Covid-19 more than a week after receiving Pfizer's vaccine, an ABC News affiliate reported on Tuesday, but a medical expert said the body needs more time to build up protection.

site_title: EU and China to agree major investment deal
summary: The European Union and China are set to agree on a major investment pact after seven years of negotiations. The Comprehensive Agreement on Investment (CAI) aims to boost ties between the two economies, allowing EU businesses to access China's vast markets. However, concerns remain over Beijing's alleged lack of respect for international labor standards, particularly regarding the treatment of Uighur minorities. The deal is expected to take months to finalize and ratify, potentially upsetting US President-elect Joe Biden's efforts to coordinate with Western allies.

site_title: Fearing Covid-19, Chinese tourists opt for new year close to home
summary: Chinese tourists are opting for domestic travel due to Covid-19 concerns, with many limiting journeys to nearby cities and avoiding leaving their provinces. Hotel bookings for the New Year weekend reached 1.8 times of last year, but most travelers are staying within an hour's train ride from their homes. Around 34 million people will travel by train between Dec 31 and Jan 3, down 6.9% from last year. The Chinese capital has canceled large-scale events and ordered travel agencies to stop selling packages, with many other cities following suit.

site_title: F&B, travel, design, arts insiders look ahead at 2021
summary: Key players in F&B, travel, design, and arts share their outlook for 2021, citing varying trends. Restaurants anticipate strong demand due to travel restrictions, while design focuses on comfort over trends, and travelers seek open spaces. The arts calendar is packed with stage and screen events, with notable exhibitions and shows, such as Iskandar Jalil's works and the Asian Civilisation Museum's Asian artifacts showcase. Young designers also showcase their creations to cope with pandemic reality, highlighting a mix of comfort, sustainability, and entertainment in 2021.

site_title: Singapore air crew to undergo more PCR tests, minimise contact during layovers: CAAS
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has announced tightened measures for Singapore air crew due to two Covid-19 positive cases among personnel of Singapore Airlines. Crew members will undergo more PCR tests and minimize contact with locals during layovers. This follows the positive cases of a cabin crew member on Dec 27 and a pilot on Dec 29. The CAAS aims to ensure the safety of passengers and crew.

images.alt_text: Currently, air crew on layover are required to stay in their crew accommodation at all times and observe strict protocols such as donning masks.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on hopes of vaccine-fuelled recovery
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a vaccine-fuelled recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.26%, the S&P 500 gained 0.25%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.44%. Investors are optimistic about the impact of COVID-19 vaccine rollouts and potential fiscal aid on the economy.

site_title: Mirach Energy fails to procure exit offer, commences winding up
summary: Mirach Energy, a Singapore-listed oil and gas company, has commenced winding up operations as it was unable to secure a reasonable exit offer. The company had been granted a three-month extension to submit an exit-offer proposal, but has now sought further extensions. It is now obtaining quotes from legal advisers and liquidators to proceed with the winding-up process.

site_title: FTSE Russell could delete more Chinese firms after US bolsters executive order
summary: FTSE Russell may delete more Chinese companies from its global benchmarks after the US strengthened an executive order barring US investment in firms with alleged Chinese military backing. The US clarification clarifies the scope of the sanctions, prompting FTSE Russell to review its exclusions. The index publisher has already removed nine Chinese companies and will make a new announcement on January 4, 2021, with additional deletions effective from January 7. MSCI has also removed 10 securities from seven Chinese firms, while S&P DJI will remove 10 Chinese companies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.42 points to 1,644.41 on Wednesday, driven by a higher volume of 7.816 billion lots worth RM3.651 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 656 to 508.

site_title: STI gains 0.74% to close at 2,869.22
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.74% to close at 2,869.22, driven by gains from Wilmar International, Singapore Airlines, and Thai Beverage Public Company. The government's announcement of S$84 million in aid to the aviation sector also contributed to the climb. Asian markets ended mixed, with South Korean shares reaching a record high, while the Nikkei 225 Index closed down 0.45%.

site_title: Singapore must position for success within new global supply chains: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore must position itself strategically within the evolving global supply chains to remain competitive, said Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. Despite securing S$13 billion of fixed asset investment commitments in 2020, Singapore must analyze emerging global value chains to understand its position and position itself in emerging sectors such as fintech and agri-tech. The country must also address domestic inequality and preserve global leadership and governance systems to avoid complacency and stagnation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore kicked off its national Covid-19 vaccination program, with a nurse receiving the first Pfizer-BioNTech jab. Another director of City Developments Limited, Terence Loh, quit citing concerns over the company's Sincere Property Group investment. A Singaporean man, Dickson Yeo, was arrested for spying for China in the US. The city-state also announced a 3.2% electricity tariff cut and a 0.3% gas tariff increase for Q1 2021. The Straits Times Index rose 0.74% to close at 2,869.22.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia launches Myanmar's first credit bureau
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) launched Myanmar's first credit bureau, a 60:40 joint venture with MB Investment. The bureau will support financial institutions and consumers by implementing a credit reporting system to promote responsible lending. It will provide credit monitoring services, risk management, and data analytics reports, aiming to make the lending market more secure and competitive. The bureau will also expand its product offerings to include scores and data analytics reports over the next two years.

site_title: Terence Loh lodges police report on allegedly improper S$5.25m transfers from Giron
summary: Terence Loh Ne-Wei lodged a police report alleging improper transfers of S$5.25 million from Giron's accounts to a relative's bank accounts between April 27 and May 5. Loh, a 36.4% stakeholder in Giron, hired accounting experts after taking over as director in mid-May. The police confirmed a report was lodged, and investigations are ongoing. The alleged transfers occurred during a time when Giron received expressions of interest from potential buyers, and a transaction is hoped to be concluded in the coming weeks.

site_title: Dollar hits two-year lows as traders ignore US stimulus delays
summary: The US dollar hit its lowest in over two years as investors ignored the latest delay in US fiscal stimulus, with the euro and Australian dollar surging instead. The dollar's decline was driven by optimism over a fiscal stimulus deal and expectations of increased global market risk appetite in 2021. Despite a setback in US Senate negotiations, analysts expect the dollar to weaken further in 2021 as President-elect Joe Biden pushes for more economic support.

images.alt_text: The dollar sunk to its lowest in more than two years in Asian trading on Wednesday and riskier currencies surged, as investors looked past the latest delay in US fiscal stimulus and bet that global market risk appetite would increase in 2021.

site_title: Sinopharm's Covid-19 vaccine 79% effective, seeks approval in China
summary: Sinopharm's Covid-19 vaccine showed 79.34% efficacy in Phase III clinical trials, with the company requesting regulatory approval in China. The efficacy rate is lower than previously reported by the United Arab Emirates, and experts warn that piecemeal data could undermine confidence in vaccines. Despite this, China's progress in developing Covid-19 vaccines is seen as positive, with several large supply deals with countries such as Indonesia and Brazil. The vaccine is among the five most advanced candidates from China and has been used in an emergency use program vaccinating hundreds of thousands of people.

site_title: China sentences HK activists to up to three years in jail
summary: China has sentenced 10 Hong Kong activists to between seven months and three years in jail for illegally crossing the border. The group, who had faced charges in Hong Kong over anti-government protests, were held virtually incommunicado in a mainland prison. Eight defendants were found guilty of the illegal crossing, with the others facing additional charges on their return to Hong Kong. Rights groups and relatives criticized the legal process, citing concerns over the defendants' treatment and safety in the mainland prison system.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end at record high, see biggest annual gain since 2009
summary: South Korean shares closed at a record high on December 30, 2020, with the Kospi index rising 1.88% to 2,873.47, driven by gains from Samsung Electronics and other heavyweights. The index posted its biggest annual gain since 2009, with a 30.8% surge. Retail investors poured in 47.5 trillion won, while foreigners were net buyers of 250.3 billion won. The won gained 6.5% against the dollar for the year, its fastest quarterly gain since 2017.

site_title: Apple loses copyright claims against 'virtual iPhone' maker
summary: Apple lost a copyright case against Corellium LLC, a Florida company that makes "virtual iPhones" used by security researchers to test vulnerabilities. A judge ruled that Corellium's product is a new, virtual platform that adds capabilities not available on Apple's iOS devices, allowing it to claim fair use under copyright law. The judge declined to dismiss a separate claim under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, ordering both sides to submit a status report.

site_title: ISD arrests Singaporean who spied for China in US
summary: The Internal Security Department (ISD) of Singapore has arrested Dickson Yeo, a Singaporean, for spying for China in the US. Yeo admitted to working for Chinese intelligence for monetary rewards and revealed previous intelligence taskings targeting other states. The ISD will interview Yeo to establish if he engaged in activities prejudicial to Singapore's security. The government views such actions as a threat to national interests and will deal firmly with individuals involved, according to the ISD. The arrest is under the Internal Security Act.

site_title: 27 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 27 new COVID-19 cases, including one community case, on December 30, 2020. The cases include a pilot and a work pass holder who tested positive for the B117 strain, which is circulating in the UK. The community case is a 46-year-old marine surveyor who works on board vessels. Epidemiological investigations are ongoing, and close contacts have been isolated and placed on quarantine. The number of new cases in the community has remained low, with only two cases in the past week who are currently unlinked.

site_title: Europe: Stocks inch higher as AstraZeneca gains on UK vaccine approval
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by AstraZeneca's 1.3% gain after the UK approved its Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use. The approval, for a two-dose regime, sparked hopes for a strong global economic recovery next year. Most markets were subdued due to thin volumes in a holiday-shortened week.

site_title: Putin targets US social media, secret agent leaks with new laws
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin signed laws allowing the country to restrict US social media giants, label individuals as "foreign agents", and crack down on security officers' personal data. The laws also introduce new restrictions for protests, cap Putin's term limits, and grant former presidents lifelong immunity from prosecution. The moves aim to increase Russia's internet "sovereignty" and fuel fears of creeping China-style controls. The laws include fines of up to 20% of turnover for sites that fail to remove banned content and jail sentences for slander and unauthorized funding of protests.

images.alt_text: President Vladimir Putin signed an array of laws on Wednesday handing Russia new powers to restrict US social media giants, label individuals "foreign agents", and to crack down on the disclosure of its security officers' personal data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks mark 10-month closing high on recovery hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a 10-month closing high on Wednesday, closing 578.62 points or 2.18% higher at 27,147.11. Investors bet on a strong global economic recovery, driven by expectations of continued monetary support. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index rose 2.05%, while the IT sector rose 4.75%. Despite US President Trump's administration strengthening an executive order on Chinese firms, investors shrugged off the move. Global indices, including China's Shanghai Composite and Japan's Nikkei, also closed higher.

site_title: Gold rises as dollar weakens despite delayed US stimulus vote
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,881.62 per ounce as the dollar weakened, despite a delayed US Senate vote on pandemic relief payments. Investors looked past the decision by Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to postpone the vote on increasing Covid-19 relief checks to $2,000. A weaker dollar is seen as a catalyst for gold, which is a hedge against inflation and currency debasement. Analysts predict further upside for gold in 2021, depending on the US inflation outlook and the Biden administration's fiscal stimulus measures.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down but Nikkei posts big 2020 rise
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on December 30, 2020, but the Nikkei index still rose 16% for the year, its highest annual close since 1989. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 27,444.17, down 0.45%, while the Topix index fell 0.80%. The year-end close marked a strong finish to 2020, despite global market volatility.

site_title: Bitcoin hits record US$28,600 as 2020 rally powers on
summary: Bitcoin reached a record US$28,599.99 on December 30, 2020, with a 295% gain for the year. The surge is attributed to increased interest from larger US investors, who view Bitcoin as an inflation-hedging asset and a potential mainstream payment method. Since breaking the US$20,000 mark on December 16, Bitcoin's value has nearly doubled.

site_title: Delhi's clean power goal has a problem: idled fossil-fuel plants
summary: Tata Power Delhi Distribution, a unit of Tata Power, is seeking to renegotiate contracts with fossil-fuel power plants in Delhi to reduce costs and free up funds for clean energy. The company has long-term contracts for nearly 2.4 gigawatts of electricity, which it claims is 20% more than needed, resulting in significant fixed charges paid to idled generation capacity. Tata Power plans to expand its renewable power portfolio, improve reliability of power supplies, and oppose lifetime extensions for ageing plants, aiming to reduce power purchase costs and increase flexibility to invest in renewables.

site_title: Breach of confidentiality
summary: A CFA Institute member, Lynn, a boutique fund management investment officer, breached confidentiality by recommending her client donate $300,000 to a not-for-profit organization, despite the client's anonymity. The breach occurred under the Preservation of Confidentiality Standard, which requires keeping client information confidential unless disclosure is required by law or the client permits it. Lynn should have sought client permission or directed the client to the organization she is treasurer of, and disclosed her position in the organization. This highlights the importance of adhering to confidentiality standards in investment management.

site_title: 2020 wrap: Robinsons, layoffs, Hin Leong were the year's most read stories
summary: The most read stories in The Business Times (BT) in 2020 included the financial woes of corporations such as Robinsons, layoffs in Singapore with over 100,000 job losses projected, and the Hin Leong saga, a debt-hit oil trading company. Other popular stories included working from home expenses qualifying for tax deductions, Singapore's employment and retrenchment matters, and the struggles of startups like honestbee and Home-Fix. These themes were influenced by the global COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on businesses and the economy.

site_title: Singapore to cut household electricity tariff by 3.2%, raise gas tariff in Q1 2021
summary: Singapore's electricity tariff will decrease by 3.2% in the first quarter of 2021, resulting in an average savings of 3.1% in electricity bills for domestic customers. The new tariff rate will be 20.76 cents per kWh, excluding GST, and 22.21 cents per kWh, including GST. Meanwhile, City Gas has raised the gas tariff by 0.04 cents per kWh, citing increased fuel costs. The changes are based on guidelines set by the Energy Market Authority and are effective from January 1 to March 31, 2021.

site_title: How can blockchain and other emerging technologies transform supply chains?
summary: Blockchain technology has the potential to transform global supply chains by streamlining processes, enabling secure data sharing, and reducing operational costs. The technology can address traditional problems in supply chains, such as documentation inefficiencies, counterparty risk, and loss. However, adoption is hindered by technical complexities, financial costs, and regulatory challenges. Despite blockchain fatigue, the technology holds promise in optimizing supply chain operations, enabling data-driven decision-making, and leveraging a single source of truth for fraud mitigation and accountability. Key initiatives, such as TradeTrust and the Singapore Blockchain Innovation Programme, aim to promote interoperability and drive innovation in the sector.

site_title: Indonesia, LG sign US$9.8b electric-vehicle battery MOU
summary: Indonesia and South Korean firm LG have signed a US$9.8 billion electric-vehicle (EV) battery investment deal, making Indonesia the first country to integrate the electric battery industry from mining to producing lithium batteries. The deal includes investments across the EV supply chain, with collaboration from other companies such as Hyundai. The agreement aims to support Indonesia's transition to a low-carbon economy and promote sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and South Korean firm LG have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on a US$9.8 billion electric-vehicle (EV) battery investment deal, the head of Indonesia's Investment Coordinating Board said on Wednesday.

site_title: UK pet owners have bone to pick with post-Brexit travel rules
summary: The UK has ended its participation in the EU passport scheme for cats and dogs, moving to a new category of "Part 2 listed status" under EU pet travel rules. This change requires pet owners to obtain an animal health certificate (AHC) 10 days prior to travel to the EU and Northern Ireland, increasing bureaucracy and costs. Vets and pet owners have expressed concerns, with some predicting fewer trips to Europe and increased hassle for all parties involved. The change affects mainland Britain, while Northern Ireland will remain subject to special rules to maintain a free-flowing border with Ireland.

images.alt_text: Vets, pet owners and others in Britain are bracing for new and potentially costly bureaucracy from Friday, when the UK ends participation in the European Union (EU) passport scheme for cats and dogs.

site_title: CDL director steps down over concerns with Sincere investment
summary: Independent non-executive director Koh Thiam Hock, 70, has stepped down from City Developments Limited (CDL) citing concerns over its investment in Sincere Property Group. This follows a similar resignation by former non-executive director Kwek Leng Peck in October. Carol Fong, group chief executive of CGS-CIMB Securities, has been appointed as CDL's new independent non-executive director. The company has also made changes to its board and committees following Koh's resignation and Fong's appointment.

site_title: Mainland China cash chasing Hong Kong stocks after record year
summary: Mainland China investors have purchased a record HK$661 billion of Hong Kong stocks, the most since 2016, despite Hong Kong's worst stock performance in over two decades. The influx of capital is driven by China's efforts to maintain Hong Kong's status as a key financial hub, with regulators investigating billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Group. Analysts expect Hong Kong's stock market to perform well in 2021, with Morgan Stanley predicting a 30,000-point Hang Seng Index and Credit Suisse Group forecasting strong consumption-driven momentum for China's economy.

site_title: Singapore pledges to renew IMF loan commitments
summary: Singapore has pledged to renew its International Monetary Fund (IMF) loan commitments totaling US$3.58 billion, including a US$1.86 billion loan for 2021-2025 and a US$1.72 billion loan for 2021-2024. The move supports the IMF's efforts to strengthen its capacity to safeguard global economic and financial stability during the COVID-19 pandemic. Singapore's renewal of loan agreements comes as part of the city-state's efforts to support multilateral efforts, with the authority expecting the total BA commitments to reach US$188.8 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks slip on Wednesday morning
summary: Malaysia's stocks slipped 0.2% on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 2.94 points to 1,632.05. The market saw 1.45 billion lots traded worth RM514.5 million, with 359 gainers and 303 losers.

site_title: Proposed change of Eagle Hospitality Trust manager falls through
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust's proposed change of manager fell through after unitholders voted against the appointment of SCCPRE Hospitality Reit Management. The trust, comprising Eagle Hospitality Reit and Eagle Hospitality Business Trust, had convened an extraordinary general meeting to confirm the new Reit manager. The proposed change, including the issuance of new stapled securities and a base fee supplement, was rejected due to lack of support. As a result, the trust will consider available options, but has limited resources to operate as a going concern, according to the trustee.

site_title: ST Index up 8 points following firm overnight gains in NY
summary: The Singapore stock market rose 0.3% or 8 points, finishing at 2,848.14, following overnight gains in the US as investor sentiment surged after the passing of a coronavirus stimulus bill. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.7% and 0.9% respectively, while Asian markets closed mixed. Top advancers included Jardine Strategic Holdings and Jardine Matheson Holdings, while ABR Holdings and glove makers declined.

site_title: Stamford Land to sell Perth commercial development for A$67.8m
summary: STAMFORD Land Corporation is selling its Perth commercial development, Stamford Green, for A$67.8 million. The 14-storey office building and adjacent heritage premises have been vacant since April 2020 due to poor leasing conditions and the Covid-19 pandemic. The sale is subject to foreign investment review board approval and does not require shareholder approval, with Stamford Land planning to reinvest the proceeds into future opportunities.

site_title: Vital for growth measures to include environmental damage
summary: A new index, the Planetary Pressures-Adjusted Human Development Index (PHDI), combines economic growth with environmental and social impacts, providing a more comprehensive measure of a country's well-being. The PHDI's addition of environmental damage to GDP growth highlights the need for countries to balance economic growth with ecological damage. While the PHDI flags personal responsibility in climate change, it falls short of prompting enough action. To combat climate change, countries, especially high-income ones, must reduce their carbon footprints and innovate to slash emissions per dollar GDP.

site_title: China's blue-chip, startup indexes hit over five-year high on growth hopes
summary: China's blue-chip index and startup board ChiNext reached record highs, with the blue-chip CSI300 index rising 1.4% to 5,113.71 points and ChiNext jumping over 3%. Investors anticipate a strong economic recovery in 2021 due to vaccine efforts to contain the coronavirus. Environmental protection shares also surged, with Contemporary Amperex Technology Co jumping 10.4% on production expansion plans. The gains came despite concerns over US investment restrictions and potential deletions from global benchmarks.

site_title: US 20-city home price index posts biggest gain since 2014
summary: US home prices rose 7.95% in October, the largest gain since 2014, driven by ultra-low mortgage rates and increased buyer demand. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index exceeded forecasts, with all 20 cities posting year-over-year gains. The surge in home prices threatens to slow housing momentum, pricing out some buyers, as sales of new and existing homes declined in November. Nationwide home prices increased 8.4% from a year earlier, the largest gain since March 2014.

site_title: The three big mistakes China made in 2020
summary: China made three significant mistakes in 2020, including underestimating the K-shaped economic rebound, muzzling billionaire critics, and mishandling defaults by state-owned enterprises. The country's failure to address income inequality, particularly in the tech sector, and its handling of defaults by SOEs, which allowed them to shield core assets from creditors, are major concerns. Additionally, China's decision to suspend the US$35 billion public listing of billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Group Co. may have put foreign investment at risk.

site_title: Petrobras receives 232.6m reais in Vitol corruption settlement
summary: Brazilian state-run oil company Petrobras received 232.6 million reais (S$59.1 million) in a settlement with Swiss energy trading firm Vitol, as part of a leniency deal with federal prosecutors. This settlement follows a broader corruption probe, Operation Car Wash, which has implicated hundreds of business and government officials. Petrobras has recovered 4.8 billion reais in settlements and compensation related to the investigation. This comes after Vitol's US subsidiary agreed to pay US$164 million to resolve US government probes into alleged bribes in Brazil and other countries.

site_title: Asia: Shares pause recent rally; euro near 2.5-year high
summary: Asian shares retreated on Wednesday as investors cashed in on a recent rally, with the euro near a 2.5-year high due to hopes of a gradual global economic recovery. The euro rose to a high of US$1.2275, while the Australian dollar and Japanese yen were steady against the US dollar. The US dollar struggled, losing 0.29% against a basket of major currencies, and supporting gold prices. Oil prices rebounded overnight, and the US Senate's vote on additional stimulus cheques was delayed, giving investors a reason to take profits.

site_title: HDB to trial smart parking system at Punggol Northshore BTO flats
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) will launch a trial of a smart parking system, Parking@HDB, at Punggol Northshore on January 4, 2021. The system will use cameras to register vehicle plates and provide in-app notifications for parking sessions. Motorists can pay parking fees with credit or debit cards, and the system will automatically deduct charges when vehicles exit. The trial will be expanded to other car parks in the district based on trial results and feedback, with the goal of implementing the smart parking system beyond Punggol Northshore.

site_title: Singapore rolls out Covid-19 vaccination exercise; NCID nurse gets first jab
summary: Singapore has launched its national Covid-19 vaccination program, with a senior NCID nurse, Sarah Lim, receiving the first Pfizer-BioNTech jab. The vaccine rollout is part of the country's efforts to reopen the economy and achieve normalcy. Other healthcare workers and vulnerable individuals are expected to receive the vaccine in the coming months, with Singapore residents aged 70 and older scheduled to start receiving jabs in February next year. The vaccine is seen as an added layer of protection against the virus, bringing relief to healthcare workers and the general public.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on last trading day of year
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on their last trading day of the year, falling 0.24% and 0.59% for the Nikkei 225 and Topix indices, respectively. The decline follows a retreat in US shares from record highs, with investors locking in profits.

site_title: Thailand offers work permits to undocumented migrants to curb Covid-19
summary: Thailand has introduced a two-year work permit program for undocumented migrant workers from Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar, aiming to curb the spread of Covid-19. The program allows approximately 600,000 to 800,000 migrants to register and work legally, with health checks and registration by mid-September. Once the program ends, authorities will crack down on undocumented workers and arrest those who fail to register. The move aims to contain the country's worst Covid-19 outbreak, with over 1,500 cases linked to migrant workers.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler greenlights electric-car production in Poland
summary: Fiat Chrysler has greenlit the production of electric cars at its Tychy plant in southern Poland, with plans to start production by mid-2022. The upgrade will utilize advanced drive systems, including all-electric drive, for Jeep, Fiat, and Alfa Romeo models. The move is part of Poland's efforts to transition away from coal and meet EU zero-net emissions targets. The investment is expected to create new jobs, although details on the value and number of new positions are unclear.

site_title: Muis, SFA looking into allegations over Malaysia cartel's non-halal meat imports, packaging
summary: The Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (Muis) and the Singapore Food Agency (SFA) are investigating allegations of a meat cartel syndicate in Malaysia smuggling and relabeling non-halal meat as "halal-certified" for sale. The agencies are looking into whether this affects the Singapore market, which only allows SFA-accredited overseas establishments to import meat. Muis is writing to Malaysia's relevant authority to request more information, while urging the public to verify information from credible sources and not spread rumors. The investigation aims to ensure halal-certified meat products can be consumed with confidence in Singapore.

site_title: First trans beauty pageant finalist makes history in Nepal
summary: Angel Lama, a 21-year-old trans woman, has made history as the first transgender woman to be a finalist in the Miss Universe Nepal pageant. Nepal is one of only a dozen countries worldwide that accept trans contestants, and this move comes after the pageant's new management relaxed its criteria to include any "bold, beautiful and confident woman" between 18 and 28. Lama's participation is seen as a step towards greater inclusivity in Nepal, a country that has become more accepting of LGBT+ people since the end of a decade-long insurgency in 2006.

site_title: American Airlines restarts US commercial Boeing 737 MAX flights
summary: American Airlines has resumed US commercial Boeing 737 MAX flights for the first time in 20 months, following a safety ban lifted by the Federal Aviation Administration. The airline's first 737 MAX flight departed Miami for LaGuardia Airport, with over half of passengers reportedly hesitant to take the jet due to two fatal crashes. The grounding was lifted after Boeing agreed to software upgrades and new safeguards on a key flight control system. American Airlines is the third carrier globally to resume flights, with the updated 737 MAX having flown about 250 commercial flights since its grounding.

site_title: AirAsia to sell bulk of stake in India operations to Tata Sons
summary: AirAsia Group plans to sell 32.67% of its stake in AirAsia India to Tata Sons for $37.7 million, allowing it to focus on recovery in key South-east Asian markets amid the pandemic's impact on travel. The sale comes after the airline reported its fifth consecutive quarterly loss and shut its operations in Japan. The deal will enable AirAsia to consolidate its presence in South-east Asia and strengthen its foothold in the region. The sale is expected to be completed by March 2021.

site_title: Activist hedge fund Third Point urges Intel to explore deal options
summary: Activist hedge fund Third Point is urging Intel to explore strategic alternatives, including outsourcing chip design and production, to boost its position in the semiconductor market. The fund, led by Daniel Loeb, has amassed a nearly $1 billion stake in Intel and is calling for immediate action to address the company's human capital management issues and declining market share. Intel shares rose 6.1% on the news, and the company has expressed willingness to engage with Third Point on their ideas. The push could lead to significant changes at Intel, including the potential divestment of failed acquisitions and a shift in the company's manufacturing operations.

site_title: Defying Trump, McConnell delays vote on US$2,000 cheques and opposes defence veto
summary: US Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has delayed a vote on President Donald Trump's call to increase Covid-19 relief cheques to $2,000, despite Trump's Twitter attacks on Republican leaders. The Senate will instead examine the issue along with other priorities, and a combined $892 billion bipartisan coronavirus relief package already contains $600 cheques. Democrats believe the stimulus cheque issue could give them an advantage in Georgia runoff elections. The Senate is expected to hold a procedural vote on Trump's veto of a defence Bill, which could lead to the first veto override of his presidency.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 2,849.72, driven by gains in Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. This follows European stocks reaching a 10-month high due to a Brexit trade deal and hopes of a US stimulus package. US stocks, however, ended lower, with the Dow and S&P 500 losing 0.2% each, amid concerns over economic reopening and pandemic aid.

site_title: Keppel Reit manager appoints Shirley Ng as deputy chief executive
summary: Keppel Reit has appointed Shirley Ng as its deputy chief executive officer, effective January 1, 2021. Ng, who is currently head of investments, joined the manager in 2018 and has been instrumental in the Reit's portfolio optimization strategy. This appointment is part of Keppel Corporation's efforts to strengthen its leadership team and succession planning, following a series of leadership changes announced in November. Ng previously worked at Alpha Investment Partners and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, bringing extensive experience in portfolio management and investment acquisitions.

site_title: Moderna in talks with S Korea to supply about 40 million doses of Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Moderna Inc is in talks with South Korea to supply 40 million or more doses of its Covid-19 vaccine, with potential distribution starting in the second quarter of 2021. The South Korean government plans to offer vaccines for 20 million people. This comes as the country speeds up its public vaccination programme following the detection of a virus variant linked to rapid infections in Britain.

site_title: US State Department approves potential sale of 3,000 smart bombs to Saudi Arabia
summary: The US State Department has approved a potential sale of 3,000 precision-guided munitions, valued at up to $290 billion, to Saudi Arabia in the final days of President Donald Trump's term. The sale, which includes 3,000 GBU-39 Small Diameter Bomb I munitions, was approved despite President-elect Joe Biden's pledge to halt arms sales to Saudi Arabia due to the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Yemen. The Pentagon cited the munitions' long-range and accuracy as reasons for the sale, which has not yet been finalized.

site_title: China meat association calls for exporters to disinfect shipments to prevent Covid-19
summary: China's top meat industry group, the China Meat Association, has called for exporters in countries with Covid-19 outbreaks to disinfect shipments before sending them to China. The association recommends disinfecting packaging at the point of origin, rather than in China, to reduce costs and increase efficiency. This comes after China has detected coronavirus on imported meat and packaging, leading to increased costs and trade disruptions. The proposal aims to ensure food safety and boost consumer confidence in imported products.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend year-end rally on Brexit deal boost
summary: European stocks rose to a 10-month high on Tuesday, driven by a Brexit trade deal and hopes of a US stimulus package. The STOXX 600 index gained 0.8% for a fifth consecutive session, with British and Irish stocks leading the way. However, the agreement's details are still unclear, and the pandemic remains a source of uncertainty. US stimulus measures and the launch of an EU vaccination drive also boosted markets.

site_title: Manhattan gentrifier stumbles with rental apartment bankruptcies
summary: A real estate firm, Emerald Equity Group, which focuses on gentrifying neighborhoods, has filed for bankruptcy after its apartment buildings in Manhattan's Upper West Side and Harlem owed $203 million to LoanCore Capital. The firm, led by Isaac Kassirer, had plans to convert the properties into condominiums but was stymied by New York's 2019 rent reform law. The bankruptcies may foreshadow wider distress among multifamily properties in the coming year, particularly in costly markets like New York where new regulations make it harder for landlords to raise rents and evict tenants.

site_title: Lessons learnt in 2020
summary: The article reflects on lessons learned in 2020 for financial planning and wealth management. Key takeaways include protecting income and mitigating risk, focusing on surplus rate to build wealth, and ignoring short-term noise to invest for the long term. The author emphasizes the importance of balancing short-term goals with long-term strategies and having a clear purpose for one's wealth. By prioritizing financial planning and investing for the long term, individuals can achieve financial independence, regardless of their income level.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng wins S$32.9m contract for HDB upgrading projects
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp has won a S$32.9 million contract from the Housing and Development Board to upgrade projects in Singapore. The contract involves designing and building upgrading projects in three precincts, with the first part focusing on design approval and the second part on construction, expected to be completed within 18 months and nine months respectively. The contract is expected to positively impact the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets in 2021.

site_title: White caviar offers an exclusive alternative
summary: White caviar, derived from albino sturgeon, is the most expensive food in the world, fetching over three times the price of black caviar. Due to overfishing and extinction, wild sturgeon populations are dwindling, but fish farms offer a sustainable alternative. Only 40 sturgeon breeders worldwide specialize in albinos, and the high investment and years-long wait for roe production make it a lucrative business. Retail is booming, driven by consumers willing to pay for the unique product, and luxury brands are seeking to capitalize on its exclusivity.

site_title: XRP cryptocurrency tumbles as Coinbase exchange moves to suspend trading
summary: Coinbase, a major US cryptocurrency exchange, announced it will suspend trading in XRP, a cryptocurrency, due to US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) charges against Ripple, an associated blockchain firm. XRP slumped 19% on Tuesday, its lowest since July, after the SEC charged Ripple with a $1.3 billion unregistered securities offering. Ripple has denied the charges, stating XRP is a currency and not an investment contract. The move comes as Coinbase prepares for a stock market listing, making it the first major US crypto exchange to list on the stock market.

site_title: Oil rises on hopes US pandemic stimulus will spur fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 38 cents to $48.00 a barrel, and Brent crude futures up 23 cents to $51.09 a barrel. The increase is attributed to hopes for US pandemic stimulus, which could boost fuel demand and stimulate economic growth. However, concerns over coronavirus lockdowns and a new variant in the UK may cap gains in the short term. Oil prices are expected to gain strength as vaccination programs pick up steam next year and Opec+ is set to boost output in January and February.

site_title: China's record 5G blueprint for 2021 electrifies telecom stocks
summary: China plans to nearly double its 5G wireless capacity in 2021, with 600,000 base stations to be built, accelerating 5G coverage across major cities. This rollout, part of a $1.4 trillion effort, is expected to boost the country's economy and underpin emerging technologies like autonomous vehicles and AI. Telecom stocks such as ZTE and Huawei are expected to benefit, while foreign providers like Ericsson and Nokia may struggle to win contracts. The move is part of Beijing's push for global leadership in key technologies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Singapore Airlines, SATS, JMH, Sembcorp, CapitaLand
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include City Developments Limited (CDL) announcing the resignation of a board member over concerns about its investment in China, while appointing Carol Fong as an independent non-executive director. Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SATS received additional government aid to support the aviation sector, with SIA shares rising 0.5% and SATS shares gaining 1.3%. Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH), Sembcorp Industries, and CapitaLand were among the strongest performers in the Straits Times Index, with JMH gaining 0.6%, Sembcorp rising 1.8%, and CapitaLand increasing 1.2%.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips from record levels, additional stimulus uncertain
summary: US stocks fell from record highs on Tuesday after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blocked a measure to increase pandemic aid checks from $600 to $2,000. The proposal required 60 votes and the backing of 12 Republicans. The US stock market had initially risen to a record high before the blockage, casting uncertainty on the path of economic reopening. The outcome of the proposal remains uncertain, leaving investors worried about the economic stimulus.

site_title: Aviation sector to get S$84 million extra support from Singapore government
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$84 million in additional funding to support the aviation sector, which is expected to recover from the pandemic-induced downturn. The funding will be used to help airlines cover increased operational costs, retrain workers, and invest in productivity. The government will also waive fees for certificates of airworthiness and licence fees for airlines, and offer subsidies for retraining pilots and ground handling services. The support aims to preserve Singapore's aviation hub status and ensure the sector's recovery.

site_title: After property scandal, Pope tightens money controls
summary: Pope Francis has issued a decree tightening Vatican finances after a scandal over a luxury London property deal. The Secretariat of State must relinquish management of funds, investments, and real estate, and submit to supervision by two other economic offices. The decree follows a 2014 investment in a London building that resulted in "enormous losses" and led to the suspension of five Vatican employees. The Pope also transferred control of "Peter's Pence" to the Administration of the Patrimony of the Holy See, aiming to increase transparency and oversight.

site_title: South-east Asian tech M&A may grow, but IPOs a wild card
summary: South-east Asian tech mergers and acquisitions (M&As) may increase in 2021 due to Chinese firms' growth appetite and investor pressure to realize returns. The reported Grab-Gojek merger, valued at US$24 billion, could lead to a public listing, potentially sparking more tech IPOs in the region. However, the outlook for South-east Asian tech IPOs remains uncertain, with observers watching for potential Spac listings from Indonesia's Tokopedia and Traveloka. Industry players expect a resurgence of M&A interest by Chinese companies and a rise in small exits driven by venture funds nearing the end of their 10-year funds.

site_title: Senate GOP faces stimulus dilemma as Democrats side with Trump
summary: Senate Republicans are unlikely to pass a bill increasing stimulus payments to $2,000, despite President Trump's backing, due to concerns over the price tag. The House passed the bill with 44 Republicans supporting it, but Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has not indicated whether the Senate will take up the bill. The move could draw an objection from a Republican, effectively shutting down the effort. The outcome may depend on Trump's actions, with President-elect Joe Biden potentially seeking additional stimulus after being inaugurated on January 20.

site_title: Thailand tightens measures to stem new wave of infections
summary: Thailand has tightened measures to combat a new wave of coronavirus infections, with Bangkok ordering sports and entertainment venues to close from Dec 29 to Jan 4. Other provinces, including Tak, Samut Sakhon, and Rayong, have also imposed restrictions. The country aims to prevent a further flare-up in infections ahead of the New Year holidays.

site_title: Brexit deal offers scant solace to City of London
summary: The UK's trade deal with the EU offers little comfort to the City of London, with EU officials needing to separately confirm that British financial regulations and oversight are strong enough to create a level playing field. The UK's finance industry faces a daily risk of losing business, with bankers and regulators expressing concerns over the long-term impact of Brexit on the sector. The industry's global stature is seen as a key advantage, with many predicting that London will reinvent itself to remain a hub, but uncertainty and complexity remain, with the EU's commitment to the City's status unclear.

images.alt_text: For now, London has hardly been hollowed out and it holds formidable advantages that will take years, if not decades, to erode.

site_title: US detects first case of Covid-19 variant as Biden offers gloomy vaccine outlook
summary: US detects its first case of a highly infectious coronavirus variant in Colorado, amid President-elect Joe Biden's gloomy vaccine outlook. Biden predicts it could take years for most Americans to be vaccinated at current distribution rates, warning of a grim winter. He also calls for increased spending to expedite vaccine distribution, expand testing, and reopen schools. Currently, about 2 million people have been vaccinated, short of the 20 million promised by outgoing President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: The first known US case of a highly infectious coronavirus variant was detected in Colorado on Tuesday as President-elect Joe Biden warned it could take years for most Americans to be vaccinated for the virus at current distribution rates.

site_title: HKEX finding it tough to pick new boss
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) is struggling to find a new CEO after Charles Li steps down on December 31. Despite being credited with internationalizing the exchange and building a bridge to China's markets, Li's outspoken style and failed £29.6 billion bid for the London Stock Exchange have led to a split within the selection committee between candidates with a strong international background and those who can operate with confidence in China. The committee is considering candidates such as Liu Che-Ning and Calvin Tai, with Laura Cha, the current chair, prioritizing candidates who align with her vision of serving Beijing's interests.

images.alt_text: Dubbed "Mr China" for linking the Hong Kong bourse closer to the mainland and helping open doors for foreign investors, Mr Li is a tough act to follow.

site_title: Ant considers holding company that could be regulated more like a bank: sources
summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant, is planning to fold its financial operations into a holding company that could be regulated more like a bank, pending regulatory approval. This move aims to curb its ability to lend and expand, but will still allow it to operate in financial services beyond payments. The company's valuation could be slashed by up to 75% if its non-payment businesses are restructured, and it is seeking guidance from regulators on an acceptable structure.

site_title: Value stocks shine amid recent market rebound: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has highlighted value investing as a significant contributor to the Straits Times Index's (STI) recent rally, with four stocks - Jardine Matheson, Sembcorp, Jardine Strategic, and CapitaLand - ranking highly for value factors. These stocks averaged 26% total returns in the current quarter, outperforming the STI. The recent rotation from healthcare and tech to cyclical sectors has driven the STI's gains, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC being key contributors.

site_title: Singapore's banks need to face digibanks' challenge
summary: Singapore's banks face significant challenges as the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) granted four digital banking licenses to four applicants, including two digital full banks and two digital wholesale banks. This move foreshadows disruption in the banking industry, as existing banks must modernize their customer experience, accelerate their digital strategy, and transform their business with the right technology to stay competitive. The new entrants are adept at using aggregate data, making it imperative for banks to adapt to remain relevant.

site_title: Bridging the distance between Singapore and Poland with a click
summary: Singapore and Poland are strengthening bilateral ties through technology, despite a 9,518km distance between them. In 2020, they issued a Joint Ministerial Statement to enhance economic cooperation and connectivity. Poland's food exports to Singapore doubled, and bilateral trade grew by 7.5%. The two countries are collaborating in fintech, medtech, and agritech, with initiatives such as the European FinTech Hackcelerator and the Asean-Poland MedTech Summit. The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and a shared approach to tackling international challenges also fuel bilateral cooperation.

site_title: Time for the Indian (growth) elephant to start dancing
summary: Deloitte predicts India's GDP to rebound to 11% in fiscal year 2022, after contracting in the previous fiscal year. The consultancy's report suggests that the country's economic growth could be "good, bad and not-so-ugly" due to various scenarios, including strong vaccine availability and declining infections. The economy is expected to reach pre-pandemic levels in early 2023, with growth ranging between 9.5% and 11.7% in fiscal year 2022, depending on the scenario. The report marks a shift away from the traditional "Hindu" rate of growth and the slow-moving "elephant" narrative, as India's economy is expected to become more dynamic and fast-paced.

site_title: Asia-Pacific wealth management a bright spot amid pandemic
summary: The Asia-Pacific wealth management market is expected to outperform other developed markets in terms of assets under management (AUM) growth and profitability, driven by a strong digital presence and increasing demand for sustainable investments. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, private banks in Singapore reported growth in AUM and net new inflows, with some banks experiencing a surge in digital adoption. The region's wealth management industry is expected to continue growing, with inter-generational wealth transfer and sustainable investments driving demand. Key players, including DBS, Credit Suisse, and UBS, are adapting to the pandemic by investing in digital services and ESG solutions.

site_title: Single-owner plots, older CBD office sites in focus as home sales keep pace
summary: Residential property developers in Singapore are focusing on single-owner plots and older central business district offices for strong sales in 2021, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The market is expected to see around 20,000 private residential sales for the full year, with the early part of 2021 showing increased buzz in residential investment activity. This follows a Q3 wave of condo launches, which will test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

site_title: LifeBrandz posts S$6.7m annual loss
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singapore-listed lifestyle investor, reported a net loss of S$6.7 million for the year ended July 31, widening from a net loss of S$3 million a year ago. Revenue fell 39% to S$3.4 million, mainly due to lower revenue from its food and beverage and travel booking services. The company attributed the decline to the closure of Japanese restaurants and global travel shutdowns. LifeBrandz is restructuring debts and negotiating debt deferments, and expects performance to be adversely affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Oil rises on hopes US pandemic stimulus will spur fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose for the third time in four sessions, with Brent crude up 1% to $51.35 a barrel and US WTI crude futures adding 0.9% to $48.03 a barrel, driven by expectations of increased US pandemic stimulus and a final Brexit deal. However, gains were limited by concerns over a new Covid variant and an upcoming Opec meeting. Crude stockpiles are expected to have declined last week, adding support to prices, but a new virus variant in the UK has capped gains and weighed on prices.

site_title: Indonesia secures vaccine deals with Pfizer, AstraZeneca
summary: Indonesia secures vaccine deals with Pfizer and AstraZeneca, with 50 million doses expected to be delivered in the first half of 2021. The country's new health minister, Budi Gunadi Sadikin, announced that 1.3 million front-line health workers will receive priority vaccination, with medical workers and public servants to follow. The strategy aims to reach herd immunity, allowing those aged 18-59 to be protected. Indonesia has secured 329 million vaccine doses, including 50 million from Pfizer and AstraZeneca.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LifeBrandz, a catalist-listed company, has incorporated a wholly-owned subsidiary in Kuala Lumpur to expand its overseas market. The new subsidiary, LB F&B, will trade food & beverage products, restaurants, and offer food delivery services. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured orders for two 24,000 TEU containerships and two 690 forty-foot equivalent unit deck carriers valued at about US$350 million. Envictus International Holdings reported a loss of RM100.9 million for the year ended Sept 30, widening from a loss of RM36.9 million a year ago due to restrictions from the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Singapore, ILO extend agreement to promote decent work in S-E Asia
summary: Singapore and the International Labour Organization (ILO) have extended an agreement until the end of 2021 to promote decent work in South-east Asia, covering areas such as occupational safety and health, social dialogue, and labor practices. The partnership, first signed in 2011, aims to build back better from the COVID-19 pandemic's impact and has supported various technical cooperation activities, including training for labor inspectors and government officials, and study visits on industrial relations and labor market information systems.

site_title: NY bans most evictions as tenants struggle to pay rent
summary: New York has passed a comprehensive anti-eviction law, banning most evictions for at least 60 days. The law protects tenants who have fallen behind on rent due to the pandemic and provides relief for small landlords from foreclosure. The measure comes as the state grapples with high unemployment and a national concern over the fate of millions of people without jobs. Tenants can protect their homes by submitting a document stating financial hardship related to the coronavirus, and the law halts eviction proceedings for existing cases until May 1. Governor Andrew M Cuomo has announced he will sign the bill, which will take effect immediately.

site_title: Is Silicon Valley passe? Not so fast
summary: Silicon Valley's influence is being reevaluated as companies like Oracle and Hewlett Packard Enterprise relocate to Texas and Austin, respectively. Meanwhile, Miami is positioning itself as a potential alternative to the Bay Area, with Mayor Francis Suarez actively courting tech entrepreneurs and investors. The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted traditional patterns of remote work and tech investment, with venture capitalists increasingly considering early-stage deals via Zoom. Despite its reputation for innovation, Silicon Valley faces challenges, including high costs and restrictive immigration policies, which may allow other regions, such as Austin and Miami, to fill the void.

site_title: In the pandemic, US Fed shows its muscle in markets still matters
summary: The US Federal Reserve played a crucial role in stabilizing the economy during the COVID-19 pandemic. In response to the crisis, the Fed took unprecedented measures, including massive bond purchases and loan programs, to restore trust in financial markets. Despite initial concerns, the Fed's balance sheet grew less than expected, and its most controversial lending programs attracted modest interest. The Fed's actions proved that its presence and speed mattered in restoring confidence, even if it couldn't address all economic problems. The crisis highlighted the Fed's evolving role in supporting government borrowing costs and setting a template for future crises.

images.alt_text: While it took the Fed months to flesh out its most innovative responses, the key steps happened with the flip of a switch in March, when its traditional tools were deployed in force.

site_title: Hun Sen hails extraction of Cambodia's 'first drop of oil'
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen announced the extraction of the country's first drop of crude oil from its waters, a milestone after years of stalled production. The oil was taken from an area off the southwestern coast of Sihanoukville, where Chevron first discovered significant reserves in 2005. The government estimates it will receive at least $500 million in royalties and taxes from the project. Hun Sen hailed the extraction as a "new achievement for Cambodia's economy" and dismissed concerns about transparency, calling it a "blessing" for the country.

site_title: Thais dipping into gold savings undermine steps to rein in baht
summary: Thailand's gold sales surged to a record this year amid the pandemic, undermining efforts to rein in the baht. Gold exports jumped to 237.4 tonnes from January to October, the highest since 2010, as households turned to gold as a financial lifeline. This trend risks complicating the government's efforts to tame the baht's rally, which has surged over 9% since April. The central bank has introduced measures to encourage gold trading in foreign currency deposits to shield the baht from price spikes.

images.alt_text: Quick cash from more than 1,800 gold shops across the nation has been one of the most common ways that Thais have weathered the economic downturn.

site_title: Short-term cost spike as foreign workers switch to employers starved of labour
summary: Foreign workers in Singapore are experiencing increased bargaining power due to a labor shortage caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, leading to higher labor costs for employers. However, industry players expect limited long-term impact on foreign worker salaries as labor conditions normalize. The new schemes allow workers on work permits to transfer more easily between employers, causing strain on companies in various industries, including construction.

site_title: Stock-picking hedge funds land investors double-digit gains in 2020
summary: Hedge funds showed mixed performance in 2020, with the average underperforming the S&P 500 index by 6.7 percentage points. However, long-short hedge funds, which take bets on stocks rising and falling, outperformed the broader market with gains of 12% over the period. Many individual firms, such as Marshall Wace and RiverPark Advisors, generated double-digit returns, driven by investments in technology and stay-at-home shares. Despite this, macro hedge funds struggled, with average gains of 1.4% over the same period.

site_title: UK army to help Covid tests as PM faces school pressure
summary: The UK government, under Prime Minister Boris Johnson, is drafting in the armed forces to assist with coronavirus testing in schools ahead of their reopening in England next week. This move comes as pressure builds to delay students' return due to a surge in cases. The government has previously set January 4 as the return date, but unions and scientists are calling for more time to prepare testing systems to prevent infections. The number of new cases in the UK has reached a daily record of over 41,000, with hospitalizations exceeding the peak of the first wave in the spring.

site_title: A 2021 wish list for the market: Looking to progress on key fronts
summary: As 2020 ends, investors in Singapore are hoping for a strong recovery in 2021. Key wishes for the local stock market include effective Covid-19 vaccines and sufficient global vaccination rates to curb the virus's spread. Another wish is for the Singapore Exchange to revisit its upsizing strategy to attract larger companies with higher market capitalization. Additionally, progress on board diversity is desired, with more women holding board seats in top companies. A global debt-fuelled financial crisis is also hoped to be avoided, with concerns over high corporate debt levels and potential chain reactions in markets.

site_title: Hyflux said to have only S$21.5m in cash
summary: Hyflux, Singapore's most high-profile debt-restructuring case, has only about S$21.5 million in cash, enough to last at least 10 months. This marks the second year in which liquidity has more than halved. The company faces about S$2.8 billion in investor claims, with judicial managers in talks with 14 new potential investors, including financial and non-financial companies. A court-supervised process began in May 2018, and the company's once corporate highflyer status has been severely impacted.

site_title: No, you did not miss a bull run
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index has surpassed the 2,800 mark, rallying by over 27% from its March bottom, suggesting a potential bull run. Despite historical declines, volatility is a normal part of investing, and timing entry points may not be as crucial as the underlying business performance. Investors should focus on buying great companies with strong management, rather than trying to time the market. Historically, declines of 30% or more are rare, and the quality of a business is a more significant factor in generating great returns than getting entry points correct.

site_title: Bid farewell to 2020, but remember the seafarers
summary: The shipping industry successfully transitioned to low-sulphur fuel in 2020, with few major issues. The "big switch" to the 0.50% sulphur regulation was relatively trouble-free, with compliant fuel widely available. However, some regulatory and technical challenges arose, including wax formation and increased cylinder wear. In contrast, the industry was unprepared for the COVID-19 pandemic, which had a significant impact on global trade and commerce. Despite this, the shipping industry demonstrated its resilience and adaptability in navigating the challenges of 2020.

site_title: EU to buy extra 100 million doses of Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine
summary: The European Union will purchase an additional 100 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, bringing the total to 300 million doses, according to European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. The decision was made after the vaccine was assessed as safe and effective. The EU aims to vaccinate its population with the vaccine, which is currently being used across the bloc.

site_title: EHT rejects Lendco's allegations of false disclosures and bad faith conduct
summary: EHT rejects allegations by Lodging USA Lendco and Claydon Hill Investments of false disclosures and bad faith conduct, stating the allegations are without merit. EHT's managers and trustee claim they have no record of any alleged notice of default on the US$89 million unsecured loan, and the proposed bridge facility does not require Lendco's consent. EHT is also assessing implications of a lender's application to appoint a receiver for a mortgage loan related to a Hilton hotel and evaluating a private arbitration request from master lessees of California-based properties.

site_title: Airbus nears 550 deliveries in year derailed by Covid-19
summary: Airbus has delivered nearly 550 aircraft in 2020, surpassing its initial forecast of 880 deliveries due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The European planemaker is nearing the milestone after 477 deliveries through November. Despite the pandemic's impact, Airbus remains ahead of Boeing, which delivered 118 aircraft by the end of November. The company's efforts to preserve orders and adjust delivery schedules have contributed to its success. Airbus is expected to retain its title as the world's largest planemaker for a second year.

site_title: EU chiefs to sign Brexit trade deal Wednesday
summary: EU chiefs Ursula von der Leyen and Charles Michel will sign the post-Brexit trade deal with Britain on Wednesday at 0830 GMT. The agreement is expected to be taken to London, where UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will add his signature. The deal marks a significant development in the UK's transition out of the EU following Brexit.

site_title: Shiseido primps for expansion in South-east Asia
summary: Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics and skincare group, is expanding in South-east Asia, where shoppers now account for one-third of its Asia-Pacific net sales. The company's APAC chief sees huge opportunities in the emerging middle class of the Asean region, predicting a potential increase to two-fifths of sales in the next five to eight years. Shiseido plans to introduce new brands and expand sales channels to capitalize on rising affluence in the region.

site_title: Cardin, father of fashion branding, dies at 98
summary: Pierre Cardin, a renowned fashion designer and entrepreneur, died at 98. He built his business empire by selling designer clothes to the masses and exploiting the name as a brand for various products. Cardin was the first to sell clothes collections in department stores and enter the licensing business for perfumes, accessories, and food. His name has been stamped on numerous products, from luxury items to tacky accessories, earning him both admiration and criticism for destroying the value of luxury brands.

site_title: Asia on course to soon overtake the US on ESG adoption
summary: Asia is rapidly adopting Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) practices, potentially surpassing the US in ESG adoption. This shift is driven by Asian investors' pragmatic approach, recognizing ESG as essential for long-term financial success and sustainability.
