site_title: Signalling fault hits Downtown Line during evening peak hours: SBS Transit
summary: A signalling fault on the Downtown Line in Singapore has caused a 20-minute delay for commuters, affecting the journey between Expo and Geylang Bahru stations. The fault was first announced by SBS Transit at 6:50pm on Monday, with some commuters reporting longer delays and stuck trains. This is the second major signalling fault on an MRT line this month, following a five-hour disruption on the Thomson-East Coast Line. The Land Transport Authority has not commented on the cause of the fault.

site_title: Will 2021 be gold for yellow metal, oil, base metals?
summary: Commodity prices are expected to rise in 2021, driven by a global recovery, vaccination efforts, and a weakening US dollar. Analysts predict a strong rally for gold, with prices potentially reaching $2,110 an ounce, while oil prices are expected to surge past $50 a barrel, with Brent reaching $55 a barrel next year. Base metals, such as iron ore and copper, are also expected to increase due to China's post-Covid-19 stimulus plan. However, analysts note that the trajectory for these commodities will not be linear and that potential dampeners include Covid-19 lockdowns and weak supply dynamics.

images.alt_text: After a destructive year, analysts think the good times will roll in 2021 for commodities - from oil and gold to silver and iron ore.

site_title: Alibaba's US$10b buyback plan fails to halt stock slide
summary: Alibaba's US$10 billion buyback plan failed to halt the stock slide of its Hong Kong-listed shares, which plummeted 9% to their lowest since June. The sharp sell-off, over two sessions, wiped out almost US$116 billion in value. The decline intensified after Chinese regulators announced an antitrust investigation into Alibaba and summoned its Ant Group affiliate to meet, amid concerns about regulatory crackdowns on co-founder Jack Ma's e-commerce and financial empire. The stock's value has dropped significantly following the announcement.

site_title: Goldman's Sheila Patel, chairman of US$1.8t asset-management unit to retire
summary: Sheila Patel, chairman of Goldman Sachs' $1.8 trillion asset-management unit, is retiring after nearly two decades at the firm. Patel, one of the company's most senior women, will step down from the partnership and become an advisory director in the new year. She was named partner in 2006 and has overseen the firm's environmental, social, and governance and impact investing efforts. Patel's successor has not been named.

site_title: What lifted Trump could sink Biden
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic policies, particularly his tax cuts and focus on a high-pressure economy, contributed to the growth of wages for typical American households. During his presidency, wages in the US grew faster than at any other time since Bill Clinton's presidency. If the economy fails to deliver similar wage increases in the next four years, Trump voters may turn to him or other Trumpian Republicans in the 2024 election. Conversely, a return to austerity policies could harm economic growth and lead to higher unemployment, benefiting Trump's opponents.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits record high after Trump signs fiscal package
summary: US stocks hit record highs after President Donald Trump signed a $2.3 trillion pandemic aid bill. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 83.4 points, the S&P 500 rose 20.0 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 109.9 points. The signing bolstered economic recovery bets, particularly for financial and energy stocks.

site_title: Elections Department to operate from new site in Novena Rise from Jan 4
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) in Singapore will relocate from its current Prinsep Street building to Novena Rise, effective January 4. The new site, formerly a school, will house the ELD's corporate office and training centre. Operations at both locations will cease with the move, marking the end of the ELD's presence at Prinsep Street.

site_title: Duterte approves record Philippine budget for pandemic recovery
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte approved a record 4.5 trillion-peso (S$124.5 billion) budget for 2021, the "heftiest stimulus package" to recover from the pandemic. The budget aims to boost economic growth, with an expected 7.5% growth rate in 2021. The government has allocated 72.5 billion pesos for vaccine purchases. The budget deficit ceiling was raised to 8.9% of GDP due to increased spending.

site_title: Lawyers who go beyond just law could create a post-pandemic paradigm
summary: Lawyers who focus on strategic work and business guidance are more effective than those who only focus on legal issues. A recent survey found that 8% of General Counsel (GCs) perform a truly "executive" role, with an 83% ability to influence CEOs, compared to 43% of "legal-only" GCs. To transition into a business leader role, GCs must shift from a risk management mindset to providing strategic and practical insights that are valued in corporate decision-making. This shift requires a change in mindset and careful consideration of time and resource allocation, with opportunities to empower legal team members and adopt technology to free up time for strategic work.

site_title: Lockheed Martin misses F-35 jet delivery target due to Covid-19
summary: Lockheed Martin missed its 2020 F-35 jet delivery target, delivering only 123 aircraft instead of the 141 target, due to the Covid-19 pandemic disrupting its supply chain and factories. The company had revised its target down to 117-123 aircraft in May 2020 due to parts shortages. The underperformance comes as the company built 8% fewer jets than planned, highlighting the challenges faced by the defense industry during the pandemic.

site_title: Leader Environmental Technologies appoints new chief executive
summary: Leader Environmental Technologies has appointed environmental scientist Lin Yucheng as CEO and executive chairman, effective January 1. Lin, who founded Citic Envirotech in 2003, will replace current executive chairman and CEO Lin Baiyin. The appointment aims to bring new leadership to the company. Following the change, LET shares gained 4.4% to close at S$0.048 on Monday.

site_title: EU-UK trade deal gets nod from bloc's top envoys in Brussels
summary: EU ambassadors have unanimously approved the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement, paving the way for its provisional application on January 1, 2021. The deal prevents tariffs on two-way goods trade and marks Britain's departure from the European single market. The agreement is expected to enter into force provisionally once the UK's post-Brexit transition ends on Thursday. The European Parliament will review the accord during its first two months of the new year, while the UK House of Commons will vote on December 30.

site_title: Ex-minister dies of Covid-19 as Japan shuts out foreigners
summary: A 53-year-old former Japanese minister, Yuichiro Hata, died of Covid-19, becoming the first incumbent lawmaker to succumb to the disease in Japan. The country has started banning non-resident foreign nationals from entering due to a new, highly infectious coronavirus variant linked to a rapid rise in infections in Britain. Japan is facing a third wave of infections, with daily cases hitting a record 3,881, and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga urged calm ahead of the New Year holidays. The government has instructed ministers to remain alert and carry out counter measures.

site_title: Delivery Hero to sell S Korean unit to get nod for US$4b Woowa deal
summary: Germany's Delivery Hero will sell its South Korean food delivery app Yogiyo to gain regulatory approval for its $4 billion takeover of Woowa Brothers. The sale is part of conditions set by the Korea Fair Trade Commission, which requires Delivery Hero to sell Yogiyo in six months. The deal clears a major hurdle for Delivery Hero to gain a dominant position in South Korea's online food delivery market, which is expected to grow to $15.4 billion this year. The sale is seen as a way to ease concerns about increased competition and higher prices for diners.

site_title: US authorises sanctions on China for Dalai Lama meddling
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed a law authorizing sanctions on Chinese officials who interfere in the selection of the next Dalai Lama. The Tibetan Policy and Support Act was passed by Congress amid concerns that Beijing will attempt to control the spiritual leader's succession. China has called the law "grossly interferes in China's internal affairs." The move is seen as a response to Beijing's efforts to influence the Tibetan Buddhist community, which is seeking greater freedoms in the Chinese-ruled Himalayan region.

site_title: Malaysia extends virus curbs by two weeks as cases stay elevated
summary: Malaysia extended its conditional movement control order by two weeks until January 14 to contain the spread of coronavirus infections. The decision comes after the country surpassed 100,000 cases and recorded a record 2,235 daily cases on Saturday. The government is struggling to stem a fresh wave, and if violations are widespread, further tightening of standard operating procedures may be considered. The nation added 1,594 new Covid cases on Monday, with borders remaining closed to foreign tourists.

site_title: Capacity restrictions for employer-provided transportation ease in Phase 3
summary: Singapore's Phase 3 has begun, easing capacity restrictions for employer-provided transportation. Starting Dec 28, 2020, the 25% reduction in maximum passenger capacity (MPC) for private buses, vans, and lorries will no longer apply. Employers must ensure workers adhere to existing safety measures, including wearing masks and avoiding interaction, and arrange private transportation for dormitory workers. The measures aim to prevent cross-infections between migrant workers and the community.

site_title: Goldman invests in Echelon in bet on at-home fitness amid Covid-19
summary: Goldman Sachs led a $65 million financing in Echelon Fitness, a Chattanooga-based company producing at-home exercise machines, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Echelon competes with companies like Peloton Interactive, offering technology-enabled treadmills, rowers, and bikes at lower prices. Its entry-level bike was priced at $500, while its top-of-the-line retailed for $1,600, compared to Peloton's $1,895. The investment gives Goldman a controlling stake in the company.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs is leading a US$65 million financing in Echelon Fitness, giving the bank and another investor a controlling stake in a maker of exercise machines as more people work out at home amid the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower, dragged down by tech stocks
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined on Monday, falling 0.3% to 26,314.63, due to a 4.3% drop in the tech index and 5.9% decline in the IT index. Regulatory concerns following China's central bank's call for an overhaul at Ant Group, and China's data curbing losses, weighed on the market. Shares in tech firms like Alibaba Group Holding dropped 8% for the sixth consecutive session, with analysts warning that shares in new economy companies may stay under pressure.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip on Monday, STI down 0.1% at 2,840.14
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.1% to 2,840.14 on Monday, despite a 0.2% gain in the KLCI and a 0.7% rise in the Nikkei 225. The decline was attributed to lower-than-usual liquidity and minimal news over the weekend. However, US President Donald Trump's signing of the Covid-19 pandemic relief and spending bill lifted sentiment in Asia, with the Hang Seng Index closing 0.3% lower. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the biggest gainer, while Hongkong Land was the largest decliner.

site_title: Thailand to see modest growth in 2021; tourism to remain flat
summary: Thailand is expected to see modest economic growth of 4% in 2021, driven by a shrinking 6.8% GDP in 2020. International tourism is forecast to remain flat, with estimated revenues of $10.2 billion, equivalent to 2.1% of GDP. The availability of vaccines could boost tourism confidence in the second half of the year, with Citi economists predicting tourist arrivals will gradually return beyond 2021.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.73 points to 1,643.90. The index saw a high volume of 8.71 billion lots worth RM3.903 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 701 to 549, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: First Reit announces a proposed rights issue at S$0.20 per unit to raise S$158.2m. Chaly Mah is appointed as the new chairman of Surbana Jurong. Capacity restrictions for employer-provided transportation in Phase 3 will be lifted, starting from Dec 28. A digital-economy pact between Singapore and New Zealand will take effect on Jan 7. Heritas Capital plans to launch a US$30m impact investing fund. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 2,840.14.

site_title: Ant turning from windfall to nightmare for global investors
summary: China has ordered Ant Group, a fintech company led by billionaire Jack Ma, to re-examine its businesses and return to its roots as a payments service, amid concerns over sub-par corporate governance and regulatory arbitrage. The central bank has demanded Ant set up a separate financial holding company, increase risk controls, and halt operations in units that service half a billion people if it fails to comply. The move could cap Ant's growth potential and limit its lucrative operations, potentially leading to a breakup of the company, although regulators have stopped short of making this move.

images.alt_text: The government could ask Ant to spin off its more lucrative operations in wealth management, credit lending and insurance.

site_title: Europe: Shares jump on US stimulus aid support, Brexit deal relief
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Monday after the UK and EU signed a trade deal, while a $2.3 trillion US stimulus package boosted investor sentiment. Britain's exit from the EU's single market was delayed due to the trade deal. The European stock index also gained as the continent's vaccination program was launched, fueling hopes for a pandemic-free second half of 2021. US stocks edged down despite the stimulus package, with investors focusing on US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Philippine troops, ministers get Covid-19 vaccine before approval
summary: Philippine troops and Cabinet ministers have received COVID-19 vaccine injections before regulatory approval, despite health ministry warnings that vaccines must be evaluated by experts and deemed safe. Interior Minister Eduardo Ano and Army Chief Cirilito Sobejana confirmed the vaccinations, but did not disclose the vaccine brand. The health ministry stated that only approved vaccines should be administered, raising concerns about safety and efficacy.

site_title: Heritas Capital to launch US$30m 'impact investing' venture fund by H12021
summary: Heritas Capital, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, plans to launch a US$30 million "impact investing" fund focused on early-stage technology startups in healthcare, education, and food industries. The fund aims to invest up to US$3 million in startups with significant social and environmental benefits. The firm's first private equity fund, Heritas Growth Fund III, will also be launched with a US$150 million target, investing in growth-stage startups in the same sectors. The decision to launch impact investing funds comes as investors increasingly prioritize responsible investments and social impact.

site_title: China ramps up virus controls to head off winter wave
summary: China has intensified health checks to prevent a coronavirus resurgence, with temperature checks, airport inspections, and neighborhood screenings implemented across Beijing. The country reported 21 new cases, mostly imported, and maintains a national death toll of 4,634. Authorities have also checked health data on QR codes of visitors to Beijing hospitals. These measures come as experts warn of a potential new variant that could be more transmissible.

site_title: Rosneft buys huge oilfield in Russian Arctic
summary: Russia's Rosneft has acquired the rights to the Payakha oilfield in the Arctic, as part of its plans to utilize the Northern Sea Route for oil and product shipping. The deal was made with Taymyrneftegaz, a company controlled by Rosneft's ex-CEO Eduard Khudainatov. Details of the acquisition's value were not disclosed. This move is part of Rosneft's efforts to expand its presence in the Arctic region and diversify its oil production sources.

images.alt_text: Russia's Rosneft said on Monday it had bought the rights to a huge oilfield in the Taymyr peninsula in the Arctic, as it presses ahead with plans to use the Northern Sea Route to ship oil and products.

site_title: German politicians reject swift easing as deaths top 30,000
summary: German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer and state premier Manuela Schwesig have rejected swift easing of coronavirus restrictions, citing a death toll over 30,000 and rising cases since October. The government has imposed a nationwide lockdown until January 10, with schools and non-essential stores shuttered. Officials warn that a "third wave" must be avoided and expect measures to be extended, with vaccinations expected to have a limited impact on the disease's spread in months to come.

site_title: South Africa mulls alcohol ban revisit as virus cases surge
summary: South Africa is considering reinstating a total ban on liquor sales amid a surge in Covid-19 cases during the summer holiday season. The ban, which could start on Tuesday and last through Jan 10, aims to lower hospital admissions from accidents and violence. The initial ban in March led to lost tax revenue and job losses in the liquor industry. A final decision has not been made, but the move is seen as a measure to control the spread of the virus.

site_title: Sole community case is a cabin crew with SIA and part-time Grab driver
summary: A Singapore Airlines cabin crew member, who is also a part-time Grab driver, tested positive for Covid-19, marking the community's first case on December 28. The 48-year-old man, who recently traveled to the US, is asymptomatic and had been isolated while awaiting further tests. His close contacts, including family members and co-workers, have been isolated and tested, with the remaining contacts to be tested upon release from quarantine. This case is considered locally transmitted due to the long time interval between travel and test result.

images.alt_text: Singapore reported five new Covid-19 cases, comprising one in the community and four that are imported, on Dec 28, 2020.

site_title: 'Demon Slayer' becomes Japan's top-grossing movie
summary: "Demon Slayer" becomes Japan's top-grossing movie, surpassing the nearly two-decade record held by "Spirited Away". The film, based on a popular manga and anime series, took in 32.47 billion yen, surpassing "Spirited Away"'s 31.68 billion yen. The film's success was boosted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with people turning to the series while stuck at home. The film's merchandise has also generated significant revenue, with at least 270 billion yen in sales as of December 3.

site_title: Chaly Mah to succeed Surbana Jurong's Liew Mun Leong
summary: Surbana Jurong appoints Chaly Mah Chee Kheong as its new chairman, succeeding Liew Mun Leong, effective January 1, 2021. Mah brings extensive board and leadership experience, having served as chairman of multiple organizations, including the Singapore Tourism Board and Singapore Land Authority. He replaces Liew, who resigned in September 2020 following the acquittal of his former domestic helper. The company expects Mah to leverage his experience to advance the group into a leading global player, anchored on sustainability and technology.

site_title: Thailand confirms 144 new coronavirus infections
summary: Thailand confirmed 144 new coronavirus cases on Monday, with 129 local infections and 15 imported cases. This brings the country's total cases to 6,285 and deaths to 60 since the first case in late January.

site_title: Alibaba antitrust fears worsen China tech giants selloff
summary: China's tech giants, led by Alibaba, are experiencing a selloff amid concerns that antitrust scrutiny will spread beyond Alibaba's Internet empire and affect other powerful corporations. Alibaba raised a proposed stock repurchase program by $4 billion to $10 billion, but its shares slid 5% in Hong Kong to a six-month low. The company has lost over $230 billion from its peak due to deepening antitrust scrutiny and allegations of monopolistic practices. Other Chinese tech giants, such as Tencent and JD.com, also fell, with investors fearing the antitrust net may widen further.

site_title: Masked and muted Olympics will still dominate crowded 2021 in sports
summary: The 2021 Tokyo Olympics, rescheduled from 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, will be the centerpiece of a crowded sporting year despite increased costs and uncertainty. Organizers face challenges in allowing foreign visitors and implementing safety measures, while athletes will be required to follow strict protocols. Other sports, such as the NBA, have adjusted their schedules to minimize overlaps with the Olympics. The Games are expected to be held with reduced festivities and a focus on containing costs, with a possible invitation to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and discussions on opposition to racism.

site_title: The craziest cruise ship coming in 2021 has a roller coaster
summary: A cruise ship, Mardi Gras, set by Carnival Cruise Lines, is ready to sail with a world-first roller coaster and a brewery producing craft beers with filtered sea water. The ship's debut is planned for April, but CDC no-sail orders and certifications may delay its operations. Persistent border closures and confirmed Covid-19 cases on ships have also raised concerns. The CDC will require test cruises to prove pandemic readiness before allowing ships to resume operations, casting doubt on the ship's April debut.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at record high on Samsung rally, US stimulus
summary: South Korean shares closed at a record high on Monday, driven by Samsung Electronics' rally, as US President Donald Trump signed a $2.3 trillion pandemic aid and spending package, offsetting pandemic-related worries. The Kospi index rose 1.74 points, or 0.06%, to 2,808.60, marking a third consecutive gain. The US aid package restored unemployment benefits and avoided a federal government shutdown, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: 10 from Hong Kong face charges in Chinese court amid tight security
summary: Hong Kong nationals, aged 16-52, face charges in a Chinese court for alleged involvement in anti-government protests. The 12 individuals were detained at sea on August 23 and held virtually incommunicado since. They were intercepted en route to Taiwan after their boat was intercepted. The charges include illegal border crossing. The case has raised concerns about the treatment of Hong Kong residents by mainland Chinese authorities.

site_title: Thousands without power, planes delayed as storm Bella lashes France
summary: Storm Bella has caused widespread disruptions in France, leaving thousands without power, with 12,000 households affected in Brittany and Normandy, and 6,000 in the Calais region. Flights from Paris Charles de Gaulle airport were delayed or re-routed, with three flights heading to the airport diverted to Paris Orly airport. The storm's impact also extended to Wales, where 20,000 households lost electricity, and England, where strong winds caused delays on railways. The winds and rains are expected to subside in some areas, but heavy showers are forecast for higher ground in southern France.

site_title: Russian sustainability scores rise, but climate goal still lags
summary: Russia's sustainability scores for major companies like Novatek PJSC and Polyus PJSC have improved, but the country's overall climate goal remains unmet. Despite high ESG scores, ambitious growth plans will lead to increased greenhouse gas emissions over the next decade. This disconnect highlights challenges investors face in evaluating environmental performance. As impact investments surge, assets in these funds reached $715 billion at the end of 2020, up from $8 billion in 2012.

site_title: Oil steadies with virus pessimism balanced by US stimulus
summary: Oil prices steadied in Asian trading, finishing near $48 a barrel, after posting its first weekly loss since October due to concerns over a new strain of Covid-19. However, optimism over a US stimulus bill, which boosted energy demand, countered the pessimism. The Opec+ alliance plans to return 500,000 barrels a day of output in January, further supporting oil prices. Despite this, economists predict a somber end to the year due to travel restrictions and a post-Christmas surge of infections.

site_title: Gig economy workers say they can no longer survive
summary: Gig economy workers worldwide are struggling to survive due to meager earnings and lack of job security. Deliveroo, Uber Eats, and other platforms use algorithms to determine earnings, often leaving drivers with minimal income. Drivers report feeling exploited and criticizing the "flexibility" offered by these jobs, which they say is actually on-demand work with little flexibility. Many drivers, such as Wissem Inal and Erica Mighetto, are forced to juggle multiple platforms to make a living, while others, like Amal Fahmi, are struggling to find stable work.

site_title: Bitcoin on longest winning run since 2019 after hitting record
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of $28,365 on Sunday, marking its longest monthly winning streak since 2019. The cryptocurrency has advanced 280% this year, with investors attributing its surge to a hedge against dollar weakness and inflation. However, regulatory scrutiny, including the SEC's accusation against Ripple Labs, may impact investor confidence. Experts predict a potential pullback, with Vijay Ayyar estimating a 10-15% drop, but also foreseeing a potential price surge to $30,000.

site_title: Drugmakers cut prices in half to secure access to China market
summary: Drugmakers AstraZeneca and GlaxoSmithKline have agreed to cut the prices of their innovative drugs in China by an average of 50.6% to gain access to the country's national insurance fund. This move comes after negotiations with the National Healthcare Security Administration, which added 119 new therapies to the list, including treatments for cancer, diabetes, and pulmonary diseases. The list, effective March 1, will cover 2,800 medications, with patients only paying a small fraction of the cost, as the majority will be covered by China's 2.44 trillion yuan national medical insurance fund.

site_title: Courts summoned to rule on climate change
summary: Citizens worldwide are filing lawsuits against governments and big polluters over climate change, with over 1,700 cases filed globally, including 1,300 in the US. While some cases aim to force governments to take action, others seek compensation and changes in practices from polluting companies. Courts have ruled in some cases, such as the Dutch Supreme Court ordering the state to slash greenhouse gas emissions, but many others have resulted in losses. The lawsuits invoke human rights, particularly the right to life, and are becoming increasingly sophisticated in attributing cause and effect on a planetary scale.

site_title: UK poised to clear Astra shot as need for vaccines grows
summary: The UK is poised to approve the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine, which could be rolled out across Britain from January 4, providing a powerful tool to fight the pandemic. The vaccine, developed with the University of Oxford, has been shown to be comparable in effectiveness to other vaccines, with CEO Pascal Soriot stating it could achieve a 95% effectiveness rate after two doses. The approval would come as the UK struggles with rising infections, with virus cases surging and the government tightening lockdowns across the country.

images.alt_text: The UK is poised to approve the Covid-19 vaccine produced by AstraZeneca Plc and the University of Oxford, giving the country another powerful tool to fight the pandemic as concern mounts over rising infections.

site_title: British tourists sneak out of Swiss ski resort
summary: Hundreds of British tourists at the Swiss ski resort of Verbier fled in the night after being forced into quarantine due to a Covid-19 variant in England. Around 200 of the 420 tourists quit under the cover of darkness, while the rest remained in the resort. The flight ban, combined with other travel restrictions, led to a significant decline in tourist numbers. The incident highlights the challenges faced by ski resorts in the Swiss Alps due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: First Reit, BRC Asia, Hong Lai Huat, Pan Ocean
summary: First Reit to raise S$158.2 million through renounceable rights issue. BRC Asia CEO sees expansion opportunities in 2021 or 2022, while Hong Lai Huat repays debt using rights issue proceeds. Pan Ocean invests S$246.5 million in shipbuilding contract for LNG carrier.

site_title: First Reit announces proposed rights issue at S$0.20 per unit to raise S$158.2m
summary: First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) has announced a proposed rights issue to raise approximately S$158.2 million, which is critical to meet debt covenants and avoid an imminent default. The issue will involve issuing around 791.1 million units at a discount of around 50.6% to the closing price. The proposal is conditional on the approval of two resolutions at an extraordinary general meeting, including a master lease agreement restructuring and a waiver of unitholders' rights to receive a general offer for their units.

site_title: Once a billionaire factory, South Korea's beauty industry turns ugly
summary: South Korea's beauty industry, once a lucrative market that turned billionaires, is experiencing a downturn. Amorepacific Group, once a US$8 billion fortune, has seen its shares fall 40% and its consolidated revenue drop 23% due to the pandemic. The shift to online shopping and lifestyle changes have reduced demand for cosmetics, with beauty retail sales in the US expected to drop over 7% in 2020. As a result, billionaires like Suh Kyung-bae have seen their fortunes decline, while new billionaires are emerging, such as Seo Jung-jin, founder of pharmaceutical firm Celltrion.

images.alt_text: Social distancing and remote work have lessened demand for makeup and led to store closures. Beauty retail sales in the US, the No. 3 market for Korean exports, will be down more than 7 per cent in 2020, according to market research firm Mintel.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US relief bill
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.74% to 26,854.03, driven by positive sentiment over the US coronavirus relief bill. The Topix index also increased 0.54%. However, investors remain cautious due to Japan's detection of the new Covid-19 strain. The US relief bill provided a boost to markets globally.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday on positive sentiment over the US coronavirus relief bill, but investors remain cautious after Japan detected cases of the new strain of Covid-19.

site_title: South Korea says Delivery Hero must sell unit for US$4b Woowa deal approval
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator, the Korea Fair Trade Commission (KFTC), has ordered Delivery Hero to sell its South Korean subsidiary, Woowa, to win approval for its $4 billion takeover of Woowa Brothers. The deal would have given Delivery Hero a near monopoly in the country's food delivery market, with a combined market share of 97% of food delivery transactions. The KFTC fears a decrease in consumer benefits and a rise in restaurant fees, prompting the sale of Woowa's Korean unit.

site_title: With just days to go, Britain urges business to prepare for end of Brexit transition
summary: Britain urges businesses to prepare for the end of the Brexit transition period, set to end on December 31, as a trade deal with the EU preserves zero-tariff and zero-quota access to the single market. The deal, finalized on Thursday, requires businesses to adjust to new rules on importing and exporting goods, customs declarations, and trade with Northern Ireland. With less than a week to prepare, the government warns of practical and procedural changes that businesses and citizens must get ready for, despite the deal offering both challenge and opportunity.

site_title: Gold gains 1% as Trump signs stimulus bill
summary: Gold prices rose 1% to $1,895.03 per ounce after US President Donald Trump signed a $2.3 trillion pandemic aid and spending package, boosting its appeal as an inflation hedge. The signing also bolstered gold's appeal to other currency holders as the dollar edged lower against a basket of currencies. This marks the metal's 24th% gain this year. Silver, platinum, and palladium also saw gains, with silver rising 3% and platinum climbing 1.7%.

site_title: Japan a hard sell for bankers when taxman can take half
summary: Japan's efforts to become a more attractive financial hub are hindered by its high tax burden, with finance professionals potentially losing up to half their earnings to the government. Despite lower living costs, such as rent and food prices, the tax burden erases these savings, making it difficult for high-earners to consider relocation. Japan is introducing tax breaks, including exemptions for inheritance taxes and changes to capital gains treatment, but it remains to be seen if these measures will generate significant business for the country.

images.alt_text: Japan's push to make itself a more attractive financial hub faces a taxing problem if it is to stop the drip-drip departure of finance professionals to other cities in Asia.

site_title: Sydney told to watch its famous New Year's Eve fireworks from home
summary: Sydney, Australia has banned large gatherings for New Year's Eve due to a mid-December Covid-19 resurgence, with 125 cases reported in the northern beach suburbs. The New South Wales Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, has limited outdoor gatherings to 50 people and restricted downtown events, with only residents with hospitality venue permits allowed. Households are also limited to hosting 10 people. The move aims to prevent "super-spreading events" and keep the city safe.

site_title: Britain to restrict promotion of unhealthy food from April 2022
summary: Britain will restrict the promotion of unhealthy food, including "buy one get one free" deals and free refills of sugary soft drinks, from April 2022. The measures aim to tackle obesity, with almost two-thirds of adults in England overweight. The government will also limit unhealthy promotions in stores and restrict advertising at checkouts and entrances. The goal is to make healthier food choices the easy option, as public health minister Jo Churchill stated, to improve the nation's health. This is part of the government's plan to address obesity and its associated health risks.

site_title: Mainland China reports 21 new Covid-19 cases vs 22 a day earlier
summary: Mainland China reported 21 new Covid-19 cases on Dec 27, down from 22 cases a day earlier, with 15 imported infections and 6 local transmissions in Liaoning province. The total number of confirmed cases is 86,976, and the death toll remains unchanged at 4,634.

site_title: BMW aims for 20% of its vehicles to be electric by 2023: paper
summary: BMW aims to have 20% of its vehicles be electric by 2023, up from 8% this year, with a goal of a quarter of a million more electric cars to be produced between 2021 and 2023. CEO Oliver Zipse also emphasized the need for faster expansion of charging infrastructure, requiring 15,000 new charging points per week.

site_title: Gold set for best close in seven weeks as Trump signs stimulus
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a $900 billion coronavirus stimulus package, boosting gold prices to a seven-week high. The precious metal surged after Trump initially declined to endorse the package, prompting losses. The stimulus package's impact on the US economy and its weakening currency have contributed to gold's gains. Silver also rose, while the dollar eased. This marks gold's first monthly gain since July and its best close in seven weeks.

site_title: Vietnam PM eyes raising of 2021 GDP growth target to 6.5%
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc is considering raising the country's 2021 GDP growth target to 6.5% from 6%, citing the success of the economy in 2020 despite the COVID-19 pandemic and adverse weather. The country's economic growth slowed to 2.91% in 2020, its lowest level in 30 years. Phuc expressed confidence in Vietnam's economic performance, stating it is now better than ever, as the country looks to rebuild and expand its growth prospects in 2021.

site_title: Seoul: Samsung Electronics rally, US stimulus lift stocks to record high
summary: South Korean shares jumped to a record high on Monday, driven by Samsung Electronics and the US stimulus package signed by President Donald Trump. The Kospi index rose 0.5% to 2,821.59, with Samsung Electronics surging 3% and other market heavyweights Hyundai Motor and Celltrion also rising. The US stimulus news outweighed concerns over the new coronavirus variant in South Korea, with foreign investors selling 126.6 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Dollar dithers in thin trade as Trump passes pandemic aid package
summary: US dollar trading remained unchanged despite President Trump signing a $2.3 trillion pandemic aid and spending package, averting a partial federal government shutdown. The pound hovered below a 2.5-year high, while the euro slipped 0.1% to US$1.2199. Analysts expect the pound and euro to decline against the dollar, reaching US$1.30 and US$1.15 by the end of the summer. The dollar index remained steady at 90.224, following a three-day slide.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.4% to 26,487.1 points, following US President Donald Trump's signing of a Covid-19 relief bill. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.2% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.5%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Monday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.15 points or 0.3% to 1,645.32 on Monday, with 335.7 million lots traded worth RM75.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 268 to 86.

site_title: South Korea reports first variant of coronavirus found in the UK: KDCA
summary: South Korea reported the first variant of coronavirus linked to the UK, found in three individuals who entered the country from London on Dec 22, according to the Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency. This variant is associated with the rapid rise in infections in Britain, marking the first instance of the UK variant in South Korea.

site_title: Malaysia to charge second glove maker over poor worker accommodation
summary: Malaysia's Labour Department plans to file 30 charges against glove maker Brightway Holdings and two subsidiaries over substandard worker accommodation. A raid found workers living in cramped, dirty shipping containers behind a factory in Kajang district. The employer lacks a proper certificate of accommodation, and facilities do not meet minimum standards. This is the second company to face charges over poor worker conditions.

images.alt_text: Malaysia aims to file 30 charges against glove maker Brightway Holdings and two of its subsidiaries, after raids that found workers'accommodation was not up to legal standards.

site_title: BOJ's Dec meeting summary exposes board rift on depth of policy review
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers were divided on the depth of its stimulus program review, with some calling for an overhaul of its strategy to achieve 2% inflation. The policy examination will focus on tweaking ETF purchases and yield curve control. Some board members want a more comprehensive assessment to avoid deflation, while others see room for tweaking YCC operations to sustain the program and control yields. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has said the review will not lead to big changes, but the board's divided views highlight the need for a more sustainable framework.

site_title: Trump signs virus relief bill after panning US$600 checks
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a US$900 billion pandemic relief bill after backing down from last-minute demands that would have undercut his negotiating team. The bill includes US$1.4 trillion in government spending and US$2.3 trillion in total relief, but Trump's signature came with a non-binding request to increase stimulus payments from US$600 to US$2,000, which is unlikely to pass. The delay may cut a week from supplemental unemployment benefits and result in a temporary loss of benefits for gig workers and the long-term unemployed.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US relief bill
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.3% to 26,738.77, driven by positive sentiment over a US Covid-19 relief bill. Investors also welcomed news of a massive zero-carbon steel plant in Austria and rebounded from recent declines in Nintendo and Sony shares. However, concerns over the pandemic, including Japan's first cases of the new strain, kept investors cautious. The government also announced a halt on non-resident foreign arrivals from overseas until late January.

site_title: Argentina agro-export companies improve labor deal to end grains port strike
summary: Argentina's influential soyoil chamber of manufacturers and exporters made a revised offer to striking workers, aiming to end a two-week labor dispute. The proposal includes a 35% salary increase and a 70,000 peso bonus to compensate for pandemic risks. The chamber claims this represents the highest salaries in the Argentine private sector. The offer comes as international sales of farm products are crucial to stabilizing the peso currency and funding coronavirus relief efforts. The dealmaking process is set to continue, with the government urging both parties to meet on Tuesday.

site_title: Orix to buy Spanish energy firm Elawan for about S$1.28b
summary: Orix Corp agreed to acquire an 80% stake in Spanish renewable energy firm Elawan Energy for approximately S$1.28 billion. The deal is expected to close in Q2 2021, pending regulatory approvals. Elawan develops and operates wind and solar power projects in Europe and the Americas, with 714 megawatts of operational projects and a development pipeline of over 10 gigawatts. The acquisition will expand Orix's global renewable energy operations and is its first deal to acquire a majority stake in an overseas renewable power company.

site_title: Hot stock: First Reit plunges 32% after announcing rights issue
summary: First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) saw its stock price plummet 32% after announcing a rights issue to raise S$158.2 million. The issue price of 20 cents per unit is a 50.6% discount to the closing price on Dec 24. The trust aims to meet debt covenants and avoid an imminent default of S$196.6 million. Over 29.4 million units were traded, exceeding usual daily volume. The rights issue will be renounceable and will represent 98% of total units in issue.

site_title: Singapore, New Zealand digital-economy pact to take effect on Jan 7
summary: Singapore and New Zealand's Digital Economy Partnership Agreement (DEPA) will take effect on January 7, 2021. The agreement was signed in June 2020 and marks the first digital-economy pact for Singapore. Following ratification by both countries, the pact will facilitate cooperation in areas such as digital trade, innovation, and cybersecurity.

site_title: RCEP: The ambitious deal to reenergise Asia Pacific trade
summary: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is the largest trade deal ever signed, covering 2.3 billion people and representing one-third of global GDP. After eight years of negotiations, the agreement was signed on November 15, 2020, and is expected to come into force in late 2021. RCEP aims to reduce barriers to trade, lower tariffs, and create a unified set of trading regulations, benefiting businesses and economies across Asia. The deal is projected to generate an additional $186 billion worth of income for the global economy by 2030, driving regional integration and cooperation, and creating opportunities for businesses to expand their trade.

site_title: Japan Nov factory output growth stalls after rising for five months
summary: Japan's factory output growth stalled in November after five months of growth, with the economy showing signs of slowing due to a recent Covid-19 resurgence. The country's industrial output was flat in November, contrasting with a 4% gain in the previous month. Economists attribute the slowdown to lockdown measures in major economies and a decline in car shipments to the US and Australia. Despite this, exports remain strong, particularly in Asia, and some analysts expect a rebound in January.

site_title: Alibaba Group increases share repurchase programme to US$10b
summary: Alibaba Group raised its share repurchase program to $10 billion from $6 billion, with the new program effective until 2022. The move comes amid China's antitrust crackdown and financial regulatory pressure on its affiliate Ant Group, which had its IPO suspended. Alibaba shares fell 7% to HK$212.20, while rival companies Meituan and JD.com also declined.

site_title: Messi to miss last match of 2020, say Barca
summary: Lionel Messi will miss Barcelona's last match of 2020 due to ankle treatment, expected to return to training after the midweek La Liga match with Eibar. The Argentine has already missed two matches in December and has scored 10 goals this season, taking him past Pele for the most goals scored for one club. Barcelona sit fifth in La Liga, eight points behind leaders Atletico Madrid, but have taken 10 points from their last four games.

site_title: Australian lobster sector claws back trade after China ban
summary: Australia's rock lobster exports, worth half a billion US dollars annually, have seen a significant increase in sales after China imposed a near-total import ban. Local fishermen, who previously relied heavily on China, are now selling to the Australian public, with prices dropping by 36% to US$34 a kilogram. The back-of-the-boat sales have provided a much-needed lifeline, but experts acknowledge that the sector needs to diversify its markets to avoid relying on a single, politically fickle customer.

site_title: Cold chain doubts delay Covid-19 vaccinations in some German cities
summary: Germany's COVID-19 vaccination campaign faced delays in several cities after temperature trackers showed that about 1,000 BioNTech and Pfizer vaccines may not have been kept cold enough during transit. The affected vaccines were in the northern Bavarian districts of Coburg, Kronach, Kulmbach, Hof, Bayreuth, and Wunsiedel. BioNTech cleared the vaccines late on Sunday, and the regional government of Upper Franconia confirmed that the vaccination program can start. The incident highlights the challenge in rolling out the vaccine while regulators review other shots, including those made by Moderna and AstraZeneca.

site_title: Wonder Woman box office hits a pandemic high in cinema, streaming showdown
summary: Wonder Woman 1984, a Warner Bros film, earned US$36.1 million at US and Canadian theaters during the Christmas holiday weekend, the highest domestic opening since the pandemic. The movie also boosted HBO Max viewership, with total viewing hours on the platform tripling on Friday compared to a typical day. The film's success led to plans for a third Wonder Woman movie, with Warner Bros accelerating development and a hybrid release strategy for 17 other movies in 2021.

site_title: Inflection point on rising wedge formation for EURUSD
summary: EURUSD has reached an inflection point on a rising wedge formation, a potential reversal pattern. Despite a bullish trend, the pair has been rejected off the dynamic resistance, coinciding with an overbought condition in the stochastic oscillator. Weakening bullish momentum is indicated by the MACD histogram falling beneath the signal line. A retracement to 1.1929 (S1) or 1.1614 (S2) is expected if prices continue to pull back, potentially signaling a return to the longer-term downtrend.

site_title: UK, EU politicians study Brexit compromise agreement
summary: The UK and EU have agreed on a historic free trade deal, with a 100% tariff liberalization on £436 billion (S$780 billion) in trade of goods. The agreement aims to protect European interests, ensure fair competition, and provide predictability for fishing communities. However, critics argue that the deal is a "hard Brexit" and will lead to costs and hassles for British companies and workers. The UK and EU will ratify the accord, with the UK parliament also expected to back it.

site_title: Singapore digital banks face hard slog but incumbents can't sit pretty either
summary: Singapore's digital banks face a challenging path to success, requiring them to build trust and manage acquisition costs. Although unlikely to pose a significant threat to incumbents in the near term, they can still put pressure on existing banks' pricing and margins. Analysts estimate that digital banks could capture 1.2% of the Singapore loan market share within three years, potentially disrupting the market for smaller foreign-owned banks. To succeed, digital banks must focus on gaining consumer trust and leveraging cost advantages to compete with incumbents.

site_title: Facebook shuts Irish units at centre of tax dispute
summary: Facebook has shut down several Irish holding companies that allowed it to shift billions of dollars in profit to the country, where taxes were lightly applied. The move comes after the US Internal Revenue Service took Facebook to court, alleging the company shifted funds through Ireland to avoid US taxes. Facebook has repatriated billions of euros in profits back to the US, citing changes in tax law. The company claims the restructuring aligns with its corporate structure and recent tax law changes.

site_title: From bean to bar, Haiti's cocoa wants international recognition
summary: Haiti's cocoa industry is gaining international recognition, despite its small production of 5,000 tonnes annually. A federation of cocoa cooperatives, Feccano, has been successful in organizing farmers and improving market prices, resulting in increased incomes for thousands of farmers. Haitian producers are now selling high-quality beans to the market, earning double their revenues by cutting out intermediaries. Local processing and production have also become more prominent, with a master chocolatier, Ralph Leroy, running a successful chocolate company, Makaya, that showcases Haitian cocoa.

site_title: Bitcoin miners in Nordic region get a boost from cheap power
summary: Bitcoin miners in the Nordic region, particularly in Sweden and Norway, are benefiting from low electricity prices due to unusually wet weather boosting hydro-electric power generation. This has led to some of the lowest power prices in the world, making the region an attractive location for mining. The resulting glut in electricity supply coincides with a year when the price of bitcoin tripled, and many miners have seen their profitability more than triple. The region's low-carbon electricity, mostly from hydro, nuclear, and wind power, also reduces the environmental impact and increases stability for institutional investors.

site_title: Oman launches Covid-19 vaccination campaign
summary: Oman launched its COVID-19 vaccination campaign on December 27, 2020, two days ahead of planned border reopenings and flight resumptions. The country, with the second-highest number of COVID-19 deaths in the Gulf, is the last GCC nation to begin inoculation. The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine will be prioritized for frontline health workers and vulnerable individuals, following a new strain of the virus detected in Britain. Oman aims to boost its economy, which is expected to contract by 10% this year due to slumping oil prices and the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Oman started coronavirus vaccinations on Sunday, two days ahead of plans to resume all flights and open borders that temporarily closed amid concerns over a new strain of the disease.

site_title: China central bank says bond defaults could strengthen market
summary: China's central bank believes bond defaults could strengthen the market by weeding out weakness. Despite a recent series of defaults by top-rated state-owned enterprises, the bond market has remained stable overall. Deputy Governor Chen Yulu stated that bond defaults promote a "mechanism based on survival of the fittest." The central bank plans to step up regulation and improve information disclosure requirements to clamp down on illegal activities and evasion of debts. The goal is to maintain market stability and rationality, while also addressing growing investor concern over corporate debt.

site_title: Champagne makers toast post-Brexit deal with thirsty Brits
summary: French champagne producers celebrated a post-Brexit trade deal with the UK, eliminating new tariffs and quotas on goods trade across the English Channel. The deal brings relief to the champagne sector, which is a significant market for the luxury sparkling wine. Champagne is a staple in British luxury, with brands like Bollinger and those supplying the Queen and royal family. The agreement ensures continued access for French champagne makers to the UK market.

site_title: Pandemic hits 2020 telco roaming revenue
summary: The pandemic has significantly impacted telco revenues in 2020, with a 4-8% decline in higher-income countries, according to GSMA Intelligence. Telcos reported low roaming income and subdued business and consumer sentiment. Despite this, some industry observers believe the worst is over, with stable mobile service revenues forecasted for the year ahead. However, analysts warn of ongoing challenges, including disruption from travel SIMs and over-the-top applications, and the high-margin nature of the roaming business. Telcos are expected to evolve their business models to adapt to the changing market.

site_title: Scrambling to save Asia's modernist buildings
summary: Residents and design buffs in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Cambodia are rallying to save or document post-war modernist buildings, which officials consider too new or ugly to protect. The Hong Kong General Post Office, a 1976 modernist-style building, is at risk of demolition after being put up for sale. Supporters argue that the building's design and history make it a significant part of the city's collective memories. Similar efforts are underway in other cities to preserve modernist landmarks, reflecting a nostalgia for changing urban skylines and an aversion to generic-looking developments.

site_title: EU countries begin coordinated vaccine rollout after clearing Pfizer shot
summary: European Union countries launched a coordinated vaccine rollout against COVID-19, with 27 nations starting vaccination efforts after clearing the Pfizer-BioNTech shot. The rollout comes as the bloc struggles with a rising number of deaths, and several countries, including Germany, have imposed restrictions to contain a winter surge. The EU aims to inoculate 450 million citizens, with supplies initially limited, but another vaccine may soon bolster availability. The process is expected to take months, with the EU hoping to reach two-thirds of its population by mid-September.

site_title: China orders Ant to return to its roots in payments services
summary: China's central bank ordered Ant Group, a financial services company led by Jack Ma, to "rectify" its lending, insurance, and wealth management services, focusing on its payments business. The move aims to curb Ant's growth in consumer loans and wealth management, which are seen as posing risks to the economy. The company must set up a separate financial holding company to ensure sufficient capital and protect personal data. Authorities criticized Ant for poor corporate governance and engaging in regulatory arbitrage, excluding rivals and harming consumers.

site_title: UAE president forms new Abu Dhabi Supreme Council
summary: UAE President Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed established a new Abu Dhabi Supreme Council for Financial and Economic Affairs, which will oversee petroleum and natural resources, as well as petroleum-related policies. The current Supreme Petroleum Council will be merged into this new council, with its members continuing to serve as ADNOC board members until a new board is appointed.

site_title: BRC Asia still keen on China expansion
summary: BRC Asia, a steel dealer, remains optimistic about its China expansion plans despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the construction sector. The company, which has a 17-year presence in China, believes the government's encouragement of prefabrication will drive growth. With a 71.9% stake in its parent company Esteel Enterprise, BRC Asia sees the key to breaking into China's market. The company also explores opportunities in Australia, Indonesia, and Vietnam. Despite a 36% decline in net profit and a 33% drop in revenue in FY2020, BRC Asia remains hopeful of its recovery and expects to aggressively pursue expansion in the second half of 2021 or early 2022.

site_title: Singapore stocks open muted on Monday; STI falls 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks opened muted on Monday, falling 0.04% to 2,840.84, as the Straits Times Index (STI) declined 1.2 points. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also traded lower, with DBS down 0.4%, OCBC 0.5%, and UOB 0.3%. The only gainer was Artivision Technologies, rising 20% after a significant trading volume. This comes after First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) announced a renounceable rights issue to raise S$158.2 million.

site_title: Sengkang MPs elected to WP CEC; party leaders Pritam Singh, Sylvia Lim retain posts
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has elected its four Sengkang GRC MPs to its top central executive committee (CEC), including He Ting Ru, Raeesah Khan, Jamus Lim, and Louis Chua. Party leaders Pritam Singh and Sylvia Lim retained their posts, while former WP leader Low Thia Khiang and former Hougang MP Png Eng Huat also remain as CEC members.

site_title: Chinese banks to feel fund-raising pain as investors fear bad loans
summary: Chinese banks are expected to face challenges in raising funds in 2021 due to concerns over bad loans, which are expected to increase by 8% annually. The sector's profit-conscious investors are wary of lending to the banks, which are ending pandemic-related loan forbearance. Chinese banks raised 1.2 trillion yuan in the first 11 months of 2020, but may need to replenish at least 1.25 trillion yuan of capital in 2021. The country's largest banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, face a shortfall in loss-absorbing debt by 2024. Smaller banks have more acute funding needs, but face challenges in gaining investors' interest due to poor share performance and concerns over credit risks.

images.alt_text: The four largest - Industrial and Commercial Bank of China , China Construction Bank , Agricultural Bank of China and Bank of China - face a shortfall in this loss-absorbing debt of 4.7 trillion yuan by the end of 2024 to meet requirements set by the Basel-based Financial Stability Board, according to Fitch.

site_title: STI highlights from 2020
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 8% in 2020 on a dividend-inclusive total return basis, despite higher participation in Singapore-listed Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs). The two STI ETFs saw S$950 million of combined net inflows, bringing their assets under management to S$2.08 billion. Banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB were among the top performers, with a 40% daily impact on the STI's performance. Keppel DC Reit and Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) provided defensive returns, with their data centre portfolios increasing exposure to 41%.

site_title: Maybank Singapore, The Majurity Trust launch special grant
summary: Maybank Singapore and The Majurity Trust have launched the Maybank Momentum Grant, a S$2 million interest-free recyclable grant for promising small charities in Singapore. The grant, worth four months of operating expenditure capped at S$150,000, aims to support small charities that have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Charities must repay the grant within five years to allow other charities to access the funding, with a panel assessing and selecting charities with a good track record and potential to widen their community impact.

images.alt_text: John Lee (left) and Martin Tan. The grant use is flexible, but must support the charities' plan to transform and scale impact.

site_title: Domestic market a thin lifeline for tourism sector
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to remain weak in 2021 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with domestic tourism playing a crucial role in the industry's recovery. The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) plans to focus on domestic demand, with initiatives such as the SingapoRediscover campaign and a S$45 million marketing blitz. However, experts warn that the industry must innovate and adapt to capture the domestic market, with some tourism-related business closures potentially inevitable. The sector is also expected to face challenges in the long term, with international travel recovery expected to be slow compared to other Asia-Pacific countries.

site_title: Healthcare workers of National Centre for Infectious Diseases first to get Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 vaccination exercise began on Dec 30, 2020, with healthcare workers at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID). The Ministry of Health (MOH) aims to vaccinate the elderly, starting with those aged 70 and above, from February 2021. The government has accepted the Expert Committee's recommendations to prioritize vaccinations for healthcare workers, essential personnel, and the elderly due to their high risk of severe illness. Vaccination will complement existing measures to mitigate the spread of the virus, with the goal of achieving high population coverage to reduce transmission and protect vulnerable individuals.

site_title: With money and waste, China fights for chip independence
summary: China is intensifying its efforts to become self-sufficient in chip production, with the government investing heavily in startups and established companies. The goal is to reduce dependence on foreign chips, a move seen as a response to US trade policies. While progress has been made, several projects have stalled due to funding issues and mismanagement. The country aims to produce 40% of its consumed chips by 2025, but experts warn that replicating complex technology is a challenging task. China's push for chip independence is seen as a key aspect of its "Five Fundamentals" for economic development, but the effort may lead to waste and potential failures.

site_title: China's imports of Australian copper concentrate lowest since at least 2016
summary: China's imports of Australian copper concentrate plummeted 77.8% to 26,717 tonnes in November, the lowest since 2016, due to a bilateral trade dispute. The decline follows October's 50% drop, amid tensions between the two countries over issues like the 5G ban and COVID-19 origins. China's total copper concentrate imports were up 8.3% from October, but still 15% lower than the previous year. The move affects Australian copper, which was the fifth-largest supplier to China in 2019.

site_title: Japan unveils green growth plan for 2050 carbon-neutral goal
summary: Japan has unveiled a green growth plan to achieve a 2050 carbon-neutral goal, including phasing out petrol-powered cars and boosting renewable energy. The plan aims to generate over half of the country's electricity from renewable sources by 2050 and reduce battery costs to make electric cars more affordable. The government also plans to use nuclear and thermal power plants with carbon capture technology and ammonia and hydrogen technologies to cover 30-40% of electricity demand. However, critics say the plan falls short of ambition, with some arguing that Japan should aim for 50-60% renewable energy by 2030.

site_title: 5% of vaccine stocks should be set aside for groups critical to Singapore's functioning: MOH expert committee
summary: Singapore's expert committee on Covid-19 vaccination recommends setting aside 5% of available vaccine stocks for critical groups essential to the country's functioning, such as water and utilities personnel. The elderly (70+ years) and those at high risk of infection (healthcare workers) will be prioritized for vaccination in the event of limited supply. The committee aims to achieve high population coverage to reduce disease susceptibility and transmission, and protect others who may not be suitable for vaccination yet.

site_title: China's industrial profits grow robustly in November
summary: China's industrial profits grew 15.5% in November, the seventh consecutive month of gains, driven by strong industrial production and sales. Profits rose to 729.32 billion yuan, easing from a three-year high in October. The coal sector saw a notable recovery, with profits rising 9.1% in November. Analysts predict double-digit growth for industrial profits over the next few months, driven by low base effects and domestic economic recovery.

site_title: China central bank urges Ant Group to set 'rectification' plan swiftly
summary: China's central bank urged Ant Group to set a 'rectification' plan swiftly to address regulatory demands. The People's Bank of China ordered Ant to rectify illegal financial activities, including credit, insurance, and wealth management businesses. Vice-Governor Pan Gongsheng emphasized the need for a concrete plan to meet regulatory demands and understand the seriousness of the required "rectification" work.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hong Lai Huat has revised its proposed renounceable non-underwritten rights issue, allocating 54.8% of net proceeds to repay outstanding debt to its CEO, Ong Bee Huat. This includes S$14.4 million from re-allocating funds originally intended for bank borrowings and project development costs. The company's internal resources are deemed sufficient for debt repayment, and the revised allocation will also cover new project land and development costs.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat changes intended use of proposed rights issue proceeds
summary: Hong Lai Huat has changed the intended use of proceeds from its proposed rights issue, allocating 54.8% of the net proceeds ($14.41 million) to repay outstanding debt to group CEO Ong Bee Huat. This debt repayment will come from re-allocated funds originally intended for bank borrowings, project development costs, and new project land and development costs. The change aims to ensure the group's internal resources are sufficient for debt repayment as and when they fall due.

site_title: Pan Ocean Co to invest in 204b won in shipbuilding contract for an LNG carrier
summary: Pan Ocean Co has invested 204 billion won (approximately S$246.5 million) in a shipbuilding contract for an LNG carrier, expanding its LNG business. The vessel is expected to be delivered on April 30, 2023. Despite a 23.7% drop in Q3 net profit to US$35.3 million and a 6.8% decline in sales to US$533.8 million, the company remains committed to its LNG business.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Five new Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore as of Sunday, bringing the total to 58,524. All cases were imported, with five being placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. No community cases or patients from workers' dormitories were reported. Investigations into 13 cases linked to a hotel where a Lebanese national tested positive are ongoing, with 37 cases discharged on Saturday, leaving 37 patients in hospital.

site_title: Vietnam's 2020 economic growth slips to 30-yr low
summary: Vietnam's economy experienced its weakest growth in at least three decades, expanding 2.91% in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, natural disasters, and a sluggish global economy. The country's trade surplus is expected to be $19.06 billion, and average consumer prices rose 3.23%. The processing and manufacturing industry drove growth, while services and agriculture sectors also saw expansion. Despite a slow fourth quarter, Vietnam's economy rebounded faster than in much of Asia, thanks to strict quarantine measures that contained the virus. This is considered a success for Vietnam amidst negative global economic impacts.

site_title: US holiday retail sales rise as online shopping booms: Mastercard
summary: US holiday retail sales rose 3% in the expanded holiday shopping season from Oct 11 to Dec 24, driven by a 49% surge in e-commerce sales. Online shopping accounted for 19.7% of total retail sales, with buy online and pick-up-in-store and contactless technologies playing key roles. Retailers, including Walmart and Target, pushed back promotions due to capacity constraints, while e-commerce giant Amazon extended its promotional period. The pandemic's shift to online shopping is expected to continue, with smaller retailers embracing new technology.

site_title: Hong Kong florist helps prisoners send Christmas gifts
summary: A Hong Kong florist, Elise Ip, has initiated a free "Send Flowers With You" project, sending over 50 gifts to relatives and friends of prisoners, including a cactus in the shape of a puppy's head to a woman in custody. The project aims to bring comfort to those in detention, with Ip stating that it reminds the world of those who have sacrificed their lives for democracy. More than 10,000 people have been arrested and thousands prosecuted in Hong Kong since the 2019 pro-democracy protests.

images.alt_text: Elise Ip holding a gift as part of the free "Send Flowers With You" project - which allows relatives and friends to receive gifts ordered by prisoners following last year's massive pro-democracy protests.

site_title: British PM sold out fish in Brexit trade deal, fishermen say
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit trade deal with the European Union has been criticized by fishermen as a "sell-out" that gives EU boats significant access to the UK's rich fishing waters. The deal allows EU boats to catch 80% of Celtic Sea haddock for another five years, despite UK fishermen's concerns. The UK government claims the deal provides a significant uplift in quota for UK fishers, but critics argue it is a defeat for the fishing industry.

site_title: Covid vaccinations start from Dec 30, with healthcare workers from NCID
summary: Singapore begins COVID-19 vaccinations on Dec 30 with healthcare workers at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID). The vaccinations will be rolled out to healthcare institutions and private providers in subsequent weeks. The government aims to vaccinate the elderly starting with those aged 70 and above from February 2021, citing the need to protect older persons from COVID-19 related mortality and morbidity. Vaccination is seen as a key enabler to getting Singapore back to a safer state of affairs, complementing safe management measures and other existing key enablers.

site_title: Beijing tightens Covid-19 curbs as cases detected across capital
summary: Beijing has tightened Covid-19 curbs amid concerns of mass travel during the holiday period, with the city reporting its fourth straight day of locally transmitted cases. Authorities have urged districts to enter an "emergency" mode, sealing off residential compounds and villages with infections. Testing has been intensified, with Shunyi district declaring a wartime mode and Chaoyang district finishing testing 234,413 people in three neighborhoods. The city has also restricted public venues and performances, with 50 million people in high-risk groups set to be vaccinated before the Chinese New Year holidays.

site_title: Japan aims to eliminate petrol vehicles by mid-2030s, boost green growth
summary: Japan aims to eliminate petrol-powered vehicles by mid-2030s as part of its "green growth strategy" to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The government plans to offer tax incentives and financial support to companies investing in green technology, with a goal of generating nearly $2 trillion in green growth by 2050. The strategy targets the hydrogen and auto industries, with plans to slash the cost of vehicle batteries by more than half and boost hydrogen consumption to 20 million tonnes by 2050.

site_title: Indian farmers agree to meet government over contentious farm laws
summary: Indian farmers have agreed to meet with government ministers, possibly paving the way for a seventh round of talks over contentious farm laws. The farmers' unions, which have been protesting since September, want the laws repealed, citing concerns they will dismantle regulated markets and affect government buying prices. The government claims the laws will benefit farmers by allowing direct sales to large traders and retailers. The meeting, set for Tuesday, is expected to address issues such as penalties for burning crop stubble and the laws' impact on farmers' livelihoods.

site_title: Year of the meme stock: Hertz, Kodak top 2020 list
summary: In 2020, Reddit's "meme stocks" captured individual investors' attention, with US stocks like Hertz, Kodak, Nikola Corp, and US Oil Fund experiencing wild swings. Hertz filed for bankruptcy but rebounded 10-fold, while Eastman Kodak's stock surged 1,481% before collapsing. Nikola Corp's valuation plummeted after allegations of deception, and the US Oil Fund's performance was hindered by its investment strategy. Meanwhile, vaccine developers like Novavax Inc saw significant gains, with its stock rising 3,000% this year.

site_title: China's Nov soybean imports from US surge on year after trade deal
summary: China's soybean imports from the US surged 136% in November, reaching 6.04 million tonnes, as cargoes booked following the Phase One trade deal arrived. This marks a significant increase from 2.56 million tonnes in November last year and 3.4 million tonnes in October. Chinese buyers stepped up purchases earlier this year to fulfill trade deal commitments, and imports of Brazilian soybeans also rose. Total US soybean imports for the first 11 months of the year reached 20.05 million tonnes, up 45% from the previous year.

site_title: Fast-food bar frozen in Pompeii ash offers clues on Roman snacking habits
summary: Archaeologists have discovered a 2,000-year-old fast-food stall in Pompeii, Italy, frozen in volcanic ash. The thermopolium, a Roman-era equivalent of a fast-food snack stall, features a preserved counter with polychrome patterns and remains of various foods, including duck bones, fish, and snails. The stall was likely abandoned as the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD began, with possible victims including a 50-year-old man and a child. The discovery provides new insights into the snacking habits of ancient Romans and is considered an exceptional find due to its complete preservation.

site_title: Indian PM makes fresh appeal to farmers protesting over new laws
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi made a fresh appeal to farmers protesting over new agricultural reforms, offering to hold talks to end the stalemate. The reforms, passed in September, have been met with resistance from tens of thousands of farmers who fear they will lead to dismantling of regulated markets and leave them at the mercy of big corporates. Modi sought to allay their concerns, promising to discuss every issue with farmers, and released $2.5 billion to 90 million farmers under a financial scheme.

site_title: Australian lobster sector claws back trade after China ban
summary: Australia's rock lobster exports, worth half a billion US dollars annually, have seen a significant increase in sales after China imposed a near-total import ban. Local authorities have allowed commercial lobster fishermen to sell large quantities from the back of their boats, leading to long queues of customers in Fremantle harbour. Prices have dropped to 36% below pre-pandemic levels, but the lobster industry acknowledges that back-of-the-boat sales are a short-term fix, and diversifying markets is key to long-term survival.

site_title: Four injured in Berlin shooting, police say
summary: A shooting in Berlin's Kreuzberg district on Saturday injured four people, with three taken to hospital in serious condition. Police say there is no indication of a political motive, and the incident is being investigated.

site_title: Europe rolls out vaccines in bid to leave pandemic behind
summary: Europe launches a large-scale cross-border vaccination program to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, aiming to inoculate all adults by the end of 2021. The European Union has secured over 2 billion vaccine doses and is promoting vaccination as a key step towards normal life next year. Despite high levels of vaccine hesitancy in some countries, leaders are encouraging equal access to vaccines across the region. Mass vaccinations are set to begin in several countries, including France, Germany, Italy, and Spain, with unique distribution methods, such as temporary solar-powered healthcare pavilions, to be used in various locations.

images.alt_text: Europe launches a cross-border vaccination programme of unprecedented scale on Sunday as part of efforts to end a Covid-19 pandemic that has crippled economies and claimed more than 1.7 million lives around the world.

site_title: Trump refuses to budge over aid bill, imperiling jobless benefits for millions
summary: US President Donald Trump has refused to sign a $2.3 trillion pandemic aid and spending package, which includes extending emergency unemployment benefits for millions of Americans. Without his signature, about 14 million people could lose those benefits, and a partial government shutdown is expected to begin on Tuesday, putting millions of government workers' incomes at risk. Trump has complained that the bill gives too much money to special interests and cultural projects, while the provision of $600 stimulus checks is too small, and has demanded that be raised to $2,000.

site_title: Russia opens criminal case against ally of Kremlin critic Navalny
summary: Russia has launched a criminal case against Lyubov Sobol, an ally of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny, over allegations she violently entered a flat linked to a secret agent involved in a plot to kill Navalny. Sobol was detained for 48 hours, contradicting the Investigative Committee's statement. The move is part of a clampdown on Kremlin opponents ahead of next year's parliamentary election. Navalny accused the authorities of silencing Sobol, who aims to run for office, and warned of "killers and poisoners" being "untouchable."
