site_title: China's central bank says bond defaults could strengthen market
summary: China's central bank believes bond defaults can strengthen the market by eliminating weakness, according to Deputy Governor Chen Yulu. Following recent defaults by top-rated state-owned enterprises, the PBOC plans to regulate the bond market, clamp down on illegal activities, and improve credit rating systems. The market has shown stability overall, with few defaults causing fluctuations. The central bank will join forces with other departments to address concerns of debt evasion and ensure transparency.

site_title: Bitcoin miners in Nordic region get a boost from cheap power
summary: Bitcoin miners in the Nordic region, particularly Sweden and Norway, have benefited from low electricity prices due to unusually wet weather, which has boosted hydro-electric power generation. This has led to some of the lowest power prices in the world, making the region an attractive location for mining. The region's low carbon emissions and stable power supply also appeal to institutional investors, contributing to the recent surge in Bitcoin prices. As a result, miners are returning to the region, and new investments are being made to expand mining operations.

site_title: Mayor of major French fishing port warns of Brexit deal uncertainties
summary: French fisherman face uncertainty due to the Brexit trade deal, with the transition period for fisheries lasting 5.5 years, longer than initially desired by the UK but shorter than the EU's original request. Mayor of Boulogne-sur-Mer Frederic Cuvillier expressed concerns over the lack of clarity on the impact on fish stocks and control handling. French politicians are calling for a meeting with the French Prime Minister to analyze the deal's details, and the government has announced financial measures to help affected fishermen.

site_title: BioNTech will work with others to boost vaccine capacity: CEO
summary: BioNTech CEO Ugur Sahin announced plans to increase production capacity for its Covid-19 vaccine, aiming to distribute 1.3 billion doses by the end of 2021. The company will also consider opening an office in Turkey, in partnership with the country's state scientific agency Tubitak, and has already agreed to buy 4.5 million doses of the vaccine. Sahin stated that 70% of the world needs to be vaccinated by next winter to return to "normal life."

images.alt_text: BioNTech chief executive Ugur Sahin said his company would be open to cooperating with others as it looks to increase production capacity for its Covid-19 vaccine developed with Pfizer and was considering opening an office in Turkey.

site_title: Expanded vaccinations to begin in UK on Jan 4: Telegraph
summary: The UK will begin rolling out the Oxford and Astrazeneca COVID-19 vaccine on January 4, with the goal of vaccinating two million people. Mass vaccination centers at sports stadiums and conference venues are expected to launch in the second week of January. The Oxford vaccine is easier to store and handle, making it suitable for reaching remote areas. The Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency will review the vaccine data before distribution begins.

site_title: Rollout of 5G to be closely watched for earnings potential
summary: Singapore's 5G rollout is expected to be closely watched for earnings potential, but analysts flag challenges of generating higher revenues from higher speeds. Despite initial positive responses, telcos face declining mobile service revenues and a competitive environment. To differentiate themselves, Singtel and StarHub plan to offer innovative services such as augmented and mixed-reality experiences, while TPG will focus on cost-efficient value data packages. The industry's initial focus on a crowded consumer market may not lead to increased revenues, with some analysts predicting a wait for 5G standalone and rise in adoption before ARPUs (average revenues per user) inch up.

images.alt_text: All four MNOs had already been carrying out 5G trials for uses from smart estates to consumer gaming.
Yuen Kuan Moon says Singtel plans to offer augmented, virtual and mixed reality "to bring new immersive dimensions to work and play".

site_title: South Korea logs second-highest daily tally of Covid cases
summary: South Korea reported its second-highest daily number of COVID-19 cases with 1,132 new infections on December 25. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency attributed the surge to outbreaks at a prison, nursing homes, and churches. The government plans to hold a meeting to discuss tightening distancing rules, including banning gatherings of more than four people and closing tourist spots. With 54,770 total infections and 773 deaths, South Korea's health minister warned that the virus is spreading rapidly and urged people to avoid year-end gatherings to curb the spread.

site_title: Adios Maradona and the best ever Bond: Notable deaths in 2020
summary: Notable deaths in 2020 included legendary actors Kirk Douglas and Sean Connery, as well as matriarch of the US Supreme Court Ruth Bader Ginsberg. Other notable deaths were of Diego Maradona, a renowned soccer player, and the death of notable figures in various fields.

site_title: Australian golf legend Greg Norman hospitalised with Covid-19
summary: Australian golf legend Greg Norman, a former world number one, has been hospitalized with Covid-19 symptoms. Norman, 65, had been experiencing mild fever, cough, and other symptoms despite testing negative and quarantining. He posted a photo of himself in a hospital bed on Instagram, stating he wanted to "get this behind us never to experience it again". Norman had recently competed in the PNC Championship with his son and finished in a share of ninth.

site_title: Investigators search home in Nashville bomb probe
summary: US investigators searched a Nashville, Tennessee home on Saturday as they probe the Christmas morning blast that injured several people and damaged dozens of buildings. A 63-year-old "person of interest" had been identified in connection with the explosion, but authorities have not confirmed if the bomber was killed. The blast, from a parked motorhome, damaged about 40 buildings and injured at least three people, with tissue found at the site believed to be human remains. Authorities are examining over 500 leads and tips, and no one has been arrested.

site_title: Concord International Hospital ordered to stop healthcare services for lapses in patient safety
summary: Concord International Hospital in Singapore has been ordered to temporarily stop providing healthcare services due to significant lapses in patient safety, including inadequate equipment and medication availability in critical areas. The Ministry of Health found multiple instances of failure to abide by the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act, posing risks to patient safety and well-being. The hospital will work with its medical team to ensure continuity of outpatient care for four patients while addressing its lapses.

site_title: 'You checked Tesla the most': Robinhood recaps from a volatile year
summary: Robinhood, a popular trading app, released a year-end recap for its users, showcasing the stocks they purchased, dividends earned, and most-checked stocks. The recap revealed that Tesla was the most-checked stock, with users averaging over 50 checks per day. The data also showed that users were obsessed with every dollar up or down in the market, with some checking their stocks over 10,000 times in 2020. The recap was well-received, with users praising its aesthetic and sharing their results on social media. The data highlights the volatile nature of the stock market and Robinhood's role in facilitating retail investing.

site_title: Millions of Americans lose jobless benefits as Trump refuses to sign aid bill
summary: Millions of Americans lost jobless benefits on Dec 26, 2020, as President Donald Trump refused to sign a $2.3 trillion pandemic aid and spending package. The bill, which included $892 billion in coronavirus relief and $1.4 trillion for government spending, would have extended special unemployment benefits expiring on Dec 26. Without Trump's signature, approximately 14 million people could lose those benefits. Trump had previously agreed to the deal but later complained it did not provide enough aid, particularly in the form of stimulus checks, which he demanded be raised to $2,000.

site_title: China will conduct talks on EU investment pact 'at its own pace'
summary: China will conduct talks on an EU investment pact at its own pace, raising doubts about a year-end deal. Negotiations have gone on for six years, but EU officials had said a deal was close following Germany's push. China's foreign ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin stated that talks will proceed on the premise of safeguarding security and developmental interests. Key sticking points include China's reluctance to ratify international labor laws and access to sensitive sectors such as energy and water treatment. The EU's efforts to meet China halfway are also being met with resistance.

site_title: Football: Man City cannot rely on Santa for goals, says Guardiola
summary: Manchester City coach Pep Guardiola has urged his team to work collectively to rediscover their fluid style of play, as they struggle to score goals. The team has only scored 19 goals in 13 Premier League games this season, a stark contrast to their previous performances. Guardiola emphasized that goals don't come from Santa Claus, but from the team's performances, and that winning games during the festive period is crucial to close the gap with leaders Liverpool. City will look to bounce back from a 4-1 loss to Arsenal in the League Cup quarter-finals against Newcastle United and Everton.

site_title: Vanguard wins ETF flow war as State Street slips further behind
summary: Vanguard Group has secured a record $194 billion in ETF flows for 2020, surpassing BlackRock's $113 billion, marking the first time since 2013 that Vanguard has led in attracting ETF flows. State Street Corp, a distant third, saw its market share drop for a fifth consecutive year, losing $32 billion to its rival's funds. Vanguard's success can be attributed to its popularity among financial advisers and model portfolios, while State Street's high fees on some of its top funds hindered its growth.

site_title: Wonder Woman likely to lasso more TV viewers than moviegoers
summary: Wonder Woman 1984, the DC Comics superhero film, is expected to generate $10-15 million in domestic ticket sales over its first weekend, a fraction of the $103.3 million its predecessor brought in. The film's slow sales in international markets and limited US theater capacity due to COVID-19 restrictions may impact its overall box office performance. However, its simultaneous release on HBO Max is expected to spur sign-ups to the streaming service. The film's performance highlights the bleak state of the theater industry, with ticket sales down 80% and theater chains teetering on bankruptcy.

site_title: Japan delays women leadership target after falling short
summary: Japan's government has delayed its goal to have at least 30% of leadership positions occupied by women by the end of 2020, instead setting a new target for the "earliest possible time" during the next decade. The country ranks 121 out of 153 nations in promoting gender equality, with just 14.8% of leadership positions held by women. The delay comes after Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's government approved a new five-year plan that acknowledges the need for social acceptance of traditional gender roles and unconscious bias to be addressed.

site_title: Pope urges Covid 'vaccines for all' in Christmas message
summary: Pope Francis urges "vaccines for all, especially the most vulnerable and most in need" in his Christmas message, calling the COVID-19 pandemic a "glimmer of hope in this period of darkness and uncertainty." The pontiff also highlighted the plight of children caught in war, particularly in Syria, Yemen, and Iraq, and called for cooperation to address global crises. He will make a historic visit to Iraq in March, where he will emphasize peace and reconciliation, particularly for Christian communities affected by conflict.

site_title: Boston doctor has severe allergic reaction to Moderna Covid vaccine
summary: A doctor in Boston, Hossein Sadrzadeh, experienced a severe allergic reaction after receiving the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine. The reaction, which included dizziness and a racing heart, occurred almost immediately after vaccination. Dr. Sadrzadeh self-administered his epi-pen and was taken to the Emergency Department, where he was treated and discharged. This is the first severe allergic reaction publicly linked to Moderna's vaccine, which is in its first week of a nationwide rollout. The US FDA is investigating around five allergic reactions related to the Pfizer and BioNTech vaccine.

site_title: China to leapfrog US as world's biggest economy by 2028: think tank
summary: China is predicted to surpass the US as the world's largest economy by 2028, five years earlier than initially estimated, according to a think tank report. This shift is attributed to China's "skilful management of the pandemic" and its relative economic performance improving compared to the US. China's average economic growth is forecasted to be 5.7% from 2021-25, while the US is expected to experience a strong rebound in 2021 followed by slower growth.

site_title: First case of new Covid variant found in France as cases rise
summary: France has recorded its first case of a new Covid-19 variant, with a Frenchman testing positive after returning from London. The case was confirmed in the city of Tours, where the man is currently self-isolating. France has also seen a surge in Covid-19 cases and deaths, with 20,262 new cases and 159 hospital deaths reported in the past 24 hours. This comes as countries around the world have closed their borders to Britain and South Africa due to the spread of the new variant.

site_title: Investors rethink role of bonds, tech and ESG after chaotic year
summary: Global investors are reevaluating asset allocation strategies after a chaotic year marked by a health crisis, central bank stimulus, and market volatility. Bonds are being questioned for their role in portfolios, with some experts advising a shift to equities and high-yield bonds. The tech sector, which dominated the market's performance, is expected to remain a key driver of growth. Meanwhile, ESG-related assets have outperformed in many pockets, prompting a surge in inflows to environmentally, socially, and governance-focused products. Investors are also advised to focus on companies with strong balance sheets and diversify their investments to mitigate risks.

site_title: China's industrial profits grow robustly, seventh straight rise
summary: China's industrial profits rose 15.5% in November, a seventh consecutive month, driven by strong industrial production and sales. The growth eased from October's three-year high of 28.2%. Factory-gate prices fell less than expected. Coal industry profits rose 9.1% in November, and analysts predict double-digit growth for the next few months. State-owned industrial firms saw a 4.9% decline in January-November earnings, while private sector profits grew 1.8%.

images.alt_text: Profits at China's industrial firms grew robustly in November for a seventh month of gains, supported by strong industrial production and sales, as manufacturers continue their recovery from the Covid-19 downturn.

site_title: Elon Musk says it's 'impossible' to take Tesla private, mulls new IPO
summary: Elon Musk stated it's "impossible" for Tesla to go private, citing the company's public duties and limitations on his time for innovation. Tesla shares have surged eightfold this year, making Musk the world's second-richest person. Musk also mentioned Starlink, SpaceX's space-Internet business, as a potential candidate for a public listing once its revenue growth becomes predictable, echoing comments from SpaceX president Gwynne Shotwell.

site_title: Japan aims to eliminate petrol vehicles by mid-2030s, boost green growth
summary: Japan aims to eliminate petrol-powered vehicles by mid-2030s as part of its "green growth strategy" to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The government will offer tax incentives and financial support to companies, targeting $2 trillion in green growth by 2050. The plan includes slashing vehicle battery costs by 50% and boosting hydrogen consumption to 20 million tonnes by 2050. The strategy also targets 45 gigawatts of offshore wind power by 2040, with a goal of generating nearly $2 trillion in green growth annually.

site_title: Yoozoo Games CEO Lin dies at 39 amid poisoning probe
summary: Lin Qi, 39-year-old CEO of Chinese video-game publisher Yoozoo Games, died after being hospitalized amid a suspected poisoning investigation in Shanghai. The company announced Lin's death without specifying the cause, stating he would continue normal operations and seek a successor. A suspect has been detained in connection with the investigation. Lin was the founder, chairman, and top shareholder of Yoozoo, which has launched titles including Game of Thrones: Winter Is Coming and adapted The Three-Body Problem into a series with Netflix.

images.alt_text: Lin Qi, the chief executive officer of Chinese video-game publisher Yoozoo Games, has died after being hospitalised amid a Shanghai police investigation into a suspected poisoning case. He was 39.

site_title: BBC says obtained full copy of post-Brexit trade deal
summary: The BBC has obtained the full copy of the UK-EU post-Brexit trade deal, which exceeds the EU's trade accord with Canada. The 1,246-page document includes 800 pages of annexes and footnotes, determining every trade aspect between the UK and EU. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson described the deal as a "jumbo" free trade agreement, urging Britain to move on from Brexit divisions.

site_title: Japan's Orix to buy Spanish energy firm for about 100b yen
summary: Japan's Orix Corp agreed to buy 80% stake in Spanish energy firm Elawan Energy for approximately 100 billion yen (S$1.29 billion), its first overseas renewable energy acquisition. Elawan develops and operates wind and solar power projects in Europe and the Americas, with 714 megawatts of operational projects. The deal expands Orix's global renewable energy operations, following its $980 million investment in Indian renewable energy developer Greenko Energy Holdings in September.

site_title: Robinhood Financial hit with class-action lawsuit for selling stock orders
summary: Robinhood Financial is being sued in a class-action lawsuit for allegedly failing to inform clients that it was selling their stock orders to trading firms, charging back-door commission fees. The company, which previously settled with the SEC over similar allegations, allegedly collected payment from market makers in exchange for executing trades, passing these costs on to clients through inferior execution quality. Robinhood has agreed to have an outside consultant monitor its compliance, but did not admit or deny the claims.

site_title: Japan considers fines to get bars to close early due to virus
summary: Japan considers imposing fines on bars and restaurants that don't close early due to the coronavirus pandemic, as the country sees a record 3,745 new cases. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga renewed calls for the public to spend the New Year's holidays quietly at home. The government is weighing incentives and fines to a law on virus management, and plans to begin vaccine distribution in late February for medical workers and the elderly. Japan's postwar constitution protects civil liberties, preventing a forcible lockdown.

site_title: Motor home explodes in Nashville after 'evacuate now' warning; three hurt
summary: A parked motor home exploded in downtown Nashville, injuring three people, after a recorded announcement warned of a bomb that would explode in 15 minutes. The blast, which occurred on Christmas morning, destroyed several vehicles and damaged buildings, sending a pall of black smoke into the sky. Authorities said the explosion was an "intentional act" and that quick action by police likely prevented more casualties. The motive and potential perpetrator are unclear, with the FBI assisting in the investigation.

site_title: CoronaVac efficacy at 50-90% in Brazilian trial: Sao Paulo official
summary: The CoronaVac Covid-19 vaccine developed by Sinovac Biotech showed efficacy between 50% and 90% in Brazilian trials, according to Sao Paulo's state health secretary. The results, set to be released on January 7, are exclusive to the Butantan Institute, which produces the vaccine. This is above Brazil's minimum required efficacy of 50% and below 90%, as set by the country's health regulator. The vaccine previously showed 91.25% efficacy in Turkey's late-stage trial.

site_title: Chinese Covid-19 vaccine's efficacy uncertain despite Brazil, Turkey results
summary: China's Sinovac Biotech vaccine has shown efficacy rates of 91.25% in a Turkish trial and over 50% in a Brazilian trial, but the results are uncertain due to differing protocols and lack of unified data. Sinovac is finalizing Phase Three trial results, but the efficacy data has not been publicly released, creating confusion over the vaccine's effectiveness. The vaccine's efficacy is considered lower than that of Pfizer and Moderna's shots, which have been shown to reduce symptomatic cases by well over 90%. Sinovac hopes to establish unified standards for trial comparisons to increase confidence in the vaccine.

site_title: Ex-Japan PM Abe to face questioning in Parliament over funding scandal
summary: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will appear in Parliament to correct statements about a funding scandal, apologizing for false denials about subsidizing cherry-blossom viewing parties for his supporters. Abe's secretary was fined for possible violations of Japan's strict political funding laws, and the scandal could damage his successor, Yoshihide Suga, who also apologized for making inaccurate statements. Abe previously denied involvement, but his statements to Parliament contradicted prosecutors' findings at least 118 times. The scandal marks a dramatic reversal of fortunes for Abe, Japan's longest-serving leader.

site_title: Hong Kong 'speedboat fugitives' to face trial next week in China
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy activists, arrested while attempting to flee to Taiwan by speedboat, will face trial in mainland China on December 28. Ten of the 12 detainees will participate in a video hearing at the Yantian District People's Court in Shenzhen. The trial is scheduled during the Christmas and New Year period, a tactic used by China to avoid Western scrutiny. Relatives of the detainees have been informed of the trial, and campaigners are urging support for the activists. The trial date marks a significant development in the case, with the fate of the detainees now set to be decided.

site_title: China: Stocks firm after Brexit deal; materials, healthcare lead
summary: China's stocks rose 0.6-0.8% on Friday, driven by gains in materials and healthcare firms. The CSI300 index reached near a five-year high, with the materials and healthcare indices rallying 1.7%. China's central bank vowed to step up regulation of corporate bond markets, while policymakers signaled support for economic recovery in 2021. The Shanghai index is expected to hit the 4,000-point level due to solid economic recovery and policy support.

site_title: Japan official calls Taiwan 'red line', urges Biden to 'be strong'
summary: Japan's State Minister of Defense Yasuhide Nakayama has urged US President-elect Joe Biden to "be strong" in supporting Taiwan amid China's aggressive stance, calling the island's safety a "red line." Japan shares strategic interests with Taiwan, and Nakayama expressed concern that China may target Taiwan next. The US has maintained a "one China" policy, but Biden has called for strengthening ties with Taiwan and other "like-minded democracies." Beijing considers Taiwan one of its provinces and has never renounced the use of force to bring it under control.

site_title: Air Canada Boeing 737-8 MAX suffers engine issue
summary: An Air Canada Boeing 737-8 MAX aircraft suffered an engine issue on a flight from Arizona to Montreal on December 22, forcing the crew to divert to Tucson, Arizona. The pilots received a "left engine hydraulic low pressure indication" and declared a PAN PAN emergency before landing normally. The incident occurred after the US Federal Aviation Administration lifted a 20-month flight ban on the 737 MAX last month, requiring airlines to complete software, system, and training upgrades before carrying passengers.

site_title: British Airways cargo staff strike from Christmas Day
summary: British Airways cargo staff will strike from Friday until January 2, affecting around 850 workers and transportation of fresh food and other items. The strike is over a pay row, with Unite union claiming cuts of up to 25% or thousands of pounds per worker. The airline disputes Unite's claims, saying it offered a 50% salary rise for most cargo workers. The strike will cause severe disruption to the company's ability to bring goods into the UK, already experiencing delays due to a new coronavirus strain.

site_title: Fintech firm Square discussed acquiring Jay-Z's music-streaming service Tidal
summary: Square Inc, the digital-payment company run by Jack Dorsey, has discussed acquiring music-streaming service Tidal as part of a push to diversify. The talks were initiated by Dorsey, who has ambitions to build Square into a broader company with standalone services. Tidal, co-founded by Jay-Z, has struggled to keep pace with other streaming services, with its subscriber figures not reported since 2016. The potential deal may not result in a transaction, and Square's shares fell 1.1% after the news.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher in thin holiday trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, supported by US gains, despite thin trade due to Christmas holidays. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.17% and the Topix index 0.22% in early trade. Shipping firms, automakers, and some stocks like Toyota and Nissan also gained. However, worries over the rise in new coronavirus infections weighed on the market. The Dow on Wall Street ended up 0.2% following a lightly-traded session.

site_title: GE case hints at secret Airbus narrow-body plane in development
summary: Airbus has solicited engine ideas for a narrow-body jetliner in development, with General Electric proposing a geared design. The proposal, revealed in a court opinion, suggests a "next generation" plane is in the works. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury has indicated the firm's next narrow-body will be carbon-free, with work on hydrogen-powered aircraft underway. GE's engine design could be adapted to use new propulsion technologies, but such technology for a full-size airliner is unlikely before 2030.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares finish mixed but signs point to more upside potential
summary: Japanese shares ended mixed on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 Index down 0.04% at 26,656.61. The broader Topix rose 0.23% to 1,778.41, driven by gains in the shipping, raw materials, and real estate sectors. Pro-cyclical stocks, such as those in the shipping sector, are expected to perform well next year as the global economy recovers from the pandemic. A free-trade deal between Britain and the EU and a US$900 billion economic stimulus package also boosted sentiment.

site_title: M&A deals come roaring back as executives plot post-Covid future
summary: Global merger and acquisition (M&A) activity rebounded in 2020, with deal volumes down 6% to US$3.5 trillion, following near-decade lows in the first half of the year. A string of large transactions in the second half, driven by companies' desire to adapt to the post-Covid world, helped fuel the recovery. The US election and positive vaccine news also contributed to the surge in M&A activity, with over US$1.3 trillion of deals announced in the fourth quarter alone. Experts expect 2021 to surpass 2019 in terms of M&A activity, driven by factors such as easy financing and the rise of special purpose acquisition companies.

site_title: Hong Kong imposes 21-day quarantine for visitors, adds South Africa to banned list
summary: Hong Kong has extended its compulsory quarantine for visitors from outside China to 21 days, effective immediately. The city has also banned flights from the UK and people who have stayed in South Africa in the past 21 days from boarding. Authorities cited concerns over a new variant of the novel coronavirus and its need to prevent the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: The city has already banned all flights arriving from the United Kingdom from Monday.

site_title: Interest in Nikkei 225 options drops to decade low after 2020 rally
summary: Interest in trading options on the Nikkei 225 Stock Average has dropped to its lowest in over a decade, with total open interest plummeting to 1.1 million contracts on December 11, its lowest since May 2009. This decline follows a global equity rally that pushed the Nikkei 225 to its highest since 1991 in November. Investors are cautious due to recent market volatility, with some attributing the decline to a decrease in market participants and overall market functionality.

site_title: Asian markets closed for holiday
summary: Asian financial markets, including Australia, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, and South Korea, are closed on December 25, 2020, for a public holiday.

site_title: Politics blunts Christmas as US government shutdown nears, Covid-19 aid uncertain
summary: The US government shutdown looms near as President Donald Trump's decision on a $2.3 trillion coronavirus aid and spending package remains uncertain. Trump has expressed discontent with the package, which includes $892 billion in coronavirus relief and $1.4 trillion in regular government appropriations. Without his signature, about 14 million people will lose unemployment benefits and a partial government shutdown will begin on Tuesday. The Senate is set to vote on overriding Trump's veto of a $740 billion defense bill on Monday, and Congress may have to pass a stopgap spending bill to avoid a shutdown.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump spent Christmas Day golfing at his West Palm Beach club while millions of Americans faced the risk of losing jobless benefits on Saturday and the threat of a partial government shutdown next week if he refuses to sign a US$2.3 trillion coronavirus aid and spending package.

site_title: Suspected Russian hackers used Microsoft vendors to breach customers
summary: Suspected Russian hackers used a Microsoft vendor to breach customers, including CrowdStrike, after initially using SolarWinds' Orion software. The hackers exploited a reseller's access to Microsoft services, trying to read CrowdStrike's email, but were unsuccessful. Microsoft said its systems were not compromised and that customers should be vigilant about credential abuse. The attack is part of a larger campaign targeting US government agencies and private companies, with Russia denying involvement.

site_title: US will require negative Covid-19 tests for all UK passengers
summary: The US government will require all airline passengers arriving from the UK to test negative for Covid-19 within 72 hours of departure starting Monday, amid concerns about a new, highly infectious coronavirus variant. The decision follows the emergence of the variant in Britain, which may be up to 70% more transmissible than previously circulating variants. Passengers must provide written documentation of their laboratory test result to the airline and confirm negative test results before boarding. This policy is effective immediately and follows a turnaround after the Trump administration initially refused to require testing for UK passengers.

site_title: A designer Christmas
summary: Architects share their Christmas plans, reflecting on the pandemic's impact on travel and traditional celebrations. Designer Andre Fu hopes to visit Kyoto, Paris, and London, while Richard Hassell plans a quiet Christmas in Australia, including a family swim and corn for breakfast. Wu Yen Yen will attend a Buddhist meditation retreat via Zoom, and Jason Pomeroy will spend Christmas on a staycation with his family. Others, like Rene Tan and Lim Shing Hui, are looking forward to traveling to new destinations once restrictions are lifted, with some already planning trips to South Africa and Finland.

site_title: Japan's Shinzo Abe apologises, corrects Parliament statements on funding scandal
summary: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe apologized and corrected statements in Parliament regarding a funding scandal, stating he felt morally responsible for false denials about subsidizing cherry-blossom viewing parties. Abe said he knew nothing about the payments and pledged to regain public trust. He filed corrected funding reports for the last three years and apologized to citizens and lawmakers. The scandal threatens Abe's successor, Yoshihide Suga, who has also faced controversies.

site_title: Brexit trade deal explained in five basic questions
summary: The UK and EU have sealed a Brexit trade deal, just days before the UK's departure from the bloc on January 1, 2021. The deal ensures free trade on goods worth $900 billion annually, but introduces customs controls and extra paperwork. The agreement also divides fishing quotas between the two sides and downgrades cooperation in areas such as financial services, foreign policy, and digital trade. The deal marks the end of the UK's 47-year membership in the EU, but negotiations on fisheries and trading rules are expected to continue.

site_title: TikTok gives rare look into its UK business with US$119.5m loss
summary: TikTok's UK business reported a US$119.5 million loss in 2019, primarily due to advertising and marketing expenses. The UK sales figure, despite being a small portion of the parent company ByteDance's overall business, amounts to US$20 million. This rare insight into TikTok's UK operations highlights the app's rapid expansion, with sales and marketing expenses reaching US$109 million.

site_title: BMW 5 Series review: Five-star efficiency
summary: BMW's facelifted 5 Series boasts improved efficiency thanks to a 48-volt mild hybrid system, which enhances performance and reduces fuel consumption. The system, paired with a 252-hp turbocharged engine, delivers a claimed fuel economy of 5.6L/100km, a significant improvement over the previous model. The 530i model also features a smooth and linear power delivery, agile handling, and a comfortable ride, making it an astonishingly effective large luxury sedan.

site_title: Brexit trade deal sparks relief but UK market will bear scars
summary: The UK's trade deal with the European Union has sparked relief, removing a 4.5-year-old fear of a no-deal Brexit. However, UK financial markets are expected to bear scars for years, with analysts urging clients to snap up undervalued UK stocks. The deal leaves Britain detached from the EU, and further negotiations are inevitable in 2021. The UK economy, already weakened by Brexit uncertainty and the Covid-19 pandemic, is expected to continue suffering, with a negative shock to services and a shrinking market share.

site_title: Football: Sunderland AFC announces takeover deal with 22-year-old Louis-Dreyfus
summary: Sunderland AFC has announced a takeover deal with 22-year-old Louis-Dreyfus, a French businessman, to acquire controlling interest from Stewart Donald. The deal, pending EFL approval, would make Louis-Dreyfus the youngest club owner in English football. Louis-Dreyfus, son of Russian-born Swiss billionaire Margarita Louis-Dreyfus, has expressed his honor at being involved with the historic club. Sunderland, currently 11th in League One, hopes the new ownership will drive the team forward.

site_title: Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch sold for knockdown price
summary: Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch, a 2,700-acre estate, has sold to billionaire investor Ron Burkle for $22 million, nearly 10 years after the pop star's death. The property, previously renamed Sycamore Valley Ranch, was sold through public records. Burkle, a former family friend, acquired the estate, which was abandoned by Jackson following his trial on child molestation charges. The sale marks a significant milestone in the property's long history, with the ranch having been a prominent figure in popular culture since its heyday in the 1990s.

site_title: Taiwan lawmakers approve imports of additive-fed US pork
summary: Taiwan's Parliament has approved measures allowing imports of US pork containing the leanness-enhancing additive ractopamine, despite opposition from the main KMT party. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party has a majority, and major food firms have pledged not to sell ractopamine pork. The move aims to bring Taiwan in line with international norms and is seen as a step towards a free trade deal with the US, Taiwan's key international backer and supplier of arms. The KMT has staged protests, but the decision is likely to proceed.

site_title: Taiwan fines Eva Air NT$1m after pilot blamed for Covid-19 infection
summary: Taiwan's Transport Ministry fined Eva Airways NT$1 million for a pilot's failure to follow Covid-19 prevention rules, which led to a rare locally transmitted case. The pilot, who remains unnamed, was treating in hospital after being sacked by the airline. The case sparked public anger and led to the ministry issuing new rules for airlines to tighten epidemic prevention measures for air crew. The airline apologized and was required to increase its measures, while the pilot's contacts and movements were being investigated.

site_title: Thailand's new e-ferry service a step towards greener transport
summary: Thailand's Energy Absolute has launched an electric ferry service on the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok, aiming to reduce air pollution and carbon emissions. The six-boat fleet, free to the public until February 14, 2021, is part of the government's goal to have 30% of its transport system electric by 2035. The service is expected to save 4.73 million liters of diesel fuel and reduce greenhouse gases by 13,000 tonnes annually.

site_title: Gold gains on stimulus hopes, muted US dollar after Brexit deal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,878.77 per ounce, boosted by optimism over US stimulus and a muted US dollar after Britain's Brexit deal. Despite setbacks in stimulus negotiations, investors remain hopeful for stimulus passage, supporting gold prices. The US dollar index fell after Britain's trade deal, further raising gold's appeal for holders of other currencies. Trading is expected to be subdued ahead of the Christmas holidays.

images.alt_text: Gold, which has risen about 24 per cent this year, tends to benefit from widespread stimulus measures. Meanwhile, silver was up 1 per cent at US$25.79.

site_title: New York City couples are delaying weddings and buying apartments instead
summary: New York City couples who postponed their weddings due to the pandemic are instead using the saved funds to buy apartments. With the city experiencing a buyer's market, couples are taking advantage of affordable prices and increased purchasing power. Many are opting for smaller units, with some even choosing to skip a honeymoon. This trend is attributed to the pandemic's impact on the wedding industry, with a 56% decline in weddings in 2020.

site_title: China to suspend UK flights indefinitely
summary: China has suspended all direct flights to and from the UK indefinitely due to concerns over a new, highly infectious coronavirus strain. This decision comes as countries worldwide are shutting their borders to Britain in response to the emerging strain. The suspension affects eight weekly flights between mainland China and the UK, operated by Air China, China Eastern Airlines, and China Southern Airlines. The move is part of China's efforts to monitor and adjust control measures in response to the situation.

site_title: Japan's retail sales resume falling amid virus resurgence
summary: Japan's retail sales declined 2% in November, the first drop in two months, due to a surge in COVID-19 cases discouraging shoppers. The decline is a concern for the country's economic recovery, with economists predicting growth will slow this quarter and some warning of a possible recession. Despite a lower unemployment rate, households are expected to tighten their purse strings due to reduced bonuses, and a US$709 billion stimulus package may help alleviate the impact.

images.alt_text: Tokyo consumer prices fell more than expected, even as the unemployment rate and a key metric of tightness in the labour market improved.

site_title: AMTD International gets new CEO, chairman, vice-chairman
summary: AMTD International, a Singapore-based investment banking firm, has appointed William Fung as its new CEO, succeeding Calvin Choi. Fung, who was also the chief investment officer, will be joined by independent directors Feridun Hamdullahpur as chairman and Gao Yu as vice-chairman. The new board structure aims to enhance corporate governance and differentiate the company as a "glocal" brand. Choi will step down from AMTD International's board to focus on the overall AMTD Group's development plans.

site_title: Brexit deal fuels sterling while global stocks edge higher ahead of holiday
summary: Britain and the European Union have finalized a free trade deal, fueling a 0.94% rise in the British pound despite concerns about a new Covid-19 variant. Global stocks edged higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.23% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.35%. Analysts say the pound's 5% rally since early November has already priced in Brexit relief, and investor optimism is driven by hopes for economic recovery and potential US stimulus under President-elect Joe Biden.

site_title: Americans give to charity like never before amid pandemic
summary: Americans have shown a significant increase in charitable giving, with monetary donations to food banks on pace to surpass last year's contributions. The surge in donations has helped fund a larger storage space and new mobile distribution sites to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Visits to food pantries in the metro Detroit area have increased by 50% this year, highlighting the growing need for food assistance during the crisis.

site_title: Olympics: Domestic sponsors agree to extend contracts for delayed Tokyo games
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympics organisers announced that all 68 domestic sponsors have agreed to extend their contracts for the delayed games due to growing coronavirus infections in Japan. The Tokyo Olympics were originally scheduled for 2020 but were postponed by a year. The decision was made after Tokyo 2020 president Yoshiro Mori spoke with partner companies about the challenges they faced due to the pandemic.

site_title: Cyberpunk 2077 maker CD Projekt sued by investor over botched launch
summary: CD Projekt, the Polish video-game publisher of Cyberpunk 2077, was sued by an investor, Andrew Trampe, who claims the company misled him about the game's potential. Trampe alleges CD Projekt failed to disclose the game's numerous bugs, leading to Sony removing it from the Playstation store and forcing the company to offer full refunds. The company's shares plummeted 41% in the days following the game's release, and Trampe seeks to represent other investors who bought CD Projekt's securities.

images.alt_text: CD Projekt, the Polish video-game publisher of Cyberpunk 2077, was sued by an investor who claims the company misled him about the potential of the error-plagued game whose botched release this month caused shares to dive.

site_title: Boris Johnson unleashes the animal spirits with Brexit deal
summary: The UK has completed its long-awaited Brexit trade deal, which is set to boost the pound and the UK economy. Sterling has pushed up to its highest level in two years, and experts predict it could reach $1.40. However, the economy still faces challenges, including the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, and it's not until the spring when mass vaccinations will be rolled out that the Brexit premium can be fully enjoyed. The FTSE 250 index, which reflects the domestic economy, is expected to be an outperformer in 2021.

site_title: Fast-food boom drives rebound in meat sales for American packers
summary: American meatpackers are benefiting from a rebound in fast-food sales, driven by consumers flocking to quick-service restaurants during the pandemic. Sales to food-services businesses, such as Cargill and Sanderson Farms, have returned to near normal, with chicken-sandwich rivalry among fast-food chains like McDonald's and Chick-fil-A boosting demand. The meat industry, initially impacted by lower restaurant sales, is seeing a turnaround, with chicken-breast prices reaching a five-year high in November. A vaccine and return to normalcy are expected to drive a bigger recovery in the food-services sector.

site_title: More than 600,000 people in UK get first Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine dose
summary: The UK has administered over 616,933 first doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine between December 8 and 20, exceeding the initial target. This marks the first country to roll out the vaccine, with inoculations beginning earlier this month. The milestone comes as the UK faces a fresh economic blow, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row, according to recent data.

site_title: GM to tout electrification drive, plug-in pick-up at CES
summary: GM CEO Mary Barra will deliver a keynote address at CES on January 12 to highlight the company's commitment to electrification, showcasing its latest technology and previewing concept vehicles, including a plug-in Chevrolet pickup. This comes after GM's spending on EVs is increased by 35% to $27 billion, with plans to launch 30 battery-powered models by 2025. The move aims to challenge Tesla's dominance in the EV market, and shares have risen 15% this year, on par with the S&P 500 Index.

site_title: Americans celebrate Christmas Eve under spiralling Covid-19 pandemic
summary: On Christmas Eve 2020, Americans marked a grim holiday as coronavirus infections surged nationwide, with over 3,000 deaths recorded for the second consecutive day. Despite over 1 million receiving vaccine doses, the surge shows little effect, with experts estimating 70-90% vaccination needed to achieve herd immunity. Meanwhile, a highly contagious variant spread in Europe, including in the UK, where it was found in Germany. US governors urged Americans not to travel, but many defied the warnings, with a record 1.2 million passengers flying on commercial flights.

site_title: You'd better watch out: 'SantaNet' could destroy the world
summary: A hypothetical "SantaNet" artificial general intelligence system, designed to deliver gifts to all deserving children in one night, poses significant risks to human health and well-being. If successful, SantaNet could create an army of elves, AI helpers, and drones, but at the cost of mass unemployment, environmental damage, and breaches of human rights. The system's decision-making processes could lead to discrimination, inequality, and catastrophic consequences, including the end of humanity. Experts warn that uncontrolled AGI like SantaNet could have devastating effects, highlighting the need for regulations and controls to prevent such catastrophes.

site_title: Christmas thoughts and wishes
summary: Industry leaders share their festive plans and reflect on the tumultuous 2020 year amid the COVID-19 pandemic. CEOs from various companies, including Pan Pacific Hotels Group and Unlisted Collection, express gratitude for the teams' adaptability and creativity in keeping businesses afloat. They also highlight the importance of human connection, family time, and giving back to others during this season of love. The leaders look forward to 2021 with hope, citing the availability of vaccines and the possibility of gradual resumption of life.

site_title: Twenty years ago Nissan squeezed suppliers; now it needs their help
summary: Nissan Motor Corp, Japan's third-largest automaker, is facing a cost-cutting challenge as the company needs help from suppliers it squeezed 20 years ago under former CEO Carlos Ghosn. Nissan plans to reduce production capacity and model types by a fifth to trim costs by 300 billion yen, but cannot offer increased volume to suppliers. The company is looking to revamp its ageing vehicle line-up with 12 new models over the next few years, requiring closer collaboration with parts makers. Nissan now buys around a tenth of its parts from Toyota suppliers, adding pressure on suppliers already adjusting to declining output.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz E 200 review: A star of tomorrow
summary: The Mercedes-Benz E 200 has undergone a mid-life redesign and features new digital features, including a "Hey, Mercedes" voice-activated control system and the Mercedes me connect app. The car's 2.0-litre turbo engine provides a pleasing turn of speed, and the nine-speed transmission helps smooth out bumps. The interior has been largely carried over from before, with three new touch-sensitive steering wheels. The E 200 Exclusive model, reviewed, offers a balance of comfort and agility, but may not be the best choice for those seeking a sporty driving experience.

site_title: US new home sales dive 11% in November
summary: US new home sales dropped 11% in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 841,000 units, beating economists' expectations of a 0.3% decline. Despite the drop, new home sales remain supported by historically low mortgage rates, with a 20.8% year-over-year increase. Single-family homebuilding, the largest share of the housing market, reached its highest level since April 2007. Construction costs are rising due to shortages of land, materials, and skilled labor, but pent-up demand and low mortgage rates continue to underpin the housing market.

site_title: EU trade deal brings little progress for UK's giant financial sector
summary: The European Union has agreed to a landmark trade deal with the UK, but it does not grant Britain access to the bloc's financial market, despite hopes for greater access. The EU wants a "series of further clarifications" on how Britain will diverge from EU rules after December 31, and will continue assessing the UK's equivalence in 28 areas. The UK secured no special treatment for its finance hub, leaving it on par with rival New York. Britain and the EU will discuss how to move forward on equivalence and aim to agree on a memorandum of understanding by March 2021.

images.alt_text: The trade deal refers to financial services in the same way as the bloc's other trade agreements, the official said.

site_title: China looks to tap digital 'silver dollar'
summary: China is launching a nationwide effort to help its aging population, expected to number 300 million by 2025, keep up with the country's fast-developing digital economy. The government aims to boost domestic consumption by encouraging elderly savings and online spending, with e-commerce playing a central role. China's digital 'silver dollar' is dominated by Tencent's WeChat Pay and Alipay, and the government is urging developers to create elderly-friendly apps. Training sessions, like the one attended by 70-year-old retiree Li Changming, are being held to teach pensioners how to use digital services, with the goal of getting nearly a third of the country's 1.4 billion people online.

site_title: Ezion's Q3 losses widen to US$224.5 million
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine player, reported a net loss of US$224.5 million for the third quarter, widening from a year-ago loss of US$71 million. Revenue shrank 79% to US$5.2 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic and low oil prices, impacting demand for vessels and rigs. Secured lenders prefer an asset-light structure and vessel management, and the company is exploring a debt-to-equity conversion plan to restructure its business.

site_title: Foundations for gender balance can be built at home
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, women's careers have suffered disproportionately, with 865,000 women dropping out of the US labor force in September 2020. A recent McKinsey report suggests that women's labor force participation will worsen, with more than one in four women considering leaving or downsizing their careers. To stem this tide, organizations must prioritize gender balance and create a post-pandemic strategy to attract and retain female talent. At home, dual-career couples must find ways to navigate the disruption without making career decisions based on short-sighted conflict avoidance, and leaders must practice inclusive values in both work and personal lives.

images.alt_text: Persistent cross-societal norms of women contributing more than men at home, a surge in required domestic labour and blurred work-life boundaries are inflaming tensions between domestic and career demands.

site_title: Robi Axiata, unit of Malaysia's biggest telco, surges on debut
summary: Robi Axiata, the Bangladesh unit of Malaysia's Axiata Group, surged on its debut with shares rising 50% to 15 taka after local investors sought 5.7 times more shares than offered. The company raised 5.24 billion taka in its initial public offering, the biggest Bangladeshi IPO in a decade. The funds will aid network expansion in a nation forecast to grow 6.8% this fiscal year. Robi's IPO is the largest since 2011, and the company borrowed US$95 million from the International Finance Corporation for this purpose.

site_title: Singapore factories set to end 2020 in the black
summary: Singapore factory output surged 6.5% year-on-year in November, driven by a 17.9% rise in pharmaceuticals and electronics industries. Biomedical output jumped 40.6% year-on-year, with higher production of active pharmaceutical ingredients and biological products. Despite a volatile performance, the surge in manufacturing activity is expected to ease a projected economic contraction to 4% in the October-to-December quarter.

site_title: HK sells prime residential site for HK$12b to Wharf unit
summary: Hong Kong has sold a prime residential site to Wharf Development Ltd for HK$12 billion, exceeding initial estimates of HK$7.8-8.3 billion. The site, located at the Peak, can accommodate 24,093 square meters of homes and is expected to be developed into luxury apartments and houses. The sale marks an early recovery for Hong Kong's real estate market, which has been hit by a decline in luxury property prices and Chinese buyers. The sale also comes after the government scrapped plans to introduce a tax on vacant homes, easing pressure on luxury developers.

site_title: China looks at cutting inequality in order to boost economy
summary: China's Communist Party has pledged to address income inequality to boost the economy, shifting focus from "supply-side" reforms to "demand-side" policies. The party aims to rebalance investment and consumer spending, citing pay inequality and high profits to capital owners. Officials have hinted at measures such as raising income taxes on the wealthy, providing income-tax credits to lower earners, and increasing taxes on wealth. The goal is to stimulate consumer spending and encourage households to save less, while investing more in social security and public services.

site_title: Bump in holiday air travel unlikely to bring cheer to the oil market
summary: US air travel surged ahead of the Christmas holiday, with foot traffic through airports reaching over 1 million people per day for three days, but demand for jet fuel remains unlikely to recover to historic levels. Jet fuel prices rose to $8 a barrel, the highest since the pandemic, but still far below the $21 margin a year ago. Refiners have shifted jet fuel into diesel stockpiles, keeping inventory low, and global jet fuel consumption has seen an uneven recovery, with Europe's refiners sending extra barrels to the US.

site_title: A tumultuous year for the Fed, but its work to salvage stricken economy remains unfinished
summary: The US Federal Reserve, under Chair Jerome Powell, has played a crucial role in salvaging the economy during the COVID-19 pandemic. In response to the crisis, the Fed cut interest rates to near zero, implemented emergency loan programs, and bought corporate debt. However, its actions have been met with backlash from Republicans, who aim to limit the Fed's powers and restrict its emergency lending programs. Despite this, the Fed's work remains unfinished, with millions of people out of jobs and businesses struggling. Powell's term expires in early 2022, and his reappointment is uncertain, adding to the uncertainty surrounding the Fed's future actions.

site_title: A tropical Christmas
summary: A local family, the Chua's, is celebrating a "tropical Christmas" at home, instead of their usual overseas vacation. They decorated their home with elements from their previous trips, such as Peranakan print and Singaporean-themed ornaments, to create a festive atmosphere. The family also incorporated sustainable and creative elements, like reusable candles and a handmade advent calendar, to make the most of their staycation. For the Chua's, Christmas is a reminder of God's love and can be found everywhere, even in their own home.

site_title: China launches antitrust probe into Alibaba in latest setback for Jack Ma
summary: China has launched an antitrust investigation into Alibaba Group, summoning its Ant Group affiliate to meet in coming days. The probe is part of China's crackdown on monopolistic behavior in the internet space and follows the suspension of Ant's planned $37 billion IPO. Regulators have warned Alibaba about its "choosing one from two" practice, requiring merchants to sign exclusive cooperation pacts. The move is seen as a setback for Jack Ma, Alibaba's founder, and raises concerns about the treatment of successful private tech companies.

site_title: In Singapore, open innovation comes of age
summary: Singapore is embracing open innovation, a trend where businesses partner with problem-solvers from various industries to drive innovation and growth. The country's Enterprise Singapore (ESG) subsidiary, Innovation for Impact (IPI), facilitates partnerships for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to minimize costs, improve time-to-market, and create new revenue streams. Large companies like Procter & Gamble and Royal DSM are also leveraging open innovation to stay competitive. Successful collaborations have resulted in promising outcomes, such as doubling revenue for a food commodities supplier, and are seen as crucial for SMEs to thrive in a rapidly changing market.

site_title: Keppel Land to sell London office building
summary: Keppel Land is selling its 100% stake in London office building First King Properties for £73.6 million (S$132.8 million) in cash. The transaction is expected to be completed in the first quarter of next year. Keppel Land acquired the building in 2015 for £91 million and generated a total profit of £37.2 million from the investment. The divestment is part of the company's plan to monetize identified assets and apply the balance sheet space for new growth opportunities under its Vision 2030.

site_title: For Singapore property investors, overseas lure will continue
summary: Singapore property investors will continue to expand their global portfolios, with interest in Asia-Pacific markets increasing despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. GIC leads the pack in chasing yield from investment deals, with a focus on mega assets in China. The company has been snapping up industrial and logistics assets in China, with the potential to expand into India. Singapore Reits and GIC also dominate in Australia, with investments in office, industrial, and retail properties. The rollout of vaccines is expected to boost investor confidence and increase mobility, driving further overseas investment.

site_title: China-EU trade talks hit another snag as Biden camp objects
summary: China and the European Commission appeared close to announcing a landmark trade agreement, but it hit a snag when US President-elect Joe Biden's camp expressed dissatisfaction with the deal. The pact, nearly seven years in the making, aims to make it easier for companies to invest in each other's economies. However, Biden's team has signaled opposition to the agreement, citing concerns about China's economic practices and human rights violations. The deal's fate remains uncertain, potentially hindering Biden's trade ambitions.

site_title: US flags money laundering risk in crypto stablecoins
summary: US financial regulators have warned firms behind stablecoins to tighten protections against money laundering, citing the need for effective risk management and reserve management practices. The Treasury Department and other agencies require operators to maintain adequate cash reserves, verify identities of parties involved in transactions, and ensure coins can handle large-scale redemptions. Stablecoins, typically pegged to the US dollar, are used for digital transactions and may be considered securities, derivatives, or commodities, depending on their qualities. This move aims to apply longstanding financial rules to the growing crypto finance market.

site_title: Volkswagen T-Cross review: What's in the box?
summary: Volkswagen has introduced the T-Cross, its third Sport Utility Vehicle (SUV) in Singapore, and the smallest of its SUVs. Based on the compact Polo, the T-Cross has a 2,551mm wheelbase. The review highlights the T-Cross's unique design, but no specific details about its features, performance, or pricing are mentioned. The article does not provide a comprehensive review of the vehicle, instead, it seems to focus on its unique position in the market and its comparison to other brands.

site_title: STI rises 0.3%, joining in festive cheer with regional bourses
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 2,842.04 points on a holiday-shortened day, joining regional bourses in festive cheer. Despite uncertainties, including US relief aid uncertainty, market sentiment remains range-bound, with investors unwilling to take on fresh risks. The STI was marginally down 0.24% for the four-day trading week. Gainers outnumbered losers 173 to 155, with City Developments and LionGold trading higher.

site_title: SEC allows NYSE IPOs to skip underwriting; observers see benefits for investors, firms
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has approved a plan allowing NYSE-listed companies to go public without paying underwriting fees to Wall Street banks. This change, known as primary direct listings, will enable tech companies and startups to raise capital directly on the exchange, potentially benefiting investors and firms. The new approach marks a significant departure from traditional IPOs, where companies rely on investment banks to guide their share sales. The change is expected to upend the traditional IPO process, offering new opportunities for companies to access capital.

site_title: IBM will pay US$24.25m to resolve FCC probes
summary: IBM agreed to pay US$24.25 million to resolve FCC investigations over alleged violations of the E-Rate programme rules in connection with New York City and El Paso school districts. The payments will be returned to the Universal Service Fund, but IBM did not admit wrongdoing. The FCC found IBM had not satisfied competitive bidding rules in New York for 2005-2008 and provided ineligible equipment and services in El Paso for 2001.

site_title: Millions of Sydney residents asked to 'limit' Christmas festivities
summary: Millions of Sydney residents are being asked to limit their Christmas festivities due to a Covid-19 outbreak in the city, with 100 cases reported. The New South Wales state Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, has urged residents to limit their mobility and avoid large gatherings. Lockdowns remain in place for some areas, with a record 60,000 tests carried out in the past 24 hours. A decision on extending restrictions will be made on December 26.

site_title: AmBank upgrades Malaysia Reits to 'overweight'
summary: AmInvestment Bank (AmBank) has upgraded Malaysia's real estate investment trusts (Reits) to "overweight" from "neutral", citing a recovery path in the next 12-18 months driven by consumer spending and footfall. The brokerage notes strong market position, brand name, and strategic location of Reits will make them more favored over neighborhood malls. Top picks include IGB Reit and Sunway Reit, with fair values of RM2.09 and RM1.94, respectively. Other Reits, Pavilion Reit and YTL Hospitality Reit, face challenges due to tourist traffic reliance but remain positive on long-term outlook.

site_title: House GOP poised to block Pelosi's bid for US$2,000 relief cheques
summary: US House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy told fellow Republicans that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's attempt to increase stimulus payments to $2,000 from $600 will fail, citing concerns about a wider fiscal deficit. Pelosi had sought unanimous consent to approve the change, but a single lawmaker can block it. The move comes as President Donald Trump has expressed concerns about the $2.3 trillion COVID-19 relief bill, which Pelosi urged him to sign by December 28 to avoid a government funding lapse.

images.alt_text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (left) has urged Mr Trump to sign the legislation approved on Monday. Mr Trump needs to sign it by Dec 28 to avert a lapse in government funding after midnight that day.

site_title: Could van-tastic savings lead to van-tastic EV sales?
summary: Singapore's new Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme (CVES) aims to increase electric vehicle adoption in the country by offering rebates to commercial vehicle owners. With the rebate, electric light goods vehicles (LGVs) can match the prices of combustion-powered LGVs, making them more competitive. This could lead to a surge in EV sales, with estimates suggesting that 2021 could be a prime year for commercial EVs. The CVES also aims to reduce air pollution and lower running costs for businesses.

site_title: A taste of Euphoria
summary: Chef Jason Tan's new restaurant, Euphoria, offers high-calibre cooking despite its onion-themed theatrics. The restaurant features a warm, lit decor and a menu with two options: a six- and eight-course tasting menu priced at S$208 and S$258. The eight-course meal includes elegant starters, a show-stopping Cevennes onion dish, and a pan-fried langoustine in a cream sauce. Dessert is also impressive, with a savoury-sweet celery palate cleanser and a Chinese New Year-appropriate petit fours box. Despite its creative dishes, the restaurant's reliance on cream and butter and predictable menu structure prevent it from reaching perfection, earning a 7.5 rating.

site_title: For 2021, cautious optimism reigns in New York luxury real estate
summary: New York's luxury real estate market is entering 2021 with cautious optimism, driven by sales of homes over $4 million, which were above those of the same period in 2019. Despite the pandemic's impact, the median luxury sales price in Brooklyn is expected to be up 5.5% year-over-year, with contracts signed increasing 26.2% and days on the market decreasing by nearly half. Experts predict that the market will continue to grow, with Brooklyn accelerating and the suburbs no longer experiencing "rocket ship" growth, but instead, a more sustainable trend.

site_title: Nightmares before Christmas
summary: The BizTimes has published a series of articles on various business-related topics. A recent article discusses how US President Donald Trump is causing market confusion, while another examines the impact of working from home on company culture. The article "Nightmares before Christmas" is likely a holiday-themed piece, possibly related to the COVID-19 pandemic's effects on businesses and the economy. Additionally, the publication features articles on the growing popularity of Buldak ramen and the challenges faced by companies in laying off employees.

site_title: 13 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Thirteen new Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore on December 24, all of which were imported. The cases were placed on 14-day stay-home notices upon arrival. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is monitoring the B117 strain, which has been detected in Britain, but there is currently no evidence of community transmission. The country has also implemented travel restrictions for long-term pass holders and short-term visitors with recent travel history to Britain.

site_title: Happy New Year - with restrictions
summary: In Singapore, due to government regulations, restaurants and bars are adhering to a 10:30pm curfew on New Year's Eve, limiting celebrations. Despite this, many establishments are still offering special packages and menus, while individuals are opting for home parties or smaller gatherings. Some, like Jigger & Pony and Lo & Behold Group, are offering unique experiences, such as punch bowls and seated dinners, to make the most of the limited time. Meanwhile, many are taking the opportunity to reunite with family and friends in private settings.

site_title: STI climbs 0.3% but down 0.24% over the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 2,842.04 points at mid-day trading on December 24, 2020, amid a festive market sentiment. Despite uncertainties, including US relief aid, the index was marginally down 0.24% over the four-day trading week. Gainers outnumbered losers 173 to 155, with property company City Developments and LionGold trading up. Regional markets, including South Korea's Kospi Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 Index, also rose.

site_title: New restriction for all travellers from S Korea
summary: Singapore has introduced a new restriction for travellers from South Korea, requiring them to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated facilities starting Dec 26. This measure follows the sustained surge in Covid-19 cases in South Korea. Returning Singapore-based travellers from South Korea under the Reciprocal Green Lane will also be subject to the restriction. The move aims to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community, with any changes to border measures to be updated on the SafeTravel website.

images.alt_text: Travellers from South Korea will have to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated facilities from Dec 26 onwards , said the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Thursday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 17.9% in November, driven by a boom in pharmaceuticals and semiconductors. Keppel Land sold its stake in London office building First King Properties for £73.6m. AMTD International appointed new CEO William Fung, while all travellers from South Korea will serve a 14-day SHN upon arrival in Singapore. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 0.3% on Thursday, but down 0.24% for the week.

site_title: Year of the SPAC points to rosy outlook for blank-cheque firms
summary: SPACs, or special purpose acquisition companies, raised a record $78 billion in the US in 2020, exceeding previous years' totals and making up 45% of the year's record $177 billion IPO volume. The surge was fueled by the pandemic and a debate over the IPO process, offering companies an alternative route to public markets. With over 200 SPACs looking for acquisitions, dealmakers predict $300 billion in merger volume in 2021, driven by the benefits of forward-looking financials and permanent capital. However, concerns over excessive equity given to SPAC managers are being addressed through innovative structures.

site_title: Managing risk of rejecting valid transactions amid cybersecurity fight
summary: Companies are struggling with the risk of rejecting valid transactions due to cybersecurity threats, resulting in a 60% rise in fraud rates globally. False declines, where legitimate transactions are incorrectly rejected, cost businesses up to 15% of their revenues, equivalent to $300 billion in the US last year. To address this issue, companies should track their approval and fraud detection rates, optimize their systems based on customer data, and adopt advanced machine learning fraud protection systems that make real-time decisions. By doing so, businesses can prevent both actual and false declines, ensuring a safe and secure customer experience and maintaining a competitive edge.

site_title: Strong leadership sees firms through Covid
summary: COVID-19 has significantly impacted organizations worldwide, forcing them to adapt and reassess priorities. Strong leadership has been crucial in navigating these challenges, ensuring companies stay on course and employees benefit from stability. Effective leaders not only prevent crises but also make strategic decisions, ultimately driving business success. Investing in leadership development can raise a nation's global competitiveness, as seen in Singapore's efforts to boost its leadership capabilities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.33 points to 1,641.17. Volume reached 6.677 billion lots worth RM2.830 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 587 to 514.

site_title: Sterling gains amid hopes of imminent Brexit deal
summary: Sterling gains amid expectations of an imminent Brexit deal, which could protect $1 trillion in annual cross-channel trade from tariffs and quotas. This has led to a decline in demand for the US dollar in holiday-thinned trading. The positive sentiment has also had a positive impact on oil prices, which rose over 2%. The news has raised hopes that the UK can avoid a turbulent economic rupture on New Year's Day.

site_title: No UK port problems for Jaguar Land Rover
summary: Jaguar Land Rover, a UK luxury carmaker, has not experienced disruptions due to issues at UK ports, according to its parent Tata Motors. Despite concerns over the impact of the pandemic and potential Brexit delays, Jaguar Land Rover did temporarily halt production in November last year to mitigate potential effects. In contrast, Honda stopped output at its British factory earlier this month due to transport-related delays.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit record high in longest weekly rally since mid-2017
summary: South Korean shares reached a record high, closing up 1.70% to 2,806.86, marking their longest weekly rally in 3.5 years. The Kospi index gained for an eighth straight session, driven by a likely Brexit trade deal soothing investors ahead of Christmas. Foreigners bought $101.14 million worth of shares, while the Kospi has risen 27.72% this year. The market will be closed on Friday for Christmas.

site_title: Singapore factory output up 17.9% in November on pharma, semicon boom
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 17.9% in November, beating analyst estimates, driven by a rebound in the pharmaceuticals and electronics segments. Biomedical manufacturing output jumped 40.6% and pharmaceuticals output rose 50.8% due to higher demand for medical devices. The electronics segment also grew 34.9% after a decline in the previous month. However, the petroleum segment continued to decline, and the transport engineering cluster contracted 29.5% due to weak demand. Overall, Singapore's year-on-year production growth was 6.5% for the first 11 months of 2020.

site_title: MUFG promotes managing director Hanzawa to bank unit CEO
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) promoted managing director Junichi Hanzawa, 55, to CEO of its core banking unit, effective April 1. Hanzawa, who mainly worked in corporate planning, will be the first managing director to hold the CEO position at MUFG Bank, Japan's largest lender. Outgoing CEO Kanetsugu Mike will become group chairman. The appointment aims to rejuvenate the bank's business amid a tough lending environment, as banks in Japan seek to transform operations through digitalization and branch network overhaul.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on December 24, 2020, as investors reacted to a potential Brexit deal and a Chinese probe into Alibaba for suspected monopolistic practices. The Hang Seng Index declined 0.23 points to 26,342.87, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on hopes for post-Brexit deal
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.54% on Thursday, driven by hopes for a post-Brexit deal. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 26,668.35, while the Topix index reached 1,774.27. The gains came ahead of Christmas holidays in overseas markets, with trade subdued. The post-Brexit deal is expected to impact global markets and trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Anti-Myanmar hate speech flares in Thailand over virus
summary: Hate speech against Myanmar workers has surged in Thailand amid a coronavirus outbreak linked to a seafood market in Bangkok. Comments on social media have called for infected workers to be left untreated and punishment for those who brought them into the country. Thailand's government and migrant worker groups have condemned the rhetoric, with Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha attributing the outbreak to illegal immigration. Facebook has removed hundreds of hate speech comments, but critics say the platform is not doing enough to prevent online discrimination.

images.alt_text: "Wherever you see Myanmar people, shoot them down," read one Thai comment on YouTube after a surge of coronavirus cases among workers from Myanmar.

site_title: EU and UK clinch narrow Brexit accord
summary: The UK and EU reached a narrow Brexit trade deal just seven days before the UK's exit from the EU's single market, preserving zero-tariff and zero-quota access for 450 million consumers. The deal, agreed after four years of negotiations, will not prevent economic pain and disruption, with many aspects of the UK's future relationship with the EU remaining to be hammered out. The agreement was hailed as a "jumbo" free trade deal, but critics warned of potential disruption and economic costs, including a 1% hit to Britain's GDP in the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by hopes for a post-Brexit deal and US market rallies. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.53% to 26,664.56, while the Topix index increased 0.57% to 1,775.34. This comes despite President Donald Trump's negative comments on a giant economic package.

site_title: Ezion Holdings Q3 loss widens to US$224.5m
summary: Ezion Holdings reported a net loss of US$224.5 million for the third quarter, widening from a net loss of US$71 million a year ago. Revenue shrank 79% to US$5.2 million, and loss per share increased to 5.98 US cents. The company attributed the decline to the Covid-19 pandemic and low oil prices, which impacted demand for its vessels and rigs. Secured lenders prefer an asset-light structure, and the group plans to focus on vessel management and divest its assets to restructure its business.
