site_title: Kuroda to seek ways to make stimulus 'nimble'
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda announced the central bank's planned policy examination aims to make its stimulus programme "nimble" to counter future economic shocks, such as the coronavirus crisis. The examination will assess the effectiveness of the central bank's yield curve control policy and operations, with the goal of achieving the 2% inflation target while minimizing costs and side effects. Kuroda emphasized the need for the BOJ to be prepared to respond effectively to future changes in economic conditions. The examination's findings will be announced in March.

site_title: Brexiteer Farage says UK will be too closely aligned to EU
summary: Nigel Farage, a Brexit campaigner, expressed concerns that the UK will remain too closely aligned to EU rules after Prime Minister Boris Johnson clinched a trade deal. Farage stated that the deal is better than the previous situation but not good enough for the UK to become a "dynamic booming economy like Singapore." He also hoped that the deal marks the beginning of the end of the European Union.

site_title: India challenges Vodafone arbitration ruling in Singapore: source
summary: India has challenged a Singapore arbitration court's ruling in favor of Vodafone Group, which awarded the company $2 billion in a tax dispute. The ruling, made in September, found India's tax claim on Vodafone to be in breach of an investment treaty. This is the second international arbitration case India has lost this week, following a $1.2 billion ruling against Cairn Energy over a tax dispute. India has faced multiple arbitrations by investors over issues including retrospective taxation and payment disputes.

site_title: Apollo casino deal is approved after bid lifted to US$1.9b
summary: Apollo Global Management Inc. won shareholder approval for its US$1.9 billion takeover of Great Canadian Gaming Corp, with 79% of shares voting in favor. The deal, which was initially met with opposition, was increased to C$45 a share after Apollo boosted its initial bid of C$39. The acquisition is expected to close in the second quarter and needs regulatory approval. Apollo plans to maintain Great Canadian's operations and expand non-gaming facilities to drive growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump on signs Brexit deal almost at hand
summary: European stocks rose on Thursday, with the STOXX 600 index gaining 0.1% and the FTSE 100 climbing 0.2%, as a Brexit trade deal seemed almost at hand with just a week left for Britain's exit from the EU. Sources in London and Brussels indicated a narrow agreement had been reached, averting an acrimonious split. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson held a late-night conference call with his Cabinet, and negotiators in Brussels worked on finalizing the agreement. The news boosted market sentiment ahead of the Christmas holidays.

site_title: China issues rules on social credit system amid public concerns
summary: China has issued guidelines for its social credit system, addressing public concerns over data management and invasion of privacy. The system aims to promote trust in companies and individuals by assessing their trustworthiness through data collection. The guidelines emphasize handling data according to law, learning from global experience, and following international standards. China will focus on supervising financial institutions and regulating the collection, storage, and use of personal information. The government aims to create a "fair and honest market environment" through the social credit system's development.

images.alt_text: China has issued guidelines on developing its social credit system, which is aimed at promoting trust in companies and individuals, amid public concerns over data management and invasion of privacy.

site_title: Broker's take: AmBank upgrades Malaysia Reits to 'overweight'
summary: AmInvestment Bank (AmBank) has upgraded Malaysia's real estate investment trusts (Reits) to "overweight" from "neutral", citing a recovery path in the next 12-18 months. The sector is expected to benefit from strong consumer spending and footfall recovery, driven by the development of vaccines and international travel. AmBank's top picks are IGB Reit and Sunway Reit, which it believes will lead the recovery due to their resilient local footfall and mass affluent customers. The brokerage has set fair values for the Reits, with IGB Reit at RM2.09 and Sunway Reit at RM1.94.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Asian peers higher on likely Brexit trade deal
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,676.50, boosted by a potential Brexit deal that would avoid Britain crashing out of the EU without a trade pact. The energy sector, driven by higher oil prices, contributed to the gains. Financial stocks and mining stocks also rose, with BHP Group climbing 2.3% and Rio Tinto adding over 1%. The Australian benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index reached its best session since November 25.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.16% to 26,386.56, driven by hopes of a soon-to-be-signed post-Brexit trade deal. However, Alibaba's decline after a China anti-monopoly probe into the ecommerce giant tempered gains. Investors broke up early for Christmas, closing the trading session.

site_title: China launches probe into Alibaba over monopoly allegations
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation has launched an investigation into Alibaba Group Holding over alleged monopolistic practices, escalating scrutiny of the country's internet giants. The probe follows pressure on Alibaba and rival Tencent Holdings, which have amassed hundreds of millions of users and gained significant influence over daily life in China. Regulators have also summoned affiliate Ant Group to a meeting to promote fair competition and consumer rights. The move marks a significant escalation in regulatory pressure on the tech industry in China.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain ahead of Christmas as virus cases plateau
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, closing at 6,664.8, ahead of Christmas, as the country's most populous state, New South Wales, reported a steady decline in Covid-19 cases. The easing of virus curbs for the holiday period and gains in energy stocks, led by Woodside Petroleum and Santos, contributed to the gains. Despite a 0.2% weekly loss, the S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for a positive year.

site_title: All travellers from South Korea to serve 14-day SHN at dedicated facilities: MOH
summary: Travellers from South Korea will be required to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at dedicated facilities in Singapore starting from Saturday, following a sustained surge in Covid-19 cases in the country. This measure applies to both incoming and returning Singapore-based travellers under the Reciprocal Green Lane. The change reverses an earlier decision made on November 2, when travellers from South Korea were allowed to serve their SHN at home.

site_title: Sterling gains, US dollar on back foot amid hopes Brexit deal imminent
summary: Sterling gains 0.2% to $1.3525 as expectations of an imminent Brexit deal boost UK economic hopes. The US dollar slides 0.3% as hopes for a trade agreement protecting $1 trillion in annual trade from tariffs and quotas reduce demand for safe assets. The euro strengthens 0.1% to $1.22025, while the Aussie dollar jumps 0.8% to 75.802 US cents. A senior British government source suggests Prime Minister Boris Johnson is poised to do a trade deal with the EU, potentially averting a turbulent economic rupture on New Year's Day.

site_title: After catastrophic year, Bollywood hopes for a 2021 comeback
summary: Bollywood's 2020 was marred by the deaths of several industry luminaries, including Irrfan Khan, Rishi Kapoor, and composer Wajid Khan. The industry struggled to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to production shutdowns and the loss of thousands of livelihoods. Despite tentative resumptions of shoots, the sector faces ongoing challenges, including pandemic restrictions and declining cinema attendance. However, with eagerly-awaited films set for release in 2021, industry experts predict a "big, big bang" comeback for Bollywood.

site_title: South Korea to import J&J, Pfizer Covid-19 vaccines for 16m people
summary: South Korea has signed deals with Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson's Janssen to import COVID-19 vaccines for up to 16 million people. The country aims to vaccinate 85% of its 52 million population. Pfizer's two-dose vaccine will cover 10 million people, with shipments expected in the third quarter of 2021. Janssen doses will be added to the initial plan for 2-6 million people, with inoculation expected from the second quarter. The government has been under pressure to address the third wave of infections, reporting its second-highest daily tally of cases.

site_title: Japan's Peach Aviation may launch all-you-can-fly pass in 2021
summary: Japan's Peach Aviation is considering launching an all-you-can-fly domestic flight service next year, offering a one-month unlimited pass for around 20,000 yen (S$257). This would be the first time the industry has tried such a service, amid a sharp decline in travelers due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Gold steadies as soft US jobs data offsets Trump stimulus threat
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$1,872.60 per ounce as investors balanced elevated US jobless claims with US President Donald Trump's threat to veto a stimulus bill. Trump demanded $2,000 payments to Americans, which could offset a 1% gain in gold prices seen in the previous session. Despite a 23% gain this year, gold prices were influenced by soft US jobs data and consumer spending decline, as well as concerns over pandemic cases and vaccination efforts.

images.alt_text: Gold prices steadied on Thursday as investors balanced elevated US jobless claims that undermined a nascent economic recovery with US President Donald Trump's threat to veto a long-awaited stimulus bill.

site_title: Dubai sees economy shrinking 6.2% this year before 2021 growth
summary: Dubai's economy is expected to contract 6.2% this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on tourism and retail sectors. The emirate's GDP fell 10.8% in the first half of the year, with the UAE as a whole expected to see a 6% economic contraction. The decline is attributed to lower oil prices, which have contributed to a global economic slowdown. In contrast, Dubai's economy is expected to see 4% growth in 2021.

site_title: AMTD International gets new CEO, chairman, vice-chairman
summary: AMTD International has appointed William Fung as its new CEO, succeeding Calvin Choi, who will step down as chairman and vice-chairman. Independent directors Feridun Hamdullahpur and Gao Yu will take over as chairman and vice-chairman, respectively. The company has also seen significant growth, with assets under management exceeding $3.5 billion and over 100 international capital markets transactions executed in the past two years, raising over $22 billion in proceeds for Asian clients.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 2,837.47, driven by easing deflation in the country's economy, with core and headline inflation at -0.1% year-on-year. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 42, with Singtel advancing 0.9% and NetLink NBN Trust flat. US and regional equities rebounded, while European shares closed up 1.1% due to Brexit deal talks.

site_title: Silicon Valley wins as SEC allows new direct listing
summary: The SEC has approved a plan by the NYSE Group to allow companies to go public through "primary direct listings," bypassing traditional IPOs with underwriting fees. This move is expected to benefit startups and Silicon Valley, potentially reducing the gap between offering prices and stock prices on the first day of trading. Direct listings, previously limited, have been used by companies like Asana and Palantir, and are seen as a game-changer for capital markets, leveling the playing field for everyday investors.

images.alt_text: Palantir Technologies' headquarters in Denver, Colorado. In September, the data-mining company, founded by billionaire Peter Thiel, used a direct listing to go public.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, Keppel, SATS, ARA Logos, AMTD
summary: Ascendas Reit proposes acquiring a logistics property in Brisbane for A$70.3 million. Keppel Corporation divests its stake in a London office building for £73.6 million. SATS increases in-house dry ice production and enhances its cooling capabilities. ARA Logos Logistics Trust launches a preferential offering to raise S$50 million for Australian property acquisitions. AMTD International promotes William Fung as CEO and appoints new chairman and vice-chairman. The Singapore Exchange closes early for the Christmas holiday.

site_title: Trump pardons former campaign chairman Manafort, associate Roger Stone
summary: US President Donald Trump issued full pardons to former campaign chairman Paul Manafort, associate Roger Stone, and Charles Kushner on December 24, 2020. Manafort was convicted as part of the special counsel probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 US election. Trump had earlier commuted Stone's sentence. The pardons came amid a tumultuous year for Trump, who faced various investigations and controversies. The move sparked mixed reactions, with some viewing it as a reward for loyalty and others as an attempt to shield himself from accountability.

site_title: Sweden aims to convert empty stores and offices to plug housing shortfall
summary: Sweden is exploring converting empty commercial properties to address its housing shortage, with around 140,000 homes needed. The government is examining the possibility of repurposing empty stores and offices, driven by the shift towards online shopping and working from home. Simplifying complex building rules is also being considered. This move could ease pressure on the housing market, potentially replicable in other countries with shortages, including Britain and the Netherlands.

site_title: Why the past is not the future for Asian tourism
summary: Asian tourism is expected to recover in 2021, but with a shift towards more intentional, greener, and more focused travel. Post-pandemic travelers will prioritize their wellbeing, seeking meaningful encounters with different places and people. Vaccination will be a key factor in persuading people to travel safely, and travelers will demand authentic, sustainable, and environmentally-friendly experiences. The hospitality industry has an opportunity to cater to these changing priorities and rebuild travel and tourism in a way that protects the environment and supports local ecosystems, businesses, and communities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, up 0.42 points or 0.03% to 1,647.92. Trading volume reached 138.29 million lots worth RM57.75 million. Gainers outpaced losers 269 to 69. The market's performance comes after a series of US-EU trade talks and amid a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: New York luxury real estate could be a bargain in 2021
summary: New York's luxury real estate market is expected to enter 2021 with confidence, driven by sales of homes over $4 million that were slightly above those in the same period in 2019. Demand from New Yorkers and those in the New York metro area is expected to continue, despite unknowns such as vaccine rollouts and economic uncertainty. Brooklyn's luxury market is also expected to remain strong, with median prices and contracts signed expected to increase year-over-year. However, foreign buyers are unlikely to return until the vaccine is successfully deployed, and Manhattan's supply of new developments is expected to continue, potentially leading to discounts and deals.

site_title: More APAC firms tap loans linking rates to sustainable goals
summary: A growing number of borrowers in Asia Pacific are tapping loans linked to meeting sustainability goals, with 18 firms signing US$7.4 billion of such debt in 2020. This marks a significant increase from 16 companies raising US$7.5 billion last year, as demand for sustainability-linked loans and bonds surges. Despite concerns about the ethics of rewarding borrowers for missing sustainability targets, experts see the debt as providing an incentive for borrowers to improve their environmental, social, and governance performance, and the market is expected to continue growing in 2021, particularly in countries such as Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: Huawei executive wants Canada's bail conditions eased
summary: Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou's lawyers plan to ask Canadian authorities to ease her bail conditions, specifically daytime supervision outside of her curfew hours. Meng, facing US extradition on fraud and conspiracy charges, is currently under court-ordered house arrest in Vancouver. The request aims to provide more flexibility in her daily life while maintaining public safety.

site_title: How poor countries can avoid a vaccine bidding war
summary: Poor countries are at risk of a vaccine bidding war, which could drive up prices and limit access to COVID-19 vaccines. The Covax initiative, a coalition of 172 countries, aims to provide equitable access to vaccines, but it faces funding and supply challenges. The World Bank has committed $160 billion to poor countries, and 73 countries have been offered debt relief, but these efforts may not be enough to meet demand. An international agreement to coordinate vaccine allocation is seen as the best way to ensure poor countries receive more doses, with the US expected to rejoin the WHO after President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration.

site_title: China looks at cutting inequality in order to boost economy
summary: China's Communist Party has pledged to implement "demand-side reform" to boost the economy, focusing on consumer spending to counter uneven recovery. The shift in focus comes as household spending lags behind investment in real estate and infrastructure. This move signals a potential increase in egalitarian policies to stimulate consumer spending. Despite being the only major economy set to grow this year, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Keppel to sell First King Properties for £73.6m
summary: Keppel Land is selling its 100% stake in First King Properties, a London office building, for £73.6m (S$131.1m) in cash. The transaction is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2026. The purchaser is ZGC King Williams Holdings, a fund managed by London and Oxford Capital Markets Limited.

site_title: Fauci says US could see return to normal by next summer
summary: US infectious disease official Dr. Anthony Fauci suggests that widespread population immunity in the US could be achieved by next summer if the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines proceeds smoothly. He recommends priority populations receive their shots by March or early April, followed by "open season" vaccinations in April. Fauci predicts 70-85% of the population will be vaccinated by the end of summer, offering an "umbrella of protection" over the country.

site_title: HK signs deal with AstraZeneca; residents can choose from 3 vaccine options
summary: Hong Kong has signed a deal with AstraZeneca to buy 7.5 million doses of its Covid-19 vaccine, bringing the city's total potential doses to 22.5 million. Residents will be allowed to choose from three vaccine options: Pfizer-BioNTech, Sinovac, and AstraZeneca. The government has also set up a fund to provide financial support for patients experiencing side effects, and a committee has been appointed to approve the emergency use of the vaccines.

site_title: Global cargo logjam deepens, delaying goods bound for retailers, automakers
summary: A global cargo logjam is deepening, delaying goods bound for retailers and automakers. A surge in demand during the Covid-19 pandemic has upended trade flows, stranding empty containers and causing bottlenecks. Container ships, sailing at full load since August, are now experiencing delays of up to three weeks. This disruption could lead to shortages and complicate the global economic recovery. Companies like Amazon and Honda have suffered delays, while importers and exporters are frustrated by the inability to move products freely.

site_title: Thai central bank holds key rate, cuts growth forecast for 2021
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 0.5% for the fifth consecutive meeting to preserve its limited policy space. The central bank lowered its economic growth forecast for 2021 to 3.2% from 3.6%, citing concerns over a new wave of the domestic Covid-19 outbreak and a strong baht currency. The decision aims to support the fragile recovery and stem baht gains, with the bank standing ready to use more monetary tools if necessary.

site_title: STI snaps four-day losing streak as regional indexes rise
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.22% higher on Wednesday, snapping a four-day losing streak, as regional indexes rose despite concerns over the US coronavirus relief bill. The STI gained 6.08 points to close at 2,833.4 points, while peer indexes such as South Korea's Kospi Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also saw gains. Keppel Corporation was a top performer, with a 1.32% gain, and Asian Micro was the most heavily traded counter, closing 75% higher.

site_title: Trump pardons spark outrage
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked outrage with pardons of corrupt Republican congressmen and security guards convicted of killing 14 civilians in a 2007 Baghdad massacre. The pardons also include four former US servicemen convicted of murder and manslaughter for the Nisur Square massacre, and two men convicted in the Russia election meddling investigation. Critics say the pardons demonstrate a disregard for justice and accountability, with many of the pardoned individuals being vocal supporters of Trump. The pardons have been met with widespread condemnation from politicians, lawyers, and human rights groups.

images.alt_text: An angry backlash on Wednesday met US President Donald Trump's pardons of corrupt Republican congressmen and security guards convicted of killing 14 civilians in a 2007 Baghdad massacre.

site_title: Frencken's S$6.2m impairment does not affect outlook: analysts
summary: Frencken Group, a Singapore-based manufacturing company, has recognized an impairment loss of S$6.2 million for fiscal 2020 due to a change in a US customer's strategic direction. However, analysts from Maybank Kim Eng and CGS-CIMB maintain their "buy" and "add" calls on the stock, respectively, with unchanged target prices of S$1.39. The impairment loss is expected to have no impact on the group's cash balances and growth outlook, as the product is not yet commercially launched.

site_title: Surge in demand for deep freeze solutions
summary: Demand for ultra-low-temperature (ULT) freezing solutions has surged amid the rollout of Covid-19 mRNA vaccines, particularly those requiring storage in minus-70 degrees Celsius temperatures. In Singapore, dry ice companies have reported increased demand, with some manufacturers anticipating a 20-30% increase in demand in the first half of 2021. However, local dry ice manufacturers have not experienced significant demand or price spikes, and ground-handlers like SATS have increased in-house dry ice production to meet the demand. Alternative solutions, such as battery-powered containers and standard power sockets, are also being developed to reduce reliance on dry ice.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up, shrugging off Trump stimulus threat
summary: US stocks finished mostly higher on Wednesday, despite weak economic data and President Trump's criticism of a $900 billion economic relief package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4%, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.1%. Investors focused on the possibility of a richer package and the agreement to purchase 100 million additional doses of the Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine. Large banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup, were particularly buoyant.

site_title: US targets Ripple cryptocurrency creators
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) charged Ripple Labs, the creators of the XRP cryptocurrency, with failing to register its digital asset securities, raising $1.3 billion. The SEC alleges that former CEO Christian Larsen and current Chairman Brad Garlinghouse "failed to register their offers and sales of XRP." The value of XRP tokens plummeted 21.77% to 33 US cents per unit, and Ripple's market capitalization dropped to $16.8 billion. Garlinghouse criticized regulators, saying the move creates an unfair advantage for US-based companies and puts Ripple at a disadvantage to its rivals.

images.alt_text: The US financial watchdog is chasing the firm behind a major cryptocurrency, accusing it of failing to respect regulations on offering unregistered digital assets.

site_title: Digital lives drive brick-and-mortar boom in data centres
summary: The shift to digital work and play has driven a boom in data centers, with developers and investors seeing opportunities in commercial real estate. As businesses and consumers consume more data, companies are preparing for increased demand, with investments in data centers expected to continue. The industry is no longer a niche market, with real estate investment trusts (Reits) focused on data centers delivering significant returns. The rollout of 5G networks is expected to further stimulate demand for data centers, with cities and states competing to offer tax incentives to attract new developments.

images.alt_text: An Equinix data centre under construction in San Jose, California. Equinix is one of the largest global data centre companies.

site_title: Facebook worries smaller rivals with openness on liability
summary: Facebook has expressed concerns about the legal immunity that protects it from lawsuits over user-posted content, potentially weakening Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The social media giant is pushing for updated regulations, but smaller websites like Etsy and Tripadvisor fear they cannot afford the increased content moderation costs. The FCC is considering a proposal to reinterpret the rules, which could impact smaller platforms. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle are seeking changes to the provision, with Democrats focusing on election misinformation and Republicans citing concerns about censorship of conservatives.

images.alt_text: Facebook says it is time to rethink the legal immunity that protects it from lawsuits over what users post online, a position that's leaving smaller websites concerned about the cost of accepting more responsibility for what appears on their platforms.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands caught in net of whales and murky waters of third-party transfers
summary: Marina Bay Sands, a casino in Singapore, has faced scrutiny over its handling of third-party transfers, which allow gamblers to settle accounts with other patrons. The casino settled a lawsuit from a Chinese businessman, Wang Xi, who claimed $9.1 million was transferred to third parties without his authorization. An internal investigation found 3,419 transfers worth $1.64 billion were made between 2010 and 2018, with employees allegedly hijacking the process. The casino has since cut back on transfers and tightened security. The US Department of Justice is reviewing whether the casino breached money laundering controls.

site_title: Keppel Land to divest Keppel Bay Tower to Keppel Reit at $657.2m valuation
summary: Keppel Land is selling its 100% interest in Keppel Bay Tower to Keppel Reit for $657.2 million, with Keppel Reit funding the acquisition through an equity fundraising and loans. The sale is expected to result in a $14.6 million gain for Keppel Corp. Keppel Reit will add the property to its portfolio, increasing its income resilience, while Keppel Land will continue to manage the property. The transaction is part of Keppel Land's portfolio optimization efforts and aligns with Keppel Corp's Vision 2030.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend recovery rally as Brexit deal hopes strengthen
summary: European shares extended their recovery rally, gaining 1.1% on Wednesday, driven by signs of an imminent Brexit trade deal. The Stoxx 600 index hit session highs, despite a 2.3% slump on Monday due to a COVID-19 mutant variant. The pan-European index is on course to end 2020 down 5% but has recovered from earlier lows. The travel and leisure sector gained the most, while banks and energy stocks rose due to rising crude prices and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Oil gains 2% after draws in US product inventories
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Wednesday, boosted by draws in US inventories of crude, petrol, and distillates. US crude inventories fell to 499.5 million barrels, while gasoline stocks and distillate stockpiles also decreased. A modest recovery in distillate demand and gasoline demand, combined with inventory draws, supported the market. The rising oil prices also followed a weak US dollar, which makes dollar-denominated commodities cheaper for holders of other currencies.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose more than 2 per cent on Wednesday, boosted by draws in US inventories of crude, petrol and distillates that lifted investors' hopes for some return in fuel demand.

site_title: Euro, Aussie gain, ignoring Trump's threat to block stimulus
summary: The euro and Australian dollar rose, ignoring US President Donald Trump's threat to block a $892 billion Covid-19 aid package. The euro reached $1.22 and the Australian dollar gained 0.7% to $0.7576, while the dollar fell 0.1% against a basket of currencies. Analysts believe the markets are expecting Trump to sign the package, despite his threat, and that risk aversion could shift to a rebound for the dollar if the Senate blocks the package.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to acquire logistics property in Brisbane for A$70.3m
summary: Ascendas Reit is set to acquire a logistics property in Brisbane, Australia for A$70.3 million. The 500 Green Road, Crestmead property is expected to be completed in Q4 2021 with a flexible design offering warehouse sizes from 9,000 to 38,000 sq m. The acquisition will increase the Brisbane logistics portfolio's net lettable area by 21% and achieve a 5 Star Green Star rating. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on Ascendas Reit's FY2019 distribution per unit, with an estimated improvement of 0.014 Singapore cents.

site_title: Alternative data key to financial inclusion
summary: Alternative data can help build credit profiles faster and secure customer authentication in the hyper-connected world, addressing financial exclusion issues in South-east Asia. The region's "credit invisible" population lacks credit history or identity information, leading to higher borrowing costs. Leveraging alternative data and digital platforms can increase lending volumes, approval rates, and improve accuracy of default predictions, opening up access to financial services for individuals and small businesses. Partnerships between businesses, credit bureaus, and the public sector are crucial in driving financial inclusion and creating a fairer consumer and business experience.

site_title: Asiapac social bonds closing in on US$10b; robust growth seen for 2021
summary: Asia-Pacific's social bond market has seen significant growth, tripling since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, with year-to-date volumes reaching $9.8 billion. This growth is expected to continue in 2021 as long-term impacts of the crisis play out. South Korea and Japan dominate the social bond space, with South Korea issuing $6.5 billion and Japan $1.7 billion. Social bonds are seen as a tool to address socio-economic crises, with investors seeking to address inequality and risks. Despite growth, the market faces challenges, including data inconsistency and the risk of "social washing".

site_title: Brexit deal marathon heads to the finish line
summary: Britain and the European Union are close to finalizing a long-elusive trade agreement, raising hopes of avoiding a turbulent economic rupture on New Year's Day. Despite rumors of a deal, no official confirmation has been made, and EU officials caution against excluding the risk of a "no-deal" scenario. Key issues remain unresolved, including fishing and competition, but a senior EU diplomat says the British have made significant concessions, particularly on access to fishing in EU waters. A deal could ensure the UK's goods trade remains tariff-free, worth nearly $1 trillion.

site_title: Surge in festive takeaways at hotels, restaurants
summary: In Singapore, hotels and restaurants are experiencing a surge in festive takeaways due to dining-in restrictions. Despite the economic climate, consumers are continuing to spend on food catering services. This trend is attributed to the desire for convenience and celebration from home.

site_title: SPH Radio reports strong 2020 listenership figures backed by survey data
summary: SPH Radio reported strong listenership figures in 2020, backed by survey data from Nielsen Radio Diary Survey. Kiss92 saw a 160,000 weekly exclusive listenership, with Money FM 89.3 having the highest median personal income of S$6,694 among its core audience. The survey also showed a doubling in listenership for Money FM 89.3, with 96.3 Hao FM registering the highest growth in core audience time spent listening. The data highlighted radio as a key media channel during the pandemic, with Nielsen reporting a 1.7% increase in audience share.

site_title: Call for overhaul of money market funds: report
summary: US policymakers should consider major changes to money market funds to reduce the risk of investor runs, a Treasury Department working group reported. The group proposed stricter rules around fund redemptions and higher capital buffers, but did not favor any specific approach. The recommendations come after a major sell-off in US markets in March 2020, which prompted the Federal Reserve to intervene with a $1.6 trillion bond purchase. Former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is expected to review "shadow banking" and the report could lead to a broader overhaul of the funds.

site_title: One million Americans vaccinated against Covid-19: official
summary: The US has reached a milestone, with over 1 million Americans receiving their first dose of a Covid-19 vaccine since its administration began 10 days ago. According to CDC director Robert Redfield, this achievement is an "early but important milestone." However, Moncef Slaoui, chief advisor of Operation Warp Speed, expressed doubts about meeting the goal of immunizing 20 million people by the end of December, citing logistical challenges. The US aims to immunize 100 million people by the end of the first quarter and another 100 million by the second quarter of 2021.

site_title: SIA testing digital health verification process for inbound passengers from KL, Jakarta
summary: Singapore Airlines is testing a digital health verification process for inbound passengers from Jakarta and Kuala Lumpur. The process, based on the International Air Transport Association's Travel Pass framework, allows passengers to securely store and present Covid-19 test and vaccination information. This pilot protocol marks the world's first digital health verification system for air travel.

site_title: EU, UK on verge of reaching post-Brexit trade deal
summary: The European Union (EU) and the United Kingdom are close to reaching a post-Brexit trade deal, with officials hopeful a compromise on fishing quotas can be reached ahead of Christmas. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron have taken over negotiations, and a "hotline" between EU President Ursula von der Leyen and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has been established. The UK has agreed to return 35% of its fishing catches to the EU, with the EU pushing for a longer transition period. The deal could be finalized by Thursday if talks continue smoothly, with the UK parliament and European Parliament set to vote on the agreement in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Fishing makes up a fraction of total trade between the EU and the UK, but it has political consequences for some EU nations. Control of British waters is also a key Brexit and Conservative election promise.

site_title: Japan's ruling party calls for more private talks on digital yen
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party has urged the Bank of Japan to speed up development of a digital yen, citing concerns it could crowd out the private sector. The party's project team, led by Hideki Murai, plans to focus on engaging with private companies and platform operators to ensure a digital yen is used in conjunction with existing settlements systems. Murai emphasized the need for policymakers to understand the private sector's efforts and for private companies to grasp the implications of a digital yen. This approach aims to maximize the potential of a central bank digital currency.

site_title: HK online banks eye business loans and wealth management
summary: Hong Kong's eight online-only banks, which started this year, have taken over $1 billion in deposits and attracted nearly 300,000 customers. They plan to venture into business lending and wealth management, seeking more lucrative opportunities beyond basic services. ZA Bank aims to break even in five years, while Mox Bank plans to add credit card and wealth management services by mid-2022. The new banks hope to win over customers with more attractive interest rates and user-friendly apps, while traditional banks respond by slashing fees and investing in digital platforms.

site_title: Time spent in the pub can be a wise investment
summary: A recent article highlights the importance of social capital in the workplace and its impact on organizations and individuals. Social capital, defined as the connections and collective attitudes that support a well-functioning society, is crucial for building trust and fostering productivity. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the issue, making it harder for people to maintain relationships and build social capital. Employers must adapt to the new hybrid work environment and find creative ways to help new employees form social capital. Research suggests that social capital boosts efficiency and reduces transaction and monitoring costs, but inadequate social capital can lead to distrust and inefficiencies.

site_title: US existing home sales fall more than expected in November
summary: US existing home sales fell 2.5% in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.69 million units, exceeding expectations. Despite a surge of 25.8% in year-on-year sales, the market remains driven by record low mortgage rates. Housing supply remains inadequate, pushing home prices out of reach for many first-time buyers, with a record low 1.28 million homes on the market and median prices jumping 14.6% to $310,800.

site_title: Amazon delays hike in the fees it charges merchants until June
summary: Amazon has delayed plans to increase fees it charges independent sellers until June, citing other logistics companies' fee hikes as the reason. In a blog post, outgoing Amazon CEO Jeff Wilke acknowledged the rising costs for merchants and expressed a desire to avoid further increasing the fees. This decision aims to ease concerns among sellers who have previously bristled at the rising costs of doing business with the company.

site_title: Japan to lay out 'green' growth strategy to meet Suga's net-zero emissions goal: Nikkei
summary: Japan plans to unveil a "green growth strategy" by 2022 to meet Prime Minister Suga's goal of slashing carbon emissions to zero by 2050. The strategy includes targets to replace petrol-powered vehicles with electric cars by 2035, install 45 gigawatts of offshore wind power by 2040, and increase renewable energy to 50-60% of Japan's total power by 2050. The plan aims to revitalise the economy and align Japan with other regions setting ambitious carbon-neutral targets, with a focus on reducing greenhouse gas emissions beyond its current 2030 target.

images.alt_text: Japan will lay out on Friday a "green growth strategy" that includes a goal to replace petrol-powered vehicles with electric cars by around 2035, the Nikkei newspaper reported.

site_title: Swiss ski resort feels chill from British stayaway
summary: Switzerland's ski resorts, including Verbier, are facing a significant blow due to a flight ban from the UK due to the new Covid-19 variant. The Swiss government has imposed a 10-day retroactive quarantine on anyone who arrived from Britain since December 14. This ruling has left hoteliers struggling to deal with the sudden loss of British winter tourists, who were expected to boost the ski resorts' businesses. The ban has put Christmas plans on ice for many, causing financial losses for the affected hotels and ski resorts.

site_title: OCBC lifts spirits of vulnerable groups struggling with mental health
summary: OCBC Bank has completed a craft project, donating nearly 3,500 handmade gifts to seven charity organizations in Singapore. The project, conducted by staff volunteers, aimed to boost the mental well-being of vulnerable groups during the pandemic. The gifts, made in just two weeks, included sensory jars, face towels transformed into bouquets, and other creative items. This is part of OCBC's larger efforts, which included a S$1.8 million donation to support needy families, migrant workers, and vulnerable seniors.

images.alt_text: OCBC staff volunteers learning from Cindy Ong (on screen), how to transform face towels into bouquets of roses, bunnies and teddy bears.

site_title: Allianz bets on London's West End with £401m office
summary: Allianz has agreed to pay £401 million (S$718 million) for a 75% stake in a portfolio of West End office buildings in London, including 10 Portman Square, Marble Arch House, and York House. The deal is part of a trend of investors betting on the long-term resilience of prime business districts despite the pandemic. This is the latest sign of investors seeking high-yielding assets, with the buildings offering returns that surpass those of government bonds. The deal is expected to complete in January.

site_title: Booking a trip in 2021? Here's how to protect your investment
summary: Travelers may consider booking trips in the second half of 2021 and beyond, as travel and prices are expected to pick up. To protect investments, experts recommend looking for flexible terms, using loyalty points or frequent flyer miles, paying with credit cards, and insuring trips. Flexible cancellation policies, such as those offered by airlines and hotels, can provide financial protection. Travelers should also negotiate and stay flexible, as some providers may agree to refundable rates or other concessions. Ultimately, taking precautions and doing research can help minimize risks and ensure a successful trip.

site_title: Will principled conservatives start their own party? I hope so
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's victory has sparked a potential fracture within the Republican Party, with principled conservatives considering forming their own party if Donald Trump continues to refuse to acknowledge his defeat and demands loyalty. Trump's actions, including his disinformation campaign and attacks on Republican officials, are driving a wedge between those who prioritize party loyalty and those who value constitutional obligations. If Trump's behavior continues, it could lead to the emergence of a new, principled conservative party, potentially strengthening the Republican Party and allowing for more bipartisan cooperation on key issues.

site_title: Make this Christmas a time for family and reflection
summary: This Christmas is marked by a focus on family and reflection amidst a tumultuous year. Industry leaders share thoughts on the holiday season, while architects discuss alternative, homey celebrations. A family in Singapore celebrates a tropical Christmas, while F&B establishments prepare for an early New Year's Eve due to the 10:30pm curfew. Meanwhile, chef Jason Tan's new restaurant, Euphoria, offers a taste of his mod-Indian cuisine.

site_title: FCT to divest Anchorpoint mall for S$110m
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) will divest its 51% stake in Anchorpoint shopping centre in Singapore for S$110 million to unrelated third parties. The sale consideration is based on the independent appraised value of the mall as of September 15, 2020. The transaction is expected to complete by March 22, 2021, and FCT's net proceeds will be used to repay debt or for working capital purposes. Post divestment, FCT's Singapore retail portfolio will consist of 10 malls with about 2.3 million square feet of net lettable area.

site_title: M&A fastest way for Big Tech to get a share of gaming pie
summary: Big Tech companies, including Google and Amazon, are expected to invest heavily in the gaming industry in 2021 through mergers and acquisitions (M&A) to reach the multi-billion-dollar market. The video game industry generated $175 billion in revenue in 2020, with broadband speed and infrastructure being major issues. To succeed, companies need to offer exclusive content, as seen with Microsoft's $7.5 billion acquisition of ZeniMax Media. Google and Amazon have yet to make major purchases, but have combined cash reserves of nearly $140 billion, making them potential buyers of industry heavyweights like Electronic Arts and Take-Two Interactive.

site_title: More growth for China in 2021, but work needed to improve global image
summary: China's economy is expected to continue growing in 2021, with a strong V-shaped recovery, driven by a quick containment of the Covid-19 pandemic and a resilient consumer market. However, economists warn that structural changes are needed to avoid a middle-income trap and to address concerns about the country's handling of the pandemic and its increasing assertive diplomatic stance. China's government is also facing criticism for its handling of the pandemic and is working to improve its global image, including by participating in global vaccination efforts.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) will not hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on a rights issue and manager retention, as the Reit manager's shareholder appeal against the Monetary Authority of Singapore's directive has not been accepted. EHT will proceed with its scheduled EGM on Dec 30 as planned. ARA Logos Logistics Trust has launched a preferential offering to raise S$50 million to finance its acquisition of Australian logistics properties and investments into two funds, with an issue price of S$0.5525 per new unit.

site_title: GCB segment ends 2020 on high note; buoyant mood expected to continue
summary: The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) segment in Singapore is expected to see increased transaction volumes and prices in 2021, following a strong end to 2020. Agents attribute the growth to ultra-high-net-worth foreigners, wealthy Asian families, and newly minted citizens taking advantage of Singapore's exclusivity and low-rise character. Prices in prime locations are forecast to rise 5-15% in 2021, while those in non-prime areas are expected to increase 3-5%. The total transaction value is expected to reach S$1.1 billion, with the number of deals projected to rise 20% from 2020.

site_title: Needed - vaccines against not only Covid-19 but also the populist virus
summary: US President Donald Trump's populist policies and attacks on experts and scientists contributed to the country's ineffective response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Trump downplayed warnings from scientists and promoted quack cures, instead appealing to emotions and scapegoating foreigners and elites. However, the development and administration of COVID-19 vaccines, led by scientists and business executives from diverse backgrounds, has demonstrated the power of brainpower and scientific genius in overcoming global challenges. This "vaccine" against populist ideology has the potential to save lives and promote a more informed and rational public discourse.

site_title: Jokowi shuffles cabinet; former banker made health minister
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has shuffled his cabinet, replacing embattled Health Minister Terawan Agus Putranto with former banker Budi Gunadi Sadikin. The move comes amid a deteriorating coronavirus crisis, with over 685,600 cases and 20,400 deaths. New Health Minister Budi has vowed to focus on handling the pandemic quickly and effectively, but experts warn that the situation could worsen if the government relies too heavily on vaccination programs. The cabinet shake-up is seen as an attempt to build public confidence, but analysts say it may not be enough to transform the government's response.

site_title: Delivery-only 'ghost' kitchens flourish during pandemic
summary: Ghost kitchens, also known as "dark" kitchens, are booming in the US during the pandemic, offering delivery-only food services from hidden commercial spaces. The trend has seen a significant increase in demand for delivery, with DoorDash handling 543 million orders in the first nine months of 2020, a three-fold increase from last year. Companies like Nextbite, Zuul, and CloudKitchens are capitalizing on this trend, offering kitchens and technical support to restaurants, while traditional caterers are also getting in on the act. The model has allowed some restaurants to survive the pandemic, but has raised concerns about job insecurity and the impact on traditional restaurants.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as weekly jobless claims drop
summary: Wall Street indexes opened higher on Wednesday, despite President Donald Trump's threat to not sign a $900 billion Covid-19 stimulus package. The Dow Jones rose 0.10%, the S&P 500 gained 0.17%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.21%. Weekly jobless claims dropped better than expected, contributing to the positive start.

site_title: Olam warns of H2 loss from impairment, but expects FY2020 to remain profitable
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-food giant, expects a loss for the second half of 2020 due to an impairment on its investment in Olam Palm Gabon (OPG) totaling around US$350 million. Despite this, the company expects its full-year net profit to remain positive, driven by strong growth in its operating portfolio. The impairment was caused by lower rainfall in Gabon, which has led to reduced yields and returns on the investment.

site_title: US consumer spending drops in Nov; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: US consumer spending fell 0.4% in November, marking the first decline since April, as the economy struggles to recover from the pandemic recession. Initial jobless claims dropped to 803,000, but remain elevated. The weak economic data bolsters expectations for a significant slowdown in economic growth in the fourth quarter and a potential contraction in output in 2021. The delayed government rescue package and new Covid-19 cases have undercut consumer spending, with economists warning that herd immunity may take time to develop.

site_title: Singapore confirms one case with UK virus strain
summary: Singapore has confirmed one case of a potentially more contagious Covid-19 strain, B117, imported from the UK. The 17-year-old Singaporean girl, who had been studying in the UK, developed a fever after returning to Singapore on Dec 6 and was confirmed infected on Dec 8. She was isolated upon arrival and her close contacts were quarantined, with all testing negative for Covid-19 at the end of their quarantine period. There is currently no evidence of the B117 strain circulating in the community in Singapore.

site_title: Trump threatens to not sign US$892b Covid-19 relief bill
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened not to sign a $892 billion coronavirus relief bill, citing its "ridiculously low" $600 stimulus checks for individuals and other spending items he dislikes. The bill, passed by the House and Senate, includes funding for individual Americans, foreign countries, and the US government. Trump wants the stimulus checks increased to $2,000 for individuals or $4,000 for couples. If the bill is not amended, Trump's choices are to sign it, veto it, or do nothing, which could result in a partial government shutdown.

site_title: Rivals likely to leverage China tariffs on Australian wines
summary: Australia's wine industry is facing a significant blow as China imposes tariffs of up to 212% on Australian wine imports, doubling the price of a bottle in Chinese supermarkets. The tariffs, imposed in response to Australia's stance on COVID-19 and Huawei's participation, have led to a decline in Australian wine sales in China, allowing rival producers such as Chile and France to fill the gap. Domestic Chinese wine production is expected to struggle to meet demand for high-quality wine, giving other countries an opportunity to gain market share.

site_title: Owl Rock, Dyal Capital to go public via SPAC merger
summary: Owl Rock Capital Group and Dyal Capital Partners have agreed to merge and go public through Altimar Acquisition Corp, a blank-cheque company, valuing the combined company at $12.5 billion. The deal is expected to raise $1.8 billion in gross proceeds, with $275 million coming from Altimar's cash trust and $1.5 billion from investors. The merged company, Blue Owl Capital, will list on the NYSE in the first half of 2021, managing $45 billion in assets.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust will not hold further EGM to vote on retaining Reit manager
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) will not hold a further extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on a rights issue and a proposal to retain its current manager. The decision comes after the Reit manager's shareholder appeal against the Monetary Authority of Singapore's directive to remove the current manager was rejected. EHT will proceed with its scheduled EGM on Dec 30 as planned, with only the original resolutions to be voted on.

site_title: Still room for upside for hospitality Reits despite rally
summary: Hospitality Reits have rallied in response to the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines, but a full recovery in revenue per available room may not occur until 2022 or 2023. Analysts suggest the availability of vaccines will lead to a recovery in 2021, but long-term business travel volumes may be affected by virtual meetings, potentially impacting RevPAR. The sector's recovery is still uncertain, with some Reits facing challenges such as low RevPAR and uncertain business travel trends.

site_title: UOB brings Christmas cheer to underprivileged children
summary: UOB's Gift for Good campaign, part of SG Cares Giving Week, distributed 2,000 Christmas presents to underprivileged children over two weeks. The campaign encouraged UOB customers to buy gifts from a dedicated online registry for children cared by New Life Stories. This initiative aims to spread Christmas cheer to those in need.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from left: Anna Qiu, Shopee Singapore head of partnerships; Dale Preston, Dairy Farm director of customer insights South-east Asia; Lim Kell Jay, head of Grab Financial Group, Singapore; Choo Wan Sim, UOB head of cards and payments Singapore; and Jacquelyn Tan, UOB head of group personal financial services, with a beneficiary.

site_title: Another new coronavirus variant detected in UK
summary: Britain has detected another new coronavirus variant, with two cases reported as contacts of cases who traveled from South Africa. The variant is highly concerning due to its increased transmissibility and mutation. Health Secretary Matt Hancock stated that the new variant is yet more transmissible than the previously discovered UK variant.

site_title: Singapore's core, headline inflation at -0.1% in November
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to -0.1% in November, matching economists' expectations, while headline inflation also fell to -0.1%. The decline was driven by smaller falls in services and electricity costs, offset by higher food inflation. Economists predict core inflation will turn mildly positive in 2021, averaging 0-1% and headline inflation to average -0.5 to 0.5%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their inflation outlook unchanged, citing labour market slack weighing on wages.

site_title: Singapore, India, Indonesia expected to be leaders in digital payments: study
summary: Singapore, India, and Indonesia are expected to lead in digital payments, with Singapore in absolute value and the three countries having the highest compound annual growth rate (CAGR) between 2020 and 2024, according to a Deloitte and Inclusion Fintech Conference study. Asia leads the world in e-commerce popularity and growth, with these countries driving the trend.

images.alt_text: India, Indonesia and Singapore are expected to lead the pack both in the absolute value of digital payments and the compound annual growth rate between 2020 and 2024.

site_title: US core capital goods orders, shipments rise in November
summary: US core capital goods orders rose 0.4% in November for the seventh straight month, suggesting business investment could offset slowing consumer spending. Orders for non-defence capital goods excluding aircraft increased 0.4% and 1.6% in October. Shipments of core capital goods also rose 0.4% in November. The rebound in business investment could help moderate the economy's growth in the fourth quarter, which is expected to be below a 5% annualized rate due to slower consumer spending.

site_title: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai granted bail
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, 73, was granted bail on Wednesday under strict conditions after being detained under China's national security law. Lai faces charges of colluding with foreign countries by calling for sanctions against Hong Kong and China. He was ordered to pay a $1.3 million bond and imposed conditions, including house arrest, a ban on social media posts, and restrictions on meetings with foreign officials. Lai's lawyer appealed the decision, citing concerns over the restrictions on the press.

site_title: Elephant Santas spread Covid-19 awareness among Thai children
summary: Four elephant Santas, wearing coronavirus masks, visited a school in Ayutthaya, Thailand, to spread COVID-19 awareness among children. The event combined Christmas and Thai elephant culture, with excited children singing carols and taking photos with the animals. This annual tradition aimed to educate children about the importance of COVID-19 prevention and awareness. The event was part of the school's annual tradition and highlighted the unique fusion of Thai culture and Christmas celebrations.

site_title: Hong Kong sells prime residential site for US$1.5b to Wharf
summary: Hong Kong awarded a prime residential site to Wharf Development for a record-breaking US$1.5 billion, exceeding initial valuations of HK$7.8-8.3 billion. The site, located at the Peak, can supply about 24,093 square meters of floor area for homes. The luxury residential market has been hit hard this year, with prices falling 8% in 2020. The sale is seen as a sign of recovery for Hong Kong's real estate market, following recent government moves to ease pressure on luxury housing developers, including scrapping plans for a tax on vacant homes.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to -0.1% in November, a slight improvement from -0.2% in October. Keppel Land sold its 100% interest in Keppel Bay Tower to Keppel Reit for S$657.2m. FCT sold its Anchorpoint shopping centre for S$110m. Cakap, an Indonesian edtech platform, raised US$3m in funding. The STI index rebounded, gaining 0.22% on Wednesday, snapping a four-day losing streak.

site_title: EU acts to prepare path to Brexit trade deal, EU sources say
summary: The European Union is preparing to implement a new trade deal with the United Kingdom on January 1, 2021, after diplomatic sources indicate agreement is imminent. The deal comes as the UK leaves the EU's customs union and single market on December 31, 11 months after its formal departure. Despite conflicting signals, EU diplomats are ready for a meeting on Thursday to finalize the agreement, which would enable a "provisional application" of the deal. Sterling has risen in response to the news, trading above $1.35.

site_title: ARA Logos looks to raise S$50m for property acquisitions
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust has launched a preferential offering to raise S$50 million, with net proceeds to be used to partially finance the acquisition of five Australian logistics properties and investments into two of the sponsor's funds. The issue price is S$0.5525 per unit, representing an 8% discount to the VWAP. About 99.5% of the gross proceeds will be allocated to the proposed acquisitions and investments, with the remaining 0.5% for fees and expenses.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to acquire new logistics property in Brisbane
summary: Ascendas Reit is acquiring a new logistics property in Brisbane for A$70.3 million, with a flexible design offering warehouse sizes from 9,000 to 38,000 square meters. The property is expected to be completed in Q4 2021 and will achieve a 5 Star Green Star rating. The acquisition will increase Ascendas Reit's Brisbane logistics portfolio by 21% and enhance the overall quality of its Australian portfolio, with a 5.6% net property income yield. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on the company's distribution per unit, with an estimated improvement of 0.014 Singapore cents per unit.

site_title: China's Ant cuts credit limits for some young Huabei users
summary: China's Ant Group is reducing credit limits for some young users of its Huabei virtual credit card product, aiming to promote "rational" spending habits. The move follows China's tightening grip on fintech companies amid concerns about debt issues. Ant's credit businesses had loan balances of 2.1 trillion yuan at the end of June, with 1.7 trillion yuan in consumer credit. The reduction comes a month after China suspended Ant's US$37 billion public listing plan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 15.58 points to 1,647.50 on Wednesday, closing higher. The index saw 6.048 billion lots traded worth RM3.41 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 841 to 354.

site_title: Swiber Holdings' judicial management extended to Jan 14
summary: Swiber Holdings' judicial management has been extended to January 14, 2021, with another hearing set to determine the extension until March 31, 2021. The company's shares have been suspended since 2016, and it was placed under judicial management the same year.

site_title: Asiapac accounts for 41% of global equity capital market deals in 2020
summary: Asia-Pacific accounted for 41% of global equity capital market deals in 2020, totaling $439.1 billion. The region's contribution was the highest since 2010, driven by countries like China emerging from the pandemic faster than the rest of the world. Healthcare deals recorded the strongest growth, up 148.6% in 2020, with bankers expecting the sector to dominate the local market again in 2021 due to the global rollout of COVID-19 vaccines.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, reversing three days of losses, as investors ignored concerns about US President Donald Trump's call for a US economic stimulus amendment. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.86%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.76% and 0.74%, respectively. The gains came despite Trump's comments, which traders seem to be brushing off.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on Brexit trade deal hopes
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday as a report hinted at a possible Brexit trade deal later in the day, boosting investor confidence. The Stoxx 600 index was led by Daimler's 2.7% gain, while the FTSE 100 lagged due to a stronger pound. US President Donald Trump threatened to not sign a $892 billion coronavirus relief bill unless stimulus checks were increased, causing some market volatility.

site_title: Allianz bets on London's West End with £401m office deal
summary: Allianz has agreed to pay £401 million (S$718.1 million) for a 75% stake in a portfolio of West End office buildings in London, owned by British Land Co. The deal includes 10 Portman Square, Marble Arch House, and York House, and is expected to complete in January. This investment demonstrates confidence in London's long-term prospects despite the pandemic's impact on the business district. The deal is at a premium to the buildings' September valuation, with investors seeking out long-lease properties for attractive returns.

site_title: China will lower import tariffs on 883 products from Jan 1, 2021
summary: China will lower import tariffs on 883 products, including aviation equipment, logs, and paper products, starting January 1, 2021. This is part of a series of tariff reductions, with over 850 products already lowered since January 1, 2020. Additionally, import tariffs on some information technology products will be further lowered starting July 1, 2021.

site_title: Thai central bank leaves key rate unchanged, lowers 2021 GDP outlook
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.5% for the fifth consecutive meeting due to ongoing coronavirus outbreaks and tourism disruptions. The bank downgraded its 2021 economic outlook to 3.2% growth from 3.6% due to the impact of the pandemic on the tourism-reliant economy. The central bank also reduced its 2020 GDP outlook to a 6.6% contraction from 7.8%. Despite the challenges, the bank's monetary policy committee voted unanimously to maintain the policy rate at the current level.

site_title: STI snaps 4-day losing streak, up 0.22% in line with key regional indexes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended a four-day losing streak with a 0.22% gain, reaching 2,833.4 points. This followed regional peers, including South Korea's Kospi Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, which also rose. Gainers outnumbered decliners 226 to 192 on the Singapore market, with Keppel Corporation being a top performer, up 1.32%. The gains were partly attributed to investor optimism despite concerns over US President Donald Trump's potential veto of a coronavirus relief bill.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; consumer spending declines in November
summary: US jobless claims fell to 803,000 for the week ended Dec 19, a seasonally adjusted decrease from the prior week, but still elevated due to COVID-19 restrictions and cases. Consumer spending declined 0.4% in November, the first drop since April, and economists expect significant slowdown in economic growth in the fourth quarter and potential contraction in 2021. The new rescue package includes direct payments and extended unemployment subsidies, but economists warn of potential savings and a slow recovery due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Xiaomi's market value tops US$100b, reaching 2018 IPO goal
summary: Xiaomi's market value surpassed US$100 billion, reaching its 2018 IPO goal. The company's stock rallied 9.1% and reached a record high in Hong Kong, with a market value of HK$802 billion (S$137.98 billion). Xiaomi's strong sales, fueled by China's "Double 12" shopping festival, have contributed to the growth. The company reported its fastest quarterly sales growth in two years, with earnings beating analysts' estimates. This milestone marks a significant milestone for the Chinese smartphone maker.

site_title: Seoul: Shares log biggest daily gain in two weeks, LG Electronics shines
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.96% to a two-week high, with LG Electronics surging 29.61% after announcing a joint venture with Magna International for electric car components. The benchmark Kospi index gained 26.14 points to 2,759.82. Foreigners were net buyers of 82.7 billion won, while the won weakened against the US dollar. US President Trump expressed support for a larger stimulus package, while South Korean President Moon Jae-in faced pressure over Covid-19 vaccine procurement plans amid a third wave of cases.

site_title: COEs end the year mostly higher in final lap of sales race
summary: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for cars in Singapore ended the year mostly higher, with the average premium only slightly higher than last year's despite a 25% smaller supply of certificates. COE prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closed at S$40,556, while those for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at S$49,300. This year's average premium is lower than the 1999 average, with a 25% reduction in supply.

site_title: Empty stores and offices: how Sweden aims to plug housing gap
summary: Sweden is exploring converting empty commercial real estate into homes to address its chronic housing shortage, estimated at around 140,000 homes. The government is simplifying building rules to facilitate conversions, with around 20% of workers expected to work from home permanently after the pandemic. This shift has led to a decline in office space demand, with some companies reducing their office areas by up to 40%. The plan aims to boost housing supply and potentially replicate in other countries with housing shortages.

site_title: Asia's capital markets to focus on vaccine in 2021, say bankers
summary: Asia's capital markets are expected to focus on vaccine-related deals in 2021, following a record-breaking year of fundraising in 2020. The region's equity capital markets (ECM) deals totaled $439.1 billion, the highest ever, driven by healthcare deals that saw a 148.6% growth in money raised. Bankers anticipate the global rollout of the coronavirus vaccine will dominate the local capital markets, with healthcare companies expected to raise funds in the first half of the year. The pace of capital market activity is expected to remain driven by liquidity from governments and central banks.

site_title: 21 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 21 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported, bringing the total to 58,482. Among the new cases, 3 are Singaporeans, 5 are PRs, and 9 are foreign domestic workers. No new community cases or cases from worker dormitories were reported. 18 cases were discharged, leaving 34 patients in hospital, with 97 recovering in community facilities. This brings the total number of recovered patients to 58,307.

site_title: China pipeline giant to buy Kunlun assets for US$6.3b
summary: China's state-owned pipeline network firm, PipeChina, is acquiring Kunlun Energy's 60% stake in a Beijing natural gas pipeline and 75% stake in its Dalian LNG company for US$6.3 billion. The deal aims to boost China's energy security and promote market competition. The acquisition is part of China's efforts to consolidate major pipelines and midstream facilities into a single entity, led by President Xi Jinping's government. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year, with Kunlun Energy's shares surging on the news.

site_title: Malaysia in talks to secure more vaccines from Russia, Pfizer
summary: Malaysia is in talks to secure 6.4 million doses of Russia's Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine and plans to increase Pfizer vaccine purchases, aiming to inoculate 82.8% of its population. The country is spending $500 million on vaccines, with additional purchases from Chinese and Russian manufacturers, as well as the Covax facility. This move aims to create a buffer against vaccine supply risks. Malaysia has already secured 12.8 million doses of Pfizer vaccine, with the first shipment expected in February.

images.alt_text: The South-east Asian nation is spending about US$500 million to buy enough vaccines to inoculate 26.5 million people, or 82.8 per cent of its people.

site_title: Malaysia launches 10-year tourism plan after RM100b loss in 2020
summary: Malaysia has launched a 10-year tourism plan to revive its battered sector, which suffered a significant loss of RM100 billion in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic. The country initially targeted 30 million tourist arrivals, but the pandemic has crippled the industry, which previously contributed 15.9% of Malaysia's GDP in 2019. The new plan aims to boost tourism and restore the sector's economic impact.

site_title: Honda to stop production at one of two India plants
summary: Honda Motor has halted production at its Greater Noida plant in India, shifting all production to its Tapukara plant in Rajasthan. The move follows declining sales of its vehicles in the country, where competitors have gained market share. Honda Cars India Ltd will now produce all vehicles and components at the Tapukara plant for domestic sales and exports, effective immediately.

site_title: HK online banks plan to offer business loans and wealth management
summary: Hong Kong's eight online-only banks, which started operations this year, plan to venture into business lending and wealth management. They have attracted over $1 billion in deposits and nearly 300,000 customers, with some aiming to break even in five years. The new banks seek to win over customers with more attractive interest rates and user-friendly apps, and are competing with traditional banks such as HSBC and Standard Chartered. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for investment advice and fees in Hong Kong, which has seen a surge in IPOs this year.

site_title: Video game firm CD Projekt sells over 13m copies of Cyberpunk 2077
summary: CD Projekt, a Polish video game firm, has sold over 13 million copies of its Cyberpunk 2077 game through December 20, accounting for retail sales and refunds. The figure is below market expectations of 16.4 million. The game, released on December 10, faced backlash over technical glitches, leading to Sony pulling it from the PlayStation Store and Microsoft offering refunds. CD Projekt's shares had fallen 40% before the game's release.

site_title: Indonesia edtech Cakap raises US$3m in Series A+ funding
summary: Indonesia-based edtech platform Cakap has secured US$3 million in Series A+ funding led by Heritas Capital to expand across Indonesia and the region. The fresh funds will be used to grow the management team, invite industry experts, and advance technological development. Cakap aims to expand its online learning platform, with plans to "invite more leaders and experts" in the education and technology industry to join the company. The funding round also saw participation from Strategic Year Holdings and other prominent investors.

site_title: Australia's goods trade surplus hits two-year lows on China trade tensions
summary: Australia's goods trade surplus fell to a two-year low in November, reaching A$1.9 billion, due to a 10% decrease in exports to China and a 11% increase in imports. The drop was led by restrictions imposed by China on Australian coal and tariffs on farm products. This is the first time the goods trade surplus has fallen below A$2 billion since November 2018. The decline is attributed to escalating trade tensions between Australia and China.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound on bargain hunting despite US, virus concerns
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.33% to 26,524.79, driven by bargain hunting despite concerns over a new coronavirus strain and US data. Investors also fretted over uncertainty in Brexit talks. The broader Topix index added 0.23% to 1,765.21. The rebound follows recent record highs, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Rivals ready to pounce as Australian winemakers eye China exit
summary: Australia's winemakers are rethinking their presence in China due to painful tariffs imposed by Beijing, which have doubled the price of Australian wine in Chinese supermarkets. The tariffs, up to 212% of the goods' value, were imposed in response to Australia's call for an inquiry into the origins of COVID-19. Rival countries, including Chile, France, and the US, are expected to benefit from the shift, as Chinese consumers seek high-quality wine. Australia's market share in China is expected to decline, potentially allowing other countries to gain ground.

site_title: South Korea's Moon under fire for vaccine plans as Covid-19 cases surge
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in faces public pressure over his vaccine procurement plans amid a surge in Covid-19 cases. The government's approach to securing vaccines has been criticized as too relaxed, and a poll shows 60% of South Koreans believe urgency should be prioritized over safety. The country reported its second-highest daily tally of cases, with 1,092 new cases on Tuesday, bringing the national tally to 52,550. The government has said vaccinations could start as early as February, but health authorities emphasize the importance of confirming the safety of the shots.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Moon Jae-in faced growing public pressure on Wednesday over his Covid-19 vaccine procurement plans as the country struggled to contain a third wave of the pandemic, reporting its second-highest daily tally of cases.

site_title: Top Glove says will no longer fire whistleblowers; opens helplines for workers
summary: Top Glove, Malaysia's largest medical glove maker, has established three helplines for worker complaints and will no longer fire whistleblowers. The company had previously fired a 27-year-old Nepali worker who shared photos of crowded factory conditions, but managing director Lee Kim Meow said the employee had admitted to trying to discredit the company. The company has since improved its processes and acknowledged areas for improvement, vowing to do more to address worker concerns.

site_title: Japan government adviser pressured Harvard before Toshiba AGM vote: sources
summary: A Japanese government adviser, Hiromichi Mizuno, allegedly pressured Harvard University's endowment fund to abstain from voting against Toshiba's management at its annual shareholders meeting, citing a potential regulatory probe. Mizuno, a special adviser to the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, told the fund that a vote against management would damage Harvard's reputation. Harvard ultimately abstained from voting, and no probe was found, but the incident highlights concerns over governance at Toshiba.

images.alt_text: Toshiba has been dogged by accounting issues.

site_title: Keppel Land to divest Keppel Bay Tower to Keppel Reit at S$657.2m valuation
summary: Keppel Land is divesting its 100% interest in Keppel Bay Tower to Keppel Reit for S$657.2m, including rental support. The acquisition is part of Keppel Reit's portfolio optimization efforts to enhance distributions and improve unitholder returns. Keppel Land will continue to manage the property, and the resultant gain for Keppel Corp is estimated to be about S$14.6 million. The divestment aligns with Keppel's Vision 2030 and will unlock capital for new growth opportunities.

site_title: Elephant Santas spread virus awareness among Thai children
