summary: Four elephant Santas, dressed in coronavirus masks, visited a school in Ayutthaya, Thailand, as part of an annual Christmas tradition. The elephants, who are cared for at the local elephant palace, used their trunks to distribute face masks to children and motorists. The event aimed to raise awareness about COVID-19, but a wildlife veterinarian criticized the practice as "questionable" and potentially stressful for the animals. The elephant handlers and the palace manager defended the tradition, saying it is a long-standing part of Thai culture and not exploitative.

site_title: Asian firms optimistic about business outlook in next six months: poll
summary: Asian firms have become the most optimistic about their business outlook in six months, with a Thomson Reuters/INSEAD Asian Business Sentiment Index score of 62, up from 53 in Q3. About half of surveyed companies (44%) said they were positive about their outlook, with 58% not hiring or laying off employees. Despite concerns over Covid-19 and vaccine scarcity, experts see a recovery taking speed, with some predicting a "year of the phoenix" in 2021. The optimism is driven by vaccine rollouts and policy support, with many firms expecting a strong rebound in global GDP and corporate earnings.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap three-day losing streak as NSW eases curbs
summary: Australian shares snapped a three-day losing streak, closing 0.7% higher on Wednesday, after New South Wales eased Covid-19 restrictions ahead of Christmas. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,643.1, driven by gains in energy, consumer, travel, and real estate stocks. However, restrictions in affected Sydney suburbs will remain in place, and the full lockdown is set to resume on December 27. Energy stocks led gains, with Woodside Petroleum and Origin Energy rising 0.9% and 1.7%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore's core, headline inflation at -0.1% in November
summary: Singapore's core inflation rate eased to -0.1% in November, matching economists' expectations, while headline inflation also fell to -0.1%. The decline was driven by smaller falls in service costs and higher food inflation. Economists expect core inflation to turn mildly positive in 2021, while domestic cost pressures remain subdued due to labor market slack. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their official inflation outlook for 2020 and 2021 unchanged.

site_title: SIA to trial digital health verification process for inbound flights from KL, Jakarta
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will trial a digital health verification process for inbound flights from Kuala Lumpur and Jakarta, starting Wednesday. Passengers flying into Singapore can securely store and present Covid-19 test results and vaccination status through a digital or paper health certificate with a QR code. This process is expected to speed up airport check-in and immigration entry, with the entire process to be integrated into the SingaporeAir mobile app by mid-2021.

site_title: France to reopen UK border after paralysing Britain's busiest port
summary: France has agreed to end a suspension of trade and transportation links with the UK, allowing European Union citizens and residents with negative Covid-19 tests to travel from the UK. The suspension, which crippled Britain's busiest port, was due to a faster-spreading Covid-19 variant. Freight traffic is expected to resume by Wednesday morning, with over 3,000 trucks stuck in south-east England. The agreement comes as the UK and EU negotiate a post-Brexit trade deal, with less than 10 days to go before a transition period ends on December 31.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts say Frencken's S$6.2m impairment does not affect outlook
summary: Frencken Group recognized an impairment loss of S$6.2 million for fiscal 2020, mainly due to a US customer's change in strategic direction. However, analysts from Maybank Kim Eng and CGS-CIMB say the loss won't affect their outlook, maintaining "buy" and "add" calls on the stock. The group expects to remain profitable in the second half of 2020 and full financial year 2020. Shares rose 5% to S$1.26.

site_title: SPH Radio reports strong 2020 listenership figures backed by survey data
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has reported strong 2020 listenership figures for its five radio stations, backed by survey data. Kiss92 saw a 160,000 weekly exclusive listenership, while ONE FM 91.3 had the highest median personal income among its core audience. Money FM 89.3 demonstrated a doubling in listenership and retained its top spot in influencing purchasing decisions. The radio stations' podcast downloads also increased by almost twofold, driven by MONEY FM 89.3 and 96.3 Hao FM podcasts.

site_title: Geylang's Advance Apartment sold for S$26.5m to local consortium
summary: A freehold site in Geylang's Advance Apartment has been sold to a local consortium for S$26.5 million, translating to a land rate of S$877 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, with an area of 11,429 square feet, is zoned for residential or institutional use and can accommodate up to 34 apartments. The sale price is expected to generate gross sale proceeds of between S$1.7 million and over S$2 million for the owners, with many small and mid-sized developers and institutions showing interest in the site.

site_title: Trump's longtime banker at Deutsche Bank resigns
summary: Deutsche Bank's longtime banker, Rosemary Vrablic, has resigned, effective as of year-end, amid efforts to cut ties with US President Donald Trump. Vrablic, a managing director, arranged for hundreds of millions of dollars in loans to Trump's company. Her resignation comes as the bank investigates a 2013 real estate transaction involving Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner. Deutsche Bank, which has about $340 million in loans outstanding to the Trump Organization, is seeking to end its relationship with the president following negative publicity stemming from their ties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.71 points, or 0.10%, to 1,630.21. The index saw 200.48 million lots traded worth RM121.95 million.

site_title: China looks to tap digital 'silver dollar'
summary: China is launching a nationwide effort to boost domestic consumption by helping its pensioners keep up with the digital economy. The government aims to tap into the "silver dollar" of elderly savings, with an estimated 300 million retirees expected by 2025, contributing around $1 trillion to the economy. To achieve this, China is providing training sessions and developing elderly-friendly apps, such as mobile payment services, to help retirees adapt to digital technology, with the goal of increasing digital fluency among the elderly population.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at start of Wednesday's trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.14% at the open of Wednesday's trade, extending losses for a fourth day, amid US President Donald Trump's criticism of the stimulus package agreed by the US Congress. The Hang Seng Index slipped to 26,083.11.

site_title: China launches bid to become commodities market player
summary: China has launched a new futures contract on the copper market, marking a significant step in its bid to become a global commodities marketplace. The Shanghai International Energy Exchange (INE) opened the contract for foreign investors on November 19, following trial runs in oil and other commodities. This move aims to increase China's market share and attract foreign investors, but it faces competition from London's London Metal Exchange (LME), which dominates industrial metals trading. China's currency control remains a challenge, but the new contract allows for onshore trading in renminbi, enabling faster currency conversion.

site_title: Gold gains as weaker dollar offsets US stimulus doubts
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,865.01 per ounce as the US dollar weakened, offsetting concerns over a US stimulus deal. President Trump's threat to not sign the pandemic relief bill sparked doubts. Gold has gained 22.9% this year, driven by stimulus measures and low-interest rates. Analysts predict gold could reach $2,000 next year if real yields continue to fall. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with silver increasing 0.8% to $25.31 an ounce.

site_title: Adelson's MBS casino paid price for courting China whales
summary: Marina Bay Sands casino in Singapore has faced scrutiny over its use of third-party transfers to facilitate high-stakes gaming, particularly with Chinese gamblers. The casino settled a lawsuit with a Chinese businessman who claimed unauthorized transfers totaling $9.1 million. An internal investigation revealed employees had hijacked the transfer process, using forged signatures and destroying originals. The casino has since reduced third-party transfers and tightened security measures. The US Department of Justice is reviewing whether the casino breached money laundering controls and retaliated against whistleblowers. Marina Bay Sands remains a profitable casino, with Asian bettors flocking to its high-end gaming facilities, despite concerns over money laundering and organized crime.

site_title: Australia: Shares set to snap three-day losing streak; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to 6,654.20 on Wednesday, snapping a three-day losing streak due to fears over the new Covid-19 strain. Gains were driven by financial and tech stocks, with leading stocks including Afterpay, Wisetech Global, and CSL. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.8% as well, with Meridian Energy and a2 Milk gaining over 4%. Despite the optimism, concerns remain about a slower global economic recovery and the impact of the new strain on markets.

site_title: Biden says will ask Congress to pass another Covid-19 relief bill
summary: President-elect Joe Biden announced plans to ask Congress to pass another Covid-19 relief bill after taking office in January. The $900 billion relief package approved by Congress earlier this week will provide a boost for millions of Americans and businesses affected by the pandemic. Biden emphasized the need for continued support, citing the need for more resources for vaccine distribution, testing, and aid for essential workers. He warned that the crisis is not yet over and that his administration will work to turn it around, promising to tell the truth and take swift action.

site_title: Japan's renewable energy sector seeks carbon-neutral windfall
summary: Japan aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, but experts say the country needs to reform outdated policies on land use and the national grid to meet the goal. The government has pledged to spend $20 billion on green tech and set ambitious new wind power targets, but critics argue that the current policy lacks ambition. Industry players favor legal reforms to free up farmland for renewable energy projects, with solar energy seen as a key area for growth, but wind power faces challenges due to grid access restrictions and lengthy environmental assessments.

site_title: NFL star, venture firms back startup's 'micro-gyms' concept
summary: Wilfred Valenta's startup, Silofit Incorporated, is scaling up its "micro-gym" concept, which offers private, hour-long fitness sessions in repurposed office spaces. Backed by NFL player Ndamukong Suh and venture capital firms, Silofit plans to expand to 12 locations in Toronto and enter the US$32 billion US gym market. The pandemic has accelerated the shift away from big box gym memberships, with 27% of regular exercisers saying they cancelled their gym membership and 12% planning to. Silofit aims to offer add-on services for fitness trainers and expand its online presence, with a goal of becoming the whole fitness and wellness professional ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Wilfred Valenta opened his first "micro-gym" almost two years ago, repurposing a 580-square-foot office space in downtown Montreal and renting it out by the hour to fitness trainers and small workout groups.

site_title: Pfizer nears deal with US government to supply additional Covid-19 vaccine doses
summary: Pfizer is close to a deal with the US government to supply at least 100 million additional Covid-19 vaccine doses from April to June in exchange for better access to manufacturing supplies. The agreement, potentially announced by Wednesday, would grant Pfizer better access to nine specialized products needed to produce the vaccine. This comes after Pfizer and partner BioNTech recently received US emergency use authorization for their vaccine candidate. The deal would provide the US with more vaccine doses as the country continues to roll out the vaccine across the country.

site_title: Wealth gap yawns wide between UK's ethnic groups: think tank
summary: The UK's ethnic wealth gap has widened, with people of Black African ethnicity holding just one eighth of the wealth of white British people, averaging £24,000 compared to £197,000. The Resolution Foundation proposes reforms, including wealth tax, help for first-time home buyers, and more generous tax pension tax relief for lower earners, to narrow the gap and help households cope with the Covid-19 crisis. The think tank warns that these wealth gaps will persist despite progress in education and employment gaps between ethnic groups.

site_title: Trump threatens to not sign Covid-19 bill, want bigger stimulus checks
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened not to sign a $892-billion coronavirus relief bill, citing its insufficient stimulus checks. He wants the amount increased to $2,000 for individuals or $4,000 for couples, and also demanded removal of wasteful spending items. The bill was passed by Congress with a $600 stimulus check for individuals. Trump's threat throws a twist into a bipartisan effort, leaving uncertainty over the relief package, which is due to be implemented before his presidency ends.

site_title: Australia's New South Wales to slightly ease lockdown rules over Christmas
summary: Australia's New South Wales (NSW) will ease lockdown rules for Sydney's northern seaside suburbs during the Christmas holidays. Starting Thursday, residents can have up to five visitors from the same affected suburbs, but restrictions will return on Dec 27. The easing of rules comes after a slowdown in new daily cases, alleviating concerns of a wider outbreak. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced the "modest changes" in response to the recent decrease in cases.

site_title: Delivery-only 'ghost' kitchens flourish during pandemic
summary: Ghost kitchens, also known as "dark" kitchens, have flourished during the pandemic as consumers increasingly turn to delivery due to restaurant closures and capacity restrictions. These commercial spaces, hidden from the public, prepare food solely for delivery. Companies like Nextbite and Zuul operate ghost kitchens, offering restaurants technical support and menu development. The trend has led to a three-fold increase in food delivery orders, with DoorDash handling 543 million orders between January and September. The model has created new demand and capitalized on restaurants that have closed, but also raises concerns about job insecurity and the potential for reduced employment in the industry.

site_title: US sues Walmart over opioid crisis
summary: The US Justice Department sued Walmart, alleging the retailer wrongly filled thousands of "invalid" prescriptions and worsened the opioid crisis. The suit claims Walmart prioritized sales over public health, ignoring red flags and failing to report suspicious orders. Walmart denies the charges, calling them "baseless" and accusing the DEA of failing to prevent bad doctors from prescribing opioids. The lawsuit could seek billions of dollars in penalties and marks the latest government crackdown on the opioid crisis, which has driven a significant reduction in US life expectancy.

site_title: UK car output down 1.4% for November, Brexit deal needed: SMMT
summary: UK car production fell 1.4% in November to 106,243 vehicles, with year-to-date production down 31% due to Covid-19 restrictions. Industry body SMMT warns that a possible Brexit shock at year-end could be catastrophic, with no trade deal in place by December 31. SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes calls for flexible rules-of-origin thresholds, a phase-in period, and a 12-month supplier declaration grace period to avoid supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: British car production fell only slightly in November but output is down by almost a third so far in 2020 due to Covid-19 restrictions and the approach of a possible Brexit shock at the end of this month, an industry body said.

site_title: Olam expects H2 loss from impairment, but sees positive net profit for FY2020
summary: Olam International, an agri-food giant, expects to report a loss for the second half of 2020 due to an impairment on Olam Palm Gabon, but expects net profit for the full year to remain positive. The impairment, valued at around $350 million, is attributed to lower rainfall in Gabon affecting the palm oil industry. Despite this, the company expects strong growth in operating performance across its portfolio to drive positive net profit for FY2020.

site_title: FCT to divest Anchorpoint shopping centre for S$110m
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) plans to divest its Anchorpoint shopping centre for S$110 million to unrelated third parties. The sale, expected to complete by March 22, 2021, will focus on repaying debt and working capital. Post divestment, FCT's Singapore retail portfolio will consist of 10 malls with 2.3 million square feet of net lettable area. The proposed transaction aligns with FCT's strategy to strengthen its portfolio with essential trades and services leases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Keppel Reit, Olam, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, LHN
summary: Keppel Corp and Keppel Reit saw developments that may affect trading. Keppel Corp's subsidiary signed an agreement to develop a solar farm in Queensland, Australia. Keppel Corp also reported compliance with US Deferred Prosecution Agreement obligations related to corrupt payments. Keppel Land is divesting its stake in Keppel Bay Tower to Keppel Reit. Olam International reported a loss for the second half of 2020 but expects positive net profit for the full year. Frasers Centrepoint Trust proposed to divest Anchorpoint shopping centre for S$110 million. LHN Limited received in-principle approval to transfer to the mainboard.

site_title: The shortcomings and hidden costs of SPACs
summary: A record 250 SPAC IPOs raised over $81 billion in 2020, with Asian investors increasingly involved. However, research studies have found that SPACs are often opaque and costly, with median share values decreasing by 34% after merger. SPAC investors may have different incentives and horizons, leading to dilution of shares and potential poor performance. Studies also show that SPACs underperform comparable companies, with negative returns of 51.9% in four years following the IPO. The SPAC boom is expected to slow down as retail investors enter the market, and regulatory scrutiny increases, potentially uncovering accounting irregularities and concerns from target companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.7% to 2,808.39, for the third consecutive day. Concerns over the novel coronavirus variant in Britain and underwhelming US economic data contributed to the decline. Losers outnumbered gainers 77 to 41, with local banks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 1.1%, 1.2%, and 0.9% respectively. US equities also closed mainly lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% and the S&P 500 down 0.2%.

site_title: UK businesses report deepening hit from renewed Covid-19 clamp-down: CBI
summary: UK businesses report a deepening hit from renewed coronavirus restrictions, with the Confederation of British Industry's monthly growth indicator showing a fall in business activity to -21, a long way above pandemic crisis low of -71 in June. The economy is expected to decline further, with economists warning of a potential new recession. Finance minister Rishi Sunak is set to spend £280 billion to protect the economy, but the government is under pressure to provide more support for businesses.

site_title: Japan's ruling party calls for more private engagement on digital yen
summary: Japanese policymakers are urging the Bank of Japan to engage more with platform operators and financial institutions to ensure a digital yen does not crowd out the private sector. The central bank plans to experiment with its own digital currency next year, amid China's rapid progress with its digital yuan. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party has called for the BOJ to speed up development of a digital yen, emphasizing the need for cooperation with private sector entities to avoid disrupting the financial system.

site_title: Oil drops as new coronavirus variant revives demand fears
summary: Oil prices dropped to around $50 a barrel on Tuesday due to concerns over a new coronavirus variant in Britain, prompting border closures and fears of demand recovery. Brent crude fell 1.2% and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1.5% as investors awaited a potential deal to restart freight with France. Despite recent vaccine rollout gains, oil prices slid nearly 3% on Monday, with some analysts predicting further price drops amid the holiday season.

site_title: Belgium found four cases of UK covid strain 'early December'
summary: Belgium discovered four cases of the UK COVID-19 mutant strain in early December, primarily in the northern Flemish regions bordering the Netherlands. The cases may be underreported due to less stringent screening compared to the UK. The new strain appears to spread more easily but shows no evidence of increased lethality or vaccine resistance. As a result, over two dozen countries, including Belgium, suspended travel from the UK out of precaution, with some experts warning that the decision to close borders may have come too late.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher despite virus, Brexit worries
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 0.44% to 26,551.76 on December 23, 2020, despite US stocks trading lower due to concerns over a new coronavirus strain, US data, and Brexit uncertainty. The broader Topix index also increased 0.42% to 1,768.46.

site_title: Trump grants full pardon to Russia probe figure George Papadopoulos
summary: US President Donald Trump granted pardons to 15 individuals, including former campaign aide George Papadopoulos, who pleaded guilty to lying to investigators about Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. Papadopoulos was sentenced to 12 days in prison and was granted a full pardon. Trump also pardoned Dutch national Alex van der Zwaan, who was fined and sentenced to 30 days in prison for lying to investigators. The pardons were part of a wave of actions taken by the outgoing president before Democratic President-elect Joe Biden takes office.

site_title: Singapore launches 3.86 hectares of industrial land supply for H1 2021
summary: Singapore has launched 3.86 hectares of industrial land for the first half of 2021, with three sites confirmed and three on the reserve list, totaling less than the 4.4 ha offered in the second half of 2020. The government has taken a cautious stance, scaling back land supply for the fifth time, amid lingering uncertainties around the COVID-19 pandemic and economic growth.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends mostly lower despite new stimulus plan
summary: US stocks closed mostly lower on Tuesday despite the approval of a new $900 billion relief package, citing worrisome economic data and concerns over a new coronavirus variant in Britain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7% and the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5% to reach a new record. The retreat was attributed to concerns over consumer confidence and new travel restrictions, with existing home sales falling for the first time in six months.

site_title: OCBC extends more than S$1b in Sora-linked home loans since launch
summary: OCBC Bank has extended over S$1 billion in home loans linked to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) benchmark in less than six months since its launch. Half of these loans were fully processed digitally, showcasing the lender's adoption of Sora as the new interest rate benchmark for the Singapore dollar cash and derivatives market. The move comes as the industry transitions away from Sibor and Swap Offer Rate (SOR) in favor of Sora, which is seen as a more stable alternative.

site_title: Google, Facebook coordinated antitrust response: report
summary: Google and Facebook coordinated their responses to an antitrust investigation into the digital advertising market, according to a US state lawsuit draft. The two tech giants allegedly agreed to "cooperate and assist each other" in responding to the probe. The case, filed by 10 US states, accuses Google of dominating digital advertising. Facebook dismissed the allegations, stating agreements between the firms were aimed at offering choices and benefits for advertisers and publishers, and not harming competition. The investigation is one of three separate actions against Google.

site_title: EU vows 'final push' in UK trade talks but fish rift threatens deal
summary: The European Union is making a "final push" to strike a Brexit trade deal with the UK, but deep rifts over fishing rights threaten the agreement. EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier said the UK's latest offer on sharing out the fish catch from British waters from 2021 was "totally unacceptable." The EU is willing to cut the value of its fish catch by 25%, while Britain demands a 30-35% cut. The two sides disagree on the length of the fisheries transition regime, with the EU proposing six years and Britain wanting three.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound as Brexit trade deal progress overshadows virus worries
summary: European shares rebounded 1.2% on Tuesday, their best day in six weeks, as optimism over a Brexit trade deal and US stimulus outweighed concerns over a new coronavirus variant in Britain. The EU is making a "final push" to strike a deal with Britain, with progress on fishing a major sticking point. Data showed Britain's economic recovery from the coronavirus crash was quicker than thought in the third quarter, helping London's blue-chip index reverse early losses.

site_title: Twitter followers of US government accounts won't transfer to Biden
summary: Twitter will not automatically transfer followers of US government accounts, such as @WhiteHouse and @POTUS, to the Biden administration when he takes office. Instead, users will have the option to continue following the new accounts or not. The decision affects millions of followers of official Trump administration accounts, but the personal account @realDonaldTrump will remain unaffected, with over 88 million followers.

site_title: Biden says huge cyberattack on US government cannot go unanswered
summary: President-elect Joe Biden stated that the US government's massive cyberattack, likely carried out by Russia, must face consequences and that he will retaliate once he becomes president. The attack, which occurred months ago, affected multiple government and corporate systems, including the departments of State, Commerce, and Homeland Security. Biden criticized President Donald Trump for downplaying the attack and failing to take adequate measures to protect the country's cybersecurity. Biden warned that he will respond in kind once he learns the extent of the damage, but has not yet identified who is formally responsible.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated room for tweaks to stimulus programme: Oct minutes
summary: The Bank of Japan's October rate review minutes showed that several board members considered tweaks to the stimulus programme, including potential adjustments to exchange-traded funds purchases. One member expressed concerns that prolonged crisis-response measures could delay structural reforms needed to boost Japan's long-term growth potential. The BOJ trimmed its economic growth forecast but kept monetary policy steady.

site_title: Joko appoints new health chief as Covid-19 deaths spike in Indonesia
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo appointed Budi Gunadi Sadikin as the new health minister, replacing Terawan Agus Putranto, amid a surge in Covid-19 deaths. Indonesia's case load has surpassed 670,000, and fatalities have reached over 20,000, prompting the cabinet revamp to bolster the government's response. The move comes as the country prepares for an annual economic contraction of up to 2.2% due to restrictions on the virus.

site_title: Looking back at 2020
summary: The article reflects on 2020's market trends, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. Key winners included snack makers Vitasoy International and Nestle Malaysia, which demonstrated resilience despite the pandemic. Conversely, department stores like Robinsons faced significant challenges due to declining returns on equity. Investors were initially overly pessimistic, but by mid-2020, the market began to recover as central banks and governments provided support. The article concludes that investors should focus on building diversified portfolios to mitigate future shocks, rather than trying to predict individual stock performance.

images.alt_text: David Kuo

site_title: Hang Seng proposes major overhaul of HK stock index
summary: Hang Seng Index is considering significant changes to its Hong Kong stock benchmark, including increasing the number of companies to 65-80, capping weightings at 8%, and fast-tracking new listings. The proposal aims to dilute the influence of its largest companies and make the index more representative of the local market. The changes are driven by the growing influence of Chinese megacaps in the city's stock market and the need to make the benchmark less outdated. The proposals are open for feedback until January 24.

site_title: Blackwells makes unsolicited offer for Monmouth Reit
summary: Blackwells Capital has made an unsolicited offer to acquire Monmouth Real Estate Investment Corp for approximately $3.8 billion, including debt, at $18 per share. This is the second proposal, following a previous offer that was rebuffed. Monmouth's board has rejected the offer, citing its strategic value and future prospects, but will review the higher proposal. Blackwells believes Monmouth is undervalued and underperformed its peers due to poor capital allocation, weak corporate governance, and an expensive financing strategy.

site_title: Apple targets car production by 2024
summary: Apple plans to produce a passenger vehicle by 2024, incorporating its breakthrough battery technology. This comes after the company's automotive efforts, known as Project Titan, began in 2014. The move marks a significant step forward for Apple's entry into the car production market.

site_title: World's richest lottery spreads Christmas cheer in Spain
summary: Spain's annual Christmas lottery, "El Gordo," distributed 2.4 billion euros to multiple winners, making it the world's richest lottery. Thousands of numbers were awarded prizes, with 1,720 tickets bearing the top-prize number 72897 selling for 400,000 euros. Winners celebrated with champagne and confetti, temporarily suspending social distancing measures. The lottery, held since 1892, has become a popular Christmas tradition in Spain, spreading holiday cheer amidst the country's struggles with the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Spain's annual Christmas lottery doled out 2.4 billion euros (S$3.87 billion) to multiple winners on Tuesday, spreading holiday cheer in one of the European nations worst hit by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Post Covid-19 recovery in 2021: Favour Asia over developed markets
summary: Asia and emerging markets (EMs) are poised to outperform developed markets in 2021, driven by a combination of positive catalysts, including a cyclical recovery, weakening US dollar, and robust earnings rebound. Asia's economies have recovered faster from the Covid-19 pandemic, while Western developed nations continue to struggle. The article suggests that Asian equities will lead in 2021, with Latin America and EMEA equities offering potential upside, but with higher risks. A stable policy under a Biden administration is also expected to support EM growth.

site_title: Re-thinking the balanced portfolio in a low-yield world
summary: The balanced portfolio, a 50/50 split between equities and fixed income, has a long-term track record of impressive returns, with an annual return of 7% and a volatility of 8.7% between 1990 and 2020. However, with low interest rates and yields, a similar performance is challenging to achieve. Investors are advised to consider raising fixed income exposure or exploring non-traditional bond classes with higher credit risk. Market timing is also discouraged, as it's difficult to consistently predict market trends. Instead, investors can leverage mean reversion by taking advantage of periods of sharp sell-offs to buy while reducing exposure in sectors or markets that are priced at unsustainable valuations.

site_title: EH-Reit cites pandemic, market risks for dive in portfolio value
summary: Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) attributed a 38.1% decline in its portfolio value to the Covid-19 pandemic and market risks. The decline fell outside projected average declines of 15.1-28.1% in the US, with the independent valuer noting that the outlook has worsened since April 2020. EH-Reit's properties, particularly those with high exposure to the mass events and groups business, are expected to take longer to recover. The company's manager expects improvements in capitalisation rates in the medium to long term, driven by market recovery and securing credible master lessees.

site_title: SMEs in Singapore wary of expanding and investing, even as sentiment improves: poll
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have seen improved business sentiment, with the SBF-Experian SME Index rising to 48.2 in the first half of 2021, up from a record low of 46.3. However, SMEs are still hesitant to expand and invest, with business expansion expectations falling to 5.04 and capital investments decreasing to 5. The gradual economic recovery from the pandemic has eased negative expectations, but SMEs are cautious due to an uncertain business climate.

images.alt_text: Business sentiment among SMEs in Singapore has eased off its record low, but firms are still expected to hold off expansion and capital investments for the first half of 2021.

site_title: No action against former PM Abe after prosecutor questioning
summary: Tokyo prosecutors have decided not to take action against Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe after he submitted to voluntary questioning in a case involving unreported political funds. Abe, who stepped down citing ill health in September, is under fire for possible violations of funding laws related to dinner parties for supporters. The decision not to act against Abe risks hurting current Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, whose approval ratings have already tumbled due to his response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Nikkei unit to provide real-time translated content on SGX platform
summary: SGX's Titan OTC platform will provide real-time, AI-translated Nikkei content in English by spring 2021. Nikkei FT ScoutAsia will offer translations of news articles on Japanese companies, stocks, and sectors, with plans to expand to other asset classes. The service aims to eliminate language barriers and information time lag for foreign investors, making it easier to access the Japanese market. The partnership is seen as a welcome feature for Titan OTC clients, enhancing their user experience.

site_title: Legal certainty critical for Indonesia's gig economy
summary: Indonesia's gig economy, fueled by ride-hailing and food delivery firms Gojek and Grab, is set to expand to $124 billion by 2025. However, a potential merger between the two companies has sparked concerns among over 4 million motorbike operators and riders, who fear losing their livelihoods and creating a monopoly. Existing laws do not provide adequate protection for these workers, leaving them vulnerable to exploitation. Experts recommend that Gojek and Grab be registered as public transport companies to bring them under government regulation, providing greater legal certainty for drivers and users alike.

site_title: UK and EU face 'Brexiternity' as building new ties will take years
summary: The UK's post-Brexit relationship with the EU will likely take years to develop, despite the December 31 transition deadline. A ratified UK-EU trade deal will be 'thin' compared to the comprehensive agreement hoped for. The UK may follow a similar path to Switzerland, negotiating bilateral deals to build its institutional relationship. The UK's future relationship with the EU could change significantly over time, potentially moving towards a more integrationist direction. The government will need to continue to devote significant attention to the Brussels-based club, which may not necessarily be better for the national interest than previous EU membership.

site_title: China rations electricity for millions as cities turn dark
summary: China is rationing electricity for millions of people amid a surge in demand due to the country's rapid economic recovery from the pandemic and frigid temperatures. Over 150 million people live in provinces with limited energy use orders, with coal shortages reported in Henan province. Residents are being told to limit energy use, with restrictions including turning off streetlights, elevators, and heating in offices. The measures are part of China's efforts to balance economic growth with environmental goals, with the country aiming to be carbon-neutral by 2060.

site_title: Confident Fauci receives Covid-19 vaccine in 'symbol' for US
summary: US infectious disease specialist Anthony Fauci received a Covid-19 vaccine, taking a 'symbolic' shot to demonstrate confidence in its safety and efficacy. Fauci, along with NIH director Francis Collins, health secretary Alex Azar, and six health workers, received the vaccine at a live-streamed event. The vaccine, developed by Moderna and the NIH, is seen as a crucial step in achieving population immunity, with experts estimating 70-75% of the population needs to be vaccinated for effective protection. A new poll shows increased willingness among Americans to take the vaccine, with 46% saying they are willing to do so.

images.alt_text: Anthony Fauci, the United States' top infectious disease specialist, received his Covid-19 vaccine on Tuesday along with other senior officials and six health workers at a live streamed event at the National Institutes of Health (NIH).

site_title: After bars and beaches, gibbons await a new home in Thailand
summary: A conservation effort in Thailand has successfully rehabilitated and released a colony of gibbons, including a rescued gibbon named Cop, who was once held captive in bars and bars. Since the start of the pandemic, three young gibbons have been rescued, bringing the total to 35 gibbons in the wild, including those born in the wild. The Gibbon Rehabilitation Project, run by the Wild Animal Rescue Foundation of Thailand, has released over 150 gibbons into the wild, with some having grandchildren, offering a rare success story in conservation efforts.

site_title: Pandemic relief fuels record growth in US Q3 GDP
summary: The US economy experienced record growth in Q3, with a 33.4% annualized rate, fueled by over $3 trillion in pandemic relief. However, this growth appears to have lost momentum as the year ended, amid rising Covid-19 cases and dwindling fiscal stimulus. The Commerce Department's third estimate of GDP confirmed this, reversing its previous estimate of 33.1%. The surge in growth was largely driven by the pandemic relief, which had a significant impact on the economy during this period.

site_title: UK student accommodation businesses taking the long view
summary: Singaporean companies with student accommodation businesses in the UK are taking a long-term view amid the worsening pandemic situation, with more than 40 countries banning arrivals from the UK. Despite uncertainty, companies are expanding their purpose-built student accommodation assets and evaluating the impact of travel bans. Metro Holdings has set up a new student accommodation fund to acquire properties in the UK, while Centurion Corporation and Mapletree Group are also assessing the situation and maintaining confidence in the resilience of the education sector.

site_title: UBS taps Credit Suisse banker Sharma to boost deals for rich
summary: UBS has hired Desh Sharma, a top wealth banker from Credit Suisse, to expand loans and sophisticated financings for its richest clients. Sharma will join UBS's global family office unit on January 4, bringing a team of four bankers with him. The move is part of UBS's strategy to increase lending to wealthy entrepreneurs, following similar hires by the bank last year. Sharma's team will focus on originating deals and providing financing for UBS's 2,000 global family office clients, working with teams in investment banking and asset management.

site_title: Will world witness 'Little England' or 'Global Britain' in 2021?
summary: The UK's post-Brexit trajectory is uncertain, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's "Global Britain" ambitions facing challenges from domestic pressures. Johnson's £16.5 billion defense spending pledge is part of a broader review, but Scotland's growing support for independence, including polls indicating 58% support, poses a significant threat. Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon is pushing for another independence referendum, which could lead to the UK's territorial integrity being tested. If Scotland becomes independent, it could undermine the UK's international influence, damaging its diplomatic, trade, and military capabilities.

site_title: Despite Covid, Brooklyn neighbourhood still a flashy Christmas village
summary: In Brooklyn's Dyker Heights neighbourhood, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, a festive Christmas village continues to thrive. The area's large single-family homes feature elaborate holiday displays, drawing large crowds, mostly in masks. The tradition, started in the mid-1980s, brings joy and laughter to locals, who are seeking positive experiences during uncertain times. Local businesses benefit from the influx of tourists, with many praising the area as a more appealing alternative to timed viewings at Rockefeller Center.

site_title: SoftBank to raise US$525m through blank-cheque company
summary: SoftBank Group filed to raise $525 million through a blank-cheque company, SVF Investment Corp, tapping investor enthusiasm for listing vehicles. The Spac will focus on tech sectors and has committed $250-300 million to a potential merger partner. SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son views the Spac as a way to invest in nascent companies while accessing public markets. The company, led by Rajeev Misra and Navneet Govil, will be listed in the US, combining Vision Fund's expertise in tech startups with SoftBank's emphasis on public stock trading.

site_title: Gridlocked government could halt US economic recovery
summary: The US government's gridlock could hinder the country's economic recovery. Despite a successful Covid-19 vaccine rollout, Congress struggled to pass a stimulus bill, leaving some benefits to expire. The ongoing political divisions will determine control of the Senate in January's run-off elections, potentially affecting the pace of withdrawal from economic support. A mixed holiday season may lead to bankruptcies, and the Federal Reserve remains ready to extend monetary accommodation. A brighter outlook in the spring may not be enough to overcome lingering unemployment, stretched business balance sheets, and a gridlocked government.

site_title: Trump makes classical style the default for federal buildings
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order establishing classical architecture as the preferred style for new federal buildings, describing modernist designs as "ugly and inconsistent". The order, titled "Promoting Beautiful Federal Civic Architecture", mandates that federal buildings be "beautiful" and praises Greco-Roman architecture. Critics, including the American Institute of Architects, have opposed the order, calling it "toothless" and arguing it undermines architectural diversity. The order applies to federal courthouses, agency headquarters, and projects costing over $50 million.

site_title: Malaysia signs deal for 6.4m doses of AstraZeneca vaccine
summary: Malaysia has signed a deal to procure 6.4 million doses of AstraZeneca's coronavirus vaccine, in addition to its existing agreements for 12.8 million doses. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced the deal on Tuesday, stating the government is also in final talks with Chinese and Russian manufacturers to secure more doses. This move comes as the country continues to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Thai travel industry faces fresh setback after new outbreak
summary: A new virus outbreak among seafood factory workers in Samut Sakhon province, near Bangkok, has prompted a 14-day lockdown, raising concerns about the impact on Thailand's tourism industry. The outbreak has taken the country's total infections to 5,716, with 1,063 confirmed cases. The Thai government is considering expanding curbs to other locales, which could further harm tourism businesses already struggling to recover from the pandemic. A nationwide lockdown or restrictions on domestic travel could be the final blow to many tourism-related companies, according to the Phuket Hotel Association.

site_title: To 2021 and beyond - a regulator's perspective
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for sustainability and long-term thinking in finance, according to Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean. As a regulator, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) is playing a key role in this shift, with initiatives such as reviewing sustainability reports and introducing meaningful sustainability ratings. Sustainability is now a fiduciary responsibility, with international obligations and scrutiny intensifying. Companies must report meaningfully to attract investors focused on environmental, social, and corporate governance issues, and timeliness is crucial in providing actionable insights.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Darco Water Technologies has granted Emsus Co Ltd a deferment of the first settlement payment of US$500,000 for its repurchasing of Darco's 75% shareholding interests in PT Panghegar Energy Indonesia (PEI). The payment was initially due on December 22, 2020, but Emsus requested a deferment to January 31, 2021, citing a delay in a back-to-back transaction. The third-party investor's eligibility for the project is pending final approval from the West Java Provincial Government.

site_title: Jobs, businesses unlikely to fall off cliff when government aid ends
summary: Singapore's economy is unlikely to experience a sharp cliff effect when government aid and relief schemes, such as the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS), expire. Analysts predict that firms will be able to adapt and manage costs carefully, with some sectors, like financial and infocomm services, already showing signs of growth. Employment growth is expected to turn positive by the first quarter of 2021, with some firms pivoting to new models or supplementing their original ones to ride the recovery. However, sectors like aviation, tourism, and the built environment may face higher risks of cessation if targeted relief measures are not extended beyond the second half of 2021.

site_title: 'Stay-at-home' trade still has legs in 2021, say top mutual fund managers
summary: Top US mutual fund managers say the "stay-at-home" trade will continue into 2021 despite the COVID-19 vaccine announcements, citing secular trends like telemedicine and e-commerce. Funds investing in these areas have seen significant returns, with some funds gaining over 130% since the start of the year. Managers also express confidence in growth companies, such as Tesla, and are not expected to change their strategies despite an economic rebound.

site_title: Pandemic's blight boosts boxship business
summary: A new, highly infectious variant of Covid-19 in the UK has led to border closures and transport disruptions, significantly impacting the international liner shipping sector. The variant, about 70% more infectious, is not considered more deadly but increases the likelihood of infection. This has resulted in the closure of most borders, including those with continental neighbors, causing transport dislocation.

site_title: Virus mutation keeps euro, pound under pressure
summary: The euro and pound were under pressure against the US dollar due to a new coronavirus strain in Britain, which closed trade routes and created supply-chain issues. However, European stock markets rebounded, easing pressure on the euro. Britain's economy recovered quicker than expected, and talks between the French and British governments continued to reopen their border. Despite this, trade talks between the EU and UK remained stalled, with disagreements over fishing rights. The US dollar index rose slightly, but the greenback's gains were muted due to market expectations of a weaker dollar.

site_title: GIC, ESR Cayman set up US$750m venture for real estate in India
summary: Singapore's GIC and ESR Cayman form an 80:20 strategic partnership to establish a $750 million joint venture to develop and acquire institutional-grade industrial and logistics facilities in India. The JV will focus on Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities and has already secured a 2.2 million square foot build-to-core asset near Mumbai and Thane. The partnership is driven by India's growing e-commerce sector, infrastructure investment, and favorable government policies. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Sub-region growth triangles can narrow development gaps among Asean members
summary: Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia are reviving the Sijori free trade triangle, a sub-regional growth triangle established in 1989 to narrow development gaps among ASEAN members. The original plan was to create a three-way economic development triangle, but it stalled due to the 1997 Asian Economic Crisis and regional terrorism. Despite this, multinational corporations continue to operate in the region, and investment into the triangle zone has risen. With the COVID-19 pandemic, the participating governments may now be the time to rethink the triangle's purpose and revise regulations to benefit all sides, emphasizing interdependence, trade, and people flow.

site_title: Join the climate club: Targets are voluntary
summary: The US government is exploring a voluntary "climate club" approach to tackle climate change, focusing on financial aid to help developing economies shift to green growth. This approach is seen as the best bet for reaching an ambitious and inclusive climate pact. The Paris climate agreement, signed by 189 countries, aims to limit global warming to below 2 degrees Celsius relative to pre-industrial levels. As the Covid-19 pandemic subsides, climate change is set to become a major global challenge, requiring effective solutions.

site_title: London luxury homes prime target of dirty money: report
summary: The UK property market, particularly luxury homes in London, is increasingly vulnerable to money laundering, with a high likelihood of buyers using UK real estate to disguise illegal activity. The UK government has upgraded the risk to medium, citing the Covid-19 pandemic and shaky demand for extravagant homes, making it easier for criminals to obtain properties at discounted prices. Over 500 properties in the UK, worth over £5 billion, have been linked to suspicious wealth, and transactions made by corporate structures in tax havens make tracking difficult.

site_title: Singapore bars visitors from UK and New South Wales
summary: Singapore has tightened border measures, barring visitors from the UK and New South Wales, Australia, due to concerns over a more virulent strain of the novel coronavirus. Long-term pass holders and short-term visitors who have traveled to the UK within two weeks of leaving for Singapore, as well as those with travel history to NSW in the past fortnight, will be denied entry. Those affected will be required to undergo a Covid-19 PCR test and serve a stay-home notice at dedicated facilities.

site_title: US existing-home sales decline for first time in six months
summary: US existing-home sales declined 2.5% in November, marking the first decline in six months, according to the National Association of Realtors. The median selling price rose 14.6% to $310,800, the fourth consecutive month of double-digit increases. Existing home sales remain brisk, with demand skewed towards more expensive houses, and the new fiscal stimulus package may prop up household incomes. The record-low inventory and tight market are expected to challenge housing affordability, particularly for first-time buyers.

site_title: Keppel Corp unit to embark on first solar farm project
summary: Keppel Corp's unit, Keppel Renewable Energy (KRE), has agreed to develop its first solar farm project in Queensland, Australia. KRE will pay A$540 (S$545) for a 45% stake in Harlin Solar Pty Ltd and provide a loan of up to A$3.24 million. The 500 MW solar farm will power over 142,000 homes and be connected to the national energy market. Construction is expected to begin in 2022 and be completed in 2023, aligning with Keppel's Vision 2030 strategy of growing its renewable assets to seven GW by 2030.

site_title: New blank-cheque companies arm up for Asian unicorn hunt
summary: More than a dozen special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) in Asia are seeking to acquire fast-growing tech, healthcare, and fintech startups, mirroring the US trend of 2020. SPACs, which raise money through IPOs and merge with firms, have raised a record $70 billion this year. Asian SPACs are targeting companies in South-east Asia, with bankers and lawyers indicating that talks are underway with numerous tech startups. This trend is expected to drive a fundraising frenzy in Asia, with potential implications for the region's growth and investment landscape.

images.alt_text: Ride-hailing and food delivery giant Gojek has been approached or is a target for SPACs, sources say.

site_title: EC calls for reopening of essential trade links to UK
summary: The European Commission has called for the reopening of essential trade links to the UK, urging member states to allow uninterrupted freight transport while discouraging non-essential travel. This move aims to end the chaos at Britain's busiest port and prevent supply chain disruptions. The Commission also recommends discontinuing flight and train bans, citing the need for essential travel and avoiding unnecessary journeys. France has restricted flights and isolated the UK, while the UK's Road Haulage Association welcomes the Commission's statement, hoping for an immediate lift of the ban.

images.alt_text: The ferry terminal at the port of Dover was empty after France shut down freight traffic in a bid to contain a new variant of Covid-19.

site_title: Singapore, Zhejiang to boost cooperation in areas like trade, innovation
summary: Singapore and Zhejiang, a coastal province in eastern China, plan to boost cooperation in areas like trade, innovation, and sustainable urban management. Seven memorandums of understanding were signed, focusing on urban governance, water technology, and environmental protection. Bilateral trade between the two regions reached $4.41 billion in the first nine months of 2020, with cumulative actual investments from Singapore to Zhejiang totaling $7.39 billion. The cooperation aims to be "pandemic-proof" and drive future growth, with opportunities for Singapore companies in trade, transport, and logistics.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine's in town; will hospitality, aviation workers be next in line for jabs?
summary: Singapore has received its first batch of COVID-19 vaccines, with priority going to healthcare workers and frontline personnel, as well as the elderly and vulnerable. The government aims to vaccinate the population by the third quarter of 2021. Initially, the focus will be on healthcare workers and those in the frontlines, such as airport and sea port staff, with subsequent priority groups including hospitality and aviation workers. Economists and industry groups suggest that these workers should be vaccinated due to their high exposure to passengers and clients.

site_title: Indonesia could get billions in US funding to join Israel push
summary: A US official says Indonesia could receive over $1 billion in additional funding from the US International Development Finance Corporation if it establishes ties with Israel, doubling the current portfolio. The US is pushing for more Muslim countries to normalize relations with Israel, and Indonesia is the world's largest Muslim-majority nation. The US has already established a joint fund with Israel and the UAE to invest regionally, and plans to help Indonesia finance its sale of a seaport. The US hopes to expand Israel's natural gas exports to counter Russian and Chinese influence.

site_title: LHN obtains approval from controlling shareholder for acquisition of Balestier property
summary: LHN Limited has obtained written approval from its controlling shareholder, Fragrance Ltd, for the acquisition of a property in Balestier. As a result, the company will not hold an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval. Fragrance Ltd, which represents 54.91% of LHN's share capital, has approved the transaction and related option to purchase. A circular with further details will be sent to shareholders on Wednesday.

site_title: Will Thoma Bravo's US$10b bet on RealPage pay off?
summary: Thoma Bravo is investing $10 billion in RealPage, a software provider for real estate firms, with plans to leverage the company's growth potential. Despite the high valuation, RealPage has shown 13% revenue growth and a 30% Ebitda margin. To achieve a good return, Thoma Bravo will need to either increase the company's value by 50% or pay down debt, which is a stretch considering the company's $300 million cash flow from operations. Thoma Bravo is optimistic about the growing real estate market and the potential for RealPage to benefit as a "pick and shovel" provider.

site_title: Aspen receives in-principle approval for transfer to SGX mainboard
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) to transfer its listing from the Catalist board to the mainboard, pending shareholders' approval via a special resolution and compliance with listing requirements.

site_title: EU calls on member states to reopen transport links to UK
summary: The European Commission has urged EU member states to reopen transport links to the UK, allowing critical trade and passenger transport to continue uninterrupted. Freight transport to and from the UK must be allowed to continue, but non-essential travel is discouraged until further notice. The EU is also warning of potential supply chain disruptions and the impact on food shortages, particularly with the UK's busiest port in Dover being shut down due to COVID-19 concerns. The UK is set to leave the EU's customs union on December 31, and without a trade deal, it will face costly tariffs and quotas.

site_title: Airbus warns of US$5b in lost orders on AirAsia X debt plan
summary: Airbus warns of potential losses of over $5 billion due to AirAsia X's restructuring plans, which may lead to adjustments in A330neo production rates. The European plane maker has already built or ordered 78 A330neos, but the proposed restructuring plan could eliminate purchase commitments, including Airbus orders. AirAsia X aims to restructure its $15 billion debt and stock, but the plan's impact on Airbus is a concern, particularly for the A330 program currently producing only two aircraft a month.

site_title: US consumer confidence unexpectedly drops, hits four-month low
summary: US consumer confidence unexpectedly dropped to a four-month low in December, reaching 88.6, below all estimates. The decline was attributed to surging Covid-19 cases and tightened restrictions. In contrast, expectations rose, and sentiment about current conditions fell. The Conference Board index marked a four-month low, indicating decreased consumer confidence amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: STI down 0.67% amid Covid-19 resurgence, fresh lockdowns
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.67% to 2,827.32 on Tuesday amid the global Covid-19 resurgence and resulting lockdowns. Aviation-related stocks declined, while companies involved in the glove and healthcare sectors gained, with UG Healthcare registering the largest gain of 9.65%.

site_title: Details on vaccination programme could be released by January, says Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Lawrence Wong announced that details on the country's Covid-19 vaccination programme could be released as early as January, but the exact timing depends on various factors, including vaccine supply and delivery schedules. Priority will be given to healthcare and front-line workers, with vaccination to begin between the end of the year and January or February. The roll-out to the general population is expected to take several months, with the aim of vaccinating everyone by the third quarter of 2021.

site_title: Covid-19: More bad news for retirement adequacy
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has worsened retirement adequacy due to reduced employment income, lower dividend payouts, and decreased investment returns. A Mercer CFA Institute study found that three factors will reduce retirement benefits: decreased investment returns, reduced future government support, and earlier access to retirement benefits. The pandemic's economic impact has led to lower interest rates, reduced government support, and increased debt, further exacerbating the issue. However, the study also notes that some individuals may be able to alleviate their situation by taking remedial steps, and saving for retirement can take time to recoup losses over the long term.

images.alt_text: Chan Choong Tho
Chan Fook Leong

site_title: EU rebuffs Boris Johnson's latest Brexit concession on fish
summary: The European Union rejected the UK's latest Brexit concession on fishing, which would have seen a 30% reduction in EU catches in British waters. This deal was part of efforts to secure a post-Brexit trade agreement, but with only nine days left before the UK leaves the EU's single market and customs union, a compromise seems unlikely. The UK remains opposed to the EU's demand for cross-retaliation, and a deal appears to be slipping further out of reach.

site_title: China to tighten regulation of community group buying
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) plans to tighten regulation of community group buying, a sector that allows local residents to buy goods in bulk at discounted prices through internet giants. The move aims to prevent monopolistic behavior and protect consumer rights. The SAMR will increase oversight of platforms like Alibaba, Tencent, and JD.Com, urging them not to compete with unreasonably low prices. This comes after Beijing issued draft rules to prevent monopolistic behavior by internet companies last month. The regulations are part of China's efforts to strengthen oversight of its big tech firms.

site_title: Japan's MUFG bank business to make managing director Hanzawa CEO
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's banking unit will promote managing director Junichi Hanzawa to CEO in April, replacing Kanetsugu Mike. Hanzawa, 55, will be the first managing director to hold the position, aiming to shake up the bank's corporate culture. The move follows a recent management reshuffle, with a new group CEO appointed in April. Hanzawa's background as a contemporary of Japanese novelist Jun Ikeido adds a literary twist to the promotion, mirroring the protagonist in Ikeido's bestselling novels.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 15.97 points lower on Tuesday at 1,631.92, with a trading volume of 7.836 billion lots worth RM 4.140 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 1,045 to 252.

site_title: Covid-19's long-term impact on economies, markets and ESG
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on economies, markets, and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices. The recovery is expected to be uneven, with hard-hit sectors such as airlines and travel unlikely to regain pre-pandemic levels. Businesses will need to adapt to new circumstances, prioritizing preparedness, remote working, and flexibility. Governments are likely to continue intervening in the economy, and globalisation may experience a re-evaluation. The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of ESG issues beyond climate change, with a focus on social and governance concerns.

site_title: EH-Reit attributes 38% fall in portfolio value to pandemic pressures, market risks
summary: Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) attributed a 38.1% decline in its portfolio value to the Covid-19 pandemic and market risks. The decline is higher than projected average declines in US property values, which ranged between 15.1% and 28.1%. EH-Reit's manager cited uncertain market outlooks, increased cost profiles, and longer recovery timelines for the industry, leading to a higher and wider range for terminal capitalisation rates and discount rates. The decline is expected to last at least three to four years, negatively impacting near-term cashflows and valuations.

site_title: Thai seafood market coronavirus infections top 1,000
summary: Thailand's coronavirus outbreak linked to a seafood market has surpassed 1,000 confirmed cases, with 1,063 cases out of 6,156 tested as of Tuesday morning. The outbreak began after a 67-year-old prawn seller tested positive on Thursday, prompting authorities to weigh introducing a wider lockdown. This marks a significant increase from Thailand's previous 4,300 infections, putting the country on high alert.

site_title: STI drops 0.67% to 2,827.32 points; glove-makers gain but aviation-related stocks lose
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.67% to 2,827.32 points on Tuesday, affected by the global COVID-19 resurgence and tighter border restrictions. Aviation-related stocks, including Singapore Airlines and SIA Engineering, declined, while glove-makers Riverstone, Top Glove, and UG Healthcare gained. SIA used 80% of the raised funds from its dilutive rights issue, potentially leading to additional mandatory convertible bonds.

site_title: In world's top ice wine region, 2020 vintage will be rare find
summary: In Canada's Niagara region, the 2020 ice wine harvest is expected to be rare due to the lowest amount of grapes earmarked by Ontario vineyards in at least 20 years. Winemakers have reduced their winter crop by 25-30% due to an exceptional summer and the pandemic's impact on tourism, which is a key market for ice wines. The scarcity will make 2020 ice wines a standout for connoisseurs, with some producers skipping the winter harvest altogether. The region's ice wine production is expected to remain high, with Arterra Wines Canada Inc. planning to pick 25-30% of its usual crop.

images.alt_text: Arterra Wines Canada Inc is the world's biggest ice wine producer and exporter. Randy Dufour (above), vice president of exports, says the company will scale back its crop to 25 per cent to 30 per cent of its usual yield.
The term "icewine" has been trademarked and is produced and sold under stringent standards.

site_title: Keppel Corp unit to embark on first solar farm project
summary: Keppel Corp's unit, Keppel Renewable Energy, has agreed to develop its first solar farm project, a 500 MW greenfield solar farm in Queensland, Australia. KRE will pay A$540 for a 45% stake and provide up to A$3.24 million in funding. The project is expected to begin construction in 2022 and be completed in 2023, powering over 142,000 homes. This move aligns with Keppel's Vision 2030, aiming to grow its renewable assets to seven GW by 2030.

site_title: Q3 GDP growth in US revised slightly up
summary: The US economy grew at a record 33.4% annualized rate in the third quarter, driven by pandemic relief, but appears to have lost momentum amid rising Covid-19 cases and dwindling fiscal stimulus. The economy remains 3.5% below its 2019 level. A new $900 billion rescue package has been approved, providing direct payments and support for small businesses, but economists say it's insufficient and too late to sustain the economy until the pandemic subsides. GDP growth estimates for the fourth quarter are around a 5% rate, with most economists expecting modest growth or contraction in the first three months of 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are cautious about expanding and investing, despite improved sentiment. A poll found that expectations for business expansion and capital investments weakened. Meanwhile, a US$750 million joint venture was established between GIC and ESR Cayman to invest in real estate in India. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) launched industrial land supply for the first half of 2021, and a new insurtech business will be launched in Indonesia by ZA Tech and OVO. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.67% to 2,827.32 points, with glove-makers gaining but aviation-related stocks losing.

site_title: 29 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 29 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported, on December 22, 2020, bringing the total to 58,461. Among the imported cases, three are Singaporeans, one is a permanent resident, and 23 are work pass holders. There were no new community cases or cases from workers' dormitories. The number of new cases in the community has remained low, with a total of one case in the past week who is currently unlinked.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open, London falls further
summary: Europe's stock markets rebounded at the open on Tuesday, with the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index jumping 0.9% to 13,359.31 points. London's FTSE 100 index, however, fell 0.2% to 6,401.41 points, extending losses from the previous session due to concerns over a more infectious coronavirus strain in Britain.

site_title: EasyJet defers more Airbus planes as virus roils air travel
summary: EasyJet defers the delivery of 22 Airbus planes to conserve cash amid the coronavirus crisis. The airline will delay handovers from 2022-2024 to 2027-2028, taking no deliveries in 2021. This move follows previous deferrals of 24 A320-family jets and comes after EasyJet cut jobs, closed bases, and reported its first annual loss in 2020. Founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou has also urged the airline to cancel its entire Airbus order for over 100 aircraft.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher on Apple boost, stimulus optimism
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher on Tuesday, driven by an exclusive report on Apple's car and battery production, as well as the approval of a coronavirus stimulus package. The S&P 500 rose 3.16 points, or 0.09%, to 3,698.08, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 42.70 points, or 0.34%, to 12,785.22. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 16.25 points, or 0.05%, to 30,200.20. The gains came as investors remained optimistic about the US economy despite ongoing trade tensions with the EU.

site_title: Japan Inc cuts bonuses to put more pressure on spending
summary: Japanese companies have reduced year-end bonuses by 9% to 865,621 yen, the largest drop since the 2009 financial crisis. This move is expected to further pressure consumer spending, already weakened by the government's halt to a domestic travel initiative. The cut in bonuses, which were previously reduced by 2.2% in the summer, affects 164 large corporations and varies by industry, with service companies taking the biggest hit. The government has unveiled a stimulus package of over $700 billion to boost the economy, which may be delayed due to the travel campaign being put on hold.

site_title: Ryanair cancels some UK services in dispute over foreign jets
summary: Ryanair cancels 12 UK domestic and international routes due to a dispute with the UK's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) over its rules on foreign-registered aircraft. The CAA claims the rules were not changed, but Ryanair argues the new requirements are impractical and contradict agreements made two years ago. The airline has only one plane registered in the UK, and other European carriers may face similar issues as the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down for third straight session
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell for a third consecutive session, dropping 1.04% to 26,436.39, amid concerns over a new strain of coronavirus triggering profit-taking. The broader Topix index also declined 1.56% to 1,761.12.

site_title: Ivory Coast company brings Black dolls to African children
summary: Ivory Coast company Naima Dolls, founded by Sara Coulibaly, has created dolls with dark skin to promote representation and self-acceptance among African children. The company, which employs 20 young women, produces 150,000 dolls per year and aims to eventually manufacture in Ivory Coast. The dolls, named after regions in the country, have gained popularity among local children and parents, who appreciate the representation and cultural pride they offer. Coulibaly's goal is to help children make positive decisions and appreciate their own beauty and culture.

site_title: Pfizer, Moderna testing their vaccines against UK coronavirus variant
summary: Pfizer and Moderna are testing their Covid-19 vaccines against the UK variant, known as B.1.1.7, which is 40-70% more transmissible. Moderna expects its vaccine to provide immunity against the variant, while Pfizer is gathering data on the vaccine's effectiveness against the new strain. The companies are conducting additional tests to confirm the results. Despite concerns, scientists believe that current vaccines will still protect against the variant, and the discovery has sparked a fresh wave of panic in the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Pfizer and Moderna are testing their Covid-19 vaccines against the new fast-spreading version of the virus that has emerged in Britain, CNN reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Vodafone offers to pay more than two billion euros to end German legal fight
summary: Vodafone has offered over 2 billion euros to buy out minority shareholders in Kabel Deutschland Holding, ending a long-running legal battle. The British firm, which acquired a 77% stake in the German cable company in 2013, will offer 103 euros in cash for each outstanding share. Minority shareholders representing 17% have accepted the offer, with hedge funds Elliott, D.E. Shaw, and UBS O'Connor agreeing not to take further action. This resolves a 2019 court ruling that Vodafone's compensation for the takeover was "adequate".

site_title: UK border crisis puts fruit supply at risk while meat piles up
summary: The UK's food supply chain is at risk due to border disruptions and a no-deal Brexit, particularly with key transport links to Europe freezing up. The UK relies heavily on imports for fresh produce, with the EU providing a quarter of the country's food supply, and is facing shortages of fruits and vegetables. Meanwhile, exporters of lamb and salmon are stuck with a surplus due to port disruptions. The situation is exacerbated by the UK's limited domestic production of fruits and vegetables, with the British Growers Association warning of potential shortages of salads, berries, and citrus.

site_title: Jokowi replaces Indonesia's health minister as Covid deaths spike
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo replaced Health Minister Terawan Agus Putranto amid a surge in Covid-19 cases, with Budi Gunadi Sadikin, a former banker and state official, taking over. Indonesia's case load has surpassed 670,000, with over 20,000 fatalities. The Cabinet revamp aims to bolster the government's response to the pandemic, which has sparked criticism from civil-society groups. The country is expected to contract by up to 2.2% this year due to restrictions.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo replaced the country's health chief as part of a Cabinet revamp to bolster government efforts against Southeast Asia's worst coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Taiwan reports first locally transmitted Covid-19 case since April
summary: Taiwan reported its first locally transmitted Covid-19 case since April 12, a 30-year-old woman who had contact with a New Zealand pilot. The case has raised concerns, with the government testing over 100 contacts and monitoring health. Taiwan has kept the pandemic under control, but imported cases have increased, prompting the government to raise alert levels. The country has reported 771 cases, mostly imported, and seven deaths, with 130 people in hospital.

images.alt_text: Taiwan on Tuesday reported its first locally transmitted case of Covid-19 since April 12, a friend of a New Zealand pilot who was confirmed to have been infected earlier this week, and is testing more than 100 contacts of the woman.

site_title: Saudi sovereign wealth fund hires new corporate finance head, makes other changes
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has hired Fahad al-Saif as its new corporate finance head, replacing Alireza Zaimi. Al-Saif brings over 20 years of experience in corporate and investment banking. The fund also appointed Rania Nashar as senior advisor to Governor Yasir al-Rumayyan. These changes aim to further diversify the fund's portfolio and reduce Saudi Arabia's reliance on oil. The fund now has over 1,000 employees and manages $360 billion in assets.

site_title: Digital payments and e-commerce booming in South and South-east Asia
summary: Digital payments and e-commerce are booming in South and South-east Asia, with India, Indonesia, and Singapore leading the pack in terms of value and compound annual growth rate. India's digital payments are expected to reach nearly $69.17 billion by 2024, with a 19.5% CAGR. Asia leads the world in e-commerce, with the region's spending expected to reach $4 trillion by 2024, accounting for 65.9% of the global market. The growth of digital payments is driven by factors such as smartphone penetration, young populations, and government support for the digital economy.

site_title: Hang Seng Indexes to shake up Hong Kong benchmark, add new constituents
summary: The Hang Seng Index, Hong Kong's main stock index, is set to undergo changes with the addition of new constituents, increasing the total number to 80 from 52. The proposed changes also reduce the weighting cap on individual constituents to 8% from 10%.
