This shift reflects the growing presence of technology companies, including secondary listings by US firms, and aims to better represent the city's evolving economy. The changes are part of a consultation paper published by the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong.

site_title: Nikkei subsidiary to develop real-time translated content on SGX platform
summary: A new service providing real-time machine-translated content from Nikkei.com will be available on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Titan OTC platform in the spring of 2021. Nikkei FT ScoutAsia, a joint venture between Nikkei and Financial Times, will use AI technology to translate Japanese content into English for Titan OTC users. The service will initially focus on news articles about Japanese companies and sectors, with plans to expand to other asset classes. The goal is to eliminate language barriers and information time lags for foreign investors and clients accessing the Japanese market.

site_title: UAE says Qatar media 'undermining' Gulf crisis progress
summary: UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs Anwar Gargash accused Qatari media of undermining efforts to resolve the three-year Gulf crisis ahead of a GCC summit on January 5. Gargash did not specify the media outlets, but comments came after Qatar's Al-Jazeera reported its journalists' mobile phones had been hacked. The GCC, which includes Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE, has been working towards a resolution, with Saudi Arabia expressing willingness to resolve the rift. A resolution is seen as crucial as Gulf states prepare for the incoming US administration of President-elect Joe Biden.

site_title: Two Vatican cardinals, papal aides, test positive for coronavirus: source
summary: Two Vatican cardinals, Cardinal Konrad Krajewski and Italian Cardinal Giuseppe Bertello, have tested positive for coronavirus. Cardinal Krajewski, 57, is hospitalized for pneumonia, while Cardinal Bertello, 78, is in self-isolation at home. It's unclear if they attended an event with the pope on Monday. The news comes as Italy continues to grapple with the pandemic, with 69,214 reported fatalities and 1.96 million cases. The Vatican is set to begin vaccinating residents and staff early in the new year.

site_title: Climate change ravages Kashmir's 'red gold' saffron crop
summary: Climate change has ravaged Kashmir's saffron crop, halving yields over the past two decades. The "red gold" crop, which has brought wealth to the region for 2,500 years, is now a thin and bedraggled crop due to dry conditions blamed on climate change. Farmers in Indian-administered Kashmir's saffron-growing region Pampore are struggling, with Abdul Ahad Mir describing the fields as "like goldmines" in the past. The decline threatens the future of the cash crop.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a third consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.71% to 26,119.25. Investors were concerned about a surge in virus cases, overshadowing the passage of a US stimulus package. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Index falling 1.86% to 3,356.78 and the Shenzhen Index falling 1.76% to 2,264.48.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drop most in two weeks on virus mutation fears
summary: South Korean shares dropped 1.6% to 2,733.68, their biggest decline in two weeks, as foreign investors took profits due to rising concerns over a new fast-spreading strain of the coronavirus and fresh Covid-related curbs at home. The benchmark Kospi has risen 24.39% so far this year, but investors are increasingly cashing in on a recent rally, citing fears over the risks from coronavirus mutation. South Korea closed ski resorts and tourist spots to curb a third wave of Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Bottlenecks rattle world economy backbone of container shipping
summary: The global container shipping industry is facing significant challenges due to the ongoing pandemic, with bottlenecks at ports from southern England to Shanghai causing delays and disruptions. In November, just 50.1% of container vessels arrived on time, down from 80% a year earlier, and on-time arrivals dropped below 30% in many regions. The main sticking point is spot rates, which have soared despite service disruptions, with the rate to ship a container from China to Europe jumping 17% last week. Shippers are calling for relief, with some expecting it not until March or so of 2021, as carriers capitalize on the industry's overcapacity and profit margins.

site_title: UK rail freight ready to relieve road gridlocks
summary: The UK rail freight industry is poised to play a crucial role in alleviating road gridlocks at the Channel port of Dover due to Brexit-related border restrictions. Freightliner Group, a leading rail company, is ready to transport goods across Britain, and its longest trains can carry around 60 containers. With the UK's rail freight volume recovering from the pandemic, the industry is gaining popularity due to environmental benefits. The rail sector is also expected to benefit from post-Brexit customs processes, with some businesses relocating away from Dover.

site_title: EU scrambles to tackle holiday season chaos as new virus strain spreads
summary: The European Union is scrambling to respond to a new strain of the coronavirus that has prompted travel restrictions with the UK, with over two dozen countries suspending flights from Britain. The World Health Organization says the UK variant may be up to 70% more transmissible, but there's no evidence it's more lethal or affects vaccine impact. EU ambassadors meet to discuss a unified approach, and the UK has begun rolling out the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, with the EU to follow on December 27.

site_title: SoftBank files for blank-cheque company to raise over US$500m
summary: SoftBank Group filed for a US$525 million blank-cheque company, SVF Investment Corp, to raise funds and invest in emerging tech sectors. The company, led by SoftBank's Rajeev Misra, aims to merge with a private company, unlocking value in the existing portfolio. This is SoftBank's maiden SPAC, coinciding with a surge in tech IPOs. The move is seen as a strategic way for SoftBank to invest in nascent companies while tapping the public markets for money, fitting with the Vision Fund's style of financial engineering.

site_title: Some travellers from UK, New South Wales not allowed to enter Singapore from Dec 24
summary: Singapore has introduced tighter border restrictions, effective December 24, due to the deteriorating COVID-19 situation in the UK and Australia. Travelers from the UK and New South Wales, Australia, with recent travel history within the last 14 days, will be denied entry. Returning Singapore citizens and permanent residents from the UK will undergo a COVID-19 PCR test, while Singaporeans, PRs, and long-term pass holders with travel history to NSW will serve a 7-day stay-home notice and take a PCR test. The restrictions aim to curb the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: Short-term travellers holding an Air Travel Pass with travel history to New South Wales (NSW) in Australia, within the last 14 days before departure for Singapore, will not be allowed to enter the Republic from Thursday.

site_title: China State Construction Engineering awarded S$237.6m PUB contract
summary: The Singapore branch of China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCE) has been awarded a S$237.6 million contract to construct two industrial liquids modules (ILMs) for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The ILMs will have a treatment capacity of 150,000 cubic meters per day and are expected to commence construction on Dec 30, 2020. Upon completion, the plant will be the first to reclaim industrial used water for reuse, marking a significant step forward in boosting Singapore's water recycling capabilities.

site_title: GIC, ESR Cayman establish US$750m JV to invest in real estate in India
summary: Sovereign wealth fund GIC and ESR Cayman establish a US$750 million joint venture to develop and acquire industrial and logistics assets in India, focusing on Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities. The partnership will develop institutional-grade facilities and acquire core assets, driven by the growth of e-commerce and infrastructure investment. The joint venture will be seeded with a 2.2 million square foot build-to-core asset near Mumbai and Thane, capitalizing on India's rapidly modernizing industrial and logistics landscape.

site_title: Thai travel industry faces 'nail in coffin' after new outbreak
summary: A new virus outbreak among seafood factory workers near Bangkok has raised concerns about a potential "nail in the coffin" for Thailand's tourism industry. The government is considering expanded lockdowns or travel restrictions, which could impact Phuket and other tourist destinations. The outbreak has prompted a 14-day lockdown in Samut Sakhon province and has raised fears among hotel owners and businesses that rely on domestic travel. Thailand's tourism industry is crucial to its economy, with foreign tourist arrivals generating over $60 billion in revenue in 2019.

site_title: In world's top ice wine region, 2020 vintage will be rare find
summary: Canada's Niagara region, known for its premium ice wine, is expected to have its smallest winter harvest in two decades due to an exceptional summer and below-freezing temperatures. The 2020 vintage will be a rare find, with only 25-30% of the typical yield available for ice wine production. This scarcity will make 2020 ice wines highly sought after by connoisseurs, who can expect to pay upwards of $400 for a half-bottle. Canadian winemakers have scaled back production, with some producers skipping the winter harvest altogether due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: ZA Tech, OVO to launch new insurtech business in Indonesia
summary: ZA Tech Global and OVO Group's holding company are launching a new insurtech business in Indonesia, offering insurance companies access to proprietary technology and applications. ZA Tech will provide know-how and platform-based solutions, while OVO will provide user insights. The partnership aims to address low insurance awareness in Indonesia and accelerate adoption, particularly during the pandemic. The move is expected to drive digital transformation in the local insurance sector, with both parties excited about the partnership and its potential to drive innovation.

site_title: Alchemy Foodtech closes bridge round led by Thai Union; eyes China expansion
summary: Alchemy Foodtech, a Singapore-based foodtech startup, has closed a seven-figure bridge round led by Thai Union Group PCL, with other investors including Temasek-backed Bits x Bites and Fuchsia Venture Capital. The round will fuel expansion in China, where one-third of adults with diabetes reside, and Singapore. Alchemy Foodtech's patented product, Alchemy Fibre, turns refined carbohydrates into healthier options, and the company plans to introduce "made with Alchemy Fibre" products to supermarkets in Singapore from January 2021.

site_title: OCBC extended more than S$1b in Sora-linked home loans since launch
summary: OCBC Bank has extended over S$1 billion in Sora-linked home loans since its launch, with half of the loans fully processed digitally. The move comes as the industry shifts towards adopting Sora as the new interest rate benchmark for the SGD cash and derivatives market. OCBC was the first bank to offer Sora-based home loans, referencing the three-month Compounded Sora. The strong take-up indicates consumers are receptive to Sora, and the market is expected to be ready for the new benchmark by 2024.

site_title: SGX-backed iSTOX lists unicorn fund with US$20,000 minimum investment
summary: iSTOX, backed by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Temasek Holdings, has listed a unicorn fund with a minimum investment of US$20,000, enabling accredited investors to access billion-dollar companies globally. The ICHAM Unicorn Opportunity Fund raised close to US$20 million and aims to invest in unicorns globally. This marks a shift from traditional, non-digitised launches, where high minimum thresholds limited participation to institutional investors and ultra-high-net-worth individuals. The use of blockchain and smart contract technology enables tokenisation and fractionalisation of securities, expanding participation to all accredited investors.

site_title: Singapore launches 3.86ha of industrial land supply for H1 2021
summary: Singapore has launched 3.86 hectares of industrial land across six sites for the first half of 2021 under the industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. The confirmed sites are in Tampines North Drive 5, Gul Avenue, and Jalan Papan, with a 20-year tenure and estimated availability from March to June next year. Three reserve list sites are also available, with varying tenures and estimated availability from February to May next year. The government aims to ensure an adequate supply of industrial space in Singapore through the IGLS programme.

site_title: Toyota to halt work in UK and France over mutant virus discord
summary: Toyota will halt production in its UK and France plants starting December 22 due to transport delays caused by a mutant strain of coronavirus spreading in the UK. The border closures have disrupted the transportation of parts, leading to the early shutdown. The UK plants will resume operations on January 5, while the France plant will restart on December 29 as scheduled. This move is part of a global effort to contain the spread of the new strain, with several countries closing their borders with the UK to prevent further infections.

site_title: Singapore's happy 'glampers' pick Changi Airport for year-end holidays
summary: In Singapore, some residents are opting for "glamping" at Changi Airport this holiday season due to travel restrictions. Guests can spend up to S$360 a night in luxury tents with amenities like air-conditioned gardens, walking trails, and an indoor waterfall. The "glamp-cations" offer a unique experience, providing a sense of the outdoors without the bugs and humidity. Many residents, including families, are taking advantage of the glamping option, which is expected to remain popular until December 28.

site_title: Malaysia procures 6.4 million doses of AstraZeneca's coronavirus vaccine: Muhyiddin
summary: Malaysia has signed a deal to procure 6.4 million doses of AstraZeneca's coronavirus vaccine, with the goal of covering over 80% of its population. The country is also in final negotiations with Sinovac, CanSino, and Gamaleya Institute for their vaccines. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced the move in a televised address, aiming to bolster the nation's vaccination efforts against the pandemic.

site_title: Thai central bank seen holding key rate at record low 0.50%: poll
summary: Thailand's central bank is expected to keep its key interest rate at a record low of 0.50% due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the tourism-reliant economy. A Reuters poll of 13 economists showed all but one predicted the Bank of Thailand's Monetary Policy Committee would maintain the rate steady. However, rising risks to growth and protracted political protests may prompt the central bank to take action sooner, with some economists predicting a rate cut by the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: China limits power supplies as demand surges on cold weather
summary: China is limiting power supplies in Hunan and Jiangxi provinces due to a surge in demand caused by cold weather and the country's industrial recovery. Power plants are cutting supplies to industrial and commercial customers by at least 18% compared to the previous year. Residential supplies remain unaffected. The outages are attributed to soaring coal and natural gas costs, with transportation constraints exacerbating the issue.

site_title: Former Japan PM Abe questioned on Monday by prosecutors: NHK
summary: Former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe submitted to voluntary questioning by Tokyo prosecutors on Monday over unreported political funds. The questioning comes after prosecutors built a case against his secretary. The Tokyo prosecutors' office declined to comment on the investigation. This development is related to payments for a dinner party.

site_title: TikTok clone gets Google, Microsoft backing in US$100m fund raise
summary: Bengaluru-based VerSe Innovation, the parent of Indian short-video app Josh, has raised over $100 million from investors including Google and Microsoft. This funding values VerSe at over $1 billion, following the ban of Chinese-owned TikTok in India. The investment will be used to scale up Josh, which has been installed on over 50 million devices, alongside its news and content platform Dailyhunt. This comes after ShareChat, another Indian short-video app, raised $40 million in September.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall further as new strain clouds near-term outlook
summary: Asia markets fell further on Tuesday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul in the red, as concerns over a new, 70% more transmissible virus strain in the UK overshadowed the rollout of vaccines and US stimulus news. Investors took profit as the festive break approached, citing concerns about the immediate impact of the latest wave of infections. The pound struggled due to Brexit trade talks, with a potential compromise on fishing grounds seen as a possible solution.

site_title: Austrians press EU to talk turkey, raise farm standards
summary: Austrian farmers are pressing the EU to adopt higher farm standards for turkey production, citing the need for more space and care for fragile chicks. Katharina and Reinhard Bauer, owners of an organic farm in Austria, showcase their cosseted turkey chicks, highlighting the delicate nature of the business. The Austrian government supports the move, and similar standards are sought across the EU to improve animal welfare.

site_title: Japan PM Suga shies away from calling state of emergency as virus cases rise
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has refused to call a national state of emergency despite rising Covid-19 cases, citing the need to show results of his pandemic countermeasures. Japan has seen a record 2,154 hospitalizations, while a group of medical associations declared their own state of medical emergency. Suga's decision comes amid falling approval ratings, with polls showing public disapproval of his handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as new virus strain clouds recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares fell 1.1% to 6,599.6 on Dec 22, 2020, amid a new coronavirus strain in Britain that triggered global travel restrictions and disrupted economic recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at its lowest since Dec 2. Several countries, including Australia, shut their borders to Britain after the country identified a mutated variant that has killed about 1.7 million people worldwide. The fall in shares was attributed to concerns about the impact of the new strain on global economic growth.

site_title: SMEs in Singapore wary of expanding and investing, even as sentiment improves: poll
summary: Business sentiment among Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has eased to a 48.2 reading, up from a record low of 46.3, but firms still expect to hold back from expansion and capital investments in the first half of 2021. Expectations for turnover, profitability, access to financing, and hiring improved, but business expansion and capital investments weakened. SMEs cited uncertainty and a desire to "better manage cash flow" as reasons for holding back, despite the easing of restrictions and the availability of the Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Movie studio behind 'James Bond' franchise explores sale: WSJ
summary: US movie studio MGM Holdings is exploring a sale, reportedly tapping investment banks Morgan Stanley and LionTree LLC, according to the Wall Street Journal. The company, behind the James Bond franchise, has a market value of around $5.5 billion. MGM Holdings has started a formal sale process, but did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

site_title: More UK retailers fight to survive after one of worst years
summary: The number of British retailers in financial distress has surged by 24% this year, with 40,000 companies facing significant financial struggles. The UK retail sector, already weakened by a crisis of confidence, has been further shaken by the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit. Several high-profile retailers, including Debenhams and Arcadia Group, have collapsed, and the industry is calling for urgent government support to help retailers weather the crisis.

site_title: Testing blitz shows Australian coronavirus cluster contained in Sydney's northeast
summary: NSW reported its lowest one-day rise in new Covid-19 cases in nearly a week, with eight new locally acquired cases, down from 15 the previous day. The cluster in Sydney's northern beaches suburbs, now 90 cases, is believed to have originated from a returning US traveller. Authorities are battling to contain the outbreak, with record rates of testing and lockdowns in place. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian expressed optimism that contact tracing and social distancing are working to bring the outbreak under control, with restrictions set to be reviewed on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip on Tuesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, tracking regional and US market declines, as enthusiasm over the US coronavirus stimulus package was dampened by the emergence of a new Covid strain in the UK. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 2,838.45, with SIA and Mapletree Logistics Trust down 0.7% and 0.5% respectively. US major indices closed mixed on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the red.

site_title: Argentine port strike worries Brazil's wheat millers: trade group
summary: A prolonged strike in Argentina's ports is causing delays in loading agricultural products, including wheat, for Brazilian wheat millers. Over 100 cargo ships are facing delays, and government data shows a significant drop in incoming wheat volumes. Brazil's wheat imports have dropped by half, and the country's internal supplies face risks if the strike continues in January. Industry representatives warn that the situation is "dramatic" and may lead to a rise in costs for millers, potentially forcing them to use less-competitive producers.

site_title: Australia's Nov retail sales surge: ABS preliminary data
summary: Australia's retail sales surged 7% in November from the previous month, driven by pre-Christmas shopping, according to preliminary data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Annual turnover jumped 13.2%, with Victoria leading the growth following the easing of coronavirus restrictions. The ABS will release its final estimate on January 11. This strong retail performance suggests a strong rebound in fourth-quarter economic growth.

site_title: SIA to trial digital health verification process on inbound flights from KL, Jakarta
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is to trial a digital health verification process on inbound flights from Jakarta and Kuala Lumpur, the first of its kind based on the International Air Transport Association's (IATA) Travel Pass framework. Passengers will securely store and present Covid-19 test and vaccination information through a digital or paper health certificate with a QR code. The process aims to speed up airport check-in and immigration entry, with the goal of integrating it into the SingaporeAir mobile app by mid-2021.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, MLT, Penguin International, CPH
summary: Singapore Airlines used 80% of the $8.8 billion raised from a June rights issue to fund operating expenses, closing at $4.38 on Monday. Mapletree Logistics Trust acquired a Japanese logistics facility for $82.1 million, with MLT units closing at $1.97. Penguin International shares soared 15% after a possible transaction announcement, closing at 57.5 cents. CPH will seek shareholder approval for the disposal of its Singapore factory.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 4.99 points lower, or 0.30%, to 1,642.90 on Tuesday. The index saw a trading volume of 108.44 million lots worth RM38.65 million. Losers outpaced gainers 178 to 130.

site_title: SoftBank bows to government pressure with fee cuts
summary: SoftBank Corp, Japan's third-largest mobile phone network operator, has cut its mobile fees in response to government pressure to boost consumer spending. The company will lower its fees, including a new 2,980 yen plan with 20 gigabytes of data per month from March. This move follows a similar announcement by rival NTT Docomo Inc. SoftBank's shares have been languishing below their 2018 IPO price, and investors are concerned about the impact of price competition on the telco's operating margin. The company has also reduced its shareholding in SoftBank Corp to 40%.

site_title: US House passes US$892b coronavirus relief package; Senate to vote
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a $892 billion coronavirus aid package, aimed at supporting the nation's pandemic-battered economy. The bill includes $600 payments to most Americans, additional payments to those thrown out of work, and funding for state and local governments, schools, and vaccine distribution. The Senate is set to vote on the bill, which is expected to be signed into law by President Donald Trump. The legislation comes as the pandemic accelerates in the US, infecting over 214,000 people daily and slowing economic recovery.

site_title: Massachusetts, Connecticut low-carbon fuel programme draws industry ire
summary: US governors from Massachusetts and Connecticut have announced a low-carbon transportation programme, but industry groups say it has flaws that will harm the use of low-pollution fuels. The Transportation and Climate Initiative programme would require large fuel suppliers to purchase allowances for pollution caused by combustion of fuels they sell in participating areas. Industry groups, including the National Association of Truckstop Operators, argue that the programme fails to encourage investment in alternative fuels and will instead penalize fuel retailers that sell traditional fuel. The programme's structure is seen as centralized and punitive, deterring businesses from investing in clean fuels.

site_title: Blackwells makes unsolicited offer for Monmouth REIT
summary: Blackwells Capital has made an unsolicited offer to acquire Monmouth Real Estate Investment Corp for approximately $3.8 billion, including debt, at $18 per share. The all-cash offer is a 6% premium to Monmouth's closing share price on Friday. Monmouth's board has rejected the lower offer of $16.75 per share, citing it did not reflect the company's strategic value or future prospects. Blackwells aims to acquire Monmouth, sell its underperforming REIT securities portfolio, and shrink the company's board size.

site_title: New coronavirus variant not out of control, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has stated that the new coronavirus variant discovered in Britain, which is 70% more transmissible than the main strain, is not out of control and can be contained with existing measures. WHO's emergencies chief Michael Ryan emphasized the need for increased intensity and duration in implementing current measures to bring the virus under control. Thirty countries have shut their borders to travelers from Britain and South Africa, where another variant has emerged, to prevent further spread.

site_title: US charges Libyan 'bombmaker' over 1988 Lockerbie attack
summary: The US Justice Department has charged a Libyan former intelligence agent, Abu Agila Mohammad Masud, with building the bomb that exploded on Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988, killing 259 people. Masud, also known as Abu Agela Mas'ud Kheir Al-Marimi, is currently being held by the Libyan government and is expected to be handed over to the US for trial. Strong evidence, including a 2012 interview in which Masud admitted to building the bomb, ties him to the bombing, which remains a mystery 32 years after the tragedy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit by worst selloff in almost two months on new virus strain fears
summary: European stocks plummeted 2.3% in their worst session in almost two months due to fears over a new, more transmissible strain of the coronavirus. The UK imposed an effective lockdown, and several countries closed their borders to Britain, including France. Travel and leisure stocks suffered their worst day in three months, with energy companies also losing ground due to declining crude oil prices. Uncertainty over Brexit trade deal negotiations and a US$900 billion fiscal aid package in the US added to market pressure.

site_title: Microsoft, Google, Cisco, VMware join legal battle against hacking company NSO
summary: Tech giants Microsoft, Google, Cisco, and VMware joined Facebook in a federal court battle against NSO, a hacking company, over its "powerful and dangerous" cyber-surveillance tools. NSO had exploited a loophole in WhatsApp's code to surveil over 1,400 people worldwide, prompting Facebook to sue for damages. The companies warned that unchecked commercial access to these tools would increase government and private company surveillance, harming innocents and stifling dissidents.

site_title: Oil tumbles as new virus strain revives demand fears
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 3% on Monday as a new coronavirus strain led to tighter restrictions in Europe, sparking concerns about a slower fuel demand recovery. Brent crude fell to $50.91 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $47.74 a barrel. The decline is attributed to the shutdown of much of Britain and the resulting tighter restrictions in Europe, which may slow down the economic recovery and subsequently impact fuel demand.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as new coronavirus strain spooks market
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, with energy and gold stocks declining, amid concerns over a new highly transmissible coronavirus strain in Britain. Oil prices dropped, and investors exited risky assets, leading to a 2% decline in the Australian energy index. Gold stocks fell 2%, while healthcare stocks gained 0.5%. The decline was also attributed to travel restrictions and curbs on the UK, which affected several countries, including India and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: US airlines prepare employee recalls as relief nears; United calls them 'temporary'
summary: US airlines American Airlines and United Airlines plan to recall tens of thousands of furloughed employees due to a $15 billion payroll support package. The relief will cover employee costs until March 31, 2021. Airlines expect the recall to be temporary due to depressed travel demand. The move comes as lawmakers aim to pass a $900 billion coronavirus aid package, which includes the airline support. The recall will require all furloughed workers to return to work and receive their full salaries during the specified period.

site_title: Self-driving startup Ouster nears US$1.9b deal to go public: sources
summary: Ouster Inc, a US startup making lidar sensors for self-driving cars and smart cities, is nearing a US$1.9 billion deal to go public through a merger with Colonnade Acquisition Corp. The deal, expected to be announced soon, would make Ouster the fifth lidar manufacturer to agree a SPAC merger this year. Ouster, which has previously raised US$142 million from private investors, plans to use the funding to expand its applications beyond autonomous vehicles, including drones, smart cities, and robotics. The merger is seen as a significant move for the self-driving industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a mixed close on Wall Street as coronavirus worries intensified. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.47% to 26,589.79, and the Topix index declined 0.73% to 1,776.02. The mixed close on Wall Street was attributed to coronavirus concerns, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday following a mixed close on Wall Street as coronavirus worries intensified.

site_title: US dollar rises as new virus strain hits pound, euro
summary: The US dollar rose against the British pound and euro on Monday as investors sought safety amid a fast-spreading new coronavirus strain in the UK, which disrupted international freight and led to a shutdown. The pound fell 2.5% against the US dollar, while the euro dropped 1.23% and 1.91% against the US dollar and euro, respectively. The UK's exit from the EU transition period on January 1 and ongoing trade negotiations also contributed to the currency fluctuations.

site_title: Washington Post to expand newsroom staff, add foreign hubs
summary: The Washington Post plans to expand its newsroom staff to over 1,000 and add 44 journalists, bringing the total to 1,010, to create a bigger global footprint. The move aims to provide 24-hour news coverage and boost digital subscribers, competing with rival The New York Times. The Post will establish new foreign bureaus in Sydney, Bogota, London, and Seoul, and will have a total of 26 foreign bureaus. The expansion highlights the contrast between the Post's growth and the decline of the industry, with many local and regional publications cutting jobs.

site_title: Maybank Kim Eng urges minorities to accept Hi-P offer
summary: Maybank Kim Eng recommends minority investors accept Hi-P International's voluntary unconditional general offer of S$2 per share, citing an attractive valuation of 19.9 times and 17.1 times price-to-earnings ratio. The offer price is 10.5% higher than the previous traded price and 62.6% above the brokerage's price target. Hi-P aims to delist from the Singapore Exchange and privatize the company to optimize management and capital resources.

site_title: Australian regulator rejects Google's undertaking to ease competition concerns on Fitbit deal
summary: Australia's antitrust regulator rejected Google's undertaking to ease competition concerns over its $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit, citing concerns over the acquisition giving Google too much of people's data. The ACCC had warned the deal could hurt competition in health and online advertising markets. Google had offered a court-enforceable undertaking to address these concerns, including not using health data for advertising and allowing competing businesses access to health and fitness data. The regulator deemed these measures insufficient to alleviate competition concerns.

site_title: South Korea orders ski resort, winter tourism shutdown to curb Covid-19 spread
summary: South Korea has ordered a shutdown of ski resorts and winter tourist spots from December 24 to January 3 to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus. The government has also banned gatherings of more than four people, with tighter anti-virus curbs to be imposed on restaurants. This move comes after Seoul and surrounding areas banned gatherings over the Christmas and New Year holidays, with the country recording its highest daily death toll from the coronavirus on Monday. The shutdown aims to slow the spread of the pandemic in the densely populated region of the capital city.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Tuesday moved to shut down all ski resorts and winter tourist spots in a bid to stop the novel coronavirus spreading as a third wave of the pandemic proves much tougher to contain in the densely populated region of the capital city.

site_title: Metro, partners set up UK student accommodation fund
summary: Metro Holdings has set up a UK student accommodation fund, Paideia Capital UK Trust, in partnership with Lee Kim Tah Holdings and Woh Hup Holdings. The fund, which has a first close of £60 million, will acquire its first property, Red Queen, Warwick, for £21.5 million, with a committed occupancy rate of 90%. The partnership aims to pursue growth opportunities in the PBSA sector across England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, and sees the sector as a resilient and diversifying asset class.

site_title: Biden receives Covid-19 vaccine live on TV
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden received a Covid-19 vaccine live on TV, boosting Americans' confidence in the jabs. Biden, 78, got the Pfizer vaccine at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Delaware, urging Americans to "listen to the experts" and continue wearing masks. This contrasts with President Donald Trump, who has promoted natural immunity and hasn't taken part in the vaccination drive. Biden praised the vaccine's development and production, but cautioned that it's just the beginning and more time is needed to halt the virus' spread.

site_title: Apple targets car production by 2024, eyes 'next level' battery technology: sources
summary: Apple is targeting 2024 to produce a passenger vehicle with its own breakthrough battery technology, a move that could challenge the automotive industry. The company's automotive efforts, known as Project Titan, have been underway since 2014, with Doug Field overseeing the project since 2018. Apple aims to build a vehicle for consumers, with a goal of reducing battery costs and increasing range. The company is also exploring a new battery design and a chemistry called LFP, which is safer and more efficient. Apple will likely rely on a manufacturing partner to build vehicles, and the company's plans are still subject to pandemic-related delays.

images.alt_text: Apple is moving forward with self-driving car technology and is targeting 2024 to produce a passenger vehicle that could include its own breakthrough battery technology, people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Scoot brings cheer to healthcare workers and vulnerable families
summary: Scoot, a Singaporean airline, recently hosted a "Scoot-mas Surprise" event, bringing festive cheer to nearly 100 healthcare workers and vulnerable families. The event, held at Changi Airport Terminal 3, featured Scoot staff volunteering as cabin crew and pilots, providing a unique aviation experience to the attendees. The event aimed to show appreciation for the hard work of healthcare workers and bring joy to children during the school holidays. Despite reduced flight schedules due to the pandemic, Scoot staff remained busy with upgrading courses and preserving aircraft to ensure their safety and well-being.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends lower as Covid-19 worries lightened by stimulus
summary: The S&P 500 closed lower on Monday, despite a long-awaited US stimulus package, due to concerns over the new, highly infectious Covid-19 strain in the UK. The package, worth $900 billion, includes unemployment aid and vaccine distribution, but its size fell short of expectations. Financials and tech were the only sectors to gain, while airline stocks slid and Tesla's stock dropped 6.5%. The Dow rose 0.12%, while the Nasdaq Composite and S&P 500 declined 0.1% and 0.39%, respectively.

site_title: December's new home sales could spike if buyers expect better growth in 2021
summary: Singapore's new home sales could spike in December, with buyers anticipating better growth in 2021. Market watchers predict a 70% increase in sales, reaching 1,300 units, including new launches Clavon and Ki Residences. This would surpass previous estimates of 1,000 units. Economic growth is expected to recover in 2021 with a 5.5% GDP growth, leading to higher property prices. Developers are gearing up for more launches, and buyers are hunting for attractive deals, driving up sales.

site_title: Wonder Woman 1984 sputters in opening weekend
summary: Wonder Woman 1984 opened to a disappointing US$38.5 million overseas, significantly lower than its predecessor's US$90.5 million. The film's US$18.8 million in China was also less than expected, with revenues down 30% compared to the previous year. The pandemic continues to impact the film industry, with new releases struggling to sell tickets. The film's debut on HBO Max on December 25 may be its best chance for success, as it competes with other releases on the same day, including Pixar's Soul on Disney Plus.

site_title: Stock watch: 2020 stars and laggards likely to switch sides in 2021
summary: Analysts predict the Straits Times Index (STI) will land between 3,000 and 3,200 points at the end of 2021, driven by economic recovery and vaccine-led optimism. Market outperformers and underperformers in 2021 are expected to be the opposite of those in 2020. Analysts expect value and cyclical stocks to benefit, with sectors dependent on domestic demand recovery posting earnings growth first, while global cyclical sectors may report improved performance from the second half of 2021.

site_title: UK working 'as fast as possible' to resolve border closures: Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the UK is working "as fast as possible" to resolve border closures with France, which shut its borders to UK hauliers in response to a new coronavirus variant. The ban, made on Sunday, has caused chaos at the port of Dover and led to concerns of food shortages ahead of Christmas. Johnson assured that supply chains remain strong and robust, and he aims to sort out the problem in the next few hours. The ban affects around 30 nations that have introduced travel bans on individuals arriving from the UK.

site_title: Face-scan firm backed by SoftBank rebrands US unit
summary: The US unit of CloudMinds, a SoftBank-backed robotics startup, has rebranded as Wright Robotics to distance itself from the blacklisted China-based firm. The unit is selling face-scanning temperature monitors through T-Mobile US amid heightened US concerns about Chinese firms collecting US citizens' personal data. The rebranding comes after the US added CloudMinds to its Entity List in May, citing the risk of the firm procuring items for China's military. Wright Robotics markets its temperature scanners as designed in California, but it is unclear how much personal data the devices can collect.

site_title: Can the GOP get out of the bubble, post-Trump?
summary: US Republican leaders, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have been reluctant to acknowledge President-elect Joe Biden's victory, instead siding with President Trump's claims of a "stolen" election. This reflects the extent to which Trump has taken hold of the GOP, with many Republicans continuing to support him and his baseless claims. The party's establishment is now seen as being controlled by Trumpism, with the risk of the party being unable to move beyond Trump's agenda. The willingness of leaders to side with Trump has led to a bubble of Trumpist ideology within the party, making it difficult for mainstream figures to gain traction.

site_title: China's online shopping addiction is killing its green packaging drive
summary: China's e-commerce giant Alibaba reported a 26% increase in packaging deliveries for Singles' Day, with 675 million packages needed to meet the surge in online shopping. This has raised concerns about the environmental impact of the event, with Greenpeace estimating that Singles' Day generated 52,400 metric tonnes of CO2 in 2017. In response, Alibaba's logistics arm Cainiao designed recyclable corrugated cardboard boxes, but the adoption remains limited due to higher costs. The nation is also exploring other efforts to reduce shipping waste, but smaller retailers are the main challenge in implementing greener packaging practices.

site_title: Seeking out the bright spots for Singapore SMEs
summary: Singapore SMEs face a longer recovery path compared to global peers, despite a relatively encouraging domestic recovery. The biggest threats to growth or recovery are a resurgence of Covid-19, decreased demand, and supply-chain disruptions. To overcome these challenges, businesses are investing in digitalization, improving cash flow management, and becoming more entrepreneurial through innovation and customer acquisition. Despite pessimism, over half of Singaporean businesses plan to increase their investment in the next year, focusing on digital adoption and innovation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CPH Ltd clarified it will seek shareholder approval for the disposal of its Singapore factory, contrary to an earlier report stating a waiver was obtained. Mapletree Logistics Trust acquired a Japanese logistics facility for $82.1 million, funded by debt and expected to be accretive at the distribution level, with a stabilized net property income yield of 4.5%. The acquisition is the trust's first in Japan and marks the company's expansion into the Asian market.

site_title: India may ease rules for non-Chinese investments from HK: sources
summary: India may relax rules for non-Chinese investments from Hong Kong, requiring beneficial owners from neighboring countries to seek government permission for stakes exceeding 10% in local firms, as part of a broader effort to speed up investment approvals amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: UK strain detected in 2 travellers to Australia; HK, India cancel UK flights
summary: Australia has detected cases of the UK's fast-spreading coronavirus strain in two travellers, while Hong Kong and India have suspended flights from Britain. The UK strain, potentially 70% more infectious, has prompted several countries to close their borders to UK travellers. Experts say current vaccines remain effective against the new strain, but more is unknown about it. Australia is in hotel quarantine, and other Asian nations are monitoring the strain while battling rising infections at home.

site_title: Yangzijiang bags US$162m new containership orders
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has entered into an agreement with SITC International Holdings Co to build and deliver six 2,600 TEU containerships worth US$162 million. The vessels are scheduled for delivery from 2022 to 2023, with option orders for identical vessels also secured. This latest order brings the group's total new orders for 49 vessels worth US$1.42 billion so far this year. The company expects to maintain order win momentum following improved market sentiment.

site_title: STI slips on concerns over global surge in Covid-19 cases
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.09% or 2.46 points to 2,846.52 points, mirroring declines in several Asia-Pacific key indices due to concerns over a global surge in Covid-19 cases. A US$900 billion relief package agreement in the US did little to alleviate investor concerns. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.76% and South Korea's Kospi Index gained 0.23%, driven by strong performance from biopharmaceutical stocks.

site_title: UK, Europe stocks dive with new movement curbs
summary: The UK and European markets plummeted on Monday due to new travel restrictions and concerns over a highly infectious coronavirus strain. The UK and several European countries, including France, Germany, and Italy, have restricted travel and movement of goods to and from the UK. The restrictions, which include border closures and port shutdowns, have led to a decline in the pound and euro, as well as a drop in stock markets. Economists predict a potential UK and European winter recession, with vaccines expected to bring normality from next spring.

site_title: Paving the way for a greener future
summary: Singapore-based cleaning services company, Chye Thiam Maintenance, is pioneering the use of innovative technology to reduce waste and increase efficiency. The company has introduced autonomous robots, such as LeoBots, to handle large-scale cleaning tasks, and invested in a semi-automatic Material Recovery Facility (MRF) to recover up to 40% of waste. CTM is also expanding its e-waste recycling capabilities and has invested in a high-tech e-waste recycling plant. With its emphasis on manpower training and employee welfare, CTM has received recognition for its quality workforce and effective use of technology, including the National Environment Agency Enhanced Clean Mark "Gold" Award.

site_title: Energy China to invest 23.8b yuan in energy project
summary: China's Energy China Group has signed a 23.8 billion yuan (S$4.86 billion) framework agreement with Erdos city government in Inner Mongolia to establish an integrated energy base, including 1 GW wind power, 5 GW solar power, and eight GW coal-fired power plants. The project aims to improve power grid stability and flexibility. This investment aligns with China's goal to boost wind and solar power capacity to over 1,200 GW by 2030 and increase non-fossil fuel energy consumption to 25% during the same period.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In Singapore, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, with the US opening lower amid Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Litmus test awaits emerging-market stocks after seven-week rally
summary: Emerging markets face a litmus test after a seven-week rally, with various events potentially disrupting the momentum. Despite a strong US stimulus windfall, successful Covid-19 vaccine rollouts, and a commodity-price boom, emerging markets may struggle to sustain their gains. Historically, such prolonged rallies have sputtered, and the current valuation and relative strength index levels are at high levels, indicating a potential correction. Economies such as Turkey, Thailand, and Egypt may be particularly vulnerable, with interest rate decisions expected in the coming weeks.

site_title: HDB to launch 17,000 BTO flats in 2021
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to launch 17,000 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in 2021, maintaining supply levels after a record 16,752 BTO flats were launched in 2020. The flats will be offered in mature and non-mature estates, including Singapore's first assisted-living public housing for seniors in Bukit Batok. The HDB aims to incorporate features such as electric vehicle-ready carparks, smart LED lighting, and waste conveyance systems in its new developments, guided by its "Designing for Life" roadmap.

site_title: Vaccinations, low rates, liquidity to drive Singapore property investment market in 2021: CBRE
summary: Singapore's property investment market is expected to rebound in 2021, driven by vaccination programs, easing border restrictions, and low interest rates. Residential, office, and industrial sales are forecasted to lead the recovery, with investors seeking higher returns and government land sales contributing to the growth. Despite a 56.8% drop in real estate investment sales volume in 2020, the market has demonstrated resilience, with the luxury residential market and government land sales helping to prop up sales.

images.alt_text: Real estate investment sales here in 2020 were propped up by the luxury residential market and government land sales, according to CBRE.

site_title: Japan endorses record budget to cope with virus pain
summary: Japan's cabinet approved a record $1.03 trillion budget draft for the next fiscal year, marking a 4% rise from this year's initial level. The 106.6 trillion yen budget aims to cope with the economic pain caused by the coronavirus pandemic, with new debt worth 43.6 trillion yen making up 40.9% of revenue. The budget must be approved by parliament early next year, with public debt nearing twice the size of Japan's US$5 trillion economy, making fiscal reform a pressing task.

site_title: Delta, British Airways to require negative virus tests for flights to New York
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced that passengers flying from Britain to New York with British Airways or Delta will require a negative coronavirus test before departure, starting Tuesday. This measure comes amid growing concerns over the fast-spreading UK variant of Covid-19. Cuomo is also in talks with Virgin Atlantic to implement similar requirements. The UK variant may be up to 70% more transmissible, according to early data, but there is no evidence it is more lethal or will affect vaccine impact.

images.alt_text: Passengers flying from Britain to New York with British Airways or Delta will have to first test negative for coronavirus, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia faces revenue crunch as spending mounts on coronavirus woes
summary: Malaysia is expected to enter 2021 with its largest spending plan yet, aiming to spur its virus-hit economy. However, the government faces concerns about funding this plan after a sovereign-rating downgrade. Revenue is forecast to rise 4.2% next year, driven by higher tax collections and a shift away from oil dependence. The government will need to balance its budget without raising taxes or introducing new ones.

site_title: First shipment of Covid-19 vaccine lands in Singapore on SIA flight from Brussels
summary: Singapore successfully received its first shipment of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, marking a significant milestone in the country's efforts to play a role in global vaccine distribution. The vaccine was transported by Singapore Airlines on a Boeing 747-400 freighter and stored at Changi Airport's cold-chain facility before being delivered to its final destination. The shipment demonstrates Singapore's readiness to transport and distribute vaccines internationally, with plans to work with major suppliers on "fill-and-finish" processes to help with global distribution.

site_title: Cold store warehouse rents to rise as Singapore aims to be hub for vaccines
summary: Singapore aims to become a hub for vaccine storage and shipment, driving up demand for cold store logistics warehouses. With a limited supply of such facilities, rents are expected to rise, offering higher capital gains for investors who enter the market early. Currently, rents stand at S$2.50-S$3.50 per square foot per month, with a 50-100% premium over conventional dry warehouses. The sector is projected to evolve into a mainstream market, benefiting investors who capitalize on the scarcity of supply.

site_title: Perfect Day sets up R&D centre in Singapore
summary: Alternative protein firm Perfect Day is setting up its research and development centre in Singapore, a joint lab with the A*Star Singapore Institute of Food and Biotechnology Innovation. The centre aims to develop analytical systems for ensuring the accuracy and consistency of Perfect Day's fermentation processes and protein ingredients. This move comes as the government boosts efforts to grow the agri-food tech sector, with initiatives such as the Singapore Food Story R&D Programme and the Agri-Food Innovation Park. The centre is expected to be operational from April next year and will focus on hiring and training local researchers, scientists, and engineers.

site_title: Shares of China's top chipmaker tumble
summary: China's top chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), saw its shares fall 4.8% in Hong Kong after being included in the US blacklist, citing national security and human rights violations. The company warned that the development of advanced technology, including 10-nanometer chips, would be affected. SMIC will communicate with the US government to seek a solution, but analysts predict customers may look for alternative suppliers due to the uncertainty. The blacklist was part of US President Donald Trump's sanctions before Joe Biden's inauguration, threatening China's semiconductor ambitions and potential geopolitical threat.

site_title: As protectionism rears ugly head, trade cooperation vital for recovery
summary: Protectionism is being discouraged as countries deal with a recession and coronavirus infections, with a focus on trade cooperation for economic recovery. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade agreement has been signed by 15 nations, including Singapore, China, and Japan, and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) bloc has pledged to work towards free trade and investment. The US, under President-elect Joe Biden, is expected to adopt a more trade-friendly policy, reversing the "American First" approach of President Donald Trump.

site_title: US lawmakers reach deal on US$900b Covid-19 relief package
summary: US lawmakers have reached a deal on a nearly $900 billion Covid-19 relief package, including aid for vaccine distribution, extra jobless benefits, and new stimulus checks. The package was reached after months of partisan debate and negotiations, with President-elect Joe Biden welcoming the agreement but calling for further support. The deal includes $25 billion in housing aid, nearly $100 billion for schools and childcare, and $600 stimulus checks, with the aim of helping struggling Americans and preventing a government shutdown.

site_title: Dubai developer Damac warns against 'dumping' in 2021
summary: Damac Properties chairman Hussain Sajwani warns that 2021 will be a challenging year for Dubai's real estate sector due to excess inventory. He cautions against companies "dumping" properties to sell, citing a 30% drop in home prices since 2014. Following similar calls, Emaar Properties has temporarily halted new construction. Measures to curb Covid-19 have led to a realization of the need to curb oversupply, with Damac also deciding not to bring new products to the market.

site_title: Tesla's rise made 2020 the year the US car industry went electric
summary: Tesla's market capitalization surged above $600 billion in 2020, surpassing the combined value of the world's top five vehicle manufacturers, marking a turning point in the US car industry's shift towards electrification. As investors and politicians pressure corporations to combat climate change, the industry is accelerating its transition to electric vehicles, with many manufacturers now forecasting electric vehicles will surpass internal combustion engines by 2030. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated this shift, with China's rapid recovery further fueling industry investment in electric vehicles.

site_title: Airline investors should brace for a turbulent ride
summary: Airline investors face a turbulent ride ahead as the global aviation sector remains fraught with challenges despite the availability of COVID-19 vaccines. Many airlines have seen their stock prices plummet by 2-61% year-to-date, but recent news of travel bubbles and vaccination efforts has lifted some stock prices. However, border reopenings and international travel resuming are unlikely to happen soon, with some countries taking over a year or more to ease restrictions. Airlines that serve domestic markets are expected to recover first, while those that rely on international travel may take longer, with some potentially burning through cash for hundreds of millions of dollars a month.

images.alt_text: The civil aviation sector is not out of the woods, and is still fraught with challenges in the short term.

site_title: 13 companies win awards as best places to work
summary: Thirteen companies, including DHL Express, Certis, and Salesforce, were named Singapore's Best Workplaces. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and Manpower Minister Josephine Teo attended the virtual event. Tan Tock Seng Hospital received a special award for Resilience. The awards recognized companies for providing counselling resources and prioritizing staff mental well-being.

images.alt_text: Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo (right) presenting CEO of Tan Tock Seng Hospital and Central Health Eugene Soh with a special award at a ceremony to recognise Singapore's best workplaces.

site_title: The survival of co-working rests on building a community
summary: Co-working operators face challenges in the post-Covid world as they need to adapt to changing work practices and technologies. The pandemic has hastened the adoption of digital tools, leading to a shift towards remote work and reduced demand for traditional office space. To stay relevant, co-working operators must remodel their spaces to support Covid-proof working environments, leverage technology to support small enterprises and new start-ups, and create social networks to add value for users. Those unable to adapt may struggle to survive, with the pandemic potentially being the last straw for some operators.

site_title: The dangerous allure of green central banking
summary: Central bankers are increasingly focusing on climate change, citing financial stability risks and market failures. However, experts argue that addressing climate change is outside their remit and that governments, not central banks, should manage climate goals and instruments. The European Central Bank's attempts to "green" its monetary policy are seen as incompatible with their independence and may not be effective, as any reduction in emissions achieved through favorable financing conditions would simply mean others need to do less. The ECB's role should be limited to supporting price stability, not addressing market failures or climate change.

site_title: Desperate need for yield pushing investors into danger zones
summary: Investors are flocking to high-yielding, high-risk bond markets in countries like Ghana, Senegal, and Belarus, seeking better returns despite rising US Treasury rates. The US Federal Reserve's signal that interest rates will stay low for longer has fueled this trend, which is also driven by the lingering presence of negative-yielding debt. Investors are being forced to venture into junk territory to secure decent yields, with some emerging markets experiencing record highs in their sovereign dollar debt. This trend is seen as a sign of the global economic recovery gaining momentum.

site_title: America isn't finished paying for Trump's incompetence
summary: US President Donald Trump is leaving office with the country still reeling from his ineptitude. The rollout of the Covid-19 vaccine has been marred by haphazard distribution, with millions of Americans still at risk. Trump's lack of engagement on the issue is a stark reminder of his inability to manage the federal government. Meanwhile, a global Russian cyberattack has compromised government agencies and corporations, with Trump refusing to take decisive action. The president's lack of concern for national security and his inability to manage the country's affairs have left the nation vulnerable to these threats.

site_title: Travel pain spreads as Europe blocks UK flights on new strain
summary: A mutant strain of the coronavirus is disrupting travel plans for thousands of travelers in Europe, leading to cancellations of flights and trains, and losses of peak revenues for airlines. The UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has clamped down on holiday visits at home and abroad, with Italy, the Netherlands, and Belgium closing their borders to the UK. Airlines' shares have tumbled, with British Airways-owner IAG SA dropping 20% and EasyJet Plc falling 18%. The travel industry is bracing for a brutal year-end, with potential long-term effects on summer travel demand.

site_title: SIA has used up 80% of S$8.8b raised from rights issue
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has used approximately S$7.1 billion of the S$8.8 billion raised from a rights issue in June. SIA also raised additional funds through loans and bonds, totaling S$2.1 billion. The airline has access to approximately S$2.1 billion of lines of credit and has the option to issue additional mandatory convertible bonds to raise up to S$6.2 billion if the crisis prolongs.

site_title: Making sense of statistics by studying Covid-19 data
summary: A global website, Worldometers, provides daily Covid-19 statistics, illustrating the value of understanding statistics. The article highlights the importance of considering the base when using percentages to describe changes, as a 20% increase may seem significant but can be minimal or misleading depending on the base. Additionally, comparing absolute figures to context is crucial, as seen in US state infection rates, which are affected by population size. Understanding statistics is essential to avoid misunderstanding and abuse, particularly in times of uncertainty and misinformation.

site_title: Penguin International shares surge after announcement on possible transaction
summary: Penguin International's shares surged 15% on Monday after the company announced possible transaction discussions with a potential investor. The shares closed at 57.5 Singapore cents, trading at a high of 59.5 cents earlier in the day. The board stated there's no certainty of a definitive agreement, advising shareholders to exercise caution. The company's shares are still down 22.3% for the year to date, with an investor who bought in 1997 experiencing a negative 13.8% return.

summary: Royal Dutch Shell plc has released preliminary fourth-quarter figures, warning of another bleak quarter for the oil and gas industry. The company expects a multibillion-dollar impairment charge, weaker oil trading, a loss in its upstream division, and sluggish fuel sales. Trading results in the oil-products division will be significantly lower than the third quarter, and Shell's upstream unit is expected to report an adjusted loss. The company also agreed to sell a minority stake in an Australian liquefied natural gas project for $2.5 billion.

site_title: MediShield report: Panel of oncologists to look into high cost of cancer drugs
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life insurance has seen a significant rise in chemotherapy claims, with payouts increasing by 40% to S$152 million in 2019. The cost of cancer drugs in Singapore is also higher, with prices 1.5 to 2 times higher than in Taiwan and South Korea. A new committee of oncologists will review coverage of cancer drugs to make them more sustainable. The government has accepted recommendations to enhance MediSave top-ups for Pioneer Generation seniors and defer premium payments until end-December 2021 for those with insufficient balances.

site_title: China's export comeback has factories scrambling for workers
summary: China's manufacturing sector has seen a significant recovery, with output rising 22.2% in industrial robots, 10.1% in computer equipment, and 15.9% in integrated circuits year-to-date, exceeding expectations. The country's global export share has increased to 13%, driven by foreign demand, particularly from the US and Europe. However, factories are struggling to find workers, with some owners resorting to hiring temporary workers at higher wages or leasing additional factories to meet demand. Despite this, policymakers see the export boom as a welcome relief, reducing the need for massive stimulus to revive the economy.

site_title: Brits rush to supermarkets ahead of Christmas as borders close
summary: Britons rushed to supermarkets ahead of Christmas, with large queues forming outside stores like Tesco and Sainsbury's in London. The UK's border closures and stricter pandemic rules led to last-minute changes, prompting shoppers to stock up on food for their own gatherings. Some supermarkets, like Waitrose, reported sold-out shelves for meat and milk, while others had adequate supplies of traditional Christmas fare. Sainsbury's warned that gaps in supplies would appear on shelves within days if transport ties with mainland Europe are not restored.

site_title: New virus strain fears set Bund yields for biggest daily drop in two weeks
summary: German bond yields dropped four basis points to -0.61% on Monday, their biggest daily decline in two weeks, amid concerns over a new strain of the novel coronavirus in the UK and a lack of progress on a Brexit deal. Safe-haven assets like the US dollar and government bonds gained, while European stocks were set to open lower. The ECB's bond buying pause until Dec 29 and a decline in market liquidity due to the Christmas holidays also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Mixed-reality set to enrich hybrid events
summary: Marina Bay Sands in Singapore has added mixed-reality capabilities to its hybrid broadcast studio, expanding its tech offerings for event organizers. The studio features a 3D stage, LED backdrops and floor, live-streaming, and hologram functionalities. This enhancement aims to enrich hybrid events.

site_title: Ariana Grande announces engagement to Dalton Gomez
summary: Pop star Ariana Grande announced her engagement to luxury real estate agent Dalton Gomez on Instagram, captioning the post "forever n then some" with photos of the couple and a diamond and pearl ring. Grande's recent album, "Positions," showcased her vulnerability in new love, following her past relationship with rapper Mac Miller, whom she dated from 2013-2018.

site_title: Aramco to bring Google Cloud services to Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Aramco has partnered with Google Cloud to bring cloud services to Saudi Arabia, as part of the country's Vision 2030 reform plans to encourage foreign investment in the technology sector. Google Cloud will establish a new region in Saudi Arabia, while a new company will be formed to supply cloud solutions and services to customers. This collaboration taps into the rapidly expanding demand for cloud services in Saudi Arabia, projected to be worth up to $10 billion by 2030.

site_title: Olam acquires US chilli pepper business, eyes more innovation, capacity expansion
summary: Olam International has acquired US-based chilli pepper business CPB for $108.5 million, expanding its product offerings and customer reach. The acquisition will enhance Olam's green chilli pepper range, which is gaining popularity due to the growing demand for natural food ingredients and bolder flavors. Olam plans to scale up CPB's operations and invest in capacity expansion to meet rising demand. The acquisition will also enable Olam to develop new products and combine different ingredients to create new offerings, leveraging its upstream integration and transparency across the value chain.

site_title: Thoma Bravo to buy software firm RealPage for US$10.2b
summary: Thoma Bravo has agreed to buy US real estate software firm RealPage for $10.2 billion, including debt. The offer is a 31% premium to RealPage's closing share price on December 18. RealPage's shares have risen 26% this year, driven by the pandemic's shift to online services. The company's executive team will continue to lead the business after the deal closes, marking the largest acquisition for Thoma Bravo, which manages over $73 billion in investments.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles at open on virus concerns
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday due to concerns over a new strain of the coronavirus in Britain, potentially disrupting the economy. The Dow Jones fell 0.07%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.68%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.25%. The market was also affected by tariff threats and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: France halts UK freight over virus alarm, rocking supplies
summary: France has suspended inbound travel from the UK, including freight, for 48 hours due to a new variant of the virus. The UK port of Dover has halted all traffic to Europe, causing delays to food supplies and disrupting post-Brexit trade talks. The government is working to restore trade links, with Transport Secretary Grant Shapps seeking to restart haulers crossing the Channel "as quickly as possible". Industry groups are urging the French government to exempt accompanied freight from the ban, and Logistics UK is calling for rapid Covid-19 testing of truckers.

site_title: Ford vs Tesla: an enlightening tale of two car companies
summary: Henry Ford financed his growth through wealthy individuals in Michigan, securing equity capital, while Elon Musk, starting Tesla 100 years later, was self-funded by his founders. Ford's first venture in 1898 raised $2,000 from four investors, and he later turned to building racing cars and partnering with Alexander Malcomson to form Ford Motor Company in 1902. In contrast, Tesla raised $319 million in Series A-F preferred stock financing between 2004 and 2010 and $465 million in 2009 from the Department of Energy. Ford's Model T launched in 1908 and became profitable and dividend-paying from the first year, while Tesla struggled to become profitable until 2013.

site_title: LCT Holdings to delist on Dec 23

site_title: Australia detects new UK strain

The guideline also specifies situations where inspection of pre-sale or pre-imported batches could be waived. This move aims to enhance product quality and safety in the country.

site_title: Regulator clears way for use of Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine in Europe
