site_title: Singapore's vaccine hub quest to drive up cold storage rents: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: Singapore is expected to see a surge in cold storage logistics rents, with prices potentially increasing by 50-100% due to the growing demand for vaccine storage and distribution. The country's quest to position itself as a vaccine hub is driving up demand, outpacing supply, and prompting developers to construct cold storage projects. This trend is expected to be sustained by the need for annual Covid-19 vaccine shots, resulting in a "sustained demand" for cold storage logistics.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank Kim Eng says take the offer from Hi-P's CEO
summary: Brokerage firm Maybank Kim Eng recommends minority investors to accept Hi-P International's CEO's S$2 per share privatization offer, citing an attractive valuation. The deal price is 62.6% higher than Maybank Kim Eng's price target and 19.9 times the price-to-earnings (PE) ratio. This offer price is also higher than Hi-P's five-year average forward PE ratio and its peers. The offer aims to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange, allowing the business to optimize management and capital resources.

site_title: Sydneysiders race for drive-through Covid tests as outbreak looms over Christmas
summary: Sydney residents rushed to get Covid-19 tests as a growing outbreak loomed over Christmas, with 15 new cases reported in 24 hours, bringing the total to 83. The New South Wales state government has opened dozens of new testing sites, conducting a record 38,000 tests in the past 24 hours. The city's northern beaches area was placed under lockdown, and residents are taking precautions to avoid tougher restrictions. Australia has recorded just under 28,200 cases and 908 deaths since the pandemic began, with the country's low tolerance for Covid-19 seen as a key factor in its success in containing the outbreak.

images.alt_text: With Sydney's beachside suburbs in lockdown due to a growing coronavirus outbreak, residents of Australia's largest city flocked in record numbers to get tested for Covid-19, hoping to hold back tougher restrictions over Christmas.

site_title: Shell inks US$2.5b Australian LNG stake sale to GIP
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc sold a 26.25% stake in the Queensland Curtis LNG Common Facilities in Australia to Global Infrastructure Partners for US$2.5 billion. The deal, expected to be completed in 2021, reduces Shell's exposure to the market while maintaining its majority ownership and operator role in the facility. The sale comes after the Australian government highlighted the gas industry as a key driver of growth. Global Infrastructure Partners, a US$71 billion asset fund manager, acquired the stake from Shell to further simplify its portfolio.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as Sydney virus spike stoke border curb worries
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.1% to close at 6,669.90 on Monday, amid growing coronavirus cases in New South Wales and fears of tighter border restrictions. The state recorded its lowest one-day rise in new cases in three days, but concerns over a fast-spreading Covid-19 strain in the UK weighed on sentiment. Energy stocks fell 1.1% as oil prices weakened, while heavyweight miners limited losses. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.1% and New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 0.6%.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags two wastewater treatment projects in Jiangsu
summary: China Everbright Water secured two wastewater treatment projects in Jiangsu province, totaling an investment of approximately 144 million yuan (S$28.8 million). The projects, including a 30-year concession period, will enhance the company's market presence in Jiangsu province. The upgrades will increase daily wastewater treatment capacity to 200,000 cubic meters. Shares of China Everbright Water remained stable at 22.5 Singapore cents after the announcement.

site_title: Amazon shuts New Jersey facility till Dec 26 on virus spike among workers
summary: Amazon has closed its New Jersey warehouse facility until December 26 due to an increase in asymptomatic positive COVID-19 cases among workers. The company is taking precautions out of abundance of caution, with no impact on operations or deliveries anticipated. Amazon employees will be paid for missed shifts. This move comes after the company reported over 19,000 US frontline workers contracting COVID-19 this year. The shutdown follows criticism of Amazon's pandemic response and its decision to keep warehouses open despite health concerns.

site_title: Alternative protein company Perfect Day to set up R&D centre in Singapore
summary: Alternative protein company Perfect Day is setting up a research and development centre in Singapore, partnering with A*STAR to leverage expertise in analytics and taste analysis. The centre will focus on developing analytical systems for fermentation processes and protein ingredients. This move aims to capture a significant share of the growing agri-food tech sector, which saw a 46.8% annual increase in venture funding in 2019. The partnership is part of Singapore's efforts to anchor agri-food innovation and foster local talent, with plans to hire and train researchers and scientists in precision fermentation biotechnology techniques.

site_title: MediShield Life Council's recommendations accepted
summary: The Singapore government has accepted the MediShield Life Council's recommendations to provide adequate protection to Singaporeans. The changes, including deferring premium payments for those with insufficient MediSave balances, will be implemented in March 2021. The government will also increase MediSave top-ups for Pioneer Generation seniors and keep net premium increases for all Singapore Citizens to no more than 10% in the first year. Premium subsidies and support measures, including a Covid-19 subsidy, will also be provided, totaling S$2.2 billion over the next three years.

site_title: Lonely Christmas in Santa's homeland as tourists stay away
summary: Tourists have stayed away from Finland's Santa Claus Village in Rovaniemi, Lapland, due to pandemic travel restrictions, resulting in a significant decline in visitors from half a million to 250,000. This has put local livelihoods in danger, with 5,000 jobs and 700 million euros in revenue lost, a 70% drop. Some businesses, such as Husky Park and the Arctic Snow Hotel, have seen a drastic decrease in footfall, but are finding ways to adapt, including offering remote meetings with Santa. The situation has left businesses struggling, with some opting to cut losses and close for the season.

site_title: China's top chipmaker tumbles after joining Huawei on blacklist
summary: China's largest chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), saw its shares fall 4.8% in Hong Kong after being included in a US blacklist. The blacklist, citing national security and human rights violations, affects SMIC's research and development of advanced technology, including 10-nanometer chips. SMIC warned that the inclusion will have a "major adverse impact" on the development of advanced technology, but will not significantly affect its operations and finances in the short term. The company plans to communicate with the US government to seek a solution.

site_title: HDB to launch 17,000 BTO flats in 2021, including in Bidadari, Queenstown and Geylang
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to launch approximately 17,000 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in 2021, including in mature estates such as Geylang, Queenstown, and Bidadari. The launch will maintain a steady supply of new flats, while considering the economic uncertainty caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. New features such as electric vehicle-ready carparks, smart lighting, and waste conveyance systems will be incorporated into the developments, as part of the HDB's "Designing for Life" roadmap.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars fall on tougher Covid-19 lockdowns
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell on Monday as stricter COVID-19 lockdowns worldwide drove investors to buy the US dollar. The Australian dollar dropped 0.5% to US$0.7585 and the New Zealand dollar eased 0.6% to US$0.7079. Stricter lockdowns in Europe, particularly in the UK, and concerns about a new strain of coronavirus contributed to the decline. Market sentiment was also negatively impacted by Brexit negotiations failing to find an agreement.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with wary eyes on virus
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, weighed down by rising coronavirus infections despite a $900 billion US Covid-19 relief package and Japan's record $1 trillion budget. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.18% to 26,714.42, while the Topix index dropped 0.23% to 1,789.05. Investors are caught between optimism and pessimism, with concerns over new infections at home and abroad. Major Japanese companies such as Nissan and Toyota fell, while Sony gained. The market needs fresh, positive factors to break through the 27,000 yen barrier.

site_title: Gold scales 1-1/2-month high on US stimulus deal boost
summary: Gold prices surged 1% to a near one-and-a-half-month high on Monday, driven by news of a US$900 billion fiscal stimulus package. Spot gold rose to $1,896.39 per ounce and US gold futures gained 0.7% to $1,902.70. Analysts attribute the boost to optimism over fiscal stimulus and the Federal Reserve's continued bond buying program, which could support gold prices until March 2021.

site_title: Hot stock: Penguin International shares soar after announcement on possible transaction
summary: Penguin International's shares surged 14% to 57 Singapore cents, trading at a high of 59.5 cents, after the company issued a holding announcement regarding a possible transaction involving shares. The board stated there's no certainty of a definitive agreement or transaction, advising shareholders to exercise caution. This comes despite the company being down 23% for the year to date.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors to focus on hybrids in SEA, part of regional 'electrification' push
summary: Mitsubishi Motors is shifting its focus to hybrid models in South-east Asia as part of its electrification strategy. CEO Takao Kato stated that conventional gasoline-electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids are more realistic choices for the region due to CO2 emissions concerns. The company plans to produce a plug-in hybrid version of the Outlander SUV in Thailand, with plans to sell around 3,000 units annually. Mitsubishi aims to add more hybrid models to its line-ups in the region, with a conventional hybrid version of the Xpander SUV also expected to be launched in the next few years.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.6% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) shedding 15.81 points to 2,833.17. The decline follows a lower close in US markets on Friday, where stocks retreated due to uncertainty over a coronavirus stimulus deal. Locally, DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell, while Penguin International rose 17% after its executive chairman announced non-binding discussions with a potential investor.

site_title: China's stunning export comeback has factories scrambling for workers
summary: China's manufacturing sector has experienced a stunning recovery this year, with production rising 22.2% for industrial robots, 10.1% for computer equipment, and 15.9% for integrated circuits, exceeding expectations. The country's export growth has topped forecasts for eight consecutive months, driven by demand from Covid-constrained consumers abroad. Factories are struggling to fill a shortage of blue-collar workers, with some employers resorting to hiring temporary workers and investing in automation to meet mounting orders. The remarkable turnaround contrasts with slower recoveries in major industrialized peers.

site_title: China's online shopping addiction killing its green packaging drive
summary: China's e-commerce giants, such as Alibaba Group Holdings, are under pressure to reduce waste generated by online shopping, particularly during the annual Singles' Day sales. Despite efforts to use recyclable materials, packaging waste continues to rise, with 675 million packages delivered in 2020, generating 9.4 million tons of packaging in 2018. The government has struggled to implement a plan to phase out single-use plastics, and smaller retailers are hesitant to adopt sustainable packaging due to cost concerns, making it a challenging issue to address.

site_title: Lockheed Martin inks US$4.4b deal to acquire Aerojet Rocketdyne
summary: Lockheed Martin has agreed to acquire Aerojet Rocketdyne for $4.4 billion, including debt and net cash. The deal is Lockheed's largest acquisition since June, aimed at bolstering its propulsion capabilities in competition with SpaceX and Blue Origin. The acquisition will preserve and strengthen the US defense industrial base, reducing costs for customers and taxpayers. The transaction is expected to close in the second half of 2021, following regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.07 points, or 0.19%, to 1,655.56. Volume was 353.45 million lots worth RM128.26 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 264 to 180.

site_title: UK government says to hold crisis meeting on Monday over virus travel bans
summary: The UK government plans to hold a crisis meeting on Monday to discuss the impact of countries banning travelers arriving from the UK and France blocking most freight. This comes after several countries imposed travel restrictions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Prime Minister will chair the meeting to address the steady flow of freight into and out of the UK. The meeting aims to assess the situation and potential measures to mitigate the economic impact.

site_title: South Korea reports record daily coronavirus deaths, raids
summary: South Korea reported a record 24 daily coronavirus deaths, bringing the total to 698, as the health system struggles to cope with a surge in infections. The country is running low on hospital beds, prompting debate over stricter social distancing measures. Police raided 60 businesses, including bars and karaoke clubs, suspected of violating rules, and 35 people were criminally charged. Seoul is considering banning gatherings of more than five people ahead of the Christmas holiday to alleviate pressure on the system.

site_title: Metro Holdings, partners set up student accommodation fund with £60m first close
summary: Metro Holdings has established a student accommodation fund, Paideia Capital UK Trust, with partners Lee Kim Tah Holdings and Woh Hup Holdings, investing £60 million. The fund will acquire its first property, Red Queen, Warwick, for £21.5 million, with a potential portfolio size of £150 million. Metro's chairman Winston Choo sees this as a "good proposition" to diversify the group's investments and generate a stable income stream.

site_title: Oil prices fall amid worries over new coronavirus strain
summary: Oil prices dropped due to concerns over a new coronavirus strain in the UK, potentially leading to tighter restrictions and a stalled global economy recovery. Brent crude fell 97 cents, or 1.9%, to $51.29 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 83 cents, or 1.7%, to $48.27 a barrel. The decline follows a 1.5% rise in prices on Friday, which reached its highest level since March.

site_title: Top Hong Kong court upholds emergency protest mask ban
summary: Hong Kong's top court has upheld a ban on face masks at protests, ruling it was proportionate and legal under a colonial-era emergency law. The decision, made in response to last year's pro-democracy protests, confirms the city's chief executive has the power to enact laws without legislative approval in times of public emergency. The ruling is a blow to democracy supporters and confirms the ban's legitimacy, despite opposition lawmakers arguing it breached the city's mini-constitution.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong government's decision to use a colonial-era emergency law to ban face masks at protests last year was both proportionate and legal, the city's top court ruled Monday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index edging up 0.39% or 104.85 points to 26,868.24. Investors weighed the impact of spreading Covid-19 infections on the economy against the positive effects of new Japanese stimulus. The broader Topix index also rose 0.37% or 6.61 points to 1,799.85.

site_title: Flights cancelled, holidays in disarray as Sydney battles pre-Christmas Covid-19 outbreak
summary: A Covid-19 outbreak in Sydney, Australia, has led to the cancellation of dozens of domestic flights, with over 50 locations across the city infected. The new cluster, detected in northern coastal suburbs, has prompted authorities to close borders to Sydney's 5 million residents, throwing Christmas travel plans into disarray. The Australian government has urged those who visited affected venues to get tested and self-isolate, with Federal Health Minister Greg Hunt stating it was "almost certain" there would be more cases on Monday.

site_title: Lights! Models! Garbage! Taiwan designer turns waste into fashion
summary: Taiwan designer Wang Li-ling is creating high-fashion clothing from upcycled materials, including old wires and bolts from the power industry. She scours dumps to collect these materials, which have been phased out after 10-30 years, and stitches them onto dresses and other items. Her designs, showcased at Taipei Fashion Week, drew a warm reception from attendees, who praised the creativity of using old materials to create something new. This approach highlights the potential for reducing waste in the fashion industry, which is notorious for its fast fashion and environmental impact.

site_title: Japan's record US$1t budget highlights Covid-19 challenge to growth, debt
summary: Japan's cabinet approved a record $1.03 trillion budget for the next fiscal year, marking a 4% rise from last year's initial level. The budget, which includes record military and welfare outlays, aims to contain the pandemic and boost growth despite dire public finances. Public debt is projected to exceed 60% of the economy, prompting concerns about fiscal discipline and a potential "fiscal cliff." The budget must be approved by parliament early next year, amidst a global trend of fiscal stimulus to prevent a deep recession.

site_title: SoftBank to file its first SPAC on Monday: Axios
summary: SoftBank plans to file its first SPAC on Monday, raising between $500 million and $600 million, according to Axios. Goldman Sachs and Citigroup are managing the process, which will be used to buy a company SoftBank hasn't previously invested in. This will be the company's first SPAC and is part of preparations for at least two additional vehicles.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower as virus cases resurge in Sydney
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.06% lower on Monday due to a surge in Covid-19 cases in Sydney, prompting states and territories to ban travelers from the city. This led to concerns about a delayed economic recovery, undoing earlier projections of a faster-than-anticipated recovery from the country's first recession in three decades.

site_title: US lawmakers near a vote on virus relief plan
summary: US lawmakers are on track to pass a $900 billion Covid-19 relief package, which includes aid for vaccine distribution, extra jobless benefits, and $600 stimulus checks. The deal reached on the Federal Reserve's powers resolves a major sticking point, allowing the central bank to set up emergency lending programs without congressional approval. The package aims to support hard-pressed households and companies, and a government shutdown, which could be disastrous, is being avoided.

site_title: EuroSports Global revs up for electric growth
summary: EuroSports Global, a luxury car distributor, is shifting its focus to electric vehicles with its Scorpio Electric brand. The company has been working on an electric motorcycle for nearly three years and aims to launch it by June 2021. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, EuroSports Global's luxury car business has remained strong, with the company posting a profit in FY2020. The company plans to expand its electric vehicle offerings in Singapore and the region, with a focus on premium markets. EuroSports Global's CEO, Melvin Goh, believes that the future is electric and that the company is well-positioned to capitalize on the growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Dubai property developer Damac soars as board weighs deal
summary: Damac Properties PJSC, a Dubai-based property developer, surged to a two-year high after announcing its board will consider an acquisition within days. The company's shares rose 14.3%, the largest gain in two months, driven by the potential deal. This comes as home prices in Dubai have slumped by over 30% since 2014, but Damac's stock has doubled over the past year. The board will meet on December 23 to discuss the acquisition.

site_title: Saudi Arabia halts international flights over virus variant
summary: Saudi Arabia has suspended international flights and entry through land and sea ports for at least a week due to a new, highly infectious strain of the coronavirus detected in Britain. The kingdom will also require passengers arriving from Europe to self-isolate for two weeks and undergo testing. The suspension affects flights starting December 8, and neighboring Kuwait has also banned passenger flights from Britain. This move comes as Europe struggles with a surge in COVID-19 cases, with the region now surpassing 500,000 deaths.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Olam, StarHub, ComfortDelGro, Tianjin Zhong Xin, Metro
summary: Singapore Airlines resumes flights to Dubai, Tokyo-Haneda, Moscow, and Munich, with increased frequencies to the US, Europe, and South Africa from January 2021. Olam International acquires a US-based chile pepper business for $108.5 million. StarHub appoints Nikhil Eapen as new CEO. ComfortDelGro Taxi to provide at least $300 monthly rental relief to drivers. Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group's controlling shareholder will be acquired by Jinhushen Biological Medical Science and Technology. Metro Holdings sets up a UK student accommodation fund with a first close of $108 million.

site_title: Olam to acquire US chile pepper business for US$108.5m in expansion of spices portfolio
summary: Olam International's food ingredients unit, Olam Food Ingredients, is acquiring US-based chile pepper business Mizkan America for US$108.5 million, expanding its spices portfolio. The acquisition, funded by internal accruals and debt facilities, is subject to US antitrust regulatory approval. Olam aims to meet consumer demand for health, nutrition, and authentic flavors, while strengthening its chile sourcing network. The deal is the first major acquisition for Olam Food Ingredients since its reorganization and is expected to be completed in January.

site_title: Producer of Little Nyonya remake raises close to S$122m
summary: G.H.Y Culture & Media (GHY) raised approximately S$122 million from its initial public offering (IPO) and issuance of cornerstone shares. The company, focused on drama, film, and concert production, debuted on the SGX Mainboard with a strong investor response, including 8.6 times subscription for the international placement and 16 times for the public offer. GHY, led by Guo Jingyu, aims to expand its international reach and leverage technology to diversify its entertainment content and products.

site_title: Dollar gains after week of losses on US stimulus and Brexit fears
summary: The US dollar rose on Friday after a week of losses due to concerns over US Covid-19 aid and Brexit trade negotiations. Investors lost confidence, citing unresolved Brexit risks and a possible government shutdown. The dollar index gained 0.21% to 90.0190, while the pound dropped 0.60% to US$1.3505. The euro was down 0.25% at US$1.2240. The uncertainty has boosted the dollar, with Brexit described as a "major risk item" that is not being resolved.

site_title: Reports of martial-law talk in Trump meeting draw outrage
summary: US President Donald Trump discussed invoking martial law to overturn the 2020 election, with advisors considering deploying the military to battleground states. However, the idea was met with strong condemnation and opposition from senior military officers, lawmakers, and the Biden administration. Trump denied reports, calling them "Fake News," and his advisors pushed back against the notion. The president's resistance to conceding defeat has drawn criticism, but he remains fixated on overturning the election results.

images.alt_text: With one month to go until Joe Biden takes office, Donald Trump remains fixated on his failed bid to overturn the 2020 election - with his advisors reportedly floating the idea of invoking martial law, triggering outrage and disbelief in Washington.

site_title: Malaysia faces revenue crunch as spending mounts on virus woes
summary: Malaysia is set to enter 2021 with its largest spending plan yet, aiming to boost its virus-hit economy. The government expects a 4.2% revenue rise next year, primarily driven by higher tax collections, but faces concerns about meeting this goal due to the ongoing pandemic. A sovereign-rating downgrade earlier this month has added to the pressure, and economists warn that the government's reliance on oil revenue is unsustainable. The government is studying consumption-tax models to diversify its revenue base, but a strong recovery is seen as crucial to meeting its spending plans.

images.alt_text: Malaysia will enter 2021 with its biggest spending plan yet to spur its virus-hit economy, but concerns are focusing on how to foot the bill after a sovereign-rating downgrade earlier this month.

site_title: UK, EU can agree on mini-deals if trade talks fail by end-month, says Gove
summary: UK Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove stated that Britain and the European Union could agree on "mini unilateral" deals if trade talks fail by the end of the month. This could include agreements that benefit one side, potentially forming a new "special relationship" between the UK and EU. Talks are unlikely to wrap up before Christmas due to disagreements over fishing rights, with the EU resisting further concessions. Failure to reach a deal would mean the UK doing business on WTO terms, causing tariffs and disruptions.

site_title: Push to put dollar value on ESG impact
summary: Investors and companies are pushing to assign a dollar value to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) impacts, aiming to better price risk for pension funds, banks, and insurers. Researchers, such as British academic Jill Atkins, propose "extinction accounting" that requires companies to assess species impact and provide scientific assessments. Some companies, like Kering and Danone, are experimenting with valuing environmental and social effects. However, critics argue that this approach may not fundamentally change behavior until impact is factored into core balance sheets and profit statements.

site_title: Airlines baulk at refunds after UK's sudden change on lockdown
summary: Airlines in the UK, including British Airways and Virgin Atlantic, are refusing to offer refunds to passengers who canceled their year-end trips due to new lockdown rules, instead offering vouchers or rebooking options. Regulators are investigating whether airlines violated consumer rights by not providing refunds. The UK Competition and Markets Authority has launched a probe into the issue, citing that the new rules are "legal requirements" and passengers are entitled to a refund. Some airlines, like EasyJet, have offered refunds, while others, like Ryanair, have not responded to requests for comment.

site_title: Nepal dissolves parliament after govt infighting
summary: Nepal's parliament has been dissolved after months of infighting between Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli and former Maoist rebel leader Pushpa Kamal Dahal. The move comes after disagreements over power-sharing and consultation. Fresh elections are set to be held in April and May 2021, plunging the country into fresh political uncertainty. Analysts predict the dissolution will be challenged in court, citing constitutional concerns. The decision follows years of instability and short-lived governments following Nepal's decade-long civil war.

site_title: US Congress reaches deal on Covid-19 aid package
summary: US Congress has reached a deal on a $900 billion COVID-19 aid package, the second-largest economic stimulus in US history. The package includes $600 direct payments to individuals, a $300 weekly boost to unemployment payments, and hundreds of billions of dollars in aid to small businesses. It also provides $25 billion for rental assistance and $15 billion in payroll assistance for US airlines to return furloughed workers. The deal must be passed by both the House and Senate before President Trump can sign it into law, but a vote before midnight Sunday is uncertain.

images.alt_text: US congressional leaders have reached agreement on a US$900 billion package to provide the first new aid in months to an economy hammered by the coronavirus pandemic, the Senate's top Republican and Democrat said on Sunday, but it remained unclear when Congress would vote to seal the deal.

site_title: US lawmakers make final push for reforms to how airplanes are certified
summary: US lawmakers are making a final push to pass landmark reforms to the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) certification process for new airplanes, following two fatal Boeing 737 Max crashes. The Senate Commerce Committee unanimously passed a bill in November, and the House of Representatives followed suit. The reforms aim to bolster misconduct investigations and discipline management at the FAA, grant new protections for whistleblowers, and address lapses in aviation safety oversight. The reforms may be attached to a $900 billion Covid-19 relief bill expected to be voted on in coming days.

site_title: Philippine peso set for more gains in 2021 on falling imports
summary: The Philippine peso is expected to rise to 47.50 by the end of 2021, marking a third year of gains, according to a Bloomberg survey. The currency has risen 5.4% this year, driven by falling imports and expected remittance rebound. The Philippine economy is forecast to start growing only in the second quarter of 2021, and the central bank remains committed to a flexible foreign-exchange rate policy.

site_title: Proportion of loss-making transactions in resale market up in November
summary: The proportion of loss-making transactions in Singapore's resale market rose to 17.1% in November, up from 15.9% in October, according to Edmund Tie Research. This increase contrasts with the primary sales market, which has seen a more buoyant performance. Senior director Lam Chern Woon attributes the rise to vulnerable segments of the market and potential homebuyers restructuring their finances after mortgage relief measures end in December. Despite this, Lam remains cautiously optimistic about a soft landing due to emerging vaccines and economic recovery.

site_title: Graffiti explodes across pandemic-era New York
summary: Graffiti has exploded across New York City since the start of the pandemic, with hundreds of store facades and public spaces being painted with vibrant and often provocative works. The trend is seen as a form of self-expression and vitality by some, but also as a sign of decay and vandalism by others. The growth of the Black Lives Matter movement has accelerated the trend, with many protesters using graffiti to express their views. The city government has been criticized for axing its graffiti removal program, leading to a surge in vandalism.

site_title: JustCo eyes global growth and an IPO
summary: Singapore-based coworking firm JustCo, valued at $1 billion, plans to undertake an initial public offering (IPO) and expand globally despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has embarked on an "asset-light" model, managing space for landlords instead of taking on long-term leases. JustCo has raised $407 million in equity funds and operates over 40 coworking spaces across nine cities. The firm expects to launch its Japanese facility in the second half of 2021 and plans to expand to other cities, including Osaka.

site_title: Index providers react to Trump executive order, drop companies with links to China's military
summary: US President Donald Trump's executive order, signed in November, prohibits US investors from buying securities issued by companies deemed to support China's military and intelligence activities. Index providers S&P Dow Jones, FTSE Russell, and MSCI will exclude 31 Chinese companies, including eight from FTSE Russell's indices and 10 from S&P Dow Jones' indices, prior to market open on December 21. The move is expected to push Chinese companies off US exchanges, potentially weakening the US dollar, which is the primary reserve currency. The decision is seen as part of a broader effort to protect US investors and counter China's growing economic influence.

site_title: Analysts positive on IPO market after resilient results in 2020
summary: Analysts expect greater listing volumes in Singapore's IPO market in 2021, driven by diversified plays and pandemic beneficiaries. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, 11 IPOs raised S$1.45 billion in gross proceeds in 2020, with seven listings ending above their IPO prices. The success of dual-listings, such as AMTD International's listing on the New York Stock Exchange and Singapore Exchange, also suggests a positive outlook for the market. Experts attribute the resilience of IPO listings to the market's focus on company fundamentals, investors' liquidity, and the availability of capital.

site_title: Britain, EU tell each other to give way in 'difficult' trade talks
summary: Britain and the EU are in "difficult" trade talks, with both sides calling for each other to make concessions to secure a post-Brexit trade deal. The EU wants to protect its single market and impose trade barriers if Britain changes its regulations, while Britain seeks to set its own rules and regulations. Talks are ongoing despite a Sunday deadline set by the European Parliament, with less than two weeks left before Britain leaves the EU's orbit at the end of the year.

site_title: WHO says in close contact with UK officials on new Covid-19 virus variant
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed it is in close contact with UK officials regarding a new Covid-19 virus variant, which is up to 70% more infectious but not considered more deadly. Vaccines are still expected to be effective.

site_title: Dutch ban UK flights to stop spread of mutated virus strain
summary: The Dutch government has banned all passenger flights from the UK until January 1 due to a new, more infectious coronavirus strain circulating in Britain. The ban comes after the discovery of the strain in the Netherlands, where a case was found in early December. The government urges citizens not to travel unless necessary and is reviewing other forms of transport to limit the spread of the virus. This ban is part of the Netherlands' five-week lockdown, which also includes closing schools and non-essential shops.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to merge Alight with Bill Foley's SPAC
summary: Blackstone is in talks to merge Alight Solutions, a benefits administrator business, with Foley Trasimene Acquisition Corp, a blank-cheque special acquisition firm backed by investor Bill Foley. The potential merger would value Alight at over $8 billion, making it a publicly-listed firm. Alight, which employs over 15,000, provides human-resource support services to large companies globally. The deal, if completed, would be facilitated through a SPAC merger, following a trend of high-profile business figures using SPACs for dealmaking.

site_title: North Korea to redevelop flagship tourist resort
summary: North Korea plans to redevelop its Mount Kumgang tourist complex into an international resort, a year after leader Kim Jong Un ordered its demolition. The complex, built by South Korea's Hyundai Asan, was once a prominent symbol of inter-Korean economic cooperation but was condemned by Kim as an "eyesore". Premier Kim Tok Hun has called for pushing ahead to turn the area into a modern and all-inclusive international tourist resort, with the goal of making it a "cultural resort envied by the whole world". The project would likely require outside investment, but may downgrade South Korean partners.

images.alt_text: Premier Kim Tok Hun (centre) stresses "the need to build the tourist area our own way", during his visit to Mount Kumgang.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality pays tribute to Kindness Heroes
summary: Frasers Hospitality has launched the "Remembering Kindness" campaign, a global initiative to celebrate and recognize individuals who have performed extraordinary acts of kindness. The public can nominate individuals, known as Kindness Heroes, who have made a positive impact on others. Selected nominees will receive a two-night complimentary stay at one of Frasers' properties worldwide. The campaign aims to give back to the community, especially during the holiday season, and to inspire others to pay it forward.

site_title: Rethinking technology talent for digital transformation
summary: Singapore's technology talent has grown by 10,000 year-on-year, but demand is expected to outstrip supply, with a projected shortage of 61,600 by 2021. Despite this, most people are digitally-conversant and can contribute to technology-driven innovations with a growth mindset and reskilling. Companies should focus on leveraging existing talent and investing in innovation hubs, such as the AI-focused innovation hub set up by NIE and Amazon Web Services for edtech research.

site_title: Thailand to test 10,000 after virus cases linked to seafood market
summary: Thailand is testing over 10,000 people for Covid-19 after an outbreak linked to its Mahachai seafood market, where nearly 700 cases have been confirmed, mostly among Myanmar workers. The authorities have locked down the market and its surrounding areas, providing food and water to migrant workers. The testing is part of active tracing efforts and will continue until Wednesday. The outbreak has raised concerns about poor working and living conditions in the seafood industry, which is fueled by a low-paid migrant workforce.

site_title: High-profile tech stars leaving Silicon Valley
summary: High-profile tech stars, including Tesla's Elon Musk and Oracle's Larry Ellison, are leaving Silicon Valley due to a shift to remote work and political polarisation. Some companies, such as Oracle and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, are also moving their headquarters to Texas. The exodus is attributed to high living costs, nightmare traffic, and droughts in the region, which has become less attractive for top talent. Several companies, including Palantir and Brex, have already left the San Francisco area, with some citing tax rates and ideological diversity as factors.

images.alt_text: Those leading the exodus include Tesla chief Elon Musk (above), Oracle founder Larry Ellison, Palantir co-founder Peter Thiel and chief executive Alex Karp.

site_title: Appeal on removal of EH-Reit's manager not successful: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has denied an appeal from Mandarin West Holdings, the sole shareholder of Eagle Hospitality Reit's (EH-Reit) manager, regarding the removal of the manager. MAS's earlier directive remains in effect, requiring DBS Trustee to remove the manager and appoint a new one. The directive was issued due to numerous breaches of the Securities and Futures Act and concerns over the manager's ability to comply with rules and regulations. The MAS had previously received written submissions from MWH, but deemed them as raising "no new material facts".

site_title: Singapore Medical Group in talks with third party on possible share transaction, in response to query from sponsor
summary: Singapore Medical Group is in talks with a third party about a possible share transaction in response to unusual price movements and high trading volume. The discussions are preliminary and no certainty exists for a transaction. The company's shares rose 11.32% on Friday to close at 29.5 cents, with about 30.97 million shares worth S$8.94 million changing hands. Any material developments will be announced if they warrant disclosure.

site_title: UBS Singapore extends collaboration with Halogen Foundation
summary: UBS Singapore has extended its collaboration with Halogen Foundation for four years, focusing on entrepreneurship skills for underserved youths in Singapore. Despite the challenges of COVID-19, UBS volunteers supported Halogen's Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship (NFTE) programme, which aims to activate entrepreneurial mindset and business fundamentals in Secondary Three students. A Break-Even Analysis web-based application, developed by UBS staff, was also introduced to help students better understand business concepts. The renewed partnership aims to provide meaningful learning experiences for youths in Singapore.

site_title: A more bullish Hang Seng in 2021?
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) had a challenging 2020, down -5.36% year-to-date, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, economic and political challenges. However, a bullish scenario suggests the index may rebound in 2021, driven by vaccine development and approvals, and the growth of technology companies. A bearish scenario warns of potential short-term market volatility, but notes that vaccine optimism will kick in by mid-2021. Regulatory pressure on big tech firms may also impact the HSI's recovery.

site_title: New strain of coronavirus in Britain out of control, warns health secretary
summary: The UK Health Secretary, Matt Hancock, has warned that a new strain of coronavirus is "out of control" and parts of England will be stuck in the highest tier of restrictions until a vaccine is rolled out. Over 16 million Britons are required to stay at home, and socializing is restricted to Christmas Day. The new strain, which has also appeared in Australia and continental Europe, can spread significantly more quickly than previous strains. Hancock says a vaccine will be available by the end of the weekend, with 350,000 people already vaccinated.

site_title: More restructuring, insolvency cases likely in 2021 as reliefs end
summary: Singapore's restructuring and insolvency cases are expected to increase in 2021 as government relief measures expire. According to Patrick Ang, managing partner of Rajah & Tann Singapore, banks and creditors may start taking action on companies that have been given time to restructure or pivot due to government assistance. Vulnerable sectors include oil and marine, retail, and construction. Ang notes that the sector's challenges will be exacerbated by commodity traders facing short-term supply disruptions and the construction sector's labor supply issues.

site_title: Danske cleared of sanctions breach, but case isn't over
summary: Danske Bank has been cleared of breaching US sanctions by the US Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), but the case is not over. An investigation into the bank's Estonian unit handling billions of dollars in suspicious funds is being closed, but OFAC may take future enforcement action if new information warrants renewed attention. Danske has been under investigation since admitting to failing to screen 200 billion euros in non-resident flows, which was a large part of the money suspected to be suspicious. The bank still faces criminal and regulatory investigations in Denmark and France.

site_title: Unit at Chuan View sold for tidy profit in Nov
summary: A 1,518 sq ft unit at Chuan View in Singapore was sold for a 270% profit, with an annualized gain of 8.7% after being held for 15 years. The top five profitable transactions were held for over 15 years, with all being freehold properties. In contrast, the top loss-making deal by percentage was a 646 sq ft unit sold for nearly half the purchase price, with an annualized loss of 6.8%. The majority of profitable transactions were freehold, while more loss-making transactions were leasehold.

site_title: Markets ushering 2021 with euphoric wave of speculation
summary: US markets are entering 2021 with a speculative wave, despite a modest annual gain on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The past year saw a record-fast bear market and rebound due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but next year's gains are expected to be tame. Speculation has been fueled by vaccine developments and stimulus cheques, with shares of Tesla and Bitcoin increasing significantly in value. However, some experts warn of a speculative bubble, with economists sounding alarms about bubbles and volatility in the market.

site_title: Singapore gets shot in the arm from global drug demand
summary: Singapore's economy has received a boost from robust global demand for medicines, with the country's pharmaceutical sector playing a crucial role in the global supply chain. Despite a recession forecasted for this year, the sector's growth has defied expectations, with output expanding 90% in September. The sector's growth has been driven by strong demand for medicines to treat illnesses such as asthma and epilepsy, and the country's exports of pharmaceuticals have exceeded imports, generating significant revenue. This has provided a much-needed boost to the country's economy, which has been hit hard by the pandemic.

site_title: Netherlands ban flights from UK after detecting new coronavirus strain
summary: The Netherlands has banned flights from the UK until January 1, following the detection of a new, 70% more infectious coronavirus strain in the UK. The ban was implemented after a case in the Netherlands revealed the same virus strain as in the UK. The Netherlands also issued a "do not travel" advisory, except in cases where it is absolutely essential. This measure comes after UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced the new strain and placed London and south-east England in Tier 4, the highest level of the country's three-tier system of rules.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 18, 2020, reveals a mixed market performance across various segments. The Capesize market saw a significant increase, with the C3 Brazil-China index reaching $16, driven by Vale's re-emergence. The North Atlantic and C5 West Australia rounds also showed improvement, with decent fixing volumes and rates rising. In contrast, the Panamax market experienced a correction, with rates easing as demand decreased. The Ultramax/Supramax market maintained a relatively healthy timecharter average, while the Handysize market remained firm despite tonnage appearing tight. VLCC rates were mostly static, and Suezmax and Aframax markets also showed mixed performances.

site_title: Time for a health check for your savings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

In a year marked by economic disruption, Singaporeans can review and optimize their insurance, investments, and taxes to manage cash flow and generate a higher net rate of return. Insurance reviews can help reduce premiums, while CPF and SRS top-ups can enhance retirement savings. Investments should be scrutinized for costs, with low-cost options like robo services and DIY platforms available. Reviewing and adjusting insurance, investment, and tax strategies can help individuals adapt to the current economic climate and achieve their financial goals. By doing so, they can mitigate the impact of the pandemic and build a more secure financial future.

site_title: How M&As and partnerships can fuel digital transformation
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital transformation in businesses, highlighting the need for a coherent and cohesive digital strategy to achieve sustainable growth and profitability. Successful digital transformation requires an innovative culture, a clear vision from the top, and leveraging mergers and acquisitions (M&A) to acquire technology and talent. Companies can either build and scale their own technology platforms or join strategic partnerships and digital ecosystems to extract synergy. A balanced approach, considering factors such as governance, leadership, and prioritization, is crucial for executing a comprehensive digital transformation.

images.alt_text: A successful digital transformation requires an innovative culture and a clear vision from the top down, which can then be translated into an actionable business strategy, writes Joongshik Wang, EY-Parthenon Asean leader and partner, strategy and transactions, at Ernst & Young Solutions LLP.

site_title: Two Singaporeans and three PRs among 19 new imported Covid-19 cases
summary: Two Singaporeans and three permanent residents were among 19 new imported COVID-19 cases confirmed on December 20, 2020. The cases were all imported, with no new community cases or cases from worker dormitories. This brings Singapore's total COVID-19 cases to 58,422.

site_title: Fear of missing out makes crypto's 350% premium look appealing
summary: Regulators' lack of approval for cryptocurrency ETFs has led to a surge in premiums for products like the Bitwise 10 Crypto Index Fund and Grayscale Bitcoin Trust. As a result, investors are paying up to 650% and 350% more than the value of their holdings, respectively. Despite the high costs, demand remains strong, with institutional investors and individual traders seeking access to Bitcoin through these products, which are often easier to buy than the underlying asset.

site_title: 67% stake in Tianjin Zhong Xin's controlling shareholder to be acquired for an undisclosed sum
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group announced that Jinhushen Biological Medical Science and Technology will acquire a 67% stake in its controlling shareholder, Tianjin Pharmaceutical Holdings, for an undisclosed sum. This comes as part of China's drive to reform state-owned enterprises. The acquisition will require Jinhushen to make mandatory cash offers for shares listed on the Singapore and Shanghai exchanges. The deal follows a 11.7% surge in the group's share price last week, prompting a trading halt.

site_title: Airlines balk at refunds after UK tells travellers not to fly
summary: UK coronavirus rules have led to a surge in cancelled flights, with many passengers unable to secure refunds. Airlines such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic are refusing to provide cash refunds, instead offering vouchers or rebooking options. The UK Competition and Markets Authority has launched an investigation into whether airlines violated consumer rights by failing to offer refunds. The government has urged people to reconsider travel plans, citing the need to prevent the spread of the new virus strain.

images.alt_text: British Airways (BA) and Virgin Atlantic Airways aren't offering refunds to passengers who cancel year-end trips because of new UK coronavirus rules, even as regulators investigate airlines' earlier refusal to hand cash back to customers caught in lockdown.

site_title: Taiwan deploys ships, aircraft as Chinese carrier passes island
summary: Taiwan deployed its navy and air force on Sunday as a Chinese aircraft carrier group, led by the Shandong, sailed through the Taiwan Strait. The deployment came amid heightened tension between Taiwan and China, which claims the island as its territory. China says its military activity is aimed at protecting sovereignty, while Taiwan has complained of repeated drills. A US warship transited the strait the previous day, further straining Sino-US ties. Taiwan's Defence Ministry described the situation as "a grave threat" to national security, with the Shandong group continuing in a southerly direction.

site_title: Saving a historic wooden German church plank by plank
summary: In Germany's Stiege town, a 1905 stave church, one of only three remaining in the country, is being relocated from a forest to the town center. The church, a national monument, was built for patients recovering from lung diseases and fell out of use after a fire damaged the nearby sanatorium in 2013. After years of fundraising and securing permits, the church is being moved plank by plank to a new site, with completion targeted for September. The project, valued at 1.1 million euros, aims to preserve the church's unique architecture and make it a community space and tourist attraction.

site_title: Covid relief deal in Congress slips to Sunday as new funding deadline looms
summary: US lawmakers struggled to clear final hurdles for a $900 billion coronavirus aid bill, pushing the deadline to a Sunday night government funding deadline. The bill, which includes one-off $600 checks and enhanced unemployment benefits, is expected to include provisions to prevent expiring Federal Reserve emergency lending programs from being revived. Despite a heated discussion between Senator Patrick Toomey and Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, a possible compromise may be emerging to narrow the focus of Fed language. Lawmakers are under pressure to finish the relief package before a midnight Sunday expiration of federal spending authority.

images.alt_text: US lawmakers struggled on Saturday to clear final hurdles to a US$900 billion coronavirus aid bill, including a dispute over Federal Reserve (Fed) emergency lending authorities, pushing any deal closer to a Sunday night government funding deadline.

site_title: The pandemic made 2020 a wild year for Wall Street
summary: US stocks experienced a wild year in 2020, marked by extreme extremes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The market crashed in March, entering a bear market, but recovered in the spring and summer with tech giants driving growth. Companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Apple saw significant increases, while others like Zoom, Clorox, and Tesla benefited. However, sectors dependent on the economy, such as cruise lines and airlines, suffered. The year ended with the approval of COVID-19 vaccines, which is expected to bring better days for the US economy and healthcare stocks in 2021.

site_title: Appeal on removal of EH-Reit's manager not successful: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has rejected an appeal from Mandarin West Holdings, the sole shareholder of Eagle Hospitality Reit's (EH-Reit) manager, regarding the removal of the manager. The directive, issued on November 30, remains in effect, requiring DBS Trustee to comply. The removal was due to numerous breaches of the Securities and Futures Act and serious concerns over the manager's ability to comply with rules and regulations. A new manager, SCCPRE Hospitality Reit Management, has been proposed.

site_title: The household product cleaning up more than just your countertops
summary: A startup, Ambrosia, is turning food waste into household cleaning products, with its first product, Veles, a bottle of cleaning spray made from post-consumer organic waste. Founder Amanda Weeks aims to divert food waste from landfills, with plans to create products for skincare and other industries. The company has been acquired by waste consulting firm Recycle Track Systems and has attracted significant investment, with over $1 billion in funding for food waste startups in 2020. Weeks' goal is to create a closed-loop system, where waste is converted into valuable products, reducing waste and greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Copper tops US$8,000 as Goldman points to commodities super-cycle
summary: Copper prices have surged to a 7-year high of over $8,000 a tonne, driven by optimism over US stimulus talks and a recovering Chinese economy. Analysts at Goldman Sachs and BlackRock predict a new commodities super-cycle, citing a weaker dollar, rising global liquidity, and increasing demand for green technologies. This has boosted miners' shares and set the stage for a profitable year, with production costs falling and supply constraints contributing to the price increase.

site_title: Google trial judge suggests potential trial date, and it is in 2023
summary: US District Judge Amit Mehta has suggested a potential trial date of September 12, 2023, for the antitrust case against Alphabet's Google. The judge noted that discovery is expected to be completed in March 2022, with pre-trial matters addressed in early 2023. The Justice Department's lawsuit focuses on Google's search and search advertising, while a broader state case, filed by 38 states and territories, includes efforts to extend dominance to devices like smart cars. Google has denied wrongdoing and the next status hearing is set for January 21.

site_title: LJHB acquires 21% of Keong Hong; Riverstone chair continues to build stake
summary: LJHB Holdings acquired 21% of Keong Hong Holdings through an off-market transaction, with chairman and CEO Ronald Leo retaining 30.85% stake. The acquisition will provide a platform for LJHB's future real estate projects in Singapore and leverage Keong Hong's regional expansion plans. Riverstone Holdings executive chairman and CEO Wong Teek Son acquired 150,000 shares, maintaining a 51.15% stake. The acquisitions are part of a trend of share buybacks among primary-listed stocks, with a total consideration of S$30.0 million over five trading sessions.

site_title: China to vaccinate 'key groups' over winter, spring: official
summary: China plans to vaccinate high-risk groups over the winter and spring before expanding to the general public, according to a senior health official. These groups include workers in the cold chain industry, customs, healthcare, markets, and public transport. China has administered over 1 million emergency doses to high-risk groups since July and has submitted data to the medical products regulator for approval of two candidate vaccines. The goal is to build group immunity and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

site_title: Philippine peso set for more gains in 2021 on falling imports
summary: The Philippine peso is forecast to gain 5.4% in 2021, its largest gain in South-east Asia, as the country's sluggish economic recovery curbs imports and remittances are expected to rebound. The currency is predicted to reach 47.50 by the end of 2021, according to a Bloomberg survey. Falling imports have boosted the current account, and the central bank has raised its forecast for a surplus next year to 1.5% of GDP. The improving economy is expected to impact the currency's supply and demand, with the central bank committed to a flexible foreign-exchange rate policy.

site_title: US Congress poised to vote on Covid aid package after Fed compromise
summary: The US Congress is poised to vote on a $900 billion coronavirus aid package, which includes $600 direct payments to individuals and a $300 weekly unemployment compensation supplement. The package was reached after a late-night compromise between Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer and Senator Pat Toomey, clearing a hurdle over Federal Reserve pandemic lending authorities. The aid package is attached to a $1.4 trillion spending bill and must be passed before midnight on Sunday to avoid a government shutdown, with President Trump urging Congress to "GET IT DONE" and deliver more direct payments.

site_title: China ex-minister sees curbing of fintech, bank tie-ups: report
summary: A former Chinese finance minister, Lou Jiwei, suggests that the country should restrict fintech giants from partnering with too many banks to prevent rising bad loans. This move would help maintain market control and mitigate potential financial risks. Lou cited a specific example of a platform with trillions of yuan in loans, warning that excessive control could lead to economic instability. His comments come as China's fintech industry continues to grow, and policymakers face pressure to balance economic growth with financial stability.

site_title: Foreigners eye return to Japan stocks after years of selling
summary: Foreign investors may return to Japan's stock market after a six-year selloff, driven by growing optimism over Japan's profit growth outpacing the US, corporate tax rises under President Joe Biden, and the Tokyo Olympics. Comgest Asset Management estimates $25.72 billion to $30.72 billion will flow into Japan's stock market next year. Foreign funds have made large purchases of Japanese equities since October, with Nomura Securities predicting $62 billion in inflows. Analysts point to relatively low valuations and cyclical stocks as reasons for the renewed interest, despite concerns about Japan's slow economic growth and aging population.

site_title: Airports advised to step up security efforts for Covid-19 vaccine cargo
summary: Airports worldwide are advised to enhance security measures to protect COVID-19 vaccine shipments amid warnings of potential targeting from organized crime groups. A global airports body, Airports Council International, recommends airports collaborate with local authorities and conduct risk assessments. The Interpol global police agency has also warned of potential threats, while discussions are underway at the United Nations aviation agency to increase dry ice transport capacity. As vaccine distribution efforts intensify, airports must prioritize the secure transportation of vaccines, which require ultra-cold storage and are considered "dangerous goods".

site_title: US employers can require workers to get Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has issued guidelines allowing employers to require workers to get a Covid-19 vaccine and bar them from the workplace if they refuse. Public health experts see this as crucial for reaching herd immunity and controlling the pandemic. The guidance clarifies that administering a vaccine to an employee for protection against contracting Covid-19 does not constitute a medical examination under the Americans With Disabilities Act. Employers must ensure that vaccination requirements are job-related and consistent with business necessity, and must handle pre-screening questions carefully.

site_title: UK's Johnson summons ministers over new Covid-19 variant: The Telegraph
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has summoned senior ministers for an emergency meeting to discuss a new, more virulent Covid-19 variant. The meeting may lead to tightened restrictions, including travel restrictions between London and the rest of the country. The government expects the AstraZeneca-Oxford University vaccine to clear regulatory approval on December 28 or 29, which could accelerate the vaccination campaign. Johnson hopes England won't need a third lockdown after Christmas, but an announcement on restrictions is possible as soon as Saturday.

site_title: In last rush, Trump grants mining and energy firms access to public lands
summary: The Trump administration is rushing to approve large-scale mining and energy projects on federal lands before President-elect Joe Biden takes office. The Interior Department and Forest Service are set to approve projects in Arizona, Utah, Nevada, and Virginia, including a copper mine in Arizona, a helium drilling project in Utah, a lithium mine in Nevada, and a natural gas pipeline in Virginia. These projects, which could increase domestic energy and mining production, reflect the administration's push to reduce regulatory barriers and promote corporate interests. Some projects, such as a uranium mine in South Dakota, will require further approvals under a Biden administration.

images.alt_text: In Arizona, the Forest Service is preparing to sign off on the transfer of federal forest land - considered sacred by a neighbouring Native American tribe - to allow construction of one of the nation's largest copper mines.

site_title: Malaysia to sign deal for AstraZeneca vaccine: Bernama
summary: Malaysia is set to sign an agreement with AstraZeneca to supply Covid-19 vaccine doses to cover about 20% of its population, with the goal of vaccinating 70%. The country has already ordered doses from Pfizer-BioNTech and the World Health Organization's Covax facility. Vaccinations for frontline workers are expected to begin early next year if the deal is concluded, amid a fresh wave of cases in the country.

site_title: Moderna Covid-19 vaccine begins rollout as US races to broaden injection campaign
summary: The US began rolling out Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine on Saturday, with over 3,700 sites set to receive and administer shots starting Monday. This marks a significant expansion of the vaccine rollout, which started last week with Pfizer's vaccine. Moderna's vaccine supplies have been moved from manufacturing plants to warehouses, and shipments will start reaching healthcare providers as early as Monday. The move comes amid record coronavirus infections and deaths.

site_title: Hong Kong manhunt underway for escaped Covid-19 patient
summary: Hong Kong authorities are searching for a 63-year-old Covid-19 patient who escaped from the Queen Elizabeth Hospital on December 18. The patient, identified as 7379, was wearing a jacket over hospital clothes and was chased by staff but recaptured. This is the first known case of a Covid-19 patient escaping from a hospital in Hong Kong, which has recorded 7,970 Covid-19 cases, including two deaths in the past two days.

site_title: WHO investigators heading to China in early January to probe virus
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) team, led by Mike Ryan, will visit China in early January to investigate the origins of the coronavirus pandemic. The team will focus on Wuhan, where the first cases were detected in December. The mission aims to identify the original point of human cases and will involve quarantine arrangements. The WHO also reported that three-quarters of cases are in the Americas and is in touch with South African researchers about a new Sars-CoV2 variant.

site_title: Microsoft working on in-house chips for its servers, PCs
summary: Microsoft is developing its own in-house chips for its servers and Surface PCs, potentially reducing its reliance on Intel and AMD. The company is working with Arm Ltd technology and licensed computing cores, rather than designing its own custom cores. This move follows Apple's release of its M1 chip in Mac computers. Microsoft views semiconductors as a key focus area and is investing in design, manufacturing, and tools capabilities. The company's goal is to gain more control over its technology and reduce its dependence on external suppliers.

site_title: Ray Dalio says son killed in car accident in Connecticut
summary: Billionaire hedge fund investor Ray Dalio announced on Twitter that his 42-year-old son, Devon Dalio, was killed in a car accident in Greenwich, Connecticut. Devon was driving when his car crashed into a store. Ray Dalio expressed his family's grief and requested time to process the loss. Devon was a co-founder/partner at P-Squared Private Equity and a Dalio Foundation board member.

site_title: Ho ho ho and 'good to go': Fauci gives Santa virus vaccine
summary: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the US top infectious disease official, has vaccinated Santa Claus against COVID-19. Fauci traveled to the North Pole to administer the vaccine, ensuring Santa can safely deliver gifts on Christmas. After vaccination, Fauci measured Santa's immunity level, finding him "good to go." This news comes as countries worldwide experience a surge in COVID-19 cases, with many preparing for the holiday under strict "stay at home" orders. The US has launched its mass vaccination campaign, offering reassurance to families that Santa can safely enter homes on Christmas.

images.alt_text: Anthony Fauci, the top infectious disease official in the United States, said Saturday he personally gave Old St Nick his jab.

site_title: Alaska's Iditarod sled-dog race rerouted due to Covid-19 pandemic
summary: The 2021 Iditarod sled-dog race in Alaska will be rerouted due to the Covid-19 pandemic, skipping the traditional route to Nome. Instead, the "Gold Trail Loop" will take racers and dogs 860 miles to the abandoned gold-mining town of Iditarod and back to the starting point. The change aims to protect mushers, dogs, and communities from the pandemic. The new route will be challenging, requiring crossings of the Alaska Range twice, and the finish line will be in Willow instead of Nome. The Iditarod will start on March 6 in Anchorage.

images.alt_text: The famed Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race across Alaska will not run to Nome in 2021, a drastic change called necessary to protect the mushers from the Covid-19 pandemic and reduce its spread in rural Alaska, race officials announced on Friday.

site_title: Zoom says it's being probed by SEC, two US attorneys offices
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and two US Attorney's offices are investigating Zoom Video Communications, the videoconferencing company, regarding interactions with China and other overseas governments, as well as security and user privacy matters. Zoom has provided information to the US Department of Justice and has terminated a former employee, Xinjiang Jin, who was charged for conspiring to censor Chinese dissidents. The company has also received grand jury subpoenas from the US Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York and the SEC.

site_title: Tech stars quit Silicon Valley as politics, pandemic weigh
summary: High-profile tech stars, including Elon Musk and Larry Ellison, are leaving Silicon Valley due to the region's high living costs, traffic, and political polarization. The shift to remote work during the pandemic has reduced the need for on-site headquarters, with some companies, like Oracle and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, relocating to Texas. Others, such as Palantir and Tesla, are also moving out of the area, with Ellison opting to work from his Hawaiian island, Lanai. The exodus is seen as a sign that tech companies are reevaluating their ties to the region, with states like Texas and Hawaii offering lower taxes and living costs.

images.alt_text: Some companies are also packing up and moving their headquarters including Silicon Valley stalwarts Oracle and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), both headed for Texas.

site_title: Philippine central bank maintains 2-4% inflation target through 2024
summary: The Philippine central bank has set its inflation target for 2023-2024 at 2-4%, maintaining a benign inflation path as the country recovers from the coronavirus pandemic. The target, set on Dec 3, is below the 2-4% target for 2020-2022, with expected inflation averaging 2.6% in 2020, 3.2% in 2021, and 2.9% in 2022. The bank's decision reflects its readiness to take further action if needed, amid a global economic recovery.

site_title: JPMorgan, Goldman to restart buybacks as Fed gives green light
summary: The Federal Reserve has given US banks the green light to resume billions of dollars in stock buybacks, with the six largest banks expected to buy back as much as $11 billion of shares in the first quarter of next year. The decision comes after banks passed a second round of 2020 stress tests, showing they have enough capital to weather the pandemic. Banks, including JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, plan to increase shareholder payouts, which could triple their payouts. The move is seen as a positive for the banking industry, but some regulators have expressed concerns about prudence and the potential impact on lending to households and businesses.

site_title: Google rolls out free, weekly at-home Covid-19 testing for all US employees
summary: Google is offering free, weekly at-home COVID-19 testing for all its US employees, with the goal of expanding the benefit globally within the next year. The company's 90,000 US staff will receive a weekly nasal swab and lab analysis, although testing is not mandatory. Google aims to provide regular testing to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in the workplace.

site_title: Fed keeps countercyclical capital buffer at zero
summary: The US Federal Reserve Board kept its countercyclical capital buffer at 0%, a tool intended to direct banks to build up capital during strong economies to bolster resilience in future recessions. This decision was made after consulting with other bank regulators, with Governor Lael Brainard not dissenting. The buffer has never been triggered, even during the record-long expansion that ended in February due to the COVID-19 pandemic and current recession.

site_title: Wells Fargo to sell student loan book to Apollo, Blackstone
summary: Wells Fargo has agreed to sell its $10 billion US private student loan book to a group including Apollo Global Management and Blackstone Group. The sale is part of Wells Fargo's efforts to pare back non-core businesses under CEO Charlie Scharf. The portfolio, which has an average Fico score of 768 and is considered high quality, will be serviced by Nelnet. Wells Fargo had previously notified customers it would exit the private student loan business and will accept new applications until late January.

site_title: Massive iceberg pivots, breaks near south Atlantic penguin colony island
summary: A massive Antarctic iceberg, A68a, has shifted direction due to strong currents in the south Atlantic, narrowly missing a South Georgia Island penguin colony. The iceberg, nearly 8,000 square kilometers in size, initially approached the island's western shelf edge before pivoting 180 degrees. According to a scientist, the strong currents caused the iceberg to "handbrake turn" in an attempt to avoid the island. The close call highlights the unpredictable nature of Antarctic icebergs and the importance of monitoring their movements.

site_title: US charges ex-Zoom executive with censoring dissidents
summary: US prosecutors have charged a former Zoom executive, Xinjiang Jin, with disrupting video meetings commemorating the 31st anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989. Jin, 39, allegedly conspired to censor speech since January 2019 and fabricated violations to justify his actions. He is accused of terminating at least four meetings and creating fake accounts to suggest meeting hosts and participants supported terrorism. If convicted, Jin faces up to 10 years in prison. Zoom has fired Jin and cooperated with federal prosecutors regarding its dealings with China's government.

site_title: Tesla shares rise in busy trade ahead of S&P 500 debut
summary: Tesla's shares surged to a record high of $695, up 6% at the close, ahead of its expected debut in the S&P 500 index. The company's addition to the index is expected to force index-tracking funds to buy $85 billion worth of Tesla shares, while selling other S&P 500 constituents. This move has been attributed to last-minute buying in preparation for its inclusion. Analysts expect Tesla's addition to the S&P 500 to be a double-edged sword, potentially increasing volatility for index trackers but also benefiting the US large-cap universe.

site_title: The WTO is having a midlife crisis
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is experiencing a midlife crisis, struggling with its relevance and effectiveness in regulating international trade. Founded in 1995, the WTO's power and influence have waned due to its inability to address issues like climate change and income inequality. The body's two largest economies, China and the US, are in a trade war, and its Appellate Body has ceased to function. To revive the WTO, the Biden administration should support the appointment of a new director-general, such as Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, and engage in soul-searching about the organization's shortcomings. A historic opportunity lies to change the direction of international trade rules and prioritize solutions to climate change and income inequality.

site_title: Hackers' broad attack sets cyber experts worldwide scrambling to defend networks
summary: A suspected Russian hacking campaign targeting US government agencies and other organizations worldwide has left cybersecurity experts scrambling to defend networks. The breach, which used malicious software in SolarWinds' Orion software, has affected at least 18,000 users, including US government agencies, a British county government, and a US internet provider. The attack has sparked a global response, with cybersecurity companies seeing a surge in demand for security technology. The US government has offered little information on the breach, and President-elect Joe Biden's transition team is preparing for a response.

images.alt_text: Suspected Russian hackers who broke into US government agencies also spied on less high-profile organisations, including groups in Britain, a US internet provider and a county government in Arizona, according to web records and a security source.

site_title: Huawei CFO's alleged actions had 'no genuine connection' to US: lawyers
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou's lawyers argue that her alleged actions in the US have "no genuine connection" to the charges, seeking to end her extradition from Canada. Meng, 48, is accused of bank and wire fraud for allegedly misleading HSBC about Huawei's business dealings in Iran. She claims innocence and is fighting extradition while under house arrest in Vancouver. Witness testimony recently concluded in her case, with her lawyers making the latest bid to have her released.

site_title: Nike posts surprise earnings growth on lower costs, strong digital demand
summary: Nike reported surprise quarterly profit growth and beat sales estimates, driven by lower costs and strong digital demand. Digital sales jumped 84% with triple-digit growth in North America, while selling and administrative expenses fell 2%. Revenue rose 9% to $11.24 billion, beating analyst estimates, and profit increased 12% to $1.25 billion. The company's e-commerce investments paid off, giving it a competitive edge over rivals like Adidas, as the pandemic boosted demand for outdoor activities.

site_title: US blacklists dozens of Chinese firms including SMIC, DJI
summary: The US has added dozens of Chinese companies, including top chipmaker SMIC and drone manufacturer DJI, to a trade blacklist as tensions between the two nations escalate. The move aims to prevent the transfer of advanced US technology to China, which the US claims is used for military purposes. The Commerce Department cited entities involved in human rights abuses, military construction, and the theft of US trade secrets. The blacklisting includes 77 companies, including 60 Chinese firms, and is seen as a last-minute effort by President Trump's administration to burnish its tough-on-China image.

site_title: US Congress passes stopgap funding bill to avoid government shutdown
summary: The US Congress passed a two-day stopgap funding bill to avoid a government shutdown, sending it to President Donald Trump for signature. The bill extends existing federal funds until September 2021, giving lawmakers time to finalize a $900 billion coronavirus aid bill and a $1.4 trillion government-wide spending bill. Negotiations have made progress, with some differences remaining, including a dispute over Federal Reserve lending programs and relief for arts venues.
