A shutdown would have forced thousands out of work and disrupted services, increasing pressure on lawmakers to come up with a relief plan.

site_title: US 5G auction soars to US$34b with Verizon leading way
summary: US 5G auction reached a record-breaking $34 billion, with Verizon leading the way at $20 billion, according to analysts. The auction, which began on December 8, features 57 bidders, including AT&T, T-Mobile, and cable companies Comcast and Charter. The sale of midband frequencies is crucial for companies to seize global leadership in 5G technology and drive years-long profits. Analysts predict Verizon will outspend AT&T by over two to one, with AT&T expected to spend around $9 billion. The auction is seen as a critical juncture for companies to remain competitive in the 5G era.

site_title: The best of Banyan
summary: Banyan Tree Group's Laguna Golf in Singapore has achieved a triple win of international award recognitions. The golf course celebrated this milestone, marking a notable achievement for the company.

site_title: US FDA authorises Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use
summary: The US FDA has authorised Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, marking the second vaccine to receive this approval after Pfizer's. The decision comes as the US faces a death toll of over 307,000 from the virus. The FDA's endorsement was made following a panel of outside experts' endorsement the day prior. This is the first regulatory authorisation for Moderna's vaccine and validates its messenger RNA technology, which was first identified in the US over a year ago.

site_title: Moukoko becomes youngest Bundesliga scorer as Dortmund flop at Union
summary: Borussia Dortmund suffered a 2-1 defeat at Union Berlin, with 16-year-old striker Youssoufa Moukoko becoming the youngest Bundesliga scorer, breaking Florian Wirtz's record. Moukoko equalized in the second half before Dortmund conceded from a set-piece as Union's Marvin Friedrich headed the winner. The loss leaves Dortmund fourth in the table, six points behind leaders Leverkusen, and Moukoko also became the youngest player in the Champions League and the youngest player in Bundesliga history in November.

site_title: Fed greenlights share buybacks, dividends for US banks
summary: The US Federal Reserve has cleared the largest US banks to pay dividends and buy back stock on a limited basis, following a second bank "stress test" in 2020. The banks have enough capital to withstand $600 billion in losses, and will be allowed to repurchase stock starting in the first quarter of 2021. The test results showed banks built up reserves during the pandemic, positioning them to weather a downturn well. The Fed has also decided not to adjust its stress capital buffer requirements.

site_title: Ace helps Ryan to ranking game win
summary: Ryan Ang claimed the 3-day 4th National Ranking Game at the Marina Bay Golf and Country Club with an ace as the decisive factor.

site_title: Boeing 'inappropriately coached' pilots in 737 MAX testing: US Senate report
summary: A US Senate report alleges Boeing "inappropriately coached" test pilots during 737 MAX recertification efforts after two fatal crashes, contradicting proper protocol. The report claims the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and Boeing officials attempted to cover up information contributing to the tragedies. Boeing acknowledged the findings and will review the report, while the FAA is constrained by an ongoing criminal investigation. The report also highlights concerns over pilot training and Southwest Airlines' operations without proper maintenance confirmation, putting millions of passengers at risk.

site_title: California hospitals overrun even as vaccine is rolled out
summary: California hospitals are severely overcrowded with Covid-19 patients, despite the rollout of vaccines, with only 2.1% of intensive care beds available. The state reported 41,000 new cases and 300 deaths, while the US leads the world in new cases and deaths. The US death toll has surpassed 311,000, and hospitalizations have set records for 20 consecutive days. Vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna are being distributed, but it will take months for them to slow the pandemic's progress.

images.alt_text: Even as high profile figures like US Vice-President Mike Pence rolled up their sleeves for Covid-19 vaccinations, patients already ill with the disease crowded emergency rooms and overran intensive care units in California, now a worldwide epicentre.

site_title: UK government pushes for lifting of US travel restrictions: sources
summary: The UK government is pushing the Trump administration to lift or soften travel restrictions that bar most people in the UK from traveling to the US. Since November, UK officials have held high-level talks with White House officials, with the proposal backed by coronavirus task-force members and federal agencies. The UK Department for Transport emphasizes the importance of restarting transatlantic flights for economic recovery and British nationals. However, the high number of coronavirus infections in Europe remains a hurdle, and the US has extended travel restrictions on Mexico and Canadian land border crossings until January 21.

site_title: Trump signs bill that could kick Chinese firms off US stock exchanges
summary: US President Donald Trump signed the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which bars securities of foreign companies from US stock exchanges if they fail to comply with American auditing standards for three years. The legislation, aimed at targeting Chinese companies, requires public disclosure of foreign government ownership and allows for Chinese companies to be kicked off US exchanges. Chinese officials have dismissed the measure as discriminatory, while the US aims to increase pressure on Beijing amid a hardening of the relationship.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Friday signed legislation that would kick Chinese companies off US stock exchanges unless they adhere to American auditing standards, the White House said, giving the Republican one more tool to threaten Beijing with before leaving office next month.

site_title: The world's CFOs have dire message for real-estate investors
summary: Global corporate executives are rethinking their real estate needs due to the pandemic, with hundreds of CFOs cutting office space, accelerating branch closures, and renegotiating rents on warehouses and data centers. This trend is expected to save millions of dollars for companies, with an estimated 12% reduction in real estate footprint. The shift to hybrid working models and remote work arrangements may lead to permanent changes in the industry, posing a long-term risk for investors in commercial real estate.

site_title: STI top gainer Sembcorp faces rougher ride next year
summary: Sembcorp Industries, the top gainer on Singapore's Straits Times Index in 2020, is expected to face a tougher year in 2021 due to concerns over economic recovery in key markets. Analysts predict a 5.1% gain for the stock, lower than the 9.6% estimated gain for the benchmark STI gauge. The company expects to incur a full-year loss in 2020, its first in over two decades, due to the pandemic. Despite a 52% year-to-date gain, shares have dropped 4% in December amid concerns over profitability and potential write-downs.

site_title: A surreal 2020 for the world of sports
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

The 2020 sports year was marked by the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the global sporting calendar. Notable events included the postponement of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, Euro 2020, and Copa America. Liverpool won their first EPL title in 30 years, while Rafael Nadal secured his 13th French Open title. The year also saw the deaths of several sports legends, including Kobe Bryant, Diego Maradona, and Paolo Rossi. Mike Tyson returned to boxing after a 15-year retirement, and the Singapore Sports Hub was repurposed as a temporary accommodation for migrant workers during the pandemic.

site_title: United Airlines to resume Boeing 737 MAX flights in February
summary: United Airlines announced it will resume Boeing 737 MAX flights in February, following the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) November decision to permit the jet to fly again after software and pilot training upgrades. The plane will return to service on February 11 from Denver and Houston, marking the latest carrier to restart flights on the 737 MAX after a 20-month hiatus.

site_title: Hospitality romantic
summary: Hilton's Asia-Pacific president, Alan Watts, is optimistic about the travel and tourism industry's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. As of November 2020, 97% of Hilton's system-wide hotels were open, and occupancy was recovering week by week. Watts attributes the industry's resilience to the rise of domestic customers, particularly in China, Japan, and Australia. He expects the recovery to progress from essential-only travel with quarantine to optional travel without pre-approval. With vaccination hopes and a growing demand for domestic travel, Watts sees a promising future for the industry.

site_title: Livestreaming takes China mutual funds by storm: innovation or cowboy investing?
summary: China's mutual fund industry is experiencing a shift towards livestreaming, driven by young, tech-savvy investors seeking ways to increase their wealth. Foreign companies, including Invesco and Vanguard, are struggling to compete with local rivals, who have adapted to the country's unique online landscape. Livestreaming has become a key marketing tool, with asset managers hosting over 90 sessions on platforms like Alipay, to promote their funds and engage with potential investors. The market is highly competitive, with some platforms creating fake transactions and users, and regulations prohibiting investment advice.

site_title: StarHub appoints parent company's deputy CEO as its chief
summary: StarHub appoints Nikhil Eapen, 48, as its new CEO, replacing Peter Kaliaropoulos, who stepped down due to health issues. Eapen, deputy CEO of parent company ST Telemedia, will start on January 1. The appointment follows a rigorous global executive search, focusing on strong leadership, industry knowledge, and corporate transformation experience. Eapen has a track record in telco and adjacent industries, having worked at Citigroup for 18 years.

site_title: Hi-P's CEO makes voluntary unconditional offer of S$2 a share with view to delist firm
summary: Hi-P International's CEO, Yao Hsiao Tung, made a voluntary unconditional offer of S$2 per share to buy out the remaining shares of the company, valued at S$1.6 billion. This move is aimed at delisting the firm from the Singapore Exchange. The offer would cost up to S$288 million for the 16.5% of shares Yao does not own.

images.alt_text: Mr Yao holds 83.4% of the total shares as at the offer date. His wife, Wong Huey Fang, holds 0.1% of Hi-P shares.

site_title: Europe: Stocks break four-day rally on Brexit trade talks, US stimulus
summary: European stocks fell 0.4% on Friday, ending a four-day rally, due to doubts over a post-Brexit trade deal and a US stimulus package. The Stoxx 600 index reversed gains despite a surprise rise in German business morale. In the US, Congress is unlikely to meet a deadline to agree on $900 billion in COVID-19 aid, potentially leading to a third stopgap spending bill. The week's 1.5% gain in the Stoxx 600 was the sixth week in seven.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls as stimulus rally cools, Tesla hits record high
summary: US stocks fell on Friday as uncertainty over a coronavirus stimulus deal weighed on the market, despite record highs earlier in the day. Tesla shares hit a lifetime high ahead of the company's addition to the S&P 500 next week. The S&P 500 technology index was the biggest drag on the overall benchmark, while FedEx fell after not providing an earnings forecast for 2021. The US Congress is unlikely to meet a deadline to agree on a $900 billion Covid-19 aid package, instead considering a third stopgap spending bill.

site_title: UK businesses seek grace period to adjust to post-Brexit rules
summary: The UK's biggest business lobby group, the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), is calling on the European Union to delay introducing new customs checks and paperwork after Brexit due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The CBI is asking for a one-year grace period for companies to comply with the new requirements, which could minimize disruption to businesses and the economy. The UK government has consistently ruled out extending the Brexit transition period, but has taken unilateral actions to try to minimize the impact on firms.

site_title: Westwood, a deserving winner of race to Dubai title
summary: Cliff Drysdale's protégé Nick Faldo was initially set to defend his title but was forced to withdraw due to a knee injury. Lee Westwood stepped in and won the 2005 Barclays Singapore Open, claiming his first major title.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in the red, STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares ended the week in the red, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.3% to 2,848.98, as uncertainty over Brexit talks and a US stimulus package weighed on the market. Other Asian markets also declined, while US stocks rose on optimism about a fiscal stimulus package. Key decliners included Jardine Strategic Holdings and DBS, while Keppel DC Reit was the biggest gainer, rising 2.2%.

site_title: Choo bounces back to edge out Yap
summary: Choo edged out Yap in a close finish at the Swing tournament. The result was a comeback victory for Choo, who was trailing at one point. Three players were initially in contention for the top spot, but Choo managed to take the lead and secure the win.

site_title: For Asia, the time to embrace sustainable investing is now
summary: Asia is poised to lead the way in sustainable investing, helping to fill the global investment gap and drive sustainable prosperity. The region's recovery from the pandemic has created momentum for sustainable investments, with many ESG funds outperforming the wider market over the last 10 years. As investors seek to build back better, Asia's expertise in sustainable investing can help drive capital towards sustainable development. With Asia's fast recovery, now is the time for the region to fully embrace sustainable investing and capitalize on its potential.

site_title: All aboard the billionaires' Bitcoin bandwagon?
summary: Institutional investors, such as billionaire hedge fund manager Alan Howard, are investing in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, with One River Asset Management setting up a fund with about $1 billion in Bitcoin and Ether. However, retail investors, who have benefited from trading US stocks, should be cautious, as Bitcoin's price can fluctuate rapidly and may not be a useful or safe investment for the average person. Data suggests that only 1% of cryptocurrency activity is driven by merchants, and Bitcoin's value has historically been volatile, with a 1,000% surge in 2017 followed by a drop to less than $3,500 a year later.

site_title: Reits (Dec 19-20, 2020)
summary: Real estate trends show a mixed bag. US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive declines, impacting the market. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record high, with further increases anticipated. Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs acquisition of Seoul hotel and retail assets was announced. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy location.

site_title: Gold rises on US fiscal stimulus bets, further appreciation would be gradual
summary: Gold prices rose this week due to expectations of a US fiscal stimulus, despite concerns over the spread of Covid-19. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged and committed to providing liquidity, supporting gold prices. The US dollar remains weak, limiting losses. Gold bulls focus on the prospects of a fiscal stimulus bill before the US Congress recess. However, the appreciation in gold prices is expected to be gradual with frequent pullbacks, driven by the ongoing pandemic and logistical challenges in vaccine distribution.

site_title: Tesla heads to S&P after meteoric rise
summary: Tesla's shares have surged nearly 700% over the past year, making it the world's most highly-valued automaker. The company's entry into the S&P 500 has sparked debate among Wall Street analysts, with some predicting a 36% decline in price to $396.30, while others expect it to more than double in value over the next five years. Despite high valuations, long-term investors remain optimistic about Tesla's prospects, citing its leading electric vehicle market position and solar energy business.

site_title: SIA to resume non-stop flights from LA and NY from Jan 18
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will resume non-stop daily flights from Los Angeles, San Francisco, and New York to Singapore starting January 18, 2021, and increase frequencies to Dubai, Tokyo-Haneda, Moscow, Munich, the US, Europe, and South Africa. The carrier will also carry vaccines and expand cargo services on these routes, primarily for pharmaceuticals, technology, and fresh produce. SIA expects significant cargo traffic and will operate new aircraft with advanced HEPA airflow management systems to ensure passenger safety.

site_title: Aleta Planet launches AP-1 virtual card that allows foreigners to make cashless payments in and to China
summary: Aleta Planet launches its AP-1 virtual card, allowing Singaporeans and foreigners to make cashless payments in China without a local bank account. The card can be used for QR code or contactless payments through UnionPay, accepted at over 52 million merchants worldwide. It also enables SMEs in Singapore to pay directly into their mainland suppliers' accounts, reducing transaction time and costs. Users can top up their virtual card with SGD or RMB, and enjoy exclusive rewards and promotions. The AP-1 virtual card is available for download from the Apple Store, Google Play, or Huawei App Gallery.

site_title: China arm of Tat Hong Holdings to be listed in Hong Kong
summary: China's Tat Hong Equipment Service, the Chinese arm of Tat Hong Holdings, has passed the hearing by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange's Listing Committee and is expected to launch its initial public offering before the end of the year. Group CEO Roland Ng plans to grow the business to capture a larger market share in China, citing opportunities in infrastructure. This move comes after Tat Hong Holdings delisted from the Singapore Exchange in 2018 and allows each business arm to operate independently.

images.alt_text: Roland Ng, chairman and group chief executive of Tat Hong Holdings, notes that listing in Hong Kong may also open doors for a secondary listing in China.

site_title: Oil settles up, marking seventh straight weekly gain
summary: Oil prices rose for the seventh straight week, settling at a nine-month high, driven by the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and a decline in the US dollar. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude both gained 1.5% to reach their highest levels since March and February, respectively. The US dollar's weekly decline, which is near 2-1/2-year lows, also supported oil prices, making commodities cheaper for international buyers. OPEC+ plans to add 500,000 barrels per day of supply in January, but is slowing the pace of supply increases.

images.alt_text: Oil settled up at a nine-month high on Friday, rounding out seven straight weeks of gains as investors focused on the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and a decline this week in the US dollar.

site_title: Glycemic Variability holds the key to diabetic complications
summary: Researchers have discovered that Glycemic Variability (GV), which measures the fluctuations in blood sugar levels, holds the key to preventing diabetic complications. GV is linked to various health issues, including eye problems, nerve damage, kidney disease, and increased rates of heart attacks and strokes. The study suggests that GV mirrors the release of insulin in the body and may trigger fat deposition, leading to visceral fat. By monitoring and controlling GV through diet, exercise, and sleep, individuals can reduce the risk of these complications and improve their overall quality of life.

site_title: US to blacklist dozens of China firms including SMIC: sources
summary: The US is set to add dozens of Chinese companies, including top chipmaker SMIC, to a trade blacklist, targeting those with ties to the Chinese military and alleged human rights violations. The move, expected to include around 80 companies, is seen as President Donald Trump's effort to cement his tough-on-China legacy. The Commerce Department will designate companies for their involvement in constructing and militarizing artificial islands in the South China Sea and alleged human rights abuses. This adds to the over 275 China-based firms and affiliates already on the entity list.

site_title: Singapore increasing checks on F&B outlets' Covid-19 measures during festive period
summary: Singapore's government will increase enforcement checks on food and beverage (F&B) outlets during the festive period to ensure compliance with safe-management measures amid the Covid-19 pandemic. F&B outlets are restricted to groups of five or less, with no intermingling allowed, and must close by 10:30pm. Strong enforcement action will be taken against those who disregard these measures, including fines, temporary closure, and prosecution. This enforcement will continue through Christmas and into Phase Three, which starts on December 28, 2020.

site_title: Trump, ahead of FDA, says Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine has been approved
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted that Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine has been approved and will ship immediately, despite the FDA's lack of public announcement. A panel of outside FDA advisers voted 20-0 in favor of the vaccine's use, with one abstention, indicating its benefits outweigh the risks. The FDA and Moderna did not comment on the matter.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to sell Australia property for A$65m
summary: Chip Eng Seng's wholly-owned subsidiary, CES Gladstone (Vic), is selling a Melbourne property for A$65 million (S$65.6 million) to a trust related to Greystar. The deal is expected to be completed on March 31 next year. The sale allows Chip Eng Seng to redeploy capital to better returns, while maintaining its long-term growth and diversification strategies in the Australia market.

site_title: The asset manager arms race has only just begun
summary: The asset management industry experienced a record year of mergers in 2020, driven by the fee war and the shift of investors to exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Notable deals included Franklin Resources acquiring Legg Mason for $4.5 billion, Morgan Stanley acquiring Eaton Vance for $7 billion, and Macquarie Group buying Waddell & Reed's asset-management unit for $1.7 billion. This trend is expected to continue in 2021, with potential targets including WisdomTree Investments and Janus Henderson, as asset managers seek to consolidate and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Apac real estate investment deals to rebound 15-20% in 2021: JLL
summary: Real estate investment deals in the Asia-Pacific region are expected to rebound 15-20% in 2021, driven by North Asia's growth and investor interest in logistics, data centers, and alternative assets. Despite a decline in direct commercial transactions in 2020, JLL predicts a new cycle of growth, with hotel, retail, and office investments also expected to pick up. Cross-border investment flows are expected to contribute to recoveries in Australia, mainland China, and Singapore, with high-yield, low-growth assets becoming more attractive in a low return, low interest rate environment.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: TaylorMade's latest golf ball, Thevar 2.0, focuses on improving greens performance rather than distance. The new ball features a slightly different approach, targeting better results on the green.

site_title: EHT receives request for EGM proposing rights issue, retention of manager
summary: Entities controlling 10.54% of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) have requested an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to propose a rights issue and retention of the current manager, Eagle Hospitality Reit Management (EHRM). The proposal includes a US$50 million rights issue and a new management fee of at least S$4.5 million per year. If resolutions are not passed, securityholders will vote on whether to delist and wind up EHT. The EGM is scheduled for Dec 30.

site_title: EFG boss Chiu throws his weight behind golf development
summary: Executive Chairman of EFG International, Albert Chiu, has expressed his support for golf development, further solidifying his role as a golf enthusiast. Chiu, 55, is also the Chairman of the EFG Young Athlete Foundation.

site_title: New York's plummeting real estate sales cost city US$1.2b
summary: New York City's real estate sales plummeted 49% this year through November, resulting in a $1.2 billion loss in revenue. This decline led to a 42% decrease in city tax revenue, mainly due to fewer commercial and residential property transactions. The real estate industry, which accounted for 53% of the city's annual tax revenue, is experiencing a crippling blow. Despite the arrival of COVID-19 vaccines, the economic crisis continues to worsen, with the Real Estate Board of New York calling for federal relief.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media IPO sees 0.8% gain on trading debut
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holding Co, a Singapore-based entertainment and content provider, made its trading debut on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with a 0.8% gain, ending the day at 66.5 Singapore cents. The stock opened at 70 cents, higher than its IPO price of 66 cents. The company plans to use the IPO proceeds to expand its TV program and film production business, and to leverage technological advancements to diversify into new media content.

site_title: Surge in privatisations as share prices remain undervalued
summary: Privatisations surged 70% in 2020 compared to 2019, with 17 take-private deals worth approximately US$5.8 billion, driven by undervaluation and the stock market's failure to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. Founders, controlling shareholders, and management teams partnered with private equity funds to rescue companies from undervaluation. The trend is expected to continue into 2021, with the Singapore market still experiencing significant valuation gaps.

images.alt_text: Persistent undervaluation and the stock market's failure to recover to pre-Covid levels have led this year's privatisations to surpass last year's in deal value by 70 per cent.

site_title: Japan raises GDP outlook for next fiscal year on lift from stimulus package
summary: Japan's government raised its economic growth forecast for the next fiscal year to 4% due to the impact of its stimulus package aimed at speeding up recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. This is the fastest annual expansion on record since comparable data became available in 1995. The forecast is based on the government's third supplementary budget, which funded a $708 billion stimulus package. Policymakers are cautious about risks, including downside risks to the economy from the pandemic and financial markets.

images.alt_text: Japan's government raised its economic growth forecast for the next fiscal year thanks to its latest stimulus package aimed at speeding up the recovery following the damage wrought by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Sentosa's award-winning Serapong course has a fresh look
summary: Sentosa's award-winning Serapong golf course has undergone a major renovation, giving it a fresh look. The course, known for its worldwide acclaim, has been updated with new features and improvements. However, no specific details on the changes were provided. The renovation marks a significant transformation for the course, aimed at enhancing the overall golfing experience.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sinarmas Land Limited's shares surged 17.5% on Friday, closing at S$0.235, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange on trading activity. The company denied any undisclosed information that could explain the unusual price movements.

site_title: GIC, Kennedy Wilson ink US$1b joint venture for urban logistics properties in UK
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has entered into a US$1 billion joint venture with Kennedy Wilson to acquire and manage urban logistics properties in the UK. The venture, which GIC will own 80% of, will focus on last-mile urban distribution centers and may expand into Ireland and Spain. Kennedy Wilson will source, acquire, and manage the assets, and the joint venture aims to capitalize on trends driven by e-commerce adoption and changing supply-chain management strategies. This partnership is part of GIC's broader strategy to invest in the urban logistics sector.

site_title: US current account deficit rises to more than 12-year high
summary: The US current account deficit surged to a 12-year high of $178.5 billion in the third quarter, surpassing expectations. Consumer spending drove the increase, with imports rising $94.4 billion to a record $602.7 billion, outpacing exports which rebounded $68.4 billion to $357.1 billion. The deficit represented 3.4% of GDP, the largest since 2008, but remains below a peak of 6.3% in 2005.

site_title: Window to the world
summary: MO Bar at the Mandarin Oriental has launched its latest menu, "Nomadic Foragers," which transports patrons to regional destinations through expertly crafted cocktails. The menu features 12 unique drinks inspired by destinations visited by the bar's team, including local flavors and vessels. The menu's design echoes the bar's interior, with a color scheme of black, gold, and champagne. This latest offering is a taste of exploration, despite a year without travel, and showcases the bar's commitment to culinary innovation.

site_title: Gojek leverages Indonesia's Bank Jago in digital banking fight
summary: Gojek has invested 2.25 trillion rupiah (S$215 million) to raise its stake in Indonesia's Bank Jago to 22.2%, giving the ride-hailing operator significant access to the digital bank's products and services. This deal allows Gojek users to open bank accounts through Bank Jago's app, and observers believe it could give Gojek considerable influence in the bank's strategic vision. The partnership aligns with Gojek's corporate strategies and provides opportunities for the company to launch digital banking products for its users, while Bank Jago gains access to Gojek's millions of users across Indonesia.

site_title: New Silkroutes appoints KPMG to carry out independent review
summary: New Silkroutes Group has appointed KPMG to conduct an independent review of two agreements involving a China unit and the valuation of its stake in a Thai firm. The review will report directly to SGX RegCo and New Silkroutes' audit and risk committee. This move comes after concerns over the agreements and valuation were raised. The outcome of the review is expected to provide clarity on the matter, although no timeline has been set for the completion of the review.

site_title: Lloyds Bank scraps all bonuses for 2020 after pandemic hammers profit
summary: Lloyds Banking Group cancelled all bonuses for its staff in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its earnings. The bank expects to set aside £4.5 billion for loan losses and will only pay above-inflation pay increases to most staff in 2021. Despite swinging to a profit in the third quarter, full-year net income is expected to be £1.1 billion, sharply lower than £2.5 billion in 2019. This decision comes after the bank and other British lenders resumed dividend payments in 2021 with conditions from the regulator.

site_title: Lexus IS 300 review: An old school delight
summary: The Lexus IS 300 is a revamp of a 2013 model, with a fresh new exterior design that belies its 36-month age. The interior, however, shows its age with outdated features such as a CD player and analog instruments. Despite this, the car delivers a driving experience that's a delight, with a turbo engine that goes from subdued to manic and a handling that's taut and under control. The IS 300's old-school charm may make it feel dated, but its tangible pleasures will appeal to keen drivers who value its unique qualities.

site_title: Mike Pence gets Covid-19 vaccine
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence received a Covid-19 vaccine shot live on television, boosting national confidence in the vaccine. Pence, his wife, and Surgeon General Jerome Adams were given the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at the White House. The event comes as President Donald Trump has sparked confusion over approval for a second anti-Covid drug and has expressed skepticism about taking the vaccine. Trump has not planned to take the vaccine immediately, citing his recovery from Covid, but will receive it when his medical team determines it's best.

site_title: China will keep policy support for economic recovery, no abrupt shift
summary: China will maintain policy support for its economic recovery, avoiding a sudden shift, to keep growth within a reasonable range in 2021. The country will continue proactive fiscal policy and flexible monetary policy, citing a statement from the Central Economic Work Conference. China's economy is expected to grow 2.1% in 2020 and 8.4% in 2021, and policymakers aim to bypass the "middle income trap" during the 14th five-year plan. The goal is to maintain continuity, stability, and sustainability of macro policies, with no sudden turn.

site_title: Conversations with friends about a better world
summary: In 2020, conversations with friends about what it means to be fair and good gained momentum, with many expressing a desire to make the world a better place. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, charitable giving surged, with a record S$13.6 million in donations on a single website in April. Corporate leaders are also discussing the impact of inequality, sparking a new narrative for post-Covid capitalism. The desire to do good is seen as a matter of thinking, not just feeling, and individuals are taking bold action to reject toxic workplace behavior and promote personal dignity.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits record high with focus on stimulus
summary: US stocks hit record highs on Friday, driven by a coronavirus stimulus package and anticipation of strong holiday sales. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 10.51 points, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 11.03 points. Despite a slight decline in the S&P 500, the market remained optimistic ahead of a weekend deadline for a stimulus deal.

site_title: China to start opening vaccination programme to general public
summary: China plans to start its vaccination programme to the general public in southwestern Sichuan province early next year, with at least one million people already receiving jabs in the country. The programme will begin after the Lunar New year holidays in February, with plans to inoculate high-risk groups by February 5. This marks the first province to outline a timeline for its vaccination plans. China has five coronavirus vaccines in development, but none have received official approval, and results from late-stage trials are yet to be published.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to sell Australia property for A$65 million
summary: Chip Eng Seng's wholly-owned subsidiary, CES Gladstone (Vic), is selling a property in Australia for A$65 million (S$65.6 million) to a trust related to American real estate developer Greystar. The sale is expected to be completed on March 31 next year and will allow Chip Eng Seng to redeploy its capital. The property, spanning 5,900 square metres, was acquired in 2016 but has yet to begin construction, and will be sold with vacant possession.

site_title: Gojek buys 22% stake in Indonesia's S$4b Bank Jago
summary: Gojek, a ride-hailing operator in Indonesia, has acquired a 22% stake in Bank Jago, a local bank valued at S$4 billion. The deal allows Gojek's users to access digital banking services through the platform. The US$160.4 million transaction gives Gojek's payments arm GoPay an overall 22.2% stake in Bank Jago. The partnership aims to leverage digital banking solutions to enhance the finances of millions of people in Indonesia, where 95 million adults lack a bank account.

site_title: StarHub appoints parent company's deputy CEO as its chief
summary: StarHub has appointed Nikhil Eapen, 48, as its new CEO, replacing Peter Kaliaropoulos, who stepped down due to family health issues. Eapen, current deputy CEO at parent company ST Telemedia, will start on Jan 1, 2021. The appointment is seen as a result of a rigorous global executive search, with Terry Clontz, chairman of StarHub, citing Eapen's experience and leadership skills as key qualifications.

site_title: More than 1.1 million ballots cast in early voting for Georgia US Senate runoffs
summary: Over 1.1 million Georgians have cast ballots in the twin US Senate runoff elections, surpassing the 1.2 million votes cast in early voting for the November presidential contest. Voter participation is on pace to rival the record-high turnout in the presidential election, with analysts predicting a close election. Democrats need to win both contests to achieve a 50-50 split in the Senate, giving Vice President-elect Kamala Harris the tie-breaking vote, and potentially blocking many of President-elect Joe Biden's legislative goals.

images.alt_text: More than 1.1 million Georgians have voted in twin US Senate runoff elections that will determine which party controls that chamber of Congress, and with it the fate of much of Democratic President-elect Joe Biden's agenda, state data showed on Friday.

site_title: German business morale ticks up in December
summary: German business confidence rose to 92.1 points in December, exceeding expectations, despite a new lockdown to curb the second coronavirus wave. The Ifo institute's monthly confidence barometer showed a 0.2-point increase from November, driven by optimism about Covid-19 vaccines. However, analysts noted that the survey closed before the latest lockdown announcement and may not accurately reflect concerns about the restrictions. The boost in confidence may be short-lived, with some economists cautioning that the economic situation will be significantly better in mid-2021.

site_title: Asia-Pacific real estate investment deals to rebound 15-20% in 2021: JLL
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investment deals are expected to rebound 15-20% in 2021, driven by North Asia's recovery and investor interest in logistics, data centers, and alternative assets. The growth is seen as a new cycle of real estate growth, with hotel, retail, and office investments also expected to pick up as economies recover from the COVID-19 impact. This rebound is attributed to investors seeking income stability.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will resume flights to Dubai, Tokyo-Haneda, Moscow, and Munich, increasing frequency to the US, Europe, and South Africa starting January 2021.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will resume flights to Dubai, Tokyo-Haneda, Moscow and Munich, and increase the frequency of flights to the US, Europe and South Africa from January 2021.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in the red, STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares ended the week in the red, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% to 2,848.98, following uncertainty over Brexit talks and a US stimulus package. Other Asian markets also declined, but US stocks rose on optimism about a fiscal stimulus package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively, while the Nasdaq climbed 0.8%. Keppel DC Reit was the biggest gainer, while Jardine Strategic Holdings was the biggest loser, declining 2.6%.

site_title: Swiss Parliament approves same-sex marriage
summary: Switzerland's Parliament approved a Bill allowing same-sex couples to marry, aligning the country with much of Europe on gay rights. However, the Christian, ultra-conservative Federal Democratic Union party plans to put the legislation to a referendum, potentially overturning the decision. Switzerland remains one of few European countries without same-sex marriage.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 21.86 points to 1,652.49. The index saw a significant increase in volume, with 8.061 billion lots traded worth RM4.386 billion. The number of losers exceeded gainers, with 864 companies closing lower compared to 378.

site_title: YouTube faces complaints of lax approach on overseas election misinformation
summary: YouTube faces criticism for its lax approach to election misinformation globally, with its policies not applying to the recent Myanmar general election. Despite deleting over 1.8 million channels for policy violations, researchers and civil society groups say the platform is unprepared to mitigate risk in countries like Myanmar, where misinformation spread rapidly. Experts warn that YouTube's hands-off approach will only escalate the issue, and the company must create policies that account for volatile situations.

site_title: Nine new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Nine new imported COVID-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore as of Friday, Dec 18, bringing the total to 58,386. All cases are on stay-home notices or isolated on arrival. The cases include 13 Singaporeans or permanent residents and four work pass holders from various countries. The number of new community cases remains low, with no cases reported in the past week. 14 cases were discharged, leaving 33 patients in hospital and 63 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Brexit trade talks enter desperate 'final hours'
summary: British and EU negotiators are in the "final hours" of their Brexit trade talks, with the UK and EU deeply divided on fishing rights. The UK will leave the EU single market on December 31, and a deal must be approved by Sunday for it to take effect on January 1. Negotiators are struggling to bridge the gap on fisheries, with the EU seeking a long-term agreement guaranteeing access for EU boats and the UK insisting on its right to decide who gets to fish in its waters.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as Covid-19 restrictions return
summary: Australian shares fell 1.2% to 6,675.50 on Friday, their largest decline in December, due to a new coronavirus cluster in Sydney that revived movement curbs and dimmed economic recovery hopes. The cluster led to border restrictions, impacting Christmas travel plans and sending travel stocks down. Financials, including the "Big Four" banks, also declined, with some local leaders' reactions seen as populist rather than economic-friendly.

site_title: GIC, Kennedy Wilson ink US$1b urban-logistics joint venture
summary: GIC and Kennedy Wilson have entered a US$1 billion joint venture (JV) to acquire and manage urban logistics properties in the UK, with the potential to expand into Ireland and Spain. The JV will be seeded with a US$220 million portfolio of 18 urban logistics assets in prime UK locations, currently owned by Kennedy Wilson. GIC will own 80% and Kennedy Wilson 20%. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for urban logistics properties driven by e-commerce adoption and changing supply-chain management strategies.

site_title: StanChart enables access of banker's guarantees via NTP's CamelONE portal
summary: Standard Chartered (StanChart) has enabled access to banker's guarantees through Singapore's CamelONE Trade Finance portal, a unified digital platform. The digital process has reduced processing errors and steps by 70% and enhanced transparency, allowing applicants to track their applications in real-time. The integration with the Networked Trade Platform (NTP) has streamlined operations for clients, including Nordic Flow Control, a systems-integration solutions provider. This is the first instance of StanChart using the CamelONE portal to issue banker's guarantees.

site_title: UK retail sales fell in November as lockdown hit stores
summary: UK retail sales fell 3.8% in November due to a four-week lockdown in England that closed non-essential stores. Despite this, sales volumes increased 2.4% compared to the same period last year, below the forecasted 2.8% rise. The decline was less than predicted, with the lockdown alone being less severe than anticipated.

site_title: ECB nominates Elderson as new bank supervisor
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has nominated Frank Elderson as the new deputy chair of its bank supervision arm, replacing Yves Mersch whose term expired on December 14. Elderson, who joined the ECB board on December 15, will be appointed by the European Union council after approval by the European Parliament.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank nominated Frank Elderson as the deputy chair of its bank supervision arm, it said on Friday, confirming a widely expected move.

site_title: Palm jumps on hopes of muted production, higher exports
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rose 1.4% on Friday, reaching RM3,426 a tonne, due to expectations of subdued production and improving exports in December. This is the third consecutive session of gains, with exports of Malaysian palm oil products rising 9.5% on-month to 725,380 tonnes. The market anticipates a negative growth in December production and zero January export tax. Gains were also supported by rival oils, including soyoil and soybean prices.

site_title: Singapore Airlines to resume daily flights to US from Jan 18
summary: Singapore Airlines will resume daily non-stop flights from Los Angeles, San Francisco, and New York's JFK International starting January 18, marking a significant increase in flights from the airline's pre-pandemic levels. The move comes as promising signs of recovery in international air travel emerge, particularly with the start of vaccine inoculation programs. The airline will operate Airbus A350-900 aircraft on the routes, and passengers will not be required to show vaccination certification, depending on state rules.

site_title: New Silkroutes appoints KMPG to carry out independent review
summary: New Silkroutes Group has appointed KPMG to conduct an independent review of two agreements involving a China unit and the valuation of its stake in a Thai firm. This comes after Deloitte & Touche issued a disclaimer of opinion on the group's financial statements for the fiscal year ended June 30. KPMG will report directly to the Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm and New Silkroutes' audit and risk committee, aiming to provide assurance on the group's financial statements. The independent review is expected to address concerns raised by Deloitte & Touche.

site_title: Ant Group stops offering sales of online deposit products at Chinese banks
summary: Ant Group, a financial arm of Alibaba, has stopped allowing individuals to deposit funds with banks via its online platform Alipay, in response to regulatory demands to mitigate financial risks. The move follows a warning from Chinese regulators that online deposits services offered by big tech companies are violating rules. Existing deposits will not be impacted, but the removal aims to prevent high-yield deposits that could lift costs for banks and intensify liquidity issues for smaller lenders. The decision comes after a planned US$37 billion stock listing of Ant Group was suspended in November.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower on news that US to blacklist more Chinese firms
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Friday due to news that the US is set to blacklist dozens of Chinese companies, including China's top chipmaker SMIC. The move, part of President Donald Trump's efforts to cement his legacy, comes ahead of the transition to Democratic President-elect Joe Biden. The Hang Seng index dropped 0.67% to 26,498.60, while China's Shanghai Composite index fell 0.29%. The US is expected to add around 80 Chinese companies to the blacklist, further escalating tensions between Washington and Beijing.

site_title: SIA to resume flights to four cities from January
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will resume flights to Dubai, Tokyo-Haneda, Moscow, and Munich, increasing frequencies to the US, Europe, and South Africa starting January 2021. Non-stop daily flights from Los Angeles, San Francisco, and New York to Singapore will resume on January 18. The airline will also carry vaccines and expects significant cargo traffic on its expanded services. SIA's commitment to the US market remains strong, with investments planned to accommodate a longer-term return to travel as market conditions improve.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media debuts on SGX at 6.1% above IPO price
summary: GHY Culture & Media, an entertainment and content provider, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange at S$0.70, 6.1% above its IPO price of S$0.66. The stock eased to S$0.665 by 10:02am, with 8.7 million shares changing hands. GHY CEO Guo Jingyu stated that the listing will enhance the firm's profile in Singapore and abroad.

site_title: Tencent-led consortium buys extra 10% of Vivendi's Universal
summary: A Tencent-led consortium has agreed to purchase an additional 10% stake in Universal Music Group (UMG) for 30 billion euros, valuing the company at 48.7 billion dollars. This deal follows a previous purchase of a 10% stake in March 2020. Vivendi, the parent company of UMG, plans to use the proceeds to reduce debt and finance share buybacks and acquisitions. The additional stake is to be exercised by January 15, 2021.

site_title: Poshmark files for IPO saying it became profitable this year
summary: Poshmark, an online resale marketplace for second-hand clothing, filed for an initial public offering (IPO) with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The company reported a net income of $21 million on revenue of $193 million for the nine months ended September 30, compared to a net loss of $34 million in the same period in 2019. Poshmark has over 70 million users and more than 130 million items sold with a combined value exceeding $4 billion. The company plans to list its shares on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol POSH.

site_title: Barclays UK chairman Cheshire steps down, Crawford Gillies takes over
summary: Barclays UK chairman Ian Cheshire is stepping down on January 1, 2021, to focus on a change program. He will be succeeded by Crawford Gillies, who will step down as senior independent director. Gillies' position will be taken over by Brian Gilvary. The decision allows Cheshire to prioritize his commitment to the change program.

site_title: Hi-P International CEO makes voluntary unconditional general offer at S$2 per share
summary: Hi-P International's CEO, Yao Hsiao Tung, has made a voluntary unconditional general offer to buy all shares of the company for S$2 per share, representing a 13.6% premium over the last traded price. The offer aims to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange. The offer price is also a 160.1% premium to the company's net asset value as of June 30, 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened steady on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index at 6,551.46 points. In the eurozone, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index both eased 0.2% due to bank and healthcare sector drag. Markets are awaiting the outcome of Britain and the EU's post-Brexit trade deal negotiations, with US-EU tariffs also in focus.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as virus concerns offset US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares ended flat on Friday, despite growing optimism about a new US economic aid package, as concerns over surging coronavirus infections at home overshadowed the news. The benchmark Kospi closed nearly unchanged at 2,772.18, with 1,062 new coronavirus cases reported, its second-highest ever daily tally. Foreigners were net sellers of US$175.10 million worth of shares, offsetting the boost to sentiment from the US economic aid news.

site_title: Philips buys BioTelemetry for US$2.8b
summary: Royal Philips has agreed to buy US-based BioTelemetry for $2.8 billion, expanding its presence in wearable heart monitors and at-home care. The deal is a 17% premium over BioTelemetry's Thursday closing price, with shareholders receiving $72 per share in cash. The acquisition is expected to boost sales growth and profit margins for Philips in 2021, particularly in the $3 billion market for heart disorder diagnosis and monitoring equipment.

images.alt_text: Royal Philips agreed to buy US-based BioTelemetry for US$2.8 billion to expand in wearable heart monitors as the Dutch company expands in the burgeoning at-home care market.

site_title: Siemens sees train boom from climate-conscious spending on rail
summary: Siemens predicts a significant growth in the global train market over the next three years, driven by increasing government spending on reducing carbon-dioxide emissions from transport. The European Union's plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 is expected to favor rail-equipment manufacturers, with Siemens expecting a quarter expansion in the global market. The company sees a rail recovery as a boon, particularly in Europe, where nations such as France and Germany are increasing rail-related spending. This is expected to lead to investments in new high-speed trains and the digitization of rail networks.

site_title: Volkswagen plans to link top executives' bonuses to ESG targets
summary: Volkswagen plans to link top executives' bonuses to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets, aiming to bolster sustainability credentials and align with investors' increasing focus on ESG performance. The move is part of a broader strategy to become carbon-neutral by 2050 and comes as the company seeks to address criticism of its governance structure. VW's updated remuneration system will track progress via key metrics, including internal decarbonisation and diversity indices, and will be put to shareholders for approval.

site_title: Japan to develop longer-range anti-ship missiles as China pressure mounts
summary: Japan plans to develop longer-range anti-ship missiles to counter China's growing presence in the East China Sea, particularly around disputed islands. The new missiles will have a range of at least 200 km and can target warships at greater distances. This move is part of Japan's anti-access area denial (A2AD) strategy to prevent foreign forces from operating freely in waters close to its home territory. The development comes as Japan acquires air-launched missiles to hit North Korean missile sites and considers strike weapons to hit ground targets in China.

site_title: ESM Goh Chok Tong has cancer surgery, will undergo four weeks of radiotherapy
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, 79, has undergone cancer surgery to remove a lump in his larynx and will undergo four weeks of radiotherapy to ensure all cancerous cells are killed off. The lump was found to have cancerous squamous cells, but scans showed no cancer in his neck or chest. Goh is encouraging people to seek medical help if they notice changes in their voice or experience a lump in their throat, citing the importance of early detection and treatment.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes lower
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed lower on Friday, down 0.16% or 43.28 points, at 26,763.39, amid concerns over rising new coronavirus cases in Japan. The broader Topix index edged up 0.04% to 1,793.24. Market sentiment remained cautious, with worries over a potential economic impact from the cases weighing on investors.

site_title: AIA to extend free Covid-19 special coverage for customers, staff till mid-2021
summary: AIA Singapore will extend its free Covid-19 special coverage until June 2021, benefiting 2.6 million customers, employees, and dependents. The insurer has already helped 500 customers with Covid-19-related medical bills. AIA Singapore's CEO, Wong Sze Keed, reaffirmed the company's commitment to supporting its community during the pandemic. The insurer has invested over S$5 million in community initiatives, including creating 500 new jobs and raising over S$550,000 for two charities.

site_title: Australia names new trade minister amid China tensions
summary: Australia Prime Minister Scott Morrison named Education Minister Dan Tehan as the new trade minister amid rising tensions with China. The move comes after Canberra called for an independent investigation into the origins of the coronavirus, leading to China imposing tariffs on Australian commodities. Former Trade Minister Simon Birmingham was named the finance minister. The reshuffle is part of Australia's efforts to address strained relations with its largest trade partner.

site_title: Singapore increasing checks on F&B outlets' Covid-19 measures during festive period
summary: Singapore's government will increase checks on food and beverage (F&B) outlets' Covid-19 measures during the festive period. Starting this weekend, enforcement checks will be conducted to ensure compliance with safe-management measures, including limiting group gatherings to five people and prohibiting intermingling. Those found flouting the rules face fines, temporary closure, and prosecution. The measures will remain in place until Phase Three takes effect on Dec 28, when gatherings of up to eight people will be allowed.

site_title: Pfizer applies for Covid-19 vaccine approval in Japan
summary: Pfizer has applied for approval in Japan of its Covid-19 vaccine, which is already being administered in the UK and US. The Japanese government has a supply deal for 120 million vaccine doses, with a focus on effectiveness and safety. Japan aims to vaccinate its residents in the first half of next year, with the government committed to making proper arrangements for the rollout.

site_title: Gucci joins Alibaba's luxury e-commerce site to woo Chinese consumers
summary: Gucci is launching two flagship stores on Alibaba's Tmall Luxury Pavilion platform, aiming to tap into China's growing luxury market. The first store will open on December 21, followed by a second store focused on beauty products in February 2021. This move underscores Gucci's efforts to reverse revenue losses due to the pandemic and capitalize on China's increasing demand for luxury goods. The partnership highlights the importance of the Chinese market for high-end brands seeking to expand their online presence.

site_title: Bank of Japan says to examine steps to make policy framework sustainable
summary: The Bank of Japan announced it will examine steps to make its monetary easing framework more sustainable, releasing findings in March 2021. The central bank extended its measures to ease corporate funding strains by six months due to the resurgence of coronavirus infections. Interest rates remained unchanged at -0.1% and 10-year bond yields around 0%. The BOJ's decision aims to provide support for the world's third-largest economy amid uncertain global outlook.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan said on Friday it will begin examining steps to make its monetary easing framework more effective and sustainable, and release its findings in March next year.

site_title: 'Star Wars' Boba Fett actor Jeremy Bulloch dies at 75
summary: British actor Jeremy Bulloch, best known for playing Boba Fett in the original Star Wars films, has died at 75 due to health complications related to Parkinson's disease. Bulloch's iconic portrayal of the bounty hunter has captivated audiences since his appearance in The Empire Strikes Back and The Return of the Jedi. Fellow Star Wars actors, including Mark Hamill and Billy Dee Williams, paid tribute to him on social media, remembering his warmth, generosity, and enduring legacy.

site_title: Cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase says it filed to go public
summary: Coinbase Global, the largest US cryptocurrency exchange, has filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission to go public. The company expects its draft registration filing to become effective after the SEC completes its review process. This marks a breakthrough moment for the industry, following a valuation of over $8 billion in 2018. Details of its listing plans were not provided, and a representative declined to comment further.

images.alt_text: Coinbase Global, the biggest US cryptocurrency exchange, said it has filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission to go public in what's anticipated to be a break-through moment for the industry.

site_title: Tesla to join elite S&P index, shaking up Wall Street
summary: Tesla is set to join the Standard & Poor's 500 index, marking a significant milestone for the electric carmaker. The company's market capitalization of $600 billion will make it the richest firm in the prestigious index, with a spectacular 680% rise in stock value this year. The move is expected to force portfolio reshuffling, with some analysts predicting a potential pullback in Tesla's stock price. Despite this, others believe Tesla's growth prospects and unique challenges in the auto sector will ensure a durable competitive edge.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index declining 0.85 points, or 0.05%, to 1,673.50. Volume was 320.91 million lots worth RM98.58 million. Gainers outpaced losers 277 to 145. The decline followed global market trends, with Europe's stocks also down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Australia imposes border curbs as Sydney virus cluster grows; Christmas travel chaos
summary: Australia has imposed border restrictions in response to a growing COVID-19 cluster in Sydney's northern beaches, with 28 new cases detected. The cluster has raised concerns about potential transmission to other areas of the city. Residents in affected suburbs are advised to stay home for three days, while authorities have named over 30 potential transmission sites. The new restrictions have thrown Christmas travel plans into chaos, with many people attempting to flee the state and some being placed in hotel quarantine. The cluster has dented Australia's success in containing COVID-19, which had seen the country go two weeks without local transmission.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to concerns over rising virus cases in Japan and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.16% to 26,763.65, while the Topix index lost 0.16% to 1,789.71. These declines offset a positive lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip as dealers track stimulus progress
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday as investors awaited the outcome of US stimulus talks, despite a record close for Wall Street. The US and lawmakers are nearing a deal on a rescue package, which would include direct payments to people, with top politicians expressing optimism. However, a cautious tone was maintained by some lawmakers, and Brexit negotiations remained a concern. The pound remained stable despite warnings of a possible no-deal, while Asia's markets were largely down, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Singapore losing value.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, dipping 0.10% to 26,650.49, following previous gains. Traders are watching US stimulus talks, which may be close to a breakthrough, and US-EU trade tensions. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.13% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.06%. Market sentiment is influenced by global economic factors and trade negotiations.

site_title: Sony pulls Cyberpunk 2077 from PlayStation store after bug backlash
summary: Sony has removed Cyberpunk 2077 from the PlayStation store worldwide, citing "customer satisfaction" due to bugs, compatibility issues, and health risks. The company will offer full refunds to gamers who purchased the game. CD Projekt RED, the game's developer, had apologized and vowed to fix bugs with patches in January and February. The game's release had been delayed twice and sparked health warnings after a reviewer claimed it caused an epileptic seizure.

images.alt_text: Sony said on Friday it was pulling the much-hyped Cyberpunk 2077 from PlayStation stores around the world citing "customer satisfaction", after complaints of bugs, compatibility issues and even health risks.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Friday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 2,855.2, as investors maintained caution due to ongoing Brexit talks, Covid-19 vaccine developments, and US stimulus negotiations. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB down 0.3% each, while OCBC rose 0.3%. Contract manufacturer Hi-P International surged 10.5% after its chairman made a voluntary offer to delist the company. Global markets saw gains, with US stocks reaching fresh records on optimism over the economy's 2021 outlook.

site_title: World's richest banker made US$16b after a brush with death
summary: World's richest banker, Uday Kotak, has a fortune of around $16 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. His Kotak Mahindra Bank has risen through the crowd by starting to slow lending to riskier sectors and keeping good corporate governance, despite a shadow-lending crisis in India. The bank has a 27% profit surge in the quarter ended Sept 30 and its shares are up 17% this year, the most among Indian peers. Kotak's strategy paid off, and he has been extended his CEO term for another three years, with investors starting to wonder what will happen after he hands over the reins.

site_title: FedEx profit leaps on rate hikes, e-commerce shipments
summary: FedEx Corp reported a 97% increase in quarterly profit to $1.30 billion, driven by rate hikes and rising e-commerce shipments. Revenue grew 19% to $20.6 billion, beating analyst expectations. Average daily package volume jumped 29% to 12.3 million, with revenue per package increasing 7%. FedEx CFO Michael Lenz expects earnings growth in the second half of fiscal 2021, despite uncertainty due to the new wave of Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as new virus cluster sows doubt about quick recovery
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday as a new cluster of Covid-19 cases in New South Wales prompted authorities to ask residents to stay at home for three days. The S&P/ASX 200 index is still headed for a seventh straight weekly gain, but airlines, financials, and energy stocks took a hit, with Qantas and Commonwealth Bank dropping 4.3% and 1.3%, respectively. Gold stocks rose 1.8% to support gains on the metals and mining sub-index.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Hi-P, GHY Culture & Media, SLB, Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Singapore stocks saw various developments on Friday, including CapitaLand's talks with tenants to boost occupancy, Hi-P International's chairman making a voluntary offer to delist the company, and the Singapore Exchange launching a China-linked steel derivative. GHY Culture & Media Holding began trading on the mainboard after its IPO, while SLB Development completed its acquisition of Thye Hong Centre. Cromwell E-Reit's non-independent non-executive director Paul Weightman will resign on December 31.

site_title: Coca-Cola to cut 2,200 jobs worldwide amid Covid-19 challenges
summary: Coca-Cola is cutting 2,200 jobs worldwide, including 1,200 in the US, as part of its restructuring efforts amid ongoing challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic and shifting consumer tastes. The 2.5% workforce reduction involves voluntary buyouts and layoffs, with annual savings expected to be around $350-550 million. The move aims to build a more agile organizational structure to address changing customer needs and behaviors, with the pandemic serving as a catalyst for the company's restructuring efforts.

site_title: Suspected Russian hacking spree reached into Microsoft: sources
summary: US officials have disclosed a massive hacking campaign that targeted government agencies, including Microsoft, the US Energy Department, and the National Nuclear Security Administration. The suspected Russian hackers used compromised updates of SolarWinds networking management software, which was used by hundreds of thousands of companies and government agencies. Microsoft confirmed it was breached, but the extent of the damage is unknown. The Department of Homeland Security is investigating, and the FBI has scheduled a classified briefing for members of Congress.

site_title: Robert Lewandowski put Messi and Ronaldo in shade with Fifa top prize
summary: Robert Lewandowski has won FIFA's 'The Best' award for top footballer, relegating Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi to supporting roles. Lewandowski, 32, scored 55 goals in the 2019/20 season, helping Bayern Munich win the treble. His disciplined approach to training and nutrition has earned him the nickname 'The Body.' Lewandowski has also been named Uefa's Player of the Year and has scored 264 goals in 306 games for Bayern Munich.

site_title: Biden taps Haaland as first Native American interior secretary
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has chosen Rep. Deb Haaland as the first Native American to lead a cabinet-level department, Interior Secretary, following a public campaign and tribal leader support. Haaland, a Democrat from New Mexico, prioritized tribal community services, environmental protection, and climate change during her time in Congress. If confirmed by the Senate, she would be the first Native American to head the Interior Department, overseeing natural resources and tribal lands.

site_title: Dubai wealth fund adds another builder in distress to roster
summary: The Investment Corp of Dubai (ICD) has taken control of state-owned developer Meydan's real estate projects, aiming to improve efficiencies in operations. This move marks a significant expansion of ICD's presence in Dubai's property market. ICD's CEO, Mohammed Al Shaibani, stated that the review of Meydan's business strategy is underway. The exact terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence turns positive first time since August 2017: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence has turned positive for the first time since August 2017, according to an ANZ Bank survey. The survey's headline measure showed a net 9.4% of respondents expecting the economy to improve over the year ahead, up from 6.9% in November. This is the highest level of optimism since March 2018. Additionally, 21.7% of respondents expected their businesses to grow in the next 12 months, the highest level since March 2018.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records on vaccine, stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records on Thursday, driven by optimism about the 2021 outlook as coronavirus vaccines advance and Congress appears close to a deal on stimulus spending. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all ended at all-time highs, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a record for the third straight session. Despite grim figures on the US coronavirus outbreak, investors remained optimistic about a 2021 recovery.

site_title: Google hit with third antitrust lawsuit, by new state coalition
summary: Google has been hit with its third antitrust lawsuit in as many months, with 38 US states and territories accusing the company of abusing its internet search dominance to eliminate competition. The lawsuit, filed by US states, claims Google's actions have protected its general search monopolies and deprived consumers of competitive choices, innovation, and new entry. Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser stated that Google's anticompetitive actions have harmed consumers and undermined new entry, with the suit going beyond a case filed by the US Justice Department earlier this year.

site_title: US panel recommends emergency approval of Moderna Covid-19 vaccine
summary: A US panel of experts has recommended emergency approval of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine, paving the way for 6 million doses to ship as soon as this weekend. The recommendation is expected to be granted by the Food and Drug Administration, making Moderna's vaccine the second to be approved in a Western country. The panel voted 20-0-1 in favor of the approval, with one abstention.

site_title: Cyberattack on US government poses 'grave risk': security agency
summary: A sophisticated cyberattack on US government agencies and private companies poses a "grave risk" and thwarting it will be "highly complex," according to the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA). The attack, which began in at least March 2020, targeted US government agencies, critical infrastructure entities, and private sector organizations using compromised software updates. President-elect Joe Biden expressed "great concern" and vowed to make cybersecurity a top priority, while Senator Mitt Romney blamed Russia and called for increased cyber defense measures.

site_title: UK says chances of Brexit trade deal are below 50%, despite EU optimism
summary: The UK's chances of securing a trade deal with the European Union are below 50%, according to senior British minister Michael Gove, just two weeks before Britain's departure from the bloc. This prediction contrasts with EU optimism and optimism from EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, who said "good progress" had been made but "last stumbling blocks remain." A deal is crucial for the £1 trillion annual goods trade between the two, and failure to agree could send shockwaves through financial markets.

site_title: Spanner in Tencent's M&A machine could be useful
summary: China's State Administration of Market Regulation (SAMR) is intensifying scrutiny on tech giants, particularly Tencent, with draft rules targeting monopolistic behavior. The agency fined a Tencent subsidiary and two other companies for failing to report past mergers, sending a message that Beijing is serious about reining in technology giants. This could limit Tencent's ability to make future purchases, potentially welcoming a slower pace for the company's M&A sprees, which have a mixed track record. The move may ultimately benefit Tencent's shareholders.

site_title: New Sydney Covid-19 cluster gives Australians 'wake-up call'
summary: A growing Covid-19 cluster in Sydney, Australia's largest city, has prompted health officials to urge thousands of residents to stay home. The cluster, initially reported with five cases, has expanded to at least 15 cases, with officials racing to identify the source of the infection on the city's northern beaches.

site_title: Fed to maintain bond buys until 'substantial' economy gains seen
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained its massive asset purchase program, promising to keep buying at least $120 billion in monthly bonds until it sees "substantial further progress" in employment and inflation. The decision, made by Chairman Jerome Powell, aims to support the economy amid a challenging winter due to the pandemic. The Fed expects to maintain its target range until labor market conditions reach levels consistent with maximum employment and inflation rises to 2% and exceeds it for some time.

site_title: US lawmakers nearing stimulus deal amid signs of economic distress
summary: US lawmakers are nearing a stimulus deal to aid the pandemic-battered economy, with a $900 billion package expected to include direct payments to Americans. The recovery has stalled, with weekly unemployment benefits rising to 885,000 and factory activity slowing in the Philadelphia region. Without an agreement, millions of unemployed workers will lose special pandemic benefits by year-end. Lawmakers are optimistic, with Republican leader Mitch McConnell saying discussions are in good faith and a deal is possible despite final issues to be hammered out.

site_title: Oil prices rise, hit nine-month high on US stimulus progress
summary: Oil prices rose to a nine-month high, with Brent crude futures settling at $51.50 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $48.36 a barrel. The price increase is attributed to optimism over US fiscal stimulus progress and record-breaking refining demand in China and India. The US dollar's 2-1/2 year low against major rivals also made oil cheaper for international buyers, contributing to the price surge. Analysts expect a rapid increase in crude oil demand in the New Year as the vaccine rolls out in the US.

images.alt_text: Oil climbed on Thursday and touched a nine-month high, with traders optimistic about progress toward a US fiscal stimulus deal and record-breaking refining demand in China and India.

site_title: Europe: Shares up for fourth session on stimulus, vaccine optimism
summary: European shares held near 10-month highs on Thursday, driven by hopes of more US stimulus and potential Covid-19 vaccine rollouts. Germany's DAX rose 0.8% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index climbed 0.3%, extending gains to a fourth straight session. The UK's FTSE 100 lagged 0.3% as Brexit trade talks progressed. Vaccine optimism and a possible US$900 billion stimulus package boosted the market, while the European Central Bank's stimulus measures also supported the recovery.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media's public tranche of IPO 16 times subscribed
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holding Co's public tranche of initial public offering (IPO) has been 16 times subscribed, with 1,402 valid applications for 48.1 million shares and indications of interest for 160.4 million shares. The offering, which includes 21.7 million shares priced at S$0.66, is expected to raise gross proceeds of S$121.7 million. The company plans to use the funds to expand its TV, film, and concert production businesses.

site_title: SLB to seek shareholder ratification for Thye Hong Centre purchase
summary: SLB Development has completed its S$112.5 million acquisition of Thye Hong Centre, a six-storey industrial building in Singapore. The company will now seek shareholder approval for the deal at an extraordinary general meeting by March 17, 2021. SLB plans to collect rental income and explore redevelopment possibilities, with a focus on increasing the building's net lettable area and injecting lifestyle elements. The acquisition is part of SLB's business expansion to replenish its land bank, and shares rose 5% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Thye Hong Centre is a freehold six-storey asset sitting on a 64,067 square foot site zoned for light industrial use, near Redhill MRT station.

site_title: Keppel to build wind turbine installation vessel in US; more bondholders accede to Floatel lock-up
summary: Keppel Corporation is building a wind turbine installation vessel (WTIV) for Dominion Energy, scheduled for delivery in 2023, worth approximately S$600 million.
