The vessel, built by Keppel Offshore & Marine's shipyard, will be available for charter hire on US East Coast projects exceeding five gigawatts of US offshore wind construction through to 2027. Separately, more bondholders have acceded to a lock-up agreement for Floatel, a 49.92%-owned subsidiary of Keppel Corp, supporting a proposed financial and corporate restructuring.

site_title: Indonesia, Philippine central banks hold key rates steady
summary: Indonesia's Bank Indonesia and the Philippines' Bangko Sentral held their benchmark interest rates steady, with Bank Indonesia maintaining a 7-day reverse repurchase rate of 3.75% and Bangko Sentral keeping its overnight reverse repurchase rate at 2%. Central bankers cited a benign inflation environment and pledged to keep policies supportive of growth, as their economies struggle with the worst virus outbreaks in Southeast Asia. The decisions are seen as a preservation of bullets for 2021, with loan growth remaining weak and funding costs high.

site_title: Labour market recovery could be slow in playing catch-up
summary: Singapore's resident employment numbers surged 43,200 in Q3, with resident employment comparable to pre-pandemic levels. However, retrenchments rose by 9,120, and resident unemployment increased to 4.8% in October. The Ministry of Manpower is cautiously optimistic about a recovery, but warns of "considerable uncertainty" due to the labour market lagging GDP growth and the complexity of the pandemic-driven recession. The economy's recovery is expected to be slow, with some jobs potentially disappearing due to digitalization and automation.

site_title: US dollar retreats as risk appetite swells
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest in over two years against major currencies after the Federal Reserve stuck to its current policy, boosting appetite for riskier currencies. The dollar retreated to a new low of 89.867 against a basket of currencies, driven by hopes for US stimulus and a post-Brexit trade deal. The European Union and UK reached "good progress" in Brexit talks, boosting the pound to a two-year high, while the Swiss franc hit a six-year high against the dollar after the Swiss National Bank stuck to its readiness to intervene in currency markets.

site_title: Chile's great pension raid
summary: Chile's Congress has authorized a second withdrawal of pension funds, leaving roughly half of pension savers with zero funds. The move, pushed by lawmakers from both right and left, allows high-income households to access tax-free pension savings to cope with the pandemic. Critics argue the government should have done more to support households, but experts say the pension system's flaws and the country's economic situation make it a necessary measure. The decision has sparked controversy, with many questioning who will pay for future pensions and the long-term impact on the pension system.

site_title: Biden to get Covid-19 vaccine next week
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden will receive the COVID-19 vaccine next week, with Vice-President Mike Pence set to get his shot on Friday. The public vaccinations are aimed at boosting confidence in the vaccine's safety. Biden, 78, is in a high-risk category for the virus due to his age, and has vowed to prioritize the fight against the pandemic. Trump will also get the vaccine, but no timeline has been set. Initial doses have been set aside for frontline workers and some government officials, with 2.9 million doses planned by the end of the week.

site_title: How business leaders can continue to reap the benefits of new world of work
summary: Business leaders can continue to reap the benefits of the new world of work by prioritizing an "always-resilient" workforce, rather than an "always-on" workforce. The pandemic has shown that remote working arrangements can lead to overwork and burnout, but with flexible working arrangements, businesses can foster a positive culture that values employee health and well-being. To achieve this, leaders should develop robust business continuity plans, provide 24/7 access to information and support, prioritize mental well-being, and promote resilience through digital tools and training. By doing so, businesses can build a resilient workforce and drive productivity and overall resilience.

site_title: EU approves Google's acquisition of Fitbit
summary: The European Union has approved Google's $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit, a smartwatch maker, after the tech giant agreed to conditions including not using health data from European users for advertising. EU competition chief Margrethe Vestager stated that the commitments will ensure the market for wearables and digital health remains open and competitive. Google's acquisition of Fitbit is expected to determine how the company uses health and fitness data, as well as interoperability between competing wearables and Android. The deal was approved after Google made commitments to safeguard these areas.

site_title: Canadian insurer Sun Life Financial bets big on Japanese workers returning to office life
summary: Canadian insurer Sun Life Financial's real estate arm BentallGreenOak plans to double staff and invest $10 billion in Japan over two to three years, mostly in office buildings in major business districts. The company is betting on a return to office life in Japan, citing the country's traditional business culture and limited space in homes for remote work. This investment will be part of a surge in commercial real estate investment in Tokyo, contrasting with declines in other major cities.

site_title: Porsche puts its electric dreams on display
summary: Porsche is showcasing its electric ambitions with a pop-up exhibition at Jewel Changi Airport in Singapore. The exhibition, featuring the Taycan Turbo, highlights the brand's plans to have more than half its output come from electric or electrified cars within five years. Porsche Asia Pacific CEO Arthur Willmann notes that the company aims to cater to local preferences, offering three concepts: combustion engines, plug-in hybrids, and fully electric cars. The brand plans to build a network of high-performance chargers for its electric vehicles and is exploring possibilities for high-speed charging in Singapore.

site_title: Number of hotels used as SHN facilities depends on supply and demand: STB
summary: The Singapore government is closely monitoring the number of hotels designated as stay-home notice (SHN) facilities, with typically 30-60 hotels in use at any time. This comes after hotels like Naumi Hotel and Amara Singapore canceled leisure bookings to accommodate SHN guests. The government has negotiated contracts with hotels to provide rooms for SHN needs, and will continue to adjust capacity based on the evolving Covid-19 situation. The move aims to combat the virus while preserving Singapore's status as an international hub.

site_title: Treats for the Christmas table
summary: Several Singaporean businesses are offering festive food and drink sets for Christmas. Culture Spoon's Wok with Man offers a Thai-inspired takeaway set ($138) with dishes such as Thai-style roast chicken and grilled pork. Starter Lab's Christmas selection includes festive breads and cakes, including a hazelnut and chocolate sourdough loaf ($18) and spiced ginger tea cake ($55). The White Rabbit offers a gourmet set ($188) with dishes such as roasted black truffle chicken and black forest log cake. Munchkins, a home-based business, offers boozy fruitcakes infused with cognac and rum. Pantler's festive gift box includes French chestnut pound cake and other sweet treats.

site_title: CapitaLand remains bullish on flexible workspaces
summary: CapitaLand is set to open its second Bridge+ flexible workspace in Singapore, a 56,000 sq ft facility offering workspace options and meeting rooms. The company remains bullish on flexible workspaces, citing the work-from-home experience as prompting firms to review their utilisation strategies. With a focus on creating an ecosystem for collaboration, Bridge+ aims to build a "FinTech hub" and foster connections among tech firms, venture capital firms, and financial institutions. The new space will be the second Bridge+ facility in Singapore, with the first launched last year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hoe Leong Corporation has appealed to strike out a civil suit in Malaysia for alleged deceit and fraudulent misrepresentation. The trial is set for October 21-25, 2021. AsiaPhos Limited secured a 21.06 million yuan banking facility for one year. Cromwell European Reit's Paul Weightman will resign as non-executive director and retire on December 31. Michael Wilde will become acting CEO of Cromwell Property Group on January 1, 2021. Sevak Limited hired Abhrajit Shaw as its new chief financial officer.

site_title: Hong Kong sets new climate disclosure rules
summary: Hong Kong's financial regulators have set a new climate disclosure rule, requiring financial institutions and listed companies to disclose the financial impact of climate change on their businesses by 2025. This change aims to harmonize climate-related disclosures globally and enable investors to make informed decisions. The rule is part of a broader plan to drive green initiatives and develop Hong Kong as a sustainable finance center, aligning with international standards such as the Task Force on Climate-related Disclosures (TCFD).

site_title: STI slips 0.5% as caution reigns over Brexit, Covid vaccine, US stimulus
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% to 2,858.02 due to cautious investor sentiment over Brexit talks, vaccine news, and a US stimulus package. The US Federal Reserve maintained its interest rate stance near zero, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2% and the S&P 500 added 0.2%. Only one out of 30 STI constituent stocks ended in the black, with Genting Singapore being the biggest decliner.

site_title: Biden's expected pick for energy secretary could lead EV charge
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's expected choice for energy secretary, Jennifer Granholm, is poised to play a key role in the US's electric vehicle (EV) industry, aiming to compete with China. Granholm, who previously led a charge to secure federal funding for electric car production in Michigan, will focus on building 550,000 EV charging stations and creating over one million jobs. To achieve this, she will need to work with Congress to approve tax credits and stimulus funding.

site_title: Singapore CBD rents to hit S$9.54 psf per month by end-2020: report
summary: Singapore's central business district (CBD) office rents are expected to decline to S$9.54 per square foot (psf) per month by the end of 2020, down 10% from 2019's peak, according to CBRE. This decline is driven by emerging vacancy in the market. In contrast, city fringe and suburban offices are showing less decline, with rents falling only 1.5% and 1.6% respectively. The decline in CBD rents may lead to "flight to quality" among companies, but capital expenditure is expected to be resisted.

site_title: US warns Pacific islands about Chinese bid for undersea cable project: sources
summary: The US has warned Pacific island nations about potential security threats posed by a Chinese company's bid to build an undersea internet cable project in the region. The $72.6 million project, backed by the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, is designed to improve communications to Nauru, Micronesia, and Kiribati. Huawei Marine, a Chinese firm, submitted a low bid, sparking US concerns, while other companies including Alcatel Submarine Networks and Nokia also bid on the project. The US is urging Pacific island nations to exercise caution in their decision-making.

images.alt_text: The United States has warned Pacific island nations about security threats posed by a Chinese company's cut-price bid to build an undersea internet cable, two sources told Reuters, part of an international development project in the region.

site_title: Transcorp to be delisted from SGX on Jan 8
summary: Transcorp Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on January 8, 2021, at 9am, following a notification from SGX RegCo. The company's controlling shareholders declined to make an exit offer to remaining shareholders, and Transcorp itself was unable to generate sufficient funds to make an offer. The delisting comes after Transcorp's counter was suspended since December last year due to a liquidity crisis. The company had previously attempted to raise funds through placement agreements but faced roadblocks.

site_title: India rejoins US watch list in possible boost for rupee, bonds
summary: India has been added to the US watch list for currency manipulation, citing the country's significant goods trade surplus and sustained net currency purchases. The move could boost the rupee and local bond markets, as the Reserve Bank of India has been buying dollars to counter foreign investment inflows. Experts say the RBI may tone down its forex intervention, supporting the rupee and bond market, and potentially leading to a more diversified reserve management strategy.

site_title: Exempt Covid-19 tests, hospitalisation charges from GST: Deloitte
summary: Deloitte has urged the Singapore government to exempt Covid-19 tests and hospitalisation charges from Goods and Services Tax (GST) to help businesses minimize compliance costs, particularly for frontline workers exposed to higher COVID-19 risks. The accounting firm disputes the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore's stance that such charges are not claimable. Deloitte suggests that employers should be allowed to claim these costs as administrative concessions to support businesses affected by the pandemic.

site_title: The season for gifting
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

This season, consider gifting items that not only bring joy but also contribute to a good cause. Talidah Coffee sources rare Yemeni coffee beans, with proceeds supporting Yemen Aid's Emergency Food Baskets programme. Maison Marcel offers stylish tableware with gift wrapping services that benefit Mercy Relief. Riau Candle Co.'s soy candles support educational and medical projects in South-east Asia. Six's Hikaru fragrance collection partners with SAMH to raise awareness on mental health issues. SPD's limited edition journal and Journey Satin Scarf support local charities that help people with disabilities. These gifts make for a thoughtful and impactful present.

site_title: Proposed acquisition of Tianjin Zhong Xin shares may be behind share price surge
summary: A proposed acquisition of Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group shares by its controlling shareholder may have driven the company's share price to surge over 11% on Thursday, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Singapore's segregated travel lane will help private jet operators take off
summary: Singapore's segregated travel lane (STL) allows private jet operators to take off, benefiting business travelers from specific countries for short stays of up to 14 days without quarantine. The move is expected to stimulate demand for private jets, particularly for business travelers seeking safety and convenience. While the commercial aviation sector remains cautious due to ongoing border restrictions, charter operators see opportunities in countries with strong domestic markets. The vaccine rollout and easing of travel restrictions are expected to boost business aviation in 2021, with charter operators optimistic about the industry's sustainability and green initiatives.

site_title: Volkswagen loses EU top court ruling in diesel scandal
summary: Volkswagen's use of defeat devices to bypass diesel engine pollution tests in the EU was deemed unlawful by the EU Court of Justice. The court ruled that such software must protect the engine against sudden damage and only justify use for specific hazards. The decision, binding on Volkswagen, may lead to record recalls and lawsuits across the industry. Multiple automakers could face similar scrutiny, with consumer lawyers warning of potential consequences.

site_title: New Zealand plans vaccine rollout in second half of 2021
summary: New Zealand plans to offer free Covid-19 vaccines to its entire population by mid-2021, with two agreements secured for 7.6 million doses from AstraZeneca and 10.72 million doses from Novavax. The country has secured enough vaccines for 3.8 million and 5.36 million people, respectively. The rollout will begin with border staff and rescue workers in the second quarter, and the general public in the second half of 2021. New Zealand's economy has rebounded with record 14% growth in the July-September quarter, driven by consumer spending and construction.

site_title: London's plan to rival Singapore as vessel registration centre a long way from policy
summary: The UK is reportedly considering a plan to rival Singapore as a vessel registration centre, but industry executives say this is still a long way from policy. The UK Maritime and Coastguard Agency has compiled a preliminary paper suggesting a revamp of Britain's shipping tax and regulation to boost business after Brexit. However, spokesmen from the UK Chamber of Shipping and the Baltic Exchange claim the paper is "blue sky" thinking and has not yet been discussed with the government. Industry experts say Singapore remains a benchmark for the UK's post-Brexit aspirations and the UK's plans are unlikely to significantly impact global registration centres.

site_title: More Singapore workers to be recruited for solar industry
summary: Singapore is launching a recruitment drive to build a skilled workforce for its solar industry, aiming to create 3,000-4,000 jobs over the next two to three years. The move comes as the country seeks to achieve 2 gigawatt-peak of renewable energy by 2030. A total of 405 solar technologist positions were available, with plans to develop a career path for solar technologists, from installation to maintenance. Memoranda of understanding were signed with nine solar companies and two training providers to tackle manpower challenges and build skills, training, and job prospects for the industry.

site_title: A love letter to Sri Lankan food
summary: Sri Lankan chef Rishi Naleendra has opened Kotuwa, a restaurant in Singapore's Little India, showcasing authentic Sri Lankan cuisine. Chef Naleendra, who has no formal training in hopper-making, has perfected his signature dish, along with other traditional Sri Lankan favorites like devilled cashews and mutton rolls. The restaurant's dishes are a perfect blend of spicy, smoky, and bitter flavors, with a focus on capturing the essence of Sri Lankan tradition. With its unique atmosphere and culinary offerings, Kotuwa has received a 7-star rating, making it a must-visit for food enthusiasts.

site_title: Britain adapts housing algorithm after backlash
summary: Britain is altering its housing algorithm to address concerns that it may lead to a building boom in the rural south at the expense of the industrial north. The change comes after criticism from lawmakers, particularly from within the ruling Conservative party, amid a nationwide shortage of affordable homes. The updated algorithm aims to prioritize areas with lower housing costs and higher demand for new homes. The move follows protests and a six-month high in UK homebuyer demand, according to an index.

site_title: Ant Group: The IPO that failed to launch
summary: Chinese regulators have suspended Ant Group's planned $37 billion IPO, citing "major issues" and changes in the regulatory environment. The Shanghai Stock Exchange explained that the regulatory interview with Ant Group founder Jack Ma and changes in the regulatory environment may result in Ant not meeting listing qualifications or disclosure requirements. The company has suspended its planned listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange as well. The move comes amid concerns about Ant's impact on the financial sector and its potential systemic risks to China's economy.

site_title: Neighbourhood Wonderland
summary: The Westnedge family in Singapore's Watten Estate Road transforms their three-storey house into a Christmas wonderland with 5,000 lights and inflatables, attracting visitors from the neighborhood and beyond. Mr. Westnedge, the family patriarch, takes charge of the decorations, which include inflatables, fairy lights, and Christmas trees. He spends nearly two months setting up and maintaining the display, which also includes baking and decorating the interior. The family welcomes visitors and enjoys the festive season, with Mr. Westnedge saying the hard work is worth it to see the smiles on children's faces.

site_title: Have a merry stay-home Christmas
summary: In Singapore, Christmas celebrations can be enjoyed from the comfort of home or in-person, despite the pandemic. Virtual Christmas markets include Christmas Wonderland and Fifty Fifti Fantastic Christmas, while physical markets like The AC Festival Wonderland offer a curated selection of fashion, furniture, and décor items. Indoor snow experiences can be found at Changi Festive Village, Snow City, and Jewel's indoor garden. Those without real trees can opt for fake ones or explore online stores like Amazon and Shopee. Additionally, the Singapore Art Museum's public art showcase and Orchard Road's virtual light-up experience offer alternative festive activities.

site_title: What the boys want for Christmas
summary: Samsung's new Galaxy Z Fold2 boasts a premium feel and impressive features, justifying its S$2,888 price tag. The device boasts a 6.2-inch HD+ Super AMOLED cover screen and a 7.6-inch QXGA+ main screen, ideal for work and leisure. It transforms into a mini workstation, allowing for multi-tasking across various Microsoft Office apps. The Galaxy Z Fold2 is a great size for a tablet and can be used as a phone, making it suitable for both work and play. Its premium design and advanced features make it a desirable gift for gadget-crazy individuals.

site_title: MAS to further extend US$60b swap facility with US Fed
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has agreed to extend its US$60 billion swap facility with the US Federal Reserve through September 30, 2021. The facility, which also includes the MAS USD Facility, provides up to US$60 billion of funding to banks to support lending to businesses in Singapore and the region. The extension aims to promote stability in USD funding conditions and anchor market confidence. This is the second extension of the facility, with the first extension set to end on March 31, 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong sets new climate disclosure rules, aligns with global standard
summary: Hong Kong has set new climate disclosure rules, aligning with a global standard, requiring financial institutions and listed companies to disclose the financial impact of climate change on their businesses by 2025. The move aims to create a common framework for investors to make informed decisions. The Securities and Futures Commission, along with other regulatory bodies, has developed a plan to promote green initiatives and drive sustainable finance in Hong Kong, positioning the city as a global sustainable finance center. This move follows a global call for better climate-related disclosures.

site_title: Key exports for November down 4.9% in second monthly drop
summary: Singapore's key exports shrank by 4.9% in November, marking the second consecutive monthly decline. Weaker shipments of integrated circuits, petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and non-monetary gold contributed to the decline. Despite this, manufacturing is expected to remain in the black in 2020, with semiconductor production and exports likely to continue growing in 2021. Analysts attribute the decline to the still-fragile global trade recovery and structural shifts towards digitalisation and work-from-home trends.

images.alt_text: Enterprise Singapore singled out weaker shipments of products such as integrated circuits, petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and non-monetary gold.

site_title: Shareholder of EH-Reit's manager files appeal to finance minister against removal
summary: A shareholder of Eagle Hospitality Reit Management (EHRM) has filed an appeal to Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat against the directive to remove EHRM as the manager of EH-Reit, citing "meritorious grounds of appeal with reasonable chances of success". The directive was issued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on November 30 due to "numerous" breaches of the Securities and Futures Act and "serious concerns" over EHRM's ability to comply with rules and regulations. The shareholder, Mandarin West Holdings (MWH), has stressed that it has injected millions of dollars into the Reit.

site_title: Who should create your next job?
summary: As the job market evolves, more people are taking matters into their own hands, becoming self-employed and creating their own jobs. Traditional mentors and coaches are no longer the primary source of job creation, instead, individuals with expertise can become mentors-coaches, offering valuable guidance and support. The gig economy is on the rise, with fragmented services and minimum overheads creating opportunities for self-started businesses. With the development of new technologies and innovations, the need for personal gigs, such as coaches and sports trainers, is increasing, making it a viable career path for those willing to take the leap.

site_title: What will happen to Covid's lost generation?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has caused significant disruptions to the education and career prospects of young people, particularly in Singapore. The lost school year and recession have resulted in a slowdown in education and learning, potentially leading to long-term effects on earnings. Young people are facing challenges in graduating into a recession, and their social mobility may be affected. The crisis has also raised questions about what it means to be fair and good, and whether this will hold true in 2021.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The COMO Group is launching its Holiday Wishes Christmas campaign, where every S$1000 expenditure at its fashion, lifestyle, and restaurant outlets earns a chance to win one of 12 curated wishes. A S$10,000 spend gives 15 chances. The campaign also supports Life Stories, a charity partner, and donates a portion of the proceeds. Meanwhile, Hi5SG has created F&B Experience packs, offering festive bundles with vouchers redeemable at selected restaurants and bars, with a portion of the proceeds going to the =DREAMS program by the South Central Community Family Service Centre.

site_title: Walmart partners with TikTok to sell merchandise while live-streaming
summary: Walmart is partnering with TikTok to sell merchandise while live-streaming on the platform. The live-stream will feature popular brands and private labels, allowing viewers to shop directly from the app. This collaboration aims to tap into TikTok's 100 million US users. The event will take place on Walmart's TikTok profile page on Friday.

site_title: Surging investor interest sends bitcoin past US$23,000
summary: Bitcoin surged past $23,000, reaching a record high, driven by surging interest from larger investors. The cryptocurrency jumped 10.5% and has gained 220% this year, with investors attracted to its potential for quick gains and perceived inflation-hedging qualities. Despite its volatility, bitcoin remains less regulated than traditional assets, but institutional investors are shedding skepticism as market infrastructure improves. PayPal's opening of its network to cryptocurrencies has also contributed to the rally, with experts predicting wider adoption will drive up bitcoin's value.

site_title: Investors, prepare for these 2021 risks
summary: Investors in 2021 face challenges due to a widening gap between Wall Street and Main Street, partly caused by central banks' accommodative policies. The global economy remains uncertain, with the risk of "scarring" eroding long-term growth. A recovering economy amid rising inflationary expectations may offset the impact of corporate bankruptcies, making it harder for investors to navigate a liquidity-driven market. To mitigate risks, investors need analytical tools and a willingness to re-examine conventional wisdom, including a more diversified portfolio construct.

site_title: SGX set to roll out China-linked steel derivative
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is set to launch a China-linked steel derivative, the first of its kind, in the first quarter of 2021. The Shanghai rebar derivative will be based on prices with Mysteel, a widely used benchmark settlement price index for steel mills and traders. The move aims to capitalize on China's industrial rebound and green push, with steel being the most recycled and sustainable material. The launch precedes a decade of SGX's efforts to expand its offerings in the steel market, with iron ore and coking coal swaps already in place.

site_title: The vintage to drink or add to your collection
summary: A wine critic tasted over 2,000 wines from around the world in 2020, due to the pandemic, and narrowed it down to his top 10. His top picks include a rare Greek white wine ($23), a California blend of Rhône varieties ($45), a sweet Sauternes ($60), a Bordeaux grand cru ($149), and an Italian Barolo ($200). The list also features a Champagne ($1,195), a rare Tawny Port ($3,800), and a Burgundy Romanée-Conti ($15,500). The critic praised the wines for their quality, complexity, and emotional connections.

site_title: UOBKH initiates coverage of United Hampshire US Reit with 'buy' call
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on United Hampshire US Real Estate Investment Trust (United Hampshire US Reit) with a "buy" call and a target price of 92 US cents. Analysts cite the Reit's defensive strength, blue-chip tenants, and long weighted average lease expiry of 8.4 years, which provides a stable income stream. The Reit's essential service providers and self-storage facilities are seen as less sensitive to economic cycles, and analysts forecast a 2021 distribution per unit of 6.1 US cents.

site_title: 91,300 job openings available, most are for long-term PMET roles
summary: Singapore's job market has largely stabilized, with unemployment slowing since August, thanks to job support measures and the recovery from the virus fallout. There are over 123,000 job openings, mostly in long-term PMET roles, with the financial services sector having the highest number of openings. The government aims to strengthen the local workforce to overcome jobs and skills challenges, with initiatives such as the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package and reskilling programs for workers affected by digitalization shifts.

site_title: Robinhood to pay US$65m to end SEC probe into stock orders
summary: Robinhood Markets agreed to pay US$65 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission allegations that the broker failed to inform clients it sold their stock orders to high-frequency traders. The case involves disclosures from 2015 to 2018, but the company claims it has become fully transparent in its communications. Robinhood's chief legal officer stated that the settlement relates to historical practices and the firm is committed to continuing to evolve and meet customer needs. The company will also have an outside consultant monitor its compliance with best execution rules.

site_title: US housing starts up for a third-straight month in November
summary: US housing starts rose 1.2% in November to a 1.547 million annualized rate, exceeding forecasts and reaching a nine-month high. This marks the third-straight month of growth, supported by strong demand for new homes due to low interest rates and Americans seeking bigger spaces during the pandemic.

site_title: US jobless claims unexpectedly jump to highest in three months
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly rose to 885,000, the highest in three months, amid the surge in Covid-19 cases and widening business restrictions. Initial claims increased by 23,000, while continuing claims declined by 273,000. The data suggests a faltering labor market recovery, coinciding with the reference period for the December jobs report, which may show a weakening labor market. The Federal Reserve pledged to maintain its bond purchases until employment and inflation make substantial progress.

site_title: First hiccups seen in US push to deliver Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US is experiencing initial hiccups in its Covid-19 vaccine distribution, with 4 delivery trays of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine being pulled back due to being colder than expected. The vaccine requires storage at 70 degrees below zero Celsius, and officials are working to determine if it can still be used. The holdup affects 3,900 doses, enough to vaccinate 3,750 people. The US has also reduced its expected vaccine allocation for next week, from 2.9 million to 2 million doses.

site_title: Saudi Arabia begins inoculating with Pfizer vaccines
summary: Saudi Arabia has begun inoculating people with the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, becoming the first Arab country to roll out the jab. The country received two shipments of the vaccine and has set up over 550 inoculation stations. Health Minister Tawfiq al-Rabiah was among the first to receive the vaccine, stating it marks the start of relief to the crisis. The rollout includes those most exposed and vulnerable to the disease, with vaccination available for free to all citizens and residents.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on stimulus bets
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Thursday, driven by optimism over a coronavirus stimulus bill. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 61.46 points, or 0.20%, to 30,216.00. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 12.48 and 72.59 points, respectively. However, an unexpected rise in weekly jobless claims pointed to further economic stress from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Google waves US$1.5b DeepMind loan as costs mount
summary: Google has loaned DeepMind Technologies £1.1 billion (S$1.98 billion) as costs mount, waiving a £400 million loan from 2019. The UK-based AI lab's revenue jumped 158% in 2019 to £265.5 million, but losses widened to £476.6 million. Google's parent has agreed to continue funding DeepMind for at least a year. DeepMind's CEO aims to produce general-purpose intelligence, developing products like energy-efficient data centers and AI with broader applications.

site_title: European Parliament sets Sunday deadline for Brexit deal
summary: The European Parliament has set a Sunday deadline for the UK and EU to reach a post-Brexit trade deal, with the EU's assembly only able to ratify an accord before the transition period expires on December 31. Negotiators are battling over fishing rights, the final obstacle to an agreement. EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said it will be "difficult but possible" to reach an agreement by Friday, with the UK Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove stating parliament will be recalled from its Christmas vacation if needed to ratify any agreement.

site_title: Bank of England keeps stimulus on hold ahead of Brexit endgame
summary: The Bank of England maintained its stimulus programme at £895 billion, keeping its bond-buying programme and benchmark interest rate at historic lows of 0.1% amid Brexit negotiations with the EU. The decision was made as London and Brussels sought to avoid the impact of import tariffs on trade from January 1. The BoE's decision follows the UK's economic contraction for the second consecutive month, adding to the pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Boeing hires pilots for airlines to help relaunch 737 MAX, say sources
summary: Boeing is hiring up to 160 pilots to work with airlines on its 737 MAX aircraft, part of a bid to ensure a smooth comeback after a 20-month safety ban. The pilots will be embedded at airlines on 35-day assignments, earning an equivalent annual salary of up to $200,000. The move aims to rebuild trust and protect the plane from operational glitches, following crashes that killed 346 people. Boeing faces $20 billion in costs from the grounding and has already invested $1 billion in pilot recruitment and training.

site_title: Snowstorm blankets US east coast, threatening vaccine rollout
summary: A major snowstorm hit the US east coast, creating challenges in the midst of a coronavirus pandemic and a mass vaccination rollout. The storm, affecting millions, left over 60 million people under bad weather warnings, with snowfall rates reaching two inches per hour in some areas. Despite disruptions, officials and delivery companies prepared to ensure vaccine delivery schedules went ahead as planned, with some areas receiving over a foot of snow before Christmas. Airlines cancelled hundreds of flights, and schools closed, while restaurants shut down due to snow alerts.

site_title: New Sydney Covid-19 cluster gives Australians 'wake-up call'
summary: A growing Covid-19 cluster in Sydney, Australia's largest city, has prompted health officials to urge thousands of residents to stay home. The cluster, which started with five cases, has now reached 17, with officials tracing the source of the infection. Chief Health Officer Kerry Chant described the cases as a "wake-up call" to Sydneysiders, citing declining mask-wearing and complacency. Residents in affected suburbs have been told to stay home for three days, while health alerts have been issued for several venues with a confirmed case.

site_title: Japan plans record US$1.03t budget, struggles to contain virus, debt
summary: Japan plans a record $1.03 trillion budget for the next fiscal year, boosted by its coronavirus response and rising welfare and military spending. The proposed budget, to be endorsed by the Cabinet on Monday, aims to help the economy recover from its Covid-19-induced slump. With the country's public debt at twice its economy, Japan is struggling to contain the virus and proceed with fiscal reform. The budget plan includes new borrowing of a record $112 trillion and tax revenue estimates at around $57.5 trillion.

site_title: EU approves Google acquisition of Fitbit
summary: The European Union has approved Google's $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit, a smartwatch maker, after the tech giant agreed to conditions including not using health data from European users for advertising. The EU's competition chief, Margrethe Vestager, said the commitments would ensure the market for wearables and digital health remains open and competitive. Google had agreed to protect personal data and allow other manufacturers to access its Android operating system without degrading users' experience. The approval comes as Google faces growing scrutiny over privacy and competition concerns globally.

site_title: Singapore shares falter as macroeconomic uncertainty lingers, STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% to 2,858.02, driven by macroeconomic uncertainty, Brexit talks, and vaccine news. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) plummeted 4.9% year-on-year, contributing to bearish investor sentiment. The Federal Reserve maintained interest rates near zero to support the economy amid the COVID-19 surge. Only nine out of 30 STI stocks ended in the black, with Genting Singapore and the trio of lenders being the biggest decliners.

site_title: Saudi Arabia begins inoculating people with Pfizer Covid-19 vaccines
summary: Saudi Arabia has begun inoculating its citizens and residents with the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, becoming the first Arab country to roll out the jab. The vaccine was administered to Health Minister Tawfiq al-Rabiah, who expressed relief and hope for a decrease in cases. Saudi Arabia has reported 360,000 cases and 6,080 deaths since the pandemic began, but has avoided a new wave of infections. The country plans to vaccinate those most exposed and vulnerable first, with a wider rollout expected in the future.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media's public tranche of IPO 16 times subscribed
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holding Co received 16 times the number of shares in its public tranche of IPO, with 48.1 million shares subscribed under the Singapore public offer and 160.4 million shares subscribed for placement shares. The offering will raise S$121.7 million, with the company's market capitalisation at S$708.7 million post-placement. GHY plans to use the proceeds for expansion into TV program and film production, acquisitions, and strategic alliances.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.06 points lower at 1,674.35 on Thursday, with 9.235 billion lots traded worth RM4.333 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 790 to 445.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Q3 resident employment surged by 43,200, with the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) expressing "cautious optimism" despite uncertainty in the labour market. Non-oil exports dropped 4.9% in November, its second straight decline. MAS extended its US$60b swap facility with the US Federal Reserve. CBD rents are expected to fall to S$9.54 psf by end-2020.

images.alt_text: Singapore's resident employment staged a strong rebound in the third quarter of 2020, lifting resident employment levels to near pre-pandemic levels, Ministry of Manpower officials said on Thursday.

site_title: Hoe Leong appeals to strike out Malaysian civil suit for alleged deceit, fraudulent misrepresentation
summary: Hoe Leong Corp has appealed to strike out a Malaysian civil suit alleging deceit and fraudulent misrepresentation. The suit, filed by solicitor Halim Saad, seeks general damages against the company and five other defendants. The trial is set for October 2021. Shares in Hoe Leong remain suspended, last trading at S$0.002 in August 2020. The appeal comes after the Malaysian High Court dismissed the application to strike out the suit earlier in December.

site_title: Rethinking technology talent for digital transformation
summary: Singapore's technology talent gap is expected to widen as demand for tech talent outstrips supply, with a projected increase of 61,600 by 2021. However, companies can rethink their tech talent strategy by involving all employees in technology roles and providing opportunities for them to innovate and upskill. This includes providing training, mentorship, and resources to employees to develop digital talent in all, and creating space for breakout teams to innovate and transform the business.

site_title: Proposed acquisition of Tianjin Zhong Xin shares by controlling shareholder may be behind share price surge
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group's share price surged over 11% on Thursday, prompting a trading halt, amid speculation of a proposed acquisition of shares by its controlling shareholder, Tianjin Pharmaceutical Holdings. The controlling shareholder is contemplating an acquisition, but discussions are ongoing, and there's no assurance a definitive agreement will materialize. The company's share price rose to a high of US$1.10 before easing to US$1.05. Tianjin Pharmaceutical Holdings holds a 42.8% interest in Tianjin Zhong Xin, and the company is in the process of reforming its state-owned enterprise.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Thursday, following an advance across most of Asia. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.82%, and the Shanghai Composite Index rallied 1.13%. Optimism over a US economic stimulus package drove the gains. The benchmark indexes in Shenzhen and China's second exchange also rose.

site_title: UK's largest watch retailer lifts forecast as demand improves
summary: Watches of Switzerland Group, the UK's largest watch retailer, raised its revenue forecast to £900-925 million for the full year, driven by stronger-than-expected demand in the first half. The company attributes the improvement to increased demand, allowing it to conduct business better than others in the industry. Swiss watch exports slipped 3.2% last month, continuing a decline of 24% this year, but the upbeat outlook provides a glimmer of hope for the battered Swiss watch industry.

images.alt_text: Watches of Switzerland Group raised its revenue forecast after a stronger-than-expected first half, providing a glimmer of hope for the battered Swiss watch industry.

site_title: HK privatisation deals to pick up pace after hitting three-year high
summary: Hong Kong's privatization deals reached a three-year high in 2020, totaling US$22.5 billion and an annual record 54 transactions. Private equity firms and tycoons are expected to accelerate take-private deals in sectors with valuation dislocations amid the economic downturn caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and pro-democracy protests. Deals are expected to continue in 2021, driven by companies in sectors such as real estate, industrials, and consumer retail, which are among the worst performers in the Hong Kong stock market this year.

site_title: France's Macron has tested positive for Covid-19
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has tested positive for Covid-19, according to his office. He will isolate for the next seven days and continue to run the country remotely, cancelling all trips, including a visit to Lebanon on December 22. The cause of his infection is not yet clear. Despite this, Macron's office stated that he is in good health and will not be hospitalized.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.18% to 26,806.67 and the Topix index up 0.32% to 1,792.58. The gains were driven by hopes for stimulus policies globally, outweighing pressure from a stronger yen.

site_title: Top Toshiba investor calls for emergency meeting to investigate July AGM
summary: A top Toshiba investor, Effissimo Capital Management, has called for an emergency shareholders meeting to investigate the firm's July AGM, citing concerns over compromised voting rights. The meeting aims to determine if the AGM was conducted fairly and impartially. Toshiba had no immediate comment on the matter.

site_title: 24 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 24 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 58,377. This is the highest number of imported cases since March 28. The cases include 13 returning Singaporeans and Singapore permanent residents, four work pass holders, and five dependant's pass holders. No new community cases were reported, and 14 cases were discharged, leaving 33 patients in hospitals and 63 recuperating in community facilities.

images.alt_text: MOH reported 24 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, on Dec 17, 2020.

site_title: Rapid digital switch puts WPP on path to recovery
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, expects its net sales to return to pre-pandemic levels by 2022, a year earlier than expected, driven by the rapid shift to e-commerce and digital services. The company has been winning new work by helping clients build their e-commerce operations and has proved more resilient than expected. CEO Mark Read attributes the success to the company's strategy of offering digital expertise, data, and creativity, which has accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's shares are up 3.5% in early trading, reversing a 23% decline on the year.

site_title: US warns Pacific islands about Chinese bid for undersea cable project: sources
summary: The US has warned Pacific island nations, particularly Federated States of Micronesia (FSM) and Kiribati, about potential security threats posed by a Chinese company's bid to build an undersea internet cable project. The US is concerned about Huawei Marine, a company now majority-owned by another Chinese firm, due to its ties with Beijing's intelligence and security services. The US has expressed strategic concerns and warned FSM to ensure the project does not compromise regional security. The project, backed by the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, aims to improve communications to the island nations of Nauru, FSM, and Kiribati.

site_title: Taiwan says hopes to cut trade surplus after US currency move
summary: Taiwan hopes to reduce its trade surplus with the US after being added to a monitoring list by the US Treasury, citing concerns over the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate. The list, which has not labeled Taiwan a currency manipulator since 1992, reflects the international economic situation and the island's trade surplus with the US. Taiwan central bank deputy governor Yen Tzung-ta stated the goal is to cut the trade surplus, which reached $23 billion in 2019. The US decision comes as Taiwan's economy has benefited from global demand for high-tech goods during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo says Covid-19 strain on hospitals is severe, raises alert to highest
summary: Tokyo raises its alert level to the highest of four stages due to the severe strain on its medical system from the Covid-19 pandemic, with a record daily high of 822 cases reported. The city's hospitals are filling up, making it difficult to balance care for Covid-19 patients with regular ones. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government is urging a reduction in the number of Covid-19 patients to alleviate the pressure, as medical service providers exhaust all spare resources.

site_title: Europe: Shares up for fourth session on stimulus optimism
summary: European shares rose for a fourth consecutive session, driven by optimism over US stimulus and potential COVID-19 vaccine rollouts in Europe. Germany's DAX climbed 1.1% to its highest since February, while the STOXX 600 index rose 0.6%. The European Medicines Agency is set to approve Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine by the end of December. London's FTSE 100 also rose 0.4% ahead of the Bank of England meeting, where policy is expected to remain unchanged.

site_title: Gold holds near one-week high as US stimulus bets dent dollar
summary: Gold holds near a one-week high at US$1,863.89 per ounce due to the US dollar's decline amid progress on a fiscal stimulus deal and the Federal Reserve's pledge to keep rates low until an economic recovery is secure. The Fed's promise to continue bond-buying until substantial progress is made in restoring full employment and hitting its 2% inflation target also supported gold. However, the size of the stimulus package is expected to be limited, and gold's downward trend may continue.

site_title: Japan man probed over insults tied to Netflix star's suicide
summary: Japanese police have referred a man in his 20s to prosecutors over online insults directed at Hana Kimura, a reality TV star who took her own life in May. Kimura was a cast member on Netflix's Terrace House. The suspect's identity will not be disclosed until prosecutors decide on charges of public insult. This move comes after Kimura's death sparked widespread outrage and discussions about online abuse and mental health in Japan.

site_title: Bank Indonesia keeps key rates unchanged at final meeting of 2020
summary: Bank Indonesia kept its key interest rates unchanged at 3.75% on December 17, 2020, as expected, to support the pandemic-hit economy. This decision follows five rounds of rate cuts this year, totaling 125 basis points. The central bank held its 7-day reverse repurchase rate, deposit facility rate, and lending facility rate at 3.00% and 4.50% respectively. The move aims to soften the economic blow from the pandemic, with the rupiah under pressure in previous months.

site_title: Alibaba facial recognition tech specifically picks out Uighur minority: report
summary: Alibaba's facial recognition technology, available in its Cloud Shield content moderation service, can specifically identify members of China's Uighur minority, according to a report by US-based IPVM. The technology, which has been described as "glasses inspection" and "smile detection", can detect ethnic groups and, specifically, Uighurs. Alibaba has denied the feature's use, stating it was only tested in an environment, but the report raises concerns about China's alleged forced labor camps and complicity by firms. The technology's removal from the software shortly after the report's publication remains unexplained.

site_title: 'China does not honour its agreements,' US admiral says after meeting no-show
summary: US Admiral Phil Davidson criticized China for not attending virtual senior-level meetings on maritime safety, calling it "another example that China does not honour its agreements." The meetings, scheduled for Dec 14-16, were part of the Military Maritime Consultative Agreement (MMCA) focused on maritime safety. China's no-show has strained US-China ties, which have deteriorated over issues such as the coronavirus, Taiwan, and territorial claims in the South China Sea. The US military has long opposed China's expansive claims and has sent warships through the strategic waterway.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter reverse changes meant to curb vote misinformation
summary: Facebook and Twitter have reversed changes to their content policies aimed at curbing vote misinformation following the US presidential election. Twitter is reverting to one-click retweets after a 20% decrease in sharing, while Facebook is restoring its pre-election news source boost. The companies are doing so as election conspiracies are less of a threat, but they may soon face a public health information problem with the COVID-19 vaccines. Both platforms have policies in place to block or label misinformation about COVID-19 and vaccines.

site_title: Thai Nov domestic car sales rise for first time in 18 months
summary: Domestic car sales in Thailand rose for the first time in 18 months in November, increasing 2.7% to 79,177 vehicles, according to the Federation of Thai Industries. This growth was attributed to government stimulus measures, new car model launches, and marketing campaigns. Thailand remains a regional vehicle production and export base for top automobile manufacturers.

site_title: Singapore CBD rents to hit S$9.54 psf per month by end-2020: report
summary: Singapore's central business district (CBD) office rents are projected to reach S$9.54 per square foot (psf) per month by the end of 2020, a 10% decline from 2019's peak. Rents in city fringe and suburban offices are showing less decline, with a 1.5% and 1.6% decrease, respectively. Companies may resist capital expenditure due to the decline, but co-working will remain relevant for flexibility. Demand for city fringe and suburban markets is expected to remain healthy, driven by business continuity planning and the development of new supply in the CBD market.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Razer Fintech partners Rely to offer buy-now-pay-later services in South-east Asia
summary: Razer Fintech has partnered with Rely to offer buy-now-pay-later services in South-east Asia for merchants using Razer's Razer Merchant Services (RMS). The partnership allows RMS merchants to provide interest-free BNPL solutions to customers. This expansion follows Rely's recent announcement of expanding services in Singapore, Malaysia, and South Korea, which secured capital from Goldbell Financial Services to process up to S$100 million in transactions. The collaboration aims to meet the needs of digital-savvy youth and millennials in the region.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, Nomura say it's time to bet on Dubai tourism
summary: Dubai's tourism industry is expected to rebound, driven by the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines, improved relations with Israel and Qatar, and the rescheduled Expo 2020 exhibition. Morgan Stanley and Nomura Holdings predict a "bumper winter tourism season" in 2021, with Emaar Malls and Emaar Properties emerging as top picks in the UAE's equity market. However, some analysts, like Hasnain Malik, caution that the recovery will be "stuttering" and not all businesses will be able to weather the downturn.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near 10-month closing high on faster recovery projection
summary: Australian shares rose to a 10-month high, closing 1.2% higher at 6,756.70 on Thursday. The economy is expected to grow 4.5% in 2021, up from a previous estimate of 4.25%, driven by stronger November employment data and rising commodity demand. Heavyweight miners and financials led the gains, with tech stocks also reaching record levels. The rebound in the economy is seen as a sign that monetary and fiscal stimulus is working, with resource exports expected to rise 5% in 2021/22 despite rising tensions with China.

site_title: Hot stock: Tianjin Zhong Xin jumps 11.7%, gets SGX query
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group shares jumped 11.7% to an intraday high of US$1.10, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on its "unusual price movements". The company's third-quarter net profit grew 56% to 153.3 million yuan, driven by lower expenses and decreased losses. As of August, UOB Kay Hian has a "buy" recommendation with a target price of US$1.25. The SGX inquiry seeks explanations for the trading activity, including any information not previously announced.

site_title: Thai central bank sees no 'material impact' after added to US currency watch list
summary: Thailand's central bank said it does not foresee a significant impact on foreign trade and investment due to being added to the US currency watch list. The Bank of Thailand stated it conducts two-way intervention to manage currency volatility and has no intention to exploit exchange rates for unfair trade advantages. Assistant Governor Chantavarn Sucharitakul emphasized the bank's commitment to domestic stability and macroeconomic policies. The move was seen as a precautionary measure, but the bank remains confident in its ability to manage the economy.

site_title: WeDoctor close to raising US$350m ahead of IPO
summary: WeDoctor is close to raising $350 million ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The company is splitting its business into two parts, valuing its healthcare services operations at over $6 billion, and its sensitive data business at a lower value to comply with regulatory demands. The IPO, led by Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase, aims to raise $500 million to $1 billion, with the prospectus expected to be filed around the February Lunar New Year. The departure of chief financial officer John Cai has complicated the deal, but the company will continue to pursue the listing.

site_title: Winter Olympics prompts skiing construction boom in China
summary: China's construction of indoor ski resorts has surged nearly fourfold, fueled by the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, with the number of ski resorts increasing from over 200 to 770. The boom has also led to a significant increase in visitors, with nearly 21 million people visiting ski resorts last year. The growth is driven by China's swelling middle class and the country's ambition to put 10% of its population on skis ahead of the 2022 Games, doubling the global tally.

site_title: Nintendo and Sony shares hit records as peak holiday season approaches
summary: Nintendo shares rose 6.6% to a 13-year high, driven by demand for its Switch console ahead of the peak holiday season. Sony's shares also reached a record, surpassing the 10,000 yen per share mark for the first time since 2001, amid strong demand for its PlayStation 5 console. The gains come as investors anticipate increased sales during the holiday season.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as dealers track US stimulus, Brexit talks
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as investors tracked US stimulus progress and Brexit optimism, despite surging infections and lockdowns. US lawmakers made progress on a bipartisan stimulus package, with a possible vote on Capitol Hill at the weekend. The Federal Reserve held a policy meeting, pledging to maintain its bond-buying program. Brexit talks appeared to be heading in the right direction, with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen saying "the next days are going to be decisive".

site_title: Seoul: Shares end lower as pandemic woes outweigh US stimulus optimism
summary: South Korean shares ended lower due to ongoing pandemic woes, despite central bank policy support and US stimulus hopes. The country reported a record number of coronavirus deaths and daily infections, sparking panic buying and threatening the public health system. The benchmark Kospi closed 1.36 points down, 0.05% lower, at 2,770.43.

site_title: Google secretly gave Facebook perks, data in ad deal, US states allege
summary: US states allege that Google secretly gave Facebook preferential treatment and access to data in an ad deal, violating antitrust laws. The deal, made in 2018, allowed Facebook's advertiser clients to place ads within Google's network, generating revenue for both companies. Google allegedly gave Facebook preferential treatment, backing down from supporting competing software to dent Google's market power. In exchange, Facebook received access to Google data and policy exceptions, enabling its clients to unfairly get more ads placed. The US Department of Justice is investigating the agreement as part of its antitrust probe into Google.

site_title: Shareholder of EH-Reit's manager files appeal to finance minister against removal
summary: A shareholder of Eagle Hospitality Reit Management (EHRM) has filed an appeal to Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat against the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) directive to remove EHRM as the manager of Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-Reit) within a month. The shareholder, Mandarin West Holdings, claims meritorious grounds for the appeal and has stressed its significant contributions to the Reit. The MAS had previously directed DBS Trustee to appoint a new manager following numerous breaches of the Securities and Futures Act by EHRM.

site_title: Dubai wealth fund adds another builder in distress to its roster
summary: Dubai's Investment Corp of Dubai (ICD) has added Meydan, a state-owned developer, to its roster of property projects, aiming to improve efficiencies in operations. ICD, which also manages Nakheel PJSC, is reviewing Meydan's business strategy to slim down debts and improve viability. The review is part of a broader consolidation effort, with Meydan's real estate operations to be redesigned and certain projects suspended. ICD aims to reduce Meydan's debt by 40% by the end of the quarter, while maintaining its commitment to all liabilities.

site_title: US sets 24-hour records with over 3,700 Covid deaths, 250,000 new cases
summary: The US has set a grim double record, with over 3,700 Covid-19 deaths and more than 250,000 new cases in 24 hours, according to Johns Hopkins University. This marks the third time in a week the country has crossed the 3,000 deaths threshold, with 113,000 people currently hospitalized due to the virus. Experts fear the situation will worsen following end-of-year celebrations, including the Christmas holiday, as the US begins its mass vaccination program.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.56% gain, rising 148.15 points to 26,608.44, following a healthy lead from New York as US lawmakers near a new stimulus package agreement. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.29 points, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.10%.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on US stimulus hopes, gold stocks boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,708.5, driven by gains in gold miners such as Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources, which climbed 1.5% and 2.3% respectively. The increase was also attributed to expectations of a massive US stimulus bill, boosting broader risk sentiment.

site_title: As Brexit looms, British hauliers fear bumps in the road
summary: British hauliers are preparing for the Brexit transition period, which ends on December 31, 2020, with concerns about red tape, paperwork, and potential tariffs. Companies are stockpiling goods and investing in infrastructure, while the UK government is building lorry parks and introducing access permits. Haulage firms are struggling to adapt to new rules, with some companies having been turned down for international permits. The situation is expected to worsen on January 1, with long tailbacks at the Channel port of Dover and potential economic activity drops.

site_title: Australia's November jobs soar again in boost to economic recovery
summary: Australian jobs surged 90,000 in November, exceeding expectations and pushing the unemployment rate down to 6.8%. The data suggests the country's A$2 trillion economy is recovering well after the pandemic. Job losses recouped over 80% of the March drop, with Victoria state leading the gains. While the overall outcome exceeded forecasts, there are still 138,000 fewer employed people and 226,000 more people without a job. The Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary measures and the government's A$300 billion fiscal stimulus are paying off, analysts say.

site_title: Singaporean jobseekers filled 47,400 positions in April-October
summary: Singaporean jobseekers filled 47,400 positions from April to October under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, with the healthcare sector leading in job placements. The financial services sector has seen growth, with 5,200 available openings, mostly in long-term PMET jobs. To address disruption in the industry, the government and financial institutions are working together to reskill and redeploy workers into new roles, with 1,700 workers already completed. Overall, there are over 123,000 available job openings, with 91,300 in long-term PMET jobs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.18 points, or 0.01%, to 1,681.23. Volume was 347.32 million lots worth RM141.33 million. Gainers beat losers 281 to 153.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH initiates coverage on United Hampshire US Reit with 'buy'
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on United Hampshire US Reit with a "buy" call and a target price of 92 US cents. Analysts highlight the Reit's defensive strength, blue-chip tenants, and long weighted average lease expiry of 8.4 years. The Reit's essential service properties are less sensitive to economic cycles, and its self-storage facilities are expected to benefit from population outflow and increasing demand for self-storage space. A 2021F dividend per unit forecast of 6.1 US cents is also mentioned.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE initiates Keppel Reit, Suntec Reit with 'sell'
summary: Maybank KE has initiated "sell" on both Suntec Reit and Keppel Reit with target prices of S$1.20 and S$0.90 respectively. Analysts attribute the downgrade to Suntec Reit's slow retail recovery and rising office vacancy, while Keppel Reit faces weak leasing fundamentals and high gearing. The research team expects further downsizing by Keppel Reit's tenants and challenges in acquisition growth.

site_title: Keppel to build vessel in the US worth S$600m; more bondholders accede to Floatel lock-up
summary: Keppel Corporation is building a wind turbine installation vessel (WTIV) in the US worth S$600 million, scheduled for delivery in 2023. The vessel, named Charybdis, will be one of the largest offshore wind installation vessels in the world, accommodating up to 119 people. The vessel will support US wind projects exceeding five gigawatts of offshore wind construction through to 2027. Additionally, Keppel Corp announced that more bondholders have acceded to the lock-up agreement related to the proposed restructuring of Floatel, a 49.92%-owned unit of Keppel Corp.

site_title: Singapore's Q3 resident employment surges by 43,200; MOM now 'cautiously optimistic'
summary: Singapore's resident employment surged 43,200 to 2.34 million in Q3 2020, nearing pre-pandemic levels. Non-resident employment contracted by 72,300, leading to a total employment contraction of 29,100. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) expressed "cautious optimism" about the labour market, indicating a strong rebound. This growth is a welcome relief after a partial economic shutdown in the second quarter, with resident employment levels now just a notch below September 2019.

site_title: Bank of England set to wait for end to Brexit stand-off
summary: The Bank of England is expected to maintain its bond-buying program and keep its benchmark interest rate at a historic low of 0.1% due to the uncertainty surrounding a possible no-deal Brexit. The BoE aims to provide enough firepower until late 2021, with economists predicting a 2% hit to economic output, inflation, and unemployment if a deal is not struck. Despite this, the Bank is relatively calm about the outlook, citing ongoing Covid-19 vaccine administration and surveys suggesting a less severe economic contraction than predicted.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat despite US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on December 17, 2020, due to the yen's appreciation despite overnight US gains. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.08% and the Topix index declined 0.09%. This comes as investors weigh on hopes for fresh US stimulus.

site_title: Australia races to trace Covid-19 source after small cluster found in Sydney
summary: Australia is investigating a small cluster of new Covid-19 cases in Sydney, with two cases reported in the city's northern coastal suburbs. This marks the end of a nearly two-week run of zero cases. Authorities are urging residents to get tested if they have flu-like symptoms. The cases come as Australia has been easing social distancing curbs and opening internal borders, with just over 50 active cases in the country.

site_title: 30 to 60 hotels serve as SHN facilities at any point in time: STB
summary: Singapore's government has designated 30-60 hotels as stay-home notice (SHN) facilities, where guests returning from abroad must quarantine. The number of hotels used as SHN facilities depends on supply and demand. Naumi Hotel and Amara Singapore have been designated as SHN hotels, with Naumi's bookings cancelled and Amara's bookings halted until February. The government will continue to monitor the Covid-19 situation and adjust capacity accordingly, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announcing Phase 3 of domestic reopening starting December 28.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, DBS, Food Empire, Jumbo, BH Global, Keong Hong
summary: Keppel Corporation is building a wind turbine installation vessel under a S$600 million contract. DBS has launched Sustaintech Xcelerator, a six-month global virtual accelerator focused on boosting nature-based carbon credits. Food Empire Holdings' subsidiary Indus Coffee obtained US$7.2 million to expand its manufacturing facility in India. Jumbo Group completed the acquisition of a 75% stake in Kok Kee Wanton Noodle for S$2.1 million. BH Global Corporation's dormant subsidiary is being wound up, but the group expects to remain profitable. Keong Hong Holdings has a new substantial shareholder, LJHB Holdings (S), which acquired a 21% stake.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lalamove seeks funds at US$8b valuation
summary: Hong Kong-based logistics firm Lalamove is seeking a new funding round at a US$8 billion valuation, about four times its previous valuation of US$2 billion. The company aims to raise at least US$500 million, with potential for more depending on investor demand. Founded in 2013, Lalamove provides van-hailing and courier services on demand, operating in 24 markets across Asia, Latin America, and the US with over 700,000 driver partners. This fundraising comes amid a surge in demand for transportation and logistics services globally due to the e-commerce boom.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, falling 0.4% or 11.68 points to 2,861.12, following weaker-than-expected non-oil domestic exports (NODX) figures and mixed regional markets. NODX fell 4.9% year-over-year in November, worse than the median estimate of 0.3% growth. Local banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also traded lower. In contrast, Mapletree Industrial Trust rose 1.1% as the US stock market finished mostly higher overnight, with the Nasdaq setting a fresh record.

site_title: MAS to further extend US$60b swap facility with US Federal Reserve
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has agreed to extend its US$60 billion swap facility with the US Federal Reserve through September 30, 2021. The facility, which also includes the MAS USD Facility, aims to maintain stability in USD funding conditions and support businesses in Singapore and the region. The extension will provide up to US$60 billion in funding to banks, complementing the MAS's daily market operations to maintain ample liquidity in the banking system. This move is seen as a critical backstop for USD funding needs globally during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Transcorp to delist on Jan 8, 2021
summary: Transcorp Holdings will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on January 8, 2021, at 9am. The company received a notification from the SGX RegCo on December 8, 2020, and will withdraw shares held with the Central Depository (CDP) as of the delisting date. Shareholders will receive physical share certificates by ordinary mail. Transcorp, which used to be in the automobile sales business, was deemed a cash company in May 2020 and had its counter suspended since December last year. The company will not make an exit offer to remaining shareholders.

site_title: Global tech giants' moves in Singapore a boon to talent ecosystem
summary: Global tech giants, including Zoom and iQiyi, are expanding their presence in Singapore, driven by the city-state's favorable business environment, infrastructure, and neutrality in geopolitical matters. This influx of foreign investment is expected to boost the local tech ecosystem, but development of the local talent pool must keep pace to maximize benefits. Experts suggest that Singapore should focus on developing skilled talent in non-tech fields, such as public policy and legal functions, to complement the entry of foreign tech companies.

site_title: Pence to get Covid-19 vaccine on Friday: White House
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence and his wife Karen Pence will receive the Covid-19 vaccine on Friday in a public display to boost national confidence. The event is part of a mass vaccination programme aimed at stopping the surging pandemic, which has already killed over 300,000 Americans. The White House hopes the public display will promote the safety and efficacy of the vaccine.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Mike Pence and his wife will get the Covid-19 vaccine on Friday in a public display designed to boost national confidence, the White House announced on Wednesday.

site_title: Former Swiss president Cotti dies, reportedly from Covid-19
summary: Former Swiss President Flavio Cotti, 81, has died reportedly due to complications from coronavirus. Cotti, who served as foreign and interior minister, passed away at an undisclosed location. Current Swiss Foreign Minister Ignazio Cassis expressed sadness over Cotti's death, stating his "political spirit will always be present in the foreign ministry." Cotti's death comes as Switzerland navigates the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Former Swiss president Flavio Cotti, who also served as the country's foreign and interior minister, has died at the age of 81 reportedly from coronavirus.

site_title: Twitter cracks down on false posts about Covid-19 vaccines
summary: Twitter has announced it will crack down on false posts about Covid-19 vaccines starting next week, following Facebook and YouTube. The platform will prioritize removing the most harmful misleading information and label tweets with potentially misleading vaccine information. This move aims to combat misinformation and protect public health.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports drop for second straight month in November with 4.9% fall
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports dropped 4.9% year-on-year in November, the second consecutive month of decline, according to Enterprise Singapore. Shipments in the electronics cluster fell 3.8% and non-electronics exports shrank 5.2%. Petrochemicals exports declined 18.5% and pharmaceuticals lost 13.4%. The decline was attributed to subdued demand and weaker-than-expected electronics and pharmaceuticals. Total trade decreased 8.7% year-on-year, with exports to emerging markets easing from the previous month's 12.1% fall.

site_title: Japan Post insurer plans 300b yen buyback from parent
summary: Japan Post Insurance, a unit of Japan Post Holdings, plans to buy back about 300 billion yen (S$3.85 billion) of shares from its parent, aiming to expand its business and rebuild after a sales scandal. The holding company will sell some shares to reduce its stake to 50% or less, allowing the insurer to develop new products and fit customer needs. The move is part of efforts to ease Japan Post Insurance's strict privatisation law restrictions. The insurer's shares jumped 8.9% following the announcement, with the stock rising about 10% this year.

site_title: New Zealand's virus recession ends with record growth
summary: New Zealand's economy has rebounded from a coronavirus-induced recession, posting record growth of 14.0% in the July-September quarter. The country's strong containment of the virus, with only 25 deaths among a population of five million, has contributed to the recovery. The finance minister attributed the growth to the government's support for workers and investments in infrastructure and jobs. Service industries drove the growth, with retail, accommodation, and restaurants seeing significant increases, while the international education and tourism sectors continue to struggle.

site_title: Tokopedia picks Morgan Stanley, Citi to manage debut listing
summary: Indonesia's e-commerce giant Tokopedia has hired Morgan Stanley and Citigroup as advisers to help accelerate its plan to go public. The company is considering a potential merger with Bridgetown Holdings, a blank-check company backed by billionaires Richard Li and Peter Thiel, which could value Tokopedia at $8-10 billion. A sale to a SPAC would be a speedier way to list in the US, but Tokopedia's co-founder William Tanuwijaya has expressed preference for a dual listing to allow Indonesian employees and consumers to own shares.

site_title: Congress nears US spending deal, Federal Reserve more upbeat on outlook
summary: US Congressional leaders are nearing a deal on a stimulus package to aid the economy amid the COVID-19 resurgence, with a smaller package expected to include direct payments to taxpayers and relief for struggling businesses. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed optimism, stating the economic outlook remains uncertain but noting a strong case for fiscal policy. The package is seen as essential to get the world's largest economy back on its feet, with new vaccines offering hope for a strong rebound in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Congressional leaders on Wednesday said they were nearing a long-awaited agreement on a stimulus package for the US economy as the Federal Reserve cautioned that the economic outlook remains uncertain.
