site_title: Lower- and middle-income workers still in hardship can tap new grant
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Social and Family Development is rolling out a new Covid-19 Recovery Grant (CRG) for lower- and middle-income workers facing financial hardship due to the pandemic. Eligible workers can receive up to S$700 a month for three months if retrenched or on involuntary no-pay leave, and up to S$500 a month for three months if facing a 50% salary loss. The grant application period is from Jan 18, 2021, to Dec 31, 2021, with online applications available via go.gov.sg/CRG.

site_title: Germany sees record death toll on first day of new lockdown
summary: Germany reported a record 952 Covid-19 deaths on the first day of a new partial lockdown, with 27,728 new cases registered. The lockdown, which includes school and shop closures until January 10, aims to halt the surge in infections. Hospitals are struggling with 83% occupancy of critical care beds. Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed concern over the situation, stating the vaccine will help but the pandemic's evolution remains unpredictable. Containment measures are expected to continue until Easter, with vaccinations set to begin on December 27.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly higher on stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a stimulus package and a dovish Federal Reserve announcement. The Nasdaq set a fresh record, closing at 12,658.19, while the Dow Jones shed 0.2% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.2%. Congressional leaders said they were nearing a long-awaited agreement on a stimulus package, helping to offset disappointment over November retail sales. The Fed maintained ultra-low interest rates and upgraded its growth forecast for 2021 and 2022.

site_title: Euro rises to highest in more than two years
summary: The euro has risen to its highest level in over two years, surpassing US$1.22 against the US dollar, driven by strong eurozone survey figures and progress in Brexit negotiations. The euro has gained nearly 13% since the European Union announced a recovery fund in May. Expectations of Europe outperforming the US in the coming months have also boosted the euro, with investors keeping an eye on the outcome of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. The euro's rise is seen as a positive sign for risk appetite in the currency markets.

site_title: Moody's holds Indonesia's credit ratings steady
summary: Moody's has maintained Indonesia's credit rating at steady, citing a stable growth outlook despite the country's economic contraction due to the pandemic. The agency expects a 2% contraction this year, followed by a 4.7% rebound in 2021. Rising debt and stagnant productivity growth pose challenges, but Indonesia's debt burden is within the median average of Baa2-rated sovereigns. Moody's also notes that the government's ability to manage institutional risks and improve productivity will be crucial for sustained GDP growth.

site_title: Luckin Coffee to pay US$180m penalty to settle accounting fraud charges: US SEC
summary: Luckin Coffee Inc has agreed to pay a US$180 million penalty to settle accounting fraud charges for intentionally overstating 2019 revenue and understating a net loss. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) found that the China-based coffee chain fabricated much of its 2019 sales, sending its shares plummeting. Luckin has not admitted or denied the charges, but has agreed to pay the penalty, which may be offset by payments to security holders. The company is also subject to approval by Chinese authorities for transferring funds.

images.alt_text: Luckin Coffee Inc has agreed to pay a US$180 million penalty to settle accounting fraud charges for "intentionally and materially" overstating its 2019 revenue and understating a net loss, US regulators said on Wednesday.

site_title: Chinese craft carrying Moon rocks returns to Earth: Xinhua
summary: A Chinese unmanned spacecraft, Chang'e-5, successfully returned to Earth with Moon rocks and soil, marking the first mission in four decades to collect lunar samples. The capsule landed in northern China's Inner Mongolia region, and the China National Space Administration declared the mission a success. The return of the samples marks a significant achievement for China's space program, following years of advancements in lunar exploration.

site_title: Oil prices rise on vaccine optimism, weaker dollar
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, driven by a weakening dollar and progress on COVID-19 vaccine rollouts. Brent crude futures increased 25 cents to $51.01 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 21 cents to $47.83. However, gains were capped by a surprise increase in US crude inventories and tighter lockdowns in Europe. Analysts attributed the market's optimism to vaccine approvals, with the US FDA expected to approve Moderna's vaccine this week. The International Energy Agency warned that oil demand will not be reversed quickly due to the pandemic.

site_title: America's zombie companies rack up US$2t of debt
summary: The US has seen over 200 companies, nearly a quarter of its largest publicly-traded firms, become "zombie companies" due to struggling to cover interest expenses. These companies, including Boeing, Carnival, and Delta, have added nearly $1 trillion to their debt, bringing total obligations to $1.98 trillion. Economists warn that zombie firms can limit economic recovery and depress employment and growth. While some argue the problem is being over-hyped, others see it as a concern for long-term economic performance, with some firms experiencing prolonged weakness in productivity and growth after exiting zombie status.

site_title: Brexit trade talks to continue for 'coming days', UK PM's office says
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's office says Brexit trade talks with the European Union will continue over the coming days, potentially requiring a recall of British lawmakers as early as next week to legislate for a deal. Parliament will begin its Christmas break on Thursday, but if an agreement is reached, lawmakers will be called back to finalize the legislation within 48 hours' notice.

site_title: Cathay Pacific expects H2 loss to be 'significantly higher' than H1
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects a "significantly higher" second-half loss than its record first-half loss of HK$9.87 billion, driven by low demand, restructuring charges, and impairments on its fleet. The airline reported a 98.6% fall in passenger numbers in November and expects to operate about 9% of pre-Covid-19 capacity in December. Cathay plans to operate less than 50% of its normal passenger capacity in 2021, but forecasts a possible recovery in the second half as Covid-19 vaccines are rolled out.

site_title: STI tracks Wall Street gains to close 0.6% higher
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% to close at a record high, tracking gains on Wall Street amid optimism over stimulus and vaccine chatter. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices gained 1.1% and 1.3%, respectively. However, experts warn of caution due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, with the risk of extended lockdowns and herd immunity still uncertain, potentially bridging a gap between now and mid-2021.

site_title: Strong virus response helps Vietnam's economy weather pandemic
summary: Vietnam's economy weathered the 2020 pandemic with a strong response, surging exports, and healthy public spending, resulting in one of the highest growth rates in the world. Analysts predict this growth will continue. However, the tourism industry and aviation sector remain affected by containment measures and border disruptions. Despite these challenges, Vietnam's economic recovery is on track, outperforming global trends.

site_title: ECB lifts ban on bank dividends, capping payout at 15 per cent of profit
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lifted its ban on bank dividends, but imposed strict limits on payout levels to 15% of 2019 and 2020 profits, or 0.2% of key capital ratio. This is more conservative than the Bank of England's 25% limit. Regulators remain concerned about banks' financial strength during the pandemic and want to ensure they have sufficient reserves to bear losses without taxpayer bailouts.

site_title: Boeing hires pilots for airlines to help relaunch 737 MAX: sources
summary: Boeing is hiring up to 160 pilots to be embedded at airlines on 35-day assignments, starting at a potential annual salary of $200,000. This move aims to ensure a smooth comeback for the 737 MAX after a 20-month safety ban, following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia that killed 346 people. The Global Engagement Pilots will act as instructors or cockpit observers to rebuild trust and prevent operational glitches. The total potential cost for this campaign is estimated to be $32 million.

site_title: Europe: Upbeat business activity, vaccine hopes lift shares
summary: European shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by strong business activity data and hopes for a Brexit trade deal. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index climbed 0.8% to a near 10-month peak, with Germany's economy showing strong growth despite a stricter lockdown. A European Commission official hinted at possible approval for the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine as early as December 23, boosting sentiment.

site_title: Slight uptick in business confidence for another quarter: SCCB
summary: Singapore's business confidence index saw a slight uptick in the first quarter of 2021, improving to -1.03 percentage points from -4.97 percentage points in the previous quarter. The index remains in the contractionary zone, indicating ongoing economic challenges. The financial and manufacturing sectors showed optimism, while the agriculture and construction sectors were downbeat. The services sector was moderately upbeat, with half of its indicators in positive territory. The overall economy is expected to remain volatile for the first six months of 2021, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB).

site_title: BP acquires majority stake in largest US carbon offset developer
summary: BP has acquired a majority stake in Finite Carbon, the largest US carbon offset developer, as part of its climate goals and to develop a new revenue stream. Finite Carbon generates carbon offset credits by paying landowners to manage forests, with a goal of generating $1 billion for landowners over the next 10 years. The acquisition brings Finite Carbon into BP's Launchpad division, which focuses on low-carbon technologies. The deal aims to expand Finite's reach into other countries and digitize carbon reporting processes.

site_title: Oil prices edge higher after US crude stockpile draw
summary: US oil prices edged higher on Wednesday, driven by a 3.1 million-barrel drop in crude inventories and optimism over a coronavirus relief package. Brent crude futures rose 32 cents to $51.08 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 20 cents to $47.82 a barrel. The stronger-than-expected inventory drop was a surprise to analysts, who had forecast a 1.9 million-barrel decline. The relief package is seen as a positive factor for the oil market, as it could boost demand and prices.

site_title: Nov condo, HDB rental volumes up despite travel curbs
summary: In November, rental volumes for condominiums and HDB flats in Singapore rose 3.8% and 6.7% month-on-month, respectively. Condo rental units increased to 4,443 units, while HDB flats reached 1,762 units. Year-over-year, private leasing is 1.1% higher, while HDB leasing is down 11.7%. Experts attribute the increase to newly married young couples renting HDB flats or private condos before their permanent homes are completed. Rents for condo units edged up 0.5% month-on-month, while HDB flat rents remained unchanged.

site_title: Switzerland ready to meet US for talks over currency manipulator label
summary: Switzerland is open to bilateral talks with the US Treasury Department after being labelled a currency manipulator. The Swiss government maintains it did not engage in manipulation and seeks to have its situation carefully analysed. Switzerland is confident in its economy's characteristics and competitiveness. No action has been taken to address the US concerns, but talks are seen as a positive step towards resolving the issue.

site_title: Oslo tests greener 'zero-emissions' building sites
summary: Oslo has tested a nearly "zero-emissions" building site, utilizing electric machinery to create a pedestrian area in the city center. The project aims to reduce climate change, air pollution, and noise. Completed in time for Christmas, the site showcases the potential for greener construction as urban areas continue to grow. This initiative could serve as a pioneer for sustainable building practices, particularly in urban areas experiencing rapid growth.

site_title: More Covid-19 support for businesses on Budget wish list
summary: The Singapore Business Federation and PwC Singapore have called for the government to extend or enhance Covid-19 business support measures ahead of the February Budget. These measures include more support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and companies looking to digitalize. The proposals come as the country navigates the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: US airlines in line for US$17 billion in pandemic relief package
summary: US airlines could receive $17 billion in government aid to recall furloughed workers and cover payrolls through March, according to a bipartisan pandemic relief package. Airlines for America, a trade group, has expressed enthusiastic support for the proposal, which would help carriers bring back workers who have been laid off due to the pandemic. The proposal comes as Congress is discussing a crucial government spending package, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi urging top leaders to meet to discuss Covid-19 relief.

site_title: Key oil market themes to watch out for in 2021
summary: Oil demand is expected to grow in 2021, driven by China and India, with Asia leading the way, accounting for 70% of the growth. However, Iranian oil could complicate OPEC+ supply management, as the US may ease sanctions and allow Iranian oil exports to increase. The pandemic has accelerated the energy transition, with China, Japan, and South Korea setting carbon neutrality goals. Global electric vehicle sales surged in 2020, and EVs are expected to reach 20% of new car sales in China by 2025 and 50% by 2035. Oil demand is expected to peak in about 20 years, according to Opec.

site_title: Central banks preach green but decisive actions yet to come
summary: Global central banks are voicing support for climate change efforts but few are taking decisive action to adjust their monetary policies to support a sustainable financial system. A survey by the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) found that most central banks see scope to adjust their strategies but are hesitant due to potential financial distortions. Only a minority have introduced measures to mitigate climate risks, and cross-border cooperation is lacking. Central banks have made progress in adopting sustainable investment practices, but more concrete actions are needed to address the climate crisis.

site_title: Vaccines a shot of hope to all for 2021, but recovery will vary
summary: The COVID-19 vaccine rollout brings hope for a better 2021, with stock markets optimistic about a recovery to pre-crisis economic levels by mid-to-late next year. The global economy's growth will depend on easing lockdown restrictions, successful vaccination, and international travel resuming. Economic recoveries are expected to vary by region, with countries like Singapore, Vietnam, and Indonesia leading the way, while others, such as Thailand and the Philippines, will recover at a slower pace. Rich countries must work with poor countries to strengthen pandemic response plans and build a better society.

site_title: Sweeping revamp creates new Vietnam bourse with more powers to watchdog
summary: Vietnam is introducing a new, single bourse, the Vietnam Stock Exchange (VSE), replacing the existing Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange (HOSE) and Hanoi Stock Exchange (HNX) starting January 1, 2021. The new bourse will have more powers to oversee and regulate the market, giving the State Securities Commission (SSC) greater independence from the Ministry of Finance. The VSE will also have wider authority to supervise and deal with market violations. The move aims to boost the stock market, increase efficiency, and attract more investors.

site_title: It's time for the digital transformation of hospitals to speed up
summary: Healthcare infrastructure is slow to adopt digital transformation, hindering its ability to respond to crises like the COVID-19 pandemic. To address this, several steps can be taken, including consolidating data, breaking down information silos, and implementing real-time data capture. Tracking healthcare assets, standardizing protocols for maintenance, and adopting cloud-enabled management can also improve productivity and support vital decision-making. Additionally, leveraging AI/ML can enable self-correcting equipment, predictive maintenance, and more efficient business models. A true digital transformation of healthcare infrastructure is necessary to prepare for future crises.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Food Empire Holdings' INDUS Coffee secured $7.2 million to expand its Indian manufacturing facility. KrisEnergy's Vietnam offshore farm-out deal was delayed until March 31, 2021. Keong Hong Holdings gained a 21% stake with a $49.4 million acquisition. Mirach Energy is winding up the company due to uncertainty over an exit offer. BH Global Corporation's dormant subsidiary is being wound up, expected to impact earnings. Jumbo Group completed its acquisition of a 75% interest in a popular dumpling noodle stall for $2.1 million.

site_title: Rising ESG focus sees launch of another green Reit index
summary: A new green Reit index has been launched by Solactive and CarbonCare, covering 49 Asia-Pacific constituents, including 8 Singapore Reits. The index assesses Reits based on their carbon emission targets and green building certifications. Japan-listed Reits comprise half of the constituents. The index aims to provide a reference for investors integrating sustainability factors into their investment strategies and mandates, with a positive correlation between greenness and performance observed in Europe and the US.

site_title: SME lender Funding Societies doubles valuation in Samsung-backed round
summary: Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer lending platform, has secured funding from Samsung Venture Investment Corporation in a round that doubled its valuation to about two times its Series B post-money valuation in 2018. The round included new backers SGInnovate, BRI Ventures, and Endeavor, and existing backers Sequoia India, Softbank Ventures Asia Corp, and Qualgro Partners. The funds will primarily be channelled towards Funding Societies' tech arm, FS Technologies, to expand its technology team across the region.

site_title: Home for Christmas, with plenty to do
summary: A Singaporean publication provides ideas for a festive stay-home Christmas, including virtual Christmas markets and local tours. The article also lists gift suggestions, including items that support communities in need, and recommends Christmas dinner options and a new Sri Lankan restaurant. In a separate section, luxury watch brands celebrate various events and milestones, such as Vacheron Constantin's 270th anniversary and Bvlgari's stellar year in the luxury market.

site_title: China's top chipmaker plunges after co-CEO quits
summary: China's top chipmaker, SMIC, plummeted nearly 10% after co-CEO Liang Mong Song resigned amid a power struggle following the appointment of a new vice-chairman. Liang had led the company's technology development and played a crucial role in its rapid growth, but analysts predict a setback in technology progress without his leadership. SMIC's market value has doubled in 2020, driven by demand for chips as China's economy recovers, but the company faces US sanctions and is seen as a national security threat by Washington, threatening its ambitions to build a world-class semiconductor industry.

site_title: Public service for a new era
summary: Singapore's public sector has accelerated innovation and digital transformation in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, leveraging technologies such as the SafeEntry system and TraceTogether for contact tracing. The government has prioritized creating flexible governance and service delivery models, with a focus on hybrid working and digital services. To achieve this, public agencies must reconfigure human work structures and review their roles and impact on service delivery. A culture of innovation, collaboration, and adaptability is essential, driven by empowered leadership and a customer-centered view of service delivery.

site_title: Modular construction meets changing needs in pandemic
summary: Modular construction has gained popularity during the pandemic, offering faster and greener alternatives to traditional construction methods. The method involves manufacturing components in a factory and assembling them on-site, reducing waste and carbon footprint. Modular construction can speed up construction by up to 50% and cut costs by 20%. Major companies, such as Marriott and Chick-fil-A, have adopted modular construction for hotels and restaurants. The industry faces challenges, including financing difficulties and labor shortages, but experts say it offers higher quality, cost certainty, and schedule certainty.

images.alt_text: A Covid-19 virus testing centre on the University of Denver campus that is built using modular construction techniques. It was constructed in 10 days in a factory in Bakersfield, and took one day to set up.

site_title: Singapore's hawker culture added to Unesco list of intangible cultural heritage
summary: Singapore's hawker culture has been officially added to the Unesco Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, marking the country's first item on the list with 463 existing entries. The recognition comes after a 24-member committee unanimously accepted Singapore's application. The decision aims to protect and promote the country's living heritage and multiculturalism, with the government pledging to safeguard and transmit hawker culture to future generations.

site_title: Online retailer Wish prices its IPO at the top end of a marketed range
summary: Online retailer Wish priced its initial public offering (IPO) at the top end of its marketed range, raising $1.1 billion and valuing the company at $17 billion. This is the 31st US listing to exceed $1 billion this year, following successful debuts by DoorDash and Airbnb. Wish's shares were sold at $24 each.

site_title: Busiest US seaport buried in imports
summary: The Port of Los Angeles reported a 25% surge in imports during November, with cargo swamping docks ahead of Christmas. The port is experiencing a "triage situation" with toy makers relying on expedited shipments to meet holiday demand. Congestion is causing delays, with 80% of arriving vessels waiting an average of four days. This is particularly challenging for the toy industry, with some shipments delayed by up to a month, impacting the Christmas season. The port is working to clear cargo, with executives helping to expedite toy shipments daily.

site_title: China's Fosun Pharma to import 100 million BioNTech vaccine doses
summary: China's Fosun Pharma agrees to import at least 100 million doses of BioNTech's COVID-19 vaccine, subject to Beijing's approval. The deal includes an initial payment of 125 million euros (S$203 million) for 50 million doses, with the remaining 50 million doses to be paid after authorization to commercialize the vaccine in mainland China. This partnership aims to ensure an adequate supply of vaccines in China, which has been rapidly developing its own vaccine candidates and partnering with foreign developers to supply the country.

site_title: Thiel-backed Bridgetown eyes merger with Tokopedia
summary: Bridgetown Holdings Ltd, backed by Peter Thiel and Richard Li, is exploring a potential merger with Indonesia's e-commerce giant Tokopedia. The special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) is assessing the feasibility and structure of the deal with Tokopedia, one of the most valuable startups in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Credit Suisse cuts asset management headcount by 10%
summary: Credit Suisse Group cut 10% of its staff at its asset management business, impacting 110 employees, as it seeks to turn around a unit hit by fund implosions and scandals. The unit oversees $659 billion in assets and aims to add $10 billion in net new assets in higher-fee alternatives and private markets offerings over the next two to three years. The cuts follow recent closures of investment vehicles, a quantitative strategy, and a 24 million franc charge on seed capital for a US real estate vehicle.

site_title: Indonesia to offer free vaccines; Joko first in line
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has announced plans to offer free Covid-19 vaccines to the public. The decision was made after reallocation of funds from other state budget matters. This move comes as Indonesia considers its response to the ongoing pandemic. The President's order instructs the finance minister to redirect funds to support the free vaccine program.

site_title: Ant conducting 'self-review' after US$35b IPO collapses
summary: Ant Group chairman Eric Jing has apologized for the company's collapse after its $35 billion IPO, attributing it to "shortcomings" and a "body check-up." The company is conducting a self-review to "properly manage" issues, including regulatory hurdles. This marks a drastic shift from co-founder Jack Ma's recent criticism of Chinese regulators, which led to the IPO's unraveling. Ant is studying China's 14th Five-Year Plan and policy insights into financial security and stability. The company's chances of reviving the IPO are slim, with regulatory challenges including capital and licensing requirements.

images.alt_text: Mr Jing seen on a giant screen at a fintech conference in Shanghai in September. Ant is striving to "properly manage" issues related to the IPO suspension, he says.

site_title: To the moon and back, Chinese R&D is leaving the US behind
summary: Chinese research and development investments have surpassed those of the US, with China spending around $350 billion on R&D since its "Made in China 2025" plan in 2016, compared to the US's $200 billion. China has also achieved significant milestones, including landing a spacecraft on the moon and returning lunar materials for research. In contrast, the US has seen a decline in federal R&D spending, with NASA spending decreasing by over half since the 1970s. China's investments are seen as a response to the US's waning investment in ideas, with China now "rapidly closing the innovation gap" with the US.

site_title: Honda recalling 1.79 million vehicles globally for safety issues
summary: Honda is recalling 1.79 million vehicles globally due to safety issues, including fires, corrosion, and software problems. The US is affected by three recalls, covering 1.4 million vehicles, including the 2002-2006 CR-V, 2018-2020 Accord and Insight, and 2012-2015 Civic Hybrid and Fit. No reported injuries have occurred, but 16 fires and 16 incidents of corrosion-related damage have been reported. Repair parts may not be available for some vehicles.

site_title: Jurong Port in talks for Lim family's terminal stake
summary: Jurong Port is in advanced talks to buy a 40% stake in Universal Terminal, a petroleum storage hub, from the Lim family behind collapsed oil trader Hin Leong Trading Pte. The deal would help monetize one of the Lim family's biggest assets amid allegations of fraud. The sale needs approval from Hin Leong's creditors, and it's unclear if other bidders are still competing for the stake. Universal Terminal, valued at $750 million, offers 2.33 million cubic meters of storage capacity and is one of the largest independent petroleum-products storage facilities in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: SGX RegCo to align listing rules with Singapore's push for restructuring hub
summary: SGX Regulation (SGX RegCo) plans to review its listing rules to align with Singapore's restructuring hub ambitions, following the passage of the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act (IRDA) in July 2020. The review aims to complement the IRDA in three areas: disclosures, shareholder approval, and listing rules written with a going-concern premise. The review will also focus on corporate surveillance, sustainability, and whistleblower intelligence gathering. SGX RegCo will work to enhance market transparency and protect shareholders, particularly in cases of financial distress and concentration risks in real estate investment trusts (Reits).

site_title: Empty hotels find new life as governments house the homeless
summary: The US government has turned to hotels to house the homeless during the pandemic, with local governments spending billions of dollars to convert properties into long-term housing. This effort has helped the lodging industry, which saw a decline in bookings. Cities such as Seattle and California have implemented programs to purchase hotels and convert them into housing, with some owners receiving high prices for their properties. The strategy is being hailed by homeless advocates as a cost-effective and faster way to provide homes, despite criticism from local residents.

site_title: Strengthening the pillars of Singapore's global media hub
summary: Singapore aims to strengthen its position as a global media hub by investing in infrastructure and capability development. However, the country must also ensure its intellectual property protections remain state-of-the-art to support this goal. Despite its strong IP protections, piracy remains a significant issue, with 17% of Singapore consumers accessing streaming piracy websites and 10% using illicit streaming devices. The government is considering legislative measures, such as judicial site-blocking and digital watermarking, to combat piracy and protect content owners' rights, which could help maintain Singapore's leadership as a global media hub.

site_title: Keppel launches second data centre fund with first close of over US$500m
summary: Keppel's asset management arm has launched its second data centre fund, Keppel Data Centre Fund II, with a first close of over US$500 million. The fund targets a size of US$1 billion and will focus on strategic investments in the Asia-Pacific and Europe data centre sector. The fund will leverage Keppel Data Centres Holdings' expertise in developing, operating, and maintaining data centres, with a focus on sustainability and reducing carbon emissions. The move comes as the data centre sector has seen accelerated growth due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US Congress 'closing in' on US$900b Covid-19 aid package
summary: US congressional negotiators are closing in on a $900 billion Covid-19 aid package, which includes stimulus talks, extended unemployment benefits, and aid to state and local governments. The deal is expected to address the pandemic's economic toll, but direct payments to individuals and new protections for companies and universities are still uncertain. Congressional leaders, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, expressed optimism about the deal, which comes as the US economy weakens after an initial rebound from the pandemic.

site_title: Al-Futtaim sells Royal Sporting House to Gulf Marketing Group
summary: Al-Futtaim, the parent company of department store operator Robinsons, has sold Royal Sporting House to Gulf Marketing Group (GMG) for an undisclosed deal value. The acquisition includes operations in Southeast Asia and Hong Kong, and will nearly double GMG's presence across 12 countries. GMG aims to build on Royal Sporting House's existing strengths and brand equity, and will explore ways to improve operations and offerings. The deal may be a sign of Al-Futtaim further downsizing its portfolio amid competition from e-commerce and other physical retailers.

site_title: Malaysia invokes emergency to stop by-elections as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Malaysia's government has declared a state of emergency to stop by-elections in two constituencies due to a surge in COVID-19 cases. The emergency was imposed in the Bugaya constituency in Sabah and Gerik constituency in Perak state. As of Tuesday, Malaysia has reported over 86,000 cases and 422 deaths. The move aims to prevent disruptions during the pandemic.

site_title: Australia ups ante in China trade row with WTO challenge on barley tariffs
summary: Australia has filed a formal appeal to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over China's decision to impose 80.5% tariffs on Australian barley imports, effectively halting a billion-dollar trade. The appeal, made by Trade Minister Simon Birmingham, comes after China imposed anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties in May. The move threatens to further strain bilateral relations, which have already been cooled due to disputes over 5G networks and the COVID-19 pandemic origins. Australia's conservative government is under pressure from farmers who face five years without access to their lucrative Chinese market.

site_title: Doha wins vote to host 2030 Asian Games, Riyadh gets 2034 rights
summary: Doha won the vote to host the 2030 Asian Games, securing the highest number of votes, while Riyadh will host the 2034 edition. The decision was made at the general assembly of the Olympic Council of Asia in Muscat. This marks a victory for Qatar, despite a long-running political dispute with Saudi Arabia, which also bid for the hosting rights.

site_title: Winding up of dormant unit to impact BH Global's earnings
summary: BH Global Corporation's dormant subsidiary is being wound up, expected to impact the group's earnings for the year ending December 31. The liquidation loss is approximately S$4.5 million, but it does not affect the group's operations and cash flow. Despite this, BH Global expects to remain profitable for the financial year. The company notes that the loss does not affect its earnings, and the group remains confident in its financial performance.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence eases from record, remains robust
summary: US homebuilder confidence eased to 86 in December, the second-best level on record, due to rising materials costs and worker shortages. Despite a slight decline, the reading indicates low mortgage rates continue to boost the industry. Demand for housing remains strong, but affordability challenges are expected in 2021 due to low inventory and rising construction costs. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index reported a four-month low in prospective buyer traffic and decreased confidence measures across all regions.

site_title: PwC Singapore calls for tax breaks on Covid-19 business spend in Budget 2021
summary: PwC Singapore has suggested tax breaks for businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic in the upcoming Budget 2021, including relief for home office setup, input tax for office equipment and utilities fees, and enhanced tax deductions for emerging sectors such as cybersecurity and agri-food investments. The firm also proposed removing caps on tax deductions for employee medical benefits and business digitalization expenditure. The goal is to support businesses and sectors that have been impacted by the pandemic while promoting sustainable economic growth.

site_title: Asean 2021 rebound will be strong but uneven among nations
summary: Southeast Asia is expected to experience a strong rebound in 2021, with GDP projected to grow 6.2% after a 4.1% contraction in 2020. However, recovery speeds will vary among nations, with Vietnam and Singapore leading the way, while the Philippines is expected to lag behind due to strict lockdowns and limited fiscal response. Analysts predict Thailand will recover by Q4 2021, and Malaysia and Indonesia will follow in mid-2021, with Indonesia's GDP contracting 2.2% in 2020 before rebounding 6% in 2021.

site_title: High yield a key factor in Soilbuild Reit's privatisation exercise, but will investors accept the deal?
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit (Soilbuild Reit) has announced a privatisation deal with Blackstone Real Estate, valuing the trust at S$0.55 per unit, close to its book value. The deal aims to address the trust's high distribution yield, which may not deliver the highest total returns. The manager of Soilbuild Reit noted that Reits with high DPU yields don't necessarily deliver the highest total returns, citing the trust's 1.6% total annualised return from 2013 to 2019. The privatisation is seen as a way to unlock value and allow the manager to experiment with strategies to create value for unitholders.

site_title: Aramco may have to sell assets, borrow more to maintain Saudi dividend
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil giant Aramco may need to sell assets or borrow more to maintain its promised $75 billion annual dividend to the government, amid uncertainty in oil prices. Despite plummeting profits this year due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Aramco is expected to continue offering the high dividend, potentially relying on external debt or asset sales to fund it. Experts predict that oil prices above $50 per barrel will be sufficient to cover the dividend, but lower prices may require Aramco to seek additional funding.

site_title: Detergent turns former teacher into one of China's richest women
summary: Pan Dong, a 55-year-old former teacher, is now one of China's richest women after becoming chairman of Blue Moon Group Holdings, a soap maker that raised $1.3 billion in Hong Kong's largest consumer IPO. With a 77% stake in the company, Pan's stake is now worth $8.6 billion, following a 13% share price increase on its debut. The company, which surpassed foreign brands like Unilever and Procter & Gamble, is China's top liquid laundry detergent provider.

site_title: British fund firm Ruffer piles US$675m into bitcoin in 'defensive move'
summary: British fund firm Ruffer Investment Management has invested around US$675 million in bitcoin, a 2.5% allocation of its total assets, as a "small but potent insurance policy" against currency devaluation. This move marks a significant signal of rising institutional interest in bitcoin, which has surged 170% this year. The allocation aims to diversify Ruffer's investments and hedge against monetary and market risks. The decision comes as investors seek yield in a record-low interest rate environment.

site_title: Bitcoin above US$20,000 for first time
summary: Bitcoin has reached a record-high of $20,398.50, trading above $20,000 for the first time. The virtual currency has seen a meteoric rise since March, driven by online payments giant PayPal's decision to enable account holders to use cryptocurrency. Several central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, are testing digital applications in response to Facebook's Libra. The surge in bitcoin has raised debate over its status as a form of money, asset, or commodity.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open slightly higher on stimulus bets
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq hitting a record high due to optimism over a potential coronavirus stimulus package. The S&P 500 gained 1.63 points, or 0.04%, to 3,696.25, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 15.98 points, or 0.13%, to 12,611.04. However, weak airline stocks and dismal retail sales data limited gains.

site_title: US blacklists Chinese, UAE-based companies over sale of Iranian petrochemicals
summary: The US has blacklisted Chinese and UAE-based companies for supporting the sale of Iranian petrochemicals. The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on four entities, including Donghai International Ship Management, Petrochem South East, Alpha Tech Trading, and Petroliance Trading, for facilitating the export of Iranian petrochemical products. The move aims to pressure Iran and complicate President-elect Joe Biden's path to renegotiating a nuclear deal. Analysts say Iran's petrochemical sector funds its malign agenda, and the sanctions freeze US assets and bar Americans from dealing with the blacklisted companies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Zoom plans to set up a new R&D centre in Singapore, hiring hundreds, and expand its co-located data centre. The Singapore Business Federation calls for extending Covid-19 support schemes until end-2021. Business confidence in Singapore improved slightly in Q1 2021, and a Singapore port is in talks to buy a stake in a petroleum storage hub. Keppel launched a second data centre fund with over $500m in its first close, and GovTech introduced face verification and multi-user SMS features for SingPass users. The STI rose 0.6% on Wednesday.

site_title: Mirach Energy taking steps to wind up as uncertainty arises over exit offer
summary: Mirach Energy is taking steps to wind up the company amid uncertainty over an exit offer. The company, after failing to exit the Singapore Exchange's watchlist, is seeking quotes from legal advisers and liquidators for winding-up costs. It faces cash flow difficulties, with only $333,000 in cash and cash equivalents as of November 30. To address this, Mirach Energy is implementing cost-cutting measures, including not renewing an office lease and cutting executives' salaries. The company is also exploring repatriation of dividends from its subsidiaries.

site_title: Strength in numbers, power in unity
summary: KPMG in Singapore and Deutsche Bank in Singapore are being recognized as Champions of Good for their corporate social responsibility efforts. Volunteering has been shown to benefit both the companies and their employees. KPMG's staff volunteers have reported improved job-related skills and personal growth from participating in various programs. Deutsche Bank's flagship corporate social responsibility program, dbSkillsPlus, aims to bring skills from the corporate sector to charities and social enterprises. The programs have fostered meaningful connections and collaborations with other organizations, contributing to a positive impact in the community.

images.alt_text: KPMG in Singapore's Make A Difference Day.
Deutsche Bank's staff volunteers engaging with the elderly.

site_title: Singapore's hawker culture added to Unesco list of intangible cultural heritage
summary: Singapore's hawker culture has been officially added to the Unesco Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, marking the country's first item on the list. The decision was made after a 24-member committee unanimously accepted Singapore's application, recognizing the culture's significance in the country's daily lives and multiculturalism. The addition comes with a commitment to protect and promote the culture, with the country required to submit a report every six years to Unesco.

site_title: Indonesia paves way for 2021 launch of sovereign wealth fund
summary: Indonesia's government has issued regulations to establish a sovereign wealth fund (SWF) with 75 trillion rupiah (S$7.05 billion) of capital, including 15 trillion rupiah from the state budget. The fund is designed to attract foreign firms as co-investors, unlike many SWFs established by wealthy countries. This move is part of Indonesia's efforts to attract new investment sources and diversify its economy.

site_title: Luxury group Kering probed for tax fraud: French prosecutor
summary: Luxury group Kering is under investigation by the French financial prosecutor's office for alleged tax fraud, dating back to 2019. Kering is accused of setting up a system in Switzerland to declare activities in third countries, primarily Italy, to avoid paying 2.5 billion euros in taxes between 2010 and 2017. The company has denied the allegations, stating it will cooperate with authorities, and previously paid a record tax bill in Italy in 2019. Kering owns top brands such as Yves Saint Laurent and Gucci.

site_title: More than 300 religious leaders urge ban on 'conversion therapy'
summary: More than 300 religious leaders from 35 countries have called for a ban on "conversion therapies" that attempt to change an individual's sexual orientation or gender identity. The statement, issued by the British Ozanne Foundation, includes representatives from major faiths such as Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, and Sikhism. Nobel Peace Prize winner Desmond Tutu is among the signatories, urging an end to the practice often done in the name of a faith. The call for a ban comes as the practice continues to be widely criticized and condemned by human rights organizations worldwide.

site_title: Australia ups ante in China trade row with WTO challenge of barley tariffs
summary: Australia has launched a formal appeal to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over China's imposition of 80.5% tariffs on Australian barley imports. The move comes after Beijing blocked a billion-dollar trade, with Australian Trade Minister Simon Birmingham stating the country has a "strong case". The WTO has started a 60-day consultation period, which could take years to resolve. The appeal threatens to further strain bilateral tensions, which have already seen China impose tariffs on Australian commodities such as beef, wine, and cotton.

site_title: Britain's top court gives go-ahead to Heathrow expansion
summary: Britain's Supreme Court gave the green light to the £14 billion expansion of Heathrow Airport, overturning a previous ruling that blocked the plan on environmental grounds. The court found that the government's climate change commitments were taken into account when designing the airport policy. Despite a downturn in air traffic due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Heathrow argues that the expansion is necessary for the future, citing the need for Britain to compete for trade with other countries.

site_title: Keong Hong Holdings has new substantial shareholder
summary: Keong Hong Holdings has a new substantial shareholder, LJHB Holdings (S), which acquired 49.4 million shares, representing a 21% stake, from Ronald Leo, the company's chairman and CEO. Mr. Leo remains the largest shareholder with a 30.85% interest. The investment is expected to provide LJHB with a platform for real estate projects in Singapore, while Keong Hong will leverage LJHB's network for regional expansion plans. Shares of Keong Hong closed down 8.57% following the announcement.

site_title: Dubai's Al-Futtaim sells Royal Sporting House to Gulf Marketing Group
summary: Dubai-based conglomerate Al-Futtaim sold Royal Sporting House to Gulf Marketing Group, a family-owned company in the Middle East. The deal includes operations in South-east Asia, Hong Kong, Egypt, and the Gulf Cooperation Council, covering over 550 sports retail stores in 12 countries and employing nearly 8,000 people. Gulf Marketing Group, which also distributes Nike and other global brands, will operate 10 warehouses following the acquisition.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.39 points to 1681.41 on Wednesday, with 830 gainers outnumbering 453 losers. The market saw a significant volume of 11.22 billion lots worth RM5.2 billion (S$1.7 billion).

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, following a rally on Wall Street driven by optimism over US stimulus talks. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.97% to 26,460.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were flat and down 0.25% and 0.35%, respectively. The gains come as investors await the outcome of US-EU trade talks, which are expected to impact global markets.

site_title: Facebook attacks Apple's iOS changes in full-page newspaper ads
summary: Facebook has launched a series of full-page newspaper ads attacking Apple's upcoming changes to its iOS 14 operating system, claiming the changes will be devastating to small businesses. Facebook claims that ads that disregard personalized targeting generate 60% fewer sales, while Apple argues that the changes will support small businesses. The move is the latest in a public battle between the two tech giants, with Facebook also criticizing Apple's expensive smartphones and App Store fees.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to spend US$150m setting up global tech centre in India
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) plans to invest US$150 million in setting up a global technology centre in Hyderabad, India, creating nearly 1,000 jobs by the end of 2021. The centre will focus on future mobility technologies, including connected vehicles, artificial intelligence, and data science. The goal is to digitalize FCA's automotive operations globally and shift from legacy to digital through emerging technologies.

site_title: Foreign visitors to Japan double in Nov from Oct as travel restrictions ease
summary: Foreign visitors to Japan more than doubled in November, reaching 56,700, after the country eased coronavirus-related travel restrictions. This represents a 98% drop from the same period last year. The government partially lifted restrictions from countries like China, South Korea, and Vietnam, allowing only essential travelers to enter. The increase in foreign arrivals is a positive sign for Japan's tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Cathay Pacific sees H2 loss 'significantly higher' than H1
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects a "significantly higher" second-half loss than its record first-half loss of HK$9.87 billion, driven by low demand, restructuring charges, and impairments on its fleet. The airline reported a 98.6% fall in passenger numbers in November and expects to operate around 9% of pre-Covid-19 capacity in December and 10% in January. Cathay plans to operate less than 50% of its normal passenger capacity in 2021 due to border closures, but forecasts a possible recovery in the second half as Covid-19 vaccines roll out more widely.

site_title: EU chief says UK trade pact closer but success not certain
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said the UK and EU are closer to a new trade deal, but it's unclear if a deal will be reached. The two sides have made progress on most issues, but two remaining problems - the level playing field and fisheries - need to be resolved. Von der Leyen stated that discussions on access to UK fishing waters are "very difficult" and that a deal could be finalized in 48 hours if Prime Minister Boris Johnson agrees to trade-offs. A deal's success is uncertain, with the UK insisting on not sealing a deal that fails to deliver on its sovereignty promise.

site_title: Malaysia invokes emergency to stop by-elections as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Malaysia's government has declared a state of emergency in two constituencies to stop by-elections amid a surge in COVID-19 cases. The decision was made as the country reported over 86,000 infections and 422 deaths. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin said the emergency was imposed in Bugaya and Gerik constituencies to prevent disruptions. This move comes after the government previously attempted to impose a nationwide emergency in October but was rejected by the king. The decision was made ahead of a crucial budget vote in parliament.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's government on Wednesday declared a state of emergency to stop by-elections in two constituencies scheduled for next month, as the country grapples with a spike in coronavirus cases over the past few months.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 2,872.80 on Wednesday, driven by advances on Wall Street as investors gained optimism from stimulus and vaccine talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also ended in the green, while the Nasdaq reached a record high. However, experts warn of caution due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the risk of extended lockdowns. Key gainers included Venture Corporation and the trio of lenders, while Jardine Strategic Holdings and Jardine Matheson Holdings were the biggest losers.

site_title: Singapore's cabbies, private-hire drivers to get extra S$133m in Covid-19 support
summary: Singapore's taxi and private-hire car drivers will receive an additional S$133 million in payouts from January to June 2021 under the Covid-19 Driver Relief Fund. The fund, on top of the existing S$55 million, provides monthly payouts of S$600 to eligible vehicles from January to March and S$450 from April to June. The move aims to moderate the impact of the pandemic on drivers' livelihoods, with about 52,000 drivers set to receive the payouts.

site_title: US retail sales tumble in sign economic rebound is sputtering
summary: US retail sales declined 1.1% in November, exceeding forecast expectations, as the economic rebound appears to be sputtering due to rising coronavirus cases and a lack of a new stimulus package. This marks the first drops in retail sales since March and April. Excluding autos and gasoline, sales fell 0.8%, with control group sales dropping 0.5%. The decline was most pronounced for clothing stores and restaurants, while e-commerce sales barely rose. Despite the drop, total retail sales remain 4.1% above the same period last year.

images.alt_text: US retail sales dropped by more than forecast in November and the prior month was revised to a decline, indicating the economic rebound is hitting bumps as coronavirus cases surge and lawmakers wrangle over a new stimulus package.

site_title: Tom Cruise erupts at 'Mission: Impossible' crew over Covid-19 breach
summary: Tom Cruise erupted at crew members on the set of 'Mission: Impossible 7' over a Covid-19 protocol breach, yelling "I don't ever want to see it again! Ever! And if you don't do it, you're fired!" The incident occurred in London, where production had resumed after previous delays due to the pandemic. Cruise, who has been enforcing strict Covid-19 rules on set, was reportedly furious after spotting two crew members standing together in violation of the rule.

images.alt_text: Actor Tom Cruise recently erupted at crew members on the set of Mission: Impossible 7 over a breach of Covid-19 protocols in an apparent effort to prevent further disruptions to a film whose production has already been delayed by the pandemic.

site_title: BP takes majority stake in US carbon offset firm Finite Carbon
summary: BP acquired a majority stake in US carbon offset firm Finite Carbon, as part of its climate goals and to develop a new revenue stream. The oil major aims to become one of the world's largest renewable power generators, with plans to increase its renewable power capacity 20-fold by 2030. Finite Carbon generates carbon offset credits by paying landowners to manage forests, and BP expects to help expand its reach into other countries. The deal is part of BP's efforts to counter falling fossil fuel profits and capitalize on expected rises in carbon credit prices.

site_title: Climate-innovation accelerator launched by Temasek, DBS, Google and partners
summary: A six-month global virtual accelerator, the Sustaintech Xcelerator, has been launched by Temasek, DBS, Google, and partners to boost confidence in nature-based carbon credits. The accelerator aims to improve the monitoring and verification of environmental, social, and economic impacts. It will support climate innovators developing solutions to increase trust in nature-based solutions (NBS). The initiative is a collaboration between the National University of Singapore's Centre for Nature-based Climate Solutions, the World Bank, and Verra.

site_title: Asean-5 to see 5% growth in 2021, 5.7% in 2022: Citi
summary: Asean-5 economies, including Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines, are expected to see 5% GDP growth in 2021 and 5.7% in 2022, according to a Citi report. Most economies, except the Philippines, are expected to return to pre-Covid levels by the end of 2021, with Vietnam and Indonesia expected to see the fastest recovery. External demand, particularly from the US and Europe, poses near-term risks, but supply chain shifts and vaccine rollouts are expected to strengthen into 2022.

site_title: Indonesia to offer free vaccines; Jokowi first in line
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has announced a plan to offer free COVID-19 vaccines to its population after reallocating funds from other matters. The program, set to be Southeast Asia's earliest, will cover 74 million doses initially, with 270 million people also receiving the vaccine. Widodo will be the first to receive the vaccine, aiming to show its safety. The cost of the program is unclear, with shipments from China's Sinovac Biotech and other manufacturers already in transit for evaluation.

site_title: Germany's Continental aims to triple profitability under new CEO
summary: Germany's Continental aims to triple its profitability under new CEO through restructuring plans. The company seeks to increase its adjusted EBIT margin to 8-11% and focus on vehicle networking and autonomous driving. Continental plans to increase automation and digitalize production. Its shares rose 4% following the announcement, which comes after the company reported a 2020 adjusted EBIT margin of 3%.

site_title: More financial help for Singapore's lower to middle-income workers
summary: Singapore is introducing the Covid-19 Recovery Grant (CRG) to provide financial support to lower to middle-income workers who are still in financial hardships despite the Budget relief measures. The grant offers up to S$700 per month for three months to employees who were retrenched or put on involuntary no-pay leave. The initiative aims to help workers while they actively search for new jobs or training opportunities.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index gaining 0.4% to 6,540.08 points, and the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also advancing 0.5%. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. The US stock market also reached fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher with eyes on US Fed
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, driven by rallies on Wall Street ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.26% to 26,757.40, while the Topix index gained 0.27% to 1,786.83. Investors await the Fed's decision, with economists expecting no change to the benchmark lending rate. A stronger yen against the dollar also weighed on the market. Shares of Panasonic, Canon, and Toyota rose, with Panasonic rallying 2.50% to 1,190 yen.

site_title: Dyson shrugs off ill-fated electric car foray with profit rise
summary: Dyson Holdings reported a 17% profit increase in 2019, despite abandoning its electric car project. The company made a net income of £711 million and revenue rose 23% to £5.4 billion. Dyson shifted its focus from the UK to Asia, investing in machine learning, robotics, and new technologies. The company is opening a new manufacturing hub and university program in Singapore and has designed plans for an air purifier that doubles as headphones. Despite a 900-job cut due to the pandemic, Dyson plans to hire over 2,000 people in South-east Asia.

site_title: ECB lifts bank dividend ban with 15% payout cap on profit
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lifted its ban on bank dividends, but imposed a 15% payout cap on profit for 2019 and 2020, or 0.2% of key capital ratio, whichever is lower. This move aims to help lenders maintain financial strength during the pandemic. Regulators remain cautious, citing concerns about banks' ability to bear losses without taxpayer bailouts. The cap is more conservative than the Bank of England's 0.2% of risk-weighted assets or 25% of cumulative quarterly profits.

site_title: Two Singaporeans among 12 new imported Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Two Singaporeans, a 39-year-old man who returned from Indonesia and a 50-year-old woman who arrived from Australia, are among 12 new imported COVID-19 cases in Singapore. All 12 cases, including the two Singaporeans, are asymptomatic or showed mild symptoms and are on stay-home notice. Singapore's total COVID-19 cases now stand at 58,353, with 25 patients in hospital and 61 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: Twitter dropping Periscope mobile app for live streams
summary: Twitter will discontinue its Periscope mobile app for live streams by March, citing declining usage and increasing maintenance costs. The app's features have been integrated into Twitter, and users will be able to access archived broadcasts before the app is removed from app stores. The decision comes as the company seeks to optimize its resources, with Twitter confident that live video still has the potential to reach a wider audience within the Twitter product.

site_title: Pandemic saps 81 million jobs in Asia-Pacific in 2020: ILO
summary: The International Labour Organization (ILO) reported that the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in 81 million job losses in the Asia-Pacific region in 2020, with women and young people disproportionately affected. Employment declined by 4.2% compared to pre-crisis trends, with a 4.6% gap for women and 4% for men. The low levels of social security coverage and limited institutional capacity in many countries hindered efforts to support enterprises and workers.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump most in over two weeks on US stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to end at 6,679.2, their largest intraday jump in over two weeks, driven by overnight US stock gains and hopes of a US coronavirus stimulus package. The S&P/ASX 200 index also rose, with miners and financials advancing 1.9% and 0.7%, respectively. The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates near zero, boosting market sentiment. However, escalating trade tensions with China weighed on sentiment, with Australia planning to appeal to the World Trade Organization over Beijing's tariffs on barley imports.

site_title: E-commerce marketing startup Epsilo raises US$2m led by Sequoia Capital India's Surge
summary: E-commerce marketing startup Epsilo has raised US$2 million in funding led by Sequoia Capital India's Surge. Founded in 2019, Epsilo is a performance marketing platform that optimizes ad spend for keywords, budget, and inventory. Its software supports over 400 online shops, generating US$280 million in annualized gross merchandise value. Epsilo has worked with prominent brands such as Procter and Gamble and Unilever, and aims to target and convert prospective consumers browsing e-commerce sites with its real-time inventory tracking and campaign analysis capabilities.

site_title: Gold scales one-week high on US stimulus bets, Fed decision awaited
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-week high on Wednesday, reaching US$1,857.89 per ounce, driven by growing hopes for US stimulus and a Federal Reserve policy decision. Investors await the Fed's final policy statement, where it is expected to keep interest rates pinned near zero. A possible yield curve control programme could boost gold prices. Meanwhile, news of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine regulatory authorisation in the US kept gains in check.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end at record high as US resumes stimulus talks
summary: South Korean shares ended at a record high on Wednesday, driven by hopes for US coronavirus stimulus and vaccine rollouts. The Kospi rose 14.97 points or 0.54% to close at 2,771.79, despite a record surge in local coronavirus cases. Top US congressional leaders resumed talks on stimulus, while South Korean Prime Minister pledged to secure more hospital beds. The won weakened, and bond yields rose, with Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine expected to receive regulatory approval this week.

site_title: Digital health app Speedoc raises S$6.7m in Series A round led by Vertex Ventures
summary: Digital health app Speedoc has raised S$6.7 million in a Series A funding round led by Vertex Ventures Southeast Asia and India. The funds will be used to drive technology advancements, including clinical validation and virtual hospital schemes. Speedoc plans to leverage artificial intelligence and machine learning to create personalized treatment plans, expanding its services in Singapore and other South-east Asia countries. The company aims to enable home care with tools like remote monitoring, telemedicine, and blended clinical pathways, addressing the medical needs of populations affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Shift towards flexible work creates new innovation opportunities: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing says the shift towards flexible work creates new opportunities for innovation. The changing nature of the workspace has prompted businesses to adopt digital solutions addressing the future of work. While the impact of Covid-19 on work is uncertain, many companies are likely to move towards flexible arrangements.

site_title: Condo and HDB rental volumes rise in November: SRX
summary: Condo and HDB rental volumes rose in November, with condominium rentals increasing 3.8% to 4,443 units and HDB rentals rising 6.7% to 1,762 flats. Year-on-year, private leasings are 1.1% higher, while HDB leasings are down 11.7%. Rents for condo units edged up 0.5% month-on-month, while HDB rents remained unchanged. Experts expect the Singapore housing market to benefit from the COVID-19 vaccination program and eased border restrictions, potentially leading to increased rental volumes and rents.

site_title: Zoom to set up new R&D centre in Singapore, hire 'hundreds'
summary: US tech giant Zoom is opening a new research and development centre in Singapore, where it will hire hundreds of key engineering staff. The centre will double Zoom's data centre capacity in Singapore, a strategic move to tap into the city-state's exceptional engineering talent and strong infrastructure. The company chose Singapore due to its pro-business environment and gateway to the Asia-Pacific region. The move is part of Zoom's growing investment in the city-state, with plans to immediately hire employees and explore new possibilities.

site_title: GovTech launches face verification, multi-user SMS features for SingPass users
summary: GovTech has launched two new features for SingPass users, allowing for face verification on computers or mobile devices, and sending a one-time password (OTP) to another user. The new features are available starting Wednesday and provide an alternative to traditional 2FA methods, particularly for users who are less digitally savvy or unable to receive SMS-OTPs. The face-verification technology includes security measures such as liveness detection to prevent fraud.

images.alt_text: With SingPass Face Verification, users can log in by entering their SingPass ID and password, followed by scanning their face on a computer or a mobile device.

site_title: Kanye West's beloved drum machine maker returns to stock market
summary: Roland Corp, the manufacturer of the iconic drum machine TR-808 Rhythm Composer, is returning to the stock market. The company, founded by Ikutaro Kakehashi, initially retreated from the market following the 2008 financial crisis. The TR-808, released in the early 1980s, has become a household name and has influenced music across decades, with artists like Billie Eilish and Kanye West paying homage to its sound. The company's return to the stock market is a significant development for the music industry.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on vaccines, signs of US stimulus progress
summary: Asia markets rose on Wednesday due to US stimulus talks, Brexit hopes, and vaccine rollouts, despite concerns over the spread of the virus and potential lockdowns. The European Medicines Agency announced a meeting to decide on authorizing the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, and the US Food and Drug Administration recommended a second Moderna vaccine. This progress boosted markets, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and other cities posting gains. Despite near-term risks, traders remain optimistic about long-term prospects, citing the potential for a big vaccine rollout and economic recovery.

site_title: Masa, US$99b and a blank-cheque company: A match made off Wall Street
summary: Billionaire Masayoshi Son, founder of the $98.6 billion Vision Fund, is exploring a potential merger between his e-commerce company Tokopedia and a blank-cheque company backed by Peter Thiel and Richard Li. The deal, valued at up to $10 billion, would allow Tokopedia to go public without a traditional IPO, a move that could help Son end 2020 on a positive note after a string of losses. The deal would also mark a strategic partnership between Son and Thiel, who have different areas of expertise, and demonstrate the potential of South-east Asia's e-commerce market.

site_title: De Beers raises diamond prices for first time since pandemic
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, raised diamond prices for the first time since the 2020 pandemic, with prices increasing by 2-3% at its final sale of the year. This marks a reversal of steep cuts made earlier this year and signals growing confidence in the industry's recovery. The diamond industry's sales have been boosted by strong holiday sales, with De Beers' latest auction exceeding $400 million, a significant increase from the $50 million sold during the second quarter of 2020.

site_title: Broker's take: Suntec Reit top pick for RHB on attractive valuations, earnings recovery
summary: RHB maintains its "buy" rating on Suntec Reit, citing attractive valuations and earnings recovery. The Reit's units trade at 0.7 times price-to-book value, with a target price of S$1.79. Analysts expect distribution per unit to rebound 25% in 2021, driven by completed development assets and positive rent reversions. However, retail performance is expected to remain under pressure, with overall occupancy at around 90% and rents under 5-15% negative rent reversions. Recovery is projected to come in 2022 for the convention wing.

site_title: US states aiming antitrust suit at Google: report
summary: US states are preparing to file an antitrust lawsuit against Google, alleging the company abuses its power by favoring its own offerings in search results. The lawsuit, led by attorneys general from Colorado and Nebraska, argues that Google disadvantages rivals by design. This comes as the US Justice Department already filed a landmark antitrust lawsuit against Google in October, accusing the company of maintaining an "illegal monopoly" in online search and advertising. The case could take years to play out and has significant implications for the tech sector.

site_title: Strong virus response helps Vietnam's economy weather pandemic
summary: Vietnam's economy weathered the 2020 pandemic with a strong response, surging exports, and healthy public spending, bucking a global recession. With fewer than 1,500 coronavirus cases and 35 deaths, the country's economy expanded 2.4% in 2020, predicted to be among the best in the world. Tourism, however, was severely impacted, with many hotels closed and jobs lost. The government's swift response, including mass quarantines and strict controls, helped cushion the economic blow, with public investment rising 34% in the first 11 months of 2020.

site_title: Shares of China chipmaker SMIC plunge after co-CEO abruptly quits
summary: China's semiconductor manufacturer SMIC plummeted nearly 10% after co-CEO Liang Mong Song quit following the company's appointment of a new vice-chairman without consulting him. Liang, a key figure in SMIC's rapid technological advancements, had been leading the company's efforts to become a major player in the global chip industry. His departure is seen as a significant setback, with analysts predicting that SMIC's future technology progress may be impacted. The move comes as China seeks to build a world-class semiconductor industry and wean itself off American technology, amid worsening tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Singapore and US sign MOU on trade financing, investment cooperation
summary: Singapore and the US have signed a 2-year memorandum of understanding (MOU) to deepen economic cooperation, enhance trade financing options, and facilitate bilateral trade and investment. The MOU aims to address global economic disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, supporting US and Singapore companies in accessing trade financing and investment opportunities. The agreement will be overseen by the US Department of Commerce and Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry, with the goal of promoting growth opportunities in both regions. The partnership is seen as a key step towards a stronger post-Covid-19 economic recovery.

site_title: Slight uptick in Singapore business confidence for another quarter: SCCB
summary: Business confidence in Singapore saw a slight uptick in Q1 2021, with the business optimism index improving to -1.03 percentage points from -4.97 in Q4 2020. The financial and manufacturing sectors showed visible improvements, while the construction and transportation sectors remained downbeat. The services sector was moderately upbeat, with half of the indicators in positive territory. SCCB expects sentiments to remain volatile for the first six months of 2021, citing the overall economy not being out of the woods yet.

site_title: Upmarket toaster maker Balmuda shares pop 88% in Tokyo debut
summary: Balmuda, a Tokyo-based consumer electronics maker, made its stock market debut with a 88% pop in shares, valuing the company at $270 million. The startup raised $30 million from its initial public offering, pricing its shares at 1,930 yen each. Balmuda's high-end toasters and fans have gained popularity, charging premium prices due to modern designs and simple product names. The company's success contrasts with established brands, which often feature multiple functions, and may address Japanese consumers' thrifty habits.

site_title: Biden joins battle for Senate as top Republican accepts win
summary: President-elect Joe Biden joined the battle for the US Senate, hosting a rally for Democratic candidates in runoff races in Georgia. Biden urged voters to turn out in force, saying "Send me these two men, and we will control the Senate!" The Electoral College had previously confirmed Biden's victory, and top Republican Mitch McConnell finally acknowledged it, congratulating Biden and praising the country's democracy. Biden also announced plans to appoint Pete Buttigieg as secretary of transportation, making him the first openly gay person confirmed to a presidential cabinet post.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.82% on Wednesday morning, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street, with hopes of a US stimulus deal. The Hang Seng Index increased to 26,421.21, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also gained.

site_title: Budget wish-list: Singapore Business Federation calls for Covid-19 support schemes to be extended till end-2021
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has called for the extension of Covid-19 support schemes until the end of 2021, citing the ongoing impact of the pandemic on businesses. The SBF recommends extending foreign worker levy rebates and the Temporary Bridging Loan Programme, which provides business loans up to S$5 million. The association also suggests improving cash flow for businesses by paying suppliers within 14 days and offering more support for digital and business transformation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.56 points, or 0.87%, to 1,688.58 on Wednesday, with a gain of 477 to 80 gainers to losers. Volume reached 506.16 billion lots worth RM220.05 million.

site_title: Prudential's Eastspring appoints new chief operating officer
summary: Eastspring Investments, the Asian asset management business of Prudential plc, has appointed Lilian Tham as its new chief operating officer (COO) effective January 4, 2021. Tham, formerly Schroders' Asia-Pacific COO, will oversee operations, digital, data, and administrative support, as well as strategic growth initiatives. She replaces Jeroen Buwalda, who is moving to a new role at Prudential Corporation Asia. Tham brings 26 years of experience in technology and operations to the position.

images.alt_text: Ms Tham will be based in Singapore and be responsible for operations, digital, data and administrative support, as well as other strategic growth and change initiatives.

site_title: SME lender Funding Societies doubles valuation in Samsung-backed round
summary: Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer lending platform, has secured a round of funding from Samsung Venture Investment Corporation, doubling its valuation to about two times its Series B post-money valuation in 2018. The funding, led by Samsung, also includes backing from existing investors and new backers. The company will use the funds to expand its technology team and channel them towards its tech arm, FS Technologies. Funding Societies aims to further fund small and medium enterprises (SMEs) across Asia and Europe, addressing the SME credit gap in the region.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance after Nasdaq ends at record high; STI up 0.4% at open
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% at open on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street's record high. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 9.95 points to 2,866.67, driven by upgrades from Maybank Kim Eng on Genting Singapore and local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The Nasdaq ended at a record high, 1.3% higher, amid optimism over US stimulus talks, while European shares rose and Asian markets followed suit, with Tokyo stocks advancing 0.7% and the Nikkei 225 index reaching 26,866.42.

site_title: US sets new 24-hour record of Covid-19 infections
summary: The US set a new daily record of Covid-19 cases with over 248,000 infections reported, and 2,706 new deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University data. Hospitalized Covid patients reached 113,000, the highest level since March. The situation is improving in the Midwest but worsening in the Northeast and West. A nationwide vaccination campaign launched on Monday will not immediately impact the surge, with experts emphasizing the need for continued face masks and social distancing measures, especially during the holiday period.

images.alt_text: The US set a new daily record of Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, with more than 248,000 infections registered in the past 24 hours, the Johns Hopkins University virus monitor reported.

site_title: Australia to launch appeal to WTO over China's barley tariffs
summary: Australia is set to launch a formal appeal to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over China's 80.5% tariffs on Australian barley, which effectively halted a $1 billion trade.
