site_title: China's Yangtze fishing communities adapt to life on land
summary: China has implemented a 10-year catch ban along the Yangtze River and its major lakes and tributaries to reverse years of overfishing and pollution. The ban has forced fishermen like Yang Zeqiang to adapt to new livelihoods, with some turning to running guesthouses and passenger ferries. However, many fishermen, like 71-year-old Zhao Zejin, struggle to find alternative income, with some selling seeds and others going into debt. The ban aims to protect the Yangtze, China's longest river, which has been severely damaged by development and pollution, with four fish species now extinct and numbers of Yangtze finless porpoises dwindling to the hundreds.

site_title: Lumber defies usual lull with building boom straining supplies
summary: Lumber prices have surged to a record high in December, with futures reaching $819.80 per 1,000 board feet, driven by strong demand from home renovations and building during the pandemic. Low inventories and production cuts have exacerbated the shortage, forcing buyers to pay up. This trend is expected to continue into early 2021, with new-home building in Canada and the US projected to rise, despite a 10% decline in US multi-family permits.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down after US losses
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down on Tuesday, following US losses and the suspension of a domestic tourism campaign due to record virus infections. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.17% to 26,687.84, and the Topix index declined 0.47% to 1,782.05. The losses mirrored those on Wall Street, where stocks had previously reached records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Australia: Miners drag shares lower on reports of China restricting coal imports
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.4% to 6,631.3, its lowest close in nearly two weeks, due to reports that China restricted coal imports from Australia. This led to a 2.1% decline in miners, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto shedding 2.3% and 1.3%, respectively. China's steel producers also called for regulatory investigation into rising iron ore prices, further hurting miners. The decline was also seen in New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index, which fell 0.5%.

site_title: Uber rival Ola to build world's biggest scooter factory in India
summary: Ola, an Indian ride-hailing firm backed by SoftBank, plans to build the world's largest scooter factory in Tamil Nadu, investing $325 million and creating 10,000 jobs. The factory will produce two million electric two-wheelers annually for Asia, Europe, and Latin America, making India a manufacturing hub for electric vehicles. The move aims to support Ola's e-scooter launch in the coming months and bolster its presence in the global electric vehicle market.

site_title: Adidas exploring strategic options, including sale, for Reebok
summary: Adidas is exploring strategic options for Reebok, including a potential sale, 15 years after acquiring the brand for $3.8 billion. The company is considering alternatives such as selling Reebok as a standalone public company or to private equity firms. Reebok's net sales fell 7% in the third quarter of 2020, but recent collaborations and a refreshed focus on women's apparel have improved the brand's prospects. Adidas will announce its new strategy on March 10, which may include selling or spinning off the brand.

site_title: China industrial output rises 7% y-o-y in Nov; retail sales up 5% y-o-y
summary: China's industrial output rose 7% year-over-year in November, surpassing analyst expectations, for the eighth consecutive month. Retail sales also increased 5% year-over-year, narrowly missing forecasts. Fixed asset investment grew 2.6% in the first 11 months of the year, matching forecasts. The data suggests China's economy is recovering from the coronavirus slump, driven by robust exports.

site_title: Oaktree offers 366.5b rupees for India shadow lender Dewan
summary: Oaktree Capital Group has offered 366.5 billion rupees to acquire Indian shadow lender Dewan Housing Finance Corp, surpassing its previous bid of 310 billion rupees. Other bidders, including Piramal Enterprises and Adani Group, have also improved their proposals. The move reflects strong investor interest in India's shadow banking sector, which has recovered following policy support and a crisis in 2018. The acquisition would give Oaktree a loan book of approximately $12 billion, with the deal to be structured over seven years.

site_title: Former Shell employee involved in gas oil misappropriation worth US$36.1m
summary: A former Shell employee, Sadagopan Premnath, has admitted to being involved in a conspiracy to misappropriate approximately $36.1 million worth of gas oil from the company between 2007 and 2018. Premnath, an Indian national, received $150,000 for his involvement and has not made restitution. He was employed by Shell around 2012 and worked with six co-conspirators who targeted vessels with Vietnamese and Greek captains for illegal oil trading. Premnath's primary role was to open or close valves using a black oil panel, controlled by senior co-conspirators.

site_title: Japan's wasabi producers farm 'green gold'
summary: Japan's wasabi producers cultivate a rare and expensive 'green gold', distinct from artificial wasabi made from horseradish. The knobbly root is difficult to grow, with most being snapped up by wholesalers. Real wasabi has a complex, mildly piquant flavor and is pale-green in color. It is not commonly consumed in Japan, due to its high cost and limited availability. The unique root is highly prized by chefs and food enthusiasts, but its exclusivity contributes to its allure and value.

site_title: Gold firms as US stimulus progress weighs on dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,831.64 per ounce, driven by a weakening US dollar, despite hopes of a faster global economic recovery due to COVID-19 vaccinations. The dollar hovered near a two-and-a-half-year low due to progress on a fiscal relief bill. However, vaccinations and potential policy changes from central banks may limit gold's gains. Other precious metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium, also increased.

images.alt_text: Gold prices inched higher on Tuesday as the dollar weakened, though the start of Covid-19 vaccinations in the United States and Canada buoyed hopes of a swifter global economic recovery and kept the metal's gains in check.

site_title: Singapore new home sales rose to 767 units in Nov, up 18.9% over Oct on economic recovery hopes
summary: Singapore new home sales rose 18.9% in November to 767 units, driven by strong demand at new launches like The Linq @ Beauty World and The Landmark. This brings the January-November total to 8,791 units, excluding executive condominiums. Sales were up 19% for EC units, but down 31.3% year-on-year. Market watchers attribute the surge to hopes of economic recovery and vaccine optimism, with buyers snapping up new condos ahead of Singapore's Phase Three reopening on Dec 28.

site_title: Caribbean refinery sells first product after yearlong delay
summary: The Caribbean refinery Limetree Bay Ventures sold its first oil product, approximately 216,000 barrels of naphtha, to BP Plc in Beaumont, Texas, nearly a year after its expected restart. The refinery, which has spent over $2.7 billion on the restart, is still struggling to bring certain units online for cleaner fuels production. Despite delays and the Covid-19 pandemic, the refinery aims to process 210,000 barrels of crude per day, targeting low-sulfur fuels for Latin America and the Caribbean markets.

site_title: Dutch set for toughest lockdown yet over Christmas: PM
summary: The Netherlands is set for its strictest coronavirus lockdown yet, with schools and non-essential shops closing for five weeks over the Christmas period. Prime Minister Mark Rutte announced the measures, citing a surge in Covid-19 cases, with the number of infections nearing 10,000 a day. The lockdown will include closures of museums, zoos, cinemas, and gyms, but cannabis "coffeeshops" and restaurants can remain open for takeaway service. The measures are the toughest since the start of the pandemic, as the country struggles with the second and third wave of the disease.

images.alt_text: The Netherlands is to go into its strictest coronavirus lockdown yet, with schools and non-essential shops shutting for five weeks over the Christmas period, Prime Minister Mark Rutte announced Monday.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall as virus surge leads to new lockdowns
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday as governments worldwide reimposed lockdowns to combat surging COVID-19 cases, despite vaccine rollouts in the US and Britain. Despite optimism over potential US stimulus, investors showed signs of market fatigue, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling on Wall Street. The pound held gains as British and EU negotiators pressed ahead with trade talks.

site_title: China search giant Baidu considers making own electric vehicles: sources
summary: China's search giant Baidu is considering making its own electric vehicles through contract manufacturing or a majority-owned venture with automakers. This move would be a step up from internet peers like Tencent Holdings, Amazon.com, and Alphabet, which have developed auto-related technology or invested in smart-car startups. Baidu's initiative aims to leverage its autonomous driving technology and internet connectivity infrastructure expertise to enter the electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: China's Baidu is considering making its own electric vehicles and has held talks with automakers about the possibility, said three people with knowledge of the matter, the latest move in a race among tech firms to develop smart cars.

site_title: Singapore to offer segregated travel lane in added effort to safely reopen borders
summary: Singapore is introducing a new travel arrangement called Connect@Singapore, a segregated travel lane (STL) that allows short-term travelers from all countries to enter the country while staying in dedicated facilities. This initiative aims to safely reopen Singapore's borders by providing a controlled environment for business, official, and high-economic value travelers. Under the STL, travelers will undergo enhanced testing and be required to stay within their pre-declared group and observe safe management measures. Applications for travelers under the STL will open in the middle of next month.

site_title: London beats Brexit and pandemic woes to top Europe's IPO charts
summary: London led Europe's initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2020, surpassing Brexit and pandemic woes with 32 deals worth $11.3 billion, accounting for over a third of Europe's proceeds. This includes listings from international issuers like Kazakhstan's Kaspi.kz and Chinese companies, with THG Holdings being the largest debut. The European market for IPOs raised $28.3 billion, exceeding the $26.7 billion raised in 2019, despite the coronavirus crisis and Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Singapore VC firm 1982 Ventures invests in Vietnam's Homebase
summary: Singapore VC firm 1982 Ventures has invested in Vietnam's real estate tech company Homebase as part of a seven-figure Pre-Series A round. The investment, alongside others from Vietnam, Silicon Valley, and Singapore, aims to support Homebase's growth. 1982 Ventures focuses on early-stage fintech startups in South-east Asia, highlighting the growing interest in the region's startup ecosystem. The investment is part of a larger trend of international firms backing Vietnamese startups, driven by the country's growing tech industry and favorable business environment.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices rise for fourth straight month in November: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose for the fourth consecutive month in November, increasing 0.3% from October and 1.3% from November 2019, according to SRX Property. The core central region (CCR) saw a 0.5% increase, while the rest of central region (RCR) and outside central region (OCR) rose 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. Resale volumes also rose 1.4% to 1,426 units, with 59.7% of volumes coming from the OCR. Experts predict continued growth in the secondary market, with ERA Realty estimating 9,000 to 10,600 units to be transacted in 2021.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as miners slump on China scrutiny over iron ore prices
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday as miners, particularly BHP Group and Rio Tinto, dropped 2.5% and 1.1% respectively due to concerns over higher regulatory scrutiny over iron ore prices in China. Iron ore futures fell 4% on Monday after China's steel producers pushed for a regulatory probe into rising prices. The news also sparked concerns over demand for Australian coal, leading to sharp declines in coal producers.

site_title: Ski slopes open in Spain's Catalonia despite pandemic
summary: Ski slopes in Spain's Catalonia region opened on December 14, 2020, despite the ongoing pandemic, with limited capacity and online ticket sales to reduce the risk of infection. The resort, La Masella, in the Pyrenees mountains, was one of the few European ski stations to reopen, with most other nations keeping their slopes shut. The decision was made to support the local economy, which relies heavily on the ski industry, and to minimize the risk of infection.

site_title: China's domestic spending continues to grow in November
summary: China's retail sales rose 5% in November, beating analyst expectations, as the country's COVID-19 outbreak is largely under control. This marks a steady recovery for the economy, with industrial production growth also increasing to 7%. However, the catering sector saw a decline of 0.6% due to the ongoing pandemic's impact on the hospitality industry. The urban unemployment rate fell to 5.2%, but experts warn it may be higher due to the informal workforce. China's economic recovery is seen as a positive sign, but the ongoing pandemic poses headwinds for global economic recovery.

site_title: SGX-backed CIC launches initiative under Digital Silk Road to boost China-Asean trade
summary: The COMMODITIES Intelligence Centre (CIC), backed by Singapore Exchange (SGX), has launched an initiative under the Digital Silk Road to boost China-Asean trade. The initiative, in partnership with ZALL Smart Commerce Group, enables digital connectivity across supply chains and borders, leveraging ZALL's business-to-business trading ecosystem and CIC's real-time global trade data capabilities. The platform, Zallgo, has already seen a surge in online transactions and has achieved a gross merchandise volume of US$13.2 billion. This move aims to enhance digital connectivity and boost trade in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Rescue cats don Santa suits for purrfect Korean Christmas
summary: In South Korea, the Catgarden cafe in Seoul is hosting a festive holiday event featuring around 130 cats dressed in Santa suits. The cafe, which rescues and rehomes stray cats, aims to raise awareness about pet abandonment during the COVID-19 pandemic. The number of abandoned pets increased by 3.7% in the first half of 2020, with many people adopting cats but also abandoning them due to worsening living conditions. The cafe's owner, Park Seo-young, encourages visitors to take responsibility for their pets for life, offering a special feast for the feline Santas on Christmas Day.

site_title: GameStop employees surprised by new shipment of PS5, Xbox
summary: GameStop employees were surprised by new shipments of PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X consoles, sending customers to stores despite limited online availability. The surprise announcement, made just hours before the public, led to chaotic crowds and health risks for employees. The consoles have been in short supply since their release last month, with both Sony and Microsoft struggling with factory and logistical disruptions. GameStop, facing staffing shortages, aimed to prioritize individual customers over resellers but apologized for the inconvenience caused.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start marginally higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the day with slight gains, edging up 0.11% to 26,418.93, following a weak lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dipped 0.08% each. Investors are awaiting key Chinese economic data, which may influence market sentiment.

site_title: WeWork, SoftBank fail to get suit over stock deal dismissed
summary: A US judge has rejected some claims in a lawsuit filed by WeWork directors over a cancelled $3 billion stock purchase deal with SoftBank. The directors, including WeWork founder Adam Neumann, allege SoftBank relied on faulty pretexts to renege on the agreement. The judge allowed contract claims to proceed but dismissed fiduciary duty claims. The ruling resolves a clash between two sets of WeWork directors who took different approaches to dealing with SoftBank, which scuttled the buyout as part of a bailout effort.

site_title: Tony award? Opera to open about Britain's Blai
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair is the subject of an opera, "Tony! (A Tony Blair Rock Opera)", written by comedian Harry Hill. The show, set to open in February 2022, is a "reckless reappraisal" of Blair's life, featuring a colorful cast of characters, including his wife Cherie, press secretary Alistair Campbell, and former US President George W. Bush. The opera plays fast and loose with facts, taking inspiration from "Citizen Kane" and "The Marx Brothers". It will be performed at the Turbine Theatre in London.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Top Glove, Yeo Hiap Seng, Civmec, Yunnan Energy, Stamford Land
summary: Top Glove's counter tumbled 5.7% to S$2.15 after a month-long lockdown on its Malaysian dormitories was lifted, following the firm's first Covid-19 death and whistleblower firing. Yeo Hiap Seng's shares closed flat after being served with RM13.7 million (S$4.5 million) writs of summons. Civmec secured A$140 million in contracts, while Yunnan Energy started trading construction materials and medical devices. Stamford Land's deputy chairman retired, and Renaissance United expects a half-year net loss.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.34 points, or 0.08%, to 1,661.40. Volume was 1.44 billion lots worth RM626.45 million, with losers beating gainers 560 to 215.

site_title: Trump says Attorney General Barr resigns
summary: President Donald Trump announced that Attorney General William Barr will resign on December 23, with Deputy Attorney General Jeff Rosen taking over as acting attorney general. Barr's departure comes after he briefed Trump on the Justice Department's review of voter fraud allegations in the 2020 election. In a letter, Barr praised Trump's record and pledged to continue investigating the allegations, despite Trump's claims of major fraud. Barr's decision follows his earlier statement that the investigation found no significant fraud, contradicting Trump's claims.

site_title: Most in Japan oppose holding Olympics in 2021: polls
summary: A majority of Japanese people oppose holding the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics in 2021, with 27% supporting the event, 32% favouring cancellation, and 31% backing a further postponement. Despite the imminent arrival of new vaccines, public sentiment has shifted little since summer polls, with 61.2% of respondents opposing the Games next year. Organisers have ruled out further delays, but the added cost of health measures and vaccines is estimated to be at least $2.4 billion, with the total budget potentially exceeding $15 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Tuesday's open; STI dips 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index dipping 2.29 points to 2,855.85. The decline followed a mostly lower close for US stocks overnight. Decliners outnumbered advancers 72 to 65, with 100.7 million securities changing hands.

site_title: Biden says Trump 'refused to respect the will of the people'
summary: President-elect Joe Biden criticized Donald Trump for refusing to respect the will of the people and the constitution, saying it's a position "we've never seen before." Biden addressed Trump's efforts to overturn his victory in several key states, which were rejected by the Supreme Court. Biden praised voters for turning out despite fears and threats, calling the harassment of officials "unconscionable." He expressed hope for unity and cooperation for the nation's good, saying it's time to "turn the page." Biden's comments came after the Electoral College formally confirmed his victory.

site_title: Australia says China coal ban would be clear WTO breach
summary: Australia has criticized China's reported ban on its coal exports, calling it a clear breach of World Trade Organisation rules. Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that the move would be in breach of WTO rules and Australia's free trade agreement with China. China's reported ban on coal exports could escalate tensions between the two countries, which have been at their lowest ebb since the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. The dispute could take years to resolve and worsen relations between Australia and China.

site_title: Gaming platform Roblox acquires 3D facial animation firm Loom.ai
summary: US gaming platform Roblox has acquired Loom.ai, a San Francisco-based startup providing real-time facial animation technology for 3D avatars. The deal aims to accelerate the development of next-generation avatars, allowing players to express emotions and facial expressions. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. This acquisition is expected to enhance Roblox's virtual world experience, providing a more immersive and engaging environment for its users.

site_title: Pinterest to pay US$22.5m to settle gender discrimination suit
summary: Pinterest will pay US$22.5 million to settle a gender discrimination suit. The settlement includes US$20 million to former chief operating officer Francoise Brougher and US$2.5 million to increase diversity and inclusion in the tech industry. Pinterest acknowledged the importance of a diverse workplace environment and will continue to improve its culture.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US losses, travel campaign halt
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following losses on Wall Street and a halt in a domestic tourism campaign due to record virus infections. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.18% and the Topix index slid 0.15%. The losses come amid global market volatility, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Apple adding privacy fact labels to App Store items
summary: Apple has begun adding "privacy labels" to App Store items, revealing what user data is gathered by games, chat, and other software. The labels, which were first announced with iOS 14, will display summaries of developers' self-reported privacy practices. Starting early next year, all apps will be required to obtain user permission before tracking. The labels will include information on tracking for advertising and sharing with data brokers, as well as data that could reveal user identity. This move aims to give users easy access to information on how their data is used.

site_title: US passes 300,000 Covid-19 deaths: Johns Hopkins tally
summary: The US has reached 300,000 Covid-19 deaths, according to the Johns Hopkins University tally, with over 16.3 million cases reported. The country started its vaccine program on Monday, with the first recipient, nurse Sandra Lindsay, receiving the Pfizer-BioNTech shot. Authorities had warned of a spike in deaths after the Thanksgiving holiday, and 2.9 million vaccine doses are set to be delivered by Wednesday, with 20 million Americans expected to receive the two-shot regimen by year's end.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia sees lowering unemployment as national priority
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) prioritizes lowering unemployment, despite the country's labour market recovering faster than expected. The RBA's Board fears a protracted period of unemployment and will provide substantial monetary and fiscal support for years to come. Rates are expected to remain at 0.1% for at least three years, and the RBA will review its bond buying program to add more stimulus if needed. Analysts predict the program may need to increase by A$100 billion to counter upward pressure on the local dollar.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter face British fines if fail on harmful content
summary: Facebook, Twitter, and TikTok face fines of up to 10% of their turnover if they fail to remove and limit the spread of illegal content in Britain. The government requires tech platforms to protect children from grooming, bullying, and pornography. Clear policies on content that causes harm, such as misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines, will also be enforced. Britain's Digital Secretary Oliver Dowden aims to restore trust in the industry and safeguard free speech. The rules, set to be introduced next year, could lead to blocked sites and senior managers being held liable.

site_title: Europe: Shares cheer Brexit trade talks extension; AstraZeneca drops
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Monday as trade talks between Britain and the European Union were extended, keeping hopes of a deal alive. The Stoxx 600 index broke a five-week winning streak, but was weighed down by a near 6% drop in AstraZeneca. The UK's FTSE 100 was range-bound, ending 0.2% lower, while German stay-at-home stocks gained after a new lockdown was announced. Optimism also stemmed from the US starting mass vaccinations against Covid-19.

site_title: GIC invests US$200m in Sinopec Green
summary: Singapore's sovereign fund GIC has invested US$200 million in Sinopec Green Energy Geothermal Development Co, a geothermal heating company backed by China's Sinopec. The venture, valued at US$1 billion, is considering an IPO in mainland China or Hong Kong as soon as next year. Sinopec Green Energy, founded in 2006, provides heating to over 60 cities in China and aims to reach 60 million square meters of connected heating capacity next year. This investment marks GIC's entry into the renewable energy sector, following previous investments in firms like Greenko Energy Holdings and Japan Renewable Energy Corp.

images.alt_text: Singapore's sovereign fund GIC has invested US$200 million in a geothermal heating company backed by China's biggest oil refiner, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Google delays return to office and eyes 'flexible work week'
summary: Google has delayed its return to office until September 2021, citing the ongoing pandemic. The company is instead testing a "flexible workweek" model, where employees would work from home four days a week and spend three days a week in the office for collaboration. This pilot plan aims to increase productivity, collaboration, and well-being. The company has not specified whether vaccination will be required before returning to the office, but is exploring ways to make vaccines available to its workers.

site_title: China's new home price rally eases in November as cooling steps take hold
summary: China's new home prices grew at their slowest monthly pace since March, rising 0.1% in November from the previous month, according to official data. This marks the weakest rate since February 2016, as policymakers continue to pursue market-cooling measures to curb financial risk in the highly leveraged sector. The number of cities reporting monthly new home price increases fell to 36, down from 45 in October, attributed to stepped-up market tightening policies and increased supply and discounting.

site_title: Hackers breach US agencies, Homeland Security a reported target
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security was targeted in a major cyberattack, along with the Treasury and Commerce departments, in what may have been a coordinated effort by a foreign government. The attack, which started in Spring 2020, has also hit major cybersecurity firm FireEye and exploited a backdoor in SolarWinds software. The hackers are believed to be nation-state actors, possibly from Russia, and have stolen sensitive data. The US government and private sector are on high alert, with experts warning of increased risks of cyberattacks.

site_title: Lawmakers push bipartisan US stimulus plan to break stubborn deadlock
summary: US lawmakers have introduced a bipartisan stimulus proposal worth $908 billion to aid the pandemic-ravaged economy, with support from Democratic and Republican lawmakers. The bill would fund programs for the unemployed, small businesses, and state and local governments, as well as offer liability protections for some employers. The proposal follows the $2.2 trillion CARES Act and aims to pass before Congress heads home for the holidays, with a deadline of December 26 when benefits expire.

site_title: Airlines warned over safety as jets return from pandemic storage
summary: Airlines are being warned to exercise extra caution when reactivating planes left in extended storage during the Covid-19 pandemic due to potential pilot rustiness, maintenance errors, and insect nests blocking key sensors. The International Air Transport Association reports a sharp rise in "unstabilised" approaches, which can result in hard landings, runway overshoots, or crashes. Insurers are questioning airlines about pilot training, while aircraft makers note that approaches and landings are the largest categories of fatal and non-fatal accidents.

site_title: US FTC seeks data on how Facebook, Twitter, TikTok and others use personal data
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is seeking data from Facebook, Twitter, TikTok, and other social media companies on how they use users' personal data, including how they collect, display ads, and utilize algorithms. The FTC aims to learn about the companies' practices affecting children and teenagers. The companies have 45 days to respond to the orders, which may lead to policy or legislative recommendations. The FTC's investigation follows concerns about the industry's opaque data collection and monetization practices.

site_title: Australian banks better prepared for crisis than in 2008: RBA
summary: Australian banks are better prepared to handle an economic downturn than in 2008, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia. Banks have nearly doubled their Tier-1 capital ratio to 14% and have large buffers to continue lending and supporting customers. The banking system has also seen strong profits, with combined profits reaching A$34 billion in 2019. The regulator has removed limits on dividend payouts, citing the system's ability to handle a severe economic downturn. This comes as Australia's economy, valued at A$2 trillion, has fared better than many developed countries.

site_title: US: Stocks reverse course, close mostly lower on Monday
summary: US stocks closed mostly lower on Monday, reversing a strong opening, amid concerns about rising Covid-19 infections and potential lockdowns in the fragile US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6% to 29,861.55, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.4% to 3,647.49. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5% to 12,440.04. The US became the sixth country to approve the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, but analysts warned that the coronavirus death toll has reached 300,000 and another full shutdown is possible in New York City.

site_title: Volkswagen buries hatchet in boardroom battle
summary: Volkswagen's supervisory board has reached a deal to end infighting over top jobs and strategy, giving CEO Herbert Diess full support for his plans to shift towards electric vehicles and break old power structures. The move comes after Diess faced conflict with worker representatives over his strategy, which is seen as a key factor in the company's "dieselgate" emissions scandal. The board's unanimous decision is expected to stabilize the company and pave the way for Volkswagen's transition to electromobility and digitalization.

site_title: London set for tighter virus curbs as new Covid-19 variant emerges in England
summary: The UK government has announced tighter Covid-19 measures for London, moving the city into the highest level of restrictions due to a rapidly rising infection rate. Pubs, bars, restaurants, and entertainment venues will be forced to close, except for takeaway food, starting Wednesday. The new restrictions aim to combat a possible new coronavirus variant.

site_title: NZ agrees on two-way 'travel bubble' with Australia in early 2021
summary: New Zealand and Australia have agreed to a two-way "travel bubble" allowing quarantine-free travel between the two countries in the first quarter of 2021. This move follows New Zealand's elimination of COVID-19 within its borders and comes after Australia had already allowed New Zealanders to travel without quarantine requirements since October. The agreement is pending confirmation from the Australian cabinet and will be finalized once details are locked down, with Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern stating that New Zealand will move cautiously to ensure safe travels.

site_title: US Electoral College confirms Biden White House victory
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden was confirmed as the next US president when the Electoral College formalized his victory over Donald Trump. With 270 electoral votes, Biden's win is now all but official. California's 55 electors voted for Biden, surpassing the threshold. The Electoral College's decision cements Biden's victory, effectively closing the door on Trump's efforts to overturn the election result.

site_title: ExxonMobil pledges emissions cut as investor campaign targets board
summary: ExxonMobil has pledged to cut emissions by 15-20% from upstream activities by 2025, and reduce flaring intensity by 35-45% and methane intensity by 40-50% by 2030. The move comes after investor campaign Engine No. 1 and California State Teachers' Retirement System pushed for the company to take action on reducing carbon emissions. The campaign also nominated four board of director candidates, with the support of the Church of England's investment arm. The company's chairman and CEO, Darren Woods, described the moves as consistent with the Paris Climate Agreement.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil announced on Monday it will reduce its emissions over the next five years bowing to growing public pressure from activists, including the Church of England, to make changes.

site_title: Rapid China inflows could push yuan to its strongest since 1993: Citi economist
summary: A Citi economist predicts China's yuan could strengthen to its strongest since 1993, reaching a 6.35-to-dollar ratio by the end of 2021, driven by foreign cash inflows chasing yuan-denominated assets. The yuan has surged 10% from its May low, supported by bets on a less hostile US-China relationship and a global economic rebound. However, policymakers face a policy quandary as a strong currency could undermine China's export-driven economy and fuel local asset bubbles.

site_title: Pandemic-driven tidying frenzy driving Japan's market for 2nd-hand goods
summary: Japan's market for second-hand luxury goods is booming due to the pandemic-driven tidying frenzy. The market saw a 31% surge in visits to homes for goods collection, with most customers being in their 50s or older. Companies like BuySell Technologies and Mercari Inc reported significant jumps in sales, with BuySell seeing a 52% increase in sales for the July-September quarter. The trend is attributed to the "danshari" mindset, where people are minimizing their life by decluttering and selling unwanted items.

images.alt_text: Buysell Technologies Co Ltd collects goods from people's homes and resells them through online stores and at old-style in-person auctions.

site_title: Oil prices steady after six weeks of gains, pressured by glut
summary: Oil prices remained steady, ending a six-week gain, due to a persistent oversupply in the market. Despite hopes that coronavirus vaccines would boost global fuel demand, Opec said global oil demand would rebound more slowly in 2021 than previously thought. Libyan oil production rose to 1.28 million barrels per day, and energy firms added oil and natural gas rigs in the US. Global onshore crude inventories remain high, and major European countries continue in lockdown mode, reducing fuel demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were little changed in choppy trade on Monday as persistent oversupply in the market largely offset hopes that a rollout of coronavirus vaccines will lift global fuel demand.

site_title: American allies need to invest in US multilateralism as well
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has pledged to re-embrace America's internationalist foreign policy tradition, seeking to strengthen US strategic global alliances and cooperate with the international community on key issues like the Covid-19 pandemic and climate change. Biden's administration will rejoin the Paris agreement, return to a leadership role in the World Health Organization, and try to resurrect the nuclear deal with Iran. However, Biden's victory was not resounding, and his administration faces significant political and economic constraints, including opposition from both Republicans and Democrats, and a powerful progressive wing within his own party.

site_title: WTO fails to net deal to halt over-fishing before deadline
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) failed to reach a deal on banning subsidies contributing to over-fishing by a year-end deadline, extending negotiations for a 20th year. The talks, chaired by Colombian ambassador Santiago Wills, will resume on January 18. The WTO acknowledged its inability to net a deal, despite years of discussions, and will continue to work towards a solution.

site_title: Airbus urges compromises on Brexit, transatlantic tariffs
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury urged the EU and UK to reach a deal on Brexit and a transatlantic aircraft subsidy dispute, citing the need for an orderly exit. He downplayed warnings of severe disruption, saying it would be "much better" for both parties to have a deal. Airbus is preparing for potential disruption if a deal is not reached, but Faury emphasized the importance of cooperation to minimize business impact. The company's manufacturing plants straddle the UK and EU, making a deal crucial for its operations.

site_title: US restaurant owners get creative to keep workers safe
summary: US restaurant owners are implementing creative solutions to keep workers safe amid the COVID-19 pandemic due to lack of clear federal guidance. Some restaurants have hired on-site medical staff, implemented contract tracing systems, and provided personal protective equipment. Examples include a Michelin-starred restaurant in Washington DC providing wearable fitness trackers and a pizza chain subsidizing Lyft trips to prevent staff from using public transportation. These measures come as 44% of restaurant employees report a coworker has contracted the virus, and more than four in five are within 6 feet of an unmasked person during shifts.

site_title: Credit Suisse's new CEO gets a crash course in risk
summary: Credit Suisse's new CEO, Thomas Gottstein, faces a series of setbacks in his short tenure, including losses from accounting frauds, questionable deals, and a $450 million impairment on an investment in hedge fund York Capital. Gottstein has centralized risk and compliance, simplified the organizational setup, and scaled back lending growth, but critics argue he has shied away from decisive moves. The bank's strategy to target entrepreneurs in Asia has been criticized, and recent stumbles have raised questions about prioritizing revenue growth over risk and compliance. A fourth-quarter loss is now likely.

site_title: UK spy thriller author John le Carre, 89, dies
summary: John le Carre, the renowned British spy thriller author, has died at 89. Born David John Moore Cornwell, he wrote over 20 books, including "The Spy Who Came In From the Cold" and "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy", selling 60 million books worldwide. A former MI6 agent, le Carre chronicled Cold War espionage in his novels, earning praise from authors like Philip Roth and Graham Greene. His final work, "Agent Running in the Field", published in 2019, reflected his deep indignation at Brexit and the British government.

site_title: Training, communication key to helping older workers adapt
summary: Singaporean firms are successfully employing and retaining middle-aged and mature workers, despite common misconceptions about their abilities. Training, technology adoption, and communication are key to their success. Companies like Osteopore International, Hai Sia Seafood, and TranZplus are finding that older workers bring valuable experience and maturity, which can give them an edge over younger counterparts. By providing flexible working hours, training, and clear communication, these firms are able to overcome concerns about the older workers' ability to adapt to new technologies and roles.

site_title: 'Promising' gas finds seen raising Jordan's supplies
summary: Jordan's majority state-owned National Petroleum Company (NPC) has discovered "promising" quantities of natural gas in the Risha gas field along its eastern border with Iraq. The discovery is expected to boost the kingdom's gas supplies by at least 70% and contribute to a 10-year energy plan aiming to secure 50% of electricity generation from local sources. The new finds could help reduce Jordan's dependence on oil imports and alleviate its $4.7 billion annual energy bill, currently straining its economy.

site_title: Some light at the end of the tunnel, but Covid-19 battle far from over
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a plan to vaccinate all citizens and long-term residents against Covid-19 by the end of 2021, with priority given to healthcare workers, seniors, and vulnerable groups. The country has set aside $1 billion for the vaccination program, which includes the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine with a 95% efficacy rate. Singapore is also expected to start Phase 3 of its gradual reopening on Dec 28, allowing more people to gather in groups and boosting businesses. However, the Covid-19 battle is far from over, with the virus still a significant concern and economic growth expected to be slow.

site_title: Greater freedoms for migrant workers in coming weeks
summary: Migrant workers in Singapore will gain greater freedoms in the coming weeks as part of a pilot scheme. Those in some dormitories will be allowed to access the community once a month and communal facilities like cooking stations and sports facilities. The pilot scheme is set to kick off in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: EU rights agency warns of pitfalls in use of AI
summary: The European Union's rights watchdog, the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights, has warned of the risks of using artificial intelligence (AI) in various areas, including predictive policing and targeted advertising. The agency urges policymakers to provide more guidance on applying existing rules to AI and ensure that future laws protect fundamental rights. The EU is considering legislation next year to cover high-risk sectors, including healthcare and energy, with rules that include safeguards to prevent discrimination and guarantee data protection.

site_title: Entering the new age of responsive real estate
summary: The real estate industry is undergoing a significant transformation in response to the changing landscape of work and technology. With the rise of remote work, the demand for flexible office spaces is increasing, and property owners must adapt to provide scalable and innovative spaces. The "hotelification" trend, inspired by the hospitality industry, is also emerging, where properties are being reimagined to offer branded and bespoke spaces for a mobile population. Additionally, the integration of artificial intelligence and smart technology is revolutionizing the way people interact with buildings, with a focus on sustainability and environmental standards becoming increasingly important.

site_title: Carlos Ghosn investigated by France over possible tax evasion
summary: Carlos Ghosn, former CEO of Renault and Nissan, is under investigation in France for possible tax evasion during his last three years in the role. French authorities are discussing whether Ghosn should have been considered a French resident during 2016, 2017, and 2018. A French judge allowed the seizure of nearly $16 million in assets from Ghosn and his wife, pending the outcome of the probe. Ghosn has denied charges of financial crimes in Japan and escaped to Lebanon last year.

site_title: Aviation, travel take-off rests on global borders reopening
summary: Singapore's aviation and travel sectors face a long and potentially bumpy recovery due to the ongoing global pandemic. International travel depends on other countries controlling the virus and reopening their borders. Experts say it's crucial for large feeder markets to get vaccinated as well for Singapore to regain its economically viable business activity levels. Vaccines are expected to be available soon, but the recovery trajectory remains uncertain.

site_title: Singapore SMEs need to adopt standards: ESG
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are advised to adopt international standards to build quality and trust in their products and services, according to Enterprise Singapore (ESG). Following the COVID-19 pandemic, the demand for quality products and services will grow, and firms that adopt standards will be better equipped to operate smoothly despite disruptions. ESG director-general Choy Sauw Kook emphasized the importance of adhering to standards, citing examples such as e-commerce transactions and logistics, which will become increasingly crucial for businesses to remain competitive.

site_title: Seating, alcohol curbs still challenging for F&B sector
summary: Singapore's F&B sector is welcoming the government's decision to allow gatherings of up to eight people from Dec 28, a move that aims to boost social activity and enhance the dining and drinking vibe. The relaxation of Covid-19 restrictions is expected to improve and sustain F&B businesses, preserving jobs. Although some operators are anticipating a rise in bookings, particularly for large family dinners during Chinese New Year, others are urging a review of safe management measures, citing restrictions that limit seating capacity and impact revenue.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit units surge 5% on 'fair' privatisation offer
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit's units surged 5% after the announcement of a privatisation offer by Soilbuild Group's executive chairman Lim Chap Huat and Blackstone Real Estate via a trust scheme of arrangement. The scheme consideration is S$0.55 in cash per unit, representing a premium of 34.5-53.2% over the volume-weighted average price. The main motivation for the privatisation is the Reit's limited ability to make accretive acquisitions due to its high DPU yield, which hinders its access to capital markets. The offer is expected to be voted on by unitholders and is expected to be effective by March 2021.

site_title: Beating the odds, Wuhan horse racing gallops beyond virus
summary: Wuhan, China, is reviving its horse racing industry after the COVID-19 pandemic, with plans for a bigger and better 2021. The city, once ground zero for the virus, has a 150-year-old horse racing scene, with a focus on Western-standard racing. Despite the absence of betting, spectators enjoy the atmosphere, with entry starting at 50 yuan (S$10). The industry is backed by local authorities and the Communist Party, aiming to boost equestrian sport. Chairman Jacky Wu expects increased competition, prize money, and foreign jockeys in the coming year, with confidence in the future of Chinese horse racing.

site_title: Holiday retail workers seek 'temporary lifeline' in warehouse jobs
summary: Holiday retail workers are seeking temporary lifelines in warehouse jobs as the pandemic shifts the focus from storefront to online shopping. In the US and Europe, available holiday jobs in customer-facing retail fell by a third, while applications jumped by 34% year-on-year. Economists say this shift is likely to become an annual online shopping tradition for future holidays, with some retailers, such as Royal Mail and FedEx, increasing seasonal hires to meet demand.

site_title: UAW auto union settles massive US corruption case
summary: The United Autoworkers (UAW) union has settled a massive US corruption case, bringing to an end a year-long investigation into theft and bribery by 15 union or Fiat Chrysler executives. The union's president, Rory Gamble, said the agreement marks the end of the government's investigation and demonstrates structural and cultural changes made to address the scandal. The settlement does not result in any criminal charges against the UAW, but rather a civil resolution.

site_title: Some hotels cancel year-end staycations to take in SHN guests
summary: Some hotels in Singapore have cancelled year-end staycations to accommodate guests required to serve their stay-home notice (SHN). Naumi Hotel Singapore and Amara Singapore have been designated as SHN facilities, and bookings for these hotels have been cancelled. This move is due to the uncertainty of the situation and the need for extra precautions and safety measures for SHN guests. Despite this, some hotels are still experiencing high occupancy rates, particularly those with "resort-like" characteristics.

site_title: Fox fur prices fly as mink cull sparks shortage
summary: Denmark's decision to cull 17 million farmed mink due to Covid-19 outbreaks has disrupted the global fur trade, leading to a shortage. Fashion houses such as Louis Vuitton, Dior, and Fendi are expected to increase demand for alternative furs like fox and chinchilla. The global fur trade, worth over $22 billion annually, is reeling from the shortage.

site_title: Possibility of EU-UK trade deal brightens
summary: The European Union and the UK have made significant progress in their trade negotiations, with a deal now appearing more likely as talks continue without deadlines. Sterling rose 1.6% against the US dollar, and UK and European stock markets rallied, following statements from EU leaders expressing confidence in a compromise agreement. Despite ongoing frustration over lack of information on import and export processes, EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier said there was "every chance" of a deal, with key issues such as tariffs and regulatory standards being addressed.

site_title: Singapore's housing market through the various crises
summary: The Singapore housing market has faced significant disruptions from global crises, including the Sars epidemic in 2003, the global financial crisis (GFC) in 2007-2008, and the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. The Sars outbreak led to a 71% decline in private housing sales, while the GFC caused a 25% drop in housing prices. In contrast, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in a 78% increase in private housing sales and a swift recovery in property prices. The government's swift intervention in both crises, including budgetary support and economic rescue packages, helped mitigate the impact on the housing market.

site_title: Facebook cannot buy its way out of competition
summary: The Federal Trade Commission and over 40 states have filed an antitrust suit against Facebook, alleging the company's acquisition of multiple companies to stifle competition is illegal. Facebook, led by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, has been accused of buying its way to dominance, ignoring the Sherman Antitrust Act. The suit claims Facebook's actions are similar to those of John D Rockefeller's Standard Oil, which was broken up in 1911. The case is seen as a long-overdue reassertion of antitrust rules, which could transform the tech industry and result in a more innovative and competitive market.

site_title: Iron ore falls after crackdown plea from China mills
summary: Iron ore futures in Singapore plummeted to their lowest since 2013 after China's China Iron & Steel Association called for authorities to investigate the raw material's rapid price rise, citing potential illegal activities. The association made similar remarks in a recent interview, urging for rational trading. The move followed similar calls from the Dalian Commodity Exchange.

site_title: Finance firms have more Brexit preparation work to do: EBA
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) warns that finance firms have more Brexit preparation work to do, with just three weeks left before the UK's departure. Some firms still lack contingency plans, and payment firms may not receive EU authorisation in time. The EBA also highlights risks, including deteriorating loan quality due to Covid-19 fallout and climate change exposures. Major banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, are moving assets and employees to the EU as Brexit talks near their conclusion.

site_title: Explosion at Saudi port hits oil tanker as Red Sea attacks mount
summary: A ship, BW Rhine, was hit by an explosion at the Saudi Arabian port of Jeddah, with no casualties reported. The incident occurred while the vessel was discharging refined products, and some oil may have escaped. The attack comes less than three weeks after an oil tanker was damaged in a possible attack at the Saudi terminal of Shuqaiq. The incident has raised concerns about the security of the Red Sea, with Yemen's Houthi rebels, supported by Iran, suspected of being behind the attacks.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stock market sees significant fund flows, with NTT DC Reit's public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks edge down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks decline due to bank and healthcare sector drag. Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. Meanwhile, Indonesia detains an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and London's Heathrow considers increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: CDL to sell Penang hotel for RM75m
summary: CDL plans to sell its 318-room Copthorne Orchid Hotel & Resort Penang in Malaysia for RM75 million (S$25 million), with a pre-tax gain expected of S$9.2 million. The sale is part of CDL's strategy to divest non-core assets and recycle capital. This is the group's third disposal since 2020, with combined sales value of S$104.8 million, resulting in pre-tax divestment gains of S$50.3 million.

images.alt_text: The divestment of Copthorne Orchid is in line with the group's strategy to extract value from its non-core hotel assets, streamline its portfolio and recycle capital following the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: CVC buys Myanmar's largest telecom tower company for US$700m
summary: CVC Capital Partners has agreed to purchase Myanmar's largest telecom tower company, Irrawaddy Green Towers, valued at approximately US$700 million. This marks CVC's first investment in Myanmar and the second-largest deal involving Myanmar assets. The acquisition is a significant move for the global private equity firm, expanding its presence in the South-east Asian market.

site_title: US$ falls; pound up 1.5% on renewed hopes for Brexit deal
summary: The US dollar fell to two-year lows due to renewed hopes for a Brexit deal, fiscal stimulus in the US, and progress on Covid-19 vaccines, lifting riskier currencies like the pound, which gained 1.5% after the UK and EU agreed to continue Brexit talks and a possible deal.

site_title: Bank of China sues BP, Hin Leong's Lim family over oil deals
summary: Bank of China has sued BP Plc in Singapore, alleging the oil company was involved in a "fictitious purchase scheme conspiracy" with collapsed trader Hin Leong. The Chinese bank is seeking US$125.7 million from BP, as well as US$187.2 million from Hin Leong's founder, Lim Oon Kuin, and his children. BP denies the allegations and will defend its position. The lawsuit is part of efforts by Hin Leong's creditors to recover funds from the insolvent firm, which has US$3.5 billion in outstanding debt.

site_title: BT Mark To Market: Dividend-yielding stocks and Reits (Ep 2)
summary: BT Mark To Market podcast discusses investing in dividend-yielding stocks and Reits in Singapore. Senior correspondent Ben Paul explores the popularity of high dividend stocks, the importance of understanding retained earnings, and the decline of Singtel as a reliable dividend-paying stock. Paul also provides insights on where to find opportunities in the market and a simple approach to investing in Reits. The podcast emphasizes the need for Singapore investors to consult with a financial adviser before making any investment decisions.

site_title: Senegalese bemused by Akon's plans to build futuristic city
summary: Singer Akon plans to build a futuristic city in Senegal, dubbed Akon City, with a $6 billion budget. The city, designed by architect Hussein Bakri, will feature shiny, pinkish buildings and include a parking lot for flying cars. However, locals are skeptical due to unanswered questions about land rights, financing, and feasibility. Promises include a training center, jobs for youth, and improved schools and health services, but experts warn that past projects have been abandoned due to inadequate funding. Residents are excited but concerned about the project's impact on the environment and local culture.

site_title: Cyclical stocks linked to domestic consumption expected to benefit
summary: Singapore's transition to Phase 3 of its reopening plan, starting Dec 28, is expected to boost cyclical stocks linked to domestic consumption, particularly banks, F&B, and telcos. Analysts forecast a 5.5% GDP growth in 2021, driven by improved private consumption and business confidence. Cyclical stocks such as banks, construction, and property firms are expected to gain momentum, while F&B and telcos are seen as top picks. Investors are advised to take a cautious approach towards vaccine-dependent stocks, but high-yielding stocks with growth prospects can provide a hedge against economic risks.

site_title: Yunnan Energy diversifies into construction materials trading
summary: Yunnan Energy International, a mainboard-listed company, has started a new business in trading and supplying construction materials and medical devices. The company's wholly-owned subsidiary, Shenzhen Yunneng International Supply Chain Limited, entered into agreements with two Chinese companies to sell and purchase construction materials. This new venture aims to diversify and improve the company's business operations and financial position, with the goal of generating higher returns for shareholders.

site_title: Freighter conversions on the rise amid e-commerce boom, falling plane values
summary: Airlines and leasing firms are converting older passenger jets into freighters in response to the e-commerce boom, betting on sustained freight demand. Companies like ST Engineering and Israel Aerospace Industries are capitalizing on the trend. The value of used planes has fallen amid the pandemic, creating an opportunity for P2F conversion companies. This shift is expected to continue as freight demand is seen as a stable investment, despite the decline in plane values. The conversion process is a financial bet on the long-term strength of the freight market.

site_title: Aedge ends trading debut at S$0.21; 5% above IPO price
summary: Aedge Group's debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board closed at S$0.21, 5% above its IPO price of S$0.20, with 2.6 million shares changing hands. The company raised S$3.2 million, exceeding its target of S$1.7 million. CEO Poh Soon Keng stated that funds will be used to acquire property, plant and equipment, develop new security solutions, and hire new staff. The company's market capitalisation stands at S$21.2 million, with a price-to-earnings ratio of 59 times.

site_title: Germany likely to be under lockdown until early next year
summary: Germany is unlikely to lift its coronavirus lockdown early next year, Chancellor Angela Merkel's top aide Helge Braun said, citing stubbornly high infection numbers. The lockdown, which will last until January 10, will restrict most stores, including non-essential shops, and some services. The decision was made to bring the pandemic under control and prevent a recession, with the economy forecast to suffer its worst recession since World War II this year.

images.alt_text: Under Germany's stricter rules, only essential shops such as supermarkets and pharmacies, as well as banks, are to remain open from Dec 16.

site_title: Asian corporates risk taking USD funding for granted
summary: Asian corporations may be taking USD funding for granted due to the recent surge in dollar-liquidity, but geopolitical tensions could pose a significant risk. Clifford Lee, DBS's global head of fixed income, warns that Asian businesses lack a sense of "paranoia" about the potential unwinding of US dollar access. Despite this, dollar-liquidity has funded Asian growth, with Asian-based investors playing a significant role in recent landmark bond issuances. However, tensions between the US and China, as well as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, may lead to a liquidity crunch, forcing Asian issuers to seek alternative funding sources.

site_title: Stage 2 of Thomson-East Coast Line to be delayed by another six months
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced that Stage 2 of the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) will be delayed by six months, pushing its completion to the third quarter of 2021. The delay is due to a software glitch in the signalling system's network component, which prompted a review of the rail system software. Other major projects, including stages three and four of the TEL, the Cross Island Line, and the North South Corridor, will also be delayed by up to a year due to Covid-19-induced factors.

site_title: Draft EU law could see tech giants fined 10% of revenue
summary: The European Union is set to unveil draft legislation that could fine tech giants up to 10% of their revenue for competition violations. The Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act aim to regulate internet giants, designating them as "gatekeepers" subject to strict conditions. Companies like Google, Facebook, Apple, and Amazon are expected to be affected, with the EU considering banning them from the market if they breach laws endangering security. The proposals will undergo a complex ratification process, with EU member states and companies influencing the final law.

site_title: Huntington Bancshares to buy TCF Financial for US$6b
summary: Huntington Bancshares is acquiring TCF Financial in an all-stock deal valued at nearly $6 billion, boosting its assets to around $168 billion. The merger will position Huntington closer to regional competitors Fifth Third Bancorp and KeyCorp. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter, with both companies believing the economy is recovering. Huntington's CEO Steve Steinour stated that the merger will enable the companies to achieve scale and accomplish things they couldn't independently.

site_title: Indonesia poised for strong economic rebound in 2021
summary: Indonesia is poised for a strong economic rebound in 2021, with its GDP forecast to soar by 7.9%, according to the OECD. The country's effective testing, tracking, and isolation programs, as well as rapid vaccination distribution, are contributing to its expected growth. Indonesia's stimulus package, which includes a $47.6 billion investment, is helping small and medium-sized enterprises stay afloat. Analysts predict that the economy will expand by 4-5% in 2021, with some warning of potential debt and regulatory challenges.

images.alt_text: On the economic front, Indonesia is likely to be the fastest-rising economy in Asean in 2021 and the second-fastest in the world after China, according to an OECD report.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as travel stocks rally on vaccine roll-out
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as travel stocks surged following the launch of a nationwide Covid-19 vaccine campaign. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.26%, the S&P 500 gained 0.32%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.56%. Alexion Pharmaceuticals jumped after a bumper buyout offer from AstraZeneca, while travel stocks rallied. The gains pushed the markets higher despite potential US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: World needs climate change surge in 2021
summary: The world needs a surge in climate change efforts in 2021 to meet the 1.5-degree temperature cap, requiring a 7.6% annual reduction in carbon emissions through 2030. UN Secretary-General António Guterres warned of a catastrophic temperature rise of over 3 degrees Celsius if no action is taken. Despite many countries pledging to the 1.5-degree target, the current trajectory makes it difficult to achieve this goal, emphasizing the need for a significant change in international behavior in the next decade to limit temperature rises.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary-General António Guterres warned that "if we don't change course, we may be headed for a catastrophic temperature rise of more than 3 degrees Celsius this century".

site_title: Renaissance United warns of half-year net loss
summary: Renaissance United, a MAINBOARD-LISTED utilities player, expects to report a net loss for its half-year ended Oct 31, primarily due to foreign currency translation impacts on its foreign-currency denominated subsidiaries. The results will be released by Dec 15. Shares closed unchanged at S$0.002 on the announcement.

site_title: Few bargains on offer as sovereign funds step up dealmaking
summary: Sovereign wealth funds have stepped up their private market investments after the Covid-19 crisis, with US$55.5 billion invested in private markets year to date, up from US$35 billion last year. Despite valuations barely budging, funds are scouting for higher returns in an ultra-low interest-rate environment. The number of investments has fallen by 10% to 274, but average deal sizes have held up, with sovereign funds participating in US$50.2 billion worth of private equity deals and US$14.7 billion worth of venture capital deals since April. High valuations may reflect investments in sectors like e-commerce and healthcare, raising questions about future returns.

site_title: Japan, Korea struggling to curb surging virus cases
summary: Japan and South Korea are struggling to curb surging COVID-19 cases. Japan suspended its "Go To Travel" subsidy program due to economic concerns, while South Korea closed schools and considered stricter curbs. South Korea reported a record 1,030 new infections, and Japan reported over 3,000 new cases, with Tokyo and Hokkaido seeing the worst outbreaks. Both countries are relying on testing, social distancing, and masks to control the spread, with few expecting significant vaccine shipments in the coming weeks.

site_title: Pharmaceutical firms to manufacture vaccine in Singapore
summary: Singapore has made arrangements with pharmaceutical companies to manufacture vaccines, as part of its Covid-19 vaccination plans. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the move in a televised address, stating the government's efforts to facilitate clinical trials and drug development in the country. This development aims to support the global fight against the pandemic and establish Singapore as a hub for vaccine manufacturing.

site_title: Vaccination plan a boost for growth in 2021, but border reopening remains key
summary: Singapore's vaccination plan is expected to boost growth in 2021, with the start of Phase 3 on Dec 28 potentially leading to a modest uplift. Economists predict exports and manufacturing will lead the recovery, particularly if a Covid-19 vaccine is distributed in developed markets. However, border reopening remains crucial, and the pace of vaccination in neighboring countries, such as Indonesia and India, may moderate Singapore's growth. The government has set aside S$1 billion for vaccines, with priority given to long-term residents, healthcare workers, and the elderly.

site_title: The yuan will keep rising. Here are 10 reasons why
summary: China's yuan is expected to continue rising due to several factors. The country has recognized the geopolitical benefits of attaining reserve currency status and has made significant progress in increasing transparency and market openness. The yuan has gained more than 4% on a real basis since 2014, outperforming other reserve currencies. China's economy is expected to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 2% growth rate predicted for 2020. The country's foreign trade surplus with the US is likely to be around $310 billion, and its share of global exports is at its highest on record. China's asset management and bond markets are also becoming more accessible to foreign investors. The digital yuan is expected to play a significant role in trading relations with Asian partners, particularly in the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: Sats tops Singapore companies in Asean corporate governance
summary: Sats has topped Singapore companies in the 2019 Asean Corporate Governance Scorecard (ACGS) with a score of 119.7 out of 130 points, jumping 10 places from its 11th position in 2017. Singapore companies averaged 88.3 points, the highest score to date, while Thai companies had the highest average score of 96.6 points. The ACGS assesses factors such as shareholder rights, disclosure, and board responsibilities, and aims to increase the attractiveness of Asean to global investors.

site_title: NauticAWT now a cash company, given a year to acquire new business
summary: NauticAWT, a Catalist-listed company, has become a cash company after selling its subsidiary, and now has a year to acquire a new business or risk delisting. The company has a 35% stake in Rich Restaurant Capital Limited and is considering increasing its stake to gain majority control. NauticAWT's CEO and executive director, John Gronbech, has resigned after nine years with the company to manage the affairs of its sold subsidiary. The company intends to apply to the Singapore Exchange to maintain its listing status.

site_title: Lockdown on Malaysia's Top Glove facilities lifted
summary: Malaysian authorities lifted a month-long lockdown on Top Glove Corp dormitories, allowing 14 factories to resume operations and 14 others to reopen in stages. The decision came after 5,000 employees tested positive for Covid-19, with the first death reported among employees from Covid-19. The government cited no pending test results and completed quarantine for negative workers. Top Glove shares fell amid reports of increasing Covid-19 vaccine availability and poor working conditions for migrant workers, leading to the firing of a Nepali employee.

site_title: Independent auditor issues disclaimer of opinion on Sunvic Chemical's financial statements
summary: Independent auditor Foo Kon Tan LLP issued a disclaimer of opinion on Sunvic Chemical Holdings' financial statements for 2019 due to material uncertainties casting doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The auditor noted discrepancies in corporate guarantees and significant net current liabilities. Sunvic Chemical has recorded cash outflows and had only 7.8 million yuan in cash and cash equivalents. The company's shares have been suspended on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list since January 14, 2020.

site_title: China watchdog fines Alibaba, Tencent unit
summary: China's antitrust watchdog fined Alibaba 500,000 yuan for failing to declare a 2017 acquisition of a department store chain, and China Literature was also fined for a 2018 deal. The regulator is reviewing a Tencent-led merger of DouYu and Huya, which could create a Chinese game streaming leader. Beijing's increased scrutiny of tech giants has raised concerns of a broader crackdown on the country's largest firms, with shares of Alibaba and Tencent extending losses.

site_title: LMIRT unitholders give green light for Lippo Mall Puri purchase, rights issue
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) unitholders approved the acquisition of a majority of strata titles in a West Jakarta mall for 3.5 trillion rupiah (S$336.5 million). The deal, initially opposed by some unitholders, received 78.6% of the total votes cast. This allows LMIRT to proceed with the purchase despite the recent opposition.

site_title: WTO fails to agree to rules to stop overfishing
summary: World Trade Organization (WTO) negotiators failed to reach a deal by the year-end deadline to cut government subsidies contributing to overfishing, according to WTO Chairman Santiago Wills. The deadline was set by UN targets in 2015, with the aim of striking a deal by 2020. Despite progress, Wills cited time lost due to the coronavirus pandemic as a major obstacle. A deal was considered closer than ever, but Wills expressed confidence in a future agreement. The WTO will continue to work on the issue.

site_title: Singapore and France working on travel green lane for short-term business and official trips
summary: Singapore and France are working on a travel green lane for short-term business and official trips, aiming to strengthen bilateral ties and enhance cooperation in areas such as food safety, sustainability, and digital economy. The framework has been agreed upon between French Minister Delegate Franck Riester and Singapore's Senior Minister of State Chee Hong Tat. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed by both countries will facilitate the exchange of knowledge and research cooperation to improve food safety standards.

site_title: AirAsia X to raise US$123m in rights issue, new shares
summary: AirAsia X proposes a US$123 million rights issue and share subscription to raise funds for debt restructuring. The airline aims to reduce its share capital by 99.9% to RM1.53 million, offsetting accumulated losses. The fundraising will be used to continue operations and potentially seek fresh funding from existing shareholders. A debt restructuring scheme, valued at S$15.3 billion, is a prerequisite for recapitalization and a comprehensive airline reset. The alternative is liquidation without returns to creditors.

site_title: Germany's Daimler to produce fully electric compact SUV in Hungary
summary: Daimler, a German luxury car brand, plans to start serial production of the EQB fully electric compact SUV in Hungary in the fourth quarter of 2021, following a 100 million euro investment. The move aims to secure 4,400 jobs in the central Hungarian town of Kecskemet, which has been struggling due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The investment is part of Hungary's efforts to boost its economy, which is heavily reliant on car manufacturing. This marks the first fully electric car to be produced in Hungary, with Daimler rival BMW also planning to produce electric vehicles in the country.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is set to start Phase 3 of its Covid-19 reopening on December 28, allowing groups of up to 8 people to gather, up from 5 currently. The government has secured over S$1 billion in vaccines, with the first shipment of Pfizer-BioNTech arriving by the end of the month. Migrant workers in some dorms will be allowed to access the community once a month under a pilot scheme.

site_title: Don't stockpile food, minister tells British shoppers
summary: The UK's business secretary, Alok Sharma, has reassured shoppers that food supplies will be maintained even if Britain leaves the EU without a trade deal. He advised against stockpiling food, saying that supply chains will still be in place. The British Retail Consortium has also warned of higher prices without a trade deal, with Tesco predicting price increases of 3-5%. However, Sharma believes the impact will be less than 2%, with some products potentially seeing a higher increase.

images.alt_text: British shoppers worried about the government failing to secure a post-Brexit trade deal with the European Union should not stockpile food, business secretary Alok Sharma said on Monday.

site_title: Muhyuddin may face showdown in final budget vote
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin may face a challenge to his leadership as opposition lawmakers, led by Anwar Ibrahim, plan to block the government's 2021 budget. The budget, totaling RM322.5 billion, is a record spending plan aimed at boosting the economy after the coronavirus pandemic. A successful opposition vote could lead to snap polls and a loss of confidence in Muhyiddin's leadership. The opposition bloc, including Umno lawmakers, has reportedly secured 113 votes, setting the stage for a showdown in parliament on Tuesday.

site_title: Migrant pay gap in rich countries was widening even before Covid-19
summary: Migrant workers in the world's richest economies are earning 12.6% less than national workers, with the gap widening due to the COVID-19 pandemic. A report by the International Labour Organization found that migrants in high-income countries are more likely to be in precarious work, with over a quarter on temporary contracts. The wage gap is also exacerbated by women migrant workers, who earn 21% less than their male national counterparts, with the gender pay gap being higher than the national average in surveyed countries.

site_title: Google services including Gmail, YouTube suffer major outage
summary: Google services, including Gmail and YouTube, experienced a major outage worldwide, preventing users from accessing these products from around 6:30 am New York time. The outage affected the US, UK, and Europe, with many services returning to normal after about an hour. Google confirmed the outage, stating that functionality was restored to the "vast majority" of users, but some remain affected. The cause of the outage remains unknown.

site_title: China sees new surge in pork prices with imports under scrutiny
summary: China has seen a surge in pork prices due to increased demand before the Lunar New Year and supply chain disruptions caused by a virus-linked crackdown on imports. Wholesale pork prices jumped 6% in the first week of December to 41.98 yuan (S$8.56) per kilogram, driven by concerns over the safety of imported meat. The crackdown has led to severe congestion at ports and predictions of a 30% decline in China's meat imports next year, potentially pushing up consumer inflation.

site_title: ManuLife to buy Aviva's Vietnam unit; enters into bank distribution pact
summary: British insurer Aviva is selling its Vietnamese business to Canadian insurer ManuLife Financial as part of its plan to exit non-core markets. The deal, valued at around £100 million, will increase ManuLife's net asset value and Solvency II surplus. ManuLife has also agreed a 16-year bancassurance partnership with VietinBank, boosting its presence in Asia's rapidly growing market. The deal is expected to be accretive to ManuLife's diluted core earnings per common share in 2022, bolstering its regional contribution.

site_title: Thai protesters to pause for now and return next year
summary: Thai protesters, led by Arnon Nampa, will pause their demonstrations for the New Year's holidays and return stronger next year.
