The movement, which has challenged the Thai establishment, initially sought the removal of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha but later demanded reforms to curb the monarchy's powers. Protesters also aim to rewrite the constitution. While a government spokesman said protesters may gather again if peaceful, the king emphasized the importance of guarding the nation and avoiding "robbers" or harm to the country. The protesters will return with "more intensity and bigger turnout" next year.

site_title: Codemasters agrees to US$1.2b counterbid from Electronic Arts
summary: Codemasters, a UK-based video game producer, has agreed to a US$1.2 billion bid from Electronic Arts, surpassing a US$956 million offer from Take-Two Interactive Software. The deal values Codemasters at 604 pence per share, a 14.4% increase over Take-Two's offer. Shares in Codemasters rose 19% following the announcement. Analysts remain unconvinced, citing Take-Two's stronger strategic rationale, but the gaming sector's boom due to the pandemic has driven up video game maker values.

site_title: Stamford Land deputy executive chairman retires
summary: STAMFORD Land Corporation's deputy executive chairman and director, Ow Cheo Guan, has retired at 72. He is the brother of executive chairman Ow Chio Kiat and uncle to CEO Ow Yew Heng. Ow Cheo Guan held a direct interest of 3.73 million shares (0.48%) and an indirect interest of 26.4 million shares (3.37%) in the group. Following his retirement, shares of Stamford Land closed up 4.76% at S$0.33 on Monday.

site_title: Pilot test in Q1 to allow migrant workers in some dorms to access community
summary: The Singapore government plans to allow migrant workers in some dormitories to access the community once a month, subject to compliance with COVID-19 testing and safety measures. As part of a pilot scheme, migrant workers will be allowed to leave their dormitories for one day a month, starting in Q1 next year. This move aims to minimize the risk of COVID-19 resurgence among migrant workers, who make up over 320,000 of Singapore's population.

site_title: Dubai sees surge in UK bookings after opening travel corridor
summary: Dubai Airports reported a surge in UK bookings, with December bookings expected to be double the previous months' due to the travel corridor between the UK and Dubai. The travel hub will not require vaccination for entry, but may consider it in the future. The airport has seen a significant increase in airline traffic, with 65% of airlines from the beginning of 2020 returning to Dubai.

site_title: Civmec secures contracts worth A$140 million
summary: Civmec Limited secured contracts worth A$140 million, including a major contract for the Iron Bridge Magnetite Project in Australia. The project, a joint venture between Fortescue Metals Group and Formosa Steel IB, will employ approximately 400 people on site. Civmec is already contracted to deliver site civil concrete works and supply steel structures and modules. Shares closed unchanged at S$0.39 following the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.44% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 26,389.52, due to global worries about virus infections outweighing vaccine optimism. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.66% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.07%. The decline was attributed to concerns about bank and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade tensions remained a focus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 21.84 points lower at 1,662.74 on Monday, with 964 losers outnumbering 461 gainers. Volume reached 11.884 billion lots worth RM7.203 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares cheer Brexit trade talks extension
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Monday after the UK and EU agreed to extend trade talks, keeping hopes for a deal alive to govern $1 trillion in trade. The FTSE 100 was flat, offset by a slide in AstraZeneca, which fell 6.3% after announcing its $39 billion acquisition of Alexion Pharmaceuticals. The extension aims to secure a deal to avoid tariffs and quotas on trade between the two sides.

site_title: Singapore must take 'calculated risk' of reopening borders: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has announced the country will reopen its borders on December 28 in a controlled and safe manner to preserve its status as an international hub. Despite Covid-19 still raging worldwide, Lee emphasized that trade and travel are essential to the country's livelihoods. He acknowledged the risk of imported cases but stated that the government will take precautions to prevent new outbreaks. Singaporeans must also remain vigilant against community circulation of the virus.

site_title: Investor optimism lifts Singapore shares, STI up 1.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.3% on Monday, driven by investor optimism over positive news locally and globally. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 36.44 points to close at 2,858.14. The country is set to enter its next phase of recovery on December 28, with gatherings of up to eight people allowed. The STI is expected to reverse its underperformance relative to Asian peers in 2021, according to RHB analyst Shekhar Jaiswal, who cited improvement in economic activity and private consumption.

site_title: Finnish nuclear operator plans Dec 17 restart after reactor trip
summary: Finnish nuclear operator Teollisuuden Voima Oyj (TVO) plans to restart its Olkiluoto 2 plant on Dec 17 after a reactor trip last week. The shutdown was caused by hot water dissolving filter particles in the reactor water clean-up system, raising radiation levels to three to four times normal levels. The event, rated zero on the INES scale, did not affect nuclear safety or radiation doses. TVO will conduct a detailed investigation and prepare an application for regulatory permission to restart power production.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Nanofilm with 'add', S$5.52 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Nanofilm Technologies International with an "add" rating and a target price of S$5.52, citing the company's proprietary FCVA coating technology, sole supplier status to major customers, and environmentally friendly production process. Analysts expect strong growth, with a 34% compound annual growth rate in revenue and 35% CAGR in earnings per share. The brokerage believes Nanofilm is poised to benefit from secular growth trends such as the Internet of Things and 5G adoption.

site_title: EQT offers to buy Recipharm of Sweden in US$2.1b deal
summary: Private equity firm EQT has offered to acquire Swedish pharmaceuticals company Recipharm for $2.1 billion in a deal that values the company at 220 kronor (S$34.8) per share. The bid, which is conditional on shareholder approval, comes as the company has seen its share price rise 36% this year following positive news about its Covid-19 treatment. EQT already holds 25.7% of Recipharm's shares and 74.3% of its votes, and the deal would be fully financed by a combination of funds from its EQT IX fund.

site_title: Over S$1b to secure enough vaccines by Q3 2021; all citizens, long-term residents to get free vaccinations
summary: Singapore has allocated S$1 billion to secure enough COVID-19 vaccines by Q3 2021, making them free for all citizens and long-term residents. The first shipment of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines is expected to arrive by the end of this month, with other vaccines arriving in the coming months. This move aims to provide sufficient vaccines for the entire population, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stating that the country is one of the first to obtain the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.

site_title: HSA grants interim authorisation for Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine in Singapore
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) has granted interim authorisation for the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine in Singapore for the prevention of Covid-19. The Expert Committee on Covid-19 Vaccination has reviewed the vaccine's safety and efficacy data and is satisfied with its safety and efficacy. The committee urges medically eligible persons to be vaccinated, with vaccinations starting with groups at greater risk, such as healthcare workers and the elderly, though remaining voluntary.

site_title: What a US$32m dinosaur can tell us about this year's art auctions
summary: This year's top art auction results, totaling US$408 million, are a far cry from the record-breaking US$605 million in 2019. The market's performance has been shaped by the pandemic, with private sales and online luxury sales booming. The top lots, including a 67-million-year-old Tyrannosaurus Rex, reveal a market where mega prices can have a temporary halo effect on lower-priced works. While the art market has survived Covid-19, it may not be thriving, and the lack of top-tier work may be pulling down total sales.

site_title: Kawasaki Heavy, Iwatani, Fortescue to develop supply chain of green hydrogen
summary: Japan's Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Iwatani Corp have signed a memorandum of understanding with Australian miner Fortescue Metals Group to develop a supply chain of "green" hydrogen. The goal is to create integrated liquefied hydrogen supply chains using renewable energy and transporting the hydrogen by ship for delivery and distribution in Japan. The move aims to accelerate Japan's hydrogen development and achieve its target of becoming carbon neutral by 2050.

site_title: Phase 3 of Covid-19 reopening starts Dec 28, groups of up to 8 allowed to gather
summary: Singapore is set to enter Phase 3 of its Covid-19 reopening on December 28, allowing groups of up to eight people to gather, up from five currently. Capacity limits on public areas and places of worship will also be eased. The move is attributed to national efforts to control the pandemic, with zero local transmission cases on most days and a strong economy. However, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that the battle is far from won and urged Singaporeans to remain cautious and vigilant.

site_title: 'Demon Slayer' nears Japan movie history, boosts economy with resilience message
summary: The film "Demon Slayer" is on track to become Japan's top-grossing film, surpassing "Spirited Away" with a total of 30.28 billion yen (S$388 million) in ticket sales. The movie's success can be attributed to its message of resilience and its nod to Japanese traditions, resonating with fans during the coronavirus pandemic. The film's merchandise and related goods have also boosted the economy, with an estimated economic impact of at least 270 billion yen. The film's popularity has also led to a surge in sales of related products, such as toys and canned coffee.

site_title: Hot stock: Soilbuild Reit rises 5.5% on buyout offer
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit's units rose 5.5% on Monday after its sponsor and Blackstone proposed a buyout offer at 55 Singapore cents per unit, a premium of 34.5% over the one-month VWAP. The offeror, Clay Holdings III, is indirectly owned by Soilbuild Group chairman Lim Chap Huat and Blackstone Real Estate. The proposed buyout aims to allow the Reit manager to access capital markets more flexibly and delist from the exchange, citing limited acquisition capabilities due to high DPU yield.

site_title: Amazon's Zoox unveils robotaxi for future ride-hailing service
summary: Zoox, an Amazon-owned self-driving startup, unveiled a fully autonomous electric vehicle, the robotaxi, designed for ride-hailing services. The vehicle can carry up to four passengers, travels at 75mph, and has a 16-hour run time on a single charge. Zoox plans to launch an app-based ride-hailing service in cities like San Francisco and Las Vegas, with affordable and competitive prices. The service is expected to launch in the future, with no specific timeline mentioned, and will be available in other countries as well.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on surging domestic Covid-19 cases
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.28% on Monday as domestic Covid-19 cases surged, outweighing hopes for economic recovery. The benchmark Kospi closed at 2,762.20, with schools ordered to close in the capital Seoul due to the outbreak. Foreigners sold 360.2 billion won worth of shares, and the won weakened to 1,091.8 per US dollar. President Moon Jae-in called for steps to help exporters affected by the won's strength.

site_title: Wild winds, huge seas and rain batter Australian tourist spots
summary: Wild winds, huge seas, and rain battered Australian tourist spots, particularly in northern New South Wales state and the northeast coast. Beaches at popular destinations such as Main Beach at Byron Bay have largely disappeared, with concrete walkways collapsing into the sea. Authorities warn of coastal erosion, hazardous rain, and huge waves, urging motorists to stay off the roads. The extreme weather is attributed to a low-pressure system off the southern Queensland coast, exacerbated by a La Nina weather phenomenon expected to bring a wetter-than-usual summer.

site_title: Iron ore slumps as speculative buying dissipates
summary: Iron ore futures slumped on Monday, with the Dalian benchmark retreating from 1,000 yuan a tonne due to dissipating speculative buying. The May iron ore contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange ended down 3.2% at 966 yuan, while the January contract on the Singapore Exchange dropped 3.7% to US$152 a tonne. Analysts attribute the price decline to iron ore hitting overbought levels, with some predicting a fair value between US$90 and US$110 a tonne.

site_title: Indian farmers step up pressure with hunger strike against reforms
summary: Indian farmers have begun a one-day hunger strike against agricultural reforms they claim threaten their livelihoods. The reforms, enacted in September, loosen rules around the sale and pricing of farm produce, leading small growers to fear price support will be lost. Despite six rounds of talks failing to resolve the issue, the government remains determined to liberalize the sector. The protest, led by farmers from Punjab and Haryana, aims to step up pressure on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government to withdraw the legislation.

site_title: CDL to sell Penang hotel for RM75m
summary: CDL plans to sell its Penang hotel, Copthorne Orchid Hotel & Resort, for RM75 million (S$25 million) to Malaysia-listed Ivory Properties Group Berhad. The sale, part of CDL's strategy to divest non-core assets, is expected to result in a pre-tax gain of S$9.2 million next year. This is CDL's third non-core hotel asset disposal since the start of the year, with a combined sales value of S$104.8 million.

site_title: Once upon a time: Pakistan's fabled storytellers fade away
summary: Pakistan's traditional storytellers are largely fading away as younger generations turn to social media and video games for entertainment. The art of oral storytelling, once a staple of the Silk Road hub of Peshawar, is being replaced by modern forms of media. Storytellers like Mohammad Naseem, who have passed down tales of history and culture, are struggling to find an audience, with many of their children and friends no longer interested in hearing their stories. The loss of this traditional art form is seen as a cultural loss, with experts warning that the stories and history of the land may soon be lost forever.

site_title: Bird flu spreads to 10th Japanese prefecture
summary: Japan's bird flu outbreak has spread to 10th prefecture, affecting over 20% of the country's 47 prefectures, with 11,000 birds to be slaughtered. The outbreak, which started in Shiga prefecture, has led to record cullings of around 3 million birds. The virus originated in wild birds, with two distinct H5N8 epidemics in eastern Asia and Europe. The World Health Organization has issued an alert to African health authorities for heightened surveillance to prevent the spread of the European strain.

images.alt_text: Japan's worst bird flu outbreak on record spread to new farms and now affects more than 20 per cent of the country's 47 prefectures, with officials ordering cullings after more poultry deaths.

site_title: Top Glove reports worker death due to Covid-19, first since outbreak at firm
summary: Top Glove, Malaysia's largest glove maker, reported the first worker death due to Covid-19 since an outbreak at its facilities. A 29-year-old worker from Nepal died on Saturday due to Covid-19 pneumonia with lung fibrosis after contracting the virus at the company's manufacturing facility in Klang. The outbreak, which involved over 5,000 workers, was detected on November 2 and led to strict movement controls and factory shutdowns. Workers reported difficulty maintaining social distancing and cramped dormitory conditions.

site_title: LMIRT unitholders give green light for Lippo Mall Puri purchase, rights issue
summary: LMIRT unitholders approved a deal to acquire majority strata titles in a West Jakarta mall for 3.5 trillion rupiah (S$336.5 million) from its sponsor, despite recent opposition from some unitholders. The acquisition, valued at 3.5 trillion rupiah, will be funded through a US$281 million rights issue and a loan of up to S$40 million. The deal has been approved by 78.6% of unitholders, with minority unitholders showing confidence in the asset's long-term value.

site_title: Singapore hotels drop leisure bookings after being designated as SHN facilities
summary: Singapore hotels have begun canceling leisure bookings to accommodate guests required to serve their stay-home notice (SHN). At least two hotels, Naumi Hotel Singapore and Amara Singapore, have notified guests of canceled bookings due to being designated as SHN facilities. The Singapore Tourism Board has been contacted for comment on the matter, but no further information is available. This shift in bookings highlights the ongoing impact of COVID-19 restrictions on the city-state's hospitality industry.

site_title: Explosion rocks Singapore-flagged tanker off Saudi port
summary: An explosion occurred on a Singapore-flagged oil tanker, BW Rhine, off the Saudi port city of Jeddah on Monday, according to the vessel's owner. The blast, which caused a fire, is believed to have been caused by an external source while the tanker was discharging cargo. No group has claimed responsibility, but it comes amid increased cross-border attacks by Iran-backed Huthi rebels in neighboring Yemen. The incident is the latest in a series of attacks on energy infrastructure in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Google delays return to office and eyes 'flexible work week'
summary: Google has delayed its return to office until September 2021, allowing employees to work from home until then. The company is also testing a "flexible workweek" model, where employees will work at least three days a week in the office and others from home. CEO Sundar Pichai stated that the goal is to improve productivity, collaboration, and well-being, citing a hypothesis that a flexible work model will lead to greater benefits. This decision extends Google's remote work period, which was previously set to begin in July.

images.alt_text: As part of the plan, Google's employees would be expected to work at least three days a week in the office while working from home the other days.

site_title: Reddit to buy TikTok rival Dubsmash
summary: Reddit is set to acquire short-video platform Dubsmash, marking its entry into the space dominated by Chinese-owned TikTok. The acquisition, involving a combination of cash and stock, was announced without disclosing financial terms. Dubsmash's team, including co-founders, will join Reddit, and the platform will maintain its own brand and tools. This move follows similar expansions by Snapchat and Facebook, as social media companies seek to capitalize on the popularity of short-video services.

site_title: Health centre water crisis increasing virus risk: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that one in four health centres worldwide lack access to water, putting 1.8 billion people at increased risk of contracting COVID-19. The lack of basic amenities endangers patients and staff, and the WHO and UNICEF found that half of healthcare centres in least-developed countries have no access to drinking water, a quarter to water for hygiene, and three in five lack basic sanitation services. Providing basic water services would cost around $1 per inhabitant, while maintaining facilities would cost $0.20 each year.

site_title: Vietnam leadership wrangling heats up as Communist Party meets
summary: Vietnam's ruling Communist Party is holding a week-long meeting to discuss leadership and policy for the next five years. General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, who has led an anti-corruption drive, may retain an important role despite health concerns. Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc is also vying for a second term, but faces competition from other candidates. Analysts predict a more unpredictable outcome, with potential candidates overage and factional infighting. The meeting's outcome is expected to maintain Vietnam's current trajectory, with no significant changes in leadership.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were five new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore, all of which were imported, bringing the total to 58,325. The cases, comprising four work permit holders and one short-term visit pass holder, were asymptomatic and detected through proactive screening. No new community cases or cases from worker's dormitories were reported, maintaining a low number of new cases. Two cases were discharged, with 58,195 patients fully recovered and 22 patients remaining in hospital.

site_title: Singapore-based tech startup Appboxo raises US$1.1m in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based tech startup Appboxo has secured US$1.1 million in seed funding from FF APAC Scout, 500 Durians fund, Plug and Play Ventures, and Antler. Established in 2019, Appboxo provides integration software allowing users to launch miniapps within native super apps. The startup plans to use the funding to scale its platform and develop its technology, adding new miniapps in travel, e-commerce, finance, and lifestyle industries. Appboxo counts major companies such as Booking.com and Klook as partners, aiming to enable any app to become a super app.

site_title: Australia: Financials lift shares on hopes of vaccine-led recovery
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,660.20 on hopes of a vaccine-led economic recovery, driven by gains in the financials sector. US stock futures gained 0.5% after the delivery of Pfizer and BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine started in the US. Tech stocks, led by Afterpay's 8.8% gain, also contributed to the rise. However, miners, energy stocks, and healthcare firms weighed on the index, with CSL falling 1.7%. The gains were limited by the healthcare sector's pressure following Australia's halted Covid-19 vaccine program.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on sound business survey
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday after the Bank of Japan's business confidence survey showed improvement for the second consecutive quarter. The Nikkei 225 index advanced 0.30% to 26,732.44, while the Topix index climbed 0.48% to 1,790.52. This marks the second straight quarter of improvement in business confidence, indicating a positive outlook for the Japanese economy.

site_title: Chinese dams under US scrutiny in Mekong rivalry
summary: The US has launched a project, the Mekong Dam Monitor, to track water levels at Chinese dams on the Mekong river, amid a rivalry with China. The 4,350-km-long waterway is crucial for 60 million people in downstream nations. China has dismissed US research claiming dams retain water to harm downstream nations, and has agreed to share water data with the Mekong River Commission. The monitor uses satellite data to show how dams affect natural flows and will be open to the public in near real-time.

site_title: MassMutual's Bitcoin foray signals widening demand: JPMorgan
summary: Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co (MassMutual) has invested $100 million in Bitcoin, indicating the growing demand for the cryptocurrency among institutional investors. According to JPMorgan strategists, this move signals a shift towards Bitcoin adoption by insurance firms and pension funds, with the potential for significant additional demand if 1% of their assets are allocated to the cryptocurrency. This could result in an additional $600 billion in demand, significantly expanding Bitcoin's market capitalization from its current $356 billion.

site_title: Apple probing if Wistron facility in India flouted supplier rules: Economic Times
summary: Apple is investigating whether its Taiwanese contractor Wistron Corp violated supplier guidelines at a violence-hit iPhone manufacturing facility in India. The facility, near Bengaluru, was attacked by workers upset about working hours and payments, resulting in damaged property and detained individuals. Wistron, which supplies Apple with iPhone 7 and iPhone SE devices, has stated that it abides by the law and is cooperating with authorities. Apple will examine if there were any discrepancies in wages agreed and paid to the staff, according to supplier guidelines.

site_title: Falling plane values, e-commerce rise fuels boom in converting passenger planes to freighters
summary: Airlines and leasing firms are converting older passenger jets into freighters amid the pandemic, betting on a boom in e-commerce. The value of used planes has fallen by 20% to 47% since the start of the year, making conversions more attractive. Cirium predicts a 36% rise in P2F conversions globally in 2021 and 2022, with companies like Air Canada, S7 Group, and CDB Aviation ordering conversions. The conversions are a financial bet that air freight demand will remain strong, and the airline industry estimates it will take until 2024 for passenger traffic to recover.

site_title: China fines Alibaba, Tencent for failing to report past deals to anti-trust regulators
summary: China's market regulator fined Alibaba Group, Tencent Holdings-backed China Literature, and Shenzhen Hive Box 500,000 yuan each for failing to report deals properly to anti-trust regulators. The fines were issued after reviewing deals, including Alibaba's deal with Intime Retail and China Literature's acquisition of New Classics Media. The regulator stated that the firms did not comply with reporting requirements, which is a violation of anti-trust laws. The fines are part of efforts to strengthen regulatory oversight and enforcement in the country's tech and media sectors.

site_title: Inspired by Mao, Wuhan river swimmers 'reborn' after virus lockdown
summary: In Wuhan, China, a city that was locked down for 76 days due to the coronavirus, residents have resumed their traditional river swimming after a long hiatus. Inspired by Mao Zedong, who famously swam in the Yangtze River in 1966, many locals, including 68-year-old Shen Peihua, have returned to their daily swims. The tradition, which predates Mao, is now being revived, with dozens of swimmers wading into the river's brown waters despite winter temperatures. The city's riverbank is also alive with people singing, dancing, and enjoying a romantic walk, a testament to the enduring power of this unique Wuhan tradition.

site_title: Credit Suisse blow-ups give untested CEO a crash course in risk
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein faces a crash course in risk management after inheriting losses from a series of scandals, including the Luckin Coffee accounting fraud and SoftBank deals. The bank has incurred significant losses, including a $450 million impairment on its stake in York Capital Management, and is at risk of a fourth-quarter loss. Gottstein has centralized risk and compliance in Zurich, simplified the organizational setup, and scaled back lending growth, but has shied away from more decisive moves. Analysts question whether the bank prioritized revenue growth over risk and compliance.

site_title: Deutsche Bank may eventually allow New York City staff to move elsewhere
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering allowing some of its 4,600 Manhattan staff to work from other US cities, amid the shift towards remote work following the Covid-19 pandemic. The bank's CEO, Christiana Riley, mentioned the possibility of cutting New York headcount by half in the next five years. Deutsche Bank expects to lower 2022 adjusted costs by 300 million euros due to the pandemic's impact on work habits. The lender has already allowed workers in New York to continue working from home until mid-2022.

site_title: Hin Leong's Lim family, BP sued for US$313m on oil deals
summary: Bank of China has sued BP Plc in Singapore for allegedly participating in a "fictitious purchase scheme" to maintain Hin Leong's liquidity. The bank claims BP was involved in US$125.7 million in fabricated oil deals. The lender also seeks US$187.2 million from Lim Oon Kuin and his children. This is part of efforts to recover losses from Hin Leong's collapse, one of the largest trading scandals in decades.

site_title: Gold inches down as vaccine rollout counters US stimulus hopes
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,836.08 per ounce as the rollout of a Covid-19 vaccine lifted riskier assets, overshadowing US stimulus hopes. Economists expect gold to rally in 2021 when vaccine optimism dies down and inflation expectations rise due to the US economy's large stimulus needs. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting starts on Tuesday, with investors betting on increased purchases of longer-dated Treasuries. Gold has gained 21% this year on near-zero interest rates and global stimulus.

site_title: China's new home prices rise 0.1% in November from October
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.1% in November from October, slowing the monthly growth pace, according to official data. This marks the second consecutive month of slowing growth. Prices rose 4.0% year-over-year, down from 4.3% in October. The government aims to curb financial risk by deleveraging the highly indebted property sector, which has recovered quickly from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Honda's UK output to resume on Monday after parts delays
summary: Honda's UK car production is set to resume on Monday after parts delays caused by transport-related issues at Britain's container ports, which have been disrupted by the Covid-19 pandemic and Brexit preparations. The production halt began on Wednesday and was expected to continue until Monday. Honda stated that full production operations will resume on Monday, Dec 14, at its British factory.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on hope vaccines will improve fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures reaching $50.05 a barrel, as hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine rollout and Brexit talks extension lifted fuel demand expectations. The US kicked off its vaccination campaign, and European countries continued lockdowns to curb the spread of the virus. Oil prices have rallied for six consecutive weeks, their longest stretch of gains since June. Investors are now waiting for Opec+ meetings to study market trends after their last decision to limit production.

site_title: Australian state says work from home is over, but employees still shun office
summary: Australia's most populous state, New South Wales, lifted its work-from-home order due to low Covid-19 numbers, but many companies plan to maintain flexible work arrangements. Despite the move, Sydney central business district occupancy remains at 45%, and employers expect a material increase in occupancy after three months. The change puts NSW ahead of other states in resuming pre-Covid arrangements, with only Victoria maintaining office restrictions.

images.alt_text: A work from home order to combat coronavirus in Australia's most populous state ended on Monday, a milestone for a country with very low Covid-19 numbers, but many companies plan to keep flexible work arrangements into 2021.

site_title: Sats comes out on top in latest Asean Corporate Governance Scorecard
summary: Sats has emerged as the top Singaporean company in the 2019 Asean Corporate Governance Scorecard (ACGS), scoring 119.7 out of 130 points. This marks a 10-place improvement from its 11th position in 2017. Singapore companies, on average, scored 88.3 out of 130 points, the highest score to date. The top 20 companies in Asean, with Malaysian companies dominating the list, were assessed based on a minimum score of 75% out of 130 points.

site_title: New Zealand aims to open to Australians in early 2021
summary: New Zealand aims to establish a travel bubble with Australia by April 2021, pending anti-coronavirus border measures. The move follows New Zealand's successful handling of the pandemic, which has resulted in just 25 deaths. To prevent overcrowding at border facilities in case of a major outbreak, New Zealand will consider arrangements for repatriating thousands of Australian visitors. The country has already announced plans for a travel bubble with the Cook Islands in the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: Jordan finds 'promising' gas finds near Iraq border
summary: Jordan's majority state-owned National Petroleum Company (NPC) has discovered "promising" new quantities of natural gas in the Risha gas field, near its eastern border with Iraq. The gas field, once considered a potential lifeline for the kingdom's energy needs, has shown promising results after a significant increase in drilling efforts, boosting quantities by at least 70%. The discovery aims to reduce Jordan's dependence on oil imports and fuel its power sector and industries, with the goal of securing nearly half of its electricity generation from local energy sources.

site_title: Australia to bring forward subsidy payment in push to keep refineries open
summary: Australia is bringing forward a payment to support its remaining oil refineries by six months to help them weather the financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The payment, worth A$83.5 million, will be made from January 1, 2021, rather than July 1, and will provide a minimum one cent payment per liter of fuel. The move aims to protect local jobs and fuel security, as well as shield motorists from higher prices, with refineries agreeing to operate at least until June 2021 to receive the payment.

site_title: Japan PM to decide on tourism campaign as approval rating plummets over virus
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga may restrict a travel subsidy program to combat coronavirus infections, which have worsened in regions like Hokkaido and Osaka. The country saw over 3,000 new infections for the first time in one day. Suga's approval rating has plummeted to 40% due to his handling of the pandemic, with public support eroding over other controversies. A meeting on Monday may expand the temporary halt to the travel campaign to Tokyo and Nagoya, further limiting the program.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.99 points, or 0.24%, to 1,680.59. The market saw a higher volume of 470.91 million lots worth RM240.07 million.

site_title: Hot stock: Top Glove loses 5.7% after report reveals Covid-19 whistleblower was fired
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest glovemaker, saw its shares plummet 5.7% after disclosing an employee died from Covid-19 and firing a whistleblower who shared photos of crowded factories without social distancing. The company has been under scrutiny for its handling of the pandemic, with over 5,000 infections reported in its Klang factories. Top Glove's net profit surged in its first quarter, but the company faces investigations into worker dormitory offenses and may face fines.

site_title: UK's Rightmove forecasts 4% rise in house prices for 2021
summary: Rightmove forecasts a 4% rise in UK house prices for 2021, despite the looming end of a tax break and rising unemployment. This growth rate is lower than the 6.6% increase seen in the past month. The housing market unexpectedly boomed after lockdown restrictions ended, driven by people seeking larger homes for remote work and taking advantage of a temporary tax reduction. The Bank of England has reported a surge in new mortgage approvals, contradicting economists' predictions of a 5% fall in house prices this year.

site_title: Saudi 'mini Ritz' corruption crackdown evokes awe, fear
summary: Saudi Arabia's anti-corruption crackdown, dubbed a "mini Ritz" operation, has resulted in dozens of arrests and the seizure of billions of dollars in cash, hidden in various locations. The campaign, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, aims to root out graft and increase revenue, with the government claiming to have recovered over $88 billion since 2017. While the crackdown has won public praise, human rights groups have raised concerns about unfair proceedings and the potential for political opponents to be targeted. The campaign's true motives remain unclear, with speculation suggesting it may be aimed at replenishing state coffers amid economic downturn.

site_title: The business of vaccines
summary: A recent article focuses on the business of vaccines, but no information about vaccines is given in the article. However, it does cover other global news, including a US tariff announcement that may impact Vietnam's garment industry and a Chinese economic slowdown, as well as stock market predictions and a Thai court case.

site_title: Singtel, UOBAM to launch mobile robo-adviser for individual investors
summary: Singtel and UOB Asset Management are collaborating to launch a mobile robo-adviser for individual investors through Singtel's Dash mobile wallet. The robo-adviser will provide personalized investment advice and enable users to invest in various asset classes. The service is expected to launch by mid-2021 and aims to make digital investments more accessible to consumers. The partnership is seen as a move to democratize access to digital investments and further Singtel's goals of digital and financial inclusion.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, reversing last week's decline, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.9% to 2,846.4. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 25, with shares of ComfortDelGro, DBS, OCBC, and UOB trading higher. Aedge Group made its trading debut on the Catalist board, with shares trading at 21.5 Singapore cents, an increase of 7.5% from its IPO price. This follows a choppy week of trading on Wall Street, where stocks finished mostly lower due to disappointment over the lack of progress on a US stimulus bill.

site_title: Gunman shot dead by police after New York Christmas concert
summary: A man opened fire near crowds gathered to watch a carol-singing event outside a New York church on Sunday, prompting police to shoot him dead. Three officers fired 15 shots, striking the man in the head, and recovered two guns and a bag with explosives. No one was injured during the incident, which occurred on the steps of the Cathedral of St John the Divine in Manhattan. The motive behind the attack is unclear.

site_title: UK manufacturers warn of 'knockout blow' from no-deal Brexit
summary: UK manufacturers warn of a potential 'knockout blow' if a trade deal with the EU isn't secured before December 31, as a no-deal Brexit could slash their growth forecast to 2.7% in 2021. British factory output in October was 7.1% below its level a year earlier, with tariffs and regulatory hurdles expected to further disrupt exports. Make UK's chief executive, Stephen Phipson, described the industry as feeling "exhausted" and predicted stagnation or a slight decline in output over the coming quarter.

images.alt_text: Britain's manufacturing industry warned of a potential 'knockout blow' if Prime Minister Boris Johnson is unable to secure a trade deal with the European Union before temporary transition arrangements end on Dec 31.

site_title: Aedge Group debuts on SGX at S$0.21; 5% above IPO price
summary: Aedge Group, a provider of engineering, transport, and security services, debuted on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.21, 5% above its initial public offering (IPO) price of S$0.20. The company raised S$3.2 million through its IPO and plans to use the funds to finance acquisitions, upgrade operations, and develop new security solutions. The firm's market capitalization stands at S$21.2 million, and its CEO aims to remain competitive in rapidly changing technologies.

site_title: Why investing in nature makes good business sense
summary: Investing in nature can provide significant benefits for businesses, as it can help mitigate climate change and generate substantial returns. Protecting and restoring tropical forests and mangroves, also known as natural climate solutions (NCS), can provide at least a third of the mitigation action needed by 2030 to meet the Paris Agreement goal. The private sector has the power to catalyze and accelerate investment in NCS, and companies that implement measures to reduce their carbon footprint can complement NCS with significant upside to investors. Investing in NCS can also provide substantial biodiversity and social benefits, making it a compelling return on investment opportunity.

site_title: Citibank Singapore to double AUM by 2025 in big wealth push
summary: CitiBank Singapore aims to double its assets under management (AUM) and triple its clients by 2025. The bank's new wealth hub at 268 Orchard is the world's largest for the group, marking its first "externally visible step" to achieve this goal. This expansion is part of the bank's push to grow its wealth business in Singapore.

site_title: UK and EU extend Brexit talks after ditching deadline
summary: The European Union and the UK have agreed to extend Brexit talks after abandoning a supposed deadline, with negotiations set to resume on Monday. EU chief Ursula von der Leyen and Prime Minister Boris Johnson have mandated their negotiators to continue talks, despite a lack of a new deadline. The UK and EU are working on a trade deal, with key issues including diverging regulations and tariffs, but Johnson insists that Britain will not compromise on the "fundamental nature" of Brexit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.06% to 26,522.10. Investors are monitoring US stimulus talks and the rollout of virus vaccines. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, adding 0.07% and 0.09% respectively. The slight increase follows global market trends, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Investors are learning to live with China's credit defaults
summary: China's authorities are allowing state-linked companies to default on debt, leading to a more accurate pricing of risk in the country's $15 trillion credit market. This shift is seen as a positive for investors, credit markets, and China overall, as it increases transparency and draws more inflows into the market. The average yield on riskier state-owned enterprise (SOE) bonds rose to a record 7.36% in recent weeks, while top-rated SOEs are also feeling the pain. The move is expected to boost the development of a genuine local high-yield market in China, with 2021 potentially being an inflection point.

images.alt_text: China's authorities are increasingly spreading the message: You should get what you pay for when it comes to corporate bonds.

site_title: Australia: Shares creep higher as tech stocks gain, healthcare stocks sink further
summary: Australian shares rose 0.14% to 6,651.6 points, driven by gains in tech stocks after Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine was authorised in the US. Healthcare stocks sank 0.9% to their lowest in two months, following Australia's decision to halt its Covid-19 vaccine programme. Tech stocks, including Afterpay and EML Payments, rose up to 1.5%, while financials climbed 0.7%. Energy stocks fell 0.9% due to a downturn in oil prices.

site_title: Taiwan says on track to apply to join trans-Pacific trade pact
summary: Taiwan plans to submit an application to join the revamped Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) after completing informal consultations with existing 11 members, according to the Taiwanese Foreign Ministry. The talks are ongoing, and member countries have expressed a positive attitude towards Taiwan's membership bid. However, a potential challenge arises from China's interest in joining the CPTPP, as Chinese President Xi Jinping has said his country would "actively consider" signing up. Taiwan is not a member of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and has sought greater access to multilateral deals.

images.alt_text: Taiwan will submit an application to join the revamped version of the Trans-Pacific Partnership once it has finished informal consultations with its existing 11 members, talks which are ongoing, the island's foreign ministry said.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.34% or 90.45 points to 26,742.97. This follows the Bank of Japan's key business confidence survey showing improvement for the second straight quarter. The broader Topix index also edged up 0.43% or 7.62 points to 1,789.63. The gains come as traders brush off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: CVC buys telecom tower firm in Myanmar's second-largest deal
summary: CVC Capital Partners has agreed to buy Myanmar's largest telecom tower company, Irrawaddy Green Towers, in a deal valued at approximately US$700 million. This marks CVC's first foray into the South-east Asian country. The sale, the second-largest in Myanmar, was completed after a year-long process involving potential bidders and local consultants. Irrawaddy serves major mobile network operators in Myanmar, including Telenor, Ooredoo, and Mytel. The deal underscores the growth potential of Myanmar's mobile communication sector.

site_title: Australia's shops see year-end spending boom as optimism returns
summary: Australia's retailers are expecting a year-end spending boom, with consumer confidence reaching a 10-year high in December. This surge in optimism is driven by households releasing pent-up savings after the lockdown and a growing preference for shopping outdoors and supporting local businesses. The recovery is expected to continue, with the Reserve Bank of Australia forecasting a 5% economic expansion next year. This could fuel the country's economic momentum, which has been boosted by the government's expansionary budget and the central bank's easing package.

site_title: Britain say Australia trade deal talks 'advancing well'
summary: Britain's trade talks with Australia are progressing well, according to Trade Minister Liz Truss, who stated that initial tariff offers have been exchanged and detailed discussions held on investment, services, and financial sectors. The talks aim to secure a long-term trade deal ahead of January 1, when the UK's transition arrangements with the EU expire. The UK seeks to establish new markets for its financial and professional services industries, with estimates suggesting a free trade deal could increase British exports to Australia by £900 million.

site_title: Bourbon denies hacking Novu's Instagram account
summary: Bourbon, the global marketing head of Bellagraph Nova Group, has denied hacking the Instagram account of Novu Aesthetics, according to a police report filed by executive director Marjory Loh. Loh alleged the hacking and deletion of posts, but Bourbon claimed it was a "clear misuse of my name" and said he has been shocked by the allegations. The Singapore Police Force is investigating the matter.

site_title: Japan's market for second-hand goods booms as pandemic spurs tidying-up frenzy
summary: Japan's market for second-hand luxury goods has seen a significant boom due to the pandemic, with people decluttering their homes and selling items such as kimonos, handbags, and jewelry. The market has benefited from companies like BuySell Technologies Co and Mercari, which have reported a surge in sales. The trend is attributed to the "danshari" mindset, which emphasizes minimizing one's life. As a result, 31% more people visited homes for decluttering in October compared to the previous year, with three-quarters of customers being in their 50s or older.

site_title: Japan business sentiment improves as economy emerges from pandemic's hit: BOJ survey
summary: Japan's business sentiment improved for the second consecutive quarter in October-December, with the Bank of Japan's "tankan" survey showing a headline index of minus 10. However, big manufacturers plan to cut capital expenditure by 1.2% due to slumping profits and uncertainties over the outlook. The economy has rebounded from its worst postwar contraction in the second quarter, but a recent resurgence of Covid-19 infections is expected to keep any recovery modest. The Bank of Japan will scrutinize this data at its rate review, considering extending stimulus measures beyond March deadlines.

site_title: Trump, Pence, other top officials to be offered Covid-19 vaccine: source
summary: US President Donald Trump, Vice-President Mike Pence, and other top officials will be offered the newly approved Covid-19 vaccine, starting on Monday, as part of a plan to ensure government continuity. Essential personnel at the White House and certain officials in the government will be vaccinated within the next 10 days. The vaccine was recommended by a CDC advisory panel, and doses will initially go to healthcare workers and elderly residents of long-term care homes. The plan aims to maintain government operations during a pandemic or emergency.

site_title: Soilbuild Group chairman, Blackstone to take Soilbuild Reit private at S$0.55 per unit
summary: Blackstone, through its partnership with Soilbuild Group chairman Lim Chap Huat, has proposed taking Soilbuild Business Space Reit (Soilbuild Reit) private at S$0.55 per unit. This represents a 34.5% to 53.2% premium over the unit's volume-weighted average price for the past year. The proposed privatisation will be carried out via a trust scheme of arrangement. The offer implies a price to adjusted net asset value multiple of 0.98 to 1.00 times, exceeding Soilbuild Reit's historical averages.

site_title: US starts huge vaccine effort as Germany returns to partial lockdown
summary: The US has begun shipping COVID-19 vaccine nationwide as part of a massive immunization effort, with 2.9 million doses to be delivered by Wednesday. The vaccine, developed by Pfizer-BioNtech, has been approved by the FDA and is expected to be delivered to all 50 states, with officials aiming for 20 million Americans to receive the two-shot regimen by year's end and 100 million by March. Meanwhile, Germany has returned to partial lockdown due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with non-essential shops and schools to close until January 10.

site_title: US dollar up as risk sentiment sours
summary: The US dollar rose as investors sought safe-haven assets due to concerns over delayed US fiscal stimulus, surging Covid-19 cases, and the possibility of Britain exiting the EU without a deal. US officials prepared for a massive vaccination campaign, with regulators advancing on approving the first Covid-19 vaccine. Oil prices rose 2% amid market uncertainty and tariffs.

site_title: Crown Resorts faces class action over October share plunge
summary: A law firm, Maurice Blackburn, has launched a second class action lawsuit against Crown Resorts, alleging corporate failings led to a 10% share price plunge in October. The lawsuit claims Crown's operations were not in shareholders' best interest between 2014 and October. The company's gaming license has been suspended, delaying a US$1.6 billion Sydney resort plan. The lawsuit seeks an order for Crown to buy back shares from affected investors. This follows an ongoing lawsuit from 2017 over a share price drop after employees were detained in China.

site_title: Trump vows to reject defence bill passed by veto-proof majority
summary: US President Donald Trump has vowed to veto a $740.5 billion defence budget bill, which was passed by a veto-proof majority in Congress. The bill includes provisions that Trump opposes, such as abolishing a law granting social media companies liability protection and renaming US military bases named after Confederate commanders. Trump's veto would send the bill back to Congress, where lawmakers would need to override it with a two-thirds majority. The legislation also includes sanctions on Turkey for its acquisition of a Russian-made missile defense system.

site_title: UOL's Clavon tops first-day launch sales this year at 442 units
summary: UOL Group's Clavon condominium in Singapore achieved the best launch-day sales volume this year, selling 442 units at an average price of S$1,640 per square foot. The sales result, which accounts for 70% of the total 640 units, exceeded expectations and is comparable to the sales of Parc Clematis. The project's attractive pricing, strong locational attributes, and UOL's reputation for design and quality were key factors in the success of the launch.

site_title: PM Lee to address nation on Singapore's Covid-19 situation on Monday
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will address the nation on Dec 14 to update the nation on the Covid-19 situation and the outlook for next year. The address comes after several major speeches by PM Lee this year on tackling the pandemic. The Health Minister and Education Minister will hold a press conference after the address, providing further details.

site_title: US Covid-19 vaccine campaign gets underway with convoy of trucks
summary: The US Covid-19 vaccine campaign launched on Sunday with a convoy of trucks carrying vaccine shipments from Pfizer's facility in Michigan. US regulators authorized the vaccine on Friday, and marshals accompanied the secured shipments to their final destinations. This is the largest and most complex vaccine distribution project in the US, amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: US government agencies hacked by group linked to foreign power: report
summary: The US government has confirmed that at least two agencies, including the Treasury, have been hacked by a group backed by an unnamed foreign government. The breach, first reported by cybersecurity firm FireEye, targeted the Treasury Department and Commerce Department, with stolen information reportedly being stolen. The National Security Council has stated that it is taking steps to identify and remedy any issues. The incident comes amid rising concerns about state-sponsored cyberattacks.

site_title: Iran says oil pipeline spillage, fire under control
summary: Iran says a fire caused by a ruptured oil pipeline in the southwest has been brought under control. The Maroun pipeline, which feeds Iran's second-largest refinery, ruptured around noon, causing an oil spill. Repairs and cleanup efforts are underway. There were no casualties from the fire. The cause of the rupture is unknown, but similar incidents have occurred in the area due to erosion and landslides.

images.alt_text: Iran on Sunday said a fire caused by the spillage from a ruptured oil pipeline in the southwest of the country has been brought under control, state news agency Irna reported.

site_title: Credit Suisse wealth management growth to remain robust
summary: Credit Suisse's wealth management business remains robust, with global growth expected to continue despite the Covid-19 crisis. CEO Thomas Gottstein attributes the bank's resilience to its diversified business model, which includes strong investment banking capabilities. The bank aims to expand client business volume, including assets under management, lending, and assets under custody. Asia-Pacific clients are driving growth, with assets under management reaching $2.25 trillion and net new assets of $9.7 billion. Digitalization is also key to the bank's strategy, with a 65% adoption rate of its digital private banking platform.

site_title: SLB moves beyond property development
summary: SLB Development, the property arm of Lian Beng Group, is shifting its strategy due to the risks involved in property development. The company is scaling back property development and increasing exposure to fund management and alternative asset classes. This move is in response to the challenging market climate. SLB Development's change in strategy aims to diversify its business and reduce reliance on property development.

site_title: Seven new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Seven new COVID-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 58,320, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. No community or dormitory cases were reported. The Ministry of Health will provide more details on Sunday night.

site_title: Hamilton expects to sign new Mercedes deal by Christmas
summary: Lewis Hamilton expects to sign a new contract with Mercedes before Christmas, ending speculation about his future with the team. Hamilton, the newly-crowned seven-time world champion, confirmed talks with team chief Toto Wolff will start in the next couple of weeks. He expressed his desire to remain with Mercedes, stating, "I plan to be here next year, I want to be here next year."

images.alt_text: Lewis Hamilton ended speculation about future intentions on Sunday when he made clear he expects to sign a new contract with Mercedes before Christmas.

site_title: British spy thriller author John le Carre dies aged 89
summary: John le Carre, British author of Cold War espionage novels, has died at 89. He wrote 25 novels and sold 60 million books worldwide. His notable works include "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy" and "The Spy Who Came In From The Cold". Le Carre's last novel, "Agent Running in the Field", was published in 2019. He died from pneumonia after a short battle with the illness, leaving behind his wife of nearly 50 years and four sons. Tributes from fellow authors, including Robert Harris, praised le Carre's genius as a writer and his impact on popular culture.

site_title: Libya's 4WD road warriors on a bumpy ride to revive tourism
summary: A group of 1,000 Libyan citizens, mostly men, embarked on a 300-vehicle convoy through the Sahara desert, two months into a ceasefire, to revive tourism in the war-torn country. Led by tour guide Joumaa Omar, the convoy aimed to showcase Libya's natural beauty, ancient ruins, and hidden oasis towns. The journey, which began at Al-Qaryah Al-Gharbiyah, near Tripoli, is a symbol of peace in a country torn by violence since the 2011 ouster of dictator Moamer Kadhafi. The trip aims to create a positive image of Libya and attract foreign tourists, who are still advised to avoid the country due to ongoing security concerns.

site_title: Apple's greatest chip challenge - replacing Qualcomm modems
summary: Apple is developing its own cellular modems to replace Qualcomm's, a significant challenge for the company. The move was reported to have caused a 7% decline in Qualcomm's stock price. Analysts question whether Apple can succeed in this task, citing the complexity of cellular technology. The development is a major challenge for Apple, which has become a chip powerhouse in the past decade.

site_title: Should New York's Midtown offices become apartments?
summary: New York City's commercial real estate industry is struggling due to the pandemic, with nearly 14% of office space in midtown Manhattan vacant, the highest rate since 2009. To address this, the Real Estate Board of New York proposes converting 1 million sq ft of office space into housing, which could create 14,000 apartments and alleviate the city's housing shortage. The proposal aims to transform the city's economy and finances, but would require changes to zoning rules and density regulations, which would need to be approved by the City Council and state Legislature.

site_title: Rise of 'shadow capital' despite pandemic putting Asean private equity in the shade
summary: A recent Bain & Company report reveals that "shadow capital" investors, who deploy direct capital throughout the private equity cycle, have remained active in Southeast Asia despite the pandemic. Over 75% of the top 30-funded startups in the region have received shadow capital investments, stabilizing the private equity scene. Shadow capital allows institutional investors to access PE assets with lower costs and increased control, driving competition among traditional private equity firms and sovereign wealth funds, which are expanding their capabilities to diversify and expand their talent.

site_title: Deliveroo Singapore launches in-app function for customers to donate
summary: Deliveroo Singapore has launched an in-app donation function, allowing customers to support Food from the Heart's (FFTH) School Goodie Bag programme, which provides food rations to low-income school-age children and their families. The virtual pop-up restaurant on the app enables customers to make donations, with Deliveroo matching the first S$10,000. The programme benefits 1,500 children and aims to provide better nutrition for the new school year. The initiative aims to encourage customers to give back during the festive period, supporting FFTH's mission to make a positive impact on the community.

site_title: Ocean freight's rising tide yet to ebb as operators steer capacity
summary: The current bull market for ocean freight is expected to ease in 2021, but rates are unlikely to collapse due to ship operators' mastery of capacity management. Demand for consumer goods has driven sharp increases in spot rates since mid-year, but analysts predict rates will plateau as shippers seek alternatives. Rates are expected to reduce to a range between 2020 and current levels, but may remain strong through the first quarter of 2021. Capacity cuts and management tactics have helped operators preserve freight rates, and the industry is now focused on securing empty containers rather than finding strong demand routes.

site_title: Ocean freight to enjoy better decade than previous one: HSBC
summary: HSBC predicts a better decade for ocean freight, citing improved profitability and capacity management. The previous decade was marred by a downcycle, excessive new vessel building, and price competition. Consolidation and bigger alliances have led to a shift in focus to profitability. Strong contract rates and rising demand in intra-Asia routes, now accounting for 31% of global container trade volumes, are expected to continue. Debt-laden companies like Pacific International Lines may benefit from the industry upswing and turnaround, with shipping stocks rallying by 64-229% in the past six months.

site_title: Bank regulators mull adjustments to caps on dividends
summary: Bank regulators worldwide are reviewing restrictions on dividend payouts and share buybacks, with some considering adjustments to caps. The Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) in the UK allows banks to pay dividends again, but with "temporary guardrails." Other regulators, such as the European Central Bank (ECB) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), have also lifted or relaxed restrictions. Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have front-loaded provisions to prepare for potential bad loans in 2021, allowing them to flex their dividend paying capacity.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report from December 11, 2020, notes that the Capesize market decreased to $10,295 on the 5TC. The market then rebounded to $11,889 by the end of the week.

site_title: Gold may see range-bound movement
summary: Gold prices are expected to remain range-bound as the market awaits news on the US stimulus package and its potential impact on the economy. Despite a recent high of $1,875 on December 8, gold has stalled after failing to capitalize on its gains. The precious metal's price action is influenced by the US Congress's negotiations over a $1.4 trillion spending package and increasing economic problems due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Investors are watching for further news on the stimulus package and its potential side effects, which could create volatility in the markets.

site_title: BN Group global marketing head denies hacking Novu Aesthetics' Instagram account
summary: Global marketing head of Bellagraph Nova Group, Antonio Giamundo de Bourbon, denies hacking Novu Aesthetics' Instagram account, contrary to allegations made by executive director Marjory Loh. A police report was filed, but investigations are ongoing. Bourbon stated that he has been shocked by the allegations and will not tolerate any misuse of his name. His personal e-mail and Instagram account have also been hacked, he claimed. The Singapore Police Force confirmed a report was lodged and investigations are underway.

site_title: Leaders to push Brexit trade talks beyond latest deadline
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and EU President Ursula von der Leyen agreed to extend Brexit trade talks beyond their latest deadline, pledging to "go the extra mile" to avoid a "no-deal" exit. The two sides face challenges in agreeing on fishing rights and a level playing field, with a failure to reach a deal potentially damaging Europe's economies and causing chaos in supply chains. Negotiators will continue talks, with the UK and EU still a long way from resolving the impasse.

site_title: South Korea says tightest virus measures may be 'inevitable'
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in stated that tightening virus measures to the strictest level is "inevitable" unless the country can contain the coronavirus outbreak. The country reported 1,030 new cases, with 1,002 locally transmitted, breaking the previous day's record. The government plans to start vaccinations before March and other treatments before January. Experts urge the government to raise social-distancing measures immediately to halt the spread of the virus, citing the country's critical moment in the outbreak.

site_title: Merkel orders Germany into hard lockdown as infections swell
summary: Germany is entering a hard lockdown from December 16, 2020, until at least January 10, 2021, due to a surge in COVID-19 infections and deaths. Chancellor Angela Merkel has ordered non-essential stores to close, employers to shut workplaces, and school children to stay home. The restrictions aim to bring down the seven-day incidence rate of 50 per 100,000, which has reached a record 169. The move comes after a softer shutdown failed to halt the virus's spread, putting pressure on the nation's health system and economy.

site_title: Robinhood crowd sweeps market, stoking 111% IPO rally in US
summary: Robinhood's IPO rally in the US market has seen a 111% return, with valuations doubling after passing from institutional investors to the broader public. Recent IPOs, including DoorDash, C3.ai, and Airbnb, have seen significant price surges, with DoorDash surging 86%, C3.ai jumping 120%, and Airbnb more than doubling its value. This trend follows a similar pattern seen in 2020, where an index of IPO stocks returned 111%.

site_title: Nerves in The City at the prospect of a 'no-deal' Brexit
summary: The UK's financial sector is on high alert as the prospect of a "no-deal" Brexit looms, sparking fears of lost clients, influence, and market turbulence. The Bank of England warns of "some market volatility and disruption for financial services, particularly to EU-based clients" if a deal is not reached by December 31. Investment bank Morgan Stanley predicts a 6-10% fall in the FTSE-250 index and a 10-20% drop in banking stocks. The loss of the EU passport will affect the ability of UK financial institutions to sell products and services across the EU, with derivatives being a key area of concern.

site_title: Warehouses lure more cash than offices in pandemic-fuelled flip
summary: US warehouse investments surged in 2020, surpassing office buildings for the first time, driven by e-commerce growth and social distancing. Industrial properties jumped 8.5% in the 12 months up to October, while retail and office properties declined. Global commercial real estate spending saw 20% of investments go to warehouses, up from 12% in 2015. Experts warn of a potential bubble, but projections predict steady price growth for 10 years, with warehouse and industrial space expected to reach 1 billion square feet by 2025.

images.alt_text: Investments in warehouse and industrial properties comprised 20% of global commercial real estate spending this year - up from 12% in 2015, said CBRE Group.

site_title: Miyoshi gets qualified opinion from auditors on FY2020 financial statements
summary: Miyoshi's independent auditors BDO have issued a qualified opinion on the group's FY2020 financial statements due to lack of sufficient audit evidence on its investment in electric vehicle company Core Power (Fujian) New Energy Automobile Co. The group's investment was reclassified to financial asset designated at Fair Value through Profit or Loss (FVTPL) after losing significant influence. The auditors were unable to obtain sufficient evidence on the fair value assessment of the financial assets at FVTPL, resulting in an inability to determine if adjustments were necessary.

site_title: Keppel contributes to uplifting rural communities in Yunnan
summary: Keppel Corporation has launched a two-year programme to support rural communities in Yunnan Province, China, as part of its partnership with the China Foundation for Poverty Alleviation. The programme aims to upgrade kitchen facilities in 20 schools and provide nutritious food to students every school day. This is part of a five million yuan (S$1 million) collaboration between Keppel and CFPA, which has previously supported over 2,100 students in Mabian County, Sichuan Province.

site_title: Sian Chay increases Singapore Paincare stake
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings' largest shareholder, Sian Chay, increased its stake in the company to 15.27% after acquiring 9 million shares for S$1.98 million. This follows Singapore Paincare Holdings issuing new shares to Sian Chay in November. The company reported a total net profit of approximately S$1.88 million in FY20.

site_title: The nominating committee as architect of corporate governance
summary: The nominating committee (NC) plays a crucial role in corporate governance, evaluating board effectiveness and recommending director candidates. As the corporate landscape evolves, the NC must adapt to ensure the board is fit for purpose, driving strategy-setting, performance, and transformation. The NC's expanded mandate includes overseeing governance practices, culture, and ethics, and should be more proactive in supporting the board's role. To up its game, the NC needs to shift from a compliance-driven mindset to a more strategic and visionary approach, potentially evolving its name to the "nomination and governance committee".

site_title: After fires, Australia gets ready for floods
summary: Australia prepares for floods after recent bushfires, with thousands bracing for severe weather on the subtropical east coast. A "severe weather warning" has been issued for the border area between New South Wales and Queensland, where up to 475mm of rain fell in 24 hours. Authorities urge people to sandbag their homes and avoid flooded roads, with beaches closed due to dangerous surf. The erratic weather is attributed to a La Nina pattern combined with climate change, and emergency services have rescued four people and received over 700 calls for help.

site_title: UK planning bailout package for industries hardest hit by no-deal Brexit
summary: UK cabinet ministers plan a multi-billion pound bailout package for industries hardest hit by a no-deal Brexit, including sheep farmers, fishermen, car manufacturers, and chemical suppliers. The proposed £8-£10 billion package aims to mitigate trade disruption and EU tariffs starting January 1. The move follows the UK's economic contraction for the second month, further exacerbating the economic impact of the Brexit transition.

site_title: PM Lee to address nation on Singapore's Covid-19 situation at 5pm on Monday
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will address the nation on Monday to provide an update on Singapore's Covid-19 situation and the outlook for next year. The address is scheduled for 5pm, followed by a press conference by Health Minister Gan Kim Yong and Education Minister Lawrence Wong. This will be Mr Lee's first address on the pandemic in over a year, following previous major speeches in February and April. The PM's address aims to reassure Singaporeans and provide an update on the country's progress in tackling the pandemic.

site_title: AstraZeneca to buy Alexion for US$39b in rare-disease push
summary: AstraZeneca has agreed to acquire Alexion Pharmaceuticals for $39 billion, adding treatments for rare blood and immunological disorders to its portfolio. The deal values Alexion at $175 per share, a 45% premium to the closing price. AstraZeneca aims to accelerate its development of immunological therapies and expand its presence in the China market. The acquisition is expected to close in the third quarter of 2021 and will add $500 million in annual synergies by 2023.

site_title: Markets priced for perfection amid vaccine roll-out
summary: US stocks rose to record highs last week as the FDA is set to approve emergency use of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. With roughly 2.9 million doses to be distributed, a successful rollout is crucial to maintaining record highs, but the market is "priced for perfection" due to astronomical valuations. Analysts expect a stimulus bill and potential Fed intervention to support the economy, but a delay in the Senate runoff election in Georgia may complicate negotiations. A successful vaccine rollout would require a smooth distribution process, while a disappointing rollout could lead to a selloff.

site_title: Bloomberg News Chinese staff member detained in Beijing
summary: Chinese authorities have detained a Chinese national, Haze Fan, working for Bloomberg News in Beijing on suspicion of endangering national security. Fan was seen being escorted from her apartment by security officials after a contact with an editor. The Chinese foreign ministry stated that her rights have been ensured and the case is under investigation. Bloomberg expressed concern and is seeking more information. This detention comes amid China's worsening relations with the US, with the country expelling foreign journalists from US media organizations.

site_title: LMIRT manager reiterates no change in EGM
summary: LMIRT's manager reiterated that there will be no changes to the Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) on Dec 14, despite receiving a letter from 50 unitholders requesting a postponement or a new EGM date. The manager claims the letter's signatories may not be valid unitholders, and all valid votes will be counted and announced during the EGM. The manager has responded to similar requests in previous letters and will proceed with the scheduled EGM as planned.

site_title: Tackling unprecedented challenges
summary: Wealth management firms, businesses, and companies worldwide have adapted to the unprecedented challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic. Financial advisers now prioritize face-to-face interactions, while technology has enabled remote working and digital engagement. Many organizations have accelerated digital adoption, business transformation, and workforce planning to position for resilience and growth. Insurers have transformed their services to conduct online sales and advisory, while cybersecurity has become increasingly critical due to the surge in data and cloud infrastructure. Companies are re-evaluating their IT strategies, exploring alternative support providers, and investing in innovation to support digital workforces.

site_title: Pro-Trump protests decry president's election loss, opposing groups clash
summary: Conservative groups in the US, claiming the Nov 3 election was stolen from President Donald Trump, staged protests across the country on Dec 12, 2020, with one in Washington turning violent. The protests, linked to pro-Trump operative Roger Stone, clashed with opposing groups, including "Proud Boys" and "Antifa" counterprotesters. Despite a US Supreme Court ruling rejecting a lawsuit to overturn Biden's election victory, Trump supporters continued to claim widespread fraud. The violence escalated at night, with police using pepper spray to separate protesters.

site_title: Solitaire LLP raises S$50,000 for Wheelchair Rugby Association
summary: Solitaire LLP's staff and clients cycled 160 km to raise S$50,000 for the Wheelchair Rugby Association (Singapore). The event, Ruck & Roll, was a round-island ride that brought together 160 cyclists, including guest of honour Edwin Tong. The funds will support the association's goals, which include promoting social inclusivity and equal opportunity for people with disabilities. This partnership aims to unite the community and promote the core values of WRAS, including inclusivity. The cheque was presented at a post-ride reception.

site_title: Ailing newspapers abandon newsrooms as pandemic deepens woes
summary: Established American newspapers, such as the New York Daily News and Miami Herald, are abandoning their newsrooms due to the pandemic's worsening the industry crisis. Pandemic workplace restrictions have led to empty newsrooms, prompting Tribune Publishing to re-evaluate its real estate needs. Many journalists fear that the loss of newsrooms will change the nature of their work and that newspapers may not re-establish them even after the pandemic. The industry's shift to digital news consumption and declining advertising revenues exacerbate the crisis, with some fearing the newsroom will become a relic of the past.

site_title: Fed may convey optimism on US economy despite stimulus deadlock
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to convey optimism about the US economy despite a deadlock on government stimulus, as it concludes its final meeting of 2020. The Fed may update its view on the economy's outlook for 2021, with vaccines against Covid-19 being rolled out. However, experts caution that the outlook is uncertain, and the Fed is unlikely to take a strong stance on fiscal policy. The Fed may focus on reassurance and signal it will not raise interest rates soon, potentially spooking stock markets if growth forecasts are more upbeat.

site_title: Nasdaq to remove four Chinese companies' shares from indexes after US order
summary: Nasdaq to remove shares of four Chinese companies from indexes due to a US order restricting their purchase. The four companies, China Communications Construction, China Railway Construction Corp, CRRC Corp, and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp, will be removed from the indexes on Dec 21. The move follows a White House executive order alleging the companies' links to China's military. Index providers MSCI and FTSE Russell have also announced similar removals of Chinese companies from their indexes, reflecting the practical impact of the US order on global market exposure.
