This is not the first time a celebrity has tested positive, with others including Tom Hanks, Idris Elba, and Kanye West.

site_title: Private credit manager notches up 55% return on pandemic fund
summary: AlbaCore Capital, a private credit manager, has closed its US$1 billion fund and managed accounts after achieving a 55% gross return through the end of November. The fund focused on beaten-up credits during the pandemic, capitalizing on the market's rally after the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank announced quantitative easing programs. The strategy yielded strong returns, with 80% of investments in safest market segments, and the firm will return capital to investors in early 2021.

site_title: Australia cancels local Covid-19 vaccine development due to HIV false positives
summary: Australia has halted the production of a homemade Covid-19 vaccine due to false positives with HIV diagnostic tests, with the government instead securing additional doses of rival vaccines. The vaccine, developed by the University of Queensland and CSL, showed antibodies interfered with HIV diagnosis, leading to false positives in trials. The decision comes as Australia secures 140 million vaccine units, with plans to start vaccinations in March 2021 and have the whole population inoculated by the end of the year.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Covid-19 vaccine production halt, post sixth weekly jump
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to close at 6,642.6 on Friday, as healthcare stocks declined following the halt of a homegrown Covid-19 vaccine production. The halt was due to trials showing interference with HIV diagnosis. Energy and gold sub-sectors gained, with oil and gas stocks rising 1% and miners reaching a fresh high since 2011. Despite the decline, the S&P/ASX 200 index posted a sixth straight weekly jump.

site_title: UK's Johnson says 'strong possibility' of no-deal split in EU trading ties
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned that there is a "strong possibility" of no-deal split in EU trading ties due to disagreements over fishing rights, economic fair play, and dispute settlement. The UK and EU have a deadline of December 31 to reach an agreement, with a no-deal scenario potentially leading to tariffs and quotas on around $1 trillion in annual trade. Johnson vowed to try to find a deal, but his comments sent sterling plummeting against the US dollar.

site_title: 2020 Mini Countryman review: Whee bit different
summary: The 2020 Mini Countryman has undergone a facelift, introducing digital features such as a semi-digital cockpit display and wireless Apple CarPlay. However, its analogue pleasures remain, including a new front grille, chiselled bumpers, and 19-inch alloy wheels. The Cooper S model boasts a new engine and engaging handling, while the standard Cooper has a more affordable price tag. The Countryman's unique blend of style and practicality makes it an appealing option, despite its slightly compromised performance.

site_title: Disney+ to get flood of new shows; launching in Singapore on Feb 23
summary: Disney+ is set to launch in Singapore on February 23, 2021, with over 500 films and 15,000 episodes. The streaming service will be priced at S$11.98 a month or S$119.98 a year. As part of its plans, Disney+ aims to reach 350 million subscribers worldwide by 2024, with a projected annual programming spend of US$14-16 billion. The company's CEO, Bob Chapek, announced that 80% of projects are now headed to streaming, rather than the big screen, with plans for dozens of new movies and TV shows from Marvel, Star Wars, and Pixar.

site_title: US commission begins process of halting China Telecom's operations
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has begun the process of revoking China Telecom's authorization to operate in the US, citing national security concerns. The FCC's chairman, Ajit Pai, stated that China Telecom may be forced to comply with Chinese government requests for information, including communications intercepts. This decision follows warnings from the US Justice Department and other federal agencies in April, and comes after the FCC previously denied China Mobile's application to provide services in the US due to similar concerns.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.1% higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 26,780.80, and the Topix edging up 0.2% to 1,780.25. The market lacked direction due to a lack of fresh clues for trade after a mixed close on Wall Street.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.9% at open on Dec 11, 2020, following the US move closer to authorizing its first vaccine, while traders monitored stimulus talks. The Hang Seng Index increased 223.62 points to 26,634.21, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.2% to 3,381.01.

site_title: Aramco hires Moelis to raise billions from asset sales
summary: Saudi Aramco hires Moelis to raise billions from asset sales, amid the kingdom's efforts to counter a severe recession. The plan includes selling stakes in subsidiaries, including a pipeline business, to raise around $10 billion. This move is seen as a quicker alternative to an initial public offering (IPO) that raised $30 billion in 2019. The strategy aims to lower the company's leverage and raise cash to counter the severe economic downturn, which is expected to contract 5.4% in 2020.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia is looking to emulate neighbouring Abu Dhabi by using its state energy firm to raise billions of dollars from investors, as the kingdom seeks cash to counter a severe recession.

site_title: United Airlines invests in carbon-capture project to be 100% green by 2050
summary: United Airlines has committed to a $1 billion investment in a carbon-capture project, 1PointFive, to remove one million tonnes of CO2 from the air annually by 2050, equivalent to 40 million trees. The project, a partnership between Occidental Petroleum and Rusheen Capital, aims to build the first US industrial-sized direct air capture plant. CEO Scott Kirby stated that carbon capture and sequestration is the only scalable technology to remove carbon from the atmosphere. The project will offset nearly 10% of United's annual emissions, marking a significant step towards the airline's goal of being 100% "green" by 2050.

site_title: Prestige Biopharma acquired by Korean depository, in sign of possible IPO
summary: Prestige Biopharma, a Singapore-registered biopharmaceuticals firm, has been fully acquired by the Korea Securities Depository (KSD), according to a regulatory filing. This acquisition may signal a possible initial public offering (IPO) on the Korean stock exchange for the near-unicorn. Prestige Biopharma had previously filed for a preliminary review for listing on Korea's main bourse in May 2020. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by KSD, and the company's IPO plans are now under consideration.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, SGX, Ascendas Reit, MIT, OCBC, Parkway Life Reit
summary: DBS is set to launch a crypto trading platform as a subsidiary of the banking group, with Singapore Exchange (SGX) taking a 10% stake. Ascendas Reit acquired a Sydney office property for A$288.9 million. MIT secured a S$300 million sustainability-linked facility from OCBC, while Parkway Life Reit acquired a nursing home in Japan for S$21.2 million. Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$21.9 million for the second quarter, reversing a loss from the same period last year.

site_title: Bank of England relaxes coronavirus curbs on bank dividends and bonuses
summary: The Bank of England has relaxed coronavirus curbs on bank dividends and bonuses, allowing Britain's seven biggest lenders to resume paying some dividends and bonuses. The decision comes after banks were told to suspend dividends and share buy-backs until the end of 2020 due to the pandemic. The Bank of England expects banks to exercise caution and prudence in determining dividend payouts, with any distributions falling within "guardrails" set by the regulator.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust bags first S$300m sustainability-linked facility from OCBC
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has secured a S$300 million sustainability-linked facility from OCBC Bank with a 6-year tenor. The facility is linked to selected sustainability performance targets, with interest rates potentially reduced on a tiered basis if targets are met. This marks MIT's first foray into sustainable financing, aimed at strengthening its capital structure and diversifying funding sources.

site_title: Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine to arrive in Canada soon, Trudeau hails 'good news'
summary: Canada is set to receive its first 30,000 doses of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine, with shipments expected to arrive soon. The approval marks the country's third, following Britain and Bahrain. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau hailed the news as "good news" and warned it's just the first step in a massive project. Canada has recorded 435,330 Covid-19 cases and 12,983 deaths, prompting major provinces to reimpose restrictions. The military will assist in distributing the vaccine to 14 sites across the country, starting Monday.

site_title: Nearly US$500m in additional funds set for Madoff victims
summary: The US Justice Department announced the distribution of nearly $488 million in additional funds to over 30,000 Madoff victims, bringing the total refunds to nearly $3.2 billion. The Madoff Victim Fund aims to return $4.05 billion to victims, with the repayment process ongoing. Bernie Madoff, the mastermind behind the financial scam, is serving an 82-year prison sentence. The additional payments mark the sixth time the fund has disbursed funds, with the total recovered value exceeding $25 billion in estimated losses.

site_title: US: Wall Street shakes off labour market data with stimulus in focus
summary: US stocks rebounded from early lows as investors focused on potential fiscal stimulus to support the economy, despite labour market data showing a jump in jobless claims. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.23%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.13% and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.54%. The US Treasury Secretary said talks on Covid-19 relief were making progress, while a Senate vote on a stopgap measure could slip to Friday's deadline.

site_title: Mazda CX-30 Skyactiv-X review: Skyactiv-X rated
summary: Mazda has released the CX-30 Skyactiv-X 100th Anniversary, a special edition car marking the company's 100th year in business. The vehicle features unique badging, wheel hub logos, and embossed 100th anniversary logos on the red leather seats. The CX-30 Skyactiv-X is powered by a first-of-its-kind Skyactiv-X engine, a significant innovation for Mazda. The car is a celebration of the company's milestone and offers a distinctive design element for customers.

site_title: Airbnb valuation surges past US$100b in biggest US IPO of the year
summary: Airbnb's shares more than doubled in their stock market debut, valuing the home rental firm at over $100 billion, in the largest US IPO of 2020. The company's stock opened at $146 and closed at $144.71, surpassing its IPO price of $68 per share. Airbnb's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, which damaged its business, was driven by increased interest in renting homes away from major cities. CEO Brian Chesky attributed the surprise profit to the company's ability to adapt and said he hopes this IPO will mark a "comeback for our hosts and for what I hope will be travel."

site_title: Pemex's trading arm suspends business with Vitol amid US bribery probe
summary: Pemex's trading arm has suspended business with Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trader, amid a US bribery probe. The US Justice Department has alleged Vitol paid bribes to Pemex employees in exchange for lucrative contracts. Vitol's US unit has agreed to pay $164 million to resolve government probes. Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador has vowed to investigate and punish those responsible if the allegations are true. The suspension affects trade between Mexico and Vitol, but it's unclear if all trade has been banned.

site_title: Bullish bets on Asian currencies hit multi-year highs as outlook brightens
summary: Bullish bets on Asian currencies have reached multi-year highs due to improving exports and expectations of higher capital inflows, driven by a vaccine-driven economic recovery in 2021. The Chinese yuan, South Korean won, and Taiwan dollar have seen significant long positions, with the yuan expected to reach 6.30 by the end of 2021. Asian currencies are also benefiting from relatively better virus containment and a likely rise in exports and portfolio inflows.

site_title: Oil shrugs off US stockpile to rise on vaccine optimism
summary: Oil prices rose to near $46 a barrel as investors remained optimistic about the impact of vaccine rollouts on global energy demand next year, despite a record increase in US crude stockpiles. The Energy Information Administration reported a 15.2 million barrel jump in American oil inventories, but prices rebounded due to a falling dollar and support from Asian refiners. Despite a week of losses, oil remains near a nine-month high as the market awaits vaccine deployments to drive demand recovery.

site_title: Louis Camilleri steps down as Ferrari CEO and Philip Morris executive chair
summary: Ferrari CEO Louis Camilleri has stepped down for personal reasons, effective immediately. John Elkann has taken over as interim CEO. Camilleri's leadership led to record-high shares, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Ferrari shares reached an all-time high of 182.95 euros in December 2020. Camilleri will be available for advice to Ferrari, while Philip Morris International has also appointed a new CEO, André Calantzopoulos, and interim chairman Lucio Noto.

images.alt_text: Ferrari chief executive officer (CEO) Louis Camilleri has retired for personal reasons, and executive chairman John Elkann has been appointed as interim CEO, the luxury automaker said on Thursday.

site_title: Oil: Brent rises above US$50 per barrel for first time since March on vaccine optimism
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 3% on Thursday, with Brent crude surging above $50 a barrel for the first time since March, driven by vaccine optimism and hopes for a faster demand recovery. Despite a large increase in US crude inventories, investors ignored the news and pushed oil prices higher. The US and Canada began vaccinations, while Britain started its rollout this week. Opec+ is set to ease its supply restrictions in January, providing additional support to the market. Oil prices have recovered from historic lows reached in April.

site_title: US set to sanction Turkey over Russian defence system: sources
summary: The US is set to impose sanctions on Turkey over its acquisition of Russian S-400 air defense systems last year. This move is likely to worsen strained relations between the two NATO allies. The sanctions are expected to be announced by the incoming Biden administration, which could further complicate US-Turkey ties. The decision is seen as a long-anticipated step, infuriating Ankara and likely to have significant implications for the region.

images.alt_text: The United States is poised to impose sanctions on Turkey over its acquisition last year of Russian S-400 air defence systems, five sources including two US officials told Reuters on Thursday.

site_title: US FDA advisers overwhelmingly back authorising Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine
summary: US FDA advisers voted 17-4 to endorse emergency use of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine, recommending it for individuals 16 and older. The FDA is expected to authorize the vaccine within days, with distribution and inoculations starting soon. The panel discussed concerns over allergic reactions and pregnant women, but ultimately deemed the benefits outweigh the risks. The vaccine was found to be 95% effective in preventing Covid-19 illness, with some protection shown before the second dose.

images.alt_text: A panel of outside advisers to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on Thursday voted overwhelmingly to endorse emergency use of Pfizer's coronavirus vaccine, paving the way for the agency to authorize the shot for a nation that has lost more than 285,000 lives to Covid-19.

site_title: UK, EU leaders agree to Sunday deadline for Brexit decision
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson must back down and accept a compromise to agree to a trade deal with the EU by Sunday's deadline. The EU's red lines remain unchanged, with the UK needing to agree to a level playing field, UK fishing quotas, and governance of regulations and disputes. A partial compromise would delay some aspects of the deal, with the UK willing to compromise on fishing and governance, but the main sticking point is rules on fair competition for business. The EU wants the UK to closely follow EU rules on workers' rights and environmental regulations.

site_title: The nominating committee: architect of corporate governance
summary: The nominating committee (NC) plays a crucial role in corporate governance, overseeing the board's effectiveness, recommending director candidates, and evaluating board independence. As the landscape evolves, the NC must transition from a compliance-driven mindset to a more proactive approach in supporting strategy-setting and driving performance. With the increasing prominence of ESG factors, the NC will need to weigh in on board structure and committee mandates. To be effective, the NC should focus on culture, succession planning, and recalibrating itself to drive meaningful changes in corporate governance.

site_title: How to be a blue ocean strategist in the post-pandemic world
summary: In a post-pandemic world, companies face heightened competition as customer demand is depressed due to reduced income and unemployment. To generate revenue and profit, firms need to create "blue oceans" of new demand. A blue ocean strategist's mindset involves reshaping industry conditions, making competition irrelevant, creating and capturing new demand, and pursuing differentiation and low cost simultaneously. By adopting this perspective, managers can unlock new opportunities and rise above challenges, rather than being victims of change and disruption.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific in the black in Q2 2020
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$21.85 million for Q2 2020, reversing a loss from the previous year. Revenue rose 12% year-on-year to US$623.45 million, driven by higher sales in the US and Philippines. The company's earnings were impacted by one-off expenses in the previous year.

site_title: US inflation measure rises by more than forecast in November
summary: US inflation rose 0.2% in November, exceeding forecasts, driven by increased costs of transportation services and apparel. The core index, excluding food and energy costs, also rose 0.2% and 1.6% year-over-year. Despite inflationary pressures, the nation awaits the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines, limiting merchants' ability to charge customers more. Unemployment benefits increased, with initial claims reaching 853,000, amid rising COVID-19 infections and business restrictions.

site_title: FLCT to divest three South Australia properties for A$29.6 million
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) has agreed to divest three leasehold industrial properties in South Australia for A$29.6 million, a 19.4% premium to their book value. The properties, located in Burbridge Business Park, account for 0.9% of FLCT's net property income and 0.4% of its portfolio value. The divestment is expected to be completed by March 31, 2021, with estimated net proceeds of A$28.1 million. The proceeds will provide financial flexibility to manage FLCT's capital and may be used for funding potential acquisitions or debt reduction.

site_title: EU leaders unblock 1.8t euro budget, recovery fund, eye climate goals
summary: European Union leaders have agreed on a 1.8 trillion euro financial package to aid the economy's recovery from the pandemic-induced recession. The deal also sets a 55% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, up from the current 40% target. Poland and Hungary, which initially blocked the package due to concerns over access to funds linked to respecting the rule of law, have agreed to lift their veto after Germany struck a compromise. The package will be implemented and will drive forward the bloc's green and digital transitions.

images.alt_text: European Union (EU) leaders unblocked on Thursday a 1.8 trillion euro (S$2.92 trillion) financial package to help the economy recover from the pandemic-induced recession after reaching a compromise with Poland and Hungary, the chairman of EU leaders Charles Michel said.

site_title: Among sparkling wines, the other half lives well
summary: A recent article argues that sparkling wines, excluding Champagne, deserve recognition and appreciation for their unique characteristics. The author suggests that the notion that all sparkling wines are inferior imitations of Champagne is a misconception. Three wines - Ferrari Trento, Domaine Huet Vouvray Pétillant Brut, and Recaredo Corpinnat Terrers Brut Nature - were tasted and found to showcase distinct qualities and flavors. The article aims to persuade readers that sparkling wines are a diverse and wonderful option, not a hierarchy with Champagne at the top.

site_title: Office S-Reits may turn from laggards to leaders, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research predicts office S-Reits in Singapore will turn from laggards to leaders in 2021, driven by a cyclical recovery. The sector's unit prices have recovered 40% from March lows, but office S-Reits' performance is still lagging. Analysts expect limited new office supply and a pick-up in Singapore's GDP to mitigate the overhang from rising flexible work trends. DBS recommends investors "stay with office winners" and predicts a return to normalcy will drive unit prices towards 1.1 times price to net asset value (P/NAV).

site_title: Digital customer experience key for Singapore's digibank licensees
summary: Singapore's digital banking licensees must prioritize digital customer experience to outmaneuver incumbents. With a population of six million residents, only 2% are unbanked, while 40% are underbanked. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in digital banking transactions, presenting opportunities for digibanks. However, new licensees face a tight timeline, especially with limited experience in financial services. To succeed, they must deliver exceptional digital experiences to attract and retain customers, capitalizing on the nation's growing demand for digital banking services.

site_title: Singapore, UK to begin talks on digital economy deal soon
summary: Singapore and the UK plan to launch negotiations for a digital economy agreement (DEA) early next year, aiming to facilitate seamless digital trade and business between the two countries. This deal, the first of its kind for Singapore with a European country, comes amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting the growing importance of digital connectivity. The UK-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) will be provisionally applied on December 31, following the Brexit transition period end.

site_title: DoorDash's stellar IPO could boost Asia valuations
summary: DoorDash's successful IPO in the US has set a benchmark for its peers in South-east Asia's food delivery sector, potentially boosting valuations and attracting more investments. The company's market value soared to $60.1 billion, with shares rising 85.8% on their first day of trading. Analysts expect this performance to influence valuations for food delivery startups, with DoorDash serving as a reference for companies like Gojek and Grab. However, challenges and differences in the South-east Asian market may impact the effectiveness of this benchmark, with some experts noting that the region's fragmented market and varying business models may lead to lower multiples.

site_title: Shophouses in prime districts snapped up; owners put more assets on market
summary: Singapore's shophouse market continues to see robust interest, with buyers snapping up properties in prime districts like D1 and D2. Softer asking prices have led to increased demand, as sellers become more realistic with their pricing due to the pandemic. Transacted shophouses in these districts fetched prices ranging from S$3,684 to S$10,747 per square foot. The market's appeal lies in its versatility, with buyers able to convert properties into various uses such as offices, co-working spaces, and F&B destinations. Experts predict this trend to continue into the next year, driven by institutional investors seeking alternative assets.

site_title: Social media exploited for 'pump and dump' activities: SGX RegCo
summary: SGX RegCo has flagged possible market misconduct activities on Telegram chat groups and social media channels, exploiting platforms for "pump and dump" schemes. These schemes involve promoting a security's interest to drive up its price, then selling shares at a profit. SGX RegCo warns investors to conduct their own due diligence and research, as information from anonymous individuals on social media may not be credible. The regulator will refer potential wrongdoers to statutory authorities for investigation of breaches of laws.

site_title: Why it is imperative to engage more digital experts on your team
summary: A survey of over 1,500 executives from three comparable economies found that companies with a critical mass of digital experts on their board are better equipped to handle the digital divergence caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Having more than a quarter of the management team with digital experience leads to a shift in decision-making towards data-driven decisions. Companies with a higher proportion of digital experts also experience less negative impact from the pandemic and are more likely to make informed decisions based on data, ultimately increasing their resilience and competitiveness.

site_title: Labour crunch, levies fuel foreign workers' training
summary: Employers in Singapore are investing in upskilling foreign workers to better deploy manpower and increase productivity, despite prioritizing local employees' skills. Companies like Lian Beng Group and Grand Venture Technology have sent foreign workers to courses, allowing them to move into higher-skilled roles. This practice may be necessary in sectors where locals are scarce, and employers see it as a way to retain talent. The Ministry of Manpower emphasizes the importance of training local workers, but some experts argue that upskilling foreign workers can be beneficial in certain industries.

site_title: 2020 BMW 4 Series review: Hot off the grille
summary: The 2020 BMW 4 Series Coupe is a sharp departure from its predecessors, boasting a distinctive nose design that sets it apart from the 3 Series sedan. With a longer, lower, and wider footprint, the car achieves an athletic yet elegant appearance. Behind the wheel, it delivers a more enjoyable driving experience, with a balanced and analogue feel, and refined ride quality. The 184hp engine provides quick acceleration, and the car's features, such as its Intelligent Personal Assistant, are similar to those of the 3 Series. With a starting price of $222,888, the 4 Series Coupe is a unique offering in the luxury car market.

site_title: CEOs in Asia need to rev up for the post-Covid road ahead
summary: CEOs in Asia must maintain momentum to survive and prosper in the post-Covid era. A decade of research on prominent companies reveals five key themes: high performers are pulling ahead, digitization and data analytics are crucial, resource reallocation is necessary, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) impact is vital, and Asia's integration is deepening. These themes will shape the opportunities and challenges for companies in 2021, as they navigate economic disruption and unprecedented trends. Maintaining momentum is essential for survival and prosperity.

site_title: StanChart closer to building digital-only bank in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore is awarded enhanced "Significantly Rooted Foreign Bank" (SRFB) privileges by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, paving the way for it to set up a digital-only bank. The enhanced privileges allow the bank to secure a lower minimum paid-up capital of S$100 million compared to S$1.5 billion for a digital full bank. This move follows StanChart's naming as the country's first SRFB in August and joins the four digital banks in Singapore that have recently been awarded licenses.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as ECB warns of slowing growth next year
summary: European stocks dropped as the European Central Bank (ECB) forecast slower growth in the eurozone next year despite introducing more stimulus measures to support the pandemic-hit economy. Eurozone banks fell 2.1% after the ECB agreed to provide lenders with ultra-cheap liquidity. The STOXX eurozone index and Germany's DAX both declined, with oil stocks rising on a surge in crude prices. The ECB's warning of slower growth in 2026 has raised concerns about the eurozone's economic recovery.

site_title: Gen Z goes investing
summary: Gen Z's investing habits are on the rise, with brokerages reporting a significant increase in account openings among 18-24 year olds due to the pandemic. This demographic, known as digital natives, is becoming increasingly involved in online investing. To better understand their behavior, The Business Times Weekend conducted interviews with Gen Z investors, exploring their strategies and investment goals.

site_title: S&P DJI removes Chinese firms from indexes
summary: S&P DJI has removed 10 Chinese companies, including Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology Co and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), from its index products due to the US executive order banning US investment in firms backed by the Chinese military. The move is seen as a challenge to investors' assumptions about a warmer relationship with China under the Biden administration. The removal of these companies may impact the ability of passive investors to replicate S&P DJI's indices, and could lead to significant market disruption and potential losses for funds tracking these indices.

site_title: About 5,500 jobs available in healthcare: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore reported that nearly 5,500 job openings are available in the healthcare sector, with three in four being long-term positions. The majority of long-term jobs (1,530) are in professional and executive roles, while support roles account for 2,550 long-term job openings. Short-term jobs (1,390) are mainly in support and administrative support roles. The healthcare sector, supported by a workforce of over 100,000 people, is offering various job opportunities, including training and traineeships, to address the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic's temporary vacancies.

site_title: Alibaba's logistics arm launches 500m yuan global tender
summary: Alibaba's logistics arm, Cainiao Smart Logistics Network, has launched a global tender valued at 500 million yuan (S$102.2 million) to strengthen its logistics network across key markets including North Asia, South-east Asia, Australia and New Zealand, and the US. The tender will cover business-to-consumer and business-to-business logistics services, with the goal of delivering greater stability and efficiency to support cross-border e-commerce businesses. Cainiao has over 3,000 logistics partners and three million courier personnel on its platform, and the deadline for tender submissions is December 15.

site_title: Insurers eyeing M&A deals to expand post-pandemic clout
summary: Insurers are aggressively pursuing mergers and acquisitions to expand their post-pandemic influence, with over $93 billion in deals announced in 2020, a record high since the last financial crisis. The industry's push for consolidation is driven by insurers seeking to strengthen their positions as the pandemic subsides. Major players, including RSA Insurance Group and Zurich Insurance Group, are among those eyeing acquisitions, setting the stage for a potentially massive year for industry deals.

site_title: STI slips 0.6% on Brexit uncertainties, US stimulus impasse
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.64% lower, retreating 18.11 points to 2,824.96, due to Brexit uncertainties, the US stimulus impasse, and rising Covid-19 cases. The losses followed an overnight sell-off in US tech stocks after Facebook was accused of breaking antitrust law. Despite vaccine rollout cheer in Asia, regional bourses were largely down, with China posting marginal gains and Malaysia up 0.1%. Analysts expect further market volatility until a stimulus deal is delivered.

site_title: The little art show that could
summary: The seventh edition of Pameran Poskad, a biennial art show featuring artworks sold at postcard prices, opens at ION Art Gallery in Singapore. The event, which limits 50 visitors per hour, showcases works by 450 artists, including senior artists like Anthony Chua and Pinaree Sanpitak, as well as young hotshots like Robert Zhao Renhui. The show's inclusive nature, allowing artworks by children and senior artists, is a key factor in its popularity. Co-organiser Seah Tzi-Yan notes that the event brings everyone together, especially during challenging times like the current year.

images.alt_text: (Left) Malaysia's Awang Damit abstract measuring 50cms by 50cms priced at S$2,500. (Right) Filipino artist Elmer Borlongan's postcard-sized artworks are priced at about S$800.
Singapore artist Robert Zhao Renhui's diasec photograph selling for S$1,000.

site_title: A winter's tale
summary: Monica Anne Lie, founder of The Ordinary Co, transforms her 110 sq m apartment into a festive snow-themed space for Christmas. She starts decorating in September and revives a childhood tradition with her husband, Justin Koh. Lie's elaborate decorations, including a 7 ft tall tree and gold and silver theme, have earned her a US$1,000 prize in a previous tree decorating contest. She prefers sustainable options, such as a plastic tree from Oncor Tree, and gets inspiration from Pinterest. Lie plans to decorate for the next two Christmases and hosts smaller parties to accommodate friends due to social distancing measures.

site_title: New type of housing targeted at seniors to be launched in Feb 2021 BTO exercise
summary: The Singapore government is launching a new public housing concept, community care apartments (CCAs), targeting seniors. The 32-square-meter CCAs will be available in the February 2021 BTO exercise, with indicative pricing ranging from S$40,000 to S$65,000 for 15- to 35-year lease tenures. Market watchers praise the move, expanding residential options for seniors, but residents must subscribe and pay for a basic service package.

site_title: Sushi show at Masaaki
summary: Sushi Masaaki, a new restaurant in Singapore, has received praise for its value and creativity in a satisfying meal. Chef Masaaki Sakashita, who previously worked at Sushi Ishi, has elevated his game with upscale, course-only options starting from $120 to $250 for lunch and $280 to $380 for dinner. The restaurant offers good value, with dishes such as snow crab and roe in a dashi vinegar jelly, grilled eel, and abalone, all expertly prepared and presented. The chef's engaging and hospitable manner adds to the experience, making it a reservation worth waiting for. Rating: 7.

site_title: UK-Singapore FTA to bring certainty and increased growth
summary: The UK and Singapore have signed a Free Trade Agreement (FTA), marking the UK's first in South-east Asia. The agreement aims to increase two-way commercial opportunities between the two trade-reliant nations, with a focus on services liberalization, removal of non-tariff barriers, and simplified customs procedures. The FTA is expected to boost trade and investment, particularly in key sectors such as digital innovation, electronics, and pharmaceuticals. It also provides opportunities for e-commerce and digital trade, aligning with the growing digital economy in South-east Asia.

site_title: SE-Asia still glimmers despite Covid-19, says panel of startup investors
summary: A panel of startup investors believes South-east Asia remains attractive for investors despite the impact of Covid-19 due to steady fundamentals, rising internet penetration, and richer human capital. The region's growing affluence is driving startup growth, and its young population and consistent growth have created a "powerful trend" driving a rise in the middle class. Major markets such as Singapore and Vietnam have responded well to the pandemic, and investors remain optimistic about the region's long-term fundamentals.

site_title: The terrifying car that Bentley's boss wants to risk his life for
summary: Bentley unveiled a recreation of its 1929 4.5-litre "Blower" car, a development mule that will be used to test its reverse-engineered classics. The car, dubbed "Car Zero," was created after 40,000 hours of work and will be driven 8,000 km on the track to simulate 35,000 km on the road. The company's chairman, Adrian Hallmark, reportedly volunteered to drive the car at top speed, despite its 240 horsepower. The recreated Blowers, costing £1.5 million each, were sold out within hours, demonstrating the value of Bentley's classic cars.

site_title: Spice and variety
summary: Chef Rishi Naleendra's highly anticipated Sri Lankan restaurant, Kotuwa, has finally opened at the Wanderlust hotel in Little India, almost nine months after its initial planned opening date in April. The restaurant's success was largely due to its home delivery menus, which were a resounding success during the pandemic. Kotuwa's menu features traditional Sri Lankan dishes with a few unique twists, including hoppers, fermented rice pancakes, and dishes like fried beef cheek and pork belly in black pepper caramel. The restaurant is located under one roof with Socieaty, a multi-concept space featuring various casual restaurants.

site_title: Small businesses hit by pandemic get 6-week period to renegotiate contracts
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law announced a 6-week period for small businesses to renegotiate contracts hit by the pandemic. Eligible companies can serve a notice of negotiation from Jan 15 to Feb 26, 2021, with 4 weeks for renegotiation and 2 weeks for counter-parties to object. Businesses with revenue under S$30 million and a 70% decline in monthly average gross income are eligible. If renegotiation fails, contracts will be terminated with default terms, including rent payment and security deposit return.

site_title: China on global charm offensive with 'vaccine diplomacy'
summary: China is launching a global "vaccine diplomacy" effort, offering its homegrown jabs to poorer countries in an effort to repair its tarnished image and increase global influence. The move comes as Western countries scramble to buy up limited vaccine supplies, and China hopes to capture a significant share of the market. Beijing has signed deals with several countries, including Malaysia and the Philippines, and is ramping up production facilities to make one billion doses next year. However, concerns remain over the safety and efficacy of Chinese vaccines, as well as the lack of transparency in the country's system.

site_title: ECB gives eurozone another shot in the arm to fight pandemic
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has expanded its debt purchase scheme and provided banks with ultra-cheap liquidity to support the eurozone economy amid the pandemic. ECB President Christine Lagarde expects a slower-than-expected recovery in 2021 but a quicker rebound in 2022, with growth projected at 3.9% and inflation at 1% next year. The bank has increased its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme by 500 billion euros and extended its scheme by nine months to March 2022 to keep borrowing costs at record lows.

site_title: World's biggest investors separate China from emerging markets
summary: Major global investors, including Amundi and Robeco, are shifting their strategies to focus on China as a distinct asset class, separate from emerging markets. This move comes amid increased demand from clients who previously invested in China through global developing-nation funds. BlackRock also views China as a standalone investment destination, rather than part of emerging markets. This shift reflects the growing economic and investment distinction between China and other emerging markets.

site_title: A US$2.5b default shows China has no mercy for weaker firms
summary: China is set to let a high-flying chipmaker, Unigroup, default on a $2.5 billion bond, marking a significant signal that foreign investors shouldn't expect Beijing to bail out weaker state-linked companies. The default will force investors to reassess the creditworthiness of these firms, which have relied on debt to expand. This move is part of China's strategy to give markets greater sway and build a stronger, more efficient economy, as it seeks to crack down on firms posing a threat to the financial system.

site_title: Vaccines herald return to offices, but US workers don't want to go back
summary: US employees are hesitant to return to offices after months of working from home due to the Covid-19 vaccines. A Pew Research Center survey found that over half of employees want to continue remote work arrangements, with 11% preferring not to work from home at all. A University of Chicago survey also found that employees value increased flexibility and are willing to trade up to 8% of their salaries for remote work. As a result, productivity may increase by up to 2.4% and some employees may resist returning to crowded workplaces, even after a vaccine becomes widely available.

site_title: BlackRock sets out strong stance on sustainability, governance
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, has issued an updated stance on sustainability and governance, engaging with companies more intensely and holding directors accountable on climate risk and other issues. The firm will vote against directors' re-election where companies are not moving with sufficient speed and urgency on sustainability. BlackRock will focus on 1,000 carbon-intensive companies in 2021, expanding from 440 last year, and will hold directors accountable for demonstrating sound governance and sustainable business practices.

site_title: Relief available for small landlords and firms renting equipment, vehicles
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Law's Re-Align Framework offers relief to small landlords and firms renting equipment or vehicles affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Landlords with leases of less than five years can renegotiate terms, while small landlords facing financial hardship can receive compensation for early lease termination. Companies renting equipment or vehicles can repay contractual arrears on an 18-month instalment plan. Eligible landlords must meet specific income criteria, and companies must serve a notice of revision during a six-week window. The relief is available until the end of the contract renegotiation period.

site_title: Nanofilm's technology will create opportunities in new markets: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price on Nanofilm Technologies International to S$4.52, maintaining its "buy" call, following the company's inclusion in three FTSE indices. The nanotechnology solutions provider's differentiated technology will open up opportunities in new markets, such as personal grooming, new energy, and 5G industries. The company's second plant in Shanghai, expected to be fully operational by end-2021, will support its growth. UOBKH analysts expect a robust 38.7% three-year compound annual growth rate for the company's earnings.

site_title: Best World 'exploring adjustments' to its China sale and distribution model
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based beauty products firm, is "exploring adjustments" to its business model in China to ensure compliance with laws on direct selling and multi-level marketing. The company plans to transition to a direct-selling model, expanding its existing licence, after facing scrutiny over its skincare sales and financials. The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm has suspended approvals for similar applications amid a nationwide crackdown on exaggerated advertisements and harmful products.

images.alt_text: Best World's long-term plan is to eventually shift to a direct-selling model in China, to address the potential risks under the country's chuan xiao (multi-level marketing) and direct-selling laws.

site_title: Euro stands its ground ahead of ECB stimulus
summary: The euro held steady ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus measures, while sterling fell after post-Brexit trade talks were extended until the weekend. Economists expect the ECB to expand its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP) by at least 500 billion euros and extend its duration to the end of 2022. The euro rose 0.04% against the US dollar and 0.7% against the pound, while sterling fell 0.3% against the US dollar. The ECB is also expected to take a strong stance against the euro's recent rise, with economists predicting a "toothless tiger" response.

site_title: New home sales rebound in November on vaccine optimism and new launches
summary: New home sales in Singapore rebounded in November with 749 units sold, a 16.7% increase from October, driven by strong demand at new launches such as The Linq @ Beauty World and The Landmark. The full-year 2020 sales volume is expected to reach 9,000-10,000 units, surpassing last year's 9,912 units. Vaccine optimism and hopes for economic recovery are seen as key factors contributing to the rebound, with new project launches and prime locations also driving demand.

site_title: CRCT announces results of preferential offering
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) announced results of its preferential offering, receiving valid acceptances and excess applications for 133.77 million units, representing 194% of available units. 68.99 million units will be issued at S$1.17 to raise S$80.7 million. The units will be listed and quoted on the mainboard from Dec 16, with Retail Crown and CapitaLand Retail China Trust Management collectively owning 21.9% of the total units.

site_title: Robinsons to close Heeren store on Dec 16; Marks & Spencer to exit Raffles City
summary: Robinsons' flagship store at The Heeren in Singapore will close on Dec 16, marking the department store's exit in the country. The Raffles City Shopping Centre outlet of Marks & Spencer will close on Dec 31 after 34 years as a tenant. Robinsons' liquidators are still in talks with the landlord at Raffles City, where the second remaining store is located. Marks & Spencer remains committed to the local market and is exploring growth opportunities, with its 10 other stores in Singapore remaining open.

site_title: Airbnb prices shares above target in 2020's biggest US IPO
summary: Airbnb Inc raised around $3.5 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) by selling shares at $68 apiece, above its targeted price range. The IPO valued the company at $47.3 billion, marking a turnaround from its decline in fortunes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's revenue rebounded in the third quarter, reaching $1.34 billion, and it posted a surprise profit of $219.3 million.

site_title: Google, Amazon fined total of 135 million euros by French data watchdog
summary: Google and Amazon have been fined a total of 135 million euros by France's data watchdog, CNIL, for violating EU cookie regulations. Google was fined 100 million euros for automatically placing cookies on users' computers without consent, while Amazon was fined 35 million euros for doing the same. The companies have been given three months to make changes or face daily fines of 100,000 euros. Both companies dispute the findings, with Google citing evolving regulatory guidance and Amazon stating it complies with all applicable laws.

site_title: Thai Union to focus on new areas of growth amid robust demand for core products
summary: Thai Union, a global seafood conglomerate, is shifting its focus to new areas of growth, driven by robust demand for core products during the pandemic. CEO Thiraphong Chansiri is betting on niche, high-value products such as seafood-derived ingredients and alternative proteins to become new growth drivers in the next five years. The company has invested in foodtech startups and is exploring joint ventures to boost growth. Despite encouraging financial results, Thai Union is taking a conservative stance, expecting around 5% topline growth, with a focus on increasing profitability.

site_title: No flipping please, says auctioneer seeking US$3m for Trump's childhood home
summary: US President Donald Trump's childhood home is up for sale for the fourth time, with a target price of US$3 million. The auctioneer hopes admirers of the president will pay the high price, despite other similar Tudor-style houses on the street listing for around US$1.3 million. The sale is being handled by Paramount Realty, which is seeking to capitalize on Trump's popularity.

site_title: Close to 5,500 jobs available in Singapore's healthcare sector
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector has over 5,500 job openings, with nearly 40% in professional and executive roles, such as nurses and allied health professionals. Long-term positions offer monthly salaries ranging from S$3,300 to S$5,200. Support roles, like patient service associates and healthcare assistants, earn between S$1,800 and S$2,300 monthly. The sector has seen over 8,000 jobseekers and trainees placed since April, with 93% finding employment in jobs, traineeships, or training positions. The government is committed to supporting workers in entering the healthcare sector, offering training opportunities and career conversion programs.

site_title: PLife Reit acquires nursing home in Japan for 1.65b yen
summary: PARKWAY Life Reit (PLife Reit) has acquired a nursing home in Japan's Greater Tokyo region from KK Habitation for 1.65 billion yen (S$21.2 million), with a 6.4% net property yield. The 100-bed facility will be secured under a 20-year master lease, extending PLife Reit's Japan portfolio's weighted average lease expiry to 11.44 years. The acquisition, funded by a yen loan facility, will increase gearing to 39.3% and boost the Reit's resilience.

site_title: New Mercedes E-Class aims to prove that smart is sexy
summary: Mercedes has launched a revamped E-Class, emphasizing computing power over horsepower. The all-time bestseller has found 14 million buyers since its 1946 inception. The new model is the centre of Mercedes' product family, according to CEO Claudius Steinhoff. This move highlights the brand's focus on smart technology, marking a shift in their approach to car design.

site_title: Theatre treats this December
summary: Singapore's theatre scene is reviving this December with three recommendations. Dream Academy's "Crazy Christmas Fun-Raiser Concert" is a high-energy show with a big brassy comedy concert, featuring the Dim Sum Dollies. Meanwhile, Sight Lines Entertainment & Chong Tze Chien's "Murder At Mandai Camp: The Case Reopens" is a gripping online whodunit that attracted 700 viewers. Lastly, T:>Works is presenting a hybrid showcase "How To Break A Window" featuring live performances, short films, and staged readings, exploring new ways to engage audiences in the post-pandemic era.

site_title: UK plans to join CPTPP; move will boost economic security
summary: The UK plans to submit an application to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) in early 2021, aiming to boost economic security and tap into a market of over US$10 trillion. British Secretary of State for International Trade Elizabeth Truss has already met with the chief negotiators of CPTPP member countries, including Singapore. A successful application would significantly expand the UK's trade opportunities in the region.

site_title: Caring and sharing
summary: Entrepreneur Jason Lee and his dentist wife Vera are adjusting their Christmas plans due to COVID-19 restrictions. Instead of hosting one large party, they'll be hosting smaller gatherings with more frequent visits from friends and family. This tradition, which started 5 years ago with 8 guests, has become a cherished annual event for Dr. Lee, who values the intimate time with her girlfriends from school days. The Lees plan to host afternoon tea sessions, allowing for more time to catch up and celebrate the holiday season.

site_title: A Merry Singaporean Christmas
summary: Singaporean chef Willin Low shares his alternative Christmas menu featuring Asian flavors using easily available supermarket ingredients. Inspired by his childhood, Low combines traditional Peranakan dishes with Christmas elements, such as mullet cranberry sambal and beef cheek rendang cottage pie. Using FairPrice Finest ingredients, he offers recipes for adobo duck, beef cheek rendang, and ngoh hiang bread fritters, showcasing a unique and festive Singaporean Christmas menu.

site_title: Robin Hu to head Temasek's international policy & governance group; Steve Howard joins as CSO
summary: Temasek has appointed Robin Hu, its head of international policy & governance group, as its new head of sustainability, while Ikea's former CSO Steve Howard joins as the head of its sustainability group. Hu, who remains a senior Temasek leader, will lead the firm's initiatives and develop a holistic sustainability framework. Howard brings experience as a leader on climate change issues, previously serving as CSO at Ikea and co-founding the We Mean Business coalition. His appointment reflects Temasek's commitment to putting sustainability at the core of its operations.

site_title: ADB sees shallower Asia slump amid better China, India prospects
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has revised its economic forecast, predicting a 0.4% contraction in Asia's GDP this year, down from the 0.7% drop previously estimated, due to a slower-than-expected decline from the coronavirus pandemic. The region's growth is expected to recover in 2021, with a 6.8% growth projection. This improvement is attributed to better prospects in China and India, which are expected to contribute to the region's economic recovery.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific reverses losses with profit of US$21.85 million for Q2 FY21
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$21.85 million for Q2 FY21, reversing a loss of US$37.35 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue rose 12% year-on-year to US$623.45 million, driven by higher sales in the US and Philippines. The company expects to return to profitability in FY2021, barring unforeseen circumstances. For H1 FY2021, Del Monte Pacific recorded a net profit of US$18.6 million, with revenue growing 11% to US$1.04 billion.

site_title: Sweden sets new daily Covid case record, says ICU beds not full
summary: Sweden has set a new record for daily Covid-19 cases with 7,935 cases on December 10, 2020. Despite the high number of cases, the country's ICU beds are not full, with 148 unoccupied beds available, representing 22% free capacity. The government has tightened public gathering recommendations and high schools will switch to distance learning to curb a severe second wave, resulting in 58 new fatalities and a total death toll of 7,354.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.86 points to 1,654.39 on Thursday, driven by higher shares. Volume reached 8.099 billion lots worth RM4.830 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 644 to 568.

site_title: Bhutan Parliament decriminalises homosexuality
summary: Bhutan's Parliament has approved a Bill to decriminalize homosexuality, making the country the latest Asian nation to ease restrictions on same-sex relationships. The Bill, which was passed by a majority of 63 out of 69 members, will need to be approved by the King to become a law. The move is seen as a victory for the LGBT+ community in Bhutan, with rights activist Tashi Tsheten calling it a "momentous day" for everyone in the country. Bhutan is the second Asian nation, after India, to relax restrictions on same-sex relationships.

site_title: DBS to launch crypto trading platform for members next week
summary: DBS, South-east Asia's largest lender, plans to launch a members-only crypto trading platform next week, facilitating spot exchanges between fiat currencies and cryptocurrencies. The platform, part of the DBS Digital Exchange, will also offer tokenised digital assets and digital custodial services. DBS holds a 90% stake in the exchange, with the Singapore Exchange holding 10%. The platform is expected to launch with trading in four fiat currencies and four established cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ethereum. DBS aims to capitalize on the growing appetite for digital assets and believes it has a first-mover advantage in the market.

site_title: Indonesia secures 155.5m doses of coronavirus vaccines, seeks 116m more
summary: Indonesia secures 155.5 million doses of coronavirus vaccines through deals with Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Covax, exceeding its target of 246.6 million doses. The country has already secured 125.5 million doses from Sinovac Biotech and 30 million from Novavax. Indonesia seeks an additional 116 million doses to reach a total of 271.5 million doses.

site_title: US inflation measure rose by more than forecast in November
summary: US inflation measure rose 0.2% in November, exceeding forecast, driven by accelerated costs of transportation services and apparel. The core index also advanced 0.2%, with transportation services jumping 1.8% and lodging costs increasing 3.9% from October. Despite inflationary pressures, the pandemic's curb on activity and limited consumer spending suggest that a broadening of inflation will take time, with merchants having limited leeway to charge more due to elevated unemployment and restrictions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore and the UK signed a free trade agreement, granting Singaporean and British companies the same benefits as under the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement. GIC's stake in DoorDash increased to US$5.04 billion after the company's market debut. StanChart Singapore moved closer to becoming a digital-only bank with enhanced SRFB privileges. Small businesses affected by Covid-19 have a six-week window to renegotiate contracts from Jan 15 to Feb 26.

site_title: Departing Hong Kong residents withdraw US$298.8m in pension funds in H1
summary: Hong Kong residents withdrew $294.79 million from their Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) pension accounts in the first half of 2020, a 13.6% increase from the same period in 2019. The number of claims was 13,600, down from 13,700 in 2019. The withdrawals were likely due to fears of erosion of freedoms in Hong Kong, following Beijing's imposition of a national security law. This trend is not unprecedented, as residents withdrew $1.44 billion in the fourth quarter of 2019 during mass protests.

site_title: Indian government offers more concessions as farmers intensify protests
summary: India's agriculture minister, Narendra Singh Tomar, has offered more concessions to farmers protesting against new agricultural legislation. The government is ready to consider changes to the divisive reforms, which have triggered the biggest protests by farmers in years. Farmers have rejected earlier compromises, fearing they will lose government guarantees on prices and be left at the mercy of private buyers. The protests, which began in November, have threatened to intensify, with farmers planning to block national highways and boycott public events. The government aims to increase farmers' income, but farmers are concerned about the impact of private investment on regulated markets.

site_title: US: Wall St falls at open as weekly jobless claims surge
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.38% to 39,954.08, the S&P 500 down 0.52% to 3,653.71, and the Nasdaq Composite down 0.80% to 12,240.15. A surge in weekly jobless claims, suggesting a stalling labor market recovery, contributed to the decline. Negotiations over fresh economic stimulus continued to drag on, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: New type of housing targeted at seniors to be launched in Feb 2021 BTO exercise
summary: The Singapore government is launching Community Care Apartments (CCAs) in February 2021, targeting seniors with senior-friendly fittings and services such as 24-hour emergency monitoring and response. The 32 sqm flats will be available for sale to those 65 and above, with lease terms ranging from 15 to 35 years. Residents will need to subscribe to a basic service package and can opt for additional care services. The apartments will be located at Bukit Batok West Ave 9 and will have a limited allocation of 160 units.

site_title: PLife Reit to acquire nursing home in Japan for 1.65 billion yen
summary: PARKWAY Life Reit (PLife Reit) acquired a 100-bed nursing home in the Greater Tokyo region from KK Habitation for 1.65 billion yen (S$21.2 million). The purchase, valued at 4.6% below market, will generate a 6.4% net property yield. The acquisition lengthens PLife Reit's weighted average lease expiry to 11.44 years and increases gearing to 39.3%. The deal is funded by a long-term yen loan facility to protect against currency fluctuations.

site_title: ECB gives euro zone another shot in the arm to fight pandemic
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has introduced new stimulus measures to support the euro zone economy amid the COVID-19 pandemic. ECB President Christine Lagarde expects GDP growth of 3.9% in 2021 and 4.2% in 2022, with inflation forecast to reach 1% in 2021 and 1.1% in 2022. The measures aim to lift the currency bloc out of a double-dip recession and provide support to the economy.

site_title: DBS launches digital exchange; crypto trading to start in a week
summary: DBS Bank has announced the launch of a digital exchange, which will include a cryptocurrency trading platform. The platform, accessible by institutional and accredited investors, will facilitate trading between four fiat currencies and four established cryptocurrencies. The exchange is expected to launch next week, with a 90% stake held by DBS and a 10% stake held by the Singapore Exchange. The platform will also include a platform for security token offerings and digital custodial services, with a first-quarter launch planned for the security token offerings.

site_title: Thai democracy activists seek UN help to repeal royal defamation law
summary: Thai democracy activists are seeking UN help to repeal the country's royal defamation law, which shields the monarchy from criticism and carries prison sentences of up to 15 years. Twenty-three leaders are facing charges under the law for headlining demonstrations demanding reforms to the monarchy. The law has been used to suppress the democracy movement, with activists stating they are treated "like animals" in prison. The protesters also demand a rewrite of the military-scripted constitution and the resignation of Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha.

images.alt_text: Thai democracy activists rallied at the United Nations' Bangkok office on Thursday (Dec 10) and asked the body to pressure the kingdom into repealing royal defamation laws they say are being used to suppress their movement.

site_title: SGX RegCo warns public of 'pump and dump' activities that exploit social media plaforms
summary: SGX RegCo warns the public of potential 'pump and dump' activities on social media platforms, particularly on Telegram chat groups. These schemes involve promoting a security's interest to drive up its price, then selling the shares at a profit. The regulator advises investors to conduct their own due diligence and research before investing, as information shared on social media may not be credible. SGX RegCo will refer suspected wrongdoers to statutory authorities for investigation.

site_title: US jobless claims rose sharply last week as economic crisis grinds on
summary: US jobless claims rose sharply last week, with over 947,000 workers filing new state unemployment benefits, up nearly 229,000 from the previous week. This marks the third consecutive week of increases, with applications up nearly a quarter-million since early November. The Labor Department reported 853,000 seasonally adjusted claims, an increase of 137,000.

images.alt_text: Applications for jobless benefits resumed their upward march last week as the worsening pandemic continued to take a toll on the economy.

site_title: Japan plans vaccine freezer buying binge as Tokyo reports record cases
summary: Japan plans to buy 10,500 deep freezers to store COVID-19 vaccines, amid a record 602 new cases in Tokyo. The country has agreements for 290 million doses, enough for 145 million people, with Pfizer and Moderna vaccines requiring extremely low temperatures. The government will oversee the vaccination operation, prioritizing frontline workers, seniors, and those with underlying health conditions. Japan's vaccination efforts are expected to begin in the first quarter of 2021, with AstraZeneca announcing 30 million doses will be supplied in this timeframe.

site_title: US crackdown on Facebook gets thumbs up from EU's Vestager
summary: European Union's antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager approved US antitrust action against Facebook Inc, praising the move as a sign of tech giants facing increasing global scrutiny. The US lawsuit follows similar cases in Canada, Australia, and EU's own antitrust probe into Oculus virtual-reality headsets. Vestager sees the trend as a shift in the debate on tech dominance, with multiple jurisdictions now taking action against tech giants.

site_title: GIC's stake in DoorDash bumped to US$5b after first-day pop in public market
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC's stake in US-based food delivery company DoorDash has increased to around US$5.04 billion after the company's market debut. GIC initially invested US$155.1 million and held 8.37% of the equity. DoorDash's shares soared 85.8% on their first day, valuing the company at US$60.2 billion. GIC's technology investment group head Jeremy Kranz is a board member of DoorDash, further solidifying the fund's involvement in the company.

images.alt_text: GIC holds 8.37 per cent of the equity in DoorDash, following the company's initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: STI back in red by 0.6% on US stimulus impasse, Brexit overhang, more virus cases
summary: Singapore shares retreated 0.64% on a listless trading day due to the US stimulus impasse, Brexit overhang, and rising Covid-19 cases. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 18.11 points to 2,824.96. The losses were partly offset by a marginal gain in China and a 0.1% rise in MM2 Asia. Nanofilm Technologies International was a standout performer, jumping 9% to S$3.88. The European Central Bank is expected to extend its support measures amid economic pressure.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares closed in the red on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.35% to 26,410.59, amid investor concerns over stuttering US stimulus talks and faltering post-Brexit trade negotiations. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight changes. The losses follow a trend seen on Wall Street, where stocks fell due to uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Robinsons to close Heeren store on Dec 16; sister brand Marks & Spencer to exit Raffles City
summary: Robinsons, a department store operated by the Al Futtaim group, will close its flagship store at The Heeren in Singapore on December 16. The sister brand Marks & Spencer will exit Raffles City Shopping Centre on December 31, with its 10 other Singapore stores remaining open. Robinsons has been conducting closing-down sales for both stores since its exit announcement in October. Marks & Spencer has emphasized its commitment to the local market, citing plans for store upgrades and growth opportunities.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.23% and the Topix index down 0.18%. Investors took profits following a decline on Wall Street, where US lawmakers disagreed over a proposed stimulus package. The benchmark indices slipped to 26,756.24 and 1,776.21, respectively.

site_title: Gul Circle industrial site goes to New Century; no award for Tampines tender
summary: JTC has awarded the tender for the 160 Gul Circle industrial site to New Century Integration for S$2.2 million. The site, spanning 3,686 sq m, is zoned for Business 2 or heavier industrial use and has a 20-year tenure. A separate tender for the Tampines North Drive 3 site was not awarded due to non-compliance with usage plans. The decision comes after four bids were received for the Gul Circle site and one bid for the Tampines site.

site_title: Paris enjoys Brexit bonus with estimated 4,735 extra finance jobs
summary: Paris has seen a significant influx of 4,735 finance jobs from the UK since Brexit, according to a French lobby group. This number, combined with other sectors, brings the total estimated job boost to 9,516. In contrast, more than 7,500 finance jobs and £1 trillion in assets have left the UK for the EU, according to consultants EY. The number of jobs moving to Paris is still a fraction of those in London, but exceeds initial post-Brexit estimates.

site_title: Pfizer says some vaccine documents accessed in EMA hack
summary: Pfizer confirmed that some documents related to its Covid-19 vaccine submitted to the European Medicines Agency (EMA) were accessed in a cyber-attack. The company stated that none of its systems were breached and that study participants' data was not compromised. The EMA launched a full investigation, and the incident is expected to have no effect on the vaccine review timeline. The EMA is evaluating the vaccine on a rolling basis, with a clearance expected towards the end of the year, and a US FDA panel is set to review the vaccine's safety.

site_title: Two Singaporean teens among six new imported Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Two Singaporean teenagers, aged 18 and 19, were among six new imported COVID-19 cases in Singapore, announced on December 10, 2020. The teens were asymptomatic and returned from the UK. All six new cases, including five other Singaporeans and a Russian, were placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. The number of new cases in the community remains low, with only one case linked to a previous case in the past week.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on US stimulus doubts, virus worries
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.33% on Thursday, closing at 2,746.46, due to stalled US stimulus talks and rising coronavirus cases. The benchmark Kospi dropped 9.01 points, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the decline. Foreign investors were net sellers of 1.36 trillion won, and the won fell 0.27% against the US dollar. South Korea reported 682 new coronavirus cases, threatening the economy and healthcare system.

site_title: EQT buys Danish passenger ferry company Molslinjen
summary: Private equity firm EQT has agreed to buy Denmark's largest passenger ferry company, Molslinjen, from a group of shareholders led by Polaris. Molslinjen, with revenues of around $308.7 million, operates 15 vessels across nine routes. EQT aims to support the company's transition to electrified ferries and introduce renewable fuel sources. The transaction is expected to close in early 2021, with no further financial details provided.

site_title: Europe: Equities advance at open
summary: European stock markets opened with tentative gains on Thursday, driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.4% to 6,592.90 points, while the Paris CAC 40 index gained 0.2% to 5,560.30 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index increased by almost 0.1% to 13,350.03 points. The gains came as investors fretted over the inability of politicians to reach agreements on US stimulus and post-Brexit trade deals.

site_title: Long-awaited Cyberpunk 2077 tops Steam game chart on debut
summary: Cyberpunk 2077, a highly anticipated game by CD Projekt, topped Steam's chart on its debut, selling a record-breaking 33 million units by the end of 2021, according to estimates. The game, set in a futuristic city, features Keanu Reeves and received acclaim for its world design and characters, despite some technical glitches. Pre-orders exceeded eight million copies, and shares surged 42% this year. The game's success is expected to set records and boost CD Projekt's market capitalization, which reached $10.8 billion after the success of The Witcher 3.

site_title: Broker's take: Nanofilm's tech will create opportunities in new markets, says UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price on Nanofilm Technologies International by 11% to S$4.52, maintaining a "buy" call. The company's inclusion in three FTSE indices is expected to increase awareness and exposure, driving higher trading liquidity. Nanofilm's differentiated technology will open up opportunities in new markets, including personal grooming, new energy, 5G, biomedical, and aerospace industries. The company's second plant in Shanghai is expected to support growth in the medium term, with a 38.7% three-year compound annual growth rate for earnings expected.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap seven-day rally as tensions with China escalate
summary: Australia's shares snapped a seven-day rally, falling 0.7% to close at 6,683.1, as tensions with China escalated. Beijing announced temporary anti-subsidy fees on some Australian wine imports, while Australia sought to boost demand for its cotton. Analysts warned that restrictions on more Australian products could be seen in the coming days. The decline was attributed to a fall in global equities and geopolitical tensions, with gold stocks losing nearly 4% following a steep sell-off in bullion prices.

site_title: Google, Amazon fined 100m euros by French data watchdog
summary: Google and Amazon have been fined 100 million euros by France's data watchdog, CNIL, for mismanaging cookies on their search engine and placing tracking devices on users' computers without consent. Amazon also received a 35 million-euro fine. The companies have been given a three-month deadline to make changes or face daily fines. The penalties are based on French rules, and the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation has increased data watchdog powers, allowing for fines up to 4% of a company's annual global sales.

site_title: Best World 'exploring adjustments' to its China sale and distribution model
summary: Best World International, a beauty products firm, is exploring adjustments to its business model in China to ensure compliance with laws on direct-selling and multi-level marketing. The company plans to transition to a direct-selling model, but the Ministry of Commerce has suspended approvals amid a nationwide crackdown. Best World has faced scrutiny over its skincare sales and financials, including questionable deposits by franchisees and concerns over accounting practices. The company has addressed concerns with the Singapore Exchange and plans to expand its direct-selling license if the ministry resumes accepting applications.

site_title: SoftBank shares leap 14% on DoorDash investment gain
summary: SoftBank shares surged 14% after the US$11.2 billion gain in its stake in DoorDash, a food delivery app, following its blockbuster stock market debut. SoftBank's 25% stake in DoorDash rose to US$11.9 billion, valuing the company at US$68.4 billion. This gain is a boon to SoftBank's US$100 billion Vision Fund, which had recorded losses. The investment is part of SoftBank's efforts to revive the fund, which has also seen gains in Uber Technologies and Arm Ltd shares.

site_title: Japan to sell over 110t yen of new bonds as pandemic costs balloon: sources
summary: Japan plans to sell over 110 trillion yen (S$1.41 trillion) of new government bonds this fiscal year to fund its stimulus packages, driven by the coronavirus crisis and tax revenue losses. The third spending package will boost new debt issuance to over 110 trillion yen, exceeding a record 270 trillion yen. The government aims to minimize increases in bonds sold to financial institutions via regular auctions, instead tapping funds from past bond issuance. The revised bond issuance plan will be announced on Tuesday, with the next fiscal year's plan to be decided on December 21.

site_title: UK GDP growth slows to six-month low as Covid hit hospitality
summary: UK GDP growth slowed to a six-month low in October, falling 0.4% after expanding 1.1% in September, due to a surge in coronavirus cases affecting the hospitality sector. This marks the weakest growth since April's lockdown. The economy has been impacted by the pandemic, with Britain's highest death toll and biggest economic hit, and is expected to take until the end of 2022 to regain pre-Covid size.

images.alt_text: Britain's economic recovery almost ground to a halt in October as a surge in coronavirus cases dealt a blow to the hospitality sector, official figures showed on Thursday.

site_title: Alibaba's logistics arm Cainiao launches 500m yuan global tender
summary: Alibaba's logistics arm Cainiao has launched a 500 million yuan global tender to strengthen its logistics network. The tender covers key markets, including North Asia, South-east Asia, Australia, and the US. Cainiao aims to expand its network of certified third-party logistics partners, curate a list of certified partners for B2C logistics services, and strengthen its warehouse and trucking network for B2B logistics services. The deadline for tender submissions is December 15.

site_title: EssilorLuxottica said to be reconsidering GrandVision deal
summary: EssilorLuxottica is reconsidering its $11.8 billion purchase of optical retailer GrandVision due to concerns over the Covid-19 crisis' impact on GrandVision's business. The company has become increasingly worried about the deal, which was agreed in 2019, amid rising market value of GrandVision shares. GrandVision shares fell 5.4% following the news, giving the company a market value of $6.3 billion.

site_title: Manhattan apartments haven't been this cheap to rent in 10 years
summary: Manhattan apartment rentals have reached a 10-year low, with the median rent plummeting 22% to $2,743 per month in November, according to a report by Miller Samuel and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. Landlords are offering free months of rent and discounts to keep units occupied, resulting in a 30% increase in newly signed leases. Despite this, the vacancy rate remains a record high of 6.14%, with the number of available listings more than doubling to 15,130. Concessions are being offered across other boroughs, with Brooklyn rents falling 8.3% and north-west Queens rents dropping 21%.

site_title: Japan's ruling party calls for tax breaks on green investment
