summary: Japan's ruling party has proposed extended tax breaks on low-emission cars and green investment incentives as part of Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's economic recovery plan, aiming to cut greenhouse gas emissions to zero by 2050. The proposal includes tax exemptions for firms increasing carbon-free investment, extending tax reductions for environment-friendly cars, and cutting tax on aviation fuel. This follows Japan's $708 billion economic stimulus package featuring support for green and digital innovation, seen as key areas for business investment to boost the economy.

site_title: StanChart Singapore moves big step closer to digital-only bank
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore has been awarded enhanced "Significantly Rooted Foreign Bank" (SRFB) privileges by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, paving the way for a digital-only bank. The enhanced SRFB privileges allow the bank to secure an additional full bank license, joining four other digital banks in Singapore. This move comes after StanChart Singapore was named the country's first SRFB in August, with MAS aiming to boost the SRFB framework. The bank is actively developing digital models for consumers in Singapore, with CEO Patrick Lee expressing excitement about the opportunity.

site_title: Indonesia to slow down pace of tobacco tax hike due to pandemic
summary: Indonesia plans to raise the excise tax on tobacco products by 12.5% in 2021, the country's finance minister said, citing a balance between health and economic concerns amid the pandemic. The move may disappoint health groups seeking stronger action, given Indonesia's high smoking rate. The government aims to lower smoking prevalence among youths to 8.7% by 2024. The tax hike will make cigarette prices more expensive but will not affect hand-rolled clove cigarette producers.

images.alt_text: Indonesia will raise the excise tax on tobacco products by an average of 12.5 per cent in 2021, the country's finance minister said on Thursday, citing a need to balance efforts to control smoking with the need to support an industry that is a major employer.

site_title: Small businesses hit by Covid-19 can ask for contract renegotiation from Jan 15 to Feb 26
summary: Small businesses in Singapore can renegotiate contracts from January 15 to February 26, 2021, due to difficulties caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Eligible companies can serve a notice of negotiation, giving the other party four weeks to renegotiate contract terms. The other party is barred from pursuing legal actions during this time. This move aims to support businesses affected by the pandemic and help them adapt to the new circumstances.

site_title: Top investor BlackRock to expand climate talks with companies in 2021
summary: BlackRock plans to engage with over 1,000 companies on climate-related issues, covering 90% of global greenhouse gas emissions linked to its clients' investments. The asset manager aims to step up its engagement efforts and consider accelerated voting actions if companies' climate commitments are not met. BlackRock also calls for companies to reach net-zero emissions by 2050 and align lobbying activities with public statements, increasing its support for climate-related shareholder proposals. These moves come ahead of the shareholder meeting season and aim to help companies improve long-term returns while addressing environmental and social concerns.

site_title: Malaysia's end-Nov palm oil stockpiles fall to 1.56m tonnes: MPOB
summary: Malaysia's end-November palm oil inventories fell to 1.56 million tonnes, a 0.58% decline from the previous month, according to the Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB). Crude palm oil production shrank 13.51% to 1.49 million tonnes, and exports declined 22.16% to 1.3 million tonnes. The decline was lower than the estimated 2% fall in inventories and 10% drop in production.

site_title: World Bank boosts target for climate-friendly financing to 35% over five years
summary: The World Bank has set a new five-year target of 35% of its financing to have climate "co-benefits," up from 28% previously, with half of climate-related financing aimed at supporting climate adaptation and resilience projects. The goal is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote lower-carbon development. The bank's institutions provided over $83 billion in climate-related finance to developing countries between 2016 and 2020. World Bank President David Malpass emphasized the need to address climate change, particularly in poorer countries, to achieve country outcomes that reduce emissions and promote sustainable development.

site_title: Japan's bird flu outbreak worsens, government orders disinfection of poultry farms
summary: Japan's bird flu outbreak worsened, with two more prefectures reporting poultry deaths and exclusion orders in place. Highly pathogenic bird flu has spread to eight of Japan's 47 prefectures, likely brought by migrating birds from the Asian/European continent. The government ordered the disinfection of all poultry farms in the country and plans to slaughter over 130,000 chickens. This is Japan's worst outbreak since 2016, with over 2 million chickens already slaughtered since the latest outbreak began. Officials are concerned about the virus making the "species jump" to humans and causing a pandemic.

site_title: Australia scrambles to find customers outside Chinese for its cotton
summary: Australia is seeking alternative customers for its cotton, particularly in Vietnam, amid tensions with China that threaten to leave the country with large stockpiles. China ordered its cotton mills to stop buying Australian cotton in October, worth around A$900 million, due to escalating tensions. However, Australia's drought-led low production meant it didn't immediately feel the impact. Now, Australian producers are exploring new markets to boost demand and mitigate losses.

site_title: 72 million-dollar HDB flats resold in first 11 months of 2020: SRX
summary: In the first 11 months of 2020, 72 million-dollar HDB flats were resold, surpassing the 64 units sold in 2019. According to SRX, this marks a new high, with 13 such transactions recorded in November 2020. HDB resale prices rose for the fifth consecutive month, but transaction volume decreased.

site_title: A US$4.5b chip deal shows dark side of the boom
summary: Taiwan's GlobalWafers has agreed to buy German semiconductor company Siltronic in a $6.07 billion deal. The acquisition, valued at 3.75 billion euros, is considered an expensive bet on consolidation, with Siltronic's major shareholder Wacker Chemie selling its 31% stake. The deal is seen as a significant bet on revenue growth or cost cuts, but industry growth is unlikely to be a driver, with strong growth expected in chip demand. The merger will create a supplier with around one-third of global silicon wafer revenue, but using its size to boost sales would raise antitrust risks, and cost cuts may not justify the premium paid.

site_title: Singapore and UK sign FTA; to work towards a digital economy agreement
summary: Singapore and the UK have signed the UK-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA), which grants the same benefits as the EU-Singapore FTA to Singapore and UK companies. The countries also plan to start negotiating a UK-Singapore Digital Economy Agreement (DEA) next year, aiming to maintain trade continuity after the Brexit transition period ends.

site_title: Shadow capital stabilised South-east Asia private equity in 2020: report
summary: South-east Asian private equity (PE) deal value fell 50% in the first three quarters of 2020, largely due to Covid-19 uncertainty, but shadow capital investors remained active, deploying direct capital throughout the cycle. The region's PE and VC scene had a thriving 2019, reaching US$12 billion in deal value. Prior to Covid-19, the PE/VC scene had consistently held above US$10 billion in deal value for three consecutive years.

site_title: S&P DJI to remove 21 Chinese firms from equities, bond indices
summary: S&P Dow Jones Indices will remove 21 Chinese companies, including Hikvision and SMIC, from its equities and bond indices due to a US administration order prohibiting the purchase of certain Chinese securities by US investors. The move affects 10 companies in equity indices, set to be removed on Dec 21, and 11 in fixed income indices on Jan 1. The US executive order aims to deter US investment in 31 Chinese companies backed by the Chinese military, effective from Jan 11.

site_title: On-demand video disrupting TV in South-east Asia, study finds
summary: A new study by The Trade Desk and Kantar has found that on-demand video services are disrupting traditional TV in South-east Asia, with 31 million out of 180 million OTT viewers not watching traditional TV in the past three months. The region now consumes 8 billion hours of OTT content per month, rivalling traditional TV viewership. The pandemic has accelerated OTT adoption, with 57% of surveyed consumers watching more OTT content and 72% planning to maintain or raise their consumption after the pandemic ends.

site_title: Goldman Sachs escalates diversity push at portfolio companies; activists want more
summary: Goldman Sachs' asset-management arm plans to pressure US companies to appoint more women and under-represented groups to their boards, but will not set specific numerical targets. The move reflects the growing importance of racial justice to investors, but also highlights the difficulty of effecting social change in the corporate arena. Goldman's influence as a major Wall Street firm will be crucial in shaping the industry's diversity efforts.

site_title: US sanctions Chinese organised crime figure 'Broken Tooth' Wan
summary: The US Treasury has imposed sanctions on Wan Kuok-koi, a notorious Chinese organised crime leader known as "Broken Tooth", for expanding his criminal activities in South-east Asia linked to Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative. Wan, 65, is the head of the 14K triad and has built operations in Cambodia, Myanmar, and Palau since his release from Macau prison in 2012. The sanctions target Wan, his World Hongmen History and Culture Association, and his Hong Kong-based Dongmei Group, which is building a casino-hubbed town in Myanmar.

site_title: Shophouses in prime districts snapped up; owners put more assets on market
summary: Shophouses in prime districts of Singapore are seeing increased buyer interest despite softer asking prices, with owners putting more assets on the market. This trend is attributed to the limited supply of these tightly-held properties, particularly conservation shophouses, which have rich heritage value. Experts believe this will test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark in the upcoming Q3 condo launches. The market's dynamics are expected to continue, with buyers snapping up shophouses in prime locations, driven by the combination of affordability and limited supply.

site_title: Credit Suisse shuts US$2b insurance units after withdrawals
summary: Credit Suisse is shutting down two US$2 billion reinsurance units, Humboldt Re and Kelvin Re, after key investors withdrew funds. The units, which reinsure natural catastrophes and other risks, will stop underwriting new business in 2021. The closures are a blow to Credit Suisse's asset management unit, which is undergoing a strategic review. The bank's insurance-linked securities investment team, managing US$6 billion in assets, is not affected. The decision follows recent years of high disaster claims and strategic decisions by key investors.

site_title: Airbnb reaches US$47b value in above-range IPO
summary: Airbnb has reached a valuation of approximately US$47 billion following its initial public offering (IPO), priced above its marketed range of US$56 to US$60 per share, with 52 million shares sold at US$68 each. The company, which rebounded from the COVID-19 pandemic by capitalizing on domestic travel, saw a 10-month period defined by the pandemic as the "most defining" in its history. Its IPO marks a significant milestone for the company, with shares expected to trade on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol ABNB.

site_title: Keppel Reit obtains A$300m in green loans from UOB, BNP Paribas
summary: Keppel Reit has secured A$300 million in green loans from UOB and BNP Paribas to finance its acquisition of Pinnacle Office Park in Sydney. The Reit's trustee has provided a corporate guarantee for the green loans, which adhere to the Keppel Reit green loan framework. The deal is expected to complete in Q4 2020 and will contribute to revenue in fiscal 2021. Analysts from DBS Group Research have maintained a "buy" rating on Keppel Reit, citing its attractive valuation and potential for growth from China tech giants.

site_title: Gold treads water after sharp sell-off on US stimulus delay
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,839.67 per ounce after a 2.5% sell-off on Wednesday due to the delay in US lawmakers agreeing on a pandemic relief package. The US House of Representatives approved a one-week funding extension, but the Senate remained undecided. Analysts expect gold to remain supported, with forecasts of $2,100 per ounce by 2021, due to accommodative monetary policy and a weaker US dollar.

site_title: Broker's take: Office S-Reits may turn from laggards to leaders, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research recommends investors "stay with their office winners" as the sector's Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are poised for a cyclical recovery. The analysts note that rising flexible-working trends may be mitigated by limited new office supply and a pickup in Singapore's GDP. Office S-Reits are trading at the sector's historical average, and DBS expects unit prices to reach 1.1-time price to net asset value (P/NAV) in 2021, driven by a return to normalcy and a higher-than-expected economic and employment expansion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 3.40 points or 0.21% to 1,645.62. The index saw 250.60 million lots traded worth RM96.48 million, with gains beating losses 236 to 120.

site_title: The spread between new and bluechip art is narrowing
summary: The gap between new and bluechip art is narrowing in the art market, according to recent auction house sales. Sotheby's and Phillips' recent sales, totaling $63.3 million and $134.6 million respectively, showed that emerging artists' works are selling for similar prices to bluechip pieces. Notable sales include Matthew Wong's 2018 work, which sold for $1.25 million above a high estimate, and Amy Sherald's 2015 work, which sold for $4.3 million. This shift in supply and demand is attributed to post-election anxiety, lack of major estates, and social turbulence, with increased online buying and wealthier collectors driving the competition.

site_title: China imposes further duties on Australian wine
summary: China has imposed fresh import duties on Australian wine, increasing tariffs to 6.3-6.4% as part of an ongoing dispute. The move follows accusations that Australian winemakers receive government subsidies, causing damage to China's domestic wine industry. The duties come on top of November's anti-dumping levies of 107-212%. The dispute is part of deteriorating relations between China and Australia, which have also seen China suspend beef imports and hit barley shipments with tariffs.

images.alt_text: China on Thursday said it had imposed fresh import duties on Australian wine as it accused Canberra of giving firms subsidies, in the latest salvo in a bitter stand-off following last month's swingeing anti-dumping tariffs.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as talks on stimulus, Brexit falter again
summary: Asian markets declined as US stimulus and Brexit talks remained stalled. The White House proposed a larger economic rescue package, but lawmakers showed little enthusiasm, citing Republican demands for liability protection and funding for state and local governments. Spiking US virus infections and strict containment measures have highlighted the need for a fresh package. Despite optimism, politicians remain hopeful, with the UK and EU still far apart on post-Brexit trade issues.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 2,832.22 points, following overnight declines on Wall Street. Regional indices, including Tokyo and Australia, also fell. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 47, with Moya Holdings Asia and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding among the top active counters. The US market closed lower amid uncertainty over a new relief package and rising coronavirus cases, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3%.

site_title: Sony to buy AT&T's anime business for US$1.18b to expand global footprint
summary: Sony is acquiring AT&T's anime streaming service Crunchyroll for $1.18 billion, expanding its global entertainment content and distribution businesses. The deal gives Sony access to Crunchyroll's 3 million paying subscribers worldwide, helping it compete with Netflix. The acquisition is part of Sony's strategy to boost gaming and entertainment revenue streams under CEO Kenichiro Yoshida. Sony's Funimation Global Group will own Crunchyroll, which is currently part of AT&T's WarnerMedia segment, following a similar acquisition in 2017.

site_title: Developing Asia's projected 2020 contraction to be less severe than expected: ADB
summary: Developing Asia is projected to contract 0.4% this year, less severe than initially expected due to China's faster-than-anticipated recovery. The region's first contraction in nearly six decades is attributed to the prolonged pandemic. However, a 6.8% growth forecast for 2021 is expected, driven by gradual recovery from the pandemic. Regional inflation is expected to ease to 2.8% this year and 1.9% in 2021, despite ongoing virus outbreaks and restrictions in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Oil rises on vaccine rollout, concern on Iraq oilfield attack
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by optimism over the Covid-19 vaccine rollout in Britain and the US, despite a large build in US crude stocks. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 23 cents to $45.75 a barrel, while Brent crude futures climbed 21 cents to $49.07 a barrel. The vaccine's potential to spur fuel demand and the US imminent approval of a vaccine are key factors. Additionally, a terrorist attack on two wells in northern Iraq raised concerns of further disruptions, but did not affect production.

site_title: China's foreign coal push risks global climate goals
summary: China's plan to fund dozens of foreign coal plants risks exceeding global climate goals, threatening the Paris accord's goal of limiting global warming to 2°C. China's investments will produce 19 gigawatts of power and emit 115 million tonnes of CO2 annually, surpassing the emissions of major economies like Britain, Turkey, and Italy. China's Belt and Road Initiative aims to increase its global sway, but Chinese banks continue to finance coal projects, contradicting President Xi's promise of "open, green and clean co-operation."

site_title: Lab meat is getting closer to supermarket shelves
summary: Lab-grown meat is progressing towards supermarket shelves, with Singapore becoming the first country to allow the sale of cultured meat. Companies like Mosa Meat, Memphis Meats, and SuperMeat are building or operating pilot sites to scale up production, aiming to reduce costs and make lab-grown meat more humane and environmentally sustainable. Despite challenges, the cell-based meat market is projected to reach $140 billion in the next decade, with economies of scale expected to lower costs in years to come.

site_title: Australia says it can beat carbon goals by 2030 without credits
summary: Australia is on track to meet its carbon emissions target by 2030 without relying on old credits from previous climate pacts, according to Energy Minister Angus Taylor. The country's emissions are projected to be 29% below 2005 levels by 2030, exceeding its Paris accord target of 26-28%. This shift in policy comes ahead of the UN Climate Ambition Summit, where countries are urged to upgrade their emissions-cutting pledges to limit global warming to 1.5°C. The move has been met with skepticism from green groups, who argue that the country needs more ambitious action to transition to cleaner energy.

site_title: Britain considers toughening tax rules on 'sharing economy'
summary: The UK is considering tougher tax rules for the sharing economy to boost revenue and ensure a "level playing field" for all businesses. A government paper raised concerns that the current tax system may favor the sharing economy over traditional businesses. The UK Treasury aims to address the "challenges" the sharing economy poses to VAT and other taxes, with a consultation document outlining proposed changes. The goal is to create a more equitable tax environment for all businesses, regardless of their structure or model.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.42% and the Topix index down 0.19%, following a decline on Wall Street. Investors sought to lock in profits ahead of the US-EU trade talks, which may impact the market.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap seven-session rally as gold stocks drag; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares snapped a seven-session winning streak as gold stocks dragged, retreating 0.56% from a nine-month high. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with most major sub-indexes trading in the red, while financials remained flat. The decline was driven by weak US stock performance, which pulled back from record levels amid stalled economic stimulus talks and a drop in Facebook shares.

site_title: China's Great Wall plans new electric, smart vehicle brand: sources
summary: China's Great Wall Motor plans to launch a new standalone brand for electric and smart vehicles, inspired by Tesla's success and Chinese startups like Nio and Xpeng. Several Chinese automakers are seeking to move their products up the value chain as China's economic planners push new technologies. This new brand is expected to offer more expensive products than mass-market lines, as conventional automakers like SAIC Motor and Changan Automobile look to increase their value.

images.alt_text: China's Great Wall Motor plans to launch a new standalone brand for electric and smart vehicles, sources familiar with the plan said, as automakers in world's biggest car market pursue growth in the new segment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, following steep falls on Wall Street due to US lawmakers' struggle to reach a new stimulus package agreement. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.63% to 26,335.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.18% to 3,365.73. The losses were also attributed to global market trends, with the US and EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit prices S$100m perps at 3.85%
summary: Starhill Global Reit's trustee plans to issue S$100 million of 3.85% perpetual securities, refinancing existing borrowings and meeting capital expenditure requirements. The perps will reset every five years to the prevailing Singapore dollar five-year swap offer rate plus an initial spread of 3.292% per annum. OCBC has been appointed the sole lead manager and bookrunner of the perps. Units of Starhill Global Reit closed flat at S$0.48 on Wednesday, awaiting the issue's completion on Dec 15, 2020.

site_title: SpaceX's Starship prototype explodes on landing after test launch
summary: SpaceX's Starship prototype exploded during a return-landing attempt after a test launch from Boca Chica, Texas. The 16-story-tall rocket, intended for human missions to the moon and Mars, blew up as it touched down on a landing pad after a controlled descent. Elon Musk attributed the accident to low fuel header tank pressure during descent, causing high touchdown velocity. Despite the failure, SpaceX obtained the necessary data from the test, and the company will continue to develop its Starship rocket.

images.alt_text: SpaceX's Starship rocket prototype exploded during a return-landing attempt on Wednesday, minutes after an apparently uneventful test launch from the company's facility in Boca Chica, Texas, live video of the flight showed.

site_title: YouTube bans new videos claiming US election fraud
summary: YouTube banned new videos claiming US election fraud, stating that enough states have certified Joe Biden as the next US president to make it official. The platform, owned by Google, will remove content alleging widespread fraud or errors changed the election outcome. This move follows the US Supreme Court's denial of Donald Trump's attempt to block vote certification in Pennsylvania, and comes as Google lifts a moratorium on election-related advertising. The ban is in line with YouTube's practice during previous US elections.

site_title: US House passes stopgap to avoid government shutdown, Senate next
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a federal spending extension, avoiding a government shutdown and keeping federal agencies operating at current funding levels until December 18. The measure, passed 343-67, is expected to clear the Senate before a Friday-into-Saturday deadline. The stopgap measure acknowledges the failure of protracted stimulus negotiations, with Democrats expressing hope for a deal but also criticizing the process as a "recognition of failure" and a "function of procrastination."

site_title: Bangladesh's Summit Group looks to Singapore for its capital-raising needs
summary: Bangladesh's Summit Power International, a Singapore-based company, is seeking capital-raising opportunities in Singapore. The company, which owns a string of power plants in Bangladesh, is exploring deals in power generation projects in Bangladesh and India, as well as opportunities in Pakistan. Summit Power International has a track record of generating positive cash flow and has made board appointments to achieve environmental, social, and corporate governance goals. The company is eyeing a higher valuation for its next capital raise, potentially in the range of US$1.5 billion, and is looking to expand its business into natural gas supply, electricity transmission, and distribution.

site_title: UK house price balance holds near 21-year high: RICS
summary: UK property surveyors reported a house price balance near a 21-year high in December, with prices increasing at their fastest rate in over 20 years. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) said the balance rose to +66, its highest reading since 1999. However, surveyors expect sales to fall when a temporary tax break expires in March 2021, leading to slower price growth. The regional split saw London's price balance at +9, compared to +76 for the rest of Britain.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, mm2 Asia, Top Glove, Keppel Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust divested three South Australian properties for A$29.6 million. mm2 Asia proposed a merger with Golden Village cinemas. Top Glove Corporation plans to reduce foreign worker dependence. Keppel Reit secured A$300 million in green loans. Nanofilm Technologies International will be added to several indices after market close on Dec 21. Starhill Global Reit issued S$100 million of perpetual securities. Moya Holdings Asia posted a net profit of S$11.9 million for the third quarter.

site_title: UK, EU leaders agree to Sunday deadline for Brexit decision: Downing Street
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen agreed to decide by Sunday whether their Brexit talks are worth continuing, citing "very large gaps" between the two sides. The leaders had a dinner discussion in Brussels, where they agreed to further negotiations by their teams over the next few days. A firm decision on the future of the talks is expected by Sunday, with Johnson determined to test all possible routes to a deal.

site_title: Wealth of US billionaires soars during Covid-19 pandemic
summary: US billionaires' collective wealth rose by over $1 trillion since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, from $2.95 trillion on March 18 to $4.01 trillion on Monday. This surge in wealth, fueled by a rebound in technology and health stocks, exceeds a proposed $916 billion stimulus package. The wealth gain could pay for stimulus checks of $3,000 for all 300 million Americans, sparking debate about higher taxes on the rich to narrow growing wealth inequalities.

site_title: FLCT to divest three South Australia properties for A$29.6 million
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) has agreed to divest three South Australian industrial properties for A$29.6 million, representing a 19.4% premium to their book value of A$24.8 million. The portfolio, located near Adelaide Airport, accounts for 0.9% of FLCT's net property income and 0.4% of its portfolio value. The divestment is part of FLCT's proactive asset management strategy, providing greater financial flexibility to manage its capital. The transaction is expected to be completed by March 31, 2021, with estimated net proceeds of around A$28.1 million.

site_title: Biden to name lawyer Katherine Tai to top trade post: reports
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden plans to appoint China expert Katherine Tai as the nation's top trade negotiator, replacing Robert Lighthizer. Tai, a Yale and Harvard Law graduate, will oversee trade policies with US trading partners, including China, the USMCA, and disputes with the European Union. She will be the first Asian-American and fourth woman to serve in the cabinet-level role, recommended by both parties for her work on the USMCA free trade pact.

site_title: Exiled Hong Kong protest leader holds first meeting with UK government
summary: Hong Kong democracy activist Nathan Law met with UK Home Secretary Priti Patel for the first time, following his exile to Britain in July. The meeting discussed the UK's plan to relax entry rules for Hong Kong holders of British National (Overseas) passports, allowing them to live and work freely in the UK. The BNO scheme was created in 1997 to allow Hong Kong residents to apply for restricted British nationality. The UK has already relaxed requirements for BNO holders to bring dependants, and further easing of rules is expected next month.

site_title: Biden's son Hunter says under investigation for tax affairs
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's son, Hunter Biden, is under federal investigation into his tax affairs, according to a statement released by his father's presidential transition team. Hunter Biden, 50, has denied any wrongdoing and claims he handled his affairs "legally and appropriately." The investigation was disclosed just five days before Joe Biden's expected inauguration, amid ongoing Republican attacks on the Biden family, including Hunter's business dealings.

site_title: Singapore's Sea to raise about US$2b in stock offering
summary: Sea Ltd, the tech startup, plans to raise approximately $2 billion through a US stock offering. The offering includes 11 million American Depositary Shares, with an additional 1.65 million available. The funds will be used for business expansion, strategic investments, and acquisitions. Sea's valuation has surged to $100 billion, driven by its successful games and e-commerce platforms, including Free Fire and Shopee. The company aims to become Southeast Asia's equivalent of Tencent and Alibaba, despite a recent slowdown in growth. Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are bookrunning for the deal.

site_title: Goldman in Florida. Hewlett in Houston. Who's next?
summary: The pandemic is prompting companies to reassess their geographical location, shifting away from high-cost coastal metros. Tech companies like Twitter have led the way, with more conservative companies following suit. Hewlett Packard Enterprise moved its headquarters to Houston, while Goldman Sachs is considering a move to south Florida for its asset management arm. This trend is changing the traditional business universe, with companies exploring non-traditional locations with lower costs.

site_title: Facebook antitrust suits seek to divest Instagram, WhatsApp
summary: US federal and state antitrust enforcers filed suit against Facebook, claiming the company abused its dominant position and seeking to unwind its acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp. The Federal Trade Commission and a coalition of state officials called for the divestment of Instagram and WhatsApp, citing that Facebook's actions deny consumers the benefits of competition. The director of the FTC's Bureau of Competition stated that Facebook's actions entrench its monopoly.

site_title: There is still chance of a Brexit deal: Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel says there's still a chance of a Brexit trade agreement, but the EU's 27 remaining members are prepared to live with no deal if necessary. The main sticking point is the "level playing field" rules, which would prevent Britain from undercutting EU standards on labor and environmental issues. Merkel expressed confidence in the European Commission's pursuit of negotiations, but warned that conditions that cannot be accepted will be tolerated.

site_title: Saudi prince asks US court to dismiss 'assassination' lawsuit
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has asked a US federal court to dismiss a lawsuit accusing him of trying to have an ex-intelligence official, Saad Aljabri, assassinated. The lawsuit, filed in August, alleged a "hit squad" was sent from Saudi Arabia to kill Aljabri in Canada in 2018. Prince Mohammed's lawyer claims the lawsuit lacks evidence and that the prince is protected by sovereign immunity as the designated heir to the Saudi throne. The case was previously rejected by Canadian courts, and the prince's lawyers argue that it does not belong in a US federal court.

site_title: China banks dole out more new loans than expected in November
summary: China's banks extended 1.43 trillion yuan in new loans in November, exceeding expectations and beating October's 689.8 billion yuan. This marks the third consecutive month of growth, with total new loans reaching 16.95 trillion yuan in the first 10 months of the year, surpassing the 2019 annual record. The central bank maintains an accommodative stance amid the global pandemic, and analysts expect a gradual withdrawal of stimulus and slowing credit growth. China's broad M2 money supply grew 10.7% in November, and outstanding yuan loans rose 12.8% from a year earlier.

site_title: Container shortage threatens India's nascent export revival
summary: India's recent export revival is threatened by a container shortage, mainly due to the global impact of Covid-19 on trade and a slump in Indian imports. This shortage has led to a seven-fold increase in freight charges, affecting industries like packaged food exports. Companies like Vimal Agro Products are concerned about the potential "big impact" of the shortage on their businesses, with exports to the Indian diaspora being particularly vulnerable. The shortage is expected to persist unless more shipping containers are made available.

site_title: In the mood for Christmas
summary: People are decorating their homes for Christmas due to travel restrictions, with many opting for artificial trees and creative decorating ideas. Local chefs and restaurants are also offering festive spreads and entertainment options, such as an Asian-inspired Christmas dinner and a sushi show at a newly launched restaurant. Meanwhile, articles on topics like mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women are also available.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower amid stimulus uncertainty
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday, closing 0.3% below the day before's record high, amid uncertainty over a new US relief package and rising coronavirus cases. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 1.9%. Despite expectations of a Covid-19 vaccine and a potential stimulus package, the market retreated due to the ongoing stalemate among lawmakers. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin unveiled a $916 billion stimulus proposal, but its passage is unclear.

site_title: EU agency assessing Covid-19 vaccines hit by cyberattack
summary: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has been hit by a cyberattack, with documents related to Covid-19 vaccines being accessed. Pfizer and BioNTech reported that their vaccine documents were "unlawfully accessed" during the attack, but stated that no systems were breached and no personal data was accessed. The EMA launched a full investigation, in cooperation with law enforcement, and assured that the cyberattack would not impact the timeline for its review of Covid-19 vaccine applications.

site_title: German exports inch up, giving economy hope of avoiding Q4 slump
summary: Germany's exports rose 0.8% in October, exceeding expectations, despite a slowdown. The trade surplus expanded to 18.2 billion euros, providing a boost to the economy at the start of the fourth quarter. Economists attribute the sector's resilience to strong manufacturing activity and export-oriented manufacturing, which helped the economy grow 8.5% quarter-on-quarter from July to September. However, the outlook remains mixed due to ongoing lockdown measures and the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Entities linked to Al-Futtaim extended Robinsons S$159.2m in loans
summary: Entities linked to Al-Futtaim extended S$159.2 million in loans to Robinsons, a department store operator, according to a document by its liquidators. The loans were provided by RSH Holdings, Robinson & Co, and ALF Global to fund trading losses. The total loan amount includes S$90.3 million and S$68.2 million from the first two entities and S$756,550 from the third entity.

site_title: DoorDash shares rocket amid IPO fever
summary: DoorDash's initial public offering (IPO) saw its shares surge 80% to $189.51, valuing the company at $39 billion. The San Francisco-based food delivery startup raised $3.4 billion, more than double its private funding valuation of $16 billion. Analysts attribute the strong reaction to investor appetite for emerging tech firms, driven by the pandemic's shift to food delivery. DoorDash is expected to take in $2 billion in revenue this year, with a 50% market share in the US meal delivery market and over 1 million delivery people.

images.alt_text: Food delivery startup DoorDash surged in a US stock market debut as investors gobbled up shares, kicking off a "unicorn parade" set to include Airbnb on Thursday.

site_title: Airbnb, DoorDash lead 'unicorn parade' to cap a hot IPO year
summary: Several hot startups, including Airbnb and DoorDash, are going public in a "unicorn parade" capping a busy year for IPOs. This year has seen 420 initial public offerings on US markets, with companies raising $144.8 billion in the process. The market is hungry for young businesses promising fast growth, particularly in technology sectors such as e-commerce and cloud computing. Analysts expect DoorDash to debut with a valuation of $38.7 billion, while Airbnb is seen as a more promising investment opportunity, with a plausible path to profitability and growth if it can contain costs.

site_title: Global economy's patchy recovery in 2021 could test oil bulls' patience
summary: Oil prices are expected to start 2021 on the back foot due to a patchy global economy recovery, despite OPEC+ output cuts aimed at speeding up the commodity's recovery. Low oil prices can hurt energy firms and oil-producing nations, leading to investment cuts and job losses. The ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, Brexit uncertainties, and rising tensions between the US and China are also weighing down the oil market. However, progress on Covid-19 vaccines may lead to a "mid-year mini boom" in oil prices, subject to vaccine rollout and economic recovery.

site_title: mm2 Asia proposes merger of its cinema business with Golden Village
summary: mm2 Asia proposes a merger with Golden Village cinemas to create the largest cinema operator in Singapore, addressing headwinds from the pandemic and streaming apps. The deal will deliver economies of scale and financial stability, with the combined business owning 22 cinemas in Singapore and Malaysia under various brands. The merger, pending shareholder and regulatory approvals, aims to provide additional working capital and strengthen the balance sheet.

site_title: US dollar nears 2½-year low as vaccine optimism grows
summary: The US dollar fell to a 2½-year low on Wednesday due to growing optimism over the COVID-19 pandemic and the potential for more US fiscal stimulus. The dollar weakened 0.2% against the euro and 0.2% against the Chinese yuan, with the yuan rising over 10% from its May lows. Investors are tracking US coronavirus aid negotiations, which have not seen significant breakthroughs, and are instead focusing on vaccine development and economic recovery.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise ahead of crucial Brexit trade talks
summary: European shares rose ahead of crucial Brexit trade talks, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index closing at its highest since February, up 0.3%. London's FTSE 100 also rose, despite trimming gains, as investors await the outcome of talks between UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

site_title: UK warns people with 'significant' allergies to skip Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for now
summary: UK health officials have issued a warning advising people with significant allergic reactions to skip the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for now due to two reported allergic reactions in NHS staff who received the vaccine. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) has advised caution on a precautionary basis, citing significant allergic reactions to medicines, food, or vaccines as a concern. The vaccine's safety data showed no serious safety concerns in clinical trials, but the MHRA is taking a precautionary approach.

site_title: Promising young companies offer hope amid crisis
summary: Young Singaporean companies, despite the Covid-19 crisis, offer a dose of optimism for the future. Six companies, including Fruits Vending, ImmunoScape, and SkyLab Networks, won the Emerging Enterprise Award for demonstrating potential for significant and sustainable growth. The winners received prizes worth S$385,000, including consultancy services and interest-free loans. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing noted the need for businesses to work together to stay competitive, while also praising the "can-do" spirit of Singapore's young entrepreneurs.

site_title: Biodiversity: Business, academia, global bodies must team up
summary: Biodiversity is closely linked to climate change, and the two issues require collaboration among business, academia, and global bodies to address. The UN's Sustainable Development Goals recognize this interlinkage. Rapid climate change poses challenges to ecosystems' ability to adapt, leading to loss of biodiversity. A shift towards a carbon-neutral economy is necessary, but this requires significant policy changes, including reducing subsidies that distort and counter-productive, such as fisheries and agriculture subsidies. Collaboration and multilateral agreements are key to preserving biodiversity, and a uniform approach to governance is needed to make a meaningful impact.

site_title: Nestle's Singapore factory trying to meet Japan's soaring Milo thirst
summary: Nestle Singapore's factory is experiencing a surge in demand for Milo powder due to an unexpected increase in demand in Japan. Despite the manufacturer stating there is no shortage of raw materials, the supply chain has been impacted. The factory is working to meet the increased demand, but the situation highlights the challenges of managing global supply chains.

site_title: Volkswagen explores new sales model for China EVs
summary: Volkswagen is launching a new sales model in China for its electric vehicles, opening showrooms in city centers and offering fixed prices, a departure from the traditional sales system. The company's joint venture with SAIC Motor has already opened its first showroom in Hangzhou, selling its ID. range of family cars. Customers can order vehicles directly through the company website, phone app, or dealers, with dealers receiving a commission from sales and not maintaining inventory. This model differs from Tesla's direct sales model and aims to increase showroom presence in China's growing EV market.

site_title: Can Joe Biden's America be trusted?
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden faces a challenge in restoring trust among allies, which was severely damaged during Donald Trump's presidency. Trump's history of lying and prioritizing personal interests over national interests eroded the country's soft power and credibility. Biden's initial statements and appointments have had a reassuring effect, but the underlying trust problem persists, fueled by concerns about the state of American democracy and the potential for another divisive president in 2024 or 2028. Biden's ability to manage the country's polarisation and address global challenges will be crucial in rebuilding trust.

site_title: Border reopenings another plus for Singapore's recovery
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to recover in 2021, with nearly half of economists surveyed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) viewing the reopening of borders as a positive factor. However, progress is expected to be slow, and a containment of the Covid-19 pandemic remains the most frequently cited upside to growth. The manufacturing sector is forecast to lift the economy with a 5.8% growth, while construction is expected to contract by 36.2%. Unemployment is expected to reach 3.7% by December, and headline inflation is forecast to come in at 0.6% in 2021.

site_title: Positive Covid case a test of safety protocols for cruises
summary: A Royal Caribbean cruise that returned early due to a passenger testing positive for Covid-19 may not significantly impact tourism if the virus is contained within the next 14 days. The cruise operator has canceled the next scheduled departure and is offering full refunds to affected guests. Industry observers believe that customers are adopting a wait-and-see attitude, and most cruise bookings remain unaffected. Experts note that the incident highlights the importance of having protocols in place for quick contact tracing and isolation, and that customers who are aware of the safety protocols are unlikely to be deterred.

site_title: Police arrest more than 20,000 suspects worldwide in online fraud sweep: Interpol
summary: Interpol has coordinated a global operation dubbed "First Light" with 35 countries, resulting in the arrest of over 20,000 suspects in online and telephone fraud. The operation, which took place on every continent, also led to the seizure of almost $154 million in illicit funds. The majority of crimes involved social engineering tactics, including business email compromise, romance scams, and smishing. The probe highlighted the transnational nature of these scams, with perpetrators often operating from a different country or continent than their victims.

site_title: Covid-19 shows R&D is 'the long game': A*Star chief
summary: Singapore's biomedical community successfully responded to COVID-19 due to decades of investment and collaboration on infectious diseases. A*Star chief executive Frederick Chew highlighted the importance of research and development being a "long game" and the need for "last-mile translation platforms" to convert research into deployable solutions. Collaboration, building trust in technology, and digital literacy are crucial in driving innovation, according to experts, who emphasized the importance of addressing potential biases and cybersecurity threats in AI development.

site_title: Rio Tinto should make restitution to native landowners: report
summary: Australian legislators have recommended that Rio Tinto Group agree to a restitution package with traditional landowners over mine blasts that damaged two ancient Aboriginal heritage sites. The report, released after four months of hearings, advises Rio and other mining companies to halt applications under a state law that allows damage to sites in exchange for permission. The state government should also replace the law with stronger protections, and Rio should make restitution to the native landowners. The report's interim findings aim to address the incident that occurred in 2020.

site_title: Proper incentives, business acumen needed for internalised Reit manager model to work
summary: Sabana Reit's failed merger with ESR-Reit has raised questions about the viability of an internalized Reit management model in Singapore. Only one successful case, Croesus Retail Trust, demonstrates that internalization is possible with a proper incentive program and a good sponsor relationship. Internal managers face challenges without a sponsor relationship, while externally managed Reits benefit from resources and talent from the parent platform. The debate highlights the need for a balance between the two structures, with some arguing that internalization can work if managed correctly, while others point to the potential for misaligned interests and lower returns.

site_title: Europe's bankers aren't ready for marriage
summary: Europe's banking union, aimed at boosting the resilience of the eurozone's financial system, faces significant hurdles. Despite a year-long pause, the project's completion seems uncertain due to rising economic nationalism and banking consolidation. The pandemic has spurred a wave of consolidation, mainly along national lines, and key issues, such as a joint deposit insurance scheme, remain unresolved. The Eurogroup plans to present a new banking union plan in the middle of next year, but deeper political issues must be addressed first.

site_title: WHO expert: Air freight prices 'outrageous' for Covid-19 vaccines
summary: WHO's logistics chief, Paul Molinaro, says air freight prices for Covid-19 vaccines are "outrageous," with some carriers charging 20 times the normal price for dry ice shipments. The pre-holiday rush has driven price inflation, but capacity is expected to ease in 2021, allowing for easier vaccine distribution. The World Health Organization hopes to deliver half a billion doses by Q1 2021, and is exploring alternative routes, such as charters, to reach low- and middle-income countries.

site_title: FireEye shares drop after company was hacked
summary: FireEye, a US cybersecurity company, announced on December 9, 2020, that it had been hacked by a foreign adversary, likely aligned with the Russian government. The attackers stole sensitive tools used to find vulnerabilities in clients' computer networks. FireEye's shares dropped 9.8% in extended trading. The motive for the attack is unclear, but the company believes the hackers sought information related to certain government customers. FireEye is investigating the breach with the FBI and Microsoft, and has published information to neutralize the stolen tools.

site_title: Endgame for Covid-19
summary: Global growth is projected to expand 5.2% in 2021, with promising vaccine trials potentially driving the Covid-19 pandemic into remission by the second half of the year. However, near-term risks remain substantial due to ongoing economic hardship, restricted mobility, and stifled economic activity. Fiscal deficits and high debt levels pose longer-term risks, with the IMF projecting 3.8% GDP growth in 2022-2025. Geopolitical tensions and rising nationalism exacerbate the crisis, while ESG factors will shape the post-Covid world. A cautious approach on risk assets is advised, with opportunities emerging in the second half of 2021.

images.alt_text: The timing and effectiveness of vaccine treatments will be the key determinant for economic activity and financial asset valuations in the upcoming year.

site_title: Indonesia holds polls under shadow of rising virus cases
summary: Indonesia held regional elections on Wednesday, despite health experts warning of the risk of new coronavirus clusters due to the country's high infection and death rates. Over 100 million people voted, with the president's son and son-in-law among the top contenders. The elections were held despite concerns about voter safety, with some polling stations providing gloves and checking temperatures. The government ignored calls for a second postponement, and officials dispute the link between the elections and the pandemic.

site_title: AirTrunk opens its first Singapore data centre
summary: AirTrunk has opened its first Singapore data centre, AirTrunk SGP1, located in Loyang, with a current capacity of 30 MW. The scalable facility is part of the company's growing Asia-Pacific platform and aims to support hyperscale customers in Singapore and South-east Asia. With a focus on sustainability, the data centre boasts a power usage effectiveness of 1.25 and uses 40% less water than the industry average. The facility is expected to reach 60 MW upon completion and is being supported by partnerships with companies such as StarHub.

site_title: Covid-19 didn't kill Topshop: a lack of creativity did
summary: Topshop's demise is attributed to a lack of creativity, not the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite investing in digital, the brand failed to maintain its creative vision, which was a key factor in its success. Under brand director Jane Shepherdson, Topshop was a destination that generated the pulse of fashion, fostering a culture of experimentation and passion. Without this creative drive, the brand squandered its brand equity, ultimately leading to its downfall. This serves as a cautionary tale for companies to prioritize creativity in their business strategies.

site_title: GM, Ford and most airlines seen lagging Paris climate target
summary: Major transport companies, including General Motors, Ford, and most airlines, are not meeting the Paris climate target of limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius by 2050. According to a report, only 18% of companies have set carbon-reduction plans aligned with the Paris Agreement. Airlines, particularly, are lagging due to their reliance on offsets rather than reducing emissions. Only 3 out of 23 assessed airlines have goals that align with the Paris accord, with United Airlines being the only carrier to meet this standard.

site_title: Blackstone, Brookfield bet on India office Reits for yield
summary: Major investors Blackstone and Brookfield are betting on India's office real estate investment trusts (Reits) to provide attractive yields amid low interest rates globally. Blackstone, a backer of Embassy Office Parks Reit, and Brookfield have agreed to pay billions of dollars for office space in India, with plans to list new Reits. The Indian Reit market is dominated by institutional investors and wealthy individuals, with yields of 7.5-8% compared to 3-5% in other cities. The market is expected to continue growing, driven by demand from companies looking to lease offices in India.

site_title: LMIRT faces opposition from unitholders on proposed Lippo Mall Puri acquisition
summary: LMIRT faces opposition from 41 unitholders, holding over 6% of the vote, who are seeking to postpone the vote on the proposed Lippo Mall Puri acquisition. The unitholders claim that the current valuation is too low, citing the early termination of leases, including a large portion vacated by department store Parkson. They also argue that the trust's occupancy rate, 91.9%, is misleading and should be adjusted to between 79.8-81.8% after accounting for the converted space. The acquisition requires approval from more than 50% of the total share of votes cast, but the unitholders' request may stall the deal.

site_title: The newest hotel amenity? Virus-scrubbed air
summary: Hotels and cruise ships are installing state-of-the-art filtration systems to tackle the coronavirus, which is believed to spread primarily through airborne transmission. Some hotels, like the Hotel Paso del Norte in Texas, are using air purification systems that emit charged ions to neutralize the virus. Airlines have been using hospital-grade HEPA filters, which are over 99% effective in capturing tiny virus particles. Researchers have found that SARS-CoV-2 aerosol particles can remain in the air for up to 16 hours, making enhanced air filtration crucial in reducing transmission.

site_title: Asian nations could mandate Covid-19 shots for travellers: AirAsia boss
summary: Asian nations may mandate COVID-19 vaccinations for travelers, according to AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes. This trend could become common in the region, with governments deciding whether to allow unvaccinated individuals to enter. Airlines are unlikely to set vaccination requirements, instead leaving it to governments to make the decision. Qantas Airways was the first airline to announce vaccination requirements for international flights, with other airlines also considering parallel requirements of vaccination or pre-flight tests.

site_title: Lured by bull market, South Koreans take out record loans, piling up debt
summary: South Korean households have taken out record loans to invest in the stock market, fuelled by the bull market, which has seen a 90% increase since March. Bank lending to households rose 13.6 trillion won in November, adding to record levels of household debt. Retail investors have borrowed a record 18.5 trillion won to buy shares, with many using existing debt to finance their investments. Regulators have introduced fresh curbs on loans, but economists warn of a "household debt bomb" that could lead to insolvency filings and bankruptcies if interest rates rise or asset prices fall.

images.alt_text: South Korea's retail investors - using savings, overdrafts, and other loans beside loans specifically taken for share buying - have purchased a record net 60 trillion won of local shares this year.

site_title: COE prices close higher across the board in latest tender
summary: COE prices in Singapore closed higher across the board in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finishing at S$40,714, up from S$37,690. The premium for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at S$45,012, and the commercial vehicle COE price ended at S$32,889, up from S$30,334. Motorcycle premiums also increased to S$7,670.

site_title: Biden's policy for businesses in Asia must start with Covid-19 recovery at home
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden plans to focus on Covid-19 recovery at home before engaging with Asia, with a new playbook needed for foreign policy. He aims to show the region that "America is back in the game" with a robust military presence, strengthened diplomatic and economic relationships, and a renewed focus on trade. Competition with China will be "selective," with a focus on technology competition and addressing critical issues like market access and intellectual property rights. The Biden administration will also re-introduce US values, prioritizing environmental, social, and governance issues.

site_title: Google, Facebook win concession in law to pay for news in Australia
summary: Google and Facebook have won a concession in Australia's world-first law requiring digital giants to pay for displaying news articles. The legislation now also recognizes the monetary value the platforms provide to news businesses by directing readers to their websites. A modification to an earlier draft, the change follows a months-long campaign by Google to get the law blunted. Facebook had threatened to block Australians from sharing news on its sites if the law is passed, but will now engage in the parliamentary process to support Australia's news ecosystem.

site_title: Gulf Oil buys OK Lim's Ocean Tankers assets in Singapore
summary: Gulf Oil International, a subsidiary of the Hinduja conglomerate, has agreed to acquire the assets of Ocean Tankers in Singapore, including a lubricant blending plant, storage tank farm, and terminal facility. The acquisition, subject to closing conditions, will allow Gulf Oil to expand its presence in the marine lubricant market and grow its business in South-east Asia. Ocean Tankers, owned by embattled oil tycoon Lim Oon Kuin, has been placed under judicial management due to significant debt and cash flow issues. The deal is seen as a strategic move for Gulf Oil to invest in the marine segment and increase its market share.

site_title: SoftBank discussing 'slow-burn' buyout to go private: sources
summary: SoftBank is considering a "slow-burn" buyout strategy to take the company private, where founder Masayoshi Son gradually buys back shares until he reaches a 66% stake. This approach would require selling assets to fund successive buybacks, taking over a year to complete. SoftBank would continue to sell assets, including its stake in Alibaba Group and Uber Technologies, to fund the buybacks, with the goal of increasing Son's ownership stake to a majority. The plan has raised skepticism among analysts, who question whether Son will pursue the buyout given the challenges and potential blowback from minority shareholders.

site_title: Singapore, Hungary ink agreement to step up cooperation in fintech innovation
summary: Singapore and Hungary signed a cooperation agreement to step up their collaboration in fintech innovation. The framework will facilitate the referral of fintech firms to each other's markets, share views on emerging trends, and enable joint innovation projects. The agreement was signed at the World FinTech Festival in Budapest, with the aim of promoting financial innovation and creating new opportunities for both countries and their regions. The partnership is seen as a significant move to harness fintech for a smarter and more efficient financial sector.

site_title: Japan's October machinery orders rebound
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rebounded sharply in October, increasing 17.1% from the previous month's drop, exceeding economists' 2.8% forecast. The jump suggests a modest revival in corporate spending, seen as necessary for the world's third-largest economy to accelerate its recovery. This development comes after the government approved a US$708 billion economic stimulus package to boost the economy, which includes direct fiscal spending and investment in new growth areas. A gradual recovery in capital spending is signaled, but policymakers warn it's too early to call a sustained turnaround.

site_title: For retail Reits, domestic spending can mitigate absence of tourist dollars
summary: DBS analysts predict that domestic spending in Singapore will offset the lack of tourist dollars in 2021, benefiting retail Reits (S-Reits) such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) and Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT). With Singaporeans unable to travel due to Covid-19 restrictions, their outbound expenditure may shift to the domestic scene. DBS sees opportunities in fashion, electronics, and F&B sectors, and recommends investors stay invested in its selected retail S-Reits, citing attractive valuations and a cyclical upturn in sentiment.

site_title: Utilising 5G to better our everyday life
summary: Singapore's TechInnovation summit discussed the potential impact of 5G technology on everyday life, highlighting its efficiency, faster data speeds, and reduced energy consumption. Applications include better healthcare treatment, reduced lags for gamers, and easier access to doctors and experts. Additionally, 5G can optimize environmental effects by reducing fuel consumption in industries such as ports and high-speed delivery trucks. Collaboration between operators, governments, and third parties will be crucial to develop meaningful solutions and unlock the full potential of 5G technology.

site_title: Guiding Italy's oldest opera house through the Covid pandemic
summary: Stéphane Lissner, former manager of Italy's Teatro alla Scala, has returned to Naples to lead the Teatro di San Carlo, the country's oldest opera house. Lissner left Paris in March 2020 due to the pandemic and social unrest, and was appointed to the San Carlo six months later. The 2020-21 season was largely cancelled, but Lissner managed to stage a few performances in concert. The upcoming season will open with Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana, and Lissner plans to create a "social and digital theatre" to broaden the San Carlo's appeal. He also discussed the potential impact of the pandemic on the theatre and the need for vaccination policies.

images.alt_text: Maestro Lissner wants to create a "social and digital theatre", broadening the San Carlo's appeal to a potentially limitless audience.
The Teatro di San Carlo was opened in 1737 and is Italy's oldest opera house - and one of its most beautiful.

site_title: Fantastic beasts take over London's Natural History Museum
summary: London's Natural History Museum has opened an exhibition, "Fantastic Beasts. The Wonder of Nature," showcasing strange creatures from the Harry Potter universe, including nifflers, unicorns, and dragons. The exhibit features over 100 real-life specimens, such as deep-sea oarfish and giant narwhal tusks, which highlight the natural world's own "fantastical" abilities. The show aims to pique younger audiences' curiosity and transform the museum's image, with plans for the exhibition to tour to several countries.

site_title: As pandemic lifelines expire, Americans in housing free fall
summary: The US housing market is facing a severe crisis as pandemic lifelines are set to expire, leaving millions of tenants and landlords vulnerable to eviction. With extended unemployment benefits expiring on December 26 and a national ban on renter evictions set to lapse on January 1, up to 40 million people could be threatened with eviction. Landlords, including many small property owners, are also at risk of losing their homes as rental income losses mount, with estimates suggesting an unprecedented $70 billion in unpaid back rent and utilities will come due.

site_title: Boeing loses 23 Max orders as Virgin Australia remakes fleet
summary: Boeing lost 23 Max 8 orders from Virgin Australia under a new agreement, replacing them with 25 Max 10 jets to serve as the airline's "backbone" for domestic and short-haul international flights. The deal also postponed initial delivery by two years to mid-2023. Virgin Australia scrapped the smaller Max 8 models as it shrinks its fleet after bankruptcy earlier this year.

site_title: Temasek hires former Ikea sustainability head as Robin Hu leaves role
summary: Temasek International has appointed Steve Howard, former chief sustainability officer of Ikea, as its new head of sustainability and stewardship group, replacing Robin Hu, who is leaving the role at the end of the year. Howard, who starts on January 1, will oversee Temasek's sustainability efforts as the firm aims to halve its net carbon emissions by 2030 and reach net zero emissions by 2050. Hu will remain in Temasek's senior leadership team in a different position.

site_title: Nanofilm Technologies International to join three FTSE indices
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International, a Singapore-based nanotechnology solutions provider, will be included in the FTSE ST Small Cap Index, FTSE ST China Index, and FTSE ST Singapore Shariah Index after December 21. The inclusion aims to increase the company's awareness and exposure to index funds, as well as bring higher trading liquidity to investors globally. This move is part of the company's efforts to grow and fortify its market position.

site_title: Singapore's 5G success will be a group effort, says S Iswaran
summary: Singapore's 5G success will depend on collaboration among industries, communities, and government, according to Communications and Information Minister S Iswaran. Building demand and developing viable use cases for 5G are crucial, and open interfaces with ecosystem partners are essential for scaling. Industry-wide "ecosystem change" is needed to achieve 5G goals, especially in the enterprise sphere. Singapore is on track to launch standalone 5G networks by end-2022 and end-2025, with Singtel, StarHub, and M1 awarded licenses to build and run nationwide networks.

site_title: Blue Moon raises US$1.27b in Hong Kong's rush of mega IPOs
summary: Blue Moon Group Holdings, a Chinese detergent maker, raised US$1.27 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, priced at HK$13.16 per share, exceeding its initial target. This is part of a record number of companies in Hong Kong raising at least US$1 billion in 2020. The IPO price was at the top of the company's range, as announced when the deal launched last Friday.

site_title: Embattled S-Reits headed for slow recovery next year
summary: Singapore's hospitality, office, and retail sector Reits are expected to recover next year, driven by positive vaccine developments. However, analysts predict a slow recovery, with price volatility expected to persist. OCBC analysts foresee continued volatility, while RHB expects hospitality Reits to recover only in the second half of the year. Despite this, some Reits, such as NTT DC Reit, have seen positive developments, with its Singapore public offer being oversubscribed nine times. Overall, the Reits' recovery is expected to be uneven and gradual.

site_title: Labour market rebound, flexible staffing seen benefiting HRnetGroup
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price on HRnetGroup, a recruitment firm, to 63.5 Singapore cents due to improving labour markets in Singapore and China. The firm's flexible staffing arrangements are seen as a potential revenue cushion against the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The brokerage reiterated its "add" rating, indicating a positive outlook for the company.

site_title: Call for mass testing in South Korea amid rising third wave of virus
summary: South Korea is experiencing a third wave of coronavirus outbreaks, with daily new cases averaging around 600 over the past week. The majority of cases have been reported in the Seoul area, prompting Governor Lee Jae-myung to call for mass testing in densely populated areas to isolate potential spreaders. The government has also signed deals with four global drugmakers to procure Covid-19 vaccines for 44 million people, with vaccinations expected to begin in the first half of next year.

site_title: US: S&P 500 hits record high on vaccine, stimulus bets
summary: The S&P 500 reached a record high on December 9, 2020, driven by hopes for a vaccine-linked economic recovery and fiscal stimulus. The Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the S&P 500 opening 3.73 points higher at 3,705.98, and the Dow Jones at 30,229.81. This was attributed to demand for economically sensitive stocks such as banks and industrials. The gains came despite uncertainty over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Moya Holdings Asia chalks up jump in Q3 net profit
summary: Moya Holdings Asia reported a net profit of S$11.9 million for Q3 2020, nearly tripling from S$4.24 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue increased 15% year-over-year to S$59.65 million, driven by the consolidation of Obor Infrastructure's financial statements. This marks a significant jump from the previous year, indicating a strong performance for the Indonesian water treatment company.

site_title: Emaar faces prisoner's dilemma: Morgan Stanley
summary: Dubai's largest property developer, Emaar Properties PJSC, faces a dilemma in 2021, according to Morgan Stanley. The company can stop new projects to alleviate Dubai's over-supplied property sector, but this would risk losing market share. This decision would also impact the company's financial performance. Alternatively, continuing with new projects could maintain market share but might not address the sector's oversupply issue. Emaar's decision will have significant implications for the company's future growth and the Dubai property market.

site_title: Singapore fintech funding rebounds in Q2 to US$278m
summary: Singapore's fintech investments rebounded to US$278 million in Q2 2020, a 4.1 times increase from the previous quarter. The majority of fintech funding in South-east Asia (65%) went to Singapore businesses, with nearly two-thirds of completed deals in Asean (95) going to Singapore firms. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, investor interest in Singapore-based fintech firms remained strong, with the city-state continuing to attract the highest funding amount in the Asean region.

site_title: Starbucks names Mellody Hobson as chair, a gain for Black directors
summary: Starbucks has named Mellody Hobson as its new chair, making her the first African American woman to chair a Fortune 500 company. Hobson, co-CEO of Ariel Investments, replaces retiring Myron Ullman III and aims to increase representation of Black, Indigenous and People of Colour to 30% by 2025. This move is seen as a gain for Black directors, who are underrepresented in corporate leadership.

site_title: US job openings hit a three-month high
summary: US job openings rose to 6.65 million in October, a three-month high, as employers adjust headcounts amid changing demand and coronavirus dynamics. This is consistent with a gradual improvement in the labor market. The number of quits increased to 3.09 million, while layoffs and discharges rose to 1.68 million. Vacancies improved in health care, construction, and manufacturing, but fell in retail and business services. Competition remains high, with 11.1 million unemployed Americans vying for 6.65 million job openings.

site_title: Moya Holdings Asia's profit after tax surges in Q3
summary: Moya Holdings Asia reported a post-tax profit of S$11.9 million for Q3 2020, nearly three times the profit in the same quarter last year. Revenue increased 15% year-on-year to S$59.65 million, driven by the consolidation of Obor Infrastructure. Despite a pandemic impact on commercial and industrial water sales, household water sales rose due to increased hygiene awareness. The group expects to remain profitable for FY2020, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Top Glove to reduce reliance on foreign workers, hire more locals as dormitory issues surface
summary: Top Glove Corporation plans to reduce its reliance on foreign workers and hire more locals to address dormitory issues. The company aims to recruit 9,000 new employees in FY2021, with 4,500 being locals, up from 3,080 or 62.3% in FY2020. This move comes after a virus outbreak among its factory workers led to the Malaysian government temporarily closing some facilities and investigating the company for violations of workers' housing regulations. Despite this, the company reported strong Q1 FY21 earnings, with net profit and revenue up due to strong global glove demand.

site_title: US airport passenger numbers dip to lowest level since July 4
summary: US airport passenger numbers have dipped to 501,513 on Tuesday, the lowest level since July 4, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Delta Air Lines' CEO Ed Bastian warned that travel during the upcoming holiday season will remain bleak, with traffic expected to hover around one-third of normal levels for the next couple of months.

site_title: STI up 0.6% on triple shot of good news
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.62% to 2,843.07, driven by a triple shot of good news including vaccine cheer, global economic recovery prospects, and US stimulus package progress. The gains also mirrored Wall Street's record highs overnight. Local stocks led by DBS, UOB, OCBC, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) were among the top gainers, with some stocks reaching 52-week highs. The market's broad narrative remains one of long-term recovery, but with short-term risks skewed to the downside due to elevated Covid-19 cases.

site_title: UK issues allergy warning over Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine
summary: British health officials have issued a warning advising individuals with a history of significant allergic reactions to avoid the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for the time being. This decision follows two NHS staff members who experienced allergic reactions after receiving the vaccine on Tuesday, but are now recovering well.

site_title: China bank loans rise more than expected in Nov, credit growth eases
summary: China's banks extended 1.43 trillion yuan in new loans in November, exceeding expectations of 1.40 trillion yuan. This marks a rise from October's 689.80 billion yuan. The increase in credit growth eases concerns about the impact of the global pandemic. The People's Bank of China maintained an accommodative stance, indicating a continued focus on supporting the economy.

site_title: Men with Covid-19 three times more likely to need intensive care: study
summary: Men infected with Covid-19 are three times more likely to require intensive care than women and 39% more likely to die from the virus, according to a study analyzing over 3 million confirmed cases from 46 countries and 44 US states between January and June 2020. The study found that biological differences, such as the immune system's response, contribute to the disparity, with women producing more type I interferon proteins that limit abnormal immune responses. The findings may have implications for future vaccines and highlight the need to consider sex as a variable in research.

site_title: mm2 Asia proposes to merge its Cathay cinema business with Golden Village cinemas
summary: mm2 Asia proposes to merge its Cathay cinema business with Golden Village cinemas in a deal that would make the enlarged business the largest cinema operator in Singapore. The merger is expected to deliver economies of scale and financial stability, as cinema operators face headwinds due to the pandemic. The proposed transaction requires approvals from shareholders, the Singapore Exchange, and other regulatory bodies, with a deadline of Dec 31, 2021, to finalize the terms. If successful, the merger could be completed through a spinoff listing on the SGX Catalist board.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd sees some transport volume recovery in 2020
summary: Hapag-Lloyd expects transport volumes in the fourth quarter to recover from sharp losses in the first three quarters, with a low single-digit gain year-on-year. The company's chief executive, Rolf Habben Jansen, attributed the recovery to a demand increase in Asia. Full-year volumes are expected to lag 2019 levels by between 1.5% and 2%. This is a result of the company's efforts to mitigate losses, with the goal of returning to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: STI gains 0.6% on triple shot of positive news
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.62% on Wednesday, driven by a triple shot of positive news including vaccine cheer, global economic recovery prospects, and US stimulus package progress. The Straits Times Index advanced 17.44 points to 2,843.07. Big gains were logged in the region, except for China, with South Korea's Kospi leading the way. The gains came despite concerns over short-term growth risks due to elevated Covid-19 cases.

site_title: US wholesale inventories revised higher; sales surge
