summary: US wholesale inventories rose 1.1% in October, higher than the initial estimate of 0.9%, and contributed to economic growth in the fourth quarter. This increase, combined with a 1.3% jump in the inventory component of GDP, suggests inventory investment could support growth. The third-quarter GDP rebounded at a 33.1% annualized rate, driven by pandemic relief, and inventories added to growth last quarter after being a drag for five straight quarters.

site_title: Fruits Vending, ImmunoScape and SkyLab Networks bag Emerging Enterprise awards
summary: Three Singaporean enterprises - Fruits Vending, ImmunoScape, and SkyLab Networks - won the Emerging Enterprise Award 2020 for demonstrating innovation, resilience, and growth potential. Weston Robot received the Best Innovation Award, TreeDots Enterprise won the Most Promising Startup Award, and Lam Tak received the Sustainability Award. The winners will receive support from Enterprise Singapore, and Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for collaboration between businesses and the government to drive growth and stay competitive in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Dutch prosecutors to probe UBS CEO over ING money laundering case
summary: Dutch prosecutors have ordered an investigation into UBS CEO Ralph Hamers over his role in overseeing anti-money laundering compliance at ING Group, his former employer. ING paid 775 million euros in a settlement in 2018 after failing to spot money laundering and other crimes. The Dutch court, which had previously allowed ING to settle, has now agreed to probe Hamers, who took over as UBS CEO in November. UBS maintains "full confidence" in Hamers' leadership abilities despite the investigation.

site_title: Deutsche Bank plans more cost cuts to meet 2022 profit target
summary: Deutsche Bank has announced plans to cut more costs to meet its 2022 profit target of 8% return on tangible equity. The bank aims to reduce costs to 16.7 billion euros, down from a previous target of 17 billion. Despite a consensus forecast of 3.3% return on tangible equity, analysts say CEO Christian Sewing is making progress in turning the bank around. Deutsche forecasts revenues of 24.4 billion euros by 2022, with growth expected in its investment bank. The bank's shares have risen 38% so far this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.75% to 26,502.84, driven by optimism over US lawmakers' potential agreement on a stimulus package. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.19% and 1.88% respectively. The positive sentiment in Hong Kong contrasts with a decline in European stocks, which were weighed down by bank and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to shrink 6% in 2020, according to a Monetary Authority of Singapore survey. The unemployment rate is forecast to hit 3.7% by year-end, potentially rising further. Private-sector economists polled by the MAS predict this growth in unemployment, despite the economy's expected contraction.

site_title: Top Glove Q1 profit soars 20 times to RM2.38b on strong global glove demand
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a net profit of RM2.38 billion for the first quarter of fiscal year 2021, a 20-fold increase from the same period last year, driven by strong demand for gloves in developed and emerging markets. Revenue more than tripled to a record RM4.76 billion, and sales volume increased by 34%. The company plans to reward 100,000 public shareholders with quarterly dividend payments, exceeding its previous payment of 11.83 sen. Top Glove attributes its robust sales figures to the Covid-19 pandemic and ongoing technological advancements.

site_title: Singapore to pilot platform next year to speed up insurance claims: MAS
summary: Singapore is set to launch a digital platform next year to speed up insurance claims, reducing processing time and errors. The platform, developed in collaboration with the Ministry of Health and insurance and healthcare sectors, will securely share data with patient consent to help reduce duplicate claims. The Monetary Authority of Singapore aims to reduce manual errors and processing time, improving the overall efficiency of the insurance claims process.

site_title: Nanofilm Tech International announces inclusion in three FTSE indices
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International, a nanotechnology solutions provider, will be included in the FTSE ST Small-Cap Index, FTSE ST China Index, and FTSE ST Singapore Shariah Index after Dec 21. This inclusion aims to increase awareness and exposure to index funds, bringing higher trading liquidity to investors globally. The move is part of the company's efforts to grow and fortify its market position, with its executive chairman stating it will enhance the company's outreach to a high-quality, diversified institutional investor base.

site_title: Tesco's Asia deal paves way for £5b return to shareholders
summary: Tesco is set to complete the $10.6 billion sale of its Asian businesses to CP Group on December 18, paving the way for a £5 billion return to shareholders. The sale, agreed in March, has received necessary approvals from Thailand and Malaysia, with Tesco expected to return £5 billion to shareholders via a special dividend and pension contributions. The company aims to focus on European businesses and make a significant contribution to its pension deficit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 14.83 points higher at 1,646.53 on Wednesday, driven by a 11.880 billion lots worth RM6.682 billion in trading volume. Losers outnumbered gainers 743 to 524.

site_title: Bank of Thailand slows down baht appreciation
summary: Thailand's central bank intervened to slow down the appreciation of the baht currency, which strengthened to 29 baht per US dollar on Wednesday. Thai exporters called for the baht not to exceed 30 baht per US dollar, citing competitiveness concerns. The Bank of Thailand did not comment on the intervention.

site_title: Rely bags up to S$100m Goldbell financing for buy-now-pay-later
summary: Rely, a fintech firm, has secured a S$100 million facility from Goldbell Financial Services to finance buy-now-pay-later transactions. The facility, provided by Polaris, a strategic partnerships arm of Goldbell, will enable Rely to expand its services to new merchants. The partnership also marks Rely's expansion into retail landlord Lendlease's 313@somerset mall. The deal aims to scale Rely's operations and enter partnerships with retailers in Singapore, Malaysia, and South Korea.

site_title: No model for sale here, but India's small investors flock to Tesla stock
summary: Indian investors, including small investors, are increasingly buying Tesla stock, with brokerages reporting a significant increase in holdings. In November, Indian brokerage Vested Finance held $2.5 million worth of Tesla stock, up from $76,000 in March. Another brokerage firm, Stockal, reported a quadrupling of Tesla holdings to $10 million. The surge in interest comes as Tesla CEO Elon Musk signals an impending India launch, despite concerns over high import duties.

site_title: COE prices close higher across the board in latest tender
summary: COE prices in Singapore rose across the board in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finishing at S$40,714, up from S$37,690. The premium for larger vehicles increased to S$45,012, while commercial vehicle COE prices rose to S$32,889. Motorcycle premiums also increased to S$7,670. The increases follow previous rises, with the premium for larger vehicles now at its highest level since 2018.

site_title: German startup Volocopter to launch flying taxis in Singapore within three years
summary: German startup Volocopter plans to launch flying taxi services in Singapore within the next three years, following partnerships with the Economic Development Board of Singapore and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. Volocopter's emission-free aircraft, capable of carrying up to two passengers, will offer touristic routes and potential cross-border flights. The company aims to hire 50 pilots and over 200 employees in Singapore to manage its operations. This move is seen as a significant step towards urban air mobility in Singapore, with the city-state set to become an important test bed for autonomous cars and electric vehicles.

site_title: Lured by bull market, South Koreans take out record loans, piling up debt
summary: South Korea saw a record increase in household borrowing in November, with bank lending rising 13.6 trillion won (S$16.74 billion) from October, driven by a bull market that has seen the benchmark index close at a record high for the fifth consecutive session. Retail investors have taken out record loans to buy stocks, with 18.5 trillion won on loan for share purchases by retail investors. Household debt has reached record levels, with South Korea's debt-to-GDP ratio standing at 100.6%, prompting regulators to introduce fresh curbs on loans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.33% and the Topix index rising 1.17%, driven by fresh Wall Street records fueled by coronavirus vaccine progress.

site_title: Al Futtaim-related entities loaned Robinsons S$159m to fund trading losses
summary: Al Futtaim-related entities loaned Robinsons S$159.2 million to fund trading losses, with S$90.3m and S$68.2m provided by RSH Holdings Pte Ltd and Robinson & Co Pte Ltd, respectively. Robinsons faces S$31.7m in claims from 442 creditors, with liquidators targeting a distribution to creditors by April to June next year. The company has S$25m worth of retail inventory, and its store closures have been attributed to "fundamental business shortcomings" and growing financial pressure.

site_title: German exports inch up, giving economy hope of avoiding Q4 slump
summary: German exports rose 0.8% in October, exceeding expectations, and the trade surplus expanded to 18.2 billion euros. This increase in exports gives Europe's largest economy hope of avoiding a Q4 slump. Despite a slowdown in exports, the country's economy remains resilient, providing a boost at the start of the fourth quarter.

site_title: 5G success needs public-private and cross-border partnerships: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran emphasized the importance of public-private and cross-border partnerships for the success of the country's 5G and digital ambitions. He stressed the need for interoperable systems and cooperation with global partners. Iswaran highlighted the need for collaboration to build up demand and drive growth in the 5G sector.

site_title: SoftBank's shares jump 7% on buyout debate report
summary: SoftBank shares jumped 7% after Bloomberg News reported that the company is considering buying back shares to boost CEO Masayoshi Son's stake. This move aims to limit the premium paid and would require Son to lift his shareholding ratio to two-thirds to squeeze out minority shareholders. The company has raised $80 billion through asset sales, sparking speculation about how Son will deploy the funds. Analysts say a buyout would limit Son's freedom to invest elsewhere, citing his preference for buying over selling.

site_title: Gulf Oil to buy OK Lim's Ocean Tankers assets in Singapore
summary: Gulf Oil International has agreed to acquire the assets of Ocean Tankers (Pte) Ltd in Singapore, including a lubricant blending plant, storage tank farm, and terminal facility. The acquisition is subject to closing conditions and will see the assets continue to operate as a going concern. The deal price was not disclosed.

site_title: Broker's take: Labour market rebound, flexible staffing can benefit HRnetGroup
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for recruitment firm HRnetGroup to 63.5 Singapore cents, citing improving labour markets in Singapore and China, and potential revenue from flexible staffing arrangements. Analysts expect China to be the largest driver of growth for North Asia, with higher margins from permanent placements. They also expect stabilisation in Singapore's labour markets, with a rebound in resident employment levels and a likely bottoming out of unemployment rates by the end of the year.

site_title: LMIRT faces opposition from unitholders on Lippo Mall Puri acquisition
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) is facing opposition from unitholders regarding its acquisition of Lippo Mall Puri. Two weeks before a vote on the deal, 41 unitholders with over 6% of the vote requested a three-month delay to commission a new valuation for the property. This could potentially postpone the acquisition, which has been in the works for over a year.

site_title: UAE says Sinopharm vaccine has 86% efficacy against Covid-19
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) health ministry announced that a Sinopharm coronavirus vaccine has an 86% efficacy against Covid-19, based on an interim analysis of a human trial. The vaccine, developed by Beijing Institute of Biological Product, a unit of Sinopharm's China National Biotec Group, shows a 99% seroconversion rate of neutralising antibody and 100% effectiveness in preventing moderate and severe cases. The analysis also revealed no serious safety concerns, and the vaccine has been officially registered. The trial involved 31,000 volunteers across 125 nationalities.

site_title: Keppel Bay Tower bags Green Mark Platinum (Zero Energy) certification
summary: Keppel Bay Tower in Singapore has been certified as the first commercial property in the country to receive a Green Mark Platinum (Zero Energy) building certification. The building achieved a low energy use index of less than 115 kilowatt hours per square metre per year, thanks to the implementation of various energy-efficient technologies. The certification marks a milestone in Singapore's green-building journey and demonstrates the feasibility of zero-energy, high-rise commercial buildings.

site_title: Royal Caribbean passenger tests negative for Covid-19 after retest and 2nd fresh test
summary: An 83-year-old Royal Caribbean passenger tested positive for Covid-19 on a Quantum of the Seas cruise ship. After retesting and a second fresh test, he tested negative, indicating the initial positive result was false. The passenger had reported diarrhea and was immediately isolated. The incident was reported by the Singapore Ministry of Health.

site_title: Australia: Shares notch seven-day winning streak; NZ closes at record high
summary: Australia's shares extended a seven-day winning streak, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.6% to a record high. Global markets advanced on positive Covid-19 vaccine news, including Britain's start of a vaccination campaign and Johnson & Johnson's expected trial results. Analysts expect an economic recovery, with GDP reaching pre-pandemic levels by the third quarter of 2021. Miner stocks, such as Fortescue Metals, hit new highs, while healthcare stocks, including Healius, gained 2.5%. New Zealand's benchmark index closed at a record high, with Infratil leading gains after rejecting a takeover offer.

site_title: Amazon eyes potential US$100m investment in India's Apollo Pharmacy: ET
summary: Amazon is considering a nearly US$100 million investment in India's Apollo Pharmacy, a move that could further expand the company's presence in the country's fast-growing drug market. This comes amid rising competition from Reliance Industries and Tata Group, which are also vying for a stake in the e-pharmacy sector. The potential investment would give Amazon an edge in the market, but it also raises concerns about the impact on traditional trader groups and the unemployment in the sector.

site_title: Over 200m new mobile banking users forecast in four APAC markets by 2023: report
summary: Mobile banking users in four Asia-Pacific countries (India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam) are forecast to increase by 209 million by 2023, a 75% rise from 2019, reaching 488 million users. India is expected to see the largest growth, with 142 million new users, while the Philippines will add 16 million and Vietnam 14 million. The pandemic is accelerating digitalisation, and by 2023, 52-62% of Internet users in these markets will have adopted mobile banking.

site_title: Blue Moon raises US$1.27b in Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: Blue Moon Group Holdings, a Chinese detergent maker, raised US$1.27 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, pricing its shares at HK$13.16. The company, backed by Hillhouse Capital, sold 747.1 million shares, giving it a market capitalization of up to nearly US$10 billion. The IPO proceeds will be used to build sales and distribution networks and expand production capacity. Cornerstone investors, including Veritas Asset Management, took a US$235 million stake in the deal, accounting for nearly 21% of the IPO.

site_title: Singapore's fintech investments rebounded to US$278m in Q2: report
summary: Singapore's fintech investments rebounded to US$278 million in Q2, a 4.1 times increase from the first quarter, according to a report by the Singapore FinTech Association and Oliver Wyman. This rebound is attributed to strong investor interest in Singapore-based fintech firms, which accounted for 42% of funding in the Asean region. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Singapore's fintech ecosystem remains robust, with over 10,000 employees and a government commitment of over US$200 million to grow the sector.

site_title: How high can you go? Wall Street exuberance makes some uneasy
summary: US stocks reached record highs at the end of 2020, driven by optimism over Covid-19 vaccine breakthroughs, fiscal stimulus, and reduced uncertainty about the presidential election. Investors have shifted funds away from cash reserves and into stocks, with the S&P 500 trading at a high valuation of 22 times forward earnings. However, some experts warn that excessive optimism could make stocks vulnerable to bad news, such as unexpected pandemic setbacks or delayed stimulus.

site_title: Real estate agency asks Trump fans to buy him childhood home
summary: A New York real estate agency is launching a crowdfunding campaign to raise $3 million to buy Donald Trump's childhood home, which was previously sold twice since 2016. The goal is to offer the house as a gift to Trump if the funds are raised. The mock Tudor five-bedroom house, valued at $1 million, has been marketed as having "intangible value" and is being targeted towards Trump fans who may be willing to contribute $3. The campaign has received a single donation of $45 so far, but the agency hopes to capitalize on the fervor surrounding Trump.

site_title: Temasek hires former Ikea sustainability head as Robin Hu leaves role
summary: Temasek International's head of sustainability and stewardship group Robin Hu will leave his role at the end of the year. His key functions will be taken over by Ikea's former chief sustainability officer Steve Howard. Hu will remain part of Temasek's senior leadership team in a different position. He previously held roles at South China Morning Post and Hong Kong. The transition will occur in December 2020.

site_title: China consumer prices drop for first time in over a decade
summary: China's consumer prices dropped 0.5% in November, the first time in over a decade, due to falling food costs, particularly pork prices that fell 12.5% after an African swine fever outbreak. Core CPI, excluding food and energy prices, remained stable at 0.5% year-over-year. Analysts attribute the decline to improved pork supply and not a faltering demand, with broader price pressures starting to pick up due to economic recovery.

images.alt_text: China's consumer prices dropped more than expected in November on falling food costs, with a key gauge turning negative for the first time in 11 years due to pork prices, according to official data released Wednesday.

site_title: Gold dips as equities climb on vaccine cheer; stimulus hopes support
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,865.46 per ounce as investors shifted towards riskier equities due to encouraging vaccine developments. However, hopes for US stimulus kept gold near two-week highs. Analysts expect the stimulus to provide gold with a tailwind, particularly given the unprecedented stimulus pumped into the economy this year, which is seen as a hedge against inflation. Markets are also watching the development of Covid-19 vaccines, with Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer making progress in their trials.

images.alt_text: Gold prices eased on Wednesday as encouraging vaccine developments pushed investors towards riskier equities, although hopes for more US stimulus kept bullion near two-week highs hit in the previous session.

site_title: Hospital staff 'truly exhausted,' says Texas doctor in viral hug photo
summary: Dr. Joseph Varon, chief of staff at a Houston hospital, expressed exhaustion while working on his 260th consecutive day of treating Covid-19 patients. Despite his exhaustion, he continued to work, even after a photo of him hugging a patient went viral, showing empathy towards his patients. Varon criticized the US failure to control the pandemic, citing inadequate lockdowns and mask mandates, which he believes have led to staff burnout and overwhelming patient cases.

site_title: Google, Facebook win key concession in law to pay for news in Australia
summary: Google and Facebook have won a key concession in Australia's world-first law requiring digital giants to pay to display news articles. The legislation, introduced to Parliament, now also recognizes the value platforms provide to news businesses by directing readers to their websites. This modification aims to balance the need for compensation with the benefits of free content. The concessions are a significant step towards resolving the dispute, which began in 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 13.82 points, or 0.85%, to 1,645.62. Volume reached 404.86 million lots worth RM168.26 million. Gainers outpaced losers 285 to 124.

site_title: Singapore unemployment rate expected to hit 3.7% by year-end: survey
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to contract by 6% in 2020, but unemployment could rise to 3.7% by year-end, according to a survey of 23 economists. The manufacturing sector is forecast to grow 5.8%, while construction is expected to contract 36.2%. Finance and insurance are expected to grow 4.6%, and private consumption is predicted to shrink 13.4%. The economy is expected to recover by 2021 with a 5.5% growth. An escalation of the Covid-19 pandemic remains the top downside risk to Singapore's growth.

site_title: Labour group seeks help for hundreds of thousands of seafarers stranded by Covid
summary: Hundreds of thousands of seafarers worldwide are stranded at sea due to coronavirus travel restrictions, unable to get medical care or return home. The International Labour Organization (ILO) is calling on nations to address their plight, adopting a resolution to provide medical care, waive visa requirements, and designate seafarers as key workers. The situation has lasted unacceptably long, with 400,000 seafarers stranded on ships and another 400,000 unable to take over their jobs, resulting in serious financial hardship.

site_title: Nokia manager exodus grows as new CEO starts strategy shift
summary: At least five senior Nokia executives, including co-presidents Basil Alwan and Sri Reddy, and chief technology officer Marcus Weldon, are leaving the company as part of CEO Pekka Lundmark's new strategy shift. The changes aim to reduce complexity, improve cost-efficiency, and drive accountability, starting next year. Lundmark stated the new model is better aligned with customer needs, with a focus on cost-cutting measures. The departures are part of a broader effort to reshape the Finnish network equipment maker.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Wednesday, rebounding from two days of losses, driven by US stimulus package progress and Wall Street records. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.78%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.17% and 0.13%, respectively.

site_title: Fantastic beasts take over London's Natural History Museum
summary: London's Natural History Museum has unveiled "Fantastic Beasts. The Wonder of Nature," an exhibition featuring over 100 specimens of real-life animals inspired by J.K. Rowling's magical creatures. The show, a collaboration with the BBC and Warner Bros, includes nifflers, unicorns, and mermaids, as well as real-life deep-sea oarfish and giant narwhal tusks. The exhibit aims to highlight the "extraordinary abilities" of real animals and transform the museum's image, attracting younger audiences. The show runs from December 9 to August 2023.

site_title: Asia: Markets boosted by fresh hopes for US stimulus
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday as a US$900 billion stimulus proposal boosted hopes for a deal before Christmas, lifting equities. The prospect of a US rescue package and vaccine rollout added to optimism, despite ongoing virus cases and containment measures. However, spiking virus cases continue to cast a shadow over trading floors.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon sees higher expenses, hunts asset management businesses
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon expects the company's 2021 expenses to exceed US$67 billion due to investments. He also expressed interest in acquiring asset management businesses and financial technology companies. Dimon praised Morgan Stanley's recent acquisitions, including the US$7 billion purchase of Eaton Vance Corp. The bank's revenue has seen a 20% increase in the fourth quarter, but Dimon acknowledged that JPMorgan is too large to acquire another deposit-taking institution, citing excess capital and a desire to accelerate growth through acquisitions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infra Trust, SIA, SATS, Geo Energy, Hatten Land
summary: Singapore stocks experienced various developments on Wednesday. Keppel Infra Trust's units closed flat at S$0.55 after entering a conditional agreement to fully acquire a Philippine petroleum products import storage facility. Singapore Airlines' shares rose 0.5% to S$4.40 after the Changi Ready Taskforce announced readiness to transport Covid-19 vaccines. Geo Energy Resources upgraded its corporate family rating to Caa1 from Caa3, with shares rising 0.6% to 17.7 cents. Hatten Land's shares surged 10.2% to 6.5 cents due to unusual trading volume.

site_title: Broker's take: Retail S-Reits can catch locals' outbound spend to offset tourists' absence
summary: DBS Group Research predicts that Singaporeans' travel spend will be diverted to domestic shopping due to COVID-19 restrictions, potentially offsetting the lack of tourist spend. Retail landlords, including S-Reits, can capture this "lost opportunity" and benefit from the shift. Analysts recommend investing in retail S-Reits like CICT, FCT, and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, citing attractive valuations and cyclical upturns in sentiment. The research team expects malls owned by these S-Reits to recover ahead of the rest of the sector and deliver higher-than-industry occupancy rates.

site_title: Australia: Healthcare, tech stocks drive shares to their highest since end-Feb
summary: Australian shares rose to their highest level since February 26, driven by gains in healthcare and technology stocks following positive US vaccine news. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.8% to 6742.5 points, with local healthcare stocks jumping 2.4% and tech stocks hitting a record high. Consumer sentiment also climbed to a 10-year high, amid gradual border reopenings. Energy stocks were the only exception, falling 0.6% due to surging infections and lockdown worries.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.40% to 26,573.51. The positive sentiment was driven by fresh Wall Street records on coronavirus vaccine progress. The broader Topix index also rose 0.17%. The gains followed recent strong performances in other markets, including Singapore, which notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Viacom poised to win suit over Netflix talent poaching
summary: ViacomCBS is poised to win a lawsuit against Netflix, a California state court judge tentatively agreed to issue an injunction against the streaming service, following a case filed in 2018 over the poaching of TV production executive Momita Sengupta. This comes after Netflix lost a similar case to Twentieth Century Fox last year and is currently being sued by Activision Blizzard for allegedly poaching its executives.

site_title: Johnson jets in to Brussels in bid to save Brexit deal
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson traveled to Brussels on Wednesday to discuss a potential post-Brexit trade deal with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen, with the deadline for a deal looming in just three weeks. Talks have stalled over fair competition, with the UK refusing to accept a mechanism to retaliate swiftly if its business regulations change. Officials on both sides express pessimism about a breakthrough, with the UK insisting on full sovereignty and the EU pushing for conditions to access its market.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was Brussels-bound on Wednesday, with Britain's fading hopes for a post-Brexit trade deal hanging on crisis talks with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen.

site_title: China stocks face US$722b overhang as share lock-ups end
summary: More than US$722 billion worth of Chinese stocks will be unlocked for sale in 2021, the largest amount since 2011, equivalent to about 7% of the entire Chinese equity market. This is due to the increasing number of restricted shares held by major shareholders and senior executives, driven by Beijing's market reforms and looser regulations. The release of these shares is expected to pressure the market, but analysts also predict a positive outlook for China's stock market next year, with over one trillion yuan of funds expected to flow into A shares.

site_title: Japan's core machinery orders jump 17.1% in Oct
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 17.1% in October, exceeding economists' forecast of a 2.8% increase, indicating a brighter outlook for the economy. This rise compared to a 2.8% increase from the previous year, suggesting a recovery in capital spending. The data suggests firms are increasing investment despite the Covid-19 crisis, providing a positive sign for the Japanese economy.

site_title: DBS rates Medtecs a 'buy' on expected high margins even after pandemic
summary: DBS Group Research initiated coverage on Medtecs International Corp with a 'buy' call, citing expected high gross margins despite the pandemic. The company is expected to sustain 90% of pre-pandemic average sale price and 60% of sale volumes, driven by self-branded product sales and new customer relationships. This may lead to a surge in 2022 earnings, with analysts predicting a 6.8-time blended P/E ratio and a cash pile of over US$100 million by the end of 2021.

site_title: Airbnb, DoorDash lead 'unicorn parade' ending hot IPO year
summary: Airbnb and DoorDash are set to debut on the stock market, part of a "unicorn parade" of hot startups going public amid a surge in IPOs this year. The two companies, valued in the billions, are expected to capitalize on the market's appetite for young businesses promising fast growth. DoorDash is aiming for an opening share price of $102, valuing the food delivery startup at $38.7 billion, while Airbnb promises a better bet once the travel industry recovers. Analysts weigh in on the market's potential for future growth and the risks of overvaluation.

images.alt_text: Airbnb and DoorDash make their stock market debut this week as part of a "unicorn parade" capping a busy year for hot startups going public.

site_title: Quarter of forecast LNG supply needed by 2040 to meet 2°C global warming limit: Wood Mackenzie
summary: A quarter of forecast new liquefied natural gas (LNG) supply will be needed by 2040 to meet demand under climate measures aiming for a 2°C global warming limit. Wood Mackenzie reports that tougher measures will increase renewable investments, putting gas demand under pressure. Green hydrogen fuel will become a major competitor to gas by 2040, achieving a 10% share of total primary energy demand by 2050. This challenges companies considering new LNG projects, with the Qatar North Field East expansion's FID space shrinking down by 77% by 2040.

site_title: A*Star scientists, engineers recognised for contributions to local SME ecosystem
summary: Seven A*Star researchers and engineers were recognized for their contributions to Singapore's SME ecosystem. The award recipients, who were seconded to SMEs under A*Star's Technology for Enterprise Capability Upgrading (T-Up) programme, helped their host companies co-develop innovative products, upskill workers, and expand internationally. The winners received the T-Up Excellence Award for their exceptional contributions and the T-Up Emerging Talent Award for their potential to meet industry needs. The awards aim to accelerate innovation in SMEs and improve their R&D capabilities.

images.alt_text: Tan See Leng, Minister in Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Trade and Industry and Manpower, delivers the opening speech for SME Day 2020 @ SWITCH.

site_title: Grab-Singtel digital bank is not a licence to print money
summary: Singtel's new digital bank, in partnership with Grab, has raised concerns among investors about its potential for profitability. While the partnership has sparked interest and Singtel's shares have risen, experts warn that the all-digital bank faces significant challenges, including limited success stories and high competition from established banks. The venture aims to target young professionals and micro-businesses, but scaling deposits and achieving profitability may take time, with some analysts predicting it may not impact earnings until 2025.

site_title: Suspected Covid-19 case on Royal Caribbean cruise to nowhere, ship returns to Singapore mid-sail
summary: A Royal Caribbean cruise ship, Quantum of the Seas, has returned to Singapore mid-sail after turning back on its three-day cruise to nowhere due to a suspected Covid-19 case on board. The ship, which had a reduced 50% capacity and mandatory mask-wearing, had announced its departure from Singapore on December 5. The ship's captain made an announcement informing guests to remain in their rooms, and the ship arrived in Singapore by 8am. This incident is part of Royal Caribbean's safe cruising pilot programme announced in October.

site_title: AirTrunk opens its first Singapore data centre
summary: AirTrunk, a hyperscale data centre specialist, has opened its first Singapore data centre, AirTrunk SGP1, in Loyang, close to the Changi North Cable landing station. The 1.5-hectare facility boasts a capacity of 30 MW in its first phase, with a planned capacity of 60 MW. The data centre is designed with sustainability in mind, using 40% less water than the industry average. It will cater to hyperscale customers, including technology companies, and supports Singapore's position as a key global data hub.

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment hits 10-year high
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment reached a 10-year high in December, climbing 4.1% from November, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index. This marks the fourth consecutive month of improvement, as the country relaxed virus restrictions and states opened their borders. The index is now 48% above its April low and has reached its highest level since 2010, indicating a significant increase in optimistic sentiment among consumers.

site_title: Biden taps General Lloyd Austin as first Black Pentagon chief
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden named retired army general Lloyd Austin as the first African-American to lead the Pentagon as Secretary of Defense. General Austin, a decorated veteran with a lifetime of service, has demonstrated exemplary leadership and character, making him uniquely qualified to address the current challenges facing the country. His confirmation will mark a historic milestone for the US military.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Joe Biden named retired army general Lloyd Austin to be secretary of defence on Tuesday, who if confirmed will become the first African-American to lead the Pentagon.

site_title: Boeing hit by more cancelled orders even as MAX nears return
summary: Boeing reported 63 net cancellations for its 737 MAX jet in November, adding to the growing tally following two deadly crashes that grounded the aircraft worldwide in 2019. Despite this, the MAX is set to resume commercial flights this month after US and Brazilian air regulators approved upgrades to flight systems and pilot training. The cancellations mark another setback for Boeing, which is struggling to regain customer trust after the crashes.

site_title: UK firms avoid hiring permanent staff in November lockdown
summary: UK firms reduced permanent staff recruitment in November due to the England-wide lockdown, relying on temporary workers instead. The number of permanent staff recruited fell for the second month in a row, the lowest since July. The job furlough scheme has been extended until March, with forecasters predicting a 7.5% jobless rate after its end. The UK is also facing Brexit uncertainty, with 29% of businesses unsure if they'll be ready for the EU transition deadline.

site_title: French prosecutors seek prison term for Sarkozy in graft trial
summary: French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy is facing a graft trial, with prosecutors seeking a four-year prison term for the 65-year-old rightwinger. Sarkozy is accused of trying to bribe a judge with a plum retirement job in exchange for inside information on an inquiry into his campaign finances. He denies the allegations, stating he "never committed the slightest act of corruption" and vows to clear his name. The trial is one of several legal cases against Sarkozy, who faces a maximum sentence of 10 years and a fine of one million euros.

site_title: Venice under water as complex dam system fails to activate
summary: Venice experienced severe flooding on Tuesday after a newly installed dam system failed to activate, causing water levels to reach 1.37m above sea level. The MOSE system, designed to protect the city during high tide, was supposed to be raised within 30 minutes to create a barrier but failed due to an incorrect forecast. The system has been plagued by cost overruns and delays, with the project costing around 7 billion euros. Venice Mayor Luigi Brugnaro stated that a bigger forecast is necessary to activate the system, and damage to UNESCO World Heritage churches occurred in a 2019 flood.

site_title: Trump signs vaccine decree after questions raised on supply
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order granting Americans priority access to vaccines, amid concerns over sufficient doses for the 100 million target by February and the entire country by June. President-elect Joe Biden warned that Congress must provide funding to meet vaccination targets, which Biden aims to achieve with at least 100 million vaccinations in his first 100 days in office. Trump's order has been questioned for its potential legality, and experts argue it could harm global efforts to distribute vaccines.

site_title: GIC-backed DoorDash doubles valuation to raise US$3.4b in US listing: source
summary: DoorDash, backed by the Government Investment Corporation, has raised US$3.36 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) by selling shares at US$102 apiece. This valuation more than doubles the company's previous valuation of US$16 billion during a private fundraising round in June. The IPO gives DoorDash a fully diluted valuation of around US$38 billion, making it one of the biggest US stock market debuts of 2020.

site_title: Brazilian airline Gol to resume flying Boeing 737 MAX
summary: Brazilian airline Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA will resume flying Boeing 737 MAX planes on commercial routes in its domestic network starting December 9. The airline expects all seven 737 MAX aircraft in its fleet to be cleared to return fully to operation by end-December. This comes after the US Federal Aviation Administration lifted the 20-month flight ban on the 737 MAX last month, following software, system, and training upgrades. Boeing's best-selling jet was grounded after two crashes in 2019, resulting in 346 fatalities.

site_title: Oil steady as Covid-19 cases, lockdowns dampen vaccination news
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday as the US state of California tightened its pandemic lockdown and Covid-19 cases surged globally. Despite optimism over vaccine advancements, investors were cautious due to ebbing fuel demand. Oil prices settled at US$48.84 for Brent crude and US$45.60 for US West Texas Intermediate, with the Opec+ group expected to meet on January 4 to discuss oil output. US crude oil production is expected to fall 910,000 bpd in 2020, according to the US Energy Information Administration.

site_title: People understand statistics better than politicians think
summary: A study reveals that the British public has misperceptions about economic concepts, such as the unemployment rate, and is skeptical about data. Despite being "deeply interested" in economics, many people question the accuracy of statistics, citing issues like the definition of unemployment and the classification of those who are economically inactive. The public's perception of a "job" as something that can support living is also a concern. The study highlights the need for economists to explain statistical definitions clearly and accurately, and for politicians to avoid cherry-picking statistics to persuade the public.

site_title: Singapore makes leap in cross-border payment arrangement with Thailand
summary: Singapore has established a cross-border payment arrangement with Thailand, enabling instant and secure money transfers between the two countries using mobile phone numbers. The linkage, which began with a few banks, aims to promote real-time services and reduce costs. Industry experts see this as a significant step towards regional integration and the development of an open network for instant and transparent payments. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to improve cross-border payments and settlements, with plans to partner other central banks in the region.

site_title: White House proposes new US$916b stimulus plan: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin unveiled a $916 billion pandemic aid proposal to Congress, aiming to break a deadlock over additional aid to the US economy. The proposal includes funds for state and local governments and liability protections for businesses, schools, and universities. Mnuchin presented the plan to Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and reviewed it with outgoing President Donald Trump. The proposal is slightly larger than a $908 billion measure proposed by a bipartisan group of senators last week.

site_title: New report makes business case for natural climate solutions
summary: A new report by Conservation International, DBS Bank, National University of Singapore, and Temasek highlights the business case for natural climate solutions (NCS) in Southeast Asia, where carbon prospecting for NCS investments is at its highest density. The report estimates that protecting these ecosystems could generate up to $27.5 billion in annual returns. Despite significant progress in implementing NCS in the region, only 3% of global climate finance goes towards NCS, with the potential for NCS to mitigate 11 gigatons of carbon dioxide annually by 2030.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher with eyes on Brexit trade deal talks
summary: European shares ended a volatile session with modest gains on Tuesday, closing 0.2% higher after a Brexit trade deal was clinched with the EU. The deal removes a major point of contention between Britain and the EU, with investors waiting for concrete signals on a wider trade deal. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index hovered near 9-month highs, with the UK's FTSE 100 flat. Meanwhile, Germany's Health Minister Jens Spahn hinted at tightening restrictions to control the spread of COVID-19.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at new records, extending rally
summary: US stocks closed at new records, extending their rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq finishing at all-time highs. The S&P 500 rose 0.3% to 3,702.25, while the Nasdaq Composite Index increased 0.5% to 12,582.77. Sentiment was boosted by positive COVID-19 vaccine announcements and anticipation of stock offerings by Airbnb and DoorDash. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also advanced 0.4% to close at 30,173.88.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust and Philippine partner to buy storage facility owner
summary: Keppel Infra Trust and its Philippine partner Metro Pacific Investments Corporation have agreed to fully acquire Philippine Tank Storage International (PTSI), owner of the largest petroleum products import storage facility in the Philippines. The acquisition is conditional and aims to expand KIT's presence in the Philippines' energy storage market. The deal is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the growing demand for energy storage solutions in the region. Financial terms of the deal have not been disclosed.

site_title: Pentagon pick shows Biden tapping Washington's 'revolving door' for aides
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has tapped WestExec Advisors, a high-powered firm with close ties to the defense industry, for at least seven key positions in his administration, raising concerns about the "revolving door" of influence peddlers. Notable hires include Antony Blinken as secretary of state, Avril Haines as director of national intelligence, and Lloyd Austin as defense secretary. Critics warn that the lack of transparency and potential conflicts of interest among these appointees could undermine the administration's efforts to address similar issues under the Trump administration.

site_title: A year on, markets are bustling in Wuhan, where Covid-19 emerged
summary: Markets in Wuhan, where Covid-19 emerged in December 2020, have largely returned to normal a year later. Despite the global pandemic, life in the Chinese city has resumed with hundreds of shoppers visiting wet markets to buy fresh produce. The city's economy appears to have recovered, with no significant signs of disruption. Wuhan's recovery serves as a positive example of China's ability to contain and recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Mountbatten Road residential site for sale with S$13m guide price
summary: A residential site at 801 Mountbatten Road in Singapore is up for sale by expression of interest (EOI) with a guide price of S$13 million. The freehold site, measuring 10,839 square feet, offers flexibility for landed housing types and is located near the upcoming Tanjong Katong MRT station and several educational institutions. The EOI exercise closes on January 12, 2021, and is seen as an opportunity for both end-users and developers to acquire a sizeable landed plot in an affluent district.

site_title: France's next-generation aircraft carrier will be nuclear-powered: Macron
summary: France plans to build a next-generation, nuclear-powered aircraft carrier to replace the Charles de Gaulle by 2038. The 300m-long vessel will have a deadweight of 75,000 tons and can carry up to 30 fighter jets. Construction costs are expected to be around 1 billion euros during the first phase, with a possible total cost of over 5 billion euros. The move aims to maintain France's status as a great power, leveraging its nuclear industry, which is the only continental European nuclear power.

site_title: RHB upgrades Singapore consumer stocks to 'overweight'
summary: RHB has upgraded Singapore's consumer sector to 'overweight', citing domestic recovery and staple-food plays as key drivers. The research team favors ThaiBev, a beer and liquor giant, as its top pick for the sector in 2021, following a post-Covid-19 consumption trend. This upgrade reflects RHB's confidence in the sector's resilience and potential for growth.

site_title: Japan approves 73.6t-yen stimulus package
summary: Japan's government approved a 73.6 trillion yen (US$708 billion) stimulus package to fund projects from anti-coronavirus measures to green tech, its third such package this year. The package includes loan schemes and actual government spending of around 40 trillion yen, aiming to protect people's livelihoods and maintain employment. The move comes as Japan faces a spike in Covid-19 infections, and the country officially exited recession last month after three quarters of contraction. The package also features a US$20 billion green tech fund and financial support for medical institutions and the elderly.

site_title: Blackstone, Brookfield seek yield with bet on India office Reits
summary: Blackstone and Brookfield Asset Management are investing heavily in India's office space, aiming to create real estate investment trusts (Reits). Brookfield agreed to pay $2 billion for 12.5 million square feet of rent-yielding offices, while Blackstone purchased $1.2 billion of commercial properties. This investment is expected to provide attractive yields and sustain demand in the coming decades, as India's economy ranks third in Asia. The move follows a trend of global investors seeking yield in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Group bought US$1.2 billion of malls and other commercial properties from a local developer, set to further expand its 9.6 million sq ft of fully-owned real estate assets in India.

site_title: Singapore, China lay groundwork towards post-Covid world with new agreements
summary: Singapore and China are laying groundwork for a post-Covid world through new agreements, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said after the 16th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation. The two countries are working together on public health and deepening connectivity. This move comes as strategies are being drawn up for a more prosperous future together. The groundwork is seen as a significant step in their evolving relationship, which has been built over the past 35 years despite not having diplomatic ties until 1985.

site_title: New Bayer chairman faces sour investors in his first major roadshow
summary: Bayer chairman Norbert Winkeljohann is facing criticism from investors during his first major roadshow, following the company's struggles with the Monsanto acquisition. Several of Bayer's largest shareholders questioned the timing of the three-year contract extension granted to CEO Werner Baumann, citing the ongoing fallout from the acquisition. The feedback is a challenge for Winkeljohann, who took the job in April. The investors' concerns highlight the difficulties Bayer is facing, and it remains to be seen how the company will address these issues.

site_title: Moody's upgrades Geo Energy on absence of near-term refinancing risk
summary: Moody's upgraded Geo Energy's corporate family rating to "Caa1" from "Caa3" due to the elimination of near-term refinancing risk. The credit rating agency also upgraded the senior unsecured guaranteed notes issued by Geo Coal International to "Caa1". The upgrades reflect the company's ability to meet minimum reserve requirements and secure mine licence extensions, giving it time to increase cash generation before the notes mature in October 2022. Despite a significant reduction in leverage, Geo Energy's credit profile remains constrained by its small scale and limited financial flexibility.

site_title: UK will suspend tariffs on US goods in bid to ease aircraft trade row
summary: The UK will suspend tariffs on US$4 billion of US goods, effective January 1, as part of a bid to ease a dispute over aircraft subsidies. The move, announced by UK Trade Minister Liz Truss, aims to de-escalate a damaging international trade conflict and deepen the UK's trading relationship with the US. The decision marks the UK's divergence from EU trade policy and comes as the US exits the "America First" presidency. Separate tariffs on steel and aluminium will remain in place.

images.alt_text: Britain will suspend retaliatory tariffs imposed on US goods as part of a dispute over aircraft subsidies from Jan 1, the trade department said, describing the move as an attempt to de-escalate a damaging international trade conflict.

site_title: Reliability record makes Singapore ideal vaccine distribution hub
summary: Singapore's reliability record and excellent logistics infrastructure make it an ideal location for vaccine distribution, particularly for Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. The country's reputation as a trustworthy and honest broker will also aid in its role as a hub. Singapore Airlines and Sats have obtained internationally-recognised accreditations for handling and transporting healthcare products. The government's approach in the pandemic, avoiding drastic measures, will also help in maintaining trust and cooperation with the global community.

site_title: Iran Nuclear Deal: A no-win for Biden
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden plans to rejoin the Iran Nuclear Deal, but opposition from Middle East allies, including Israel and Saudi Arabia, makes this task challenging. Critics argue that the deal froze Iran's nuclear program, while proponents claim it addressed American concerns. Iran's pragmatic leaders want to revive the deal and lift international sanctions, but the country's more radical forces oppose it. The US faces opposition from Republicans, some Democrats, and international partners, making a successful re-entry into the deal uncertain.

site_title: Manhattan luxury-home buyers are back, lured by deep discounts
summary: Manhattan luxury-home buyers are resuming their activity despite the pandemic, with 227 contracts signed in the past three months for homes priced at $4 million or more, compared to 219 in the same period last year. Deep discounts on luxury properties, rising stock portfolios, and low mortgage rates are driving the surge, with many buyers being New Yorkers who believe in the city's eventual recovery. Several high-profile deals were reported, including a 58th-floor condo at One57 selling for 35% less than its original price.

site_title: Three bars and pubs to reopen for two months under nightlife pilot
summary: Singapore's government has allowed three bars and pubs to reopen for two months under a trial pilot to restart the nightlife industry safely. Bell Bar, Bar Kiharu, and Skinny's Lounge were selected from six nominations, with enforcement agencies monitoring compliance with safe-management measures. The establishments must close by 10:30pm, and owners expressed concerns about reduced operating hours and potential lack of crowds. The pilot aims to assess the feasibility of scaling up nightlife operations, with karaoke outlets and nightclubs expected to start in January.

site_title: Value has room to surprise further
summary: The article discusses the expected rebound of global economies and markets in 2021, driven by a supportive mix of fiscal and monetary expansion, a weakening US dollar, and a broad-based weakening of the dollar. This is expected to lead to a reflationary environment, favoring cyclical and value-oriented assets. Key investment ideas include emerging markets equities, developed markets like Japan, Singapore, and Europe, and small cap equities, particularly Asian small caps. These investments are expected to outperform growth-oriented assets in the coming quarters.

site_title: Euro rises on upbeat economic sentiment
summary: The euro rose against the US dollar on upbeat economic sentiment from Germany, where investor confidence soared in December, exceeding expectations. The eurozone's third-quarter GDP was revised, but the euro still traded 0.04% higher to $1.2112. In contrast, the pound sank 0.4% against the US dollar and euro due to uncertainty over Brexit trade deal negotiations. Implied volatility on the pound hit eight-month highs, signaling traders' preparation for potential market swings.

site_title: Felda to take full control of crude palm oil plantation giant FGV
summary: Malaysia's state-owned Federal Land Development Authority (Felda) has agreed to acquire a 13.88% stake in palm giant FGV Holdings from two state-linked agencies for RM658 million, paving the way for Felda to take full control of the world's largest crude palm oil producer. The deal will allow Felda to gain statutory control over FGV, enabling it to control plantations, downstream operations, and subsidiaries. The acquisition is expected to contribute positively to Felda's future earnings and strengthen its control over FGV's operations.

site_title: Safety@Sea event highlights initiatives to facilitate crew changes
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore hosted its annual International Safety@Sea event online due to the pandemic. The event, centered around "Maritime Safety: New Normal, New Paradigms," featured over 600 participants from 60 countries, discussing safety at sea issues and best practices. Key speakers included IMO officials and industry leaders, emphasizing the importance of cooperation and innovation in addressing maritime safety challenges. The event highlighted initiatives to facilitate crew changes, with Singapore facilitating over 60,000 crew changes. The industry looks forward to mass vaccination efforts, which may ease restrictions on seafarers and improve global shipping operations.

site_title: Covid-19 slams retirement adequacy, especially in hard-hit sectors
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted retirement adequacy worldwide, particularly in hard-hit sectors. A Mercer CFA Institute study found that lower contributions to retirement schemes, lower investment returns, less government support, and earlier access to retirement benefits will reduce worldwide retirement benefits. Job losses, especially in tourism and gig sectors, have reduced workers' contributions to pensions. In Singapore, the government has implemented measures to cushion the blow, but subsidies cannot last forever, and job losses are expected in 2021. The study's findings highlight the need for individuals to reskill and pivot to growth areas to secure their livelihoods.

site_title: Republicans can't handle the truth
summary: US President Donald Trump's attempts to overturn the 2020 election results have been met with widespread support from his Republican party, despite a lack of evidence of significant fraud. A survey found that only 27 Republican members of Congress are willing to acknowledge Joe Biden's win, while two-thirds of self-identified Republicans believe the election was rigged. This willingness to accept false information is not new, as Republicans have a history of rejecting facts that contradict their policy preconceptions, including climate change denial and conspiracy theories. The party's refusal to accept reality has led to a culture of post-truth politics, where facts are secondary to ideology.

site_title: Vaccine logistics can give air cargo sector a much-needed shot in the arm
summary: Singapore's air cargo sector is poised to play a crucial role in transporting Covid-19 vaccines, with Changi Airport seeing a tripling of weekly cargo flights. While the revenue boost from vaccine transportation may not be substantial, it could help pave the way for a gradual recovery in passenger air travel and demonstrate the air cargo community's readiness for the future. The industry's transformation and digitalization could also be accelerated, with companies investing in software systems for real-time monitoring of temperature and location.

site_title: Christmas trees: an elusive bit of happiness for Canadians
summary: In Canada, Christmas trees have become a symbol of hope amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, with sales surging 25% nationwide. Many Christmas tree farms and lots were sold out weeks before the traditional start of the season, with some growers reporting record-breaking demand. The trend is attributed to Canadians seeking festive energy during lockdowns and cancelled holiday events, with the Christmas tree market experiencing significant growth over the past five years.

images.alt_text: Customers lining up to carry out their freshly cut trees at Drysdale's Christmas tree farm, where one can cut down their own evergreen, near Barrie, in Ontario.
There's been a run on Christmas trees as Canadians, trapped inside because of the pandemic, try, in record numbers, to bring some joy into their lives.

site_title: Alcohol distributors see more B2C business as wholesale orders dip
summary: Alcohol distributors in Singapore are experiencing revenue growth despite the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by a surge in online orders for booze. However, the industry is still recovering from the closure of nightlife establishments and restrictions on group sizes. Bigger distributors, such as CornerStone Wines, are bearing the brunt of the impact, while smaller, niche players like Distilled and The Drinking Partners are seeing more success with e-commerce and building strong ties with consumers. To accelerate recovery, industry players are pushing for extended alcohol servicing hours and increased capacities at on-premise establishments.

site_title: A vaccine's journey
summary: A COVID-19 vaccine's journey is being closely monitored, with logistics and hospital operations playing a crucial role in its distribution. Key developments include Tesla's expansion into India and its robotaxi plans in California and Arizona, as well as FedEx partnering with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Delta Air Lines has lifted its travel demand outlook, boosting shares.

site_title: STI closes flat on directionless trading amid cautious mood
summary: Singapore shares closed flat at 2,825.63, as traders played the waiting game amid rising Covid-19 cases and geopolitical uncertainty. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.12 points higher in directionless trading. Major regional markets, except Malaysia, Taiwan, and Australia, finished lower due to stalled US stimulus package negotiations and market sentiment dampened by news.

site_title: Singapore is most expensive city in South-east Asia for fitting out offices
summary: Singapore recorded the highest average fit-out cost for offices across South-east Asia at US$112 per square foot (psf) in 2020-2021, according to Cushman & Wakefield. This is down from US$115 psf a year ago, with mechanical and engineering works making up the largest proportion of costs. Singapore ranked 15th most expensive city in the Asia-Pacific region, with Manila being the next most expensive at US$87 psf, followed by Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur. Despite challenges caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, Singapore's office fit-out costs may become more attractive as a regional hub.

site_title: SIX and SBI planning digital-asset exchange based in Singapore
summary: SIX Digital Exchange (SDX) and SBI Digital Asset Holdings plan to launch a digital-asset exchange in Singapore by 2022, subject to regulatory approval. The joint venture aims to provide active offerings, including equity, debt, and crypto assets, to market participants across South-east Asia and globally. The exchange will be fully regulated by existing Singapore law, with plans to connect to Swiss and Japanese businesses and establish partnerships. The goal is to establish global liquidity in the digital asset market.

site_title: 'Not clear' if US will join RCEP; Commerce Secretary Ross says he is sceptical
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressed skepticism about the US joining the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), citing concerns over the agreement's terms and conditions. He also stated that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would have increased the US trade deficit and was never going to happen. Ross acknowledged RCEP's significance but left the US' participation open-ended. US President-elect Joe Biden also declined to comment on RCEP, but pledged to release his trade agenda details after his inauguration.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hatten Land, a CATALIST-listed property developer, reported unusual volume movements in its shares on Tuesday, resulting in a 10.2% price increase. The company stated it was unaware of any material information not previously announced that could explain the trading. Meanwhile, City Developments (CDL) received an A score from CDP for its sustainability and water security efforts, marking the third consecutive year for climate change strategy and the second year for water security.

site_title: Why tech unicorns should get smaller individual investors on board
summary: Tech unicorns face barriers to investing due to manual and costly processes for issuing equity. High minimum investment thresholds, typically $1 million or more, exclude individual investors and accredited investors. However, new digitized securities platforms using blockchain technology and smart contracts can automate the process, reducing costs and increasing access to unicorns for smaller investors. This can lead to a more competitive market, driving up the value of equity and benefiting existing investors. Digitized securities can also allow unicorns to stay private longer, shielding them from short-term market pressures.

site_title: US: Wall St dips at open on rising virus cases; eyes on stimulus deal
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as rising coronavirus cases threatened to hinder an economic revival. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 opened lower, with the Nasdaq Composite also down. Investors await progress in ongoing US Covid-19 relief package negotiations.

site_title: 2020: The year of the great reset
summary: The year 2020 marked a transformative decade, with the COVID-19 pandemic triggering a global economic reset. Despite regrettable events, the year's developments, including positive vaccine breakthroughs and easing uncertainty, set the stage for economic recovery in 2021. The global economy is expected to experience a reflationary force, with central banks maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy and fiscal support. However, significant resets in three key areas - economic, geo-political, and environmental - will require recalibration by governments and investors. China's rapid rebound and the rise of Asia are key drivers of the global economic recovery, while the climate crisis and ESG considerations will prompt interest in sustainable investing.

site_title: Certis partners BT BAF for its annual Community Give-Back
summary: Certis, a Singapore-based security services provider, partnered The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) for its annual Community Give-Back program. The six-month event kicked off with a workshop at Morning Star Community Services, where Certis staff and BT BAF youth befriended children and taught art and digital technology skills. Certis donated S$20,000 to BT BAF as a presenting sponsor. The program aims to inculcate the spirit of giving back to the next generation and support children and youth with meaningful activities.

site_title: Covid-19, though terrible, helped push digital financial revolution: Bill Gates
summary: Bill Gates stated that the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the digital financial revolution, prompting governments to address financial inequities. He aims to enable two-thirds of the world to gain financial access within the next 10 years through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Gates emphasized the importance of central banks and financial institutions in facilitating digital financial inclusion, noting that cash can be less reliable. He also highlighted the need for equitable distribution of COVID-19 vaccines and urged governments to prepare for the next pandemic, warning that complacency will not be tolerated.

site_title: US Q3 productivity revised to 4.6% rate
summary: US worker productivity increased at a 4.6% annualized rate in the third quarter, according to the Labor Department. This growth was likely overstated due to the sharp rebound in output from the Covid-19 pandemic recession, which outpaced employment gains. The economy expanded at a historic 33.1% annualized rate, while the labor market has only recouped about 56% of lost jobs, resulting in a wide gap between output and employment.

site_title: Mercedes sells French car plant to billionaire Ratcliffe's Ineos
summary: Jim Ratcliffe's Ineos agreed to buy a French car plant from Daimler, the manufacturer of Mercedes-Benz, to improve efficiency and produce its debut SUV, the Grenadier. The Hambach plant will continue producing an electric minicar for Smart, while Ineos plans to build Grenadiers there by late next year. The deal will secure about 1,300 jobs and is part of Daimler's efforts to optimize its global production network after the COVID-19 pandemic. The sale won't significantly impact Daimler's fourth-quarter earnings.

site_title: Hosting WEF a major coup for Singapore and crucial to healing MICE sector
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has chosen Singapore as the host for its Special Annual Meeting 2021, a significant coup for the city-state. This move is seen as a major stepping stone to heal the country's meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions (MICE) sector, which has been disproportionately impacted by the pandemic. Hosting WEF will enhance Singapore's reputation as a great MICE destination and is expected to contribute to the sector's full recovery.

site_title: Singapore arm of London club behind dinner at steakhouse that breached Covid-19 rules
summary: The Singapore arm of London-based Soho House, a private members' club, has been identified as the organizer behind a Halloween-themed dinner at Gemma Steakhouse that breached Covid-19 rules. The dinner, priced at S$140 per head, was marketed to Soho House members and their guests, with 17 reservations made for groups of 4-5. Closed-circuit TV footage showed diners mingling without masks, despite reminders to take their seats. Soho House has cooperated with the Singapore Food Agency in its investigation, while Gemma Steakhouse was ordered shut for 20 days for violating safe-distancing measures.

site_title: Four tech trends that will define the year of recovery in 2021
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a global economic downturn, with the Asia-Pacific economy contracting by 2.2% in 2020. However, the International Monetary Fund projects a 6.9% GDP growth for the region in 2021. To aid in the recovery, four key technology trends will shape the road to recovery, including innovation, AI, cybersecurity, and digital transformation. These technologies will help businesses and nations navigate new challenges brought by the pandemic and shape society in 2021.

site_title: Apple launches US$550 over-ear headphones into crowded market
summary: Apple has launched its US$550 over-ear headphones, entering the competitive market with features like wireless pairing, noise cancellation, and superior audio quality. The headphones will work with Siri digital assistant and have physical side controls. They come in several colors and have a 20-hour battery life. The launch marks Apple's expansion into accessories, with the company generating US$31 billion in sales from accessories in its last fiscal year. The headphones are part of a broader audio product strategy that includes the HomePod speaker and Beats headphones.

site_title: MAS awards qualifying full bank licence to China Construction Bank
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has awarded a qualifying full bank (QFB) licence to China Construction Bank under the China-Singapore Free Trade Agreement Upgrade Protocol. This allows the bank to offer a full suite of banking products and establish a commodity trade financing centre, investment banking transaction centre, and fintech innovation centre in Singapore. The licence follows China Securities Regulatory Commission's approval for the establishment of DBS Securities (China) in August. Singapore and China also discussed initiatives to enhance financial cooperation, including digital finance, green finance, and yuan cooperation.

site_title: Antler, EF and 500 Startups join ESG's Startup SG Founder programme
summary: Startups Antler, Entrepreneur First (EF), and 500 Startups have joined the Startup SG Founder programme, a mentorship and early capital initiative by Enterprise Singapore. The programme aims to support first-time entrepreneurs with innovative business ideas. With additional funding of S$150 million, the programme will provide better support to startups, particularly those led by women and underrepresented groups. The new partners will help identify eligible startups and provide guidance to help them scale from Singapore and seize opportunities in the region and beyond.

site_title: Tata, Mistry spar over a US$13b valuation difference
summary: The Tata Group and billionaire Pallonji Mistry's conglomerate Shapoorji Pallonji Group are locked in a dispute over a $13 billion valuation difference of Mistry's 18.4% stake in Tata Sons, worth $14.5 billion. Mistry's group had made a $24 billion offer to swap its stake for shares in listed Tata firms, but Tata's valuation threatens to prolong the battle. The disagreement is the latest chapter in a four-year-old feud that began with a boardroom coup in 2016, leading to the ouster of Cyrus Mistry as Tata Group chairman.

site_title: Apple could block apps that don't comply with new privacy feature
summary: Apple threatens to remove apps from its App Store if they don't comply with an upcoming feature allowing users to block advertisers from tracking them across different applications. The App Tracking Transparency feature, set to debut early next year, requires explicit user permission to track users across apps and websites. Apple's senior vice president, Craig Federighi, said developers who fail to comply will have their apps taken down, and the industry will adapt to provide effective advertising without invasive tracking. Critics, including Facebook, argue the change could disproportionately harm smaller developers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.81 points to 1,631.70 on Tuesday, closing higher. The market saw 11.255 billion lots traded worth RM6.392 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 652 to 594.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to acquire 80% of Philippine storage facility owner
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has entered a conditional agreement to acquire 80% of Philippine storage facility owner Philippine Tank Storage International (Holdings) Inc (PTSI). The acquisition, valued at US$267 million, will give KIT control over the largest petroleum products import storage facility in the Philippines, capturing demand from key regions. The deal is expected to diversify and grow KIT's portfolio, while strengthening its distributable cash flow, according to its CEO.

site_title: Moody's upgrades Geo Energy after near-term refinancing risk removed
summary: Moody's upgraded Geo Energy's corporate family rating to Caa1 and senior unsecured guaranteed notes to Caa1, citing the elimination of near-term refinancing risk after the company met conditions to prevent a put option from being triggered in April 2021. The upgrades reflect the removal of refinancing risk and give Geo Energy time to increase cash generation before notes mature in October 2022. The stable outlook notes the company's limited financial flexibility and small scale, which constrains its credit profile.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) plans to link its PayNow system with Thailand's PromptPay, a first-of-its-kind global payment system. The air cargo community is ready to ship ultra-cold Covid-19 vaccines. Singapore will maintain trade links and strengthen connectivity. The city-state recorded the highest average office fit-out cost in South-east Asia. Carsome, a used car platform, raised US$30 million in funding. The Straits Times Index closed flat, awaiting updates on rising Covid-19 cases and geopolitics.

site_title: CCCS seeks public views on SIA, Vistara's proposed commercial cooperation
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is seeking public feedback on a proposed commercial cooperation framework agreement between Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Vistara, a joint venture between Tata Sons and SIA. The agreement, which extends an existing codeshare partnership, aims to improve scheduling, pricing, sales, and marketing. CCCS is assessing whether the cooperation would infringe Singapore's Competition Act, but both airlines claim it will result in significant consumer and economic benefits, including increased capacity and improved connectivity. The public can provide feedback until December 21, 2020.

site_title: Spectre of forever-empty offices and malls haunts commercial mortgage backed securities
summary: The commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) market, valued at over $550 billion, may face losses even after COVID-19 vaccines become widespread, as key parts of the real estate market may not return to full strength. Analysts warn that demand for office space, hotels, and stores may drop permanently due to the pandemic, leading to losses in bonds rated BBB and AA. Experts predict losses could average 5-8% for CMBS, with some notes rated BBB potentially losing up to 64% of their face value.

site_title: Look back in seven years, and look forward to a brighter 2021
summary: A business consultant reflects on their seven-year journey from a stable job to starting their own fund. Key takeaways include not being too trusting and seeking legal advice before signing agreements, and providing the best services at a fair price to customers. Despite harsh market conditions, including the COVID-19 pandemic and trade wars, sound investing means proper risk management, patience, and conviction. The consultant advises aspiring entrepreneurs to adopt a similar approach, focusing on values and personal touch.

images.alt_text: While events and news cycles change, one thing that doesn't change is the fundamentals of sound investing. Sound investing means having a proper risk management, not over-paying for an asset, and making sure you get value for what you pay for.

site_title: GE pours US$4b into balance sheet as cash flow rebounds
summary: General Electric (GE) has poured $4 billion into its balance sheet, including prefunding $2.5 billion in pension requirements and repaying $1.5 billion of an intracompany loan. This move aims to reduce debt and strengthen the company's financial footing.
