summary: JD Health International, the online healthcare platform and pharmacy of Chinese e-commerce company JD.com, surged 28% in Hong Kong's grey market trading, marking the city's biggest IPO of the year. The company raised HK$27 billion after pricing its sale of 381.9 million shares at HK$70.58 each. The IPO's success comes after Ant Group's failed US$35 billion share sale in Shanghai and Hong Kong, and is seen as a sign of strong investor appetite for listings in the city.

site_title: SocGen's retail shift seeks to save over 450m euros
summary: SocGen aims to cut costs by 450 million euros by combining its French retail operations with Credit du Nord, reducing branches to 600-1,500 by 2025. The integration will cost 800 million euros, with no staff dismissals expected. The move follows a difficult year for the bank, which recently cut 640 jobs. SocGen targets 4.5 million customers for its online banking unit Boursorama by 2025, with a cumulative loss of 230 million euros to acquire new clients. The bank's stock has fallen 41% this year.

site_title: S Korea to boost testing amid threat of 'medical collapse'
summary: South Korea is boosting testing amid a surge of 615 new Covid-19 cases, the largest daily tally since February, with 8,311 patients in quarantine. President Moon Jae-in ordered expanded testing and tracing, deploying the military and public service personnel, and easing hospital rules to free up beds. Authorities predict daily cases will reach 550-750 this week and 900 next, warning of a "medical collapse" if numbers aren't contained.

site_title: Millions in UK to start receiving Covid-19 vaccine on 'V-Day'
summary: The UK begins its nationwide Covid-19 vaccination rollout on Tuesday, with millions set to receive the Pfizer/Biontech vaccine. The vaccine, with a 95% efficacy rate, will be administered at 50 hospital hubs across England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The government is urging people to take the vaccine, despite a recent poll showing 67% would accept it, with 23% saying they would not. Experts warn that social distancing is still necessary, especially for vulnerable populations, and that other vaccines, such as the Oxford/AstraZeneca and Moderna vaccines, are still awaiting approval.

site_title: Bank of Japan becomes Japan's biggest stock owner with 45.1 trillion yen hoard
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has surpassed the Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) as Japan's largest stock owner, with a portfolio valued at 45.1 trillion yen ($579 billion). The BOJ's massive ETF purchases and valuation gains led to this milestone.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore-based building maintenance firm, has secured contracts totaling S$21.38 million, bringing its total financial year projects to S$42.26 million. The contracts include a S$10.5 million interior-rejuvenation project for an integrated resort and four repair-and-redecoration projects worth about S$8.65 million. These projects are expected to be completed by October 2022.

site_title: RHB raises its target price for ComfortDelGro, citing easing competition
summary: RHB has raised its target price for ComfortDelGro to S$1.90, citing easing competition in the taxi business following the closure of HDT Singapore and a potential Grab-Gojek merger. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal notes that the merger should reduce competitive intensity, allowing ComfortDelGro to improve its earnings. RHB has also raised its 2021-2022 earnings estimates by 3-4% due to a higher utilisation rate for ComfortDelGro's taxi fleet.

site_title: Public health cooperation a new item on agenda for key Singapore-China meeting
summary: Singapore and China will discuss pandemic preparedness and vaccine collaboration at a virtual meeting on Tuesday as part of the 16th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC) meeting. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and Chinese Vice-Premier Han Zheng will co-chair the meeting. The countries aim to strengthen connectivity and cooperation to support the recovery from the pandemic and contribute to a more networked future. Singapore and China also plan to deepen their financial connectivity, promote the flow of goods, and work together on sustainable development, digitalization, and air connectivity.

site_title: Trust in technology has to be earned, not claimed, says Microsoft chief
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella emphasized the need for tech companies to "earn trust, not claim it" during a fireside chat at the Singapore FinTech Festival. He cited four core principles - privacy, cybersecurity, AI ethics, and Internet safety - to build trust among users. Nadella also highlighted the importance of deep listening skills and customer obsession in understanding and meeting customer needs. He encouraged tech companies to strike a balance between harnessing data and adhering to principles of responsibility and ethics.

images.alt_text: Disruptions from the pandemic could accelerate tech adoption by financial services, but trust in technology has to be "earned, not claimed", said Microsoft's chief executive Satya Nadella.

site_title: From Tokyo to Beijing, growing old is hard to do
summary: Japan's health ministry is set to release its 2020 birth and death estimates, expected to confirm a shrinking indigenous population and a darkening demographic shadow. The country's population has been declining since 2008, with deaths outnumbering births by over half a million in 2019. Japan's experience serves as a warning to China, which faces a similar demographic crisis due to its aging population and declining birth rates. China's over-65s ratio is expected to reach 25% in 15 years, mirroring Japan's current 29% ratio.

site_title: Door will always be open for India to rejoin RCEP trade pact: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed his country's openness to re-engaging with India on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade agreement. This comes ahead of Singapore's term as coordinator of Asean-India dialogue relations in 2021. Lee hopes to see India revisit the merits of joining RCEP, indicating a potential re-evaluation of the agreement.

site_title: Sabana Reit independent director resigns after merger with ESR-Reit hits the skids
summary: Sabana Reit's independent director Ng Shin Ein has resigned, effective Dec 31, to pursue other interests. The move comes after the proposed merger between ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit fell through. Ng stated that scaling up is the right direction for Sabana Reit, despite some unitholders preferring to break up the portfolio for a one-off gain. The resignation was announced in a filing to the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: S&P revises outlook for Singtel to negative
summary: S&P Global Ratings has revised its outlook for Singtel to negative due to the telco's deteriorating leverage, but maintained its "A" long-term and "A-1" short-term issuer credit ratings. The downgrade reflects Singtel's impact from the pandemic and slow economic recovery, with debt-to-EBITDA ratio expected to weaken to 2.6-2.7x in FY2021. The company has taken steps to manage leverage, but S&P does not expect significant payback from 5G investments within two years.

site_title: US: Nasdaq closes at record high as growth names get a lift
summary: The US stock market closed at a record high on Monday, with the Nasdaq advancing 0.5% to a record close, driven by gains in mega-cap growth stocks such as Apple and Facebook. Despite new Covid-19 restrictions in California, large cap growth stocks edged up 0.36%, while value stocks declined 0.56%. Investors are awaiting a potential stimulus package from the US Congress, with a one-week stopgap funding bill expected to be considered.

site_title: Flush with cash, Chinese hog producer builds world's largest pig farm
summary: Chinese hog producer Muyuan Foods has built the world's largest pig farm, a massive industrial facility in rural China with 21 buildings, aiming to raise more hogs than any company in the world. The new farm, which began construction in March and operations in September, represents the trend of replacing small, traditional farms with industrialized facilities, despite carrying a risk of disease. This move follows the devastating impact of African swine fever on traditional farms.

site_title: Shippit bags A$30m in Series B round to drive regional expansion
summary: Shippit, an Australian e-commerce logistics company, raised A$30 million in a series B round led by US-based Tiger Global. The funds will drive regional expansion in Southeast Asia, particularly in the Philippines and Indonesia, and will be used for product development and hiring 100 new staff, including 50 software developers. With a 50% month-on-month growth rate, Shippit aims to double its staff count and grow at least 100% year-on-year for the next three years, enabling its scalable logistics platform to support e-commerce growth in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Lufthansa ground staff agree on deal to avoid layoffs
summary: Lufthansa ground staff in Germany have agreed to a 200-million-euro cut in personnel costs to avoid layoffs until March 2022. The deal covers 35,000 staff, includes cancelled bonuses and suspended wage increases, and protects employees from compulsory redundancies. 71% of Verdi union members accepted the deal, seen as a vote of solidarity among Lufthansa employees. The agreement comes as the airline faces an unprecedented slump in travel demand due to the pandemic, and work will start on agreeing measures from 2022 when the government's short-time work scheme ends.

site_title: BT BAF's 11th end-of-year production takes a virtual spin this year
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) held its 11th end-of-year production online, featuring 67 cast members, including dancers, musicians, and artists. The event, which took place on December 4, was the first major online show for BT BAF and was streamed on Facebook and YouTube. Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, the event showcased the talents of children and youths, with many crediting arts programs for helping them develop their passions. BT BAF has supported over 19,000 children and youths through various arts programs, and plans to establish a new space at One Holland Village by 2024.

site_title: JC Penney's retail and operating assets to exit Chapter 11
summary: JC Penney has exited Chapter 11 bankruptcy with the acquisition of its retail and operating assets by Simon Property Group and Brookfield Asset Management. The deal, valued at nearly all assets, allows JC Penney to continue operating properties and distribution centers. The company will access approximately $1.5 billion in new financing, and its JCPenney banner will continue to serve customers. The restructuring process is expected to complete in the first half of 2021, preserving tens of thousands of jobs.

site_title: Cybercrime costs to top US$1t this year: researchers
summary: Cybercrime is expected to cost the global economy over $1 trillion this year, a 50% increase since 2018, according to a report by McAfee and the Center for Strategic and International Studies. The cost of online criminal activity exceeds 1% of global economic output, with significant non-monetary impacts, including system downtime, intellectual property loss, and damage to an organization's reputation. Only 44% of surveyed companies have plans in place to prevent and respond to security incidents.

site_title: More Singapore fintech firms looking to hire local talent, report suggests
summary: More Singaporean fintech firms are looking to hire local talent, with 28% of respondents expecting mostly local hires, up from 9.6% in 2019. The majority (62.5%) still expect a mix of local and foreign talent. The pandemic has had a positive impact on the fintech industry, with 68% of respondents believing it has fueled a shift towards digital processes. The sector remains resilient, with 97% of firms intending to expand their headcount in the next year.

site_title: South-east Asia's Internet economy on the cusp of big change, says Alphabet chief
summary: Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai says the South-east Asian internet economy is on the cusp of a "massive transformation" as COVID-19 accelerates digital adoption. To close the digital divide, Google is focusing on infrastructure, affordable devices, and financial connectivity through its Google Pay platform. Pichai emphasizes the importance of digital skills and tools for small businesses and entrepreneurs, highlighting the need for partnerships and collaboration. He also notes that expanding digital trade could add $1 trillion to GDP by 2025 and create new opportunities for growth and job creation.

site_title: World Economic Forum to be held in Singapore in May
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has announced that its Special Annual Meeting 2021 will be held in Singapore instead of Switzerland due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. WEF President Borge Brende cited concerns over health and safety for participants and staff in Europe. The event is scheduled for May 13-16, 2021.

site_title: Ezion unit wins US$83.4m contract to transport and install wind turbines
summary: Ezion, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Ezion Holdings, has secured a US$83.4 million contract from Foxwell Energy Corp for the transportation and installation of 31 offshore wind turbines. The one-year contract, set to begin in September 2024, is for a Taiwanese state-run utility's offshore wind farm. This project is not expected to significantly impact Ezion's earnings or net tangible assets for the 2020 financial year.

site_title: Oil falls amid surging virus cases and US-China tensions
summary: Oil prices fell around 1% on Monday due to surging coronavirus cases and US-China tensions, undermining the positive impact of an Opec+ deal on production. Brent crude fell 46 US cents to settle at US$48.79 a barrel, while US crude fell 50 cents to settle at US$45.76 a barrel. Rising tensions between the US and China, the world's top oil consumers, have weighed on the market. A surge in coronavirus cases has also led to renewed lockdowns, including in the US and Germany.

site_title: EU approves measures to punish human rights abusers
summary: The European Union has approved a new framework to punish human rights abusers worldwide. The EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy allows member states to freeze assets and ban travel for those committing "serious violations." This new measure is comparable to the US Magnitsky Act, which has been used to impose sanctions on senior Russian officials. The EU's decision comes after eight associates of Russian President Vladimir Putin were sanctioned for their alleged involvement in the poisoning of opposition leader Alexei Navalny.

site_title: Construction firms worry about margins as cost of labour rises
summary: The Singapore government plans to allow employers to bring in more existing work pass holders and new migrant workers to address the construction industry's labor crunch. This move comes as companies face challenges due to a shortage of foreign workers, with some firms raising wages by up to 30% to retain workers. The industry is concerned that the shortage could lead to higher prices and reduced profit margins, with some firms potentially turning in losses. The government aims to address the issue through measures such as expedited work permit applications and temporary flexibility in employment rules.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record high; S&P 500, Dow open lower
summary: The Nasdaq Composite reached a record high on Monday due to growing hopes for a new stimulus bill, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones dipped amid Sino-US tensions over Hong Kong. The Nasdaq closed at 12,487.63, a 0.19% gain, while the S&P 500 fell 0.18% to 3,692.47 and the Dow Jones dropped 0.22% to 30,150.91. The record high was seen as a positive sign for the US market, but tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong continue to weigh on global stocks.

site_title: Japan set to unveil US$706b stimulus package
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is set to unveil a US$706 billion stimulus package to boost the economy amid rising virus cases and declining support for his Cabinet. The package, worth around 40 trillion yen, includes fiscal measures, loans, and investments to support structural changes and disaster management. The spending is partly financed by a third extra budget and will include a green technology fund and support for digitalization. The measures aim to maintain the economy's momentum while containing the virus, but face challenges in boosting consumer spending, particularly due to the potential spread of the virus through travel subsidies.

site_title: ISOTeam announces contract wins worth S$21.38m
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore-based building maintenance firm, has secured contracts worth S$21.38 million, bringing the total secured for the financial year to S$42.26 million. The contracts include a S$10.5 million interior-rejuvenation project for an integrated resort in Singapore and four repair-and-redecoration projects worth S$8.65 million. CEO Anthony Koh expressed optimism despite a challenging industry, concluding that the latest wins end the year on a positive note.

site_title: Philip Jeyaretnam appointed Judicial Commissioner of the Supreme Court
summary: The President has appointed Philip Jeyaretnam as a Judicial Commissioner of the Supreme Court, starting January 4, 2021. Jeyaretnam, a leading commercial litigator and international arbitration counsel, was conferred Senior Counsel in 2003 at 38, making him one of the youngest to hold the title.

site_title: Trust in technology has to be earned, not claimed, says Microsoft chief
summary: Microsoft's CEO Satya Nadella emphasized the importance of earning trust in technology, not claiming it, in a fireside chat at the Singapore FinTech Festival. He cited four core principles: privacy, cyber security, AI ethics, and Internet safety. Nadella noted that as data becomes increasingly accessible, companies must balance their capabilities with responsibility, and that "some person in some company is responsible" for adhering to these principles. He also highlighted the importance of empathy and deep listening skills in building customer obsession.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% lower, ending two straight days of gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.51% to 2,825.51 on Monday, ending two straight days of gains, as the local bourse mirrored a mixed performance in the region. The retreat was attributed to geopolitical concerns and falling oil prices, but vaccine rollout hopes kept investors optimistic. Key players, including Singtel and Sembcorp Marine, bucked the trend with gains, while conglomerate Sembcorp Industries issued a profit warning. Market participants will focus on the US stimulus deal and macro releases this week.

site_title: UBS' Weber sees no deal with Credit Suisse in the near term
summary: UBS Group Chairman Axel Weber stated that a potential combination with Credit Suisse is unlikely in the near term due to recent executive changes and the complexity of such a transaction. This comes after Credit Suisse departing chairman Urs Rohner suggested a merger with UBS, citing potential benefits. A feasibility study on a mega-merger was conducted by UBS two months ago, but no deal is expected in the near future.

site_title: Dubai's biggest developer Emaar halts new construction work
summary: Dubai's largest developer Emaar Properties has halted new construction work due to oversupply in the Gulf city's real estate market. Chairman Mohamed Alabbar cited the ongoing coronavirus crisis and improving demand as reasons for the halt. Despite this, the market remains oversupplied, and demand is still not meeting supply, according to Alabbar.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on worries over US-China relations
summary: European shares slipped on Monday due to rising US-China tensions, with the DAX index and STOXX 600 falling 0.1%. The US is preparing to impose sanctions on Chinese officials over Hong Kong's disqualification of opposition legislators. Banks led declines, down 1.7%, while consumer and healthcare stocks rose. The pound fell due to uncertainty over a Brexit trade deal. Negotiators are set to hold another call on Monday evening to address differences on fishing rights and competition.

site_title: China suspends beef imports from sixth Australian beef supplier
summary: China has suspended imports of beef from Australia's Meramist, the sixth supplier to face such a move, without providing a reason. This decision comes as China has already banned imports from five other Australian beef suppliers this year, citing issues with labelling and health certificates. The move further strains Australia's ties with its top trade partner, China, which have been deteriorating since Canberra called for an enquiry into the origins of the coronavirus.

site_title: Singaporean who returned from Indonesia among 13 new Covid-19 cases
summary: Singapore reported 13 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 58,273. The new cases include a Singaporean man who returned from Indonesia, a permanent resident from India, and 10 work permit holders from India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Myanmar. All cases were imported, with none in worker's dormitories or the community. Eight cases were discharged on Monday, leaving 76 active cases, with 48 recuperating in community facilities. The country has seen 29 deaths from complications arising from COVID-19.

site_title: Ikea turns the page: drops iconic catalogue after 70 years
summary: Ikea, a budget furniture giant, has discontinued its iconic catalogue after 70 years due to a shift in shopping habits towards online platforms. The 2016 peak of 200 million copies distributed to households and stores in 50 markets has decreased to 40 million in the latest edition. This move reflects the company's efforts to adapt to the changing consumer behavior and maintain its presence in the market.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Common financial mistakes of the sandwich generation (Ep 85)
summary: The Business Times podcast "BT Money Hacks" discusses common financial mistakes made by the sandwich generation, typically Gen X-ers and millennials in their 30s and 40s, who care for both their children and ageing parents. The top two mistakes include not taking enough risk beyond fixed deposits and bank accounts, and not having a step-by-step plan to fix these mistakes. The podcast also provides advice on how to help ageing parents with medical cover and assess funds that deliver income rather than long-term growth.

site_title: Covid-19 case detected at ASL Shipyard
summary: A confirmed imported case of Covid-19 was detected at ASL Shipyard in Singapore, affecting a 53-year-old employee who worked there between Nov 30 and Dec 2. The employee had traveled to Indonesia and returned to Singapore on Nov 28, testing negative for the virus before developing symptoms on Dec 2. The Singapore Ministry of Health has determined that the employee had no close interactions with colleagues, allowing the shipyard to resume operations. ASL has taken precautionary measures, including isolating personnel and conducting thorough cleaning and disinfection.

site_title: France's SocGen to shut 600 branches by 2025 by merging bank networks
summary: France's Societe Generale (SocGen) plans to shut 600 branches in France by 2025 by merging its two retail banking networks. The move is expected to save the bank over 350 million euros in costs by 2024 and nearly 450 million euros in 2025. The online bank Boursorama aims to target 4.5 million clients by 2025, despite posting cumulative losses of around 230 million euros until 2023. The bank's CEO, Frederic Oudea, has accelerated initiatives to boost profitability.

site_title: Singapore a key hub for blockchain research and commercialisation: report
summary: Singapore has produced the highest number of blockchain research publications in ASEAN and the third highest globally, with nearly 28 blockchain-related publications per million resident population. The country ranks sixth globally among highly-cited blockchain publications and has the highest average number of citations for blockchain publications. A survey found 70% of respondents support blockchain technology and believe its growth will accelerate. The report also notes the growing trend of companies using blockchain for supply chain improvements and the increasing adoption of blockchain for verifying health credentials.

site_title: Door will 'always be open' for India to rejoin RCEP trade pact: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the door will always be open for India to rejoin the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade agreement. This comes ahead of India's term as coordinator of Asean-India dialogue relations in 2021. Lee acknowledged India's significant influence on the global stage and expressed hope for a deeper partnership between the two nations.

site_title: Kingfisher joins other British retailers to return virus business rates relief aid
summary: Kingfisher, a British retailer, has joined other major retailers in returning Covid-19 business rates relief aid. The company, which benefited from increased DIY projects during lockdowns, announced the move amid scrutiny over retailers taking government funds while paying dividends. Sales have improved since reopening stores in April and May, driven by higher demand for home improvement. Kingfisher's decision follows similar announcements from Tesco, Sainsbury's, and Morrisons, as well as smaller retailers like Pets at Home.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has launched the world's first system allowing citizens to consolidate their financial information across seven major banks and government agencies. The system aims to promote inclusive tech innovation and partnerships to spur global recovery. Meanwhile, Japfa sold 80% of its Greenfields Dairy Singapore to TPG and Northstar for US$236m, while CapitaLand formed a US$300m JV to grow its multifamily asset portfolio in the US. Corporate earnings also saw Singapore shares close 0.5% lower, ending two straight days of gains.

site_title: Losses balloon at UK's Ted Baker as lockdowns hammer retail sales
summary: UK fashion retailer Ted Baker reported a pretax loss of £39 million in the first half of 2020, up from £2.7 million a year earlier, due to coronavirus-led lockdowns and Brexit uncertainty. The company's turnaround plan aims to deliver £31 million in annual savings. Despite this, its balance sheet is stronger than expected, and operational cash flow is expected to be positive for the full year. The main operational risk remains the impact of a no-deal Brexit on the flow of goods into the UK.

site_title: Venture investor Highland Europe raises 700m euros for fourth fund
summary: Highland Europe, a venture capital group, has raised 700 million euros for its fourth fund, its largest to date, focusing on European software and internet startups. The new fund brings the total raised by Highland Europe to 1.8 billion euros since its inception in 2012. The group has joined funding rounds of over 100 million euros this year and made seven new investments, while two portfolio companies have found buyers. The fund's co-founder and partner Fergal Mullen attributes the surge in deal activity to accelerated tech adoption trends in 2020.

site_title: Moroccan geeks flock to 'paradise for hackers'
summary: Morocco's 1337 campus, a free coding institute, has become a hub for skilled young hackers, offering project-based training in programming and innovation. With its 24-hour campus and tuition-free model, the center attracts students who have dropped out of traditional education or have self-taught skills. The institute, founded by Morocco's phosphate giant OCP, works closely with a French programming school and aims to address the country's severe need for tech expertise, with a focus on "invisible youth" who have developed rare skills on their own.

site_title: Singapore adds three charges against director in Wirecard case
summary: Singapore authorities added three new charges against R Shanmugaratnam, a director of Citadelle Corporate Services, in a case linked to Wirecard's collapse. The charges involve falsifying letters about cash in escrow accounts, totaling 377.5 million euros (S$610.9 million). This brings the total number of charges to 14, covering 1.2 billion euros in cash. Shanmugaratnam is the first person to be indicted in Singapore over the Wirecard scandal, which has had a global impact.

site_title: Solve yawning income gap, and make another billion? DBS throws down gauntlet
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, has launched a nationwide financial data sharing initiative, SGFinDex, to help narrow the income inequality gap exacerbated by Covid-19. The platform, accessible via DBS' digital financial planning tool, aims to provide financial guidance to lower-income earners. Since its launch, 53% of 1.8 million users have monthly incomes of S$2,999 or less, and 400,000 users have seen their finances turned around. DBS chief Piyush Gupta expects the growth of these underserved markets to amount to a "billion-dollar business" in three to five years.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Giant vertical farm opens in Denmark
summary: Denmark's largest vertical farm, Nordic Harvest, has opened in a Copenhagen warehouse, covering 7,000 square meters. The farm uses 20,000 LED lightbulbs and produces 200 tonnes of produce in the first quarter of 2021, with plans to increase to 1,000 tonnes annually. Founder Anders Riemann emphasizes the environmental benefits of the farm, using green electricity and recycling water and nutrients. The farm aims to reduce the need for traditional farming and provide fresh produce to local clients.

site_title: SUSS, ESG platform to trial blockchain solutions for trade and connectivity
summary: Singapore University of Social Sciences (SUSS) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) launched the Blockchain for Trade & Connectivity (BTC) Network to innovate and test blockchain solutions for supply chains and trade. The platform aims to reduce barriers to trade and advance the trade and connectivity sector towards a secure and effective digital future. Supported by the National Research Foundation, the initiative will enhance interoperability between blockchains and offer a test bed for blockchain solutions with global supply chain companies and digital trading platforms. The goal is to promote greater efficiency and transparency across global supply chains.

site_title: Pounds dives on report Johnson to abandon Brexit talks
summary: The pound plummeted over 1% against the dollar and 1% against the euro after reports that Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to abandon post-Brexit trade talks with the European Union. The news, published in The Sun, comes despite the European Parliament's tight deadline to ratify an accord before the UK leaves the single market on December 31. The UK's FTSE 100 index fell 0.2%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices dropped 0.7% and 1.0%, respectively.

site_title: HSBC sees more Hong Kong problems as politician accounts frozen
summary: HSBC Holdings has been at the center of controversy in Hong Kong after a former pro-democracy lawmaker, Ted Hui, accused the bank of freezing his and his family's accounts. The incident occurred amid a police investigation in Hong Kong and China's imposition of new security measures, eroding faith in the city's banking system. Hui's family was able to transfer their savings after the accounts were temporarily unfrozen, but police later ordered HSBC to block the accounts again, calling the incident "extremely serious" and impacting customer confidence.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed sharply lower on Monday, falling 1.23% due to profit-taking and concerns over China-US tensions. Despite China's exports rising at their fastest pace in almost three years, the Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,506.85. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also fell, with the Shanghai Index down 0.81% and the Shenzhen Index down 0.30%.

site_title: Indonesia receives over a million Chinese Covid-19 vaccine doses
summary: Indonesia has received 1.2 million doses of a Covid-19 vaccine made by China's Sinovac, with plans to distribute them to medical workers and other high-risk groups. The vaccine's efficacy and safety will be checked by Indonesia's food and drug agency and the country's top Muslim clerical body. The delivery comes as Indonesia struggles to control soaring case rates, with over 575,000 infections and 17,000 deaths. The government has paid $60 million for the doses, with another 100,000 expected to be delivered by CanSino next month.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has received 1.2 million doses of a Covid-19 vaccine made by China's Sinovac, officials said, as the world's fourth most populous nation struggles to get soaring case rates under control.

site_title: BOJ becomes biggest Japan stock owner with S$579b hoard
summary: The Bank of Japan has become the largest owner of Japan's stocks, with a portfolio valued at 45.1 trillion yen (S$579 billion) in November, surpassing the Government Pension Investment Fund. The BOJ's massive exchange-traded fund purchases and valuation gains have contributed to its dominant presence in the market, raising concerns over its influence on prices. The combination of the BOJ and GPIF's holdings has distorted market dynamics, with experts warning that the BOJ may face scrutiny over its continued buying of equities at elevated prices.

site_title: Giant Japanese steel mill signals pandemic-recovery taking root
summary: Nippon Steel Corp, Japan's third-largest steelmaker, is restarting facilities it shut earlier this year due to the pandemic. The company plans to reopen at least three blast furnaces as demand for steel recovers, with a focus on the automotive industry. Steel prices in Asia have risen due to China's strong economy, supporting global crude steel output, which is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels next year. Nippon Steel's plan to cut output by shutting ageing mills remains on track, despite the recovery in demand.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at record high for fifth straight session
summary: South Korea's Kospi index closed at a record high for the fifth straight session, rising 13.99 points or 0.51% to 2,745.44. Retail investors snapped up tech giants such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, while foreigners were net sellers of 89.6 billion won. The benchmark bond yield fell, and the won held steady against the dollar. China's November trade data showed exports rose at the fastest pace in almost three years, boosting sentiment. However, the South Korean government imposed heightened social-distancing rules to contain the nation's largest wave of coronavirus infection.

site_title: StanChart, UnionBank complete Philippines blockchain-enabled bond issuance
summary: Standard Chartered and UnionBank of the Philippines have completed a proof of concept for a blockchain-enabled bond issuance, issuing a 9 billion pesos (S$249.8 million) dual bond. The bond was tokenized on a platform co-created by UnionBank and StanChart's innovation arm, SC Ventures. Orders were received and allocated without direct investor allocation. The pilot aims to provide retail investors with direct access to issuers, increasing accessibility and efficiency. The Philippines' Securities and Exchange Commission will need to approve the program for full implementation.

site_title: Flush with cash, Chinese hog producer builds world's largest pig farm
summary: China's top pig producer, Muyuan Foods, has built the world's largest pig farm, with a capacity to house 84,000 sows and their offspring. The mega farm, valued at 40 billion yuan, aims to increase efficiency and reduce disease risk through automation and technology. However, experts warn that the high-density design carries significant risks, including the spread of deadly African swine fever. The farm's success could disrupt global pork markets, potentially reducing imports and sending prices soaring.

site_title: Airbnb streamlines fees as it tilts toward biggest hosts
summary: Airbnb is requiring most professional hosts outside North America to include service fees in the rate presented to guests, shifting from a 3% guest fee to a 15% host fee. This change aims to simplify pricing and is seen as cost-neutral for most guests. The move is part of Airbnb's preparation for its initial public offering (IPO) and is expected to drive 17% more bookings. Hosts with fewer properties may face concerns about raising prices, but most professional hosts are expected to adapt to the new fee structure.

site_title: Cisco to buy Iodine for US$750m to boost AI offerings
summary: Cisco Systems is set to acquire UK-based cloud communications software provider Iodine for US$750 million, including debt. The deal aims to boost Cisco's AI offerings and position the company as a networking software and services provider. Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins seeks to shift the company's focus from hardware to software and services, responding to an industry trend of outsourcing functions to remote data centers. The acquisition is expected to close in the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: JPMorgan hires UBS banker for Asia equity capital markets role: sources
summary: JPMorgan has hired UBS banker Huang Peihao as co-head of its equity capital markets (ECM) business in Asia, excluding Japan. Huang, who was UBS's head of Asia ECM, left the Swiss bank to join JPMorgan. He will work alongside Gregor Feige, and UBS will cover Huang's responsibilities with Lauro Baja, head of Asia Pacific Capital Markets. This move comes after JPMorgan appointed Francesco Lavatelli as head of ECM business for the Asia-Pacific in October.

site_title: Gold steadies as US stimulus bets outweigh vaccine hopes
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$1,837.04 per ounce as US jobs data showed the fewest workers in six months, bolstering hopes for fiscal stimulus. Despite optimism around coronavirus vaccine rollouts, the gold market was capped by the news. Markets expect the US stimulus package to support gold prices, as it raises the prospect of inflation. The bipartisan nature of the deal suggests further compromise in the US Congress, which could benefit gold.

site_title: Australia's IGO in talks to buy US$1.5b stake in lithium mine from China's Tianqi: sources
summary: Australian nickel-gold miner IGO is in talks to buy a $1.5 billion stake in the Greenbushes lithium mine from China's Tianqi, which urgently needs funds to repay loans. The deal includes a stake in the world's largest hard-rock lithium mine and other assets in Australia. IGO will fund the purchase with existing cash and debt, and Macquarie Capital and Citigroup will advise on a potential capital raising to partly fund the deal. The acquisition is a significant move by IGO and reflects the growing importance of lithium in the electric-vehicle market.

site_title: Asia capital markets gear up for a busy December after record fundraising
summary: Asia's capital markets are expected to remain active in December, with 43 deals raising $12.7 billion in the first four days, three times the amount of the same period last year. This brings the year's total to a record $355.4 billion, surpassing the previous record of $306.2 billion in 2010. The surge in fundraising is driven by strong financial markets, investor appetite, and liquidity, with Hong Kong and China accounting for the largest share.

site_title: The super-rich are buying luxury online like never before
summary: The super-rich are increasingly buying luxury items online, with Christie's and Sotheby's reporting record-breaking sales. Christie's has seen a 200% increase in online sales, with a total high estimate of $40 million, while Sotheby's has quadrupled its year-over-year volume of online sales, reaching $150.5 million. Online luxury sales have been driven by a shift in buyer behavior, with 10 years of digital adoption occurring in just 10 months, and a 60% increase in sales of objects over $100,000.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB raises ComfortDelGro's target price on less competitive taxi industry
summary: Broker RHB has raised its target price for ComfortDelGro to S$1.90, up from S$1.70, due to a decline in competitive intensity in the taxi industry amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The analyst notes that Grab's potential merger with Gojek could further reduce competition, while the company's focus on its financial services business and food delivery services may also support earnings growth. RHB maintains a "buy" recommendation for ComfortDelGro.

site_title: Australia: Shares scale nine-month high as miners rally further
summary: Australia's shares reached a nine-month high on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.6% to 6,675. The rally was driven by iron ore prices, which rose further due to supply concerns and robust demand in China. Mining stocks, including Fortescue Metals Group and BHP Group, scaled new highs. Energy stocks also gained, while financials underperformed due to regulatory woes. The gains were despite concerns about the US-China relationship, which led to a decline in broader Asia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, erasing early gains, as investors took profits following a recent surge. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.76% to 26,547.44 and the Topix index lost 0.86% to 1,760.75. The decline was attributed to profit-taking.

site_title: For Dolce & Gabbana, no crying over crisis, be inventive
summary: Italian fashion designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have adapted to the coronavirus crisis by becoming more inventive and resourceful. With traditional runway shows and in-person appointments now difficult, they have turned to creating mini-films for their upcoming haute couture collections, which will be broadcast online. The crisis has actually sharpened their inventiveness, with the pair stating they are "back like they were in the years 1985-86," rediscovering the happiness of savouring their work.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus crisis has upended the norms of the fashion world, but Italian designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana believe it has spurred them to be more inventive and resourceful.

site_title: India's Serum Institute seeks emergency use nod for AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine candidate
summary: Serum Institute of India, the world's largest vaccine producer, has sought emergency use authorization in the country for AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine candidate, Covishield. The vaccine can be stored at 2-8 degrees Celsius and distributed easily in India, which has the world's second-highest number of infections. Serum's move comes after Pfizer Inc also applied for similar authorization. The vaccine has shown high effectiveness against severe Covid-19 infections in clinical studies conducted in the UK, Brazil, and India. The move aims to save lives and make the vaccine available for use in the country.

site_title: These two words will strike fear into gadget makers this Christmas
summary: Global electronics companies face a potential sales slump this Christmas due to supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic. Shuttered factories, reduced flights, and lockdowns are hindering the robustness of companies' supply chains. Major tech giants such as Sony, Nintendo, and Apple are at risk of lost sales, despite efforts to mitigate challenges. The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed the critical importance of a company's supply chain, and those that can navigate these challenges will have a strategic advantage.

site_title: Ying Li group CEO detained in China in bribery probe
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate's CEO Hu Bing has been detained in Beijing due to suspected bribery. The detention is unrelated to the company's operations, and Hu will cease as CEO, executive director, and nominating committee member with immediate effect. Yang Haishan, a non-executive director, will take over as acting CEO. The company's shares fell 7.7% to 7.2 Singapore cents as of Monday morning. The investigation's outcome is still unknown, and the company's Chinese legal counsel is following up with authorities for more information.

site_title: LMIRT manager denies request to postpone voting for acquisition of Lippo Mall Puri
summary: LMIRT manager denies request to postpone voting on the proposed acquisition of Lippo Mall Puri, which was scheduled for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Dec 14. Certain unitholders requested an additional resolution to postpone the voting, but the manager declined, stating the EGM will proceed as planned. The acquisition is among other items to be discussed at the EGM.

site_title: Shadow banks show signs of recovery as India economy rebounds
summary: India's shadow lenders show signs of recovery as the country's economy rebounds from an unprecedented recession. Two out of four indicators compiled by Bloomberg improved last month, with shares of shadow banks increasing and debt piles trimmed. A stronger shadow banking industry is crucial for the economy's recovery, as it provides funds to those banks can't reach, including the poorest. Despite this, global rating companies warn of potential stress ahead, citing increased bad loans and withdrawal of pandemic-era support. India's GDP growth has improved, but challenges persist.

site_title: Hot stocks: Singtel, Sea jump after digital-bank win; iFast, Razer sink
summary: Singtel and Sea Limited saw their shares surge after being selected to set up digital banks in Singapore, while iFast Corp and Razer Inc tumbled after failing to secure licenses. Singtel jumped 10.5% and Sea surged 8.3% after winning the digital full-bank (DFB) and digital wholesale bank (DWB) licenses, respectively. In contrast, iFast lost 29% and Razer sank 9.3% following the news. Analysts expect Singtel to expand into a profitable business and diversify away from its mature telco businesses, while Sea may face pressure on its margins as it expands into the financial services segment.

site_title: Nokia leading a 6G wireless network project for European Union
summary: Nokia is leading a 6G wireless network project called Hexa-X, funded by the European Union, in collaboration with Ericsson, Orange, Telefonica, Intel, and Siemens. The project aims to develop 6G technology using super high-frequency terahertz airwaves, enabling advanced connectivity, real-time holographic imaging, and potential brain-body technology. The project's objectives include establishing a vision, road map, and timeline, and facilitating interaction with US government agencies to fund research and technology development, with a target completion date of 2030.

images.alt_text: Nokia is leading a group of companies and universities in a European Union funded wireless project called Hexa-X to help jump-start a new generation of mobile technology that's already being called 6G.

site_title: South Korea's Moon orders more testing as coronavirus cases surge
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in has ordered expanded coronavirus testing and more thorough tracing amid the country's latest surge in infections. As of midnight Sunday, 615 new cases were reported, with 8,311 confirmed patients in quarantine, the highest ever. The government will mobilize resources to track infections and deploy the military and public service personnel to set up more testing facilities. The positive test rate is 4.2%, significantly higher than the year's average. Authorities have also imposed heightened social distancing rules in the capital Seoul and surrounding areas until the end of the month.

site_title: PropNex appoints ex-Huttons Asia CEO as strategy and development officer
summary: PropNex Realty has appointed Goh Kee Nguan, former Huttons Asia CEO, as its strategy and development officer, effective Dec 1, 2020. Goh will help spur business growth in tech and real estate development, and drive innovation with tech-enabled solutions for salespersons and clients. CEO Ismail Gafoor expects technology to remain key in the industry post-Covid-19.

site_title: Sequoia Capital warned of a 'black swan'. Instead, 2020 is one of its best years ever
summary: Sequoia Capital, a leading venture capital firm, initially predicted a "black swan" event in March 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, advising companies to cut spending and jobs. However, the pandemic unexpectedly benefited technology companies, with the stock market recovering and businesses going public, including Airbnb and DoorDash. Sequoia's funds have seen record returns, with at least two funds reporting 11-fold and 8-fold returns, respectively, after fees. The firm's reputation as a visionary investor has been reinforced, with investors crediting its ability to adapt and predict the pandemic's impact on technology companies.

site_title: Regional equity markets approach 2021 buoyant on the back of vaccine hopes: DBS
summary: Regional equity markets are optimistic heading into 2021 due to vaccine hopes, trade partnerships, and stable US-China ties, according to a DBS report. The report estimates 38% of the world's population could be vaccinated by end-2021 and herd immunity achieved by end-2022. Market valuations are elevated, but DBS sees no alarm, citing similarities with the post-2009 global financial crisis bull market. Regional markets are trading at 16 times their 12-month forward P/E levels, slightly above two standard deviations over a 15-year period.

site_title: Bird flu outbreak in Japan spreads to fifth prefecture
summary: Bird flu has spread to a fifth Japanese prefecture, Hiroshima, with two egg-producing farms in Mihara city infected. The outbreak, Japan's worst in over four years, has led to the culling of nearly 2 million chickens since its start last month. Avian influenza has been detected in Kagawa prefecture, where the outbreak began, and human transmission is not possible. The Japanese agriculture ministry has restricted exports within a 3km radius and slaughtered over 130,000 chickens at the affected farms.

site_title: China's Covid-free 'Hawaii' chases local tourist dollar with a vengeance
summary: China's southernmost island province of Hainan, known as the "Hawaii of China", has seen a surge in domestic tourism since being coronavirus-free for six months. October arrivals exceeded the year-earlier figure by 3.1%, with 9.6 million visitors, while foreign visitors plummeted 87%. The island's duty-free shopping and wedding destinations have attracted tourists, with tourism spending reaching 12 billion yuan in the past four months, a 214.1% increase from the previous year. The island's normalcy and warm weather are drawing tourists, with bookings for December increasing 51% from the previous year.

site_title: Airbnb plans to raise price target range for IPO: source
summary: Airbnb plans to raise its initial public offering (IPO) price target range to $56-$60 per share, up from its previous range of $44-$50 per share, according to a source. This would value the company at $41.8 billion, exceeding its pre-pandemic valuation of $31 billion. The IPO is set to debut on December 10 on Nasdaq and is one of the largest and most anticipated US IPOs of 2020.

site_title: New CEO drives Wipro stock up 70% without stepping into office
summary: Wipro's new CEO, Thierry Delaporte, has driven the company's stock up 70% in five months despite not physically visiting the Bangalore headquarters. Delaporte has focused on customers, meeting 130 over video conference, and stepped up acquisitions. He aims to turn the struggling business around and put Wipro back on track after years of stagnating financials. Delaporte's predecessor, Abidali Neemuchwala, failed to achieve his target of building Wipro into a $15 billion company by 2020. Delaporte's turnaround plan includes accelerating growth, reaching the growth level of competitors by year two, and outdoing them by year three.

site_title: UK power costs to rise without net zero market reform
summary: The UK power market needs urgent reform to cope with increasing renewable capacity and reach net zero by 2050. A report by Policy Exchange suggests that local supply-based pricing could save £2 billion a year. This summer's test run showed the system is not ready for increasing renewables, leading to 44% higher running costs. By 2050, wind and solar could generate two-thirds of electricity, requiring customers and suppliers to balance variable energy and flexible demand. A more regional approach to pricing could lead to £50 billion annual electricity costs and 6% lower household bills.

site_title: Melbourne welcomes first international flight in five months as Covid curbs ease
summary: Melbourne welcomed its first international passenger flight in five months, marking a significant milestone as Australia's Covid-19 curbs ease. The flight arrived from Sri Lanka, with stricter hotel quarantine standards enforced by police officers. This follows a revised system similar to Sydney's, which has successfully accommodated thousands of returning Australians without clusters emerging. The move aims to test Victoria's revamped system, with hundreds of people expected to arrive each week.

images.alt_text: Australia's second-largest city welcomed its first international passenger flight in five months on Monday, an arrival that will test the state of Victoria's revamped hotel quarantine system.

site_title: In last-ditch bid for Brexit deal, leaders' theatrics show the stakes
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen engaged in a last-ditch phone call to finalize a Brexit deal, with a Dec 31 deadline looming. The two sides are wrestling over state aid, fishing rights, and rules on fair competition. If an agreement cannot be reached, the EU will impose tariffs on British goods, potentially disrupting cross-channel trade. The outcome is uncertain, with Johnson facing pressure from Brexiteers and the EU seeking to maintain its sovereignty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.84 points, or 0.11%, to 1,620.01 at the start of the week, with 1.43 billion lots traded worth RM510.2 million.

site_title: More power to you: Singapore cracks a world's first in democratising finance
summary: Singapore has launched the world's first system, the Singapore Financial Data Exchange (SGFinDex), allowing citizens to consolidate their financial information across seven major banks and government agencies. With their SingPass, users can access their personal financial information, such as deposits, credit cards, and loans, and other information like HDB loans and CPF balances. This move aims to democratize finance and give citizens more control over their financial decisions. The system is a significant step towards a more personalized and secure financial experience for Singaporeans.

site_title: There are no short-cuts to a low carbon future
summary: Asian businesses face increasing pressure to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and meet global climate targets, with many turning to carbon offset programs. However, a survey by Schneider Electric found that 34% of energy professionals were less than confident in their corporate sustainability goals, highlighting the need for stronger, long-term commitments to reduce emissions. Digital technologies can help businesses monitor and limit energy usage, with a 30% reduction in energy usage seen in some cases, and can also offer opportunities for energy storage and renewable resources. Companies that adopt a digitally-powered all-of-business approach can mitigate future risk and differentiate against competition.

images.alt_text: Singtel's 1.65 MWp solar energy installation on the rooftop of its Bedok Data Centre.

site_title: Avocados are 'pandemic-proof' crop in lockdown health craze
summary: Avocado consumption has reached record highs in Europe and the US, driven by health-conscious consumers during the pandemic. According to Xavier Equihua, CEO of the World Avocado Organization, consumption is "off the charts" as people seek healthy and wellness-focused options. This trend is expected to continue post-pandemic, with the fashion industry also embracing healthy eating. The increased demand has helped to stabilize the avocado market despite initial drops at the start of the Covid crisis.

site_title: In a world's first, Singaporeans get aggregated view of finances across banks
summary: Singapore has launched the world's first system, SGFinDex, allowing citizens to consolidate their financial information across seven major banks and government agencies. The system enables users to retrieve their personal financial information, such as deposits, loans, and investments, using their SingPass. Participating banks include DBS, OCBC, UOB, and others. The service aims to empower individuals to plan for their finances and make better financial decisions. It is the first public digital infrastructure to use a national digital identity and online consent framework, and is expected to spur more equal and transparent competition within the financial sector.

site_title: Singapore continuing to seek new travel bubble partners despite HK setback: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore continues to pursue new travel bubble partners despite the delay in the Hong Kong arrangement, Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung said. Countries like Australia, Brunei, China, New Zealand, and Vietnam have been allowed to enter Singapore with minimal restrictions. The Singapore-Hong Kong travel bubble, initially set for November 22, will be reviewed between Christmas and New Year. Ong hopes other countries will reciprocate and open travel bubbles with Singapore, citing the country's successful control of the Covid-19 virus.

site_title: First electric only car-charging station opens in the UK
summary: The UK has opened its first all-electric auto service station, part of a £1 billion programme to roll out 100 electric facilities by 2025. The station in Essex features 36 rapid chargers powered by renewable energy and can charge a battery with 200 miles of capacity in 20 minutes. This is part of a larger push to phase out traditional engines in cars by 2030, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson aiming to slash greenhouse-gas emissions. Electric vehicle sales in the UK have risen 122% in the past month, with many countries investing in EV charging infrastructure to meet the expected 30 million electric vehicles on the road by 2040.

site_title: China holds meeting on coal mine safety after accidents
summary: China's State Council held an emergency meeting on coal mine safety following recent fatal accidents, including 23 deaths at a Chongqing mine. Authorities called for "decisive measures" to control risks and curb incidents. Local governments and companies are prohibited from demanding higher output than quotas, and there will be no grace period for mines slated to close. The move aims to ensure safety and prevent accidents, but may also impact coal production and prices.

site_title: Sembcorp expects fiscal 2020 loss after recording S$89m in impairments
summary: Sembcorp Industries expects a full-year loss for 2020 due to S$89 million in impairments, primarily from a revised strategy for its UK Power Reserve assets and a wastewater treatment plant in Nanjing, China. The company expects to maintain positive operating cash flow, driven by its energy and urban businesses. Impairments also result from the exit of a major customer and a service agreement termination. The group will release its unaudited financial results on February 23, 2021.

site_title: Tata at crossroads as AirAsia India, Vistara reach critical juncture
summary: Ratan Tata's two airlines, AirAsia India and Vistara, are at a critical juncture due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Tata group, which owns 51% of each airline, is struggling to make a profit, having lost around $845 million combined through March this year. The group is considering its options, with some analysts suggesting buying state-run Air India or bowing out. Experts say the Tata group needs to deploy significant capital to run a successful airline, and its single-minded devotion to making an airline work at any cost may not be enough.

site_title: Medtecs, Taiwan's Mytrex tie up for vertical integration of PPE production operations
summary: Medtecs International Corporation has partnered with Mytrex Health Technologies to explore vertical integration of personal protective equipment (PPE) production operations in Taiwan, the Philippines, and the US. The collaboration aims to minimize supply chain disruptions and ensure product quality. The two companies will leverage each other's strengths and capabilities to expand their presence in the international market and explore strategic partnerships.

site_title: Sinovac secures US$515m funding to boost Covid-19 vaccine production
summary: Sinovac Biotech has secured US$515 million in funding from China's Sino Biopharmaceutical Limited to double the production capacity of its coronavirus vaccine, CoronaVac. The investment will give Sino Biopharmaceutical a 15.03% interest in Sinovac Life Sciences, a subsidiary of Sinovac. The deal will enable Sinovac to manufacture 300 million vaccine doses annually and aims to complete construction of a second production facility by the end of 2020, increasing annual production capacity to 600 million doses.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.2% to 2,844.03, tracking gains on Wall Street. Shares of Singtel surged 9.8% after the telco won a digital full-bank license, while iFast fell 28.5% after failing to secure a digital wholesale bank license. Other notable movers included Japfa and BT. The gains come as regional markets follow Wall Street's post-election rally, with Tokyo and Australia also trading higher.

site_title: Lessons from the failed Sabana-ESR Reit merger
summary: The proposed merger of Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) and ESR-Reit was called off after a last-minute vote by unitholders failed to pass, largely due to opposition from activist investors Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital, who held 11% of Sabana Reit's units. Investors are advised to focus on high-quality Reits with proven track records of growth through fundraising and DPU-accretive acquisitions.

site_title: SFF x Switch 2020 Ep 4: MAS' Ravi Menon previews the 2020 Singapore FinTech festival
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore's managing director Ravi Menon previews the 2020 Singapore FinTech festival, set to take place from Dec 7-11. He emphasizes the importance of collaboration between financial institutions, startups, and regulators to drive growth and stability in the financial sector. The festival aims to promote Singapore as a hub for FinTech and attract international investment. Menon also highlights the festival's unique features, including exclusive podcasts and panel discussions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday, driven by global rallies on hopes for US stimulus and coronavirus vaccines. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.26% to 26,821.29, while the Topix index gained 0.27% to 1,780.69. This follows recent global market gains, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: BoE's Haldane says consumer spending has come back at a 'real pace': Daily Mail
summary: Bank of England Chief Economist Andy Haldane stated that consumer spending in Britain has returned at a "real pace" following the relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions. This comes after the British parliament approved regional lockdown measures, allowing people to begin spending accumulated savings of approximately £100 billion. Haldane's comments suggest a positive economic outlook, but the UK economy still faces challenges, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: SocGen, Credit du Nord green-light retail bank merger: paper
summary: Societe Generale and Credit du Nord have approved a plan to merge their retail banking operations. The combined entity, expected to take 18-24 months, will generate significant synergies and boost profitability. With 10 million clients, the merged bank will be France's third-largest listed lender. The move comes as part of Societe Generale's efforts to overhaul its operations, following a 57% increase in shares since historic lows.

site_title: Japfa to sell 80% of Greenfields Dairy Singapore for US$236m to TPG, Northstar
summary: Japfa, a Singapore-based agri-food company, will sell 80% of its Greenfields Dairy Singapore (GDS) business to affiliates of TPG and Northstar Group for $236 million. Japfa will retain 20% of GDS and continue to support the management of the business. The deal values GDS at $295 million, with Japfa expecting to receive $244 million in cash following the transaction. Japfa plans to use $150 million for an interim special dividend and other purposes. The deal is conditional on shareholder and lender approval, with completion expected in February next year.

site_title: Paysafe near a US$9b deal to go public
summary: Paysafe Group, a US$5.34 billion online payments firm backed by Blackstone Group Inc. and CVC Capital Partners, is set to go public in a deal with a blank-check firm led by billionaire Bill Foley. The deal, valued at US$9 billion, including debt, is expected to be announced this week. Foley Trasimene Acquisition Corp. II will raise over US$1 billion in new equity to support the transaction, which would be one of the largest blank-check mergers this year. The deal is still pending finalization and talks could change or fall apart.

site_title: Mike Ashley's Frasers Group in talks to buy Debenhams
summary: Mike Ashley's Frasers Group is in talks to buy Debenhams, a move that could save thousands of jobs at the ailing UK department store. Frasers Group, which already owns House of Fraser, is in negotiations with Debenhams after talks with JD Sports Fashion ended. The deal would require Frasers to pay around £280 million and could involve operating Debenhams' 124 stores on a 12-month licence. The move comes after Debenhams faced liquidation and the failure of Arcadia Group, which employed 13,000 people.

site_title: Open innovation is the key to overcoming Covid-19 challenges
summary: Singaporean companies turned to open innovation to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, leveraging partnerships with external parties to develop new products and solutions. This collaborative approach allowed for faster development of workable solutions. According to Edwin Chow, assistant CEO of Enterprise Singapore, crowdsourcing became the "natural option" for enterprises in need of innovative solutions. This strategy enabled companies to adapt to the challenges posed by the pandemic and pave the way for long-term digital adoption.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Monday, tracking a record on Wall Street, driven by optimism over a potential US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.13% to 26,870.58, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.06% to 3,446.65. The news follows recent record highs on Wall Street, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, UOB, Singtel, Keppel, Sabana Reit, iFast, Japfa
summary: Singapore stocks are experiencing new developments that may impact trading. DBS, OCBC, and UOB may review or cut exposure to Chinese state-owned enterprise customers due to high-profile bond defaults. DBS aims to expand its retail customer base to a million within the next few years. site_title: CapitaLand forms US$300m JV to grow multifamily asset portfolio in US
summary: CapitaLand has formed a US$300 million joint venture to acquire and develop multifamily assets in the US, primarily in the south-east and South-west markets. The partnership will focus on Austin, Texas, with an initial project expected to be completed in 2023. The 341-unit suburban multifamily property will feature smart home features and be situated near commercial and leisure activities. This investment adds to CapitaLand's US portfolio, now valued at S$4.7 billion, and reflects the company's preference for the multifamily sector due to its resilience and stable yields.

site_title: Australia's payments board resumes review of retail payments regulations: RBA's Lowe
summary: Australia's Payments System Board has resumed its review of retail payments regulations, led by Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe. The review, paused during the pandemic, will discuss issues such as transaction fees and buy-now-pay-later providers. Lowe stated the board has not reached final conclusions and will meet with industry participants in the coming months. The review is expected to conclude by mid-2021, with potential changes to the interchange framework and no-surcharge rules for buy-now-pay-later providers still uncertain.

site_title: Trump says his lawyer Giuliani has Covid-19
summary: US President Donald Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, has tested positive for Covid-19, according to Trump. Giuliani, 76, is considered high-risk due to his age and has been seen frequently without a mask. Trump's efforts to challenge the election loss may be hindered if his team self-quarantines for at least a week. This diagnosis comes after Trump held a large, unmasked rally in Georgia and follows a surge in US coronavirus cases, with over 230,000 new infections reported in a single day.

site_title: Ivory Coast cocoa producers end chocolate war with Hershey's
summary: Ivory Coast cocoa producers have ended their dispute with Hershey's after the US chocolate giant committed to paying a premium above the market price. The Living Income Differential (LID) of $400 per tonne of cocoa is a bonus for farmers to lift their incomes. Ivory Coast's Coffee Cacao Council lifted the suspension of Hershey's sustainability certification programmes after the firm's commitment, following a video interview on Dec 1. Ghana's decision is unclear, but the deal aims to improve the lives of millions of small farmers in the region.

site_title: UOB pioneers new AI solution for anti-money laundering checks
summary: UOB has implemented a new AI solution to combat financial crime, enabling the bank to identify higher priority cases from thousands of suspicious transaction alerts. The solution, developed in collaboration with Tookitaki Holdings, has a 96% true positive prediction rate in the "high priority" category. The AI solution uses machine learning and greater computational power to sharpen its detection capabilities, allowing UOB to spot sophisticated transaction patterns and connect data points with entities using the financial system. The bank plans to expand the solution globally and continue investing in advanced technology to strengthen its anti-money laundering system.

site_title: GRAPHIC: At a glance
summary: Singapore's OCBC Bank has named Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. This move comes after Wong's retirement. The bank's decision is part of the broader financial sector's shift in Singapore's innovation and startup ecosystem. Meanwhile, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expected to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is forecasted to slow, increasing pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Regulators need to step up, meet demand for ESG investments
summary: Regulators in Southeast Asia, particularly Singapore, need to step up their efforts to meet the growing demand for Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investments. While some countries have rules and regulations in place, more can be done to accelerate and increase these efforts. Industry observers say that companies must comply with ESG demands to retain value and attract investors, with ESG funds outperforming and attracting capital. Regulators can mandate standards for ESG metrics, encourage adoption of leading disclosure practices, and counteract risks of sustainability fraud.

site_title: Finger on people's financial Pulse
summary: Life insurer Prudential is launching wealth-centred features in its AI-powered mobile app, Pulse, to make financial planning easier. The new features include a chatbot named Ruby, which builds a customer's financial profile and offers personalized advice. Ruby also serves as the custodian of the Pulse digital wallet and offers rewards for engaging with financial topics. The move aims to motivate more people to be financially ready and make financial planning simpler, with a focus on millennials who are bracing themselves for a financial squeeze.

site_title: Coronavirus death toll in Italy tops 60,000
summary: Italy's COVID-19 death toll has surpassed 60,000, according to the country's health ministry. The milestone comes as the rate of infections stabilizes, allowing for eased restrictive measures in several regions. Italy, the first European country affected by the pandemic, has reported 60,078 deaths from 1,728,878 infections.

site_title: Companies with shaky finances join in US stock exuberance
summary: US stocks have rallied 4.3% over the past five days, driven by companies with shaky finances, the longest streak in 13 months. The weak-credit group is up 25% since October and poised for its best quarter of relative performance since 2009. Leverage is paying off in upcycles, with investors piling into riskiest companies despite deteriorating business fundamentals. The S&P 500 has also reached record highs, with all four major indexes closing at record highs for the first time since January 2018.

site_title: Pompeo brands Venezuela vote a 'fraud'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo denounced Venezuela's legislative elections as a "fraud and a sham" engineered by President Nicolas Maduro. Pompeo called the vote a "sham" in a tweet, while Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido has also boycotted the polls, labeling them a "fraud." The outcome would strengthen Maduro's grip and weaken Guaido, who is backed by the US.

site_title: Boxing: Mayweather to return for exhibition bout with YouTuber Logan Paul
summary: Floyd Mayweather, a 43-year-old undefeated boxer with a 50-0 record, announced on Instagram that he will return to the boxing ring for an exhibition bout against YouTube personality Logan Paul on February 20. This will be Mayweather's first fight since his professional win over Conor McGregor in 2017. Paul, who has a 0-1 record, lost to fellow YouTuber KSI in a previous exhibition match. The venue and details of the event have yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Singapore banks on watch over Chinese SOE exposure, say analysts
summary: Singapore banks are reviewing their exposure to Chinese state-owned enterprises (SOEs) amid a recent wave of high-profile defaults. DBS, the largest foreign creditor to Huachen Automotive Group, which defaulted on a 1 billion yuan (S$204.3 million) bond, may cut its exposure to Chinese SOEs. Analysts estimate that DBS's credit cost for Huachen's default could be S$150-S$180 million, with potential for Singapore banks to move to a blanket-cover downgrade on the credit profile of Chinese SOEs. However, most analysts believe that Chinese banks' size and economic importance will prevent a drastic reduction in exposure, with the Chinese government likely to intervene to maintain financial stability.

site_title: DBS wants a million retail customers invested and insured
summary: DBS aims to have 1 million retail customers insured and invested in the next few years, aiming to set an industry benchmark in digital financial planning. Currently, the bank has less than half a million customers invested and insured, but this number has increased by 20% year-over-year. The bank's NAV planner tool has seen 400,000 customers turn their finances around and over 8 in 10 new fund investing customers arrive through the platform. DBS is leveraging its wealth of consumer data to help customers "make sense" of their financial numbers and execute their plans.

site_title: AMTD aims to provide a 'one-stop' fintech solution for the region
summary: AMTD Group, a Hong Kong-based fintech firm, aims to provide a comprehensive, 360-degree solution for its clients in the region through its fintech arm, AMTD Digital. The firm has acquired several companies in Singapore, including Nexia TS and PolicyPal, and invested in five fintech companies. AMTD's goal is to create a one-stop digital solution, with plans to acquire more firms and merge them to achieve this objective. The firm's CEO, Calvin Choi, emphasizes the importance of talent acquisition and networking to drive growth in the fintech industry.

site_title: Workers' remittances in Asean drop in Q2
summary: Workers' remittances in the Asean region declined in Q2 2020, reversing the previous year's growth due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Research by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office found that earnings transfers to Cambodia, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines shrank year on year. The decline is attributed to job losses among migrant workers, posing a worrying sign for household incomes and local economies.

site_title: Singapore fintech proves resilient
summary: Singapore's fintech industry has proven resilient despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The industry saw a significant drop in funding to $883 million in Q1 2020, but the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) rolled out a $125 million support package to help fintechs recover. Investments have started recovering, with fintech investments reaching $462 million in the first half of 2020, up 19% from the same period in 2019. The industry is expected to continue growing, with the issuance of digital bank licenses set to drive further development.

site_title: Round-the-clock experience of fintech and innovation
summary: The Singapore FinTech Festival (SFF) and Singapore Week of Innovation & Technology (SWITCH) returned in a hybrid format, offering a 24-hour online platform and over 40 global satellite events. The event features over 240 hours of immersive content, masterclasses, and exclusive insights from over 800 global speakers. The hybrid model aims to boost sales cycles, foster cross-border partnerships, and generate investments, particularly in the post-Covid world.

site_title: Light at the end of tunnel from vaccine, stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks rose last week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average topping 30,000 for the first time ever, as a vaccine for Covid-19 appears to be within reach. Moderna expects to deliver 60 million vaccinations in the US by the end of the first quarter.
