The vaccine is expected to break the back of the pandemic, but Dr. Fauci warns of a potential "darkest hour" before recovery.

site_title: Britain gets ready for roll-out of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine this week
summary: Britain is set to become the first country to roll out the Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, initially making it available at hospitals before distributing to doctors' clinics. The rollout starts on Tuesday, prioritizing the over-80s, frontline healthcare workers, and care home staff and residents. The vaccine has been ordered for 40 million doses, enough to vaccinate 20 million people in the 67 million-strong population. The rollout coincides with Brexit negotiations, with the government having contingency plans in place to avoid disruptions.

site_title: Gold light brightens Christmas spirit in Venice
summary: Italian artist Fabrizio Plessi has created a festive Christmas display in Venice, using special lighting and projections to brighten up the city's landmarks. The display includes a golden tree in Saint Mark's Square and a "Golden Age" screen on the Rialto Bridge, which reflects yellow light onto the Grand Canal, creating a fantasy atmosphere. The event aims to bring comfort and culture to the city during the COVID-19 pandemic, with Plessi stating that "this Christmas is different, but I strongly believe in positivity." The display is a unique and creative way to celebrate the holiday season in Venice.

site_title: Regulator fines Bank of China over loss-making product
summary: The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission fined Bank of China 50.5 million yuan (S$10.3 million) for irregularities in a loss-making product linked to crude oil, citing irregular product management and risk management. The bank faces potential losses of up to six billion yuan for investors, and regulators have asked commercial banks to halt sales of wealth management products that could leave investors with unlimited losses. Bank of China has accepted the penalties and is considering compensating investors.

site_title: Singapore's digital economy due to bounce back
summary: Singapore's digital economy is expected to bounce back, driven by the resilience of online travel-related bookings. To stay on the path to profitability, businesses in the Internet economy must remain critical. A report by Temasek, Google, and Bain highlights the need for Singapore to diversify its digital economy and invest in emerging sectors.

site_title: Cheap platinum back in vogue as Chinese buyers tap cash hoards
summary: Platinum is experiencing a resurgence in demand, driven by Chinese buyers tapping into their cash hoards. The metal's relative value and competitiveness compared to gold are key factors, with prices rising 25% since November. Luxury watchmakers, including Omega, are seeing increased interest in platinum, with sales jumping 20% in the third quarter. The World Platinum Investment Council expects China's platinum jewellery consumption to rise 13% next year, marking the first increase since 2013.

site_title: Mastercard taps on tech to boost SME funding access, e-commerce needs
summary: Mastercard is launching new tech platforms to boost access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the region, addressing the limited financing options that hinder their growth. The pandemic has exacerbated the issue, with a growing need for digitalisation to stay afloat. Mastercard aims to connect 50 million small businesses and 25 million women entrepreneurs to the digital economy by 2025. The company is partnering with other firms to automate access to working capital finance and drive greater digital efficiency across the retail supply chain in Asia.

site_title: Credit Suisse's outgoing chairman signals bank may mull UBS merger
summary: Credit Suisse's outgoing chairman, Urs Rohner, suggests the bank may consider a merger with UBS, citing the benefits of a combined entity having more clout. Rohner's comments come after CEO Thomas Gottstein mentioned potential acquisitions, and UBS chairman Axel Weber previously rejected merger reports. A merger would face regulatory hurdles, but Rohner believes it's "not unreasonable" and would bring benefits. Rohner's comments come as European banks try to bulk up before cross-border consolidation takes hold, with domestic mergers heating up in countries like Spain and Italy.

site_title: Value with a vengeance: Investors bet Europe's rally has legs
summary: European value stocks are gaining momentum, with the MSCI Europe Value Index rising 23% since October 29, outperforming its growth counterpart by 14.6%. This trend is seen as a potential multi-year outperformance for value stocks, with some managers adding value to their portfolios. However, others express skepticism about the sustainability of the recovery, citing dependence on government actions and poor earnings visibility.

site_title: S. Korea clamps down as virus cases hit 9-month high
summary: South Korea imposes stricter social-distancing measures, including a ban on gatherings at high-risk venues and limiting restaurant hours, as the country faces its worst resurgence of COVID-19 cases in nine months. The measures, effective from Dec 8, include a ban on gatherings of more than 50 people, no spectators at sporting events, and a suspension of gatherings at karaoke bars. The government aims to curb the virus and restore ordinary life as early as possible.

site_title: Lights, camera, construction!
summary: New York City is emerging as a hub for television and film production, with many studios planning to expand or build new facilities in Queens and Brooklyn. Several soundstages, including Netflix's planned six-stage facility in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and Broadway Stages' 11-stage facility in Ditmars Steinway, Queens, are set to break ground in 2024. site_title: Securing Asian cities against cyber threats
summary: Singapore is poised to capitalize on the growing demand for cybersecurity solutions as cities worldwide transition into a more digital world. International companies such as Acronis and Group-IB have relocated their headquarters to Singapore, and the government is investing in training local cybersecurity talent and developing its startup ecosystem. With its smart city expertise, Singapore aims to become an Asian hub for cybersecurity technologies.

site_title: Kia to recall 295,000 US vehicles for engine fire risks
summary: Kia Motors is recalling 295,000 US vehicles due to engine fire risks. The affected models include 2012-2015 Sorento, Forte, and Optima Hybrid, as well as 2012-2015 Sportage. Dealers will inspect and repair the engine compartment, and Kia is developing a software update to address the issue. This recall comes after Kia and Hyundai agreed to a $210 million civil penalty for failing to recall 1.6 million vehicles in a timely manner. The companies also face additional fines for inaccurately reporting recall information.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 4-10, 2020, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Transatlantic C8 and Pacific C10 markets remained strong, with rates at $12,725 and $16,638, respectively. The Panamax market experienced tightness, with premium rates paid for quick Baltic coal trips. VLCC rates rose modestly, with time-charter equivalent earnings increasing by 45-50%. Suezmax and Aframax rates declined, while the MR market saw decent activity.

site_title: Indonesia names Cabinet minister as suspect in million-dollar graft case
summary: Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission named Social Affairs Minister Juliari Batubara as a suspect in a million-dollar bribery case, along with four others. This is the second time a Cabinet minister has been designated a suspect in a corruption case over the past few weeks. President Joko Widodo warned officials against misusing public funds. The designation is part of ongoing efforts to combat corruption in Indonesia, a country with a history of high-profile graft cases.

site_title: Toronto eyes tax on empty homes in bid for real estate revenue
summary: Toronto is proposing a tax on empty homes to generate revenue for affordable housing and free up rental housing in the city's tight market. The tax, which could bring in up to C$66 million, would target properties that are vacant and not being rented out. If adopted, it would be implemented in 2022 and would aim to address the issue of speculators driving up housing costs. The proposal comes amid concerns over the impact of non-resident foreign owners on the housing market.

site_title: UOB counts on omni-channel edge to fend off digital bank challenge
summary: UOB is banking on an omni-channel approach to compete with Singapore's upcoming digital banks, leveraging its digital capabilities and physical network to offer customers the best of both worlds. While customers are comfortable with digital engagement, they prefer a personal touch for big or long-term commitments. UOB's internal study found that customers are comfortable with digital engagement during awareness, consideration, and servicing stages, but prefer bankers' assistance during the purchasing stage. The bank has invested in transforming its physical touchpoints and using data to complement its online and offline integration, giving it an edge over digital banks.

site_title: Asia's payments market still poised for growth
summary: Asia's payments market is expected to experience a decline in revenue by 1-8% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but remains poised for long-term growth. Despite disruptions, the sector is expected to rebound rapidly, with growth rates potentially exceeding $1 trillion by 2022 or 2023. Key trends shaping the industry include the rise of contactless payments, increased adoption of digital solutions, and the emergence of new players, such as fintechs and "big techs."

site_title: Innovation at scale is critical: UOB
summary: UOB executive Susan Hwee emphasizes the importance of innovation at scale in the Asean region, where banks must compete in a diverse market. site_title: Oil from US-sanctioned producers becoming less taboo in Asia
summary: Asian oil importers, including India and China, are seeking a resumption of crude oil exports from US-sanctioned producers Iran and Venezuela under the Biden administration. site_title: JD.com becomes China's first online mall to test digital yuan
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest online retailer, will test the country's first virtual mall using digital yuan, a cryptocurrency backed by the central bank. The pilot program, launched by JD Digits, will allow customers to pay for certain items with digital yuan. Approximately 100,000 vouchers worth 20 million yuan will be issued to Suzhou city residents on December 11. This marks the latest step in China's efforts to bolster its digital currency and promote the development of the digital and real economies.

site_title: Why startups should embrace ESG factors
summary: Startups are increasingly considering Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors as essential drivers for success in today's markets. Ignoring ESG issues can lead to significant drops in revenue and investments, lawsuits, and loss of operating licenses. Businesses that prioritize ESG issues can stand out from competitors, attract top talent, and cultivate a devoted customer base. A strong ESG focus can also improve financial performance and reduce employee turnover. By identifying and reporting on relevant ESG factors, startups can demonstrate their commitment to sustainability and attract impact investors.

site_title: US dollar net shorts climb to highest level in five weeks
summary: US dollar net shorts rose to $25.74 billion, the highest level in five weeks, according to Reuters and Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. site_title: Keppel FELS terminates US$425m contract to build drilling rig
summary: Keppel FELS has terminated a $425 million contract with Awilco Drilling to build a mid-water drilling rig, citing Awilco's inability to make a second installment payment. Separately, Keppel announced a lock-up agreement for a proposed restructuring of Floatel, with the goal of creating a new company and avoiding further impairment.

site_title: Asia's fintech funding on the mend
summary: Asia's fintech funding has shown signs of recovery, with Singapore-based fintechs drawing in $167 million in Q3 2020, a 56% increase from the previous quarter. The Asia-Pacific region as a whole saw a 46% decrease in fintech fundraising from the same period last year, but a 8.7% increase in the third quarter alone. Investors remain open to new opportunities, particularly in payments and early-stage fintechs, with 15 out of 23 large funding rounds still having new investor participation.

site_title: Digital challenger banks offer promise of inclusion
summary: Digital challenger banks in South-east Asia aim to provide financial inclusion to the underbanked and unbanked population, particularly in developing markets. With the region projected to reach a GDP of $4.3 trillion by 2030, these banks have a significant opportunity to disrupt the traditional banking sector. To succeed, they must prioritize customer needs, leverage modern technology stacks, and tap into existing ecosystems to provide seamless financial services, thereby granting access to millions of underbanked individuals.

images.alt_text: About 68 per cent of adults in Vietnam, and 65 per cent in the Philippines, are unbanked. South-east Asia thus offers a compelling market for new banking entrants.

site_title: Ki Residences sells 22% of units in virtual launch
summary: Ki Residences at Brookvale, a 12-storey condominium in Singapore, sold 143 out of 660 units at an average price of S$1,790 psf through a virtual launch, with 60% of luxury collection units sold. Prices started from S$1,668 psf, with units ranging from 1,245 to 2,239 sq ft. The developers reported strong support from buyers, including investors and owner-occupiers, seeking a well-designed and reasonably priced 999-year leasehold luxury product.

site_title: Has the ECB made the wealth gap wider?
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is accused of exacerbating the wealth gap in the eurozone through its ultra-loose monetary policies, including quantitative easing. By lowering interest rates and buying debt, the ECB has benefited shareholders and wealthy individuals, while modest households have seen limited gains. While the ECB's policies may have reduced unemployment among the bottom 20% of wage earners, the impact on inequality remains uncertain. The bank's policies have also negatively affected thrifty households, with low interest rates leading to a decline in savings values.

site_title: ECB to beef up stimulus as second virus wave bites
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to increase its stimulus package in response to the resurgence of the COVID-19 virus, which is expected to impact the economy. The move aims to support growth and mitigate the effects of the second virus wave. No specific details on the amount of the stimulus are provided, but the decision reflects the ECB's efforts to address the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Boeing mulls equity sale, plans new cut to Dreamliner output
summary: Boeing is considering an equity sale and reducing its production of the 787 Dreamliner to five planes per month by mid-2021, amid a soaring debt burden of $61 billion. The company's debt increased by $30 billion earlier this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Boeing is also prepared to speed up deliveries of the 450 737 Max planes it built but couldn't deliver during the grounding, with a potential value of $87 billion in inventory. The company aims to reduce debt and invest in the business, but the financial impact of the pandemic is expected to be volatile.

site_title: Last-ditch push to Brexit deal starts with recriminations flying
summary: UK and EU negotiators resume Brexit talks amid recriminations, with significant differences remaining on key issues such as the level playing field for businesses, fisheries, and governance. The talks, which had broken down previously, are seen as the last-ditch effort to reach a deal before the UK's departure from the European single market and customs union on December 31. A deal is crucial to avoid tariffs and quotas, and relations between the UK and EU could be poisoned for a generation if one is not reached.

site_title: Pandemic hits tiny Moldova's hopes for wine tourism boom
summary: Moldova's wine tourism industry has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with wine sales and tourism plummeting by 10-30% and 78% respectively. The country's wine industry, which has been a bright spot for the economy, has struggled to recover. Major wine resorts, such as Cricova and Castel Mimi, have been forced to find creative ways to stay afloat, including producing spirits and offering alternative experiences. Despite the challenges, officials are optimistic that the industry will recover quickly once borders reopen.

images.alt_text: The Cricova winery (above) used to receive up to 450 visitors a day, but now gets only a handful of guests.
A cat has the run of the place at the Castel Mimi Wine Resort (above), which has lost 70 per cent of its tourist flow.

site_title: Will DBS hit psychological S$30 high again?
summary: DBS Bank's share price has experienced a series of ups and downs since 2018, with a strong intermediate five-wave impulse move from 2016 to 2018. However, the bullish optimism was short-lived, and the price fell below the psychological S$30 mark after a bearish reversal. The bank's recent recovery has raised questions about the prospect of a triple zig-zag formation, with some analysts suggesting that DBS may be in a corrective phase. To confirm the next move, prices need to clear resistance hurdles and reach beyond 161.8% expansion levels, with a potential price target of S$27.50 to S$28.50.

site_title: Virtue out of adversity
summary: The Singapore FinTech Festival, initially hindered by Covid-19, successfully transitioned to a virtual format, attracting top speakers and innovators, including Bill Gates and Jane Fraser, the first woman to run a major US bank. The festival showcases the potential of digital platforms to transcend borders and drive innovation. The Singapore fintech sector has seen a surge in investments, with S$1.2 billion in the first 10 months of 2020, and financial institutions plan to create 1,800 new jobs, including tech-related positions. The festival highlights the need for global collaboration to address challenges such as climate change.

site_title: Plan to tweak VCC framework to draw more single family offices
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering tweaking the variable capital company (VCC) framework to attract more single family offices (SFOs) to register and manage VCCs in Singapore. The proposed changes would relax the requirement for "permissible fund managers" subject to certain conditions, allowing SFOs to manage VCCs. This move aims to provide tax benefits, access to Singapore's double-tax treaty network, and cost efficiencies through a single board of directors and common service providers. If approved, the enhancements could attract more SFOs to set up a presence in Singapore, potentially leading to a growth in total assets under management by SFOs to around US$20 billion.

site_title: Dispute at Opec puts UAE's ambitions on display
summary: The UAE's state oil company plans to spend $122 billion to boost production capacity, potentially straining its relationship with Saudi Arabia and Opec. The UAE's ambitious plans to maximize energy wealth may lead to ongoing tension with its neighbor, as they have diverged in recent months on various issues, including the war in Yemen and foreign policy. The Opec meeting reached a compromise, but the UAE's desire for more influence and a better quota within the group may continue to be a point of contention.

site_title: Lufthansa seen shedding 29,000 staff by year end; 10,000 German jobs in 2021
summary: Lufthansa is expected to shed 29,000 staff by the end of 2020 and another 10,000 jobs in Germany in 2021 due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on air travel. The airline has also reduced its schedules, fleet, and staff across its subsidiaries, with air travel not expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels until 2025.

site_title: Singapore law firm Oon & Bazul makes rare appointment of non-lawyer as equity partner
summary: Singapore law firm Oon & Bazul has made a rare appointment, promoting its business development head, Abdul Malik Anwar Deen, as an equity partner. The 45-year-old, who has been at the firm for over three years, is the fifth equity partner at Oon & Bazul. The appointment is seen as a progressive move, recognizing the value of non-legal professionals in driving a law firm's growth and profitability. The firm's managing partner believes that involving non-lawyers at the ownership table will send a signal to lawyers that their ideas are taken seriously, and will also free up senior lawyers to focus on matters of law.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Australian unit of The Hour Glass has acquired a four-storey retail and commercial office building at 139 Collins Street in Melbourne for a freehold property. The building, occupying 563 square metres, has a basement carpark. The seller is Jarema, and the acquisition was announced in a bourse filing.

site_title: Singapore opens up to make finance accessible
summary: Singapore has unveiled plans to make finance more accessible through technology, aiming to fill underserved gaps in the market. The country has granted digital banking licenses to Grab-Singtel and Sea, and Ant Group, as well as a consortium of Chinese companies. The goal is to empower individuals to take charge of their financial health through digital planning tools, nudging those on the lower income ladder to save and manage their finances more effectively. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is also introducing a common gateway for application programming interfaces to provide a seamless view of assets and liabilities, and is opening up access to payment rails for non-bank financial institutions.

site_title: The Hour Glass unit to buy Melbourne office building for A$68 million
summary: THE Hour Glass unit has agreed to purchase a Melbourne office building for A$68 million. The four-storey building, with a basement carpark, spans 563 sq m and features 2,494 sq m of gross lettable area. The acquisition will complement the company's regional commercial properties, funded by internal resources and bank borrowings. The transaction is subject to Foreign Investment Review Board approval.

site_title: Business leaders see innovation as a 'must': Microsoft study
summary: A Microsoft study across 15 Asia-Pacific markets found that 74% of business decision-makers now see innovation as a "must" for performance and resilience, up 11% from the previous year. The study attributed this shift to the Covid-19 pandemic, which drove organisations to adapt and innovate to ensure business continuity. Financial institutions, however, showed a lower proportion of organisations recognising innovation as a "must," with the proportion of mature organisations increasing by over 40% during the study period. Experts cited adopting a customer-centric mission, a healthy risk appetite, and leveraging data analytics and AI as key to innovating effectively.

site_title: Ki Residences sells 22% of units at S$1,790 psf
summary: KI Residences at Brookvale, a 12-storey condominium in District 21, Singapore, sold 143 out of 660 units at an average price of S$1,790 psf, with prices starting from S$1,668 psf. The development received strong support from buyers, including investors and owner-occupiers, with 60% of luxury collection units sold. The sales gallery remains open for viewers by appointment or through appointed agents.

site_title: Japan mulls limited resumption of inbound tourism from spring: Asahi
summary: Japan's government is considering a limited resumption of inbound tourism from spring, with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's administration focusing on allowing small tour groups from Asian countries with low coronavirus infections. Tourists would need to test negative, submit travel itineraries, and follow strict health protocols, including daily updates and tracing app use. The move aims to boost domestic tourism, which has been impacted by the third wave of coronavirus infections in Japan, and follows progress in rolling out coronavirus vaccines.

site_title: Alita Resources creditor Austroid Corp appoints administrator for restructuring
summary: Austroid Corp, a secured creditor of Alita Resources, has appointed a voluntary administrator to potentially restructure the Catalist-listed firm. Administrator Robert Kirman is assessing the group's position for a restructure or recapitalization. Alita, which defaulted on a $40 million loan due to a lithium price collapse, had its trading suspended since August last year. The company had previously obtained the Singapore Exchange Regco's nod for a proposed delisting. A further update on operations and the recapitalization process will be released in due course.

site_title: Technology: The common factor between sustainability and finance
summary: Financial institutions in South-east Asia can leverage technology to promote convergence of green finance standards and reduce asymmetric information, supporting the growth of sustainable investments. The region has seen increased interest in sustainability despite the COVID-19 pandemic, presenting opportunities for institutions to accelerate the transition to a more sustainable economy. New regulations and initiatives, such as the Green Investment Programme in Singapore, aim to drive green finance growth, with the goal of building trust with stakeholders. However, the region still lags behind others in terms of green finance issuance, contributing only 3% of global totals.

site_title: Digitalisation and tech here to stay
summary: Businesses worldwide have adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic, with key changes including the shift to remote work, digitalization, and increased focus on sustainability and responsible investing. Experts note that the pandemic has accelerated the adoption of flexible practices, such as work-from-home, and has led to a fundamental shift in the way businesses think about trust, relationships, and work arrangements. As companies move forward, they are prioritizing digital transformation, employee well-being, and adaptability to navigate the new normal.

site_title: Boys' Brigade Share-A-Gift 2020 urgently appeals for donations
summary: The Boys' Brigade Share-A-Gift 2020 is urgently appealing for donations to support 41,423 beneficiaries, but has only achieved 8% of its target at the halfway point. The charity project, launched on November 18, aims to provide support to those in need amid the pandemic. Due to COVID-19 measures, the project is now accepting only cash donations via online platforms, and not every beneficiary will receive the signature food hampers. The deadline to donate is unclear, as the project has crossed its halfway point and is now relying on public contributions to meet its target.

site_title: Wireless comms firm Whizpace secures 6m yuan for China expansion
summary: Whizpace, a Singapore-based wireless communications firm, has secured 6 million yuan (S$1.2 million) for its Chinese expansion. The funds come from a Suzhou government grant and a Chinese angel investor. Whizpace's subsidiary, Whizpace (Suzhou) Co, will use the funds to accelerate its team and business expansion. The company's TV White Space "Super Wi-Fi" solution, which can save network deployments by up to 90%, is seen as an opportunity to capture the Chinese market.

site_title: Malaysia's EPF increases Riverstone stake to 7%
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has increased its stake in Singapore-listed Riverstone Holdings to 7.02%, surpassing the 7% threshold. The EPF had previously reported a 6.00% stake in October. Riverstone Holdings' executive chairman and CEO Wong Teek Son acquired 100,000 shares between Dec 1 and 2, increasing his total interest to 51.14%. The company's expansion plans, including phase 6, are on track to raise production capacity by 1.5 billion pieces annually.

site_title: Five new coronavirus cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Five new coronavirus cases were reported in Singapore on Sunday, all of which were imported and had been placed on stay-home notice. The total number of cases now stands at 58,260. There were 13 new cases on Saturday, with one locally transmitted case and 12 imported cases. No new community cases were reported. Hospitalized patients remain at 26, while 42 are recovering in community facilities.

site_title: TikTok sale deadline on hold as talks with US continue
summary: The Trump administration's deadline for TikTok's US asset sale has been extended indefinitely as talks with the Chinese company continue. Despite multiple extensions, a final deal has yet to be reached, and the US Treasury Department has stated that no fine or punishment will be imposed for missing the deadline. The administration is eager to complete the sale before President-elect Joe Biden takes office on January 20, but the deal remains stuck in limbo. TikTok has proposed a plan to sell part of the app to American companies, but China's blessing is still required.

site_title: China completes its first-ever docking in lunar orbit
summary: China successfully completed its first-ever docking in lunar orbit as part of the Chang'e-5 mission, bringing back lunar samples after four decades. The cargo capsule carrying samples lifted off from the lunar surface on Thursday and docked with the orbiter on Sunday, marking a space first for the nation. This achievement marks China's progress in catching up with the US and Russia, and scientists hope the samples will help them learn more about the Moon's origins and volcanic activity. China will become the third country to have retrieved samples from the Moon if the return journey is successful.

site_title: Keppel unit enters lock-up agreement for Floatel restructuring
summary: Keppel's unit FELS Offshore has entered a lock-up agreement to facilitate the restructuring of offshore vessel player Floatel. The agreement, involving 1L bondholders and Keppel, aims to acquire certain Floatel subsidiaries and restructure debt obligations. The move is expected to result in a new entity acquiring Floatel's vessels and assuming debt, with Keppel holding 49.92% of the new company's equity. The restructuring is expected to have no significant impact on Keppel's carrying value of Floatel.

site_title: Austrian ex-finance minister gets eight years in jail for corruption
summary: Austrian ex-finance minister Karl-Heinz Grasser was sentenced to eight years in prison for corruption, becoming the country's biggest corruption trial since World War II. He was found guilty of abuse of power and involvement in 9.6 million euros in kickbacks related to the sale of state-owned apartments. A co-defendant admitted passing on insider information, enabling a consortium to buy 60,000 flats for 961 million euros. Grasser and his co-defendants will appeal the verdict.

site_title: Keppel FELS terminates US$425m contract with Awilco Drilling unit
summary: Keppel FELS has terminated a $425 million contract with Awilco Drilling to build a mid-water drilling rig due to the Awilco unit's inability to make its second instalment payment by March 2021. This marks the second instance of a contract between Keppel FELS and Awilco being terminated, with the first contract also worth $425 million axed in June. Keppel FELS is seeking to retain $43 million paid by Awilco and reimbursement of its costs, and does not expect any reversal of revenue recognized in respect of the contract.

site_title: Beatles survivors Macca and Ringo still making music
summary: Paul McCartney, 78, and Ringo Starr, 80, are still making music, decades after the Beatles disbanded. McCartney is set to release his 18th solo album, McCartney III, on December 18, where he wrote, recorded, and played every instrument. Ringo will tour with his All Starr Band, featuring greats like Joe Walsh and Steve Lukather, in June 2021. Both musicians continue to defy age, with McCartney citing "making music for yourself" as a driving force behind his creative output. Their continued success has been hailed as a testament to their enduring talent and dedication to their craft.

site_title: iFast maintains digibank ambitions despite failed wholesale licence bid in Singapore
summary: iFast Corp plans to continue pursuing a digital banking licence despite failing to secure a digital wholesale bank (DWB) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). MAS awarded licences to Sea, Grab-Singtel, Ant Group, and a Greenland Financial consortium. iFast remains committed to obtaining a digital bank licence, including in other jurisdictions, and will focus on improving its fintech ecosystem and consumer, enterprise, and fintech solutions.

site_title: Lufthansa will have shed 29,000 staff by year end: Bild am Sonntag
summary: Lufthansa plans to shed 29,000 staff by year's end, with 20,000 cuts outside Germany and 10,000 in Germany next year. The airline has already burned through $4.85 billion of its $9 billion government bailout and has 27,000 too many full-time equivalent staff. A deal to cut costs and save jobs has won the support of a majority of Verdi trade union members, who work for the German airline as ground staff. Lufthansa expects air travel not to recover to pre-pandemic levels before 2025.

site_title: Kia recalls 295,000 US vehicles for fire risks
summary: Kia Motors is recalling 295,000 US vehicles due to engine fire risks, citing a risk of fires while driving. The affected models include 2012-2013 Sorento, 2012-2015 Forte and Forte Koup, 2011-2013 Optima Hybrid, 2014-2015 Soul, and 2012 Sportage. Dealers will inspect and make repairs as necessary. This recall follows a previous agreement with Hyundai Motor to pay a record $210 million civil penalty for failing to recall vehicles in a timely manner, with Kia facing a $70 million penalty.

site_title: Three generations, one roof: US trend amplified in pandemic
summary: In the US, a growing trend of multigenerational households, where three or more generations live together under one roof, has been amplified by the COVID-19 pandemic. According to Pew Research Center, one in five people now live in such households, a rise that began in the 1980s and accelerated with the Great Recession in 2009. This trend allows young adults to maintain financial stability while raising children and caring for elderly relatives, with many opting to stay with their parents until their children become financially independent.

images.alt_text: The phenomenon has been on the rise since the 1980s, when immigrant families arriving from Asia and Latin America tended to reside in households that ran the gamut in the age of residents.

site_title: Online education firm Coursera is said to weigh 2021 IPO
summary: Coursera, an online education firm, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in 2021, potentially valuing the company at around $5 billion. The company is in talks with potential underwriters and has raised $130 million at a valuation of $2.6 billion. Founded by Daphne Koller and Andrew Ng, Coursera partners with over 200 universities to offer courses, certifications, and degree programs. No final decision has been made, and Coursera could remain private. This move comes as online education booms amid the pandemic.

site_title: MindChamps unit to sell preschool for S$800,000 to Yirong Education
summary: MindChamps PreSchool Singapore has agreed to sell its preschool, MindChamps UPT, to Yirong Education for S$800,000 in cash. The sale price is above the preschool's book value and net tangible assets value. The transaction is expected to have a positive impact on MindChamps' financial results for the year ending December 2021. The sale is part of MindChamps' strategy to optimize its portfolio and generate returns for shareholders.

site_title: Glencore's billionaire boss picks his look-a-like replacement
summary: Glencore, the world's largest commodity trader, has named Gary Nagle as its new CEO, succeeding billionaire Ivan Glasenberg who will retire in 2021. Nagle, also South African, shares similarities with Glasenberg in his background and career. The transition will take six months, during which Nagle will work closely with Glasenberg to address investor concerns about the coal business, corruption probes, and a declining share price. Glasenberg will remain a significant shareholder and custodian of his shareholding.

site_title: Trump keeps up baseless fraud claims at rally for US senators in Georgia
summary: US President Donald Trump attended a rally in Georgia to support Republican senators in the state's January runoff elections. Trump reiterated his claims of widespread voter fraud in the 2020 presidential election, despite being rejected by state and federal officials. He also pressured Georgia Governor Brian Kemp to take further steps to help him overturn the election results. Trump's appearance raised concerns among some Republicans that it could turn off voters or make them feel that voting is pointless. The runoff elections will determine which party controls the US Senate, with Democrats needing to win both seats to control the chamber.

site_title: Razer to push youth bank, undeterred by failure of Singapore bid
summary: Razer will proceed with its digital banking plan, Razer Youth Bank, targeting millennials in Malaysia and the Philippines, despite failing to secure a Singapore licence. CEO Lee Li Meng stated that other markets, such as Europe, the Middle East, or Latin America, may be considered if regulators are supportive. The Singapore government recently awarded two digital full-bank licences to a Grab Holdings-Singapore Telecommunications venture and Sea Ltd.

site_title: Opec wrangle puts UAE's ambitions on display
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has sparked tension within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) by announcing plans to boost production capacity to five million barrels a day, despite a current quota of 2.6 million barrels. The move, which could lead to a showdown with Saudi Arabia, is part of the UAE's efforts to maximize energy wealth and establish its Murban crude as a regional benchmark. The UAE's ambitions play into a wider shift in the dynamic between Abu Dhabi Crown Prince Sheikh Mohammed Bin Zayed and Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who have diverged in recent months on various issues.

site_title: Even billionaire investors are buying Bitcoin. Should you?
summary: Billionaire investors, including Mike Novogratz, are buying Bitcoin amid its recent surge in value. The cryptocurrency has been gaining popularity, with new investors including celebrities like Snoop Dogg and Ashton Kutcher. Financial advisers recommend Bitcoin as a potential long-term investment, particularly for younger investors, but warn against putting emergency savings into it. The cryptocurrency's volatility and lack of transparency are concerns, with some experts comparing it to "fools' gold." Despite these risks, some see Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation and a potential way to boost returns in a low-rate environment.

site_title: Indonesia names second cabinet minister as suspect in a graft case
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency has named Social Affairs Minister Juliari Batubara as a suspect in a million-dollar bribery case, along with four others, over the procurement of Covid-19 social assistance packages. This is the second cabinet minister to be designated a suspect by the Corruption Eradication Commission in recent weeks. President Joko Widodo warned officials against misuse of public funds, stating he will not protect those involved in corruption. The ministry has agreed to cooperate with the investigation, and Batubara will be taken into custody.

site_title: Grab-Singtel group puts cybersecurity at top of digital bank agenda
summary: Grab and Singtel's consortium is prioritizing cybersecurity for their digital bank, following a fine for data breach in July. The bank will also focus on data governance and building a robust infrastructure, hiring around 200 staff in Singapore by the end of next year. Cybersecurity will be a top priority, with high safety standards expected by regulators, and the bank will serve consumers and small businesses, targeting young professionals and gig workers. The digital bank aims to complement Grab and Singtel's ecosystems, with no fees derived from its products distributed on Grab's platform.

site_title: Pfizer seeks emergency approval for Covid-19 vaccine in India, media say
summary: Pfizer has applied for emergency use authorization of its COVID-19 vaccine in India, according to media reports. The US company's vaccine requires storage at -70°C, which is a challenge for most Indian cold storages. India is pinning hopes on locally tested vaccines instead, with nearly 9.57 million COVID-19 cases reported. The application was made despite concerns about the vaccine's storage requirements and India's reliance on locally developed vaccines.

site_title: Perennial consortium to acquire former Big Box in Jurong East for S$118m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings is set to acquire the former Big Box property in Jurong East for S$118 million, with plans to redevelop the site into a business park, Perennial Business City. The redevelopment will increase the property's gross floor area to 1.5 million square feet and feature large floor plates, ample car parking, and a rooftop garden. The transaction is part of Perennial's foray into the asset class and is expected to be completed by mid-February 2021.

site_title: South Korea reports 583 coronavirus cases, off nine-month high
summary: South Korea reported 583 new coronavirus cases, the lowest daily increase since a nine-month high, largely in the capital Seoul and surrounding regions. The country has 36,915 infections and 540 deaths. To combat the surge, Seoul imposed unprecedented curfews and reduced public transportation in the evenings. The government is considering tightening restrictions, including closing karaoke bars and limiting religious gatherings. The situation is critical, with only 59 available sickbeds for severe cases, which may run out in less than two weeks.

site_title: Coal mine accident in China's Chongqing kills 18
summary: A coal mine accident in China's Chongqing city killed 18 people, with 24 trapped underground due to excessive carbon monoxide gas. The incident occurred at the Diaoshuidong coal mine, which was shut for over two months. This is the region's second such accident in two months, following a fatal incident at the Songzao coal mine in September. The mine has a history of safety issues, including a 2013 hydrogen sulphide poisoning incident that killed three people. An investigation is underway.

site_title: US ends exchange programmes with China, calling them 'propaganda'
summary: The US State Department has ended five cultural exchange programs with China, labeling them "soft power propaganda tools." The programs, funded under the 1961 Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act, were operated entirely by the Chinese government. The decision was made due to their perceived propaganda nature, differing from other MECEA-funded programs that are mutually beneficial. The US has terminated the Policymakers Educational China Trip Program, the US-China Friendship Program, the US-China Leadership Exchange Program, the US-China Transpacific Exchange Program, and the Hong Kong Educational and Cultural Program.

site_title: Joe Biden says jobs report is 'grim', warns of 'dark winter' as Covid-19 rages
summary: President-elect Joe Biden described the US jobs report as "grim," warning that the economic recovery is stalling due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. He urged Congress to pass a $908 billion coronavirus relief bill immediately to alleviate the pain. Biden also announced plans to name Jeff Zients as his coronavirus "czar" and Janet Yellen as Treasury secretary. The president-elect faces pressure to make ethnically diverse picks for his administration, particularly for the remaining slots, as he prepares to take office in January.

site_title: SIA readies seven Boeing freighters for vaccines transportation, with passenger jets on standby
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) is preparing to transport coronavirus vaccines using its seven Boeing 747-400 freighters, with passenger jets on standby for increased capacity. The carrier has a dedicated task force and has inked master-leasing deals with cold chain container providers to ensure sufficient temperature-controlled containers. SIA will track shipments using devices on board and a 24/7 cargo hub operations team. The airline has also expanded its cold chain service network to include Brisbane and Melbourne, with a history of transporting 22,000 tonnes of pharmaceutical shipments last financial year.

site_title: Yangzijiang undervalued, set to bottom out, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to a "conviction buy" due to its undervalued shares, trading at a 0.5 time price-to-book value. The company boasts superior financials, including an 8% return on equity and a sustainable dividend yield. Analyst Ho Pei Hwa attributed the underperformance to overhang and selling pressure resulting from MSCI deletion. The research note concludes that YZJ is set to bottom out, presenting a buying opportunity.

site_title: Japan retrieves space probe that may hold clues to origin of planets
summary: Japan has retrieved a space probe capsule from Australia's outback after a six-year mission to gather samples from an asteroid. The Hayabusa2 probe, launched in 2014, collected dust from the asteroid Ryugu and returned to Earth in 2019. The capsule, carrying extensive samples, was flown by helicopter to a domestic research facility in Japan. The samples may hold clues to the origins of the planets and the origins of life on Earth, including organic matter that could have contributed to life. The successful retrieval is a significant milestone in the mission.

site_title: UK, EU call in leaders to save trade talks
summary: UK and EU leaders are set to discuss trade talks, paused due to disagreements on fisheries, fair competition guarantees, and future disputes, with less than four weeks before Britain completes its Brexit journey. Negotiators have agreed to brief their principals on the state of play, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen to speak on Saturday. The talks, which have stalled since Thursday, center on French demands over fishing rights in British waters, and a no-deal exit is seen as a nightmare scenario for businesses and investors.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq all end at records, extending rally
summary: US stocks reached fresh records, extending a post-election rally, despite disappointing US jobs data showing a stalled jobs recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all finished the week at all-time highs. Analysts believe the weak jobs data supports the need for a new fiscal stimulus package, with President-elect Joe Biden urging Congress to act immediately. Despite soaring coronavirus cases, investors are optimistic about vaccine approvals and an economic recovery in 2021.

site_title: US sets new record of 225,000 Covid cases in one day
summary: The US recorded a new record of 225,201 Covid-19 cases in 24 hours, according to Johns Hopkins University, for the second consecutive day. Additionally, 2,506 Covid-related deaths were reported in the same period. This marks a dramatic resurgence in the US epidemic in recent weeks, with the country now leading the world in both cases and deaths.

site_title: Gold recovers after breaking US$1,800; weaker greenback negates vaccine optimism
summary: Gold prices rebounded above the US$1,800 psychological trading level this week, driven by a weaker US dollar and concerns over the global economy's recovery from surging Covid-19 infections. Despite vaccine development progress, the market's safe-haven demand remained dampened. Investors should look out for the potential long-term benefits of a weaker US dollar, with major banks predicting a weaker greenback. However, gold's technical picture remains weak, and a strong close above US$1,850 is needed to confirm a long-term recovery.

site_title: The smart watch: telemetry for humans?
summary: A smartwatch, like the latest Apple watch, is being developed to measure oxygen levels and electrocardiograms, potentially paving the way for it to become a telemetry device for humans. The device may also measure blood sugar levels, similar to the Abbott Libre device, which tracks blood glucose continuously without finger pricks. Research has shown that individual sugar responses to food are unique, and correcting these patterns can lead to improved health outcomes, including weight loss and reduced fatigue. Continuous glucose monitoring devices have been shown to impact heart attacks, strokes, and mortality in diabetic patients, and non-invasive blood glucose monitoring is being developed, potentially revolutionizing the fight against diabetes and other health problems.

site_title: Oil rises, hovers below US$50 a barrel on hopes for US stimulus
summary: Oil prices rose 1.11% to $49.25 a barrel, hovering below $50, on expectations of a US economic stimulus package and a potential COVID-19 vaccine. A bipartisan $908 billion aid plan gained momentum in the US Congress, outweighing rising supply and increased COVID-19 deaths. OPEC+ agreed to increase oil output slightly from January, but continue existing supply curbs, reducing production by 7.2 million barrels per day.

site_title: San Francisco mayor orders strict new lockdowns as pandemic spirals
summary: San Francisco Mayor London Breed has ordered strict new lockdowns and business restrictions across the Bay Area in response to the COVID-19 surge. The measures, which include closing all personal services, outdoor dining, and most public gatherings, are among the harshest of any major US city. Breed cited the rapid spread of the virus, saying "what we are seeing in our city, our region, our state and our country is a virus that is taking over." The lockdowns apply across five Bay Area counties, with the goal of reducing transmission and containing the outbreak.

images.alt_text: The mayor of San Francisco on Friday ordered new lockdowns and business restrictions across the Bay Area in the face of the Covid-19 surge, as political leaders nationwide ramp up pressure on Americans to stay home until vaccines can be distributed.

site_title: US dollar edges higher as Brexit talks pause, but posts worst week in a month
summary: The US dollar edged higher on Friday, rising 0.1% to a 2-1/2-year high of $90.725, amid paused Brexit talks between the EU and Britain. This pause weighed on sterling, which fell 0.2% against the dollar, while the euro and Swiss franc rose to their highest levels in a month. The US dollar's gain was largely due to investors' focus on riskier currencies, despite a weaker-than-expected US employment report.

site_title: Brown is the new green
summary: Investors are shifting from blunt exclusions and integration strategies to more sophisticated approaches in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing. As motivations behind ESG investing evolve, effectiveness is becoming more important, with public asset owners drawn to ESG by superior risk-adjusted returns. The increasing availability of detailed ESG data and emerging disclosures regulations will enable investors to better measure and tie capital to specific indicators and behaviors. This shift is expected to impact market dynamics, with "dirty" industries potentially becoming the most sought-after targets in capital markets.

images.alt_text: An oil and gas processing plant in Lake Charles, Louisiana. Investors focused on environmental, social and governance factors have much to gain from steering corporate shifts to more effective lower-carbon strategies.

site_title: Gold eases but on track for first weekly gain in four weeks
summary: Gold fell 0.3% to $1,834.92 per ounce, but is on track for a weekly gain of 2.6% as investors book profits and equities rally. Bets for US stimulus keep gold as an inflation hedge, despite a weak US payrolls report. The US economy added fewest workers in six months, cementing expectations of fiscal stimulus. Gold prices are also influenced by a weaker US dollar, negative real rates, and concerns surrounding inflation.

site_title: Have Covid-19 passport, will travel
summary: Covid-19 passports are being proposed as a standardized travel and health protocol, requiring proof of vaccination for international passengers. This move aims to establish "relatively safe corridors" for vaccinated travelers, similar to Hong Kong and Singapore's successful "corridors" that have curbed coronavirus cases. However, concerns over data security, privacy, and ethics must be addressed, as the technology poses significant technical and vulnerability risks, including potential hacking and exposure of sensitive information.

images.alt_text: Securing passenger data is the key challenge for airlines as they consider Covid-19 passports that will exchange digital handshakes with a range of other devices.

site_title: Thai central bank says GDP could underperform next year
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Sethaput Suthiwart-Narueput said the country's GDP may underperform next year due to weak tourism. Despite a stronger-than-expected third-quarter GDP, the central bank still forecasts 3.6% growth for next year, with a 6% contraction expected this year. The central bank will review its forecast on December 23 and may revise its prediction if third-quarter GDP numbers are revised. Monetary policy will remain accommodative and focused on growth, while fiscal stimulus will remain in place until mid-next year.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on oil gains, stimulus hopes
summary: European shares rose on Friday, with the FTSE 100 reaching nine-month highs, driven by gains in oil stocks and hopes for US fiscal stimulus. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6%, while Germany's DAX climbed 0.4%. Disappointing US jobs data strengthened stimulus hopes, and progress on a post-Brexit trade deal remains uncertain. The European Central Bank is expected to keep policy rates on hold but increase bond-buying at its meeting on Thursday.

site_title: iFast not aware of digital banking licence outcome when SGX queried trading activity
summary: IFast Corporation stated it was unaware of the digital banking licence outcome until after a query by SGX, and the company later revealed it did not secure the licence. The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced the licence denial after trading hours.

site_title: Buying Bitcoin: The basics
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Bitcoin can be bought with various payment methods, including bank accounts and debit/credit cards, through reputable exchanges. To buy, an individual must create an account, verify their identity, and transfer the cryptocurrency to a personal wallet. Bitcoin can be divided into small fractions, and its price can fluctuate. Some vendors accept Bitcoin as payment, but it's primarily used as an investment or store of value. Bitcoin funds are available to qualified investors, but are not suitable for most people due to high minimum investment requirements. Bitcoin derivatives have also come under scrutiny due to regulatory issues.

site_title: US mortgage rates hit record low for 14th time this year
summary: US mortgage rates reached a record low of 2.71% for the 14th time this year, according to Freddie Mac. This drop is the lowest in data since 1971 and is attributed to the Federal Reserve's plan to hold its benchmark rate near zero. While the low mortgage rates have fueled a homebuying boom, a tight supply of homes has driven up prices, limiting sales growth. This has led to a slowdown in the housing market, with a measure of contracts to buy previously owned homes falling for a second straight month in October.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SATS raises its multi-currency medium-term note (MTN) programme to S$2 billion, allowing potential access to bond markets for future growth investments. GLH's hotel division has been served £1.9 million in rent arrears by UK landlord Topland Group Holdings. Sincap Group extends repayment deadline for US$6 million to April 2021.

site_title: Biden says he'll take vaccine, wants it to be free for Americans
summary: President-elect Joe Biden says he'll take a coronavirus vaccine to demonstrate its safety and ensure it's free for Americans. Biden aims to rebuild trust in science, blaming President Trump's administration for fueling vaccine skepticism. Vice President Mike Pence also assured the public that the fast-track vaccine development process didn't compromise safety standards. A vaccine could be approved this month, with deliveries starting as early as December 14. Several high-profile figures, including former Presidents Obama, Bush, and Clinton, have also expressed their intention to take the vaccine.

site_title: Acquisition growth to continue for industrial S-Reits in 2021
summary: DBS Group Research expects Singapore industrial Reits to deliver 5% growth distributions in 2021, driven by acquisitions worth over S$5 billion. Analysts Dale Lai and Derek Tan name Mapletree Logistics Trust, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, and Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust as top picks. However, the excess supply of industrial space may temper organic rental growth potential in 2021, with most landlords focusing on tenant retention. The researchers also highlight potential demand for logistics and business parks driven by Singapore's vaccine distribution and high-tech industries, with logistics-focused players expected to be the most leveraged.

site_title: Keppel raises US$400m in first closing for Vietnam-focused fund
summary: Keppel Corp's asset management arm and property arm have launched a Vietnam-focused real estate fund, raising US$400 million in its first closing. The fund, named the Keppel Vietnam Fund, has a target size of US$600 million and aims to invest in real estate projects in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. It will have assets under management of about US$1 billion when fully leveraged and invested. The fund's success will allow Keppel Capital to expand into a new geography and strengthen its product offerings for global investors, while Keppel Land will use the capital to scale up its presence in Vietnam.

site_title: Europe's big guns serve up football feast
summary: Europe's top football leagues are set to feature high-profile matches this weekend, with several key games to watch. In the English Premier League, Tottenham Hotspur will host Arsenal at their stadium for the first time in over nine months, with Spurs looking to extend their lead at the top. Meanwhile, Real Madrid face a crucial test against Sevilla, while Bayern Munich are expected to secure a win against RB Leipzig. AC Milan, meanwhile, will look to maintain their unbeaten streak when they visit Sampdoria.

site_title: Ryanair puts rivals on notice with big Boeing jet rollout
summary: Ryanair plans to expand across Europe with 210 new Boeing 737 Max jets over the next four years, with deliveries starting in early 2021. The airline aims to capitalize on the post-pandemic travel rebound and is using its financial strength to outmaneuver rivals. CEO Michael O'Leary believes the Max's fuel efficiency, reduced noise, and increased seating capacity will give Ryanair a cost advantage. The move is seen as a strategic gamble, with analysts noting Ryanair's aggressive cost-cutting and risk-taking approach.

site_title: Indian jeweller's 12,638-diamond ring sets world record
summary: An Indian jeweller, Harish Bansal, has set a Guinness World Record for the most diamonds in a ring with 12,638 tiny diamonds in "The Marigold - The Ring of Prosperity". The floral-shaped ring, weighing 165 grams, took Bansal two years to design. Each of the eight-layer flower petals is unique. Bansal has declined requests to sell the ring, citing it as a matter of pride and a priceless creation. The previous record was 7,801 diamonds, set in India.

site_title: The jury is still out on what to do about record global debt levels
summary: Global debt levels have reached a record US$272 trillion as of the third quarter, according to estimates by the Bank for International Settlements and Institute of International Finance. The ongoing debate centers around how to tackle this issue, with options including growth and infrastructure spending, raising taxes, or issuing bonds. As the pandemic ends, countries must decide on a strategy to repay the debt, with no clear consensus in sight.

site_title: Home-bound customers may boost festive food retail sales
summary: Singapore's festive food retail sales may see a boost this year as more individuals, rather than corporations, shop for holiday treats. Hotels and retailers report increased demand for pre-ordered items and festive takeaway goodies, with some seeing a 10-15% rise in sales compared to last year. While corporate clients still make up the majority of sales, more households are choosing to celebrate at home, driving up demand for take-home festive menu items and log cakes.

site_title: StanChart Singapore mulls digital-only bank under 'rooted foreign bank' framework
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore is exploring an additional banking licence under the Significantly Rooted Foreign Bank (SRFB) framework, which would allow it to set up a digital-only bank. The bank, named the country's first SRFB in August, is interested in qualifying for the enhanced SRFB framework to deepen its presence in Singapore. StanChart Singapore would leverage its technology and experience from its digital bank in Hong Kong to operate a similar platform, with a strong ecosystem partner. The bank did not submit an application for a digital full bank licence.

site_title: Diamonds that rock
summary: Luxury house Louis Vuitton showcased two massive diamonds, the 549-carat Sethunya and the 1,758-carat Sewelô, at Capella Singapore, highlighting the "yin and yang" of rare finds. The diamonds were discovered at Lucara's Karowe diamond mine in Botswana. The showcase also features 90 jewellery pieces, including designs inspired by the galaxy and planets, created by Francesca Amfitheatrof. The collection, titled Stellar Times, incorporates stones such as emerald and sapphire to evoke the earth's colors. The display is a rare opportunity to see these extraordinary diamonds and jewellery pieces.

site_title: Grab-Singtel, Sea and Ant Group bag Singapore's first digital bank licences amid surprise twist
summary: Singapore has awarded digital bank licences to three consortiums, including Grab-Singtel and Sea, marking a surprise twist in the race. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) awarded two full-bank licences and three wholesale bank licences, bringing the total number of digital banks to four. The move is seen as a step towards increasing diversity and innovation in the financial sector, following the COVID-19 crisis. The four digital banks will emerge in early 2022, with Grab-Singtel and Sea's licences being the most anticipated. This marks a significant development in Singapore's banking liberalisation story.

site_title: Mystery surrounds US$7b outflow from Vanguard S&P 500 fund
summary: A record US$7 billion was withdrawn from the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO) on one day, accounting for about 4% of its assets, sparking speculation over the identity of the investor. Trading volumes were below average, and no obvious large transactions were reported, leading analysts to suggest that a major holder executed an over-the-counter trade. The withdrawal suggests that VOO is being used by large institutions, in addition to retail investors, who prefer its lower expense ratio of 0.03% compared to its competitor SPY.

site_title: Billions in SRS, delayed gratification, and the need to do more now
summary: Singapore's Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) has seen significant growth, with $10.6 billion in contributions as of 2019, but many accounts remain idle, earning low interest rates. To maximize returns, savers must adopt delayed gratification and take compensated risk, which requires education on managing investments and volatility. The Singapore Fintech Festival aims to address this issue by launching financial literacy programs at grassroots level, targeting those with little to no financial knowledge. Experts emphasize the need for fintech companies to prioritize client-centric outcomes and eradicate product kickbacks to create a more inclusive and wealthier society.

site_title: Even with vaccines, airport testing is here for the long haul
summary: Airport testing for COVID-19 is expected to remain a long-term necessity, despite the rollout of vaccines. Companies like XpressSpa and Collinson are scaling up rapid and PCR testing in airports to facilitate safe air travel and reduce quarantine requirements. Despite challenges, the efforts are gaining momentum, with increased availability of rapid tests and growing interest from airlines. Coordination among agencies is needed to establish a unified system for verifying results, but the need for testing has become more urgent due to the ongoing pandemic and the desire for long-awaited holiday travels.

site_title: Thai central bank says GDP may be worse than expected next year
summary: Thailand's central bank head, Sethaput Suthiwart-Narueput, warns that the country's GDP may underperform next year due to weak tourism. Despite this year's economy beating reduced forecasts, the central bank will remain accommodative with monetary policy focused on growth and fiscal stimulus until mid-2021. The Bank of Thailand may need to revise its forecast after third-quarter GDP came in better than expected. Tourism is expected to remain weak, with 9 million tourists forecast for 2021, which may be optimistic.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng warns of FY2020 net loss owing to Covid-19 resurgence in Malaysia
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a beverage company, expects to post a net loss for FY2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic in Malaysia, where it is based. The company attributes the loss to the absence of one-off gains on asset disposals and fair value gains on financial assets. Despite a cautiously optimistic start to H2, renewed lockdowns in the fourth quarter have raised uncertainties. Yeo Hiap Seng has a strong balance sheet and plans to adapt commercial strategies, prioritizing grocery and e-commerce channels, and announcing unaudited financial results by February 28, 2021.

site_title: US adds China's SMIC and CNOOC to blacklist over ties to Chinese military
summary: The US added China's SMIC and CNOOC to its blacklist of alleged Chinese military companies, citing ties to the Chinese military. The move, part of President Trump's legacy, aims to curb China's access to the US market. The list now includes 35 companies, with the addition of China Construction Technology Co and China International Engineering Consulting. The blacklisted companies will face penalties, including restrictions on US investors buying their securities, starting from late 2021. China has condemned the move, calling it an "abuse of national power."

site_title: Singapore shares end week in the black, STI up 0.62%
summary: Singapore shares ended the week in the black, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.62% to 2,839.89. Retail sales slowed in October, with a 8.6% year-on-year decline, but edged up 0.2% month-over-month. The market's recovery is seen as a "glimmer of light" by analysts, with potential for Q2 2021 retail sales to jump due to the low base in 2020.

site_title: Ikea announces second India store
summary: Ikea to open its second Indian store in Mumbai on December 18, marking the furniture giant's expansion in the country. The new store will create over 6,000 jobs by 2030, with a goal of having half of its employees be women. This follows the successful launch of Ikea's first Indian outlet in Hyderabad two years ago. Ikea plans to open 25 outlets in India by 2025 as it diversifies away from Western markets, capitalizing on the country's growing middle class.

images.alt_text: Ikea said on Friday it will open its second Indian store on December 18, seeking to woo the nation's growing middle class with Swedish functionality and a dash of local masala.

site_title: Sabana's activist investors to fast-track plan to internalise management after merger with ESR scuppered
summary: Sabana Reit's activist investors are fast-tracking a plan to internalize management after a proposed merger with ESR-Reit fell through. The move comes after 66.67% of unitholders voted in favor of the internalization proposal, while 33.33% opposed it at an extraordinary general meeting. The plan aims to enhance the Reit's portfolio returns and complete an asset-enhancement project, with the manager prioritizing leasing activities and completing the asset enhancement initiative at New Tech Park. This is the first time a Reit merger has been voted down by unitholders, highlighting a lack of confidence in the current board and manager.

site_title: Gaming startup mod.io raises US$4m from Sequoia's Surge
summary: Gaming startup mod.io has raised US$4 million in seed capital led by Sequoia Capital India's Surge programme and the Makers Fund. The company provides tools and analytics solutions for gaming studios to support user-generated content and mods. Since its launch in 2019, mod.io has enabled UGC to be shared in over 50 games across 11 platforms, with 65 million UGC downloads. Co-founder Scott Reismanis predicts mods will become a key game feature, with creator economies thriving on agnostic platforms like mod.io.

site_title: Malaysia's top pension fund sees minimal hit from extra outflows
summary: Malaysia's largest pension fund, the Employees Provident Fund (EPF), expects minimal impact from additional outflows due to the pandemic. With US$216 billion in assets, the fund had prepared for withdrawals by boosting cash levels. It plans to rebalance its portfolio without disrupting the market, using liquid assets to cater for withdrawals. The fund's ability to invest is determined by investment income, not just contributions. Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Abdul Aziz recently allowed over 8 million EPF members to tap their retirement funds, raising the withdrawal limit to US$2,463.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.41 points to 1,621.85. The index saw 14.216 billion lots worth RM6.751 billion traded, with 731 losers outweighing 580 gainers.

site_title: US hiring rebound stalls amid surge in virus cases
summary: US nonfarm payrolls increased by 245,000 in November, but the labor market rebounded at a slower pace amid a surge in COVID-19 cases. The unemployment rate dropped to 6.7%, but the labor-force participation rate and employment-population ratio declined. This slowdown may worsen the labor market next year and increase the chances of a weaker economic recovery, potentially prompting new fiscal aid and stimulus measures.

site_title: Singapore retail sales decline eases to -8.6% in October
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 8.6% year-over-year in October, easing from a 10.7% fall in September. The decline, while slower, still indicates a significant drop in consumer spending. Economists expect the year-on-year declines to continue narrowing but predict a full recovery remains distant. Retail sales excluding motor vehicles fell 11.2% year-over-year, with some industries, such as supermarkets and hypermarkets, showing growth. Positive year-on-year growth is expected to return in early 2021, possibly around Chinese New Year in February.

site_title: DiSa defends suitability of Lim Soon Hock to remain as independent director
summary: Digital security firm DiSa defended the suitability of Lim Soon Hock to remain as an independent director, following a Singapore Exchange query. DiSa cited the closure of an investigation into Stratech Systems in 2006, in which Lim was an independent director, and stated that no charges were brought against any director. The redesignation was made due to DiSa disposing of joint ventures where Lim had shareholdings. DiSa maintained that Lim's involvement in other investigations does not impact his suitability as an independent director.

site_title: Welcome to our world: Singapore banks sound battle cry to digital banks
summary: Singapore banks have welcomed the four newly licensed digital banks, expressing readiness for competition. Deputy chairman of UOB, Wee Ee Cheong, stated that the new digital banks will add to healthy competition, driving digital innovations for the benefit of consumers and businesses. This move is seen as a significant step in Singapore's progressive banking industry.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and trade tensions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined with bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Grab-Singtel digital bank to add 200 local staff by end-2021
summary: Grab-Singtel's digital bank plans to hire around 200 staff in Singapore by end-2021 to build a robust banking infrastructure. The bank, led by Charles Wong, a Citibank veteran, aims to serve consumers and small businesses, focusing on young professionals and micro-small and medium enterprises. The consortium, which includes Grab and Singtel, plans to launch the bank in early 2022 and offer personalized, accessible, and trusted financial products. The bank will also open up technology and fintech-related roles, aiming to develop a "sustainable business" in Singapore.

site_title: StanChart Singapore mulls digital-only bank as 'significantly rooted foreign bank'
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore is exploring an additional banking licence under the Significantly Rooted Foreign Bank (SRFB) framework, which would allow it to set up a digital-only bank. This move comes as the bank is already operating a digital-only bank, MOX, in Hong Kong. As an SRFB, StanChart Singapore can have up to 50 places of business, with the option to leverage technology and experience from MOX to operate a similar platform in Singapore. The bank's goal is to deepen its presence in the market and offer a digital banking model to its clients.

site_title: M1 users hit by third fibre broadband outage this year
summary: M1 users in Singapore experienced a fibre broadband outage on Dec 4, 2020, marking the third disruption to the telco's services this year. The outage, which affected fixed voice services, was reported on M1's Facebook page and was also tracked by Downdetector. The cause of the outage is currently under investigation. This incident follows previous disruptions in May due to a corrupted database and software fault. M1 has been fined $400,000 by the Infocomm Media Development Authority in September.

site_title: Halcyon Agri unaware of reason behind share price swings
summary: Halcyon Agri, a Singapore-based natural rubber supplier, denied knowledge of unannounced information causing its recent share price fluctuations. In response to a query from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo), Halcyon Agri stated it was unaware of any material information not previously disclosed. The query followed "unusual price movements" in the company's shares, prompting the regulator's investigation.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng expects FY2020 net loss with Covid-19 resurgence in Malaysia
summary: Beverage company Yeo Hiap Seng expects a net loss for FY2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact in Malaysia, where the company generates the majority of its revenue. The company's cautious optimism for the second half of the year is tempered by renewed lockdowns and cases in Q4. Despite this, Yeo Hiap Seng maintains a strong balance sheet and plans to adapt commercial strategies, prioritizing grocery and e-commerce channels. The company expects to announce its unaudited financial results on or before February 28, 2021.

site_title: Investors scramble for bite of Burger King India IPO with US$9.5b of bids
summary: Burger King India's initial public offering (IPO) drew 150 times the offered shares, with $9.5 billion in bids, exceeding its $110 million goal. The IPO aims to raise funds for new store openings and debt reduction, with plans to have at least 700 restaurants in the country by 2026. Despite a slowdown in the pandemic, investors are optimistic about the country's food service sector, with analysts citing a young and affluent population's preference for international restaurants.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, boosted by vaccine hopes and progress in US stimulus talks. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.40%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.07% and 0.50% respectively.

site_title: Ferrari F8 Spider review: A convertible bond
summary: The Ferrari F8 Spider is a high-performance convertible that offers a unique blend of style, comfort, and thrilling driving experience. With a 3.902cc twin-turbo V8 engine producing 720hp, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in 2.9 seconds and reaches a top speed of 340km/h. The F8 Spider's design is sleek and aerodynamic, with a low-slung wedge shape that embodies speed. It also features advanced driver assistance systems and a comfortable, feature-rich interior. While the F8 Tributo (fixed-roof version) is slightly quicker and lighter, the Spider's convertible top and more relaxed driving experience make it a desirable option for those who want to enjoy the thrill of driving every day.

images.alt_text: If you're going to drop seven figures on a mere car, it might as well look like a million bucks, and the F8 Spider fits that description to perfection.
If you're going to drop seven figures on a mere car, it might as well look like a million bucks, and the F8 Spider fits that description to perfection.

site_title: US: Wall St opens near record highs as grim jobs data fuels stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks opened near record highs on Friday, driven by grim jobs data that fueled hopes of a new fiscal stimulus package.
