The Dow Jones rose 0.07%, the S&P 500 gained 0.12%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.18%. The jobs growth was worse-than-expected, sparking bets on additional economic support.

site_title: US trade deficit widens less than expected in October
summary: The US trade deficit widened 1.7% to $63.1 billion in October, less than the forecasted increase of 2.1% to $64.8 billion. Imports rose 2.1% to $245.1 billion, while exports accelerated 2.2% to $182.0 billion. The narrower trade deficit may contribute to economic growth in the fourth quarter, as it was a drag on GDP in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: The United States' trade deficit increased less than expected in October, suggesting trade could contribute to economic growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Apple Pay targeted in Dutch antitrust probe into payment apps
summary: The Netherlands Authority for Consumers and Markets has launched an antitrust probe into Apple's payment app, Apple Pay, over concerns that users are limited to making NFC payments using the app, restricting their choice of financial apps. The regulator will investigate whether this limitation reduces users' freedom of choice, potentially resulting in a penalty. This probe follows EU antitrust probes into Apple Pay's terms and conditions and legislation that could force Apple to open up NFC to competitors, as the company competes with banks and fintechs in the Dutch market.

site_title: Grab-Singtel, Sea selected for digital full bank licences
summary: Grab-Singtel and a Sea Ltd entity have been selected for digital full bank licences in Singapore. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) deemed the pair "clearly stronger" than the other applicants, who will meet prudential requirements before receiving their licences. The new digital banks are expected to commence operations from early 2022. The selection was based on a holistic assessment of value proposition, ability to manage a digital banking business, and contributions to Singapore's financial centre.

site_title: Norway to use all three vaccines to stop Covid-19, says health minister
summary: Norway's health minister announced the country will use all three Covid-19 vaccines developed by Moderna, AstraZeneca, Pfizer, and BioNTech to inoculate its population. The country expects to receive 2.5 million doses in the first quarter of 2021, covering 1.25 million people. Norway's population is 5.4 million, and non-EU citizens will receive vaccines obtained by the European Union through Sweden.

site_title: Singapore welcomes four digital banks with Grab-Singtel, Sea nabbing coveted full-bank licences
summary: Singapore has awarded four digital bank licences to Grab-Singtel and Sea, marking a new chapter in the country's banking liberalisation story. The four winners will commence operations from early 2022, offering digital full banks and wholesale banks to meet the needs of under-served segments in Singapore and the region. MAS expects the new digital banks to establish a "path towards profitability" based on five-year financial projections. The successful applicants were assessed on their value proposition, ability to manage a prudent business, and growth prospects, with MAS considering the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on their financial projections.

images.alt_text: The final four that made the cut came from a shortlist of 14 candidates in June, with five digital full banks and nine digital wholesale banks left in the running.

site_title: US job gains miss expectations in November
summary: The US economy added 245,000 jobs in November, missing expectations of 469,000 jobs. This was the smallest gain since May and the fifth straight monthly slowdown in job gains. The jobs recovery from the pandemic recession is threatened by a resurgence in new Covid-19 cases and a lack of government relief money, leaving employment below its February peak.

site_title: South Korea's Moon replaces ministers as sinking ratings put policy agenda at risk
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in reshuffled his cabinet amid a record low approval rating of 37.5%, citing housing policies and the ongoing coronavirus crisis as major concerns. The reshuffle aims to refresh his administration with new ministers, but critics argue that policy reforms are necessary to regain support. Moon's presidency is limited to a single term, and his approval ratings have been eroded by scandals involving the justice ministry and top prosecutors. Key policy goals, including a green new deal initiative and prosecutor's office reform, remain uncertain.

site_title: Thai researchers unearth rare whale skeleton
summary: Thai researchers have discovered a rare, 5,000-year-old Bryde's whale skeleton at an inland site west of Bangkok. The 12.5-meter-long skeleton was found in early November and is believed to be the only one in Asia. The skeleton, partially fossilized, was excavated and 90% of its bones have been recovered. The bones will be carbon-dated to determine the exact age and will be exhibited after preservation. The discovery is expected to aid research into Bryde's whale populations and geological conditions at the time.

site_title: Bank of England's Saunders says floor for rates might be just below zero
summary: Bank of England policymaker Michael Saunders stated the effective floor for interest rates might be "a little below zero," sparking uncertainty over its exact level. The Bank of England is reviewing the feasibility of negative interest rates, which could impact monetary policy settings. Saunders' comments follow the UK economy's contraction for the second month, adding to pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Sincap defers repayment deadline for at least US$6m owed by firm of CEO's brother
summary: CATALIST-listed Sincap Group has extended the repayment deadline for at least US$6 million owed by its CEO's brother-owned company, Artwell, to April 2021. The repayment will be deferred, with Artwell to repay US$6 million by April 28, 2021, and continue to pay US$1 million per month thereafter. Sincap's CEO and executive chairman, Chu Ming Kin, has provided interest-free loans and verbal commitments to support the company, allowing it to remain a going concern despite initial queries about its ability to do so.

site_title: In new stimulus, Japan to offer regional banks incentives to merge
summary: Japan plans to offer subsidies to regional banks that merge with rivals as part of a stimulus package to boost economic growth in regional areas. The proposed package also includes a review of regulations to spur digitalization. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga aims to support rural areas and their struggling lenders, which have suffered from thin margins amid low interest rates. The stimulus package is expected to be finalized on December 8, with at least three public-sector investment funds to promote green investment and university research.

site_title: Consultancy urges Indonesia to adopt remote working post-pandemic
summary: Consultancy firm Kearney urges Indonesia to adopt remote working post-pandemic, citing the country's potential to establish a digital economy and standardize remote working models. The government and enterprises must collaborate to address infrastructure and talent issues. DBS economist Radhika Rao suggests the economy will be supported by consumption, corporate restocking, and net exports in 2021, but reforms are needed to improve investment appeal amidst global supply chain shifts.

site_title: Sats quadruples multicurrency MTN limit to S$2b for potential growth investments
summary: SATS has increased its multicurrency medium term note (MTN) limit to S$2 billion, up from S$500 million, to potentially access the bond markets for growth investments. The company, an inflight catering services provider, stated that the upsize creates flexibility for future fundraising needs. While there is no immediate need to raise funds, the option to tap the bond market may become attractive for financing new acquisitions and growth investments in the future.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A proposed merger between ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit fell through after exactly a third of Sabana Reit's unitholders voted against amendments to the trust deed. Singapore retail sales declined 8.6% in October, but showed improvement from the previous month. A consortium led by Perennial acquired Big Box in Jurong East for S$118m. Ascendas Reit raised S$396.5m through a preferential offering. The Singapore Exchange issued a query over iFast's trading activity, while SINCAP deferred repayment of US$6m owed by a firm linked to its CEO. The STI ended the week 0.62% higher.

site_title: Ant Group, Greenland-linked consortium selected for digital wholesale bank licences
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has selected Ant Group's unit and a consortium comprising Greenland Financial Holdings Group, Linklogis Hong Kong Ltd, and Beijing Co-operative Equity Investment Fund Management for digital wholesale bank (DWB) licences. The regulator chose just two out of 14 applicants, citing their "demonstrably stronger" performance across criteria. The successful applicants must meet prudential requirements before receiving their licenses, with operations expected to commence in early 2022. MAS aims to introduce digital wholesale banks as a pilot and review future licensing.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: Europe's leading stock markets opened mixed on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.5% and the Paris CAC 40 adding 0.3%. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index dipped 0.1%. The mixed performance follows the US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: iFast says not aware of digital banking licence outcome as SGX queries trading activity
summary: iFast Corporation, a wealth management and brokerage platform, said it is unaware of the outcome of the digital banking licence in Singapore, despite "unusual price movements" in its shares. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) queried iFast about the trading activity. In response, iFast stated it expects the licence result to be announced by the end of this year, and confirmed it is compliant with listing rules. The company's shares rose 5.5% after the query, and were trading at S$3.81 as of 3:33pm.

site_title: Nasdaq apologises for Australia stock exchange outage
summary: Nasdaq has apologized for an Australian stock exchange outage on November 16, which caused nearly a full session of trading to be wiped out. The outage was attributed to a software issue in the tailor-made combinations (TMC) order book, used primarily by retail and institutional traders of equity derivatives. ASX plans to reintroduce some TMC functionality on December 21. Nasdaq's CEO Adena Friedman expressed apologies to ASX, its customers, and those impacted, acknowledging the importance of providing mission-critical technology.

site_title: GL's hotel unit served notices for £1.9m over rent arrears
summary: GL Limited's hotel division, GLH, has been served £1.9 million (S$3.4 million) in rent arrears, interest, and costs by UK landlord Topland Group Holdings. GLH attempted to negotiate rental concessions due to the Covid-19 pandemic but was unsuccessful. The company will seek legal advice and defend itself against the claims, which are expected not to have a material impact on profits. GLH will continue to engage with landlords to reach mutually supportive arrangements.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes lower over coronavirus worries
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed lower on December 4, 2020, due to concerns over coronavirus vaccine distribution. The benchmark index fell 0.22% to 26,751.24. Investors awaited a press conference by Japan's prime minister and US data later in the day.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end on a record high
summary: South Korea's Kospi index reached a record high, closing 1.31% up at 2,731.45 points, driven by gains in Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix due to a power outage at a rival chipmaker and optimistic sector outlook. Foreign investors bought $707.70 million worth of shares, while the country reported 629 new COVID-19 cases, prompting the Seoul mayor to require establishments to close at 9 pm daily.

site_title: Neuroglee raises US$2.3m in pre-seed funding from Elsai and Biofourmis CEO
summary: Neuroglee, a Tokyo-based healthtech startup, has secured US$2.3 million in pre-seed funding from Elsai and Biofourmis CEO Kuldeep Singh Rajput. The company aims to develop digital therapies for neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. With this funding, Neuroglee plans to advance its product pipeline and create a "holistic approach to treatment" by combining digital therapies with medication. The startup was founded by Aniket Singh Rajput, Kuldeep's younger brother.

site_title: Who will be Singapore's next digital banks?
summary: Singapore's next digital banks are yet to be announced, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expected to make a decision in the near future. The MAS has been evaluating several banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, to become the first digital banks in the country. The MAS has stated that the digital banks will be required to meet certain criteria, including a minimum capital requirement of SGD 1 billion. The selection process is expected to be completed in the coming months, with the MAS aiming to launch the digital banks by 2026.

site_title: Three new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Three new Covid-19 cases were reported in Singapore, bringing the total to 58,242, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. No community cases or patients from worker's dormitories were announced. The country has seen a low number of community cases, with only four new cases in the past week. With 58,130 people recovered, 26 patients remain in hospital, and 29 deaths have been reported due to Covid-19 complications.

site_title: Most Singapore millennials find managing money difficult since start of Covid-19: StanChart
summary: A Standard Chartered study found that 60% of Singapore millennials struggle to manage their finances since the COVID-19 outbreak, with only 18% feeling in control of their personal finances. 38% of millennials are more confident in achieving long-term financial goals, compared to 25% of those over 45. To meet financial goals, 41% of millennials aim to better track and budget their spending. The study, which surveyed 12,000 adults across 12 markets, also noted that uncertainty around income is the most common worry across all generations.

site_title: Perennial consortium to acquire Big Box in Jurong East for S$118m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings will acquire the former Big Box property in Jurong East for S$118 million, with plans to redevelop it into a 1.5 million sq ft business park called Perennial Business City. The project will feature large floor plates, ample car parking, and a rooftop garden. Perennial will own a majority 51% stake in the development, with other investors holding the remaining shares. The redevelopment is expected to capitalize on the Jurong Lake District's potential as Singapore's second central business district.

site_title: Airbus bets on hydrogen to deliver zero-emission jets
summary: Airbus aims to develop a zero-emission, hydrogen-powered jet within the next five years, backed by governments and billions of euros in subsidies. The project, led by Glenn Llewellyn, involves studying three designs and addressing storage challenges, such as storing hydrogen in the plane's body or under the wing. If successful, the first hydrogen aircraft could start flying passengers in 2035, potentially halving the aviation industry's emissions and making eco-conscious travel more viable. The development of green hydrogen could also be accelerated by governments scaling up low-carbon hydrogen production to achieve net-zero goals.

site_title: Singapore shares end the week in the black, STI up 0.62%
summary: Singapore shares ended the week in the black, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.62% or 17.55 points to close at 2,839.89. Top performers included City Developments, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and the trio of banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC. Retail sales in Singapore slowed in October, down 8.6% year-on-year, but edged up 0.2% seasonally adjusted month-on-month. Analysts predict a possible rebound in retail sales in early 2021.

site_title: Philippine inflation picks up, but central bank keeps door open to easing
summary: The Philippine inflation rate accelerated to 3.3% in November, the fastest rise in 20 months, driven by food price spikes after typhoons. Despite exceeding expectations, the central bank described the jump as "transitory" and kept the door open for further policy action to support the pandemic-hit economy. Core inflation quickened to 3.2%, and the average inflation rate for January-November was 2.6%, within the 2-4% target range. The central bank has not ruled out further easing, citing uncertainty due to the resurgence of the virus in various regions.

site_title: BioNTech founder vaults into world's richest on 250% surge
summary: BioNTech co-founder Ugur Sahin has become the world's 493rd-richest person after the UK approved the use of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the German firm. Sahin's net worth has surged to US$5.1 billion, a 250% increase for the year, following a 95% effective vaccine. BioNTech's shares have jumped 8% this week, and the company is awaiting approval from the US FDA and EU regulators. Sahin's wealth has been boosted by the successful vaccine, which has cleared the way for its deployment.

site_title: UBS appoints Keller-Busse to lead Swiss unit, first big move under Hamers
summary: UBS has appointed Sabine Keller-Busse as president of UBS Switzerland, the first woman to lead the Swiss unit, following a major revamp under new CEO Ralph Hamers. Keller-Busse, who joined UBS in 2010 and was named group COO in 2018, will succeed Axel Lehmann at the end of January 2021 and leave the bank at the end of July. Iqbal Khan, co-president of global wealth management, will succeed Keller-Busse as president EMEA, effective February 1.

site_title: Broker's take: Yangzijiang undervalued, set to bottom out, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to a "conviction buy", citing the company's undervalued shares and improving fundamentals. The analyst notes that YZJ trades at an unjustifiably low 0.5 times price-to-book value, despite superior financials and a sustainable dividend yield. The research team has a target price of S$1.40, representing a 54% upside on Thursday's close, and believes the stock is set to bottom out with improving fundamentals.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on US stimulus hopes, post fifth straight weekly gain
summary: Australian shares rose on Friday, ending a one-week high, driven by gains in financial and energy stocks on US stimulus hopes. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 6,634.1, its highest since Nov 26, for a fifth straight weekly gain. The main driver was the bipartisan US economic package, with heavyweight financials and energy stocks jumping 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. The benchmark index also posted a 0.5% weekly gain.

site_title: SFF x Switch 2020 Ep 3: How the Singapore FinTech Festival adapted to Covid-19
summary: The Singapore FinTech Festival adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic by implementing a 24/7 hybrid model for its 2020 event, allowing global speakers to join remotely. This innovative approach showcased the potential of digital innovation and collaboration, bridging physical, security, and cross-border boundaries. The festival demonstrated that digital events can be effective and engaging, paving the way for future global conferences. This adaptation enabled the festival to proceed despite the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 8.6% in October, improving from September
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 8.6% in October year-on-year, improving from September's 10.7% fall. The total retail sales value was S$3.3 billion, with online sales accounting for 10.5%. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales fell 11.2%. Most retail industries experienced year-on-year declines, with food and beverage services seeing the largest drop of 23.5%. Supermarkets and hypermarkets saw the strongest growth in sales, up 22.3%.

site_title: Gold on track for weekly gain as US stimulus hopes dent dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,843.99 per ounce, set for its first weekly gain in four, amid growing optimism over a US fiscal stimulus deal and a weakening dollar. The dollar is expected to be its worst week since early November, making gold cheaper for other currency holders. A bipartisan US$908 billion coronavirus aid plan gained momentum in the US Congress, and Pfizer slashed its target for the rollout of its Covid-19 vaccine on supply disruptions.

site_title: Payments startup Stripe teams up with Goldman, Citi to offer banking services
summary: Stripe, a payments startup, has partnered with Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and other financial institutions to launch banking services through its Stripe Treasury platform. The platform embeds financial services using APIs onto Stripe's platform, allowing customers to send, receive, and store funds. The partnership aims to expand services in the US and provide a global reach. Canadian e-commerce company Shopify has also extended its partnership for Shopify Balance, a business account for independent businesses and entrepreneurs. This move is expected to provide deeper financial services to Stripe's customers.

site_title: WHO looks at e-certificates for Covid-19 vaccination
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is considering introducing electronic vaccination certificates to track and monitor individuals who have received Covid-19 vaccines. This move comes as Britain became the first country to approve the use of a Covid-19 vaccine, boosting hopes for an end to the pandemic. The WHO's proposal would require collaboration with member states to establish a national law framework for the e-certificates, which have not yet been finalized.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization (WHO) said it was considering introducing electronic vaccination certificates, as hopes for an end to the pandemic were boosted after Britain became the first country to approve use of a Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as financials cap losses in miners
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,626.0, driven by a 0.7% gain in financials, with the "Big Four" banks advancing. However, miners fell 0.7% after a record rally in iron ore prices and a lowered forecast from Vale. The healthcare sector hit its lowest in a month, with losses in Resmed and Fisher & Paykel Healthcare. The S&P/ASX 200 index was on track for its fifth consecutive weekly gain, likely adding 0.4%.

site_title: Broker's take: Excess industrial supply in 2021 may temper rental growth, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research warns that excess industrial supply in Singapore in 2021 may temper rental growth, as 700,000 sq m of new industrial space was delayed due to the pandemic and will be rolled over to 2021. This will bring the total new supply to 2.2 million sq m. Analysts expect landlords to focus on tenant retention, leading to tempered organic rental growth potential. However, business parks and logistics sectors are expected to see demand driven by Singapore's IT infrastructure and vaccine distribution opportunities, potentially leading to robust rental growth in the medium term.

site_title: China warns of risks of inflated credit ratings amid bond defaults
summary: China's interbank bond market regulator, the National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors (NAFMII), has warned of inflated credit ratings amid widespread industry problems following state-owned enterprise defaults. The regulator found shortcomings in rating models, databases, and execution systems at several firms, including Dagong Global Credit Ratings, which upgraded 17 issuers in the third quarter. This has led to concerns about the credibility of Chinese credit ratings and potential rating inflation, undermining investor faith in even the safest ratings. The regulator is reviewing the industry to address these issues.

site_title: Taiwan says trade deal would show US support in face of China pressure
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen stated that a trade deal between Taiwan and the US would demonstrate US support for the democratic island amidst China's pressure. Taiwan has been seeking a trade deal with its key backer, and Tsai announced the relaxation of US pork and beef imports in August. The trade deal would strengthen economic ties and demonstrate the US' commitment to Taiwan, according to Tsai.

site_title: Asean economies see Q2 drop in remittances
summary: Remittances from migrant workers in the Asean region, including Cambodia, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines, declined year-over-year in Q2 2020, reversing previous year's growth. This decline is attributed to job losses across the region, fueled by the Covid-19 pandemic. The drop in remittances poses a worrying sign for household incomes and local economies, highlighting the economic impact of the pandemic on the Asean region.

images.alt_text: A queue for remittance services at a Western Union outlet in Singapore on Nov 7, 2020.

site_title: Netflix hit 'The Crown' blasted for anti-Charles bias
summary: The fourth season of Netflix's 'The Crown' has sparked controversy in Britain, with critics accusing show creator Peter Morgan of taking too much artistic license in portraying Prince Charles. The series depicts Charles' unhappy marriage to Princess Diana and his infidelity with Camilla Parker-Bowles, leading some to claim the show is "anti-Charles." Royal biographers and historians have disputed the accuracy of these portrayals, with some calling it a "hatchet job" against Charles. The show's creator has defended the show's approach, but critics argue it has blurred the line between drama and history.

site_title: Margin for compromise limited as Brexit talks go down to wire
summary: European diplomats have reached the end of their concessions in trade talks with Britain, with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier warning that a compromise may be too costly for Brussels. The UK is pushing ahead with a law that could undermine EU trust, despite warnings from EU member states, particularly France and the Netherlands. Negotiations on key issues such as fisheries, regulation, and governance are stalled, with a deal unlikely before December 31 when the UK will exit the EU single market.

site_title: US said to be in talks to resolve charges against Huawei's CFO
summary: The US Justice Department is in talks to resolve charges against Huawei's CFO, Meng Wanzhou, who was arrested in 2018 on wire and bank fraud charges related to alleged security risks. A possible deferred prosecution agreement could allow Meng to return to China if she admits wrongdoing. The talks come amid rising tensions between the US and China, with the US seeking to bar allies from using Huawei's equipment due to security concerns. Negotiators will speak again this week, with hopes of reaching a deal before the Trump administration leaves office.

site_title: China's budget store Miniso takes on Toys 'R' Us with new chain
summary: Miniso Group Holding, a Chinese budget retailer, is expanding into the US$86 billion global toy market with its new chain "Toptoy." The first store will open in Guangzhou this month, offering low-cost, popular products among Chinese children, such as "pop toys" and "blind boxes." Miniso aims to capture China's growing toy market, which is expected to become the world's largest by 2022. The company's founder, Ye Guofu, hopes to differentiate Toptoy from traditional toy retailers with its focus on quality and unique products.

site_title: Trump campaign stop in Georgia for Senate runoffs could be risky
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to visit Georgia on Saturday for a campaign rally supporting Republican Senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue in the January 5 Senate runoffs. However, Trump's erratic behavior and refusal to acknowledge his election defeat may deter voters, with some party power players expressing concerns that the rally could be counterproductive. The stakes are high, as a Democratic victory would give Vice-President Kamala Harris the deciding vote, potentially altering the balance of the Senate. Trump's ability to excite his supporters is undeniable, but the outcome of the runoffs remains uncertain.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.06 points, or 0.07%, to 1,627.20. The market saw a slight edge in gains, with 291 shares gaining and 86 losing.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,826.39, driven by gains from Keppel Corp, which launched a Vietnam-focused real estate fund raising US$400 million. Meanwhile, ISOTeam and Hong Lai Huat Group fell 11.6% and 9.1% respectively after receiving warnings from the Singapore Exchange Regulation. US stocks ended mixed, with the Dow and S&P 500 up, while the Nasdaq Composite rose to a record high.

site_title: Some Sino-US relations damage 'beyond repair', Chinese state media warns
summary: Chinese state media warns that some damage to Sino-US ties is "beyond repair" due to US counter-China measures, including limiting visitor visas for Chinese Communist Party members and banning Xinjiang cotton imports. The move comes amid a rising rancour, exemplified by a Twitter spat between a US senator and Chinese reporter. The warning suggests that any attempt to ease tensions may be futile, as the current US president intends to maintain a hardline stance.

site_title: Is Wall Street ready to work on China time?
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill that could remove Chinese companies listed on American exchanges, allowing financial workers to sleep at night. This comes after nearly a decade of working irregular hours to buy into Chinese tech companies listed on US exchanges, due to time zone differences. The bill could impact tens of thousands of financial workers who have built their careers trading and servicing companies like Alibaba Group Holding and JD.com.

site_title: India's central bank keeps key rates steady as expected
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept key interest rates steady as expected, maintaining an accommodative policy stance to revive growth. Governor Shaktikanta Das stated the economy is rebounding faster than expected but warned signs of recovery are far from being broad-based. The decision was made amid persistently high inflation.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as virus cases cloud vaccine optimism
summary: Asia markets were mixed on Friday as concerns over the coronavirus pandemic overshadowed vaccine optimism. Record virus cases in the US and Italy highlighted the need for governments to maintain restrictions. In the US, lawmakers appeared to be nearing an agreement on a new stimulus package, with a bipartisan proposal backed by Democratic leaders and some Republicans. Asian markets were affected, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai falling, while Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore gained. Oil prices extended gains as Opec producers agreed to increase output, but analysts warned of potential compliance issues if the global economy recovers stronger than expected.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.31% on Friday, following a record performance on Wall Street, as investors hope for a US stimulus deal. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,811.59, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined slightly. The gains were driven by optimism over the US stimulus package, despite US-EU tariff threats.

site_title: South-east Asia office renovation costs stayed low in 2020
summary: Renovation costs in South-east Asia remained relatively low in 2020, with Bangkok overtaking Ho Chi Minh City as the cheapest urban centre for office fit-outs. The regional average cost rose 4.7% to US$93 per square foot, while costs in cities like Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, and Manila increased by 3.9%, 8.5%, and 5.1% respectively. Despite this, prices in cities like Bangkok and Manila may hold steady or dip due to competition among contractors. The average cost is expected to rise in 2021 due to challenges such as labour shortages and higher delivery costs.

site_title: Obama, Bush, Clinton as well as US President-elect Biden ready to publicly receive Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Former US presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and President-elect Joe Biden have expressed willingness to publicly receive the COVID-19 vaccine to boost public confidence. Obama stated he would get vaccinated if top expert Anthony Fauci approves it, while Bush and Clinton also plan to get vaccinated on camera. Biden plans to follow suit after government approval. The US aims to immunize 100 million people by the end of February, with COVID-19 vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna-NIH expected to be approved soon.

site_title: Keppel raises US$400m in first closing for Vietnam-focused real estate fund
summary: Keppel Corp's asset management arm Keppel Capital and property arm Keppel Land launched a Vietnam-focused real estate fund, raising US$400 million in its first closing. The fund, named the Keppel Vietnam Fund, targets US$600 million and will invest in real estate projects in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. Keppel Capital will manage the fund, while Keppel Land will develop and manage properties. The fund aims to leverage up to US$1 billion and expand Keppel Capital's presence in Vietnam and global investor offerings.

site_title: Hollywood 'Con Queen' arrested in Britain: FBI
summary: A 41-year-old Indonesian man, Hargobind Tahilramani, also known as the "Con Queen of Hollywood," has been arrested in Britain on a US extradition request for allegedly impersonating top Hollywood executives and swindling aspiring stars out of hundreds of thousands of dollars. Tahilramani, who used fake accents and threatened victims, faces charges of wire fraud, identity theft, and conspiracy. The scam, which began in 2013, targeted victims worldwide, including women and men, and was only stopped despite global Covid travel bans.

site_title: US tightens travel rules for Chinese Communist Party members
summary: The US State Department has tightened travel visas for Chinese Communist Party (CCP) members, restricting them to a single entry and a one-month validity period. This decision is seen as a response to CCP activities deemed "hostile to US values" and "nefarious." The move affects millions of Chinese citizens, including party members and their families. The US has also restricted journalist visas and closed Chinese consulates in the US, leading to retaliatory actions from China. The tensions between the two nations continue to escalate.

site_title: Proposed merger between ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit falls through
summary: The proposed merger between ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit has fallen through after exactly a third of Sabana Reit's unitholders voted against amendments to the trust deed, thwarting the scheme. The merger had received 66.67% of the votes in favor, but required 75% or more to pass. Unitholders cited a preference for Sabana Reit to remain standalone, and the manager expressed commitment to continuing to create value for all unitholders. This marks the first time a proposed merger has been voted down in the 18-year history of the Singapore Reit market.

site_title: GIC-backed Affirm looks to Canada with acquisition of buy-now-pay-later firm PayBright
summary: Affirm Holdings, backed by GIC, has acquired Canadian buy-now-pay-later firm PayBright for C$340 million, expanding its presence outside the US. This deal marks the first major consolidation in the BNPL industry, driven by an online shopping boom during the Covid-19 pandemic. Affirm's IPO showed revenue nearly doubled and net loss narrowed, indicating the company's growth potential. The acquisition aims to capitalize on intensifying competition in the BNPL market.

site_title: Ascendas Reit preferential offering oversubscribed; raises S$396.5m
summary: Ascendas Reit's preferential offering for new units was oversubscribed, raising S$396.5 million. The offering, part of a S$1.2 billion fundraising, saw 196.8 million new units applied for, 1.5 times the available 133.9 million units. 79.2% of units were validly accepted, with excess applications accounting for 67.7%. The new units, priced at S$2.96, are expected to be listed on Dec 9.

site_title: Private equity firm Thoma Bravo raising blank-check acquisition vehicle: sources
summary: Private equity firm Thoma Bravo is raising a blank-check acquisition vehicle through an initial public offering, becoming one of the first technology-focused buyout firms to join Wall Street's SPAC craze. The SPAC will target software and technology sector acquisitions. Thoma Bravo declined to comment on the plans. This move follows a surge in SPACs, which have raised over $70 billion this year, according to SPAC Research.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.31% or 82.69 points at 26,726.68, and the Topix index down 0.15% or 2.63 points at 1,772.62. The decline was attributed to a higher yen against the dollar, as investors awaited key US jobs data later in the day.

site_title: US bankruptcies drop to 14-year low as coronavirus cases surge
summary: US bankruptcy filings reached a 14-year low in November, totaling 34,440, driven by a decline in non-commercial filings. This drop contrasts with a worsening economic outlook due to surging COVID-19 cases. Despite this, Chapter 11 bankruptcies increased 40% to 654, as companies seek restructuring in uncertain financial conditions. The government's pandemic relief programs, including eviction moratoriums and extended unemployment benefits, are set to expire at the end of the year, prompting lawmakers to revive negotiations over a new relief package.

site_title: Japan may create up to 2t yen fund to promote green investment: sources
summary: Japan's government is considering creating a 1 trillion- to 2 trillion yen (S$12.82 billion to S$25.65 billion) fund to promote green investment, as part of its third stimulus package. The fund aims to support environment-friendlier areas, including technical development in battery storage and carbon emission reduction. This initiative is part of the government's efforts to boost green investment and address climate change concerns.

site_title: SGX queries Halcyon Agri on trading activity; shares up 29.8% this week
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has issued a query to Halcyon Agri Corp regarding unusual price movements in its shares, which have gained 29.8% this week. The query seeks information not previously announced by the company that may explain the trading activity. Halcyon Agri's shares were trading at 30.5 Singapore cents on Friday, unchanged from the previous close. The company's most recent announcement was on November 26, providing updates on its third-quarter business performance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, ThaiBev, Keppel, CDL, ISOTeam
summary: Ascendas Reit's preferential offering was oversubscribed, with 1.5 times the total units available, raising S$396.5 million. ThaiBev's issuer rating was affirmed by Moody's, changing the rating outlook from negative to stable. Keppel Corp launched a Vietnam-focused real estate fund, while City Developments Limited saw a jump in bookings for staycations. ISOTeam's shares surged 7.2% before the Singapore Exchange Regulation warned shareholders to exercise caution. LionGold Corp proposed issuing up to S$10 million in convertible bonds, and Dairy Farm International's Meadows brand recalled its bottled water due to bacterial contamination.

site_title: Four die in UK chemical tank blast: police
summary: Four people died in a chemical tank blast at a waste water treatment plant in Avonmouth, western England. The explosion occurred in a silo holding treated bio-solids, and a fifth person was injured but not seriously. An investigation has been launched by the Health and Safety Executive. Police ruled out terrorism and said the cause of the explosion was unknown. Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed his condolences to the victims and their families.

site_title: Kelley Aerospace to take 250 aviation jobs under its wing; eyes S$150m investment
summary: Kelley Aerospace, a US-based aircraft manufacturer, plans to establish a presence in Singapore with a S$150 million investment, creating over 250 local jobs. The company aims to train 500 pilots in five years and manufacture carbon fibre components for private jets and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). Kelley Aerospace is developing a business jet that can fly at the speed of sound and plans to maintain a fleet of 100 aircraft by 2024. The company also plans to design and manufacture UAVs and collaborate with Singaporean universities for research and development.

site_title: Germany blocks Chinese takeover of satellite tech company: report
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's government has blocked a Chinese defense company from acquiring a German satellite technology company, IMST, due to national security concerns. The acquisition was deemed to pose a threat to public order and security. The Economy Ministry confirmed that the cabinet agreed to block the deal, citing actual and serious risks. This move comes as the government pushes to toughen up oversight of non-EU takeovers, with a draft law aiming to lower the threshold for review from 25% to 10%. The deal involved China Aerospace Science and Industry Corporation's subsidiary, Addsino.

site_title: Britain 'rushed' Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine approval: Fauci
summary: Leading US infectious disease scientist Anthony Fauci criticized Britain for rushing through its approval process for the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, suggesting it may undermine public faith. Fauci stated that Britain's regulator "ran around the corner of the marathon and joined it in the last mile," contrasting with the US FDA's careful approach. The move was seen as a politicized decision, prompting skepticism from European neighbors. Britain approved the vaccine ahead of its neighbors, citing Brexit as the reason, but this has raised concerns about the credibility of its regulatory process.

site_title: Tesla skeptic regrets betting against Musk: report
summary: Prominent investor Jim Chanos, founder of Kynikos Associates, has acknowledged missing the mark in betting against Tesla due to its soaring shares, now over seven times their 2019 level. Chanos, known for his past successes in betting against Enron, has reduced his exposure to the trade. Tesla's shares rose 4.3% after Goldman Sachs upgraded its price target to $780, citing accelerating battery electric auto adoption. Elon Musk frequently dismisses short sellers as "haters."

site_title: Trump refuses to say if he has confidence in attorney general
summary: US President Donald Trump refused to confirm whether he has confidence in Attorney General Bill Barr, who contradicted Trump's claims of election fraud. Barr stated that the Justice Department has not found significant voter fraud, confirming the conclusions of various government officials. Trump questioned Barr's efforts, saying he hasn't looked hard enough for "massive fraud." This marks a further deterioration in Trump's relationship with Barr, who has publicly disagreed with the President's claims.

site_title: Slack's CEO is back in the passenger seat after Salesforce deal
summary: Slack CEO Stewart Butterfield is returning to the passenger seat after selling the company to Salesforce for $27.7 billion. Butterfield had taken Slack public last year but instead opted for the acquisition deal with Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff. The deal marks Salesforce's largest acquisition, and Butterfield's net worth jumped $400 million. The decision may seem surprising given Butterfield's past dissatisfaction with working under someone else, but he expressed enthusiasm for the combination, calling it "the most strategic combination in the history of software." Butterfield will run Slack as a division of Salesforce.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SGX RegCo warns shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in ISOTeam shares due to a surge in trading volume from a small group of connected accounts, responsible for 83% of buy trades on Sept 24. The accounts engaged in cross trades and trading among themselves on 41 of 44 trading days. ISOTeam reported a full-year loss of S$21.49 million after its results release in Oct.

site_title: America's Covid-19 outbreak enters worst phase as winter arrives
summary: The US is experiencing its worst phase of the Covid-19 outbreak as winter arrives, with the death rate exceeding 2,000 a day and a total of over 273,000 deaths. Hospitalizations are at a record 100,000, and experts warn that the situation will worsen, potentially leading to 450,000 deaths by February. Despite vaccine development, few states are imposing new lockdowns, and restrictions are patchwork, with a lack of national coordination. The country's decentralized governance system is seen as a weakness in the crisis.

site_title: A time for reinvention
summary: Singaporean personalities reflect on the challenging 2020 year, with actress Jeanette Aw noting that despite her film schedules being disrupted, she's had an "oddly good" year. Aw used the time to focus on personal growth, creating content for Instagram, and planning future projects. She emphasizes the importance of self-improvement and learning new skills during difficult times, encouraging others to do the same.

site_title: KKR closes in on US$800m warehouse deal amid e-commerce boom
summary: KKR & Co is nearing a deal to purchase a portfolio of approximately 100 US warehouses valued at over US$800 million. This transaction would significantly increase the company's sector exposure to about 30 million square feet. The deal comes as the e-commerce boom continues, with the sector receiving a boost during the pandemic. The transaction is expected to close as soon as next week.

site_title: Singapore to tackle greenwashing, carbon trading, to boost sustainable finance: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) plans to tackle greenwashing in the carbon trading market and boost sustainable finance. The regulator aims to standardize carbon-credit trading and curb the sale of "green" financial products that don't meet standards. MAS will also attract rating agencies and service providers to verify carbon footprints and green standards. The move follows growing global demand for sustainable finance, driven by companies' targets to reduce carbon emissions to net-zero. Singapore is Asean's largest green finance market, and the MAS has already launched several initiatives to support green finance.

site_title: Nasa buying Moon dust for US$1
summary: NASA has awarded contracts to four companies to collect lunar samples at discounted prices of $1 to $15,000, setting a precedent for private sector exploitation of space resources. The companies will collect lunar regolith during scheduled unmanned missions in 2022 and 2023, and ownership will be transferred to NASA. The move aims to establish a precedent for resource extraction and utilization in space, with the goal of paving the way for a sustainable human presence on the Moon and eventually Mars.

images.alt_text: The US space agency NASA awarded contracts to four companies on Thursday to collect lunar samples for US$1 to US$15,000, rock-bottom prices that are intended to set a precedent for future exploitation of space resources by the private sector.

site_title: US: Boeing surges on a mixed day for stocks
summary: Boeing shares surged on Thursday after announcing its first major order of the 737 MAX, lifting the Dow Jones Industrial Average 0.3% to 29,969.52. US stocks ended little changed despite mixed economic data, including a report on coronavirus vaccine supply chain challenges. The news came after a lengthy grounding of the 737 MAX.

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat; Miners, Rolls-Royce lift FTSE 100 to 6-month high
summary: European shares ended flat on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 reaching a six-month high due to gains from miners Rio Tinto, Glencore, and Anglo American, and Rolls-Royce's 16% surge on a potential re-entry into the narrow-body jetliner market. Ireland's ISEQ index jumped 2% to a near 11-month high, while cautious comments on a post-Brexit trade deal kept sentiment in check.

site_title: UK vows 68% emissions cut by end of decade
summary: The UK government has set a legally-binding target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 68% by 2030, compared to 1990 levels, as part of its plan to become carbon neutral by 2050. The new target, faster than any major economy, includes banning new petrol and diesel vehicle sales, increasing offshore wind power, and scaling up hydrogen production. The move aims to create and support 250,000 jobs through a "green industrial revolution." The target has been welcomed by some business groups, but environmental campaigners have called it insufficient, urging more ambitious cuts to address global warming.

site_title: Housing frenzy in New Zealand exposes perils of ultra-low interest rates
summary: New Zealand's housing market is experiencing a frenzy, with houses selling for hundreds of thousands of dollars above government valuations. At a recent auction in Wellington, a young couple was forced to bow out of bidding on a basic three-bedroom home due to the high prices. The market's rapid growth is attributed to ultra-low interest rates, which have driven a rush into bricks and mortar. The government has taken notice, with Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's government asking the central bank to intervene, citing concerns over rising prices and inequality.

site_title: Gary Cohn channels Goldman minus self-awareness
summary: Former Goldman Sachs chief operating officer Gary Cohn is resisting repayment of a $10 million bonus, four years after leaving the firm amid its role in the 1MDB scandal. Cohn, who left Goldman in 2016, is one of several current and past leaders who were asked to give back $174 million as part of a collective atonement. His refusal to repay his bonus has raised questions about his self-awareness and willingness to make amends.

site_title: 'Calibrated' GLS, falling condo inventory could revive en bloc market: analysts
summary: Singapore's "calibrated" release of residential supply under the first-half 2021 government land sales (GLS) programme is expected to revive interest in the en bloc market, according to analysts. The programme will see a 17.2% increase in supply, with three private residential sites and one executive condominium site confirmed. Analysts predict a healthy level of bidding for confirmed list sites, with some expecting a possible return of the en bloc cycle as unsold inventory declines to 26,600 units in Q3 2020. The government's move aims to address the current undersupply in the primary market.

site_title: Warner Bros to stream 2021 movie releases
summary: Warner Bros announced that it will release its 2021 movie slate on HBO Max and in theaters simultaneously, including The Matrix 4 and Denis Villeneuve's Dune remake. This move follows the studio's earlier release of Wonder Woman 1984 on Christmas Day via streaming and big screen. Warner Bros chair and CEO Ann Sarnoff stated that the decision is a response to "unprecedented times" requiring creative solutions.

site_title: Richard Li partners Peter Thiel to set up US$595m blank-cheque company
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li is partnering with PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel to establish a $595 million blank-cheque firm, Bridgetown Holdings, to acquire one or more South-east Asian companies. The move comes amid Hong Kong's political uncertainty and follows Li's expansion outside the city, including investments in Thai insurance, Vietnam, and Indonesia. Bridgetown will focus on new economy sectors, including technology, financial services, and media, and has begun discussions with potential targets. Li's knowledge of the region's consumer appetites and patterns will work in his favour, despite new economy startups facing difficulties in South-east Asia.

site_title: HK media tycoon Jimmy Lai denied bail after fraud charge
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai was denied bail on a fraud charge related to the lease of his Apple Daily tabloid. The charge, which does not fall under the national security law, marks the latest crackdown on pro-democracy figures in the Chinese-ruled city. Lai, a critic of Beijing, was detained and the case has been adjourned until April. His arrest is part of a broader intensification of authorities' crackdown on opposition figures since the imposition of national security legislation in June.

site_title: Covid-19 makes uneasy bedfellows of Grab and Gojek
summary: Grab and Gojek, rival ride-hailing companies in Southeast Asia, are edging closer to a merger due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and rising competition from Sea. The firms are believed to be discussing merger terms, with Grab potentially acquiring Gojek, according to reports. The union would address concerns over market share and allow the companies to counter Sea's growing presence in the region. Regulatory approval will be a key hurdle, but talks may intensify as the companies seek to capitalize on their early mover advantages.

site_title: Dollar plumbs two-year lows; Aussie and Kiwi stabilise
summary: The US dollar index hit a two-year low on Thursday, falling to 90.918 due to optimism about US fiscal stimulus and Covid-19 vaccine developments. The Australian and Kiwi dollars stabilized, while the euro reached a two-year high above US$1.21. Investors remain risk-on despite economic damage caused by the pandemic, driven by expectations of further stimulus and a potential return to normal trade relations under the Biden administration.

site_title: Resident incomes fell in June, but employment levels bounce back
summary: Singapore's resident income fell 0.6% in June to S$4,534, the first drop in 16 years, due to the pandemic. However, employment levels have since bounced back to pre-Covid levels. The real median income slipped 0.3% after accounting for inflation, with the 20th percentile income level for the bottom 20% of earners falling 4.5%. Despite this, employment rates remain high, with 80.3% of residents aged 25-64 in work, and the unemployment rate remaining steady at 2.1%.

site_title: Singapore's cottage industry gets a digital lift
summary: Singapore's micro-entrepreneurs, including home bakers and small business owners, have turned to the internet to expand their operations amid the pandemic. Social media platforms and online commerce have facilitated this shift, enabling them to reach a wider audience. As a result, the digital cottage industry has gained momentum, with many individuals now selling their products online and leveraging e-commerce to grow their businesses. This trend is expected to continue, offering new opportunities for entrepreneurs in the country.

site_title: Singapore PMI continues reversal back to the norm
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment continued to be buoyant in November, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling 0.1 point to 50.4, indicating a slower expansion. The electronics sector PMI rose 0.1 point to 51.1, marking the fourth consecutive month of expansion. Experts attribute the mixed readings to a reversal in growth trajectory, with Irvin Seah stating that the manufacturing sector is transitioning from a V-shaped recovery to a square root-shaped growth pattern. Despite this, the electronics industry is expected to remain a key driver of growth in early 2021.

site_title: Christmas getaway at Mandarin Orchard Singapore
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore offers a Christmas getaway package, starting at $268++ per night, which includes a one-night stay, breakfast, and set lunch at Chatterbox. The package also includes access to perks such as discounted dining, picnic baskets, and a Meritus Club upgrade. The hotel's Make-It-Your-Own package offers additional deals, including late check-out and bottle deals. Bookings can be made directly on mandarinorchard.com.sg or by calling 6737 2200.

site_title: EU and Singapore must continue to 'stay the course' on free trade: Iswaran
summary: Minister-in-Charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran emphasized the importance of continuing to "stay the course" on free trade between Singapore and the European Union (EU), despite populist pressures globally. The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) has helped bilateral trade remain steady despite the pandemic, and both sides must maintain a strong stance in favor of free trade and multilateralism. An Administrative Arrangement on Cluster Cooperation was signed to facilitate cooperation and business activities between industry clusters in Singapore and the EU, and deeper cooperation in the digital economy is also being explored.

site_title: Alibaba-backed vehicle startup AutoX starts driverless testing
summary: Chinese autonomous vehicle startup AutoX, backed by Alibaba Group, has started fully driverless vehicle testing in China with 25 Pacifica minivans from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV. The company will test the technology in Shenzhen and five other cities without a remote centre, citing safety concerns. This move follows AutoX's successful testing of a passenger vehicle on California's public roads in July, becoming the second firm after Alphabet's Waymo to do so. The company aims to attract deep-pocketed partners and take an early lead in autonomous driving.

site_title: Chinese researchers quit US amid crackdown
summary: Over 1,000 Chinese researchers have left the US amid a US crackdown on alleged technology theft, with US authorities launching multiple criminal cases against Chinese operatives for industrial and technological espionage. The US Justice Department claims the researchers, affiliated with China's People's Liberation Army, fled after the FBI conducted interviews in 20 cities. China denies the accusations, calling them "ludicrous". The US allegations have raised concerns about Chinese agents targeting the incoming Biden administration, with officials warning of a "breadth of foreign influence activity".

site_title: Affin Bank weighs IPO of asset management unit
summary: Affin Bank is considering an initial public offering (IPO) of its asset management unit, Affin Hwang Asset Management, which could raise approximately RM500 million. The IPO is expected to happen in the second half of 2021, pending discussions with advisers. Affin Bank owns 63% of the investment manager, which manages over 60 billion ringgit worth of assets. A successful listing could boost Malaysia's first-time share sale market, which has raised US$477 million in IPOs so far this year.

site_title: Barneys New York to return in 2021 after pandemic delays revival
summary: Barneys New York, a luxury retailer, will reopen in 2021 after pandemic delays. The first two stores are set to open in Manhattan and Connecticut in the first quarter of 2021. The stores were originally planned for a September opening, but the health crisis delayed the revival. Authentic Brands Group, the owner, had licensed the brand to Saks Fifth Avenue in North America. Barneys had filed for bankruptcy twice and liquidated its remaining merchandise before closing its flagship in February. The brand plans to expand to China and Korea in the next two years.

site_title: LionGold proposes issuance of redeemable convertible bonds
summary: LionGold Corp is proposing to issue up to S$10 million of 10% redeemable convertible bonds, with 10 tranches of S$1 million each, to be consolidated into a single series. The bonds will bear interest at 10% per annum and can be converted into up to 3.33 billion new ordinary shares at a conversion price of S$0.003. The company plans to use 70% of the net proceeds to fund growth and expansion plans, with the remaining 30% for general working capital.

site_title: China's fur farms see opportunity as countries cull mink over coronavirus fears
summary: China's fur farms are resuming operations as countries cull mink due to coronavirus fears. Despite concerns over public health risks, Chinese suppliers are taking advantage of a surge in global prices for prized fur. Authorities in Denmark have culled 15-17 million mink after some tested positive for a mutated form of the coronavirus. China, the second-largest mink fur producer, has shown a zero-tolerance approach to new infection risks, but has taken little action against its 8,000 mink farms holding five million animals.

site_title: Robinsons Land picks banks for Philippines US$500m Reit IPO
summary: Robinsons Land, a Philippine developer led by Lance Gokongwei, has picked UBS Group and Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI) as arrangers for a planned initial public offering (IPO) of a US$500 million real estate investment trust (Reit). The Reit will be backed by an office portfolio valued at up to US$2 billion. The listing could take place in Manila by mid-2021, with potential additional banks to be added later. This move is expected to boost the country's IPO market, which raised US$802 million in 2020.

site_title: LMIRT unitholders question size, timing of Lippo Mall Puri acquisition
summary: Unitholders of Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) questioned the proposed S$336.5m acquisition of Lippo Mall Puri's strata title units from Lippo Karawaci. The deal, valued at 9 times LMIRT's market cap, has raised concerns about gearing levels and dilutive effects. The trust's manager faced scrutiny over pricing and timing, with some investors seeking more information on the transaction. The acquisition is part of LMIRT's efforts to expand its portfolio and increase its assets under management.

site_title: House approves restrictions on China firms listing in US
summary: The US House of Representatives approved legislation that could lead to Chinese companies, including Alibaba and Baidu, being removed from US exchanges if regulators aren't allowed to review their financial audits. The bill, which has bipartisan support, requires companies to disclose government control and allows US inspectors to review their audits. The measure is expected to be signed by President Trump, intensifying scrutiny of ties with China. The move follows US sanctions against a Chinese company and customs officers impounding shipments from the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps, a military-affiliated entity.

site_title: A meaty affair at Gemma
summary: Beppe De Vito's new Italian steakhouse, Gemma, has opened in Singapore, offering a unique dining experience with a focus on high-quality meats. The restaurant, formerly known as Art and Aura, features a new head chef, Daniele Sperindio, and a menu that includes aged salmon, cured duck prosciutto, and dry-aged steak. While the opening bite was slightly disappointing, the restaurant's later offerings, such as the wagyu tartare and pasta dishes, were well-received. With its focus on quality ingredients and Italian flair, Gemma is a promising addition to Singapore's dining scene.

site_title: Eurozone business activity shrinks in Nov, but optimism surges
summary: Eurozone business activity contracted in November due to strict lockdowns to combat Covid-19, but optimism surged due to vaccine hopes. The economy is predicted to shrink this quarter, but quarterly growth forecasts for 2021 were upgraded due to vaccine progress and ECB support.

site_title: Corporate governance a key factor for DBS' takeover of LVB to work
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has taken a historic step by rescuing a local bank, Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB), through a takeover by DBS Bank India Ltd (DBIL). LVB had experienced serious governance issues, resulting in deterioration of its financial performance. The RBI emphasized the importance of strong corporate governance practices, which are essential for a company's long-term growth. The acquisition highlights the challenges of inheriting corporate governance problems and risks from a struggling bank, and the need for effective management to ensure a successful merger.

site_title: 1% of PPP borrowers received more than one-quarter of the loan money: report
summary: A report by the Small Business Administration reveals that 1% of Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) borrowers received over 25% of the $523 billion disbursed, with 600 businesses, including law firms and restaurants, receiving the maximum $10 million loan. Most PPP borrowers, 87%, received loans of $150,000 or less, totaling $146 billion. Lenders collected $18 billion in fees, with JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America among the largest recipients. The data release comes as the US economy faces a dark winter ahead, with small businesses fearing their survival.

site_title: Big tenants trading places as building owners make big changes
summary: CIMB Bank has leased over 50,000 sq ft in the office podium of 30 Raffles Place, relocating from Singapore Land Tower. Boston Consulting Group is expected to move to 79 Robinson Road, occupying the top two floors. Lazada is in lease negotiations for 51 Bras Basah Rd, potentially occupying 100,000 sq ft. The moves come amidst the Singapore office leasing market's lull, with some tenants taking advantage of lower rents to secure prime space. The market saw negative net absorption of 81,000 sq m in the first nine months of this year, with rental values down 3.8% from Q2 2020.

site_title: Is the secret to sustainable finance at our fingertips?
summary: A growing trend in sustainable finance is emerging, where ordinary people are using digital platforms to invest in projects aligned with their values, such as renewable energy and biodiversity. With one billion people now banking online and micro-investing apps booming, consumer-led financing is seen as a potential solution to fill the sustainable financing gap estimated at $5-7 trillion a year. Large asset managers, including BlackRock and UBS, are expanding their ESG offerings, while crowdfunding platforms and fintech companies are connecting small investors to projects. This shift towards a citizen-centric investment model has huge implications for financial services and the planet.

site_title: Books for thinking, drinking and changing the world
summary: The publishing industry continues to produce books about wine and spirits, exploring various aspects of the industry. Five notable books from 2020 and one from 2019 highlight the complexities of Bordeaux wine and its reevaluation of terroir, as well as personal stories of women in the industry who have faced challenges. "Wine Girl" by Victoria James shares her harrowing yet gripping memoir of overcoming adversity, while "The New Wines of Mount Etna" by Benjamin North Spencer offers an insider's guide to the region. Other books, such as "Wine and the White House" by Frederick J Ryan Jr, explore the role of wine in presidential history.

images.alt_text: Books exploring wine and spirits from every angle. Here are five of the best from 2020, and one from 2019.

site_title: Covid-19 prompts spurt in new, small businesses like no other crisis
summary: Singapore has seen a significant surge in small business formations during the Covid-19 pandemic, with 30,304 new businesses registered from June to October, compared to 22,138 in the first five months of the year. The majority of these new entities are small companies and startups, with most having less than S$100,000 in issued capital. Digital platforms have been a key factor in this growth, with many entrepreneurs turning to e-commerce and online-delivery services to reach consumers. The sectors of food and beverage services and retail trade have seen the steepest increase in new businesses formed.

images.alt_text: The Covid-19 crisis has thrown Singapore into its worst recession since independence. But it has also ignited the biggest spark of small business formation in crisis times.

site_title: Recipes for innovation, if you dare
summary: Netflix's leadership book "No Rules Rules: Netflix and the Culture of Reinvention" advocates for a culture of autonomy and freedom, where employees are given complete autonomy and radical honesty. However, critics argue that this approach can lead to worker protections being compromised, with no vacation policy and a "Keeper Test" that encourages managers to fire employees they wouldn't fight to keep. The book's co-author, Erin Meyer, argues that the discomfort from firing is worth it for the freedom, but acknowledges that not everyone wants this kind of freedom and that it may not be suitable for all companies, particularly those in risk-averse cultures like Singapore.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia IPO chalks up 15% premium on debut
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) made a successful debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard, closing 15% above its IPO price of S$0.93 at S$1.07. The stock saw 9.4 million shares change hands, with a trading volume of S$10.3 million. CBA's IPO was oversubscribed, with the company now listed on the SGX.

site_title: All dressed up
summary: Amanda Leong, a 28-year-old former beauty queen, is busy decorating her luxurious home in Bukit Timah for Christmas. Despite having three young children and a busy schedule, she loves hosting and decorating the house. This year, she's going big with a gold and silver theme, featuring a two-storey high artificial tree and festive decorations. She's also cooking for smaller parties and has started her own jewellery label, Candy & Carats, which she plans to launch soon. Leong plans to spend Christmas Day at home with her family, opening gifts and enjoying leftovers.

site_title: SEEDS Capital seeks co-investors to back deep-tech startups
summary: SEEDS Capital, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, is seeking co-investors to back deep-tech startups with up to S$150 million in funding. The government has allocated an additional S$300 million under the Startup SG Equity scheme to support these startups, which require larger investments and longer gestation periods due to higher risks. The move aims to catalyze investment into deep-tech startups, which are less attractive to investors.

site_title: Singapore stocks rebound from Wednesday's loss, STI up 0.41%
summary: Singapore stocks rebounded from Wednesday's loss, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.41% to close at 2,822.34. Top performers included Jardine Strategic Holdings, Singapore Airlines, and ComfortDelGro. Amid a potential merger between Grab and Gojek, DBS Group Research sees this as a positive development, with less competition expected and potential consolidation of private rental fleets.

site_title: Thai protests target king's property investments worth billions
summary: Thai protesters are targeting the country's royal family's property investments worth billions of dollars, sparking a public discourse about the monarchy's economic influence. The Crown Property Bureau, managed by the palace, holds stakes in companies like Siam Commercial Bank and Siam Cement, as well as vast plots of land in Bangkok. Protesters are demanding a revocation of the 2017-2018 legal changes that consolidated the king's control over the agency's assets and profits. The issue has become a rallying cry for protesters, who are also criticizing the government's handling of the monarchy and the rising costs of royal affairs.

images.alt_text: The Dusit Central Park development sits on land owned by the Crown Property Bureau. The Thai royal family is the biggest shareholder in two valuable companies, Siam Commercial Bank and Siam Cement, and in large plots of land housing malls, hotels and offices.

site_title: More than 400 lawmakers from 34 countries back 'Make Amazon Pay' campaign
summary: More than 400 lawmakers from 34 countries have signed a letter to Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, backing the "Make Amazon Pay" campaign, which demands improvements to working conditions and full tax transparency. The campaign, launched on Black Friday, is backed by over 50 organizations, including US Congresswomen Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib, and former UK Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn. Amazon has responded, stating it has a strong track record of supporting employees and customers, but has accepted scrutiny from policymakers.

site_title: Startup mentality is saving small businesses
summary: Small businesses are adopting a "fail fast" approach similar to startups to survive the pandemic. By pivoting and trying new strategies, companies like Practice San Francisco and The Greater Knead have seen increased revenue and efficiency. With the shift to online sales and direct customer relationships, businesses are capitalizing on new opportunities and adapting to changing consumer behavior. As a result, small businesses are seeing a 22% drop in numbers, but are also experiencing a surge in innovation and resilience.

images.alt_text: After the pandemic hit, small businesses found themselves making changes to aspects of their business. If the change worked, it was adopted, and if not, then something else is tried. It is how startups work.

site_title: Singapore is world's second-most connected country in DHL ranking
summary: Singapore ranks as the world's second-most connected country in the 2020 DHL Global Connectedness Index, despite the pandemic's disruption to trade and capital flows. It scored 89 points, just two points behind the top-ranked Netherlands. Singapore excelled in international flows of goods, capital, information, and people relative to its domestic economy. The country maintained its position from the previous edition, while the Netherlands jumped up from third place. This ranking reflects Singapore's strong economic resilience and connectivity despite global challenges.

site_title: Ryanair agrees to buy 75 737 MAX jets in boost for Boeing
summary: Ryanair ordered 75 Boeing 737 MAX jets with a catalogue value of $9 billion, boosting Boeing after regulators lifted a 20-month safety ban. This is the largest order for the MAX since 2018 and comes after the airline already has 135 jets on order. The deal, which is expected to be completed early next year, could be a pivotal moment in Boeing's efforts to rehabilitate the MAX model. The order is likely to be completed at a significant discount, potentially exceeding 50% off catalogue prices.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens flat
summary: The S&P 500 opened flat on Thursday, with hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine-driven recovery and economic stimulus countering concerns about rising coronavirus cases and high unemployment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.12%, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.16%. The S&P 500 opened lower by 0.73 points at 3,668.28.

site_title: Platts to include US crude grade WTI in its dated Brent oil price assessment
summary: S&P Global Platts plans to include US crude grade WTI in its dated Brent oil price assessment, a move expected to provide additional volume and robustness to the benchmark. The inclusion, proposed for cargoes loading in March 2022, would be the first non-North Sea grade to be included. The decision follows the addition of WTI Midland in 2020 and reflects the declining oil production in the North Sea. Platts will accept feedback on the proposal until February 5.

site_title: Indonesia eager to clinch French Rafale fighter jets deal
summary: Indonesia is nearing a deal to purchase 48 French Rafale fighter jets, with negotiations advancing at a fast pace. The country aims to finalize the purchase before the end of the year, but French negotiators are focusing on fine-tuning details. The potential deal could bring French Rafale jets to Indonesia, marking a significant addition to the country's military capabilities.

site_title: LionGold proposes issuance of up to S$10 million in convertible bonds
summary: LionGold Corp proposes issuing up to S$10 million in 10% unlisted and redeemable convertible bonds, with a 10-year term and a conversion price of S$0.003. The bonds will be consolidated into a single series and can be converted into up to 3.33 billion new shares, representing 9.38% of the company's enlarged share capital. The net proceeds will be used for growth and expansion plans, with 70% allocated to this purpose. The bonds will bear a 10% annual interest rate, payable annually.

site_title: Lufthansa adds flights as confined Germans plot festive breaks
summary: Lufthansa is expanding its Christmas flight schedule in response to a surge in bookings from German tourists. The airline will add flights to southern European destinations, including Greece, Italy, and Spain, and reactivate routes to major cities to carry expatriates. This move aims to meet rising demand and help the carrier recover from the coronavirus crisis. Lufthansa, which received a 9 billion euro government bailout in June, needs to double operations to stem losses. The airline's expansion marks a rare piece of good news for the carrier.

site_title: France mourns ex-president Giscard
summary: Former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, aged 94, died from Covid-19 complications. Giscard served as president from 1974-1981, implementing social reforms and modernizing France's nuclear power and transportation systems. Tributes from French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel hailed Giscard as a great European statesman. Macron described Giscard's legacy as still guiding France, while Merkel mourned the loss of a "great European". Giscard's family announced that funeral ceremonies would take place in strict intimacy.

site_title: Chevron tightens belt again with billions more in cuts
summary: US oil major Chevron has cut its long-term capital and exploratory budget by billions to $14-16 billion through 2025, aiming to ride out a collapse in oil prices and preserve its dividend. The company has slashed spending plans and laid off staff amid a sharp decline in oil demand and revenue due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite the cut, Chevron plans to raise investments in key areas like the Permian basin and maintain a $14 billion budget for next year.

site_title: Aedge Group to raise S$1.7m in Catalist listing
summary: AEDGE Group, a Singapore-based provider of engineering and security services, plans to raise S$1.7 million through a private placement and listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The company will sell 16 million shares at S$0.20 each, representing 15.1% of its enlarged share capital. This listing will increase AEDGE's market capitalization to S$21.2 million and result in a price-to-earnings ratio of 59 times.

site_title: RHB initiates coverage of Prime US Reit with 'buy'
summary: RHB has initiated coverage on Prime US Reit with a "buy" rating and a target price of US$1, citing the REIT's "resilient and attractive" yield and stable rental income.
