The analyst notes Prime's sustainable yield of 9% is among the highest in the sector, and the REIT's strong asset and tenant quality, with limited near-term lease expiries. RHB expects Prime to maintain stable rental income despite the US economy's sharp negative impact from Covid-19.

site_title: UK approval of Covid-19 vaccine is a giant hooray for science
summary: The UK has approved the Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, making it the first coronavirus vaccine to be approved for mass use globally. The vaccine, which is 95% effective, will be prioritized for those working and living in care homes, healthcare workers, and the elderly. The UK will receive 40 million doses by next year, enough for 20 million people, and the vaccine's mRNA technology has been hailed as a game-changer for vaccine development. However, the rollout will be slow, taking until next summer, and there are concerns about public acceptance and the potential impact on other vaccine trials.

site_title: Thai central bank adjusts rules on banking capital instruments
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand (BOT), has adjusted rules on banking capital instruments to ease investor concerns about banks' interest payments. Tier 1 capital instruments can now pay interest without prior approval if their capital adequacy ratios meet requirements, and tier 2 capital instruments no longer require banks to postpone interest payment schedules. This move aims to allow banks to raise more capital, increasing their capital levels and liquidity, and ultimately supporting economic recovery by enabling them to provide more loans to businesses and households.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grab is in a position to make acquisitions and is financially strong despite a tough year, according to CEO Anthony Tan. The company is reportedly closing in on a merger with Indonesian rival Gojek. Meanwhile, Singapore's employment rate rose to pre-Covid levels, with 80.3% of residents aged 25-64 in their prime working age. StanChart launched a global learning hub to train 8,000 staff, while UOB debuted on the SGX with a 21.5% increase in its IPO price. Singapore stocks rebounded, gaining 0.41% in the STI.

site_title: M&C reports spike in bookings for Singapore, London hotels ahead of holiday season
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels reported a significant spike in bookings for its Singapore and London hotels ahead of the year-end festive season and Chinese New Year. In Singapore, bookings increased nearly sevenfold to 31,480 room nights from August to November. This growth is attributed to robust domestic demand. The hotels' restaurants also saw increased bookings. This surge in bookings is a positive sign for the hospitality industry in Singapore and London.

site_title: J&T Express opens third Singapore warehouse
summary: J&T Express, an e-commerce logistics provider, has opened its third Singapore warehouse, located in the west region, to improve efficiency and daily volume capacity. The move is part of the company's nationwide warehouse expansion plans. J&T Express has seen significant growth in Singapore, with daily deliveries doubling during the pandemic, driven by increased online shopping. The company is accelerating its expansion plans, hiring more drivers, and extending delivery hours to meet rising demand. This is part of J&T Express' goal to support customers as they turn to digitalization.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat proposes to raise up to S$26.9 million via rights issue
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group is proposing a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to raise up to S$26.9 million, partly financing its second mixed-use development project in Phnom Penh. The issue price of S$0.091 per rights share represents a 36.4% discount to the last transacted price and a 19.7% discount to the theoretical ex-rights price. The minimum subscription scenario yields S$14.4 million, while the maximum scenario totals S$26.9 million.

site_title: China's approval of South Korean game lifts hopes of better ties
summary: China has granted a licence to a South Korean mobile game, raising hopes for improved relations between the two countries. This is the first licence awarded by China to a South Korean computer game in four years, following a period of restrictions on South Korean games and entertainment. The licence was granted to Com2us, the developer of the popular mobile game Summoners War, and shares in game and entertainment firms have jumped. The move is seen as a positive step towards cooperation in culture and content areas, following a visit by China's top diplomat, Wang Yi, to South Korea last week.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution in trading of ISOTeam shares
summary: SGX RegCo has warned investors to exercise caution when trading ISOTeam shares, citing unusual trading activity. The counter surged 7.2% in a single day in September, with 71% of trades coming from a small group of connected accounts. These accounts engaged in cross trades and trading among themselves on 41 of 44 trading days. SGX RegCo is reviewing the trades and may refer the case to authorities if warranted. The unusual activity occurred after ISOTeam released its year-end results, which showed a full-year loss of S$21.49 million.

site_title: US service sector activity slows to 6-month low in November
summary: US service sector activity has slowed to a six-month low in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing activity index falling to 55.9, the lowest since May. The slowdown is attributed to widespread Covid-19 restrictions and the impending expiration of $3 trillion in government relief. Despite this, employment in the services sector rose to 51.5, indicating a moderate labor market recovery. A bipartisan emergency relief package has been proposed to address the economic concerns, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stating President Trump would sign the package if Congress approves it.

site_title: New US jobless claims down by 75,000
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 712,000 last week, a 75,000 decline, beating expectations. The four-week average for initial claims also fell by 11,000. However, 20.2 million people continued to receive unemployment benefits, a decline of 350,000. The drop in claims may not provide much comfort due to the Thanksgiving holiday affecting the figures, and economists expect initial claims to rebound strongly next week.

site_title: No change to STI constituents
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents remain unchanged following the December quarterly review. The reserve list of five highest-ranking non-constituents by market capitalization, including Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust and Keppel Reit, will replace ineligible constituents through corporate actions. The next review is scheduled for March 2026. FTSE Russell partners with Singapore Press Holdings and the Singapore Exchange to jointly calculate the STI.

site_title: Lombard Odier survey of ultra wealthy cites sustainability as key trend
summary: A survey of 150 ultra high net worth individuals in seven Asian countries found that 89% believe sustainability is a trend that is here to stay, but 56% are skeptical it will generate superior returns. 61% already consider ESG and sustainability in their investments, but 56% have not increased their sustainability factors. With low interest rates expected to persist, 78% of respondents favor discretionary mandates over advisory ones, citing a growing need for advice.

site_title: Moody's affirms Thai Beverage's 'Baa3' issuer rating
summary: Moody's Investors Service has affirmed Thai Beverage Public Company's "Baa3" issuer rating, changing the rating outlook from "negative" to "stable." The affirmation reflects the company's resiliency in operations, driven by its leading market position in the domestic alcohol segment. Moody's expects ThaiBev to pare down debt, lowering its leverage to below 4x within the next 12-18 months, as it reported a 9% increase in Ebitda to 28.5 billion baht for the financial year ended September 2020.

site_title: Facebook accused of squeezing rival startups in virtual reality
summary: Virtual-reality startups accuse Facebook of using its market power to muscle out rivals in the virtual-reality market. The social media giant's Oculus acquisition has led to accusations of copying promising ideas, using below-cost pricing, and making it harder for competing apps to work on the platform. Developers claim Facebook's practices are stifling competition, with some being forced to delete their apps or change their functionality to comply with the company's policies. The US Justice Department is investigating Facebook's virtual-reality business, and the Federal Trade Commission is preparing to bring an antitrust case against the company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 29.54 points to 1,628.26. The index saw a significant increase in volume, with 12.372 billion lots traded worth RM6.169 billion. The gain was largely due to the high number of gainer stocks, which more than doubled the number of loser stocks, 907 to 401.

site_title: Aedge Group to raise S$1.7m in Catalist listing; prices shares at S$0.20 each
summary: Aedge Group, a Singapore-based provider of engineering and security services, plans to raise S$1.7 million through a private placement of 16 million shares at S$0.20 apiece, representing 15.1% of its enlarged share capital. The IPO is in conjunction with its proposed listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. This will increase the company's market capitalization to S$21.2 million, with a price-to-earnings ratio of 59 times.

site_title: Britain's John Lewis won't return pandemic business rates relief
summary: Britain's John Lewis Partnership will not repay pandemic business rates relief, citing an "incredibly uncertain" outlook. The employee-owned group, which includes John Lewis department stores and Waitrose supermarkets, received government support to help navigate the crisis. The decision not to repay the relief was welcomed by the government, which stated it would consider support only where it is no longer needed. John Lewis plans to invest any profits in its partners, business, and charitable giving, rather than paying a bonus.

site_title: Thai protest leader faces contempt charge over PM court ruling
summary: Thai protest leader Parit "Penguin" Chiwarak faces a contempt charge for criticizing a court ruling that upheld Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha's eligibility to live in an army residence. The ruling sparked widespread protests and defied a court warning against "vulgar" criticism. Chiwarak has been charged under Thailand's strict royal defamation laws, which prohibit criticism of the king and his family, alongside five other protest leaders. Nearly 50 protesters have been charged with sedition, which carries a seven-year prison sentence.

site_title: Grab in 'position to acquire' amid Gojek merger speculation, says CEO
summary: Grab CEO Anthony Tan stated the company is in a position to make acquisitions and is financially strong despite a tough year, amid speculation of a merger with Indonesian rival Gojek. Tan said Grab has hit full recovery and is the top food delivery player in Indonesia, and that there will be "rumours and gossip" but they shouldn't distract from the company's work. The talks between Grab and Gojek are still fluid and may not result in a transaction, with one potential structure involving Tan becoming chief of the combined entity.

site_title: Meadows brand bottled water recalled after bacteria found during SFA checks
summary: Bottled water from the brand Meadows, a house brand of supermarkets Giant and Cold Storage, has been recalled in Singapore after a type of bacteria, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, was detected during routine sampling. The affected 1.5-liter bottles, sold only at Giant supermarkets, were imported from Malaysia and have an expiry date of Nov 9, 2022. Consumers are advised not to drink the water, and those concerned should seek medical advice. The Dairy Farm Group has removed the affected products from shelves and offered full refunds to customers.

images.alt_text: Bottled water from the brand Meadows has been recalled after bacteria was found in the product.

site_title: World food price index jumps in Nov to almost six-year high: FAO
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world food price index rose to almost a six-year high in November, increasing for a sixth consecutive month. The index averaged 105 points, up from 101 in October, marking its biggest monthly increase since July 2012. This rise is attributed to various factors, including global economic uncertainty, tariffs, and sanctions. The increase in food prices is expected to have significant impacts on global food security and poverty levels.

site_title: 3M to cut 2,900 jobs in restructuring
summary: 3M to cut approximately 2,900 jobs globally as part of restructuring efforts, aiming to achieve pre-tax savings of up to US$350 million. The move will also involve scaling back investments in slower-growing markets. The company expects a pre-tax charge of US$250 million to US$300 million, primarily incurred in the fourth quarter of 2020. CEO Mike Roman attributes the decision to the accelerated pace of change and disruption caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UOB pioneers new AI solution for anti-money laundering surveillance
summary: UOB is pioneering a new AI solution to enhance its anti-money laundering surveillance, utilizing machine learning to identify suspicious transactions and connected parties. The solution, developed in collaboration with Tookitaki Holdings, has a 96% true positive prediction rate and enables the bank to pinpoint higher priority cases, deploying resources swiftly to investigate potential money laundering attempts. The AI solution will be used concurrently on two AML risk dimensions, strengthening the bank's system to deal with emerging risks and expanding to cover all UOB accounts globally.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stocks remained steady at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index edging up 0.1% to 6,468.54 points. In the eurozone, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index both dipped 0.1%. Traders weighed hopes for Covid vaccine progress against rising infections and uncertainty over a post-Brexit trade deal and US stimulus package.

site_title: Singapore stocks rebound from Wednesday's loss, STI up 0.41%
summary: Singapore stocks rebounded from Wednesday's loss, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.41% to close at 2,822.34. Top gainers included Jardine Strategic Holdings, Singapore Airlines, and ComfortDelGro. A report on Grab's potential merger with Gojek was cited as a positive factor by DBS Group Research. Asian markets also ended the day up, with South Korean shares reaching a record high. Analysts expect risk premium compression and economic recovery to lead to more upside for Asia stocks.

site_title: American Airlines goes full throttle to restore Boeing MAX fleet
summary: American Airlines is restoring its Boeing 737 MAX fleet, completing safety changes ahead of a phased return to service. The airline's maintenance team, the largest in the world, has worked 64,000 hours to prepare the 24 grounded jets. Deliveries of new jets are set to begin as early as this week, and American plans to launch commercial service on December 29 with a daily flight between Miami and New York City. Each plane will undergo operational readiness flights and receive FAA sign-off before flying passengers.

site_title: Walmart's Flipkart to partially spin off digital payments business
summary: Walmart-controlled Flipkart is partially spinning off its digital payments business, PhonePe, to raise US$700 million in primary capital. PhonePe, which has over 100 million monthly active users, will be valued at US$5.5 billion. Flipkart will remain PhonePe's majority shareholder, with the funds aimed at fueling PhonePe's growth. This move aims to expand PhonePe's access to capital and compete with other payments pioneers like Paytm and GooglePay.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB initiates coverage on Prime US Reit with 'buy'
summary: RHB Securities has initiated coverage on Prime US Reit with a "buy" rating and a target price of US$1, citing the Reit's "resilient and attractive" yield and stable rental income. The brokerage attributes Prime's high yield to its strong asset and tenant quality, limited near-term lease expiries, and diversified portfolio. Despite near-term headwinds, RHB expects the office sector to remain relatively resilient, with strong demand from certain tenants offsetting the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: SEEDS Capital seeks co-investors to dole out S$150m to deep-tech startups
summary: SEEDS Capital, the investment arm of Enterprise Singapore, is seeking co-investors to back early-stage deep-tech startups in Singapore with up to S$150 million. The government has allocated an additional S$300 million under the Startup SG Equity co-investment scheme, aiming to draw over S$800 million of private funding over the next decade. SEEDS Capital is focusing on three deep-tech sectors: advanced manufacturing and engineering, health and biomedical sciences, and urban solutions and sustainability. The call-for-partnership will open on Dec 7 and close on Jan 17, with interested parties able to submit proposals.

site_title: Singapore PMI drops marginally but remains in expansion for 5th month
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment remained buoyant for the fifth consecutive month in November, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping marginally to 50.4, indicating slower expansion compared to October. The slight decline marks the fifth month of expansion, suggesting the manufacturing sector continues to grow.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at record high on chip, auto boost
summary: South Korean shares closed at a record high on Thursday, driven by gains in chip and auto stocks. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.76% to 2,696.22, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix jumping 1.44% and 5.05%, respectively. Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors surged 7.67% and 6.41%, respectively, after reporting strong November sales. The won strengthened to its highest since June 2018, and foreign investors bought 211.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The country also reached a deal with AstraZeneca to purchase its coronavirus vaccine candidate.

site_title: Aston Martin-backed report overstates electric car climate harm
summary: A report by Aston Martin and several industry peers claims that electric vehicles (EVs) need to be driven 78,000 km before they're cleaner than combustion engines, but a researcher disputes this figure, stating it underestimates emissions and overstates EV benefits. The report's methodology is based on one EV model and doesn't account for fuel production or combustion-engine emissions. The UK and California have set targets to phase out combustion engines by 2035, driving investment in EVs and infrastructure. Industry experts say the report's misinformation hinders efforts to address climate change.

site_title: Singapore's new Covid-19 case in dormitory detected in proactive surveillance
summary: A new locally transmitted Covid-19 case was reported in Singapore, detected through proactive surveillance in a workers' dormitory. The man, asymptomatic, had a low viral load and is being isolated and quarantined. This brings Singapore's total to 58,239 cases, with 58,130 recovered and 26 in hospital. The number of new community cases remains low, with only four cases in the past week, all unlinked.

site_title: SFF x Switch 2020 Ep 2: Tech boom in the Covid-19 era
summary: Singapore's tech industry experienced a boom during the Covid-19 era, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's managing director Ravi Menon discussing the sector's growth in an interview. The Singapore FinTech Festival, set to take place from Dec 7-11, will feature discussions on the industry's future. Key statistics mentioned include the oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer and Singapore's ranking as the world's top port for a 12th consecutive year.

site_title: Asia tech conference ditches Hong Kong for Malaysia
summary: A major Asia-focused tech conference, Rise Conference, has shifted its location from Hong Kong to Malaysia, citing a desire to attract tech talent. The annual conference, which has been held in Hong Kong for five years, will move to Kuala Lumpur in 2022. This move is seen as a blow to Hong Kong's efforts to boost its tech industry. Organisers cited Malaysia's more favorable business environment and lower costs as reasons for the change. The conference's relocation marks a significant shift in the region's tech landscape.

site_title: EU-Singapore trade held steady despite pandemic; both sides must 'stay the course' on free trade: Iswaran
summary: Singapore and the European Union maintained steady bilateral trade despite the pandemic, with the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) continuing to promote an open rules-based multilateral trading system. Minister-in-Charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran emphasized the importance of "staying the course" on free trade, as populist pressures mount globally. The EUSFTA, signed in 2019, serves as a symbol of excellent bilateral relations and has helped to foster economic cooperation between the two parties.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.74% on Thursday, following a broader Asia advance, driven by a push in Washington to agree a new US economic stimulus. The Hang Seng Index ended at 26,728.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21%. The gains were in line with global market trends, which were boosted by economic stimulus discussions.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund seeks up to US$7b loan for investments
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is seeking up to $7 billion in loans from international banks to fund new investments. The PIF aims to raise the funds through a multi-currency revolving facility and plans to complete the fundraising early next year. The fund will use the cash for opportunistic investments, following a successful $11 billion loan in 2018 and a $10 billion bridge loan repayment in 2020. The PIF's funding strategy includes borrowing, retained earnings, and asset transfers from the government.

site_title: Singapore ranked world's second-most connected country in DHL index
summary: Singapore has been ranked the world's second-most connected country in the 2020 DHL Global Connectedness Index, with the Netherlands taking the top spot by just 2 points. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Singapore's international flows in goods, capital, information, and people relative to its domestic economy remain high, with the country maintaining its position from the previous edition. The pandemic has transformed global connections, with digital flows surging and international trade and investment recovering, but the world's level of global connectedness is set to decline in 2020.

site_title: Alibaba's Cainiao in talks with China vaccine makers over logistics
summary: Alibaba's logistics arm Cainiao is in talks with Chinese vaccine makers to provide Covid-19 vaccine logistics. Cainiao aims to deliver vaccines globally in 72 hours, and has partnered with Ethiopian Airlines to transport temperature-sensitive medicines. China has multiple vaccine developers in final clinical trials, and the partnership is China's first cross-border medical cold chain route. This move is crucial in the pandemic, where vaccines require specific temperature control for storage and transportation.

site_title: US toughens visa rules for 'malign' Chinese Communist Party members
summary: The US has issued new visa rules restricting travel to the US by Chinese Communist Party members and their families, limiting their visas to one month and a single entry. Previously, party members could obtain 10-year visas. The move is part of efforts to protect the US from the party's "malign influence" amid strained relations between the two nations, which have sunk to historic lows. The Trump administration aims to cement its tough-on-China legacy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up on vaccine hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks edged up 0.03% on Thursday, driven by optimism over coronavirus vaccines, which deflated selling pressure after a recent surge. The Nikkei 225 index rose 8.39 points to 26,809.37, while the Topix index gained 1.28 points to 1,775.25.

site_title: Nestle to invest 3.2b Swiss francs to cut carbon emmissions
summary: Nestle plans to invest 3.2 billion Swiss francs (S$4.79 billion) over five years to cut carbon emissions and reach net zero by 2050. The company aims to halve emissions by 2030 and use 100% renewable electricity at 800 global sites by 2025. It will also promote regenerative agriculture, plant 20 million trees annually for 10 years, and offset business travel by 2022. Nestle plans to source ingredients from farmers using regenerative practices, with 14 million tonnes expected by 2030.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie to buy Waddell & Reed Financial for US$1.7b
summary: Macquarie Group has agreed to buy US-based investment management firm Waddell & Reed Financial for US$1.7 billion in cash, expanding its retail footprint. The deal, valued at US$25 per share, represents a 48% premium to Waddell's last closing price. Macquarie's CEO, Shemara Wikramanayake, led the asset management unit that made the acquisition. The deal is expected to close in mid-2021 and will place Macquarie as a top-25 actively managed mutual fund manager in the US.

site_title: Vanguard loses US$590m stock mandate from Taiwan funds
summary: Vanguard Group lost a US$590 million stock mandate from Taiwan funds due to weak performance. The assets, managed under an Asia-Pacific mixed index mandate, returned 13% since 2016, compared to the benchmark's 26% gain. The loss marks a blow to Vanguard's Asian operations as it reshuffles its portfolio. The mandate was redeemed prematurely, according to a Bureau of Labor Funds update posted in December.

site_title: Libor needs a legislative fix even if demise has been delayed
summary: Delaying the end of dollar Libor until mid-2023 may provide temporary relief, but it doesn't address the need for a legislative solution for hundreds of billions of dollars in legacy contracts linked to the benchmark. The Alternative Reference Rates Committee (ARRC) chairman, Tom Wipf, warns that many of these contracts, including Libor mortgages and student loans, will still be outstanding after the 2023 deadline, posing a threat to financial stability. A legislative fix is still necessary to ensure a smooth transition and protect financial markets.

site_title: Hong Kong's auction market is soaring as New York stumbles
summary: Hong Kong's auction market is thriving, with Christie's sale of 19th, 20th, and 21st-century artworks achieving six world records. In contrast, New York's leg of the sale largely disappointed, with only a few lots selling above estimates. Despite a live audience in Hong Kong, which reported fewer COVID-19 cases, New York's auction house specialists bid via phone and text, with many lots failing to find buyers. The result highlights a return to the old normal in the art market, where in-person interactions are valued over digital ones.

site_title: JD Logistics seeks bank pitches for Hong Kong IPO of up to US$3b: sources
summary: JD Logistics, a subsidiary of Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com, is seeking bank pitches for a Hong Kong IPO of up to US$3 billion. The logistics business was spun off in 2017 and is expected to raise between US$2 billion and US$3 billion. Investment banks UBS, Bank of America, and Haitong Securities are in the running for the lead role, following presentations on November 27. The IPO is expected to be launched in the first half of 2021, with no firm target set yet.

site_title: Indonesian President calls on central bank to take bigger role in reforms
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged Bank Indonesia to take a more significant role in the country's reforms, particularly in job creation and economic growth. He hopes the central bank will contribute to mobilizing the real sector and creating new jobs. This comes after his administration and parliament's financial commission filed a draft bill expanding BI's mandate to include economic growth and employment. The exact reforms Widodo referred to are unclear, but the move suggests a potential increase in central bank involvement in the country's economic policies.

site_title: Westpac signs enforceable undertaking with regulator due to weak risk controls
summary: Westpac Banking Corp agreed to a court-backed enforceable undertaking with Australia's banking regulator, APRA, due to "long-standing weaknesses" in its risk controls and poor oversight. The regulator stated Westpac failed to improve risk governance despite two years of remediation, contributing to a lawsuit and fine over improper payments. The bank must develop and fund a remediation plan, have progress reviewed quarterly, and integrate it into executive remuneration metrics within 90 days. This follows a breach of capital requirements and undermines APRA's confidence in Westpac's ability to remediate weaknesses.

site_title: US Jewish doctor tweets on treating Covid patient with Nazi tattoos
summary: A California doctor, Taylor Nichols, shared his shock after treating a severely ill patient with neo-Nazi tattoos, sparking conflicting emotions due to the pandemic's toll on his mental health. The patient, who begged for help, was intubated and Nichols did everything he could to save his life. However, seeing the hate symbols on the patient's body made Nichols feel ambivalent and took a toll on his compassion, highlighting the challenges of working in a hospital treating vulnerable populations during the pandemic.

site_title: Employment rose to pre-Covid levels after Singapore's 'circuit breaker'
summary: Employment in Singapore rose to pre-Covid levels in the third quarter, with 80.3% of residents aged 25-64 in their prime working age holding jobs. However, real median income dipped 0.3% in 2020. The employment rate for women remained stable, while men's rates eased by 0.9%. The employment rate for youths aged 15-24 declined by 3.0 percentage points due to a longer stay in school and part-time work. The resident unemployment rate for professionals increased by 0.6%, with industries harder hit by Covid-19 having a higher concentration of non-PMETs.

site_title: KKR nears US$800m US warehouse deal with e-commerce booming
summary: KKR is nearing a deal to acquire a US warehouse portfolio valued at over US$800 million. The 100 properties, located in cities such as Atlanta, Chicago, and Baltimore, will be financed by Barclays with US$700 million in commercial mortgage-backed securities. The deal reflects the growing demand for warehouses as e-commerce continues to boom, with KKR increasing its exposure to the sector to 30 million square feet. This acquisition is part of KKR's broader strategy to capitalize on the e-commerce trend, which is expected to drive demand for large distribution centers.

site_title: Gold rises to over one-week high on sagging US dollar
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-week high, reaching US$1,835.37 per ounce, due to the weakening US dollar amid hopes for coronavirus vaccine roll-outs and potential US stimulus. The dollar's near 2-1/2-year low favored riskier assets and supported gold. A bipartisan US stimulus proposal and vaccine progress also contributed to the gold price increase. However, experts noted that much of the vaccine optimism is already priced in by markets, and the long-term impact on gold prices may be limited.

site_title: Japan set to ban sales of new petrol cars in mid-2030s: reports
summary: Japan plans to ban the sale of new petrol cars in the mid-2030s as part of efforts to reach carbon neutrality by 2050. This move is part of a push to promote electric and hybrid vehicles, building on existing efforts to curb CO2 emissions. The country aims to increase the share of low-emission cars to 50-70% by 2030. The announcement is expected to be made next week, following Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's 2050 deadline for carbon neutrality. This move has been welcomed by activists and the UN, despite Japan's heavy reliance on fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: Japan wants to ban sales of new petrol cars in around 15 years' time as part of efforts to reach carbon neutrality by 2050, reports said Thursday.

site_title: WeChat deletes Australian PM's appeal to Chinese community
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's appeal to the Chinese community on WeChat has been deleted, with the platform citing "misleading words" as the reason. The post promoted Australia as a "free, democratic, liberal country" amidst a diplomatic spat between the two nations. WeChat's action has been criticized by Australia's Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, who said the move was "unnecessary" and Australia won't back down on its grievances against China, including meddling in Hong Kong and the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Ivanka Trump questioned under oath in lawsuit over use of inauguration funds
summary: Ivanka Trump was questioned under oath in a civil lawsuit alleging misuse of nonprofit funds for Donald Trump's 2017 inauguration. The District of Columbia Attorney General's office claims the Trump family's real estate business and other entities misused funds to enrich themselves. The lawsuit alleges the nonprofit overpaid for event space at the Trump International Hotel, with one instance involving a private reception for Ivanka, Donald Jr., and Eric Trump costing over $300,000. The suit seeks to recover $1 million allegedly funneled to the Trump family business.

site_title: Half of Singapore consumers prefer to shop local to help Covid-hit firms: poll
summary: Around half of Singapore consumers prefer to shop at local businesses to help them recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a UOB survey of 1,000 respondents. This desire to support local businesses is not unique to Singapore, with over 60% of consumers across South-east Asia wanting to stand in solidarity with their local businesses. The study also found that affluent consumers are more likely to support sustainable businesses, with 54% of consumers across Asean wanting to buy from brands that use sustainable practices.

site_title: Google violated US labour laws in clampdown on worker organising: regulator
summary: The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) has issued a complaint against Google alleging the company violated US labor laws by unlawfully monitoring and questioning employees who were protesting against company policies and trying to organize a union. Google was accused of placing employees on administrative leave and terminating them for accessing documents related to internal forums and meetings rooms. The complaint also found Google's tactics aimed at deterring workplace organizing. Google has said it acted legally and will respond to the complaint by December 16. The case could lead to reinstatement of fired workers and changes in company policies.

site_title: Davos may move to Singapore as WEF holds talks on 2021 location
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has held preliminary talks with Singapore officials about relocating its 2021 Davos meeting due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak in Europe. The WEF is considering alternative locations, including Singapore, but no decision has been made. The event, which typically brings world leaders and celebrities, has already been postponed from January to May. The WEF plans to make a decision by Christmas, prioritizing health and safety.

site_title: StanChart launches global learning hub; to train, upskill 8,000 staff by 2022
summary: Standard Chartered has launched a global learning hub, diSCover Lab, to train and upskill 8,000 Singapore staff by 2022. The hub offers a hybrid approach of virtual and face-to-face training in areas such as blockchain, data, AI, and personal development. The bank invested S$5 million to strengthen its Singapore workforce and support its digitalisation and business growth plans. The diSCover Lab brings together nine future skills academies and partners with tertiary institutions, government agencies, and industry partners to hire and train talent in future growth areas.

site_title: Growth in China's services sector soars on stronger consumer demand: Caixin
summary: China's services sector growth accelerated in November, reaching 57.8 on the Caixin/Markit PMI, the second-highest reading since 2010. New business rose at the fastest pace in over a decade, with new export business expanding for the first time in five months. Services firms hired more workers and business confidence improved, suggesting a further recovery in consumer demand. Analysts expect the recovery momentum to continue for several months, with China's economy expected to grow about 2% in 2020.

site_title: Private housing supply from confirmed land sale sites up 17.2% for H1 2021: MND
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) announced a 17.2% increase in the supply of private housing units from confirmed land sale sites for the first-half 2021 government land sales (GLS) programme. This marks the first significant increase in supply since 2017, driven by healthy demand in the market. Developers are experiencing a much-needed boost to their land inventory, with Huttons Asia's director of research attributing the increase to the strong demand in the market.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as miners ride iron ore rally, rival drops forecast
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a three-month high, driven by a rally in iron ore prices and a downgraded forecast by Brazilian mining rival Vale, benefiting miners BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,616.8, marking its third consecutive gain session. Financials declined 0.3%, with Qantas Airways' shares slipping 1.1% despite a boost from the reopening of Australian state borders.

site_title: Hong Kong pro-democracy media tycoon charged with fraud
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, 73, has been charged with fraud, the latest in a string of prosecutions against high-profile democracy campaigners. Lai, owner of pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily, faces charges related to allegedly using company offices for unauthorized purposes. The charges come amid a clampdown in Hong Kong since China imposed a national security law in June, with opposition politicians disqualified and activists charged or investigated. Lai has long feared authorities want to shut down his newspaper, which has vocally taken on Beijing.

site_title: US venture capital investments exceed 2019 levels despite pandemic gloom
summary: US venture capital investments exceeded $137.3 billion in 2019, surpassing the 2020 total of $139.6 billion, despite the initial pandemic slowdown. This marks the third consecutive year US venture capital investments have exceeded $100 billion. The growth can be attributed to remote work and an e-commerce boom.

site_title: Nomura to hire 100 for Asia wealth, fixed income expansion
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to hire 100 new staff in Asia for its wealth and fixed income businesses, with a focus on private bankers and fixed income professionals. The move aims to bolster the firm's presence in the region, where competition for high-net-worth individuals is increasing and interest rates remain higher than in developed economies. The hires will be made over the next two to three years, with a goal to boost assets under management in Asia to $35 billion.

site_title: Battered but unbowed by coronavirus, Tokyo's gay district forges stronger ties
summary: Tokyo's Shinjuku Ni-chome gay district, a haven for Japan's LGBT community, has shown resilience despite the coronavirus pandemic. When the district became a ghost town in April, bar owners and landlords slashed rents, with some crowdfunded to stay afloat. The community has come together, with Tamashiro, a former closeted individual, now running a bar. Despite challenges, Ni-chome remains a vital hub for the LGBT community in Japan, where some gay men still marry women. Efforts to support the district have been ongoing, with local business leaders and government officials working together to ensure its survival.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate after rally, eyes on US stimulus talks
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Thursday, struggling to build on last month's rally, as investors awaited US stimulus talks and vaccine rollouts. Despite Britain's approval of a Covid-19 drug, optimism had largely been priced in, with near-term virus concerns keeping advances in check. The focus now shifts to US and European regulators, and the rollout that will allow economies to recover. Markets are also watching US-EU tariffs and the impact of US President Trump's threats on the stock rally.

site_title: Australia says international borders to stay shut for 'some time' despite vaccine progress
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that international borders will likely remain closed for "some time" despite progress in COVID-19 vaccine rollouts. The approval of the Pfizer vaccine in Britain has sparked hopes for rapid global inoculations, but Australia will continue to keep its borders shut to non-Australian citizens and non-permanent residents. This decision aims to protect the country from the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.34% on Thursday, driven by growing hopes of a US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index increased 90.84 points to 26,623.42. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index barely moved, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.08%. The gains come as US lawmakers close in on a stimulus package for the stuttering US economy, lifting investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rose at the start of business Thursday morning on growing hopes Washington lawmakers are closing in on a much-needed stimulus package for the stuttering US economy.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia debuts on SGX S$1.15, 23.7% above IPO price
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$1.15, 23.7% above its IPO price of S$0.93 per share. The company received strong interest from institutional and other investors, with 60.8 times oversubscription for its public offering and cornerstone investors subscribing for 28 million new shares. CBA raised S$23.6 million, with plans to use S$11.8 million for strategic investments and S$7.1 million for organic growth initiatives.

site_title: Indonesian tech consumers outpace global peers in electronics appetite
summary: Indonesian consumers are highly enthusiastic about technology, with 31% classified as "early adopters" of tech, surpassing the global average of 18%. These early adopters are predominantly young males with higher disposable income, more likely to buy new smartphones in the next six months. The country's large and receptive consumer audience presents opportunities for businesses targeting South-east Asia, while the government's incentives for electric cars could increase sales volume. The recently-signed Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership may also benefit the digital sector and attract investments for Indonesia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.97 points, or 0.19%, to 1,601.69 on Thursday, with 228.43 million lots traded. Gainers outpaced losers 270 to 69.

site_title: Boeing's upgraded 737 MAX completes first flight with media onboard
summary: Boeing's 737 MAX completed its first post-grounding flight with media on board, marking a step towards commercial service on December 29. The 45-minute flight from Dallas to Tulsa was part of a public relations effort to address concerns about the aircraft's safety. The flight came weeks after the US Federal Aviation Administration cleared the jet following design changes and new training. Boeing is bracing for intense publicity and has set up a 24-hour "situation room" to monitor every MAX flight globally. The move is seen as critical for Boeing's reputation and finances, which have been impacted by the grounding and the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Federal Reserve sees more signs activity slowing as optimism wanes
summary: The Federal Reserve reported that US economic activity slowed in November, with four regions experiencing little or no growth and four others seeing activity dip. Cases of Covid-19 surged, prompting authorities to reimpose restrictions, and businesses expressed concerns about the future. Despite positive outlooks, optimism has waned, and the recovery remains incomplete. Employment continued to rise, but at a slow pace. The Fed emphasized the need for more government aid to sustain the recovery, warning that small businesses may not survive the winter without it.

images.alt_text: More US regions saw economic activity stall or slow in November as Covid-19 cases surged, and businesses were less upbeat about their prospects, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's son partners Peter Thiel to set up US$595m blank-cheque company
summary: Billionaire Richard Li, son of Hong Kong's richest man Li Ka-shing, is partnering with PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel to establish a $595 million blank-cheque firm for acquiring South-east Asian companies. The move comes amid Hong Kong's political uncertainty, and Li has learned risk management from his father. The firm, Bridgetown Holdings, will focus on new economy sectors and has begun discussions with potential targets. Li's net worth is $4.9 billion, and he has a history of taking calculated risks, including a failed attempt to sell assets to overseas investors in 2006.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Geo Energy, Credit Bureau Asia, Addvalue Technologies
summary: Geo Energy Resources reached its coal reserve threshold, avoiding a mandatory note purchase. Credit Bureau Asia received 60.8 times more applications for its IPO than shares available. Addvalue Technologies partnered with Inmarsat and Pivotel for a connectivity solution for sport-fishing vessels. Singapore banks increased support for micro-enterprises with collateral-free loans, while CDW Holding posted a net profit of US$46,000 for the nine months ended September.

site_title: Former French President Giscard d'Estaing dies of Covid-19 at 94
summary: Former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, a key architect of European integration, has died at 94 after contracting Covid-19. He served as president from 1974 to 1981, modernizing French society and launching major projects, including the TGV train network. Giscard was known for his progressive policies, including allowing divorce by mutual consent and legalizing abortion. Tributes poured in from across the political spectrum, with former presidents and European leaders praising his legacy in European integration and modernizing France.

site_title: Total Covid cases in Americas up by 30% in one month
summary: The Pan American Health Organization reported a 30% surge in Covid-19 cases across the Americas in one month, from 20.5 million in October to 26.9 million by the end of November.

site_title: US states plan to sue Facebook next week: sources
summary: US states, led by New York, plan to sue Facebook next week over possible antitrust violations. The lawsuit, involving over 40 states, accuses Facebook of strategically buying small rivals, including Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014. The Federal Trade Commission is also considering a related complaint. This marks the second major lawsuit filed against a Big Tech company this year, following the Justice Department's lawsuit against Google in October. The exact details of the complaint remain unknown.

site_title: NBA says 48 players test positive for Covid-19
summary: The NBA announced 48 players tested positive for COVID-19 in a recent round of tests, with a positivity rate of 8.8%. This is a significant increase from the zero positive tests reported during the 2019-2020 quarantine bubble. The league will test all players daily throughout the season, with players who test positive required to refrain from workouts for at least 10 days. The NBA's first preseason games are set to begin on December 11.

images.alt_text: The NBA announced Wednesday that 48 players have tested positive for the coronavirus, a dramatic increase over the zero positive tests reported during last season's quarantine bubble in Florida.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100's surge on UK vaccine approval pulls shares off lows
summary: European stocks closed flat on Wednesday as London's FTSE 100 surged 1% on the UK's approval of Pfizer and BioNtech's Covid-19 vaccine. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended steady, with Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and HSBC among the biggest boosts. Germany's benchmark DAX index lagged, and the country is planning to extend restaurant and hotel restrictions until January 10. Despite the uncertainty, ING warns the unemployment rate points to a mild labour market impact from the crisis, bringing upside risk to the GDP outlook for next year.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened lower on Thursday, edging down 0.18% or 47.46 points to 26,753.52, amid profit-taking despite hopes for vaccines to tackle the new coronavirus. The broader Topix index rose 0.10%.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday, STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 2,798.81. Credit Bureau Asia made its trading debut, with shares rising 19.4% to S$1.11. Other local banks, including Singtel, DBS, and OCBC, fell, while Geo Energy Resources rose 6.4%. US stocks finished a choppy session mostly higher, with the S&P 500 reaching a record.

site_title: Trump expected to sign bill that could delist Chinese companies: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to sign a bill that could delist Chinese companies from US exchanges unless they comply with US auditing standards. The bill, passed by the Senate and House, would give companies three years to comply before being removed. Companies such as Alibaba, Pinduoduo, and PetroChina could be affected. If signed, the measure would increase pressure on Chinese companies listed on US exchanges to adhere to US auditing rules.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump is expected to sign a bill that could prevent some Chinese companies from listing their shares on US exchanges unless they adhere to US auditing standards, the White House said on Wednesday.

site_title: Biden set to revamp US trade tactics - but not policy
summary: President-elect Joe Biden plans to maintain the US's current trade policies, including tariffs on China, during his first term. He wants to focus on reviving the US economy and investing in domestic workers before entering new trade agreements. Biden has signaled a willingness to stick with the "phase one" deal with China and will not remove tariffs without concessions from Beijing. He aims to mend relations with US allies, particularly the European Union, which could give Washington a stronger position to press China for further concessions.

site_title: Over 1,000 Chinese researchers quit US; agents target Biden team: US officials
summary: Over 1,000 Chinese researchers have left the US amid a crackdown on alleged technology theft, US officials said. The researchers, affiliated with China's People's Liberation Army, fled after the FBI conducted interviews and the State Department closed China's Houston consulate. Chinese agents are also targeting the incoming Biden administration, according to the US Director of National Intelligence. The US Justice Department has launched multiple criminal cases against Chinese operatives for industrial and technological espionage. China has described the visa crackdown as "naked" political persecution and racial discrimination.

site_title: Oil prices rise on UK vaccine approval; signs Opec+ may maintain output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 1.75% on Wednesday, with Brent crude oil futures reaching $48.25 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $45.28 a barrel. The increase was driven by the UK's approval of a Covid-19 vaccine, boosting hopes for a demand recovery. Opec+ producers, including Russia, are expected to maintain output cuts of 7.7 million barrels per day, despite concerns from the UAE about its ability to continue deep reductions. US crude inventories fell 679,000 barrels, while oil production rose 100,000 barrels per day.

images.alt_text: Oil prices settled higher on Wednesday as Britain's approval of a Covid-19 vaccine boosted hopes for a demand recovery and on mounting expectations that producing countries will maintain output limits next year.

site_title: Benefits of the EUSFTA
summary: The European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) has several benefits, including increased trade opportunities, reduced tariffs, and enhanced investment. The agreement aims to boost economic growth, create jobs, and promote innovation. Key benefits include improved market access, streamlined regulatory processes, and increased competition. The agreement also aims to protect intellectual property rights and promote sustainable development. Overall, the EUSFTA is expected to enhance economic cooperation between the EU and Singapore, promoting a more interconnected and prosperous region.

site_title: US expects 100 million people vaccinated by February
summary: The US aims to vaccinate 100 million people against Covid-19 by the end of February, covering approximately 40% of the adult population. This plan, set to start in mid-December, prioritizes the elderly, healthcare workers, and first responders. The vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna-NIH are expected to be approved, with the first doses scheduled for delivery on December 15. The goal is to reach 20 million, 30 million, and 50 million people in December, January, and February, respectively, with the total exceeding 100 million.

site_title: JL Family Office unveils boutique property investment firm
summary: JL Family Office has launched a boutique property investment firm, The Land Managers Holdings, with an initial capital commitment of S$250 million. The firm will focus on value-add and developmental opportunities in Singapore, Europe, and Greater China. Its first acquisition is a shophouse in Singapore, with plans to expand into the UK, Germany, and Greater China. The firm aims to achieve decent yields, targeting investment ticket sizes between S$20 million and S$50 million. With its initial capital, The Land Managers plans to grow the business steadily over the next five to 10 years.

images.alt_text: "My father told me from a very early stage in my career that while he co-founded ARA , it was never meant to be a family business." - Andy Lim, founder of The Land Managers and group CEO of JL Family Office

site_title: Trump floats idea of 2024 White House run
summary: Donald Trump is musing about a potential 2024 White House run despite losing the 2020 presidential election to Joe Biden. Trump's lawyers and supporters continue to file lawsuits and call for extraordinary intervention, such as martial law, to force a new vote. Trump released a 46-minute video claiming he was robbed of victory in a "rigged" election.

site_title: Home to a robust fintech sector
summary: European Union is home to a robust fintech sector, driven by the use of technology to bridge gaps in services provided by traditional banks. The sector has evolved significantly since the 2008 global financial crisis, influenced by trends, regulations, and innovations such as open banking, digital economy, and cryptocurrency. The EU is now home to over 40 companies valued above $1 billion, with opportunities in alternative banking, payments, wealth management, and insurance. Countries like Singapore and Poland have established themselves as fintech hubs, with Singapore's regulatory approach and Poland's mobile payment system showcasing their commitment to innovation.

site_title: China edges past US as Europe's top trade partner
summary: China surpassed the US as Europe's top trade partner in the third quarter of 2020, with total trade between the EU and China reaching 425.5 billion euros, compared to 412.5 billion euros with the US. This marks the first time China has taken the top spot, as the EU's trade with China increased 4.5% while US trade decreased 11.4% and 10.0% in imports and exports, respectively, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the US economy.

site_title: DBS, StanChart slash savings rates further
summary: DBS and Standard Chartered (StanChart) will slash savings rates for their respective accounts starting January 1, 2021, due to a grim interest rate environment. DBS will cut interest rates on its Multiplier account, with tiered rates reduced for customers who meet specific transaction requirements. StanChart will lower its Jumpstart savings account interest rate to 0.4% for the first S$20,000, with higher rates for balances above S$20,000. The cuts follow a series of rate reductions by other financial institutions, including OCBC and UOB.

site_title: Yellen and dollar diplomacy - US Treasury has much to fix
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen must address the damage caused by former President Donald Trump's currency policy, which undermined the dollar's global role. Trump's administration confused markets with conflicting policies, including talking down the dollar while using trade actions to boost it. This approach, combined with unilateral sanctions and protectionist tariffs, eroded the dollar's credibility. Yellen must now correct this course and restore the dollar's stability, which will require improving domestic economic performance and adopting a more coordinated foreign exchange approach.

site_title: G.H.Y Culture & Media set to be SGX's third non-Reit mainboard listing this year
summary: G.H.Y Culture & Media Holding Co, a Cayman Islands-incorporated entertainment and content provider, is set to become SGX's third non-Reit mainboard listing this year. The company has lodged its preliminary prospectus and secured cornerstone investors, including Epical Entertainment and OSIM International. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to invest in production, acquisitions, and strategic alliances to expand its TV programme and film production business segments. The company aims to use 30% of its net profit after tax for dividends, with a net profit of S$13.1 million in the first half of 2020.

site_title: Salesforce to buy Slack in US$27.7b megadeal
summary: Salesforce has agreed to acquire Slack in a US$27.7 billion deal, set to close next year pending shareholder and regulatory approval. The acquisition will mesh Slack's messaging technology with Salesforce's platform for managing marketing and sales teams, aiming to challenge Microsoft's dominance in online collaboration and productivity. Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff sees the deal as a strategic move to shape the future of enterprise software and transform the way people work in a remote world.

site_title: The real class war in the US is within the rich
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's nominations for Treasury Secretary and Secretary of State reflect a "restoration of their deposed oligarchy," with Ivy League graduates and Wall Street executives dominating key positions. Peter Turchin's theory of "elite overproduction" suggests that a surplus of educated graduates has led to resentment among those who feel excluded from the elite. This surplus has contributed to the rise of populism, with the "not-quite-elite" and underemployed humanities graduates forming an alliance with more genuinely aggrieved groups. The theory also applies to Brexit and the populist right, highlighting a potential reckoning for liberals and populists alike.

site_title: Netflix plans to double its spending on original content in Asia
summary: Netflix plans to double its spending on original content in Asia in 2021, aiming to cement its stronghold in the region, which saw the fastest growth in subscribers. The move is expected to be at least $1 billion, following its current investment of nearly $2 billion since 2018. The company seeks to tackle rivals such as Disney+, Amazon Prime Video, and WeTV, while also navigating increased regulatory scrutiny and competition from local platforms. Netflix aims to maintain its 35% market share in the Asia-Pacific region and expand its presence in India and Southeast Asia.

site_title: US: S&P 500 edges to another record in mixed Wall Street session
summary: US stocks closed at record levels on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 rising 0.2% to 3,669.01. Despite mixed signals on the economy, investors were boosted by news of a Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine clearing the way for global vaccination efforts. Boeing surged 5.1% after a test flight of the 737 MAX, while Pfizer shares rose 3.5%. However, Salesforce dropped 8.6% after announcing a $27.7 billion acquisition of Slack Technologies.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished a choppy session mostly higher on Wednesday as investors weighed signs of economic weakness caused by rising Covid-19 cases against further progress on vaccines.

site_title: Evergrande Property eases on HK debut
summary: Evergrande Property Services' Hong Kong debut saw its shares fall marginally, shedding initial gains, due to concerns over debt and competition. The spinoff of China's second-largest property developer raised US$1.8 billion but struggled to shake off worries about its parent company's financial health. Shares of China Evergrande also fell, and the Hong Kong market declined 1%. Experts attribute the lukewarm response to concerns over the parent company's high debt level and restructuring prospects.

site_title: Qantas to start repairing finances by June as local demand jumps
summary: Qantas Airways expects to repair its finances by June 2021, with a rebound in domestic sales after major state borders in Australia reopened. The airline will fly its normal domestic schedule next quarter and generate enough cash to begin fixing its balance sheet. Qantas is optimistic about the recovery, with its domestic network expected to be the profit engine of the group. International flights are unlikely until at least July 2021, and Qantas expects to post a "substantial" net loss for the year ending June 2021.

site_title: Barnier says no guarantee of Brexit trade deal as talks grind on
summary: European Union Chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned that there is no guarantee of a trade deal with Britain before the end of the year, despite intense negotiations. The talks have blown through several deadlines, with some diplomats expressing frustration and concerns that the EU is giving in too much to UK demands. The UK is optimistic about striking a deal, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson is also prepared to move on without one. The talks' outcome will be decided in the next few days, with the EU and UK needing to ratify any agreement by December 31.

images.alt_text: Chief EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned on Wednesday he can not guarantee he will strike a trade deal with Britain before the end of the year, but London insisted it was still optimistic.

site_title: HDB 'lottery' conundrum: analysts weigh in on ways to mitigate it
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats, particularly those in prime areas, have raised concerns about affordability due to the "lottery effect." When certain flats completed their 5-year minimum occupation period (MOP), they were sold for 60-70% gain, sparking worries about gentrification. Analysts suggest measures such as shorter leases, longer MOPs, and resale buyer income caps to mitigate the issue, but there are no simple answers due to the complexity of the problem. The government is considering measures to keep prices affordable, but the implementation of a resale levy or capital gains tax is more likely, according to experts.

site_title: In banking, size is becoming a strength in fintech battle
summary: Traditional banks are redefining their approach to compete with fintech companies, leveraging their size and scale to anticipate emerging customer needs and deliver societal impact. By tapping into their vast customer data, banks can identify deep insights and build models that predict customer behavior with high accuracy. This foundation allows them to redefine their role and invest in services that deliver real value and sustainable financial health to customers, making them more attractive and relevant in people's daily lives.

site_title: Dim sum in the EU? SBF aims to help Singapore companies make inroads into Europe
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) aims to help Singaporean food manufacturers tap into the European Union market, leveraging the recently signed EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA). The agreement allows for tariff-free entry of certain Asian food products, with a combined quota of 1,250 tonnes per year. SBF plans to reach out to companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), to generate demand and facilitate trade. The Federation also hopes to establish online marketplaces and business-to-business connections to boost networking among companies.

site_title: Thailand plans 43.5b baht of additional stimulus to spur consumption
summary: Thailand plans a 43.5 billion baht ($1.9 billion) stimulus package to boost domestic consumption, with 22.5 billion baht going to 5 million new consumers and 1,500 baht to 14 million low-income earners. The package aims to revive the economy, which is expected to contract by 6% this year due to the pandemic. The government predicts a recovery to pre-pandemic levels of 40 million visitors by 2024, with tourism expected to take two years to recover.

site_title: A concerted push to create more jobs and boost economic growth
summary: The European Union's Ambassador to Singapore, Barbara Plinkert, emphasizes the importance of implementing the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) to boost economic growth and create more jobs. She highlights the agreement's potential to provide a level playing field for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and enhance market access, ultimately contributing to the EU and Singapore's deeper economic integration and convergence in setting standards.

site_title: America's 'little land mines' could prevent a summertime boom
summary: The US economy may experience a rapid recovery by summer as vaccines become widely available. However, a cold winter is predicted, which could cause damage to the economy and hinder rapid healing. The development of vaccines and easing of public health conditions will be crucial in preventing long-term economic damage. The outcome will depend on the actions of the US Congress, which must make key decisions for the winter economy.

site_title: EU-Singapore FTA continues to open doors for companies a year on
summary: The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) has reached its one-year anniversary since entering into force on January 1, 2020. The agreement, the first between the EU and an Asean country, aims to strengthen trade and investment links between both markets. It has been successful in opening doors for companies, with key benefits including reduced tariffs and increased market access. The agreement continues to be a positive development for businesses and investors in both regions.

site_title: Canada plans new tax for foreign home buyers to curb speculative purchases
summary: Canada is planning a new tax on foreign home buyers to curb speculative purchases, following a rise in housing prices that has left many Canadians unable to afford homes. The tax is expected to be outlined in the spring budget, with the goal of ensuring foreign owners pay their fair share. This measure comes as Canada's home prices have risen 88.3% in the last decade, with detached properties in smaller centers driving recent gains. The government aims to balance housing affordability with foreign demand.

site_title: Get the year-end celebrations going
summary: This year-end special issue, BTLuxe Christmas, showcases how people are making the most of the holiday season amidst the pandemic. The article features interviews with celebrities, industrial designers, and business owners, offering a luxury spin on Christmas celebrations. It also includes tips and recipes for home cooks and decorating ideas, as well as suggestions for far-flung destinations for next year's Christmas travel. The issue aims to inspire readers to make the most of the festive season, despite the challenges of 2020.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia's IPO 60.8 times subscribed
summary: Credit Bureau Asia's initial public offering (IPO) received 60.8 times the number of shares subscribed by retail investors, with 91.3 million shares and S$84.9 million in application monies. Institutional investors also showed strong interest, subscribing for 5% or more of the offering shares. The company's market value at the IPO price of S$0.93 per share is expected to be about S$214.3 million. The IPO is seen as a vote of confidence in the company's resilient business model and growth plans.

site_title: Strong IP regime essential for FrieslandCampina's innovation efforts
summary: FrieslandCampina, a top European dairy cooperative, emphasizes the importance of a strong intellectual property (IP) regime in driving innovation. The company's regional office in Singapore, which opened in 2011, plays a key role in developing dairy-based beverages and infant nutrition products for Asian markets. With the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) now in force, FrieslandCampina sees opportunities for growth, including increasing its pool of R&D talents and potentially turning its Singapore Development Centre into a global hub.

site_title: Shared outlook, mutual interests cement firm EU-Singapore ties
summary: The European Union (EU) and Singapore have a strong and growing bilateral relationship, anchored by significant trade, investment, and people-to-people ties. The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) is a high-standard agreement containing tariff liberalization, market access commitments, and provisions on 21st-century trade issues. The EUSFTA has been in effect since 2019 and has helped bolster the EU's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic by facilitating trade and investment. The EU and Singapore are also exploring opportunities in the digital economy, with potential for the ASEAN region's internet economy to treble to $300 billion by 2025.

site_title: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi raises US$3.9b in equity deal
summary: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp has raised US$3.91 billion in an equity deal, including Hong Kong's largest top-up placement since 2006. The deal involves the sale of one billion shares at a price of HK$23.70 (S$4.09), surpassing CNOOC's 2006 placement. Xiaomi's total raising now stands at US$3.91 billion, with a convertible bond deal also finalized. The company's stock has risen 147.5% this year, but analysts see the deal as manageable for the market.

site_title: Thai PM wins crucial legal battle to stay in office
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha survived a constitutional court challenge over his living arrangements, which could have led to his removal from office. The nine-judge court ruled that Prayut was not guilty of conflict of interest by residing in an army residence after leaving the military. This decision allows Prayut to remain in office despite months of street protests. The ruling is seen as a victory for Prayut, who has faced opposition from various quarters, including his own daughter's ethics case.

site_title: Leveraging the EU-Singapore FTA to export Asian food products
summary: The European Union's food and beverage sector is the largest contributor to jobs and value-added, with exports doubling over the last decade. EU companies can leverage the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement to export Asian food products to the EU, with Singapore's strong quality and standards infrastructure positioning it as an ideal partner for trade. Countries like France, the Netherlands, and Poland also offer opportunities for food companies to establish a presence in the EU market, with each country having unique strengths and export specialties.

site_title: US dollar recovers from 2½-year low
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% against a basket of major currencies, reaching its highest level since April 2018, as investors awaited further fiscal stimulus in the US. A bipartisan group of senators and House members proposed $908 billion in Covid-19 relief measures, while US Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi held talks on stimulus. The euro set an all-year high against the dollar, but analysts expect it to be pressured by the European Central Bank's potential rate cut.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CDW Holding, a precision components maker, reported a US$46,000 net profit for the nine months ended September, reversing a US$1.94 million loss from a year ago. Revenue rose 7.9% to US$76.18 million, driven by a recovery in the LCD backlight units segment. Meanwhile, Addvalue Technologies partnered with Inmarsat and Pivotel to offer connectivity solutions for US fishing vessels, following regulatory changes.

site_title: US House to approve Bill blocking China firms from US markets
summary: The US House of Representatives is expected to pass the "Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act" bill, which would block Chinese companies from listing on US exchanges unless they comply with US auditing standards within three years. The bill, sponsored by Republican Senator John Kennedy and Democratic Senator Chris Van Hollen, aims to address concerns over Chinese companies' lack of transparency and audit practices. If passed, the bill would also require public companies to disclose ownership or control by a foreign government.

site_title: US accuses China of 'flagrant violation' of sanctions against North Korea
summary: The US has accused China of violating international sanctions on North Korea, describing it as a "flagrant violation." The US will offer up to $5 million in rewards for information about sanctions evasions. Deputy Assistant Secretary Alex Wong warned of new US sanctions against China-based individuals and entities. The US aims to enforce a UN sanctions regime aimed at persuading North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons.

site_title: Tariff elimination, dispute resolution mechanism are EUSFTA highlights for Patec
summary: Patec, a Singapore-based engineering solutions provider, has seen benefits from the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), which went into effect in November 2019. The agreement eliminates tariffs for over 80% of Singapore's exports to the EU, providing opportunities for the company to expand its business. The EUSFTA also offers a dispute resolution mechanism, reducing the need for costly and complicated legal battles. With the agreement, Patec has been able to lower its product prices and improve its competitiveness in the European market, with Deputy CEO Kelvin Wee citing the EU's strong engineering and design capabilities, and the presence of over 500 million consumers as key advantages.

site_title: Singapore an ideal hub to steer growth in Asia
summary: Evonik, a specialty chemical company, has chosen Singapore as a key node in its global network due to its robust intellectual property regime and "open mindset" of Asia. The company has a long history in Singapore, with its first office established in 1969, and has invested over $1.6 billion in the country over the past five years. Evonik has also established an Asia Research Hub in Singapore, focusing on additive manufacturing and other growth topics. The company credits supportive government agencies, a robust talent pool, and a culture of trying and failing for its continued investment in the country.

images.alt_text: From left: Dr Sher Lin Ee, head of Digital Lab Asia, and Shirley Qi, regional president, Evonik South East Asia, New Zealand & Australia. "In Asia, we start quick and we start small. If we fail, we try again," says Ms Qi.

site_title: Vietnam PM orders halt to international commercial flights
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc has ordered the halt of international commercial flights following the nation's first local coronavirus cases in almost three months. Rescue flights bringing Vietnamese citizens home from abroad are allowed to continue. The Ho Chi Minh City government is tasked with tracing and isolating those who came into contact with the infected individuals.

site_title: An attractive market for consumer goods
summary: The European Union, with a population of 446 million and high purchasing power, is an attractive market for consumer goods producers. The EU's e-commerce sector is rapidly growing, expected to be worth 717 billion euros by the end of 2020, with a 12.7% increase from the previous year. This presents a significant opportunity for businesses looking to expand into the EU market.

site_title: The EU and Singapore: strong partners for open, fair and free trade
summary: The EU and Singapore have strengthened their economic ties through the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), which came into force in November 2019. The agreement promotes free, fair, and open trade, providing preferential market access for European and Singaporean companies. The EU and Singapore aim to work together to mitigate the effects of climate change, promote sustainable development, and reform global economic governance. As the global economy recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic, the EU and Singapore are committed to deepening their partnership and promoting sustainable growth.

site_title: South Korea passes law to allow BTS to postpone military service to age 30
summary: South Korea's parliament passed a law allowing globally recognized K-pop artists, including BTS, to postpone their mandatory military service to age 30. The amendment aims to boost the country's cultural status and economy, with the oldest member of BTS, 27-year-old Jin, nearing enlistment. This move comes after a poll showed 53% of respondents supported special treatment for BTS, while 47% opposed it. The law provides exceptions for artists who improve the country's cultural status and will ensure entertainers recommended by the culture minister can defer their service to age 30.

site_title: Singapore banks boost support for micro businesses
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB have increased support for micro businesses with collateral-free loans, totaling over $1.3 billion since March 2020. DBS has approved over 10,000 loans to SMEs, with more than 5,000 going to micro enterprises, and has simplified credit documentation processes.
