summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe signaled the need for policy support due to a bumpy and uneven economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. He stated that economic growth is expected to be "solidly positive" in the September and December quarters, but unemployment remains high, and wage increases and inflation are too low. Lowe reiterated that a policy of negative interest rates is unlikely, and the bank will continue to use its tools to address high unemployment. The RBA also left its cash rate at a record low 0.1% and maintained its A$100 billion quantitative easing program.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records on vaccine, stimulus hopes
summary: US stock indices closed at records on Tuesday, driven by optimism over potential coronavirus vaccines and revived stimulus talks. The S&P 500 rose 1.1% to 3,662.45, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.3% to 12,355.11, both setting new highs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.6% to 29,823.92. The gains offset concerns over rising Covid-19 cases.

images.alt_text: Major US stock indices closed at records again on Tuesday as optimism over potential coronavirus vaccines and revived stimulus talks in Congress offset worries about rising Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Biden calls on US Congress to pass 'robust' relief plan
summary: President-elect Joe Biden called on the US Congress to pass a "robust" aid plan to address the Covid-19 economic crisis, warning of a "tragedy" for American families if inaction occurs. Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen emphasized the need for further stimulus, warning that inaction would lead to further devastation. The US Congress remains deadlocked on new aid legislation, with economists urging more support as the country faces difficult months ahead. Biden's administration plans to push for more measures to right the economy, with the president-elect set to be sworn in on January 20.

site_title: Zoom's revenue forecast tops estimates amid 2021 concerns
summary: Zoom's revenue forecast for the current quarter exceeded analysts' estimates at $811 million, but the growth is expected to slow down, topping previous quarters. The company's stock has surged in 2020, raising concerns about its valuation and sustainability. Investors are also worried about cost issues, with a decline in adjusted gross margin to 68.2% in the third quarter. Executives expect similar numbers in the next fiscal year before margins improve, suggesting a potential slowdown in the company's pandemic-driven growth.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on vaccine hopes; Brexit talks eyed
summary: European shares rose on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 index up 0.7% following record-breaking gains in November. Optimism around a coronavirus vaccine candidate from Pfizer and BioNTech boosted the market. London's blue-chip index rallied 1.9% after data showed improving confidence and the UK's fastest growth in factory activity in three years. However, manufacturing activity in France and Germany slowed in November, and expectations for a weak first quarter remain. Brexit talks are ongoing, with a chance of a turbulent exit without a trade deal.

site_title: Euro near three-month high as US dollar takes a hit
summary: The euro is near a three-month high, driven by expectations of US monetary stimulus and a strengthening recovery in riskier currencies. The US dollar fell, with the euro/dollar exchange rate up 0.3% at $1.1964. Investors are short dollars amid optimism over vaccine trials and a potential Federal Reserve response to support the economy. The Fed meets on December 15-16, and Chair Jerome Powell's remarks will be closely watched for clues on future monetary policy.

site_title: Wendy's to open 250 cloud kitchens in India as Covid-19 hits
summary: Wendy's is partnering with Rebel Foods to open 250 cloud kitchens in India, its largest cloud-kitchen outsourcing deal, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Cloud kitchens, remote facilities without seating or cashiers, prepare food exclusively for delivery. The move aims to adapt to lockdowns and social distancing, as deliveries surge and traditional stores aren't optimal for meeting demand. Wendy's plans 150 physical stores over the next decade, alongside the cloud kitchen push, in a market seen as under-penetrated for quick-serve restaurants.

site_title: Arizona and Wisconsin confirm Biden's victories over Trump
summary: Arizona and Wisconsin have confirmed Joe Biden's victories over Donald Trump in their respective states, dealing a significant blow to Trump's campaign efforts to overturn his defeat. Biden won Arizona by 10,457 votes and Wisconsin by a margin of over 20,000 votes. The certifications trigger the appointment of electors who will cast Arizona's 11 Electoral College votes for Biden, unless a court intervenes. This marks the latest loss in Trump's efforts to challenge the election results in court, despite failing to produce evidence.

site_title: Chinese probe lands on Moon to gather lunar samples
summary: China successfully landed a probe on the Moon, marking the country's first attempt to collect lunar samples in four decades. The Chang'e-5 spacecraft, named after the Chinese moon goddess, entered the Moon's orbit after a 112-hour journey and will collect 2kg of material from the Oceanus Procellarum region. The samples will be returned to Earth in a capsule programmed to land in northern China's Inner Mongolia region later in December, making China the third country to have retrieved samples from the Moon.

site_title: Gaming platform Roblox acquires Imbellus assets ahead of IPO
summary: Roblox Corp acquired Imbellus' intellectual property assets, valuing the cognitive assessment start-up at $57.5 million from a 2018 private fundraising round. Imbellus develops simulation-based tests for human thought processes, with a potential application as a substitute for standardized college entrance exams. The acquisition is aimed at enhancing Roblox's recruitment practices ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: Loose monetary policy makes outlook murky
summary: Indonesia is testing the concept of Modern Monetary Theory (MMT), which argues that fiscal policy has a more direct impact on economic activity than monetary policy. With countries worldwide running high fiscal deficits and central banks' balance sheets reaching unprecedented levels, policymakers are considering MMT as a way to boost economic growth. Indonesia's foray into MMT has seen positive reactions in the currency and sovereign bond markets, but the long-term implications and potential risks remain unclear. The IMF warns that high debt levels will continue to climb, and policymakers must consider how to finance these deficits.

site_title: Sabana Reit: 'Nothing unusual or improper' about merger's voting process
summary: Sabana Reit's manager has defended the proposed merger's voting process, stating that it is "nothing unusual or improper." The voting procedures, which allow only one proxy per unitholder, are the same as those used in all Reit mergers in Singapore to date. The manager argues that this ensures each proxy submitted will count as one, making it clear if a unitholder is voting for or against the scheme. The merger is set to be voted on at an extraordinary general meeting on Friday.

site_title: Oil slides as Opec+ delays decision on output cuts
summary: Oil prices declined for a second consecutive day, dropping 1% as Opec+ postponed a meeting to decide on output cuts in January, leaving markets uncertain. Brent crude fell to $47.42 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate to $44.55 a barrel. Industry data showed US crude inventories rose by 4.1 million barrels last week, exceeding analyst expectations for a draw of 2.4 million barrels. The delay in Opec+ decision has added to market uncertainty, contributing to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Post's India unit, Quantium Solutions, has been placed under voluntary liquidation due to losses. The 66% indirect subsidiary had been loss-making and was shut down after a strategic review in 2019. Mapletree Logistics Trust will not proceed with an A$21.25 million purchase of a Brisbane warehouse due to unfulfilled conditional agreement factors. Thomson Medical Group has set up a new unit, Thomson X, to partner healthtech startups and deliver innovative solutions.

site_title: 2021 to bring more corporate distress
summary: Singapore's economy may face more corporate distress in 2021 as private markets distinguish between viable and struggling enterprises amid the pandemic. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will continue fiscal support, but with a "tricky balancing act" to taper, target, and pivot to more productive means. Structural changes in industries like air travel and retail will require adjustments, and the MAS will ensure orderly consolidations to promote strong, healthy businesses. Fiscal support will need to be gradually rolled back to avoid a cliff effect, with a focus on enhancing medium-term growth potential through training subsidies and digitalization.

site_title: Pandemic has forced cities to rethink urban mobility
summary: Cities worldwide are rethinking urban mobility in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a focus on cleaner, safer, faster, more equitable, and more accessible transportation systems. Many cities are exploring alternative modes of transportation, such as cycling and public transport, and regulating the mobility environment to address concerns like congestion and safety. Digital capabilities and data analysis are also becoming essential elements in efficient transport systems, with cities embracing open data and making mobility information available to the public.

site_title: BTS's Life Goes On debuts at No 1 on US Billboard chart
summary: BTS's song "Life Goes On" debuted at No. 1 on the US Billboard chart, marking the first foreign-language song to achieve this feat in the chart's 62-year history. The song, predominantly sung in Korean, topped the US Hot 100 in its debut week. This achievement cements BTS's status as a trailblazing act, following their previous No. 1 hits "Dynamite" and a BTS remix of "Savage Love." The band's success highlights the growing appeal of Korean culture in the US, following the Oscar win of "Parasite" in 2020.

site_title: The mall is dead, long live the mall
summary: Retailers worldwide are facing a massive reset post-pandemic, with iconic stores like Robinsons in Singapore and Zara's parent company Inditex shutting down or significantly downsizing. The shift to e-commerce has accelerated, with online sales increasing 151.2% in June, but this surge won't offset the damage from store closures and reduced spending. Experts predict the global fashion industry will shrink by a third, losing $640 billion in revenue this year. To survive, retailers must integrate online and offline channels, offering unique experiences and services, such as concert halls and fitness clubs, to remain relevant in the retail landscape.

site_title: Retail landlords must reinvent the shopping mall to thrive in new normal
summary: Retail landlords must adapt to the new normal by reinventing shopping malls with more activities, food & beverage, and emerging trends such as e-commerce and cloud kitchens. The pandemic has accelerated e-commerce growth, with 13% of total retail sales in Singapore expected by 2023. To thrive, landlords need to pivot and cater to resilient segments, such as F&B, and adopt innovative strategies like data analytics and augmented reality. Those who fail to adapt will get left behind, with retail rents expected to fall by 10-15% in 2020 and 5-10% in 2021.

site_title: Killing Libor proves even harder than global regulators imagined
summary: Regulators have delayed the retirement of the London interbank offered rate (Libor) by 18 months to 2023, giving them more time to facilitate an orderly transition. The decision comes as officials struggle to address the threat of trillions of dollars of existing contracts and instruments that lack a clear replacement rate. The delay is seen as a recognition that the task has proven far more daunting than initially anticipated, with many warning of potential systemic risks and a wave of disruptive litigation if a solution is not found.

site_title: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon turns into a big run for charity
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon has transformed into a solo charity run due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Participants can now run at their own pace and record their distances on smart devices, a change introduced since the launch of the SCSM Virtual Club in August. This shift allows runners to maintain their fitness goals while supporting charitable causes, with the marathon's charity component continuing to raise funds for various organizations.

site_title: UAE, an attractive business destination
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is a top investment destination and leading trading partner in West Asia for Singapore, with over 600 Singapore companies operating in the country. Singapore has a significant presence in the UAE, with around 3,000 Singaporeans living and working there. Bilateral trade and investments have grown steadily, with total trade reaching $21.3 billion in 2020. The UAE and Singapore have signed a Comprehensive Partnership pact to deepen cooperation in areas such as trade, investment, defense, and sustainable development. The UAE Embassy in Singapore is promoting business cooperation and people-to-people relations to encourage investment growth in both countries.

site_title: Euro zone factories lagging Asia's recovery from Covid-19 crisis
summary: Euro zone factories experienced a slowdown in November due to renewed coronavirus lockdown measures, lagging behind Asia's recovery from the Covid-19 crisis. China's factory activity accelerated to a decade-high, while Germany's growth was the euro zone's strongest. The European Central Bank is expected to provide additional stimulus, and the euro zone is at risk of its first double-dip recession in nearly a decade. Meanwhile, Britain's factories recorded their fastest growth in almost three years, driven by stockpiling and a looming post-Brexit customs deadline.

site_title: UK retailer Debenhams to be liquidated; Philip Green's Arcadia files for insolvency
summary: UK retailer Debenhams will undergo a liquidation process, resulting in store closures and potential job losses of 12,000. The decision follows the failure to find a buyer and comes a day after Philip Green's Arcadia group entered administration, threatening 13,000 jobs. This further exacerbates the UK retail sector's challenges during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UAESBC: The business nexus between the UAE and Singapore
summary: The UAE and Singapore have a strong business relationship, with two-way trade valued at $18 billion in 2019. Singapore is the UAE's leading trade and investment partner in the Gulf Cooperation Council, while the UAE is the largest investor in Singapore from the GCC. The GCC-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was signed in 2013, and a UAE Singapore Business Council was proposed in 2014 to enhance cooperation. The relationship has grown significantly since then, with a total estimated investment of $8 billion in Singapore from the UAE.

site_title: OECD cuts global forecast, warns governments need to maintain support
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has cut its global growth forecast to 4.2% in 2021, citing a pattern of coronavirus pandemic outbreaks and lockdowns. The US, euro area, and UK forecasts were downgraded, with rising risks of permanent damage. The OECD warned governments to maintain support beyond the end of lockdown measures and avoid "fiscal cliffs," targeting vulnerable companies and groups. The organization's chief economist, Laurence Boone, emphasized the need for sustained government action to prevent a loss of confidence and a more depressing outlook.

site_title: Washington establishment hails Biden victory as return to status quo
summary: The article discusses how Washington establishment members reacted to the 2020 US presidential election, where Joe Biden won. The author recalls a 2016 article about Bethesda, Maryland residents, who were predominantly members of the establishment and expected Hillary Clinton to win. The author notes that these individuals, including federal government officials, lawyers, and media professionals, came together in their opposition to Donald Trump, regardless of party affiliation. The Biden victory is seen as a return to the status quo, with the establishment welcoming the outcome.

site_title: Top Glove under investigation over Covid-19 outbreak; UG Healthcare to test workers
summary: Malaysian glove-maker Top Glove is under investigation for alleged offenses involving worker dormitories, with 19 investigation papers opened by the Malaysian government. The firm has cooperated with authorities and is working to improve worker accommodations. Top Glove has spent RM20 million on purchasing apartment units for workers and previously invested in hostels. Separately, UG Healthcare will conduct Covid-19 testing on employees, with minimal disruption to manufacturing operations.

site_title: Mirae's successful nix of its hotels' purchase may sink other deals
summary: A Delaware judge ruled in favor of Mirae Global Asset Investment Co, canceling a $5.8 billion deal to purchase 15 luxury US hotels from Dajia Insurance Co due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the transaction. The ruling, the first of its kind in Delaware, may pave the way for other firms to walk away from deals crippled by the pandemic. The judge found Dajia failed to operate the hotels in an "ordinary manner" as required by the deal, and ordered Dajia to cover Mirae Global's legal fees and return the deposit.

site_title: China new home price growth cools in November, private survey shows
summary: China's new home prices grew 0.32% in November, a slight decrease from the 0.4% gain in October, according to a private survey. Fewer cities reported monthly gains, with 28 experiencing lower home prices. The southern Pearl River Delta and eastern Yangtze River Delta drove market strength, while cities in eastern Shandong province saw significant price drops. Annual new home price growth rose 3.63%, down from 3.52% in October. Policy tightening and demand weakness contributed to the slowdown.

site_title: Companies' leverage risk worsens as earnings fall and debt rises
summary: Singapore's corporate sector faces heightened leverage risk due to declining earnings and rising debt, with the corporate non-performing loan ratio rising to 3.4% in Q3 2020. Debt ratios have increased to 163% and median interest coverage ratios have fallen to 1.1, affecting sectors hard hit by the pandemic. While firms' debt servicing ability is considered sufficient for now, the banking system's corporate non-performing loan ratio and loan asset quality are expected to deteriorate, particularly in sectors with prolonged earnings weakness.

site_title: US October pending home sales unexpectedly fall for a second month
summary: US pending home sales unexpectedly declined 1.1% in October, marking a second consecutive month of decline, as higher prices and limited listings hindered the housing market. The decline was more pronounced than the 2% drop in September and missed economists' expectations of a 1% gain. Despite this, contract signings are up 20% from last year, driven by record-low mortgage rates and buyer demand for larger homes. The National Association of Realtors attributes the decline to rising home prices and affordability concerns.

site_title: 1918 Germany has a warning for 2020 America
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Stop the Steal" campaign bears a parallel to the "stab-in-the-back" myth in 1918 Germany, which fueled resentment and anger. The myth claimed Imperial Germany never lost World War I, and its proponents exploited this narrative to blame others for the country's defeat. Similarly, Trump's claims of a stolen election are stirring similar emotions in the US. This parallel highlights the dangers of denying reality and exploiting public frustration, a tactic used by Adolf Hitler to rise to power in Germany.

site_title: New US Treasury chief is the right woman for the times
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has chosen Janet Yellen, the former Federal Reserve chair, as his Treasury secretary. Yellen, an economist with a reputation for being data-driven and non-ideological, has the trust of progressives and conservatives alike. Her focus on the human impact of economics and her belief in prioritizing work in fields like healthcare and childcare align with Biden's "caring economy" ideas. As head of the Financial Stability Oversight Council, Yellen will have the power to shape financial regulation and potentially undo deregulation efforts of the Trump administration, addressing concerns about debt and systemic risk in the financial system.

site_title: Keppel Land to divest remaining 30% stake in Dong Nai Waterfront City
summary: Keppel Land is divesting its remaining 30% stake in Dong Nai Waterfront City in Vietnam for approximately S$115.9 million. The transaction follows the 2019 divestment of 70% stake to Nam Long Investment Corporation. The deal is expected to be completed in the first half of 2021 and will result in a gain of about S$52.5 million for Keppel Land. The company plans to monetize identified assets and apply the balance sheet space for new growth opportunities under its Vision 2030.

site_title: CapitaLand sells three Japan malls, Seoul office block for S$448m; enters Japan logistics sector
summary: CapitaLand has divested three Japanese malls and an office building in South Korea for a total of S$448.7 million as part of its portfolio reconstitution strategy. The divestments include La Park Mizue, Vivit Minami-Funabashi, and CO-OP Kobe Nishinomiya Higashi in Japan, and ICON Yeoksam in Seoul. The company has entered the Japanese logistics sector through a joint venture with Mitsui & Co Real Estate, with plans to develop and operate a logistics project in Greater Tokyo.

site_title: Affirming the global stature of India's farmers as they protest farm bills
summary: Indian farmers, who have contributed significantly to the country's economic success, are protesting against new agricultural legislation they fear will destroy their livelihoods. Despite their efforts, India ranks 11th in the world's services sector and 12th in manufacturing, whereas its agriculture sector is the second-largest globally, with a 8% share. The farmers' concerns must be addressed by the authorities to avoid undermining the country's economic progress.

images.alt_text: Indian farmers are protesting against the central government's recent agricultural reforms, which they fear will destroy their livelihoods.

site_title: Running Paris Opera never going to be easy
summary: Alexander Neef, the new director of the Paris Opera, faces significant challenges in his first role, taking over amidst a pandemic, labor strikes, and internal unrest. Neef, 46, had just begun his job five weeks prior, overseeing an annual budget of 220 million euros, after being blindsided by his predecessor's sudden departure. Despite the grim situation, Neef has an insider's knowledge of the institution, having worked as casting director under Gerard Mortier from 2004 to 2008. He aims to address institutional racism, commissioned an external investigation, and is planning to explore the modern repertory with a diverse range of works, including operas by Philip Glass and John Adams.

site_title: BT News Tablet gets even more attractive for Christmas
summary: The Business Times (BT) is launching a Christmas promotion for its News Tablet Edition, offering a gift bundle worth up to S$150, including a limited edition tablet cover, microSD card, and device protection plan. The promotion was launched on Dec 1 and aims to make the digital edition more attractive for subscribers. Readers, such as Lim Shi Min and Tang Xiaochao, have praised the convenience and stability of the digital edition, citing improved access to news and business information.

site_title: America's back, but not all Americans may be happy about it
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's new team of foreign policy and national security advisers signals a reversal of Donald Trump's "America First"-style nationalist isolationism. Biden plans to rejoin international alliances, prioritize foreign policy, and address global issues such as climate change and the nuclear deal with Iran. However, his commitment to multilateral geo-strategy may be constrained by anti-interventionist and protectionist attitudes among some Americans, limiting the administration's ability to resurrect traditional internationalist policies.

site_title: SC Capital unit proposed as Eagle Hospitality Reit's new manager
summary: SC Capital unit SCCPRE Hospitality Reit Management has been proposed as the new manager for Eagle Hospitality Reit, following a request-for-proposal process that evaluated all options to protect EHT's interests. The proposal was decided after discussions with EHT's financial adviser Moelis, and the incoming manager is part of the SC Capital real estate private-equity group. The appointment is subject to approval at an extraordinary general meeting, and the current manager's removal is expected to be completed within a month. Trading of EHT stapled securities remains suspended.

site_title: China funding squeeze at small banks is warning sign for market
summary: China's smaller banks are facing a funding squeeze, with the cost of one-year interbank debt rising to 3.34% and widening the gap with the People's Bank of China's medium-term loans. This trend is a warning sign for the financial system, as rising corporate defaults and a volatile market for short-term borrowing are affecting larger lenders. The People's Bank of China may soon pull back on emergency stimulus measures, leading to elevated borrowing costs and a potential slowdown in the economy.

site_title: Singapore to be Infineon's first global hub with AI in all job roles
summary: Infineon Technologies, a German microchip maker, plans to establish Singapore as its first global hub for artificial intelligence (AI) in every job function. The company will invest S$27 million over three years, upskilling 1,000 employees and deploying 25 unique AI projects by 2023. The initiative aims to make AI the foundation of the company's next 50 years, without requiring changes in staffing. The move is seen as a significant step in Singapore's semiconductor industry, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat praising Infineon as a role model for creating jobs for locals.

site_title: HK October retail sales down 8.8%, first single-digit fall since June 2019
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales declined 8.8% in October, marking the first single-digit fall since June 2019. This drop follows revised declines of 12.8% in September and 6.7% in June 2019, indicating a possible recovery from coronavirus restrictions. The decline is a sign of easing restrictions on spending and tourism in the global financial hub.

site_title: Track record matters, so does performance presentation
summary: Retail investors in Singapore prefer to evaluate robo-advisory platforms and traditional funds based on historical performance over several economic cycles, rather than just recent data. To ensure transparency and fairness, financial professionals should adhere to established best practices, including the CFA Institute's Performance Presentation Standard, which requires full disclosure of investment performance data and prohibits misrepresenting past performance. Compliance with the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) is also recommended for accurate reporting.

site_title: Bitcoin hits new record, this time with less talk of a bubble
summary: Bitcoin surpassed its previous record of $19,783 in March 2020, reaching an all-time high of $19,833. The surge is attributed to a less speculative fever, with American investors and traditional investors treating Bitcoin as an alternative asset like gold. Regulators and mainstream financial companies have made cryptocurrencies safer and more accessible, with PayPal and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency allowing banks to hold cryptocurrencies. This shift is part of a broader exuberance in cryptocurrencies and stock markets, defying a pandemic-induced recession.

site_title: Thai authorities race to trace potential Covid-19 outbreak after four test positive
summary: Thai authorities are racing to contain a potential Covid-19 outbreak after four women tested positive on returning from Myanmar. The women, who worked in a notorious border town, may have been in contact with over 100 people. Authorities have tested those individuals and are tracking down more. The women's workplaces in Tachilek, a hub for the Golden Triangle's drug trade, have not been confirmed. Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha urged calm, saying there's no need to panic. Thailand has managed to keep Covid-19 infections low, but the porous border with Myanmar poses a risk.

site_title: Is Bezos the last, best hope for stranded seafarers?
summary: Shipping industry leaders have turned to Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos for help in resolving the crew change crisis and supporting stranded seafarers, who are stuck on their ships due to Covid-related restrictions. The crisis has caused significant humanitarian and safety issues, with over 400,000 seafarers stranded at sea. Industry bodies, including the International Chamber of Shipping, have written to Bezos, urging him to use his influence to push for public recognition of seafarers as "key workers" and champion their cause at the highest levels of government. Bezos is seen as a potential last hope for the industry to resolve the crisis and prevent devastating consequences for global trade.

site_title: BMW and SAP join forces to build German auto data alliance
summary: BMW and SAP have formed a data-sharing alliance with other German firms to build a cloud-based platform, Gaia-X, that doesn't rely on US or Chinese technology. The platform will enable car manufacturers to identify production bottlenecks and avoid production outages. The alliance aims to secure value-added manufacturing and employment in Europe, with Siemens, Deutsche Telekom, Robert Bosch, and ZF Friedrichshafen also participating. The move follows concerns over data control and geopolitical tensions in the wake of the US-China trade war.

site_title: HSBC increases stake in Saudi British Bank to 31%
summary: HSBC has increased its stake in Saudi British Bank to 31% through a share purchase. The move follows an accelerated book build process launched by NatWest Markets and Banco Santander. The stake increase is part of HSBC's efforts to strengthen its presence in the Middle East market.

site_title: US: Wall St gains on vaccine cheer, robust China data
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by better-than-expected Chinese factory data and optimism over a COVID-19 vaccine rollout before year-end. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.54%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher.

site_title: Australia's housing market roars back, boosting wealth and construction
summary: Australia's housing market has seen a significant rebound, driven by record-low interest rates that are fueling demand from first-time buyers. Home prices rose 0.8% in November, marking a 3.1% gain for the year. New home approvals reached 20-year highs, boosting consumer wealth. This surge is attributed to the low interest rates, which have made borrowing more affordable for first-time buyers. The improved market conditions are expected to have a positive impact on the construction industry.

site_title: Vaccines key to re-igniting travel; Moderna vaccine could be in Singapore in December
summary: Singapore's air travel bubble with Hong Kong is postponed to next year due to a sudden surge in Covid-19 cases in Hong Kong. The delay highlights the need for a vaccine to restore confidence in international travel. Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine is expected to be approved in Singapore by December or January. Aviation experts believe that a vaccine could be a key factor in the recovery of the industry, with potential growth opportunities in air cargo services and ground handling.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector sentiment hits new highs in November
summary: China's manufacturing sector sentiment reached new highs in November, with the official manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 52.1, the highest reading in over three years. The Caixin PMI also rose to more than a decade high at 54.9. The economy is recovering, driven by a pickup in consumer demand, with the non-manufacturing PMI at 56.4. Analysts expect the recovery to continue, but caution that challenges, including the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, may impact growth in the coming quarters.

site_title: US manufacturing sector slows in November
summary: US manufacturing activity slowed in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's index dropping to 57.5, its lowest since November 2018. The decline was attributed to a resurgence in Covid-19 infections, which may disrupt production at factories. Manufacturing output remains 5% below its pre-pandemic level, and economists expect a sharp deceleration in economic growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Moderna seeking approval for use of its Covid-19 vaccine in Singapore
summary: Moderna is seeking approval to use its COVID-19 vaccine in Singapore, with the first vaccine potentially arriving as early as December. The company's CEO, Stephane Bancel, has expressed confidence in the vaccine's safety and effectiveness, citing a 94.1% efficacy rate in a late-stage clinical trial. Moderna has applied for emergency use authorization in the US, where it is also competing with Pfizer-BioNTech for approval. The Singapore Health Sciences Authority is reviewing the application, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong aiming to secure a portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines for the country.

site_title: Home loans need close tracking as GDP dip worsens household debt-to-GDP ratio: MAS
summary: Singapore's household debt-to-GDP ratio has reversed its pre-pandemic decline to 67.1% in Q3, driven by a sharply lower GDP this year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has expressed concern, citing uneven labour market recovery and potential increase in credit risk for housing loans. The regulator is monitoring housing loans from vulnerable households closely, advising households to remain prudent in taking on new debt and servicing existing obligations.

site_title: UK November house prices jump by most in nearly 6 years
summary: UK house prices surged by 6.5% in November, the largest annual increase in nearly six years, according to Nationwide. The boom in the housing market comes as the broader economy struggles with the COVID-19 pandemic. This marks a reversal of the trend seen in previous months, with homebuyer demand rebounding to a six-month high. The significant increase in prices is attributed to a strong demand for housing, despite the ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: Denzai acquires majority stake in Huationg
summary: Denzai Holdings has acquired a 71% stake in Huationg Holdings, a Singapore-based heavy lifting and transportation provider, for an undisclosed sum. The deal, completed through a wholly-owned subsidiary, Denzai Singapore Asia Pacific, marks Denzai's entry into the Singaporean market. Huationg will retain its name and serve as the regional headquarters for Denzai. The acquisition aims to leverage Denzai's size and regional presence to boost Huationg's market share, particularly in the face of uncertainty in the local oil and gas industry.

site_title: Vornado to cut 70 jobs, reduce salaries in bid to slash expenses
summary: Vornado Realty Trust is cutting 70 jobs and reducing salaries to slash expenses by over $35 million. The real estate investment trust, a major Manhattan property owner, will see a $23 million reduction in net income for the fourth quarter. The company is also shifting president Michael Franco to chief financial officer, replacing Joseph Macnow. These moves come as the pandemic continues to impact New York's economy, with Vornado's shares dropping 40% this year.

site_title: Asian stocks rally on positive vaccine news, upbeat Chinese data
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.29% to 2,814.12, driven by positive vaccine news and upbeat Chinese data. Moderna announced emergency regulatory approval for its COVID-19 vaccine, while a business survey showed China's factory sector activity accelerated at its fastest pace in a decade. Asian markets, including the Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite Index, also rose, with the Kospi closing 1.66% higher.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust axes planned A$21m purchase of Brisbane warehouse
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has cancelled a planned A$21.25 million purchase of a Brisbane warehouse due to unfulfilled conditions. The decision will not impact the trust's distribution per unit for the 2021 financial year. The trust has completed acquisitions in China and Vietnam, using S$575.8 million from its equity fund-raising. Its units closed at S$1.95, down 1.02%.

site_title: Cathay Cineplexes in the news as mm2 mulls cinema Catalist spinoff
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED mm2 Asia, owner of Cathay Cineplexes, is evaluating a spinoff of its cinema business onto the Singapore Exchange's junior Catalist board. The cinema business is currently conducted through its subsidiary, mm Connect, which includes Cathay Cineplexes in Singapore and Malaysia-based mm2 Star Screen. This move aims to separate the cinema business from the rest of the company, potentially allowing for more flexibility and growth opportunities. The exact timeline and details of the spinoff are not specified.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Giuliani said to have discussed a pardon with Trump
summary: Rudy Giuliani, President Donald Trump's lawyer, discussed a potential preemptive pardon with Trump as recently as last week, according to two people. Giuliani's business dealings in Ukraine and his role in ousting the American ambassador are under investigation by federal prosecutors. It's unclear who raised the topic of a pardon for Giuliani, but Trump has not indicated what he will do. This comes as Giuliani's potential criminal exposure remains unclear.

site_title: SoftBank buys 10.1% stake in Sinch after its meteoric surge
summary: SoftBank has acquired a 10.1% stake in Sinch, a Swedish cloud-based platform provider, after the company's stock price surged 300% this year. SoftBank's co-founders sold 5.2 million shares to the company, and SoftBank also subscribed to an additional 1.2 million shares. The deal is worth over US$800 million based on Sinch's current market value. Sinch's stock price rose 7.8% on the news, following its transformation into the best-performing company on the Stoxx Europe 600 index during the pandemic.

site_title: Century 21 sells US$175m pandemic legal claim
summary: Century 21 Stores, a US department store chain, is selling a stake in its business interruption insurance claim against insurers for $175 million. The claim, stemming from COVID-19's devastating impact, is Century 21's most valuable asset. Insurance companies have generally prevailed in similar lawsuits, arguing that diseases cannot cause physical damage to trigger payouts. The sale will help Century 21 repay creditors, including $50 million in secured debt. A hearing is scheduled for a New York bankruptcy court to discuss the sale and the identity of the buyer.

site_title: SingPost's loss-making Indian e-commerce logistics unit under liquidation
summary: SingPost's Indian e-commerce logistics unit, Quantium Mail Logistics Solutions (India), has been placed under voluntary liquidation due to significant losses. The decision follows a 2019 strategic review of operations, with the unit to focus on core Asia-Pacific markets instead. The liquidation is expected to have minimal impact on SingPost's financial results for the year ending March 2021. Shares of SingPost closed at S$0.72, up 0.7%, after the announcement.

site_title: UK's Johnson urges lawmakers to back regional Covid restrictions
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged lawmakers to support regional Covid-19 restrictions, with over 40% of England's population facing the toughest tier of restrictions. The plan has sparked criticism from his own party, with 80 Conservatives criticizing the system as too draconian. Johnson argued that regional tiers are needed to control the virus, but faces opposition from his own party and lawmakers. The UK's month-long national lockdown ends on Wednesday.

site_title: Libra inks letter of intent with potential white knight on S$6m investment
summary: Libra Group, a distressed Catalist-listed firm, has entered a letter of intent (LOI) with SMTM Investment, a potential white knight, for a S$6 million investment. The investment would be used to restructure Libra and its wholly-owned unit Kin Xin Engineering, with S$3 million allocated to subscribe for new shares and S$3 million as a working capital loan. The parties aim to finalize definitive agreements by January 15, with SMTM being an unrelated third party of Libra.

site_title: The year Australia's central bank was dragged into QE fold
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) marked its first use of quantitative easing (QE) in its 30-year history in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The move came as the economy teetered towards recession, with the jobless rate at 7% and the RBA cutting interest rates to 0.10% to stimulate domestic demand. The RBA also expanded a lending facility for banks and established a three-year yield target to contain a currency surge. The QE program aimed to narrow the spread of Australia's longer-term debt and was seen as a key step in engineering a strong domestic economy amidst an increasingly worrying relationship breakdown with China.

site_title: Singapore Oct visitor arrivals up, but still at a minuscule 13,400
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals jumped 41.1% to 13,400 in October, but remain far below pre-pandemic levels. The tourism industry's performance is still recovering, with average occupancy rates declining to 56.7% from 66% in July. Revenue per available room improved to S$77, but remains 60.6% down year-over-year. Experts expect a slow rebound, with the re-opening of travel from key source markets like China and Indonesia crucial for a meaningful recovery.

site_title: Ayala unit lists US$300m perpetual green bond on SGX
summary: AC Energy, the energy platform of Philippines' conglomerate Ayala Corp, has listed US$300 million in perpetual green bonds on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), marking the first public green bond out of the Philippines in 2020. The bonds carry a 5.1% fixed coupon for life and are guaranteed by the firm. This offering is part of AC Energy's US$2 billion medium-term note programme, certified as Asean Green Bonds by the Philippine Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: South Korea passes law to allow BTS to postpone military service
summary: South Korea's parliament passed a bill allowing K-pop artists like BTS to postpone military service to age 30, making exceptions for those who improve the country's cultural status and economy. The amendment to the Military Service Act aims to address the concerns of globally recognized artists who are required to serve for about two years. The change is expected to benefit K-pop groups like BTS, who have become a significant contributor to South Korea's cultural and economic landscape.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to cut one in three jobs at retail banking hubs
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to cut one in three jobs at its retail banking hubs in Frankfurt and Bonn, affecting around 350 employees, as part of efforts to reduce costs and restore profitability. The redundancies will be carried out by the end of 2022 and will focus on the Postbank retail banking arm. This move follows the bank's overhaul efforts to shift focus from investment banking to private customers and corporations. The bank has lost money for the past five years and aims to make its private customer business profitable and sustainable.

site_title: India diesel sales take a dip with festive cheer fading fast
summary: India's diesel sales dropped year-on-year in November, marking a second consecutive month of decline, as the festive season demand boost faded quickly. Diesel sales fell 7% year-on-year, while gasoline sales rose 4.9% year-on-year. The uneven fuel demand recovery is prompting refineries to adjust production and manage stockpiles amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, which has hit India's economy, contracting by 7.5% in the third quarter.

site_title: Airbnb sets terms for US$2.6b IPO
summary: Airbnb plans to raise up to $2.6 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) by offering 51.9 million shares at $44 to $50 apiece. The company's valuation as a public company would be nearly $35 billion, its highest valuation to date. Existing investors, including Sequoia and Founders Fund, will control the company through Class B shares, which carry 20 votes each. The IPO would be the fourth-largest in the US this year, following a strong year for new listings on US exchanges, which have raised $152 billion this year.

site_title: Thailand urges calm after four test positive for virus
summary: Thai authorities have urged calm after four women tested positive for the coronavirus upon returning from neighboring Myanmar, where the virus is rampant. The women worked in an "entertainment center" in Tachilek, a notorious border town, and may have been in contact with over 100 people. Thai health officials are tracing potential contacts and have put the city of Chiang Mai on high alert. Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha said there's no need to panic, and authorities have stepped up surveillance to prevent illegal migrants.

site_title: mm2 evaluating Catalist listing of cinema business
summary: mm2 Asia is evaluating a spin-off of its cinema business, which would enable the unit to be financially independent and raise funds for new growth opportunities without relying on the parent company. The spin-off and listing on the Catalist board would also incentivize senior management personnel to deliver the best possible value to shareholders. The board has appointed professional advisers to advise on the proposal.

site_title: Amazon says sellers racked up more than US$4.8b in sales over weekend
summary: Amazon reported that independent sellers on its platform generated over $4.8 billion in worldwide sales from Black Friday through Cyber Monday, a 60% increase from the same period last year. More than 71,000 small businesses had surpassed $100,000 in sales during the holiday season. Amazon did not release its own sales figures, but stated it was its biggest holiday season ever.

site_title: Collapse of two UK retailers puts 25,000 jobs at risk
summary: Two UK retailers, Debenhams and Arcadia, are on the brink of collapse due to the coronavirus fallout and fierce online competition, risking 25,000 jobs. Debenhams plans to close its 124 UK stores and online operations if no alternative offers are received, while Arcadia, which owns Topshop, has fallen into administration, putting 13,000 jobs at risk. The collapse comes as the UK retail industry faces unprecedented pressure, with the government minister Michael Gove questioning the management decisions that led to Arcadia's downfall.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees higher provisions in US$680m mortgage-backed bonds
summary: Credit Suisse has signaled a potential US$380 million fourth-quarter hit from a long-standing legal case over residential mortgage-backed securities, adding to the bank's woes. A New York judge has ordered the bank and municipal-bond insurer MBIA to estimate damages related to the 2007 mortgages, with MBIA seeking US$740 million in damages. Credit Suisse has already set aside US$300 million to cover losses, and may increase the amount if the judge does not provide an update before year's end. The bank faces billions of dollars in claims related to the sale of securities that plummeted in value during the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: OECD cuts global forecast, urges governments to maintain support
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has cut its 2021 global growth forecast to 4.2% due to the resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic, warning that governments must maintain support to prevent a worsening economic situation. The forecast was lowered for the euro area and the UK, with the latter's projection reduced to 4.2% from 7.6%. The OECD cautioned that a pattern of outbreaks and lockdowns may persist, potentially causing permanent damage if support is withdrawn too soon or vaccines are not delivered effectively.

site_title: UG Healthcare to test Malaysian workers for Covid-19
summary: UG Healthcare, a glove manufacturer, will conduct Covid-19 testing on its Malaysian employees as a precautionary measure. The testing will not disrupt its manufacturing operations and is expected to have minimal impact on its financial year performance. The move follows recent revelations about workers' dormitory conditions at Top Glove, a Malaysian glovemaker, which led to a government investigation. The company's shares closed at S$0.68, down 1.45%, following the announcement.

site_title: Xiaomi seeks up to US$4b in shares, convertible bonds
summary: Xiaomi, China's second-largest smartphone maker, is seeking up to $4 billion in funding through a share placement and convertible bond sale. The company is selling 1 billion shares at a discount of 6.3-9.4% and offering a 42.5-52.5% premium on a convertible bond. The funds will be used for business expansion, market share increase, and strategic investments. This follows Xiaomi's growth in market share, particularly after it surpassed Huawei in overseas markets due to American sanctions.

site_title: Slow tourism recovery can't lift Thailand economy yet
summary: Thailand's economy is unlikely to recover from the recent economic contraction due to the slow return of tourists. Barclays economists expect the services balance to improve only slightly, with the current account surplus narrowing to 3.7% of GDP in 2021. The return of tourists is expected to be slow and will depend on the availability of a Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 39.55 points to 1,602.26 on Tuesday, closing higher. The index saw 9.187 billion lots traded worth RM5.348 billion, with 760 gainers and 479 losers.

site_title: CDW Holding sends research for possible anti-cancer drugs for peer review
summary: CDW Holding has submitted research findings for a potential anti-cancer drug, anti-Cripto-1, a monoclonal antibody developed jointly with Japan's Okayama University. The antibody showed promise in suppressing tumor growth in mice and has been submitted for peer review. CDW expects to license the intellectual property rights to pharmaceutical industry players for clinical trials in 2022, with the possibility of manufacturing and distributing the resulting drugs. Further clinical trials are needed to determine the antibody's efficacy in human patients.

site_title: Restaurant industry has yet to tap full potential of technology, say industry players
summary: The restaurant industry has not fully leveraged technology to its potential, despite the COVID-19 pandemic's accelerated digitalization. Industry players and restaurateurs agree that technology can help differentiate businesses, improve productivity, and enhance customer experience. However, adopting technology is hindered by chefs' reluctance to adopt new kitchen technologies and lack of data collection capabilities. Experts recommend restaurants invest in technology, standardize across brands, and prioritize data collection and integration to derive long-term value. By doing so, restaurants can drive customer growth and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Reaching the Summit
summary: Muhammed Aziz Khan, founder and chairman of Summit Power International, was named an Outstanding Leader in Asia by the ACES Awards. He has led a national effort to bolster Bangladesh's infrastructure and social landscape, managing large investments and long project implementation times. The Summit Group of Companies, employing over 6,000 people, has achieved numerous firsts in Bangladesh's energy sector, including the country's first private sector power generation plant, LNG terminal, and largest fibre optic network. Khan emphasizes the importance of a good leader caring for others intellectually and physically.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes out wild pandemic year with Dow, S&P at records
summary: US stocks closed out the pandemic year with record highs, with the Dow and S&P 500 reaching new peaks. The S&P 500 gained 66% from its March low, the Nasdaq 43.6%, and the Dow 7.2%, marking the biggest yearly gains since 2009. The gains were fueled by massive stimulus and progress on a vaccine. Despite an economy still recovering, tech and consumer discretionary sectors performed well, while energy was the weakest. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached new highs earlier in the week, and investors now look to a post-pandemic world, with two US Senate races set to determine control of the chamber.

site_title: Trump extends immigration bans despite opposition from US business groups
summary: US President Donald Trump extended immigration bans blocking many "green card" applicants and temporary foreign workers until March 31, 2021, despite opposition from US business groups. The bans, set to expire on December 31, 2020, aim to protect US workers amid the pandemic-battered economy. President-elect Joe Biden has criticized the restrictions, but has not yet said whether he would immediately reverse them.

site_title: Wintry weather arriving in Europe boosts power and gas prices
summary: Colder-than-normal weather in Europe is expected to boost power and gas prices, marking the second increase since the start of the heating season. The rising temperatures are raising hopes that this winter will revert to the 30-year average, contrary to the record warmth in 2019. Energy demand is expected to rise due to coronavirus restrictions and those working from home increasing their heat usage, testing a new market theory.

site_title: Hong Kong Oct retail sales down 8.8% y-o-y, first single-digit fall since June 2019
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales plummeted 8.8% in October, the first single-digit decline since June 2019, due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The drop in sales follows a revised 12.8% decline in September and a 6.7% fall in June 2019. Total retail sales fell 27% in the first 10 months of 2020, and the government has extended the postponement of an air travel bubble with Singapore. The city's tourist arrivals in October dropped 99.8% from a year earlier, and sales of jewellery and valuable gifts also fell sharply.

site_title: Thomson Medical sets up new unit to partner healthtech startups, associations
summary: Thomson Medical Group has established a new unit, Thomson X, to partner with healthtech startups and international associations to deliver innovative solutions. The unit aims to "future-proof" the company's business model and extend its reach. Thomson X has a paid-up capital of S$100 and is funded through internal resources. The incorporation is expected to have no material impact on earnings. This move follows the accelerated adoption of healthtech solutions during the Covid-19 pandemic, which has enabled new wellness and healthcare-seeking behavior and patient empowerment.

site_title: Singapore customers to soon have a single view of what they own and owe across major banks
summary: Singapore plans to announce a single platform for consumers to view their financial information from major banks, allowing them to share consolidated data with financial institutions and non-banking entities. The platform, first reported in 2019, aims to provide a unified view of customers' financial data across various banks. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will oversee the implementation of the platform, which is expected to enhance financial transparency and convenience for consumers.

images.alt_text: In time, it could also make it simpler for consumers to compare products and services for better financial planning.

site_title: OCBC adopts risk-management framework Equator Principles for infrastructure projects
summary: OCBC bank has adopted the Equator Principles, a risk-management framework for financial institutions, to guide its assessment and management of environmental and social risks in large-scale development projects. The move is part of the bank's push towards responsible financing and builds on its previous sustainability commitments. By adopting the Equator Principles, OCBC aims to strengthen its environmental, social, and governance related disclosure and reporting, ensuring strict environmental and social standards are applied in project development and construction processes.

site_title: Oyo has US$1b to fund operations until IPO, CEO tells employees
summary: Oyo Hotels CEO Ritesh Agarwal told employees the Indian startup has about $1 billion to fund operations until an initial public offering (IPO). The company is recovering from the coronavirus fallout and aims to reach revenue per available room of 60-80% of pre-pandemic levels. Oyo, valued at $10 billion before the downturn, is working to get its business in shape for a public offering, with investors providing input on the business. The company has cut its headcount by two-thirds to about 10,000.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.7% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also rising 0.6%. The rebound followed a 1.5% decline on Monday. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus. Despite the rebound, the markets remain volatile, with the US stock market edging towards fresh records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Aeroflot reports third-quarter core profit as traffic improves
summary: Aeroflot, Russia's flagship airline, reported a third-quarter core profit of 20.09 billion roubles (S$353.51 million), driven by partial traffic recovery and lower operating costs. The airline's passenger traffic decline slowed to 45.3% in the third quarter, down from nearly 90% in April-June. Aeroflot cut operating costs by almost a third to 77.42 billion roubles. The airline's low-cost subsidiary, Pobeda, saw a 10.6% increase in passenger traffic in October.

site_title: Cleaner at Changi Airport T3 transit area is Singapore's sole Covid-19 community case
summary: A 66-year-old cleaner at Changi Airport's Terminal 3 transit area tested positive for Covid-19, marking Singapore's sole community case. The cleaner was asymptomatic when tested and lives in Yishun with her husband. The infection was detected through bi-weekly routine testing of front-line workers. This case is part of two reported local transmission cases on December 1.

site_title: Battle over borscht: new front in Russia-Ukraine conflict
summary: A Ukrainian chef, Ievgen Klopotenko, sparked a new front in the Russia-Ukraine conflict by pushing for borscht to be recognized as part of Ukraine's cultural heritage. Klopotenko, a graduate of Le Cordon Bleu, claimed borscht was first mentioned in 1548 in a European traveler's diary and arrived in Russia with Ukrainian settlers. The Ukrainian culture ministry agreed to submit an application to UNESCO, but Russia disputed the claim, stating borscht is a national dish of multiple countries, including Russia. The dispute highlights tensions between Kiev and Moscow, with Klopotenko viewing the battle as a fight for Ukraine's identity.

site_title: Asian stocks rally on Tuesday, STI up 0.29%
summary: Asian stocks rallied on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.29% higher at 2,814.12. Positive vaccine developments and upbeat Chinese data drove the gains. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding led the STI, while SIA and City Developments Limited also saw gains. Asian markets across the region followed suit, with the Nikkei 225, Hang Seng Index, and Shanghai Composite Index all rising. Analysts attribute the rally to declining risk-aversion levels, with some predicting further gains ahead of the year-end rally.

site_title: Bitcoin faces regulatory scrutiny after record-breaking rally
summary: Bitcoin's record-breaking rally in 2020 has sparked regulatory scrutiny, as the cryptocurrency's growing acceptance as an asset class raises concerns among regulators. The incoming Biden administration's potential impact on the crypto space is uncertain, with some experts warning of tighter regulation and others expressing concern about antitrust lawsuits and erosion of internet privacy. Despite these challenges, many investors remain bullish on Bitcoin's prospects for 2021, with some predicting a target price of over $100,000.

site_title: Investors left in the lurch as investment platform CoAssets runs into trouble
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will review CoAssets' licensed subsidiary, CA Funding, for potential regulatory breaches. CoAssets, an investment platform, has faced trouble, leaving investors in the lurch. The MAS typically does not disclose its dealings with regulated financial institutions. The review and potential action against CA Funding are ongoing, with the MAS taking necessary steps to address any regulatory issues.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.86% to 26,567.68, driven by vaccine hopes and data showing China's economic recovery is on track. The Shanghai Composite Index surged 1.77% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rallied 1.64%. These gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and came despite US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Britain first to approve AstraZeneca/Oxford Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Britain has become the first country to approve the AstraZeneca/Oxford Covid-19 vaccine, following a recommendation from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency. The vaccine, which has an overall efficacy of 70.4%, will be administered in a two-dose regime, with the UK ordering 100 million doses. This approval comes as the country battles a major winter surge driven by a new, highly contagious variant of the virus.

site_title: China's top banking regulator pledges 'special' oversight on fintech giants
summary: China's top banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, has pledged "special and innovative regulatory measures" on fintech giants, including Jack Ma's Ant Group, to eliminate monopolistic practices and strengthen risk controls. The measures aim to address concerns over digital currencies, cybersecurity, and data protection. Fintech firms will be subject to the same supervision and risk management requirements as banks, and the regulator has criticized Internet loan companies for violating regulations under the guise of "financial innovation". The move signals increased regulation following Ant's US$35 billion IPO delay in November.

images.alt_text: China's top banking regulator said China plans to impose "special and innovative regulatory measures" on financial technology giants such as Jack Ma's Ant Group, to eliminate monopolistic practices and strengthen risk controls in the industry.

site_title: Loading of more than 140 grains ships in Argentina delayed due to strike
summary: A strike by oilseed workers in Argentina's ports has stalled the loading of over 140 agricultural export ships, causing a delay in the country's agricultural exports and foreign exchange inflows. The strike, which began on December 9, is over a compensation package, with workers demanding a one-shot 25% raise and a bonus of 130,000 pesos, while the manufacturers' union is offering a 25% raise in three phases. The Argentine government is sponsoring talks to resolve the issue, which is critical to the country's economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Tuesday with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on Tuesday with losses, extending a third consecutive day of declines. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.17% to 26,260.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.28% and 0.35%, respectively. Investors are concerned about surging global virus infections and lockdowns, contributing to market uncertainty.

site_title: US to allow small drones to fly over people and at night
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has announced rules allowing small drones to fly over people and at night, addressing security concerns with remote identification technology in most cases. The rules, set to take effect 60 days after publication, require drones weighing 0.55 lb or more to broadcast remote ID messages via radio frequency broadcast. This move aims to integrate drones into US airspace for commercial deliveries, with companies like Amazon, Walmart, and Alphabet's Wing already testing drone services.

site_title: China could restrict bank tie-ups with fintech platforms, official suggests
summary: China's former finance minister Lou Jiwei suggests restricting the number of banks a single fintech platform can partner with to prevent market dominance and bad debts. This move aims to maintain competition and regulate the growing fintech industry. China has vowed to strengthen oversight of its big tech firms, including Alibaba and Tencent, amid concerns over data collection and antitrust issues. Regulators have already fined tech firms for not reporting past deals properly and have proposed a digital tax on companies holding user data. This move is part of China's efforts to regulate the fintech sector and protect consumers.

site_title: M1 users hit by second fibre broadband outage in a month
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications company, experienced a second fibre broadband outage in a month, affecting users nationwide. The outage occurred around 10am on December 21, with over 12,000 reports on Downdetector, and was resolved by the company. M1 apologized to customers and advised those still experiencing issues to restart their devices. This is the second major outage in the company in less than a month, following a 30-hour disruption in May due to software and hardware faults.

site_title: Consortium led by Singapore's GIC to invest US$203.24m in Vingroup medical unit
summary: A consortium led by Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) has agreed to invest US$203.24 million in Vingroup's medical unit, Vinmec. Vingroup will remain the controlling shareholder after the deal. Credit Suisse acted as the sole advisor to Vingroup. The investment is part of Vingroup's expansion plans in the medical sector.

site_title: First-ever margin trading and securities lending deals by foreign QFII investors completed in China
summary: Foreign qualified institutional investors (QFII) in China have completed the first margin trading and securities lending deals in the mainland stock market. Guotai Junan Securities facilitated the transactions, which aim to improve the long-short balance and increase market activity. This follows China's expansion of QFII's investment scope in September, allowing for greater foreign participation in margin financing and securities borrowing and lending business. The deals are expected to promote market growth and stability in China's stock market.

site_title: Cabbies to get extra S$300 a month in pandemic rental relief from operators
summary: Singapore's taxi drivers will receive at least $300 a month in additional rental relief from cab operators from January to June, totaling almost $5,000. The move aims to cushion the impact of the Self-Employed Person Income Relief Scheme (Sirs) ending. The government has disbursed about $120 million in payouts to 40,000 taxi and private-hire car drivers, and the Land Transport Authority (LTA) will conduct checks to ensure the assistance is passed on.

site_title: US shoppers grab last-minute holiday gifts, pick up online orders in-store
summary: US holiday shoppers rushed to complete last-minute purchases, with many opting for in-store pickups for online orders due to concerns about delayed deliveries. Retailers expect a record-breaking $36.1 billion in sales on "Super Saturday" ahead of Christmas, driven by curbside business and online shopping. The surge in online retail is partly due to vaccine shipments being prioritized, leading to concerns about delayed gift deliveries. Shoppers were seen grabbing gifts quickly and using tactics such as contact-free games to lure them into stores.

site_title: Oil edges higher after Brexit deal, gains capped by pandemic
summary: Oil prices rose modestly on Thursday, driven by a late-day buying session after the UK and EU reached a post-Brexit trade deal. US West Texas Intermediate crude and Brent crude futures settled up 0.11 and 0.09 cents, respectively. However, the market's gains were capped by concerns about the ongoing pandemic, with worldwide infections still growing. Investors are awaiting the wider distribution of vaccines to boost demand. Despite this, the Brexit deal is seen as supportive, and markets are expected to remain clouded by the pandemic for several months.

site_title: Telegram messaging app to launch pay-for services in 2021
summary: Telegram founder Pavel Durov announced plans to launch pay-for services in 2021, aiming to generate at least $500 million in revenue per year. This move will enable the company to develop new features and welcome billions of new users. Durov stated that Telegram will begin generating revenue starting next year, marking a significant shift for the encrypted messaging app.

site_title: US response to Putin may close door to more arms control talks under Trump
summary: The US has reiterated a proposal to extend the 2010 New START treaty, a strategic arms limitation treaty with Russia, but it appears to be closing the door to further talks under the Trump administration. The treaty expires on February 5 unless the presidents agree to a five-year extension. US President-elect Joe Biden will need to act quickly after taking office, as a lapse would fuel a new nuclear arms race. The proposal was rejected by Russia, which had proposed a similar one-year extension with verification measures.

site_title: Maybank KE starts coverage of Keppel Reit, Suntec Reit with 'sell' calls
summary: Maybank KE initiates "sell" calls on both Suntec Reit and Keppel Reit, citing weak fundamentals and headwinds for the Reits. Suntec Reit's slow retail recovery and rising office vacancy are key concerns, while Keppel Reit's DPU is seen as "unexciting" versus peers. The research team expects further downsizing by Keppel Reit's tenants and challenges in acquisition growth due to high trading yields. Target prices are set at S$1.20 for Suntec Reit and S$0.90 for Keppel Reit.

site_title: Covid's lost generation?: What this year's disruptions will cost Singapore's young adults, and what lies ahead for them
summary: Singapore's young adults face significant disruptions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which may cost them opportunities and hinder their professional employability. With the global economy battered, well-paying jobs are scarce, and fresh graduates struggle to find employment. The government's support measures, such as the SGUnited Jobs and Skills scheme, may help mitigate the effects, but economists warn of long-term implications, including skill loss and a lack of pipeline of local talent in mid-career and senior management positions. The younger generation may become a "lost generation" if they don't gain valuable experience and opportunities early in their careers.

site_title: South Korea fears for Covid-19 patients amid sickbed shortage
summary: South Korea is experiencing a Covid-19 surge, with 1,053 new infections reported, a record fourth consecutive day of over 1,000 cases. The country is facing a severe shortage of hospital beds, with only four critical-care beds available in greater Seoul, resulting in six deaths this month waiting for beds. Despite the surge, the government has not raised social distancing restrictions to the highest level, citing the burden on businesses, and instead emphasizes the need for "social consensus."

site_title: Delta Air Lines in talks to add more quarantine-free flights
summary: Delta Air Lines is in talks with governments to add more quarantine-free flights overseas, following the success of its recently launched tested flights to Europe. The US carrier plans to expand these routes to other destinations, including the Pacific, to revive demand battered by Covid-19. The tested flights, which require passengers to undergo three tests before and after travel, are seen as a faster alternative to vaccinations in resuming international travel without quarantines.

site_title: HKEX's outgoing CEO predicts 'irreversible' move toward China
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing's outgoing CEO Charles Li predicts his successor will need to double down on his strategy to integrate the city's marketplace with China. Li, known as "Mr China," expects a link allowing mainland investors to buy bonds in Hong Kong will be unveiled next year, and the city's financial hub will continue to push toward the mainland despite resistance in China. Li, who has focused on diversifying the business, said Hong Kong is on an "irreversible track" of connecting its markets with China.

site_title: Thailand relaxes travel curbs for tourists from over 50 countries
summary: Thailand has relaxed travel restrictions for tourists from 56 countries, including Australia, France, and the US, allowing them to travel without visas and undergo a mandatory two-week hotel quarantine. Visitors must provide a COVID-19 certificate 72 hours prior to travel and undergo three tests during quarantine. The move aims to boost the tourism industry, which has been hit hard by the pandemic. The revised rules apply to countries not previously included in the travel ban, with the option for a 90-day special tourist visa for other eligible countries.

site_title: Gates and Bezos funds back hydrogen-powered plane startup
summary: ZeroAvia, a hydrogen-powered aviation startup, has raised US$37.7 million from the UK government and investors including Bill Gates and Amazon's Climate Pledge Fund. The funding will support the development of a 19-seat hydrogen-electric powered plane, aiming to cut carbon emissions from the aviation sector. The company plans to demonstrate a 500-mile flight with 20 seats by 2023 and scale up to 1,000 miles with over 100 seats by 2030. This investment follows a successful first flight in September and partnerships with 10 airlines.

site_title: Moderna confirms supply agreement with Singapore's MOH for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Moderna confirms a supply agreement with Singapore's Ministry of Health to support Covid-19 vaccine efforts. The company, specializing in mRNA-based medicines, aims to secure access to a safe and effective vaccine for Singapore's population. The agreement is part of ongoing efforts to secure vaccine supplies globally.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng unit served three writs of summons by former distributors
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's wholly-owned indirect subsidiary in Malaysia, Yeo Hiap Seng Trading Sdn Bhd, has been served with three writs of summons by former distributors seeking RM13.7 million (S$4.5 million) in total claims. The writs were filed after the non-exclusive agreements with the distributors were terminated. Yeo Hiap Seng disputes the actions and will vigorously defend them, while also seeking recovery of sums owed by the former distributors. The company does not expect the actions to impact its sales, but may impair the recovery of sums owed for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Sweden explores moving to a digital currency
summary: Sweden's government is launching a review to explore the feasibility of adopting a digital currency, following the country's already cashless society. The review, led by Anna Kinberg Batra, aims to complete by November 2022. Sweden's central bank is running a pilot project with Accenture to introduce an electronic krona based on blockchain technology. The decision to issue a digital currency will be made at the political level, with the goal of ensuring safe and inclusive digital payments. The review comes as Sweden's cash usage drops to its lowest level ever, with less than 10% of payments made with cash.

site_title: Merkel seeks to regain grip on virus with hard holiday lockdown
summary: Germany will implement a hard lockdown starting Wednesday, December 16, 2020, in an effort to curb the rapidly spreading coronavirus pandemic. Non-essential stores will be closed, workplaces must be shut down, and school children will be encouraged to stay home. The lockdown will last until at least January 10, with Chancellor Angela Merkel warning of risks to the nation's health system. The measures come after a looser shutdown failed to halt a surge in infections and deaths, with over 22,000 deaths and 1.35 million infected reported in the country.

site_title: Asia: Pound rises on Brexit talks extension, vaccine lifts stocks
summary: The pound rose against the dollar and euro after Britain and the EU agreed to extend post-Brexit trade talks past a self-imposed deadline. Sterling gains were tempered by Prime Minister Boris Johnson's warning that a deal was far from certain with less than three weeks until Britain leaves the single market. Meanwhile, Asian markets rose despite surging coronavirus infections, with vaccine optimism supporting traders.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings has been awarded a S$192.3 million contract by the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth for the construction of an Outward Bound Singapore Campus. CapitaLand Retail China Trust's preferential offering was oversubscribed, with 133.77 million units accepted at S$1.17 each to raise S$80.7 million. Meanwhile, oil prices rose over 2% due to market concerns and global trade tensions, with US stocks opening lower amid tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.2% to 2,832.15. Major indices on Wall Street hit new records overnight, driving gains for local stocks. Shares of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, DBS, UOB, and aviation-related counters such as SIA and SATS were among the gainers. The Changi Ready Taskforce announced its readiness to handle Covid-19 vaccine cargo, and Hatten Land shares rose 7.7% after responding to a query from the Singapore Exchange RegCo.

site_title: ECB's grasp on inflation weakening with pandemic slump
